title: COMPANY NEWS;OWNER OF SPALDING AND EVENFLO CONSIDERS A SALE
description: The Spalding and Evenflo Companies said yesterday that its corporate parent, the Cisneros Group of Venezuela, planned to "explore options" for selling all or part of the company. Spalding and Evenflo, which is based in Tampa, Fla., also said that it expected its branded sales to total $1 billion in 1996. Cisneros bought the Spalding sporting goods company and the Evenflo infant products business in 1984. Cisneros said it was considering a sale because it wanted to pursue opportunities in the telecommunications industry.

My son, Michael, who can lay tile, fix plumbing, refinish floors and repair computers, couldn't understand why the difficulties he was having with an espresso machine were the cause of such hilarity.

title: Japanese Stocks Lower
description: Stocks were trading lower here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues stood at 21,815.01, up 226.29 points, or 1.03 percent. On Tuesday, the index lost 193.73 points.

description: For years, the Stratfield School has been the kind of prize-winning elementary school for which families would move from one side of town to the other. More recently, envious parents in other neighborhoods have pressed the Connecticut Board of Education to explain why their schools' scores on standardized tests were so far behind Stratfield's, fueling an often angry debate on the quality of public education here.

description: Congressional auditors and a Federal Aviation Administration inspector, who testified from behind a screen to conceal his identity, told a Senate subcommittee today about severe problems with the agency's system for inspecting aircraft.

description: France's national conscience has long been personified by an 83-year-old Roman Catholic priest known as Abbe Pierre, or Abbott Pierre. He would emerge intermittently from the seclusion of his religious community in Normandy to denounce society for its obsession with money, and successive governments for ignoring the plight of the poor and homeless.

description: Aiming to capitalize on surprising signs of growth in New York City's manufacturing sector, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced a plan yesterday to try to encourage the new industrial enterprises like computer software, video production, recycling and cargo shipping that have emerged as economic bright spots in recent years.

title: Clinton Aids Beef Industry In a Season Of Low Prices
description: President Clinton moved today to soften the economic blow to beef producers caused by a spring drought and slumping cattle prices, ordering the Agriculture Department to open millions of acres of environmentally sensitive land for grazing and to start buying beef for next year's public school lunch program now.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Medical Leave Is Down
description: Over the last year, Essex County officials say, the number of county employees on workers' compensation leave has dropped from 60 to 4. The reason, County Executive James W. Treffinger said yesterday, is a recent change that is saving the county $2.1 million a year.

description: The State Senate approved a bill tonight that would outlaw a type of late-term abortion, knowing that it has virtually no chance of becoming law because Democrats in the Assembly are blocking it.

Walter Thompson unit of the WPP Group, to handle the media planning and buying parts of its account, with billings estimated by trade publications at $140 million. Those duties had been handled by BBDO Los Angeles, a unit of the Omnicom Group. The creative part of the account continues in-house.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Parcells Shortens His Patriots Contract
description: New England Patriots Coach BILL PARCELLS has renegotiated his contract so that it will expire after the 1996 season instead of 1997, ESPN reported last night. The move is another indication of growing discord between Parcells and the Patriots' owner, BOB KRAFT, and could clear the way for Parcells to land another job after next season. Parcells and Kraft disagreed over tactics at the draft last month. Parcells wanted a defensive player in the first round and was reportedly upset when the Patriots chose Ohio State receiver TERRY GLENN. (AP)

title: L.I. Landowners Plan Suit Over Pine Barrens Purchase Prices
description: A group of property owners in the heart of Long Island's Pine Barrens preservation area announced plans today to sue the state and Suffolk County, claiming that their land was being taken from them without fair compensation.

title: General Strike Fails in South Africa
description: A general strike, called to fight a constitutional provision, seemed to fizzle today.

title: Boxer Is Dead After Collapse
description: Lance Hobson died today from a brain hemorrhage after collapsing in the sixth round of a fight on Monday night.

title: Study Links Cancer Risk To Red Meat
description: Women 55 to 69 years old who ate red meat frequently appear to be more likely to develop a certain type of lymph cancer than those who ate less red meat, a study in Iowa has found.

title: With TV Off, Real Life Reasserts Itself
description: Bill Davis, a real estate developer, was out the door by 5:30 A.M. to catch a plane to Miami. At 7:30 his wife, Barbara, was fixing breakfast for their three children, Bradley, age 7, and Andrew and Benjamin, 4-year-old twins. Bradley was rushing to eat and get dressed before school.

title: Foreign Affairs;Heartland Geopolitics
description: For the past few years Congress has been cutting the foreign aid budget, refusing to pay U.N. dues and closing embassies and consulates (almost 40 out of 275 posts since 1992) on the knee-jerk assumption that this was what the public wanted at the end of the cold war. There is this view in Congress that out there in the "real" America, people don't care about foreign policy and certainly don't want to pay for it now that the Soviets are gone. I beg to differ. What you find when you go to the heartland is that many people are keenly interested in foreign policy and open markets and are far more willing to contribute to them than are the know-nothing freshmen Republicans who claim to speak in their names.

title: A Right to Be Safe
description: How many widows are there in the former Yugoslavia? No one has thought to tally them. Of the 250,000 war dead, most were men and boys between the ages of 15 and 50. Countless men are missing -- perhaps 8,000 from Srebrenica alone.

title: SUNY Chancellor Resigns Post After Battling Pataki's Trustees
description: After months of tension and disagreement over the direction of the State University of New York and Gov. George E. Pataki's plans to streamline it, the Chancellor of the 64-campus, $5 billion system turned in his resignation yesterday.

description: IT'S no secret that corporate Olympic sponsors and other savvy companies -- Coca-Cola, Georgia-Pacific, I.B.M., Jet Set Sports and NBC among them -- have heavily booked some of the best restaurants in Atlanta during the Games to entertain top clients. So, if calling ahead to reserve a table or private room ever counted, it does now with opening ceremonies a mere 10 weeks away.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;2 Companies Pick Campbell Mithun
description: The Nabisco Biscuit Company unit of RJR Nabisco Holdings and Conagra Inc. have selected Campbell Mithun Esty in Minneapolis to introduce a line of premium-priced, low-fat cookies and bread crisps under the Healthy Choice brand name, which Nabisco is licensing from Conagra. Billings were not disclosed, but Brandweek reported that advertising and promotional spending would total $10 million to $15 million.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;National Westminster To Close 350 Branches
description: National Westminster Bank P.L.C. said yesterday that it planned to streamline its banking business for consumers in the next five years and close about 350 branches. A spokesman, Paul Lockstone, declined to estimate how many jobs would be cut and refused to comment on a report in The Times of London that said about 15,000 jobs would be lost. NatWest, which has 2,100 branches, now employs about 48,000 people. (Bloomberg Business News)

description: There were some relatively famous names on the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center's program at Merkin Hall on Monday night, the final installment of its Music of Our Time series this season. Judith Weir has become one of the best-known opera composers in English, Richard Rodney Bennett is famous for his film music, and Paul Moravec's scores have been much recorded in the last couple of years.

description: Family members of a police officer slain on a Bronx street heard three young men plead not guilty yesterday in the killing, in what may become New York City's first death penalty case since the state reinstituted the penalty last year.

description: The F.B.I. is taking control of the investigation into how Giuliani administration officials awarded $43 million in welfare contracts, and it is cutting out the city's Investigation Commissioner, senior law enforcement officials said yesterday.

description: House and Senate negotiators tentatively agreed today on a measure that would eventually require states to begin mandatory testing of newborns for H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, if health officials cannot reduce the number of infected infants, people involved in the talks said tonight.

The agreement will save an annual total of $148,000, said Edward Gross, acting executive director of the Turnpike Authority.

description: The man accused of killing 35 people at a Tasmanian tourist site lay in his hospital bed today while he was formally charged with murder.

title: Harmony to Be Acquired
description: Harmony Holdings Inc. said today that the Capital Media Group and Unimedia S.A. had signed a letter of intent to acquire Harmony for about $21 million in cash and stock. The purchase price is $3.50 a share, Harmony said. Harmony shareholders will receive one-third in cash and two-thirds in Capital Media common stock at the average closing price for the five trading days before the date of shareholder approval, the company said. Harmony's stock rose 6.25 cents today, to $2.5625. Harmony is a Los Angeles-based television commercial and music video production company with production offices in Los Angeles and New York.

title: COMPANY NEWS;COURT ALLOWS SALE OF GENERIC FORMS OF ROGAINE
description: Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc. was denied a court order yesterday that would have blocked the sale of generic versions of nonprescription Rogaine, its treatment for hair loss. Judge Robert Holmes Bell of the Federal District Court in Grand Rapids, Mich., denied the drug maker's request to extend by three years its exclusive marketing of the over-the-counter form of Rogaine. Three companies are now cleared to sell generic versions of the drug: the Lemmon Company, a unit of Israel's Teva Pharmaceutical Industries; Alpharma Inc. of Fort Lee, N.J., and Bausch & Lomb Inc. of Rochester. John Vanderstar of the law firm Covington & Burling said Pharmacia & Upjohn had predicted sales of about $1 billion during the next five years for nonprescription Rogaine. Without an injunction against generic makers, Rogaine sales will drop to about $655 million, he said.

title: Unabom Suspect Appeals
description: Theodore J. Kaczynski, the Unabom suspect, asked the Supreme Court today to order a hearing on his effort to have the Government barred from prosecuting him.

description: The State Department issued its annual report about terrorism around the world today and listed the same seven countries as last year as sponsors of international terrorism.

description: American Ballet Theater's current staging of "Don Quixote" is too well-behaved for what may be the most raucous comic ballet to come out of Russia in the 19th century.

title: Who Trains Trainers? Everyone and No One
description: ALIX REDMONDE, who teaches aerobics classes in Manhattan, is still haunted by a session with the personal trainer she hired five pears ago while preparing for an aerobics competition. One day the trainer, a substitute for Ms. Redmonde's vacationing coach, pushed her left leg too far into a stretch. "I felt my hamstring go off kilter," she recalled.

title: 30,000 for Baritone
description: The Richard Tucker Music Foundation has chosen the baritone Dwayne Croft for its 1996 award, worth $30,000. Mr. Croft, a native of Cooperstown, N.Y., has appeared at the Metropolitan Opera House in "Pelleas et Melisande," "Le Nozze de Figaro," "Madama Butterfly" and "La Boheme," among other works. He is to perform in the award gala on Oct. 27 at Avery Fisher Hall.

description: Welch & Nehlen Advertising in Garden City, L.I., said yesterday that it had acquired Groome Associates in New York and absorbed Groome to form Welch Nehlen & Groome. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Joint Venture in Ethylene
description: The Huntsman Corporation and the Enron Liquid Services Corporation have agreed to form a $400 million joint venture to build and run an ethylene production plant. It is expected to be built at a Huntsman operation in Port Arthur, Tex., and to be completed by 1999. The plant will produce a minimum of 1.5 billion pounds of ethylene a year. Ethylene is a colorless, gaseous and flammable hydrocarbon obtained from natural or coal gas.

description: Pepsico Inc. reported yesterday that it had strong first-quarter volume growth in its snack-food, soft-drink and restaurant businesses in a performance that analysts said presaged a return to the company's traditional double-digit increases in annual earnings.

description: Reggie Lewis's widow yesterday sued the team of cardiologists that said the Boston Celtics star could eventually return to basketball after he collapsed during a playoff game.

Last night at Christie's, buyers happily snapped up a van Gogh for $10.3 million and a Degas pastel for $5.4 million.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HIGHWOODS PROPERTIES IN DEAL FOR CROCKER REALTY
description: Highwoods Properties Inc. has agreed to buy Crocker Realty Trust Inc. in a $537.5 million deal that will significantly expand Highwoods's holdings in the Southeast. Highwoods will acquire all of the stock in Crocker, a real estate investment trust in Boca Raton, Fla., for $11.02 a share, or about $297.5 million, and will assume about $240 million of debt. Highwoods, which is based in Raleigh, N.C., will gain a portfolio that includes 70 suburban office buildings totaling 5.7 million square feet in seven Southeastern states. Highwoods's shares rose $1.50 yesterday, to $30.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. Crocker shares rose $1.125, to $11.125, on the American Stock Exchange.

"Spring is the time when asparagus start peeking up out of the ground," said Mrs. Kamman, the cooking instructor, author and former restaurateur, who was in New York recently to teach classes in seasonal menus at Peter Kump's School of Culinary Arts.

description: The pro football landscape changed again today when the 30 National Football League owners approved the Houston Oilers' move to Nashville by a vote of 23 to 6, with one abstention; 23 votes were needed for approval.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF SYKES ENTERPRISES NEARLY DOUBLE ON DAY ONE
description: The shares of Sykes Enterprises Inc., a company that provides assistance for computer users, nearly doubled on their first day of trading. The company, which is based in Tampa, Fla., had sold 3.4 million shares at $18 each, to raise $61.2 million. Yesterday, the shares closed at $35.50 after Nasdaq trading of more than 3.4 million shares. Sykes runs so-called technical call centers, where the company answers questions from customers on behalf of computer makers and software companies. The company also provides internal computer support services to corporations.

title: Corrections

The 1,667 grants will go to arts organizations in all 50 states. About half the grant money, $22.3 million, is for state and regional arts agencies.

title: N.B.A. PLAYOFFS;Rockets Smother Johnson And Push Toward Clincher
description: That whistle tonight was not a referee picking on Hakeem Olajuwon.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MERRILL LYNCH TO BUY LENDER'S SERVICE FROM PRUDENTIAL
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Lender's Service Inc., a provider of appraisal, title and closing services to the mortgage and real estate industry. Terms were not disclosed. Merrill Lynch will acquire Lender's Service from the Residential Services Corporation of America, a unit of the Newark-based Prudential Insurance Company of America. Pittsburgh-based Lender's Service, which employs about 450 people, will become part of Merrill Lynch's Private Client Group.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS;Swiss Franc and German Mark Drop After Official's Comment
description: The dollar rose yesterday against the Swiss franc and the German mark after Switzerland's Finance Minister called for a weaker franc.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Massimino Will Coach at Cleveland State
description: ROLLIE MASSIMINO, who coached Villanova to a National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship but faltered as JERRY TARKANIAN's successor at U.N.L.V., was hired yesterday as the coach at Cleveland State.

title: Computer Market to Grow
description: The worldwide personal computer market is expected to grow by 19.1 percent in 1996, with the United States market likely to expand by 13.6 percent, according to Dataquest, the technology market research firm. Worldwide PC shipments are expected to reach more than 71.7 million units this year, accounting for $148.2 billion in revenue, and to grow to 131.7 million units, or $264.3 billion in revenue, by 2000.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PERRI PELTZ, a co-anchor for the weekend "Today in New York" on WNBC-TV, is due to give birth to her second child tomorrow, but she plans to fulfill two engagements before she goes to the labor room.

title: Politics of Gasoline
description: Republicans pushed for repeal of a 1993 gasoline tax, blaming the Administration for higher pump prices. And in response to the President's move to tap Federal oil reserves, oil prices fell in futures markets.

title: BASEBALL;The Clock Keeps Ticking and Yanks Keep Hitting
description: The big, orange clock perched above the center-field scoreboard at Camden Yards became the focus in the ninth inning tonight as the Yankees and Orioles crawled toward a record. It ticked on and on while the Yankees' John Wetteland pursued the last three outs.

title: AT WORK WITH: Judith Leiber;Handbags That Make Headlines
description: AFTER all these years -- let's hear it for poetic justice -- Judith Leiber's complexion is flawless.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESSS;Aid Is Delayed For Olympic Air
description: The European Commission ordered Greece today to keep out of the day-to-day running of its national airline Olympic Airways, blocking a state aid payment to the airline until its demands are met.

title: Mortar Found on Iranian Ship In Pickles Bound for Germany
description: A powerful mortar and a huge shell have been discovered in a cargo of pickles being shipped from Iran to Germany, and officials said today that they may have been intended for use by terrorists against Israeli targets in Western Europe.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bankruptcy Seems Near For German Shipbuilder
description: The financially troubled German shipbuilder Bremer Vulkan Verbund A.G. said yesterday that it had been unable to negotiate a settlement with its creditors on a rescue plan. There now appears to be no way to save the company from bankruptcy. A judge said he would decide soon whether to begin bankruptcy proceedings.

title: A Life's Work Disrupted in Liberia;Newark Native Hopes to Return to Her Study of Chimps
description: Before dawn on the day before Easter, Betsy Brotman huddled with several other people in the center hall of her house in Monrovia, Liberia, as a storm of explosions and gunfire swept the neighborhood.

title: Real Estate;Mickey Mouse may be coming to Manhattan, but thanks to Heskel Elias, he's coming to Queens, too.
description: IT'S an interesting combination, Mickey Mouse and Heskel Elias.

title: In Performance;THEATER
description: A Musical Reincarnation Of a Period of Pop Optimism 'Have a Nice Day!' Theater East

title: No Headline
description: We looked at each other, and we said, have you heard of this? And each of us looked at the other and said no, and I think we smiled and said this is important."

title: Suspended School Board Is Reinstated in the Bronx
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew's efforts to remove corrupt school boards in academically troubled districts sustained a second significant court defeat in a week yesterday as a judge declared that he had overstepped his powers in suspending a school board in the South Bronx.

title: Steps From Verse
description: Poetry and Dance," an exhibition focusing on choreography inspired by poetry, will open at the Dance Collection of the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts on Sunday. Among the featured dances are productions of "Afternoon of a Faun," by Vaslav Nijinsky and Jerome Robbins and Martha Graham's "Letter to the World." The free exhibition, presented in tribute to Lincoln Kirstein, will include photographs and other materials and run through July 20. There will also be free poetry readings on Monday, Tuesday and next Wednesday in the library's Bruno Walter Auditorium, with the first devoted to Kirstein's writing. Information: (212) 870-1630.

title: Cocaine Washes Ashore
description: Dozens of plastic-wrapped packages of cocaine dropped or dumped by smugglers were swept ashore by waves today on two Florida beaches, the police said. An employee of a bait-and-tackle shop found one stash at Pompano Beach, north of Fort Lauderdale. It contained 43 pounds of the drug in individually wrapped packages inside a plastic-wrapped bale, said Sgt. Scott Gooding of the Pompano Beach Police Department. In Dania, city workers found a sack filled with 21 2-pound "bricks" of cocaine, the police said.

title: Lawyer Pleads Guilty in Thefts Of More Than $1.5 Million
description: As some of his victims watched with bitter satisfaction, a Long Island lawyer and accountant pleaded guilty yesterday to stealing more than $1.5 million through schemes that included looting a dead woman's estate and defrauding a company's pension plan. The thefts also included embezzling the money of elderly law clients whose investments he was handling.

title: Debt Insurance Deal For Orange County
description: Orange County said today that it had taken a major step toward emerging from bankruptcy by securing insurance for its planned recovery financings.

title: Moises Ville Journal;Sun Has Set on Jewish Gauchos, but Legacy Lives
description: There are four synagogues in this remote farming town of 2,000 residents. The bakery sells Sabbath bread and cookies. Many buildings have Hebrew lettering and the Star of David on their facades. And children playing in the street use Yiddish words like "shlep" and "shlock."

title: Metro Matters;Raising Funds By Arresting Journalists
description: LAST week, two reporters were arrested at the Waldorf-Astoria for doing their jobs.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;High Spenders in the House
description: United States Representative Donald M. Payne, Democrat of Newark, spent more last year than any other member of New Jersey's 13-member House delegation on salaries and office expenses, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TERRA INDUSTRIES SAYS IT WILL BUY BACK SHARES
description: Terra Industries, a producer of fertilizer and other agricultural products, said yesterday that its board had authorized the repurchase of up to 8.5 million of its common shares. Terra, which is based in Sioux City, Iowa, said its majority shareholder, Minorco S.A. of Luxembourg, had indicated that it would not sell any of its shares. After the buyback, Minorco's stake will increase to 59 percent from 53 percent. The shares will be repurchased on the open market and through privately negotiated transactions during the next 15 months. Terra has 81.4 million common shares outstanding. The shares rose 25 cents yesterday, to $13.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: A Fusion Ticket in Russia
description: As fusion politics goes, the putative alliance between the Russian presidential candidates Grigory Yavlinsky and Aleksandr Lebed may be in a class by itself. The rough American equivalent might be pairing George McGovern and Gen. Curtis LeMay. Mr. Yavlinsky is an American-educated economist who wants to keep Russia on the path of democratic reform, while Mr. Lebed is a recently retired army general who has promised to restore order in Russia and make it a great power again.

title: I.B.M. Plans to Buy Back $2.5 Billion in Stock
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said today that it planned to buy back another $2.5 billion of its stock.

title: One Federal Judge Does Battle With 19 Others
description: The setting was dignified, the issues high-toned and the counsel distinguished. But these niceties could not change one irrefutable fact: that the battle joined in court today between Judge John H. McBryde and the 19 members of the judicial council for the Fifth Circuit is one of the biggest, rawest brawls in the history of the Federal judiciary.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Guard Robbed Inside Bank
description: An armored car guard delivering cash to the Midlantic Bank at lunchtime yesterday was beaten and sprayed with Mace and robbed of close to $500,000, the authorities said. One assailant was waiting inside the bank, and another entered after the guard, who was not identified, said Special Agent Ann R. Todd, a spokeswoman for the Newark office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Designates China As Worst Copyright Violator Washington designated China as the worst violator of agreements intended to combat the piracy of American videocassettes, compact disks, computer software and other products, a step that seemed to lay the groundwork for sanctions against Beijing.

title: In Performance;CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: A Daring Pianist Ventures Rachmaninoff in Debut Recital Terrence Wilson 92d Street Y

title: Republicans Push for Gasoline Tax Repeal
description: Republicans began pitching the repeal of a 1993 tax on gasoline today with all the fervor of a political campaign, pledging rapid tax relief to drivers who they maintained had been saddled with higher pump prices by a tax-loving Clinton Administration.

title: Germans Mustn't Shun Holocaust Discussion
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place;What Fuels Nasdaq Rise? A Handful Of Big Issues
description: It looks like heaven for smaller stocks these days. But in fact it is bigger stocks that are providing a lot of the action in the Nasdaq stock market.

title: Blades Pleads No Contest
description: Brian Blades, the Seattle Seahawks receiver, pleaded no contest today to a charge of manslaughter in the shooting death of his cousin Charles Johnson last July 5. Blades could face as much as nine and a half years in prison. He will appear at a sentencing hearing before Broward Circuit Court Judge Susan Lebow on May 28.

title: TV Notes;The End Is Near
description: So little time, so little time," Phil Donahue used to say, shaking his head, dashing from one person in his studio audience to another, trying to do justice to all their questions.

title: Uncovered At Harvard: Alcott's First Novel
description: The manuscript of Louisa May Alcott's very first novel, all but unknown to scholars and written when the author was 18, has been found in the Houghton Library at Harvard University, where it was apparently miscatalogued a generation ago.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on April 22 about Robert J. Shaw, a television writer. misattributed the Nov. 21, 1980, episode of "Dallas," which revealed who shot the character J. R. Ewing, and misstated its place in the sequence. The author was Loraine Despres, not Mr. Shaw; it was the fourth episode of the season, not the premiere.

title: Journal;Caught in Charlotte's Web
description: The plan, no doubt, was to burnish his image, a la slick Bill Clinton and his sax on "Arsenio Hall" in '92: Newt Gingrich, accompanied by a coterie of animals and zookeepers, turned up all over the airwaves last weekend to prove that he is both a more lovable and greener guy than his dismal poll ratings and his party's poor environmental record might suggest. But Operation Dr. Dolittle backfired so badly that even the conservative columnist Tony Snow observed that the Speaker looked as if "he had turned desperate, like the widow who fights off loneliness by taking in 97 cats."

title: Shark Substance Found to Limit Tumor Growth
description: A novel substance found in sharks has controlled the growth of brain tumors in experimental rats and prolonged their lives, researchers from Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine reported yesterday.

title: Democrats Outflank G.O.P. In First Campaign Skirmishes
description: Senator Bob Dole fired the first shot last Friday afternoon: a single-page press release and letter to President Clinton demanding repeal of the 4.3-cent gasoline tax increase enacted as part of Mr. Clinton's 1993 deficit-reduction program. Mr. Dole, his aides said, would ride the issue through the coming week.

title: Canine Liberation
description: Cheers for the urban guerrillas of New York City, the dauntless men and women who let their dogs loose in the parks! Willing to pay $100 fines and even go to jail, these individuals are demanding that parts of Central Park become leash-free. Dog lovers of New York, unite! You have nothing to lose but choke chains, and the parks to win.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Big Environmental Purchase
description: A threatened piece of unspoiled land has been saved from development under what the New Jersey Conservation Foundation says is one of the largest land acquisitions made in the state by a nonprofit group.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Mathis a Falcon for Four More Years
description: The six-year veteran receiver, TERANCE MATHIS, who has caught 189 passes for 2,381 yards for Atlanta, signed a four-year contract with the Falcons yesterday. Terms of the contract were not disclosed. (AP)

title: N.H.L PLAYOFFS;Graves Gets 50 Stitches
description: For those looking for omens, today's practice offered a glaring one: Adam Graves, a key figure in the Rangers' last playoff meeting with the Pittsburgh Penguins, suffered a deep cut inside his mouth when he was hit with the puck on a clearing attempt by goaltender Mike Richter.

title: 19 Bourbons on 19th St., for Derby Week
description: THIS is bourbon week at Cafe Beulah, at 39 East 19th Street, in honor of the annual running of the Kentucky Derby on Saturday.

title: Politics Entered Wildlife Refuges Long Ago
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;FIDELITY FINANCIAL TO ACQUIRE CIRCLE FINANCIAL
description: Fidelity Financial of Ohio Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the Circle Financial Corporation of Cincinnati in a transaction valued about $27.6 million. Fidelity will exchange $38 in cash or stock for each share of Circle Financial, subject to pricing and other provisions. Fidelity is the holding company for Fidelity Federal Savings Bank, which has about $249.4 million in assets and operates three branches in the Cincinnati area. Circle Financial is the parent of People's Savings Association, which has assets of $229.4 million and operates seven branches in the region. Circle shares rose $7.125 yesterday, to $34.625, in Nasdaq trading; Fidelity shares fell 62.5 cents, to $10.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Airline Refuses Blame in Carew Incident
description: A dispute between ROD CAREW and a flight attendant on a Northwest Airlines flight was the result of "poor communication" and the attendant will not be reprimanded, an airline spokesman said yesterday.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Nets' Future Will Wait Until Friday
description: Despite the hope of the National Basketball Association Commissioner, DAVID STERN, that the Nets' owners would quickly resolve their future, no deadline has been set for an internal restructuring or a sale to an outside buyer.

title: N.H.L PLAYOFFS;Arbitrator Says Rangers Have to Pay Bonuses
description: The Rangers, who have passed the first step in their quest for this year's Stanley Cup, are still paying for the Stanley Cup they won two years ago.

title: Witch Trial Held in Maine, but Issue Is Church's Compound on a Bay
description: Three weeks have passed since Valerie Van Winkle was convicted by her church of maintaining she was a witch, and though it sure beats being burned or hanged, the humor of having neighbors greet her with lines like "Cast any good spells lately?" is definitely wearing off.

title: The Crystal Palaces
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Officer Held in Robbery
description: A New Jersey police officer here for a law enforcement conference was arrested yesterday after a six-mile chase and charged with robbing a bank, The Associated Press reported.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about newspaper circulation trends at the nation's largest dailies referred incorrectly in some editions to the agency that reports circulation figures. It is the Audit Bureau of Circulations, not the Audit Board of Circulations.

title: Personal Health
description: FOR some 20 million Americans with obstructive sleep apnea, sleep is a nightly struggle with a function that is fully automatic for most people: breathing. While asleep, their ability to inhale becomes blocked for a brief time -- for 10 seconds to a minute or more -- until they arouse enough to gulp in air with a snort that can rattle the windows. Then they immediately fall back into a sound sleep and the cycle starts over, often repeating itself hundreds of times a night.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Latest Data Hurt Prices Of Treasuries
description: The prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday, dragged down by strong economic data that heightened fears that inflation could accelerate.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;CIGNA CORP. (CI,N)
description: The Cigna Corporation said first-quarter operating earnings rose 50 percent, exceeding expectations, because of improved profit in its property and casualty division.

title: Prices of Crude Oil Retreat, But Not Outlook for Gasoline
description: Oil prices fell in futures markets yesterday in response to President Clinton's decision to tap the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, but the cost of gasoline at the pump is expected to remain high through most of the summer as increased demand from motorists collides with tight supplies.

title: Tobacco Whistle-Blower Acknowledges Plaintiff Lawyers Paid Him
description: A paralegal who provided anti-tobacco lawyers a crucial set of documents about a tobacco company's secret studies on the health dangers of cigarettes says the lawyers gave him more than $100,000.

title: Wine Talk
description: THERE'S a grape shortage in California. That's unfortunate, but it will pass. Someone will grow more grapes. Then there will be too many. Happens every time.

title: Estrogen Patch Appears to Lift Severe Depression in New Mothers
description: NO ONE says new mothers have it easy. Nights spent waking up every two hours and days spent trying to figure out just why the baby is crying so much leave about 80 percent of new mothers physically exhausted, emotionally drained and despondent over their seeming inability to do anything well. Call it the baby blues.

title: CYCLING;Riders Take Marks for DuPont
description: The Tour DuPont, the most important bicycle race outside Europe, begins Wednesday, and many people are trying to make it a battle between Lance Armstrong and Tony Rominger. Neither one is buying that. The 12-day competition will start here with a 47.6-mile circuit race. Then it will wind through Virginia, North Carolina and South Carolina and end with a 9.1-mile time trial in Marietta, Ga.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Contract Talks Heat Up For Giants and Brown
description: Giants quarterback Dave Brown has recently been anxious about his contract situation. He wants to get it done and get it done soon. Period. And although contract negotiations are sometimes as topsy-turvy as a carnival ride, he could soon get his wish.

title: Budd Granoff Is Dead at 77; A Show-Business Innovator
description: Budd Granoff, a one-time Broadway press agent who fell in love hard and ended up as a pioneering television syndicator, died on Sunday at his home in Englewood, N.J. He was 77.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Hoechst Earnings Flat Before Special Gains
description: Hoechst A.G., the German chemical company, said yesterday that its profit would have been flat in the first quarter if not for extraordinary gains from sales of assets. Those gains pushed pretax profit up 27 percent. Hoechst earned 1.25 billion marks ($822 million) before taxes, up from 984 million marks a year earlier. Sales were unchanged at 13 billion marks ($8.55 billion). (AP)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about differences between the board of the State University of New York and its Chancellor, Thomas A. Bartlett, misattributed Mr. Bartlett's selection in 1994. He was appointed by the board, not by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.

title: Chef Plans A 3-Star Juggling Act
description: Last year, when Joel Robuchon said he would retire at 50, the food world wondered whether it was just an idle threat. But if he did go through with the move and walk away from a Michelin three-star career, who could possibly succeed him at the restaurant that bears his name in the hotel Le Parc in Paris?

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Barbara Walters Recalls 20 Years of Confessions, Digressions and Tears
description: To Boris Yeltsin she says, "Do you drink too much?"

title: Telecommunications Talks Postponed as the U.S. Balks
description: A 53-nation negotiation in Geneva on opening telecommunications markets to international competition was saved from collapse yesterday by moving the deadline to next year. Last-minute objections by the United States had threatened to scuttle the effort to liberalize the $500 billion global market in telecommunications.

title: Use Incentives to Cut Psychotherapy Cost
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;British Airways Delays Ordering Small Jets
description: British Airways P.L.C. confirmed yesterday that it had shelved plans to buy $1 billion worth of small jetliners because the airline had not cut enough costs in its short-route business. In January, British Airways, the world's biggest long-haul airline, said it had asked five aircraft makers to bid to supply 60 new jets.

title: An Array of Opponents Do Battle Over 'Parental Rights' Legislation
description: Congress and state legislatures are becoming battlegrounds over politically charged "parental rights" bills, hailed by conservatives as ways to protect parents' ability to raise their children and criticized by many education and health organizations as threats to children and schools.

title: Higher Suicide Risk for Perfectionists
description: ALASDAIR CLAYRE was a high achiever: brilliant enough to be compared with Sir Isaiah Berlin as a philosophy undergraduate at Oxford, a recipient of the prestigious Prize Fellowship of All Souls College. He also wrote a novel, performed his own songs as a folk singer and produced award-winning television programs.

title: Waving the Special-Interest Flags
description: New York's Republican State Chairman, William Powers, boasts that he raised a record-breaking $3 million with a single event last week. Tickets to a reception billed as "A Celebration of New York" cost $500. A seat at Gov. George Pataki's table for dinner was $100,000. Like a recent two-hour cocktail party for health-care business interests that netted $600,000 for Assembly Democrats, the Republicans' gala was really a celebration of the power of money in New York politics.

title: Status Unclear On Donadoni
description: There were reports out of Milan yesterday that Roberto Donadoni might play for Italy in the European Championship in June, but the MetroStars said the star midfielder would join the team for its game at Giants Stadium Saturday night against Tampa Bay.

title: TV Notes;'City Arts' Prevails
description: City Arts," the funky half-hour magazine program that explores the local arts scene on WNET-TV, Channel 13, in New York, has been poking its hand-held cameras into studios, museums, rehearsal halls and even late-night back alleys (to film graffiti artists) for two seasons now. It's unheralded and practically unheard of in the clamor of prime-time TV, but last week, "City Arts" won four local Emmy Awards for outstanding entertainment and performing arts programming (and one for best opening-title sequence). And on Manday the producers were told that it has been renewed by WNET for a third season, beginning in October.

title: COMPANY NEWS;THOMSON TO SELL 7 NEWSPAPERS, POSSIBLY MORE
description: The Thomson Corporation of Toronto agreed yesterday to sell seven Canadian newspapers and said it was negotiating to sell seven others in Ontario as part of its strategy to focus on regional markets. Terms were not disclosed. Thomson, which once owned most of Ontario's daily newspapers, would be left with only two in the province, The Globe and Mail in Toronto and The Chronicle-Journal in Thunder Bay. Hollinger Inc., which bought 19 newspapers from Thomson last year, agreed to buy 6 dailies and 1 community paper in Newfoundland, New Brunswick, Nova Scotia and Prince Edward Island. As part of the deal, Hollinger is transferring to Thomson three weeklies in Alberta. Thomson is a unit of the Woodbridge Company.

title: World News Briefs;Europeans Seek Talks On U.S. Cuba Embargo
description: The European Union said today it was taking the first step toward involving a World Trade Organization panel in a dispute over a new American law that strengthens trade sanctions against Cuba.

title: Rio Ex-Officer Is Convicted In Massacre Of Children
description: In a trial that lasted for 24 hours straight, a jury convicted a former policeman for his role in a night of killing in 1993 that culminated in the deaths of street children who were sleeping in the doorway of a cathedral.

title: Use Incentives to Cut Psychotherapy Cost;No Money-Saving Cure
description: To the Editor:

title: Restoring Their Good Names;U.S. Companies in Trademark Battles in South Africa
description: Geoffrey, the Toys "R" Us giraffe, has finally come home to Africa. And now that he is here, he can hang out with Ronald McDonald and splash on Ralph Lauren cologne. Soon, he may even be able to buy Victoria's Secret lingerie for a friend.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SCITEX REJECTS A SWEETENED TAKEOVER OFFER
description: The Scitex Corporation said yesterday that it had rejected a second proposal from the investor Davidi Gilo to acquire the company and take it private. Scitex, an Israeli maker of computer imaging systems, said such a move would not be in the best interests of shareholders. The Scitex statement came in response to a letter dated Sunday in which Mr. Gilo said his investor group would be prepared to acquire Scitex for $25 a share. At that price, Scitex would be worth more than $1 billion. Scitex shares fell 12.5 cents yesterday, to $21, in Nasdaq trading. Mr. Gilo had offered $20 a share in March.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF INTERNEURON RISE AFTER APPROVAL OF DRUG
description: The shares of Interneuron Pharmaceuticals Inc. rose yesterday after the company won approval on Monday to sell its anti-obesity drug Redux, which works by making people believe they have had enough to eat. Redux, which will be sold in the United States by the American Home Products Corporation, is the first drug treatment for obesity approved by the Food and Drug Administration in more than 20 years. The drug will be available starting this summer and will cost about $2 a day. Shares in Interneuron, which is based in Lexington, Mass., rose $2.25, to $39.375, in Nasdaq trading. American Home Products is based in Madison, N.J.

title: THEATER REVIEW;A Sam Shepard Revival Gets Him to Broadway
description: Children do grow up in the most unexpected ways, even, it would seem, a certain dead baby beneath an Illinois farm yard. Seeing the Steppenwolf Theater Company's inspired revival of Sam Shepard's "Buried Child," which opened last night at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, you may find yourself thinking, "My, how big you've gotten."

title: Iverson Expected to Turn Pro
description: Allen Iverson is expected to disclose his National Basketball Association plans on Wednesday, and the Georgetown star is likely to become the first player in Coach John Thompson's 24 years to leave early for the pros.

title: Clinton and Peres Find Mutual Admiration
description: President Clinton and Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel signed an anti-terrorism accord today at the White House and then bathed each other in mutual appreciation, while denying that they were endorsing each other for re-election.

title: BASKETBALL;Basketball Coach At Cornell Resigns
description: After three consecutive losing seasons and the suicide of one of his assistants, the Cornell basketball coach Al Walker has resigned, citing personal reasons. Athletic Director Charles Moore said the search for a new head coach would begin immediately.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Manhattan's New Man Is All Green
description: Described as a man who "bleeds Jasper green," John Leonard was introduced yesterday as the new head basketball coach at Manhattan College.

title: FORMER CHIEF OF DELPHI ON-LINE SERVICE BUYS IT BACK
description: Three years after the News Corporation bought the Delphi on-line service, the former chief executive of Delphi has bought it back for an undisclosed price. The executive, Dan Bruns, who left Delphi two years ago, led a team of entrepreneurs who jumped at the chance to buy it back earlier this year, around the same time as the News Corporation's Internet joint venture with MCI Communications fell apart. Mr. Bruns announced his return to Delphi subscribers, whose numbers have been dwindling, on line this week.

title: Board Member Quits in Dispute at Insurer
description: Sphere Drake Holdings Ltd., an insurance company, said this week that John C. Head 3d had resigned as a director, saying the board refused to investigate the company's business practices.

title: House Passes Compromise Bill On Spending for AIDS Care
description: The House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly tonight to renew the Federal program that funnels millions of dollars to state and local governments for the care of people with AIDS or who carry the virus that causes the disease.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on April 23 with an article about a resurgence of patriotism among Chinese students misstated the location of the war memorial shown. It is at the Nanjing museum, not on the campus of Nanjing University.

title: Strong Auto Sales Point to Rising Confidence
description: Despite rising gasoline prices, two of the biggest auto makers reported strong April sales today that exceeded analysts' expectations, providing another sign that consumers' confidence is growing.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Triage With an Eye on Society's Costs
description: At one point in tomorrow night's thoughtful documentary on PBS, George Strait makes a telling observation about television's treatment of medical matters. The subject is the birth of a very premature baby, about 24 weeks old. Mr. Strait, a medical reporter for ABC News, confesses that if he had been covering this story on his usual beat, the birth would have been celebrated as a miracle and left at that.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Britain Puts Price On Railtrack Shares
description: The British Government said yesterday that it would sell the nation's rail track and signaling equipment to the public at a price lower than that it had originally sought. Shares of Railtrack will cost between L3.5 and L3.9, or a total of between L1.75 billion ($2.62 billion) and L1.95 billion. The exact price will not be known until trading starts on the London Stock Exchange on May 20.

title: Immigrant Workers Aren't Stealing Jobs
description: To the Editor:

title: QUANTUM HEALTH AGREES TO MERGE WITH OLSTEN
description: Quantum Health Resources Inc. said yesterday that it had entered into a definitive agreement to be acquired by the Olsten Corporation for stock worth about $273 million. Quantum, which is based in Indianapolis, distributes pharmaceuticals and provides other health care services, and Olsten, which is based in Melville, L.I., provides temporary staffing, including health care workers. The proposed merger provides for an exchange of 0.58 of a share of Olsten common stock for each share of Quantum common stock. It would be accounted for as a pooling of interests. On the New York Stock Exchange, the shares of Olsten closed yesterday at $31, up 62.5 cents, so each Quantum share would be worth about $17.98. The stock closed at $14.50, up 25 cents a share, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Our Towns;Scarlett Fills Mailbox And Hearts
description: WHEN Scarlett's white kitten died the other day not entirely unexpected given the degree of his burns -- another avalanche of calls tumbled in to the North Shore Animal League.

title: PHYSICIANS HEALTH SHARES FALL AS EARNINGS DROP IS SEEN
description: The stock of Physicians Health Services Inc. fell about 10 percent yesterday after the company, a managed health care concern based in Trumbull, Conn., said declining premiums would result in an unexpected drop in earnings for the first quarter. The shares of Physicians Health fell $3.1875, to $29.5625, in Nasdaq trading. Earlier, the shares had touched $26.50. Wall Street had been expecting the company to earn 40 cents a share, based on the average estimate of six analysts surveyed by IBES International. It earned $3.14 million, or 33 cents a share, in the first quarter of last year.

title: CYCLING;Results Are Out, Enthusiasm Is In
description: The Tour DuPont, the most important bicycle competition outside Europe, started today with a race to nowhere that did not count. But the day's leaders did not mind because they had achieved something, and the others among the 112 professional riders from 16 teams did not mind because they survived a day's racing.

title: May: Springtime to Most, Sweeps Time to Networks
description: It's May, and television executives' fancy turns to . . . just about everything.

title: 4 Sentenced in Cat Killing
description: Four former members of a state champion baseball team have been sentenced to six months of probation and 40 hours of community service for pummeling a cat to death with baseball bats.

title: Pataki, in High Court, Exchanges Barbs With Top Judge
description: Gov. George E. Pataki brought his roiling quarrel with the judiciary into the heart of the state court system today, using a ceremony before the Court of Appeals to exchange genteel barbs with the state's highest-ranking judge over the rights and responsibilities of politicians in criticizing members of the judiciary.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;The Nets' Owners Drop Their 'For Sale' Sign
description: Just when they finally appeared set to sell the team to John McMullen and make him the owner of two of New Jersey's four professional teams, the owners of the Nets reversed their position yesterday and decided to keep the team in the family.

title: World News Briefs;Cuban May Day Rally Renews Communist Vow
description: Throngs of Cubans waving flags and chanting slogans packed Revolution Square today for a May Day rally aimed at showing that Cuba is adhering to Communism despite renewed American pressure for change.

title: Calendar: A Benefit And 3 Exhibitions
description: To Benefit Glass Art Urban Glass, 647 Fulton Street (Rockwell Place), downtown Brooklyn; (718) 625-3685.

title: Lockheed No. 1 At the Pentagon
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation, which was created in a merger last year of the Lockheed Corporation and the Martin Marietta Corporation, has replaced the McDonnell Douglas Corporation as the largest military contractor, the Pentagon said this week.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about allegations of tampering with tests at Stratfield School in Fairfield, Conn., gave an erroneous name to the panel that had been investigating the school's high test scores. It is the Fairfield Board of Education, not the Connecticut Board of Education.

title: No Peripatetic Curator
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Domestic Abuse Slows Courts
description: A dramatic increase in domestic violence cases over the last five years has placed a "staggering" burden on New Jersey's court system, according to a report released yesterday by a committee that has been examining the state's judicial system for the last year.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;Baseball's marketing plan: Take an old familiar score and energize it with some  Cool and Soul.
description: LL COOL J, the rap star, and Aretha Franklin, the Queen of Soul, may appear to be unusual choices to market Major League Baseball, which is struggling to recapture its magic as the national pastime after two strike-shortened seasons.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TRACK AND FIELD;Canadian Discus Thrower Is Suspended
description: GLADYS NORTEY, a Canadian discus thrower at Iowa State, was suspended for three months yesterday by Athletics Canada for taking a medication that contained a banned substance. Athletics Canada said Nortey had tested positive for pseudoephedrine at a meet on March 2. Nortey had taken the over-the-counter product, Seldane D, to combat allergies. (AP)

title: The Channel Islands' Discreet Charm Mixes Flexibility and Solidity
description: IF YOU want to learn about the art of compromise, ask a Channel Islander. Or, more particularly, ask a Channel Island-based private banker.

title: Stewart Funeral Homes
description: Stewart Enterprises Inc. said today that it would buy six funeral homes and a cemetery. Terms of the purchases were not disclosed. Stewart's new cemetery is in Virginia, and the funeral homes are in California, Virginia, Oregon, Puerto Rico and Australia.

title: Dancers' Explosiveness Rubs Off on a Quiet Clown
description: What can a nerd in a bowler hat and too-big shirt and pants teach a bunch of hip-hop dancers about rap? And vice versa? Plenty, if the nerd's name is Bill Irwin, and the hip-hoppers are the Ghettoriginal Productions Dance Company.

title: World News Briefs;Police Hold Thousands As Indians Go to Polls
description: The police detained thousands of people across the country today and took up positions at polling stations on the eve of the second phase of India's general elections.

title: COLLEGE LACROSSE REPORT
description: Bucknell

title: Refugees From Mutilation
description: The case of Fauziya Kasinga, a young woman seeking asylum in the United States, has drawn renewed attention to an abhorrent practice, female genital mutilation. Ms. Kasinga, threatened with this barbaric fate, fled her home in Togo 18 months ago. After first being denied by an immigration judge last year, her claim will be reviewed today by the Board of Immigration Appeals.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DIVIDEND TO RISE 15% AND STOCK WILL BE SPLIT
description: Pepsico Inc. said yesterday that it would raise its dividend by 15 percent and that it would split its stock 2 for 1. Pepsico, the soft-drink and fast-food company, will distribute two shares for every share held as of May 10. The company will then raise its quarterly dividend to 11.5 cents a share from 10 cents, when accounting for the split. The higher dividend will be paid on June 28 to shareholders of record on June 7.

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;Brett Lindros Calls It Quits
description: Speaking sadly of a career he is ending at age 20 because of repeated concussions, the Islanders' Brett Lindros said yesterday that he was quitting because he did not want to risk "the possibility of blindness as well as permanent brain damage."

title: Currents;Espresso With an Artist
description: JAMES ROSENQUIST paints. He also designs espresso cups for Illycaffe, an Italian brand of coffee that sells for $9 for an 8.8 ounce can.

title: PANEL URGES SHIFT IN HOW NEW YORK PAYS HEALTH BILLS
description: A mayoral advisory panel has recommended that New York City fundamentally change the way it pays for health care for the indigent, proposing that the government subsidize insurance for the uninsured rather than maintain the current system of subsidizing hospitals that treat the poor.

title: Political Briefs
description: New Hampshire Candidate's Pledge: Read Her Lips . . .

title: No Headline
description: There you are doing international television, debating Presidential politics, and all that's running through your mind is: Can these people see my stomach moving like this?" SUSAN MOLINARI, a Congresswoman in her final month of pregnancy. [B2:5.]

title: On Moving Chambers
description: To the Editor:

title: Tapping the New Wealth of Women
description: LOS ANGELES  When Alison A. Winter began her career in banking in 1971, the industry at large had yet to fully recognize one potential client base.

title: Immigrant Workers Aren't Stealing Jobs
description: To the Editor:

title: Tougher Asylum Rules Are Dropped by Senate
description: The Senate today dropped from its bill on illegal immigration provisions that would have made it more difficult for foreigners to gain asylum here. But senators kept a provision that critics contend will lead to a national identification card.

title: GOLF;Australian Takes L.P.G.A. by Storm
description: Karrie Webb has made only one real rookie mistake this season. It wasn't when she made her first double bogey of the year -- on the 15th hole of her seventh L.P.G.A. tournament, after 414 straight holes without one -- or when she finished tied for 19th in that event, the first time all year she wasn't in the top seven.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Meeting Is Disrupted At British Aerospace
description: The annual shareholders meeting at British Aerospace P.L.C. ended in chaos yesterday as demonstrators stormed the stage, hurling eggs and shouting that company directors were "guilty of genocide." Fighting broke out, and about a half-dozen demonstrators were dragged from the conference room.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;A Village Gets a Bequest
description: Dorothy Kraft was born in Brooklyn in 1908 and died in New York last August, but that did not stop her from leaving much of her fortune to Ridgewood, where she grew up.

title: Targeting Hungary's Nouveau Riche
description: BUDAPEST  At Citibank's year-old customer branch, ultra-preferred customers have their own personal money advisers and access to a business center and conference room, complete with mini-bar. Customers deemed "VIP," or even "VVIP" by OTP Bank have an even greater distinction: they don't even have to bank in the same place as their lower-income fellow Hungarians. The Very, Very Important People banking with OTP have their own branch and can do their banking in a private room, assisted by a privatecounselor.

title: Crompton & Knowles Is Set To Buy Uniroyal Chemical
description: The Crompton & Knowles Corporation agreed today to buy the Uniroyal Chemical Corporation for about $1.4 billion, veering from its main dye-making and machinery businesses to products that are not vulnerable to swings in the fashion industry.

title: INSIDE
description: Educating New Jersey

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Ex-Ohio State Coach Suffers Aneurysm
description: FRED TAYLOR, who coached Ohio State to the 1960 National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament championship, was hospitalized in critical but stable condition yesterday after undergoing surgery for a brain aneurysm. Taylor, 71, underwent surgery on Tuesday for a blister on a blood vessel in his brain, said a spokesman at Riverside Methodist Hospitals in Columbus, Ohio. (AP)

title: The Pop Life
description: Pete Townshend is a man stuck in his own past. He has just released a CD-ROM exploring the various adaptations of his 1969 rock opera "Tommy" and a compilation of his old solo songs, "The Best of Pete Townshend" (Atlantic); he is planning to perform his 1973 rock opera, "Quadrophenia," on June 29 in London with the rest of the Who and such guests as Eric Clapton, Bob Dylan and Alanis Morissette. And he is working on a script to make a theater piece out of "Lifehouse," an unfinished science-fiction project from the early 70's based on a hypothetical six-month-long rock concert.

title: 98 Tour for City Ballet
description: The New York City Ballet has announced a 50-state tour to begin in 1998, the company's 50th anniversary. The tour is to begin with a Fourth of July performance on the Mall in Washington, to be telecast by PBS. For the tour, the troupe will split into companies of 30 dancers each.

title: Heave Ho, Heave Ho: Awaaay Starks Goes!
description: Just before halftime tonight, John Starks heaved a desperation shot from just beyond midcourt. It hit nothing but net.

title: Teen-Ager Is Charged With Killing Friend
description: An argument between two teen-agers who had known each other since the fourth grade ended Tuesday night when one pointed a shotgun at the other and pulled the trigger, killing his friend, the police said today.

title: Currents;4-Apartment Show House Has Big Design Solutions
description: IF good things come in small packages, so, too, can good ideas come in small show houses.

title: Subway Explosions Panic Passengers
description: Hundreds of subway riders scrambled for the exits, hundreds more were trapped in stalled trains and service was shut down on the city's busiest subway line for hours last night after a series of electrical explosions underneath a southbound train on the Lexington Avenue line at around 7 P.M. Thirty people were treated for minor injuries .

description: NEW YORK

title: Corrections
description: The Nasdaq National Market stock table and the listing of most active Nasdaq stocks in the Market Indicators in Business Day yesterday misstated Tuesday's closing price and change from the previous day for the shares of Uunet Technologies Inc. in some copies. Uunet's shares closed at $58.75, up $10.50.

title: New Jersey Panel Adopts New Academic Standards
description: In an effort to equalize the quality of instruction offered throughout New Jersey's widely dispersed public school systems, the state's top education policy board today adopted new academic standards that are to be put into practice during the next six years.

title: Alice Kornegay, 65, Advocate For East Harlem Housing Groupdr
description: Alice Kornegay, a powerful community advocate in East Harlem for the better part of 40 years, died on Tuesday at North General Hospital. She was 65.

title: The Long Unabom Manhunt Becomes a Paperback Sprint
description: With the shipment of its first load of Unabom paperbacks yesterday, it appears Warner Books has triumphed in a frantic literary 100-yard dash made fierce by its tantalizing prize: a quickie book with the shelf life of a head of lettuce.

title: Currents;A Calling For Castoff Dressers And Sofas
description: DO you have any used sofas or dressers that you want to find a new home for? If so, the Partnership for the Homeless is playing your song.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Chained Inmate Escapes
description: Wearing ankle irons, a belly chain, handcuffs and prison garb, an inmate from the county jail escaped yesterday from a Municipal Court holding area just after he appeared before a judge, the police said.

description: Crab Apple Choices

title: All Acts, Good and Bad
description: To The Home Section:

title: Negotiator Abandons His Effort To Settle Standoff in Montana
description: James (Bo) Gritz, the former Green Beret colonel who has been negotiating with the anti-government Freemen, today gave up trying to persuade the group members to surrender, saying they had taken an "oath to God" not to leave their compound until their demands were met.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It was one of those quintessentially New York evenings Tuesday, when more than 200 people from the worlds of theater, cabaret and restaurants gathered to honor FAITH STEWART-GORDON, the longtime owner of the Russian Tea Room, who sold it to the restaurateur Warner LeRoy last June. The International Association of Women Chefs and Restaurateurs gave her its Outstanding Achievement Award at a Russian dinner in the Hudson Theater on West 44th Street.

description: Debt

title: Decorators' Bills: Air-Kiss and Tell
description: UPTOWN, an exasperated billionaire refused to pay his interior designer's outstanding bills upon learning that four chairs of Russian Imperial provenance, purchased through the designer for $1 million, were worth only one-tenth that amount.

title: A Transformed Mali Deserves U.S. Support
description: To the Editor:

title: ON BASEBALL;An Old Game Finally Gets New Beat
description: To compare the start of the 1996 baseball season to last year's is like comparing L L Cool J to Gene Autry.

title: BASKETBALL;Another School Star Might Go for N.B.A.
description: The high school basketball star Jermaine O'Neal may follow his fellow high school star and friend Kobe Bryant straight from high school to the National Basketball Association draft, O'Neal's coach said today.

title: Of Marriage, Money and a Lawmaker's Woes
description: A month ago, Representative Wes Cooley, a freshman Republican from eastern Oregon, mistook an April Fool's spoof for real news and cited it in a speech. Asked about the gaffe by a reporter from his home state, Mr. Cooley is reported to have replied that he would beat her up if she were not a woman.

title: Of Rivers and Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Furnish Your Rooms With Rent-a-Guest
description: THE most misunderstood and neglected phase of interior decoration often comes after the room is done: Who will see it? What will they say? Will they even get it?

title: Standing Out Among the Men in Suits;Molinari, an Urban Republican, Balances Power and Pragmatism
description: Susan Molinari rested a stack of papers against her belly and trudged from the Capitol to one of her last public appearances here for a while, as she waits to become the third serving member of Congress to give birth.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;Cavaliers Say Bulls Will Have to Earn It
description: As the Knicks turn their attention to the Chicago Bulls, there is a question of whether they are simply wasting their time. After all, the Bulls, who had a better record than any team in National Basketball Association history -- 72-10 -- have been called the best team in history.

title: THEATER REVIEW;The Power Of Money, As Wilde Saw It
description: An Ideal Husband," Oscar Wilde's melodramatic comedy first produced in London in January 1895, has long been overshadowed by the playwright's masterpiece, "The Importance of Being Earnest," which came to the West End just one month later. "The Importance" dazzled just about everybody except George Bernard Shaw, who much preferred the earlier work. Now Peter Hall is giving us the opportunity to rediscover the joys of "An Ideal Husband" in his company's gorgeous-looking, delectably acted London production, which opened last night at the Ethel Barrymore Theater.

title: Antitrust Investigators Examine Illinois Bond Sale
description: The Justice Department is investigating whether some of the country's biggest mutual fund groups acted illegally when they decided not to buy securities at a recent municipal bond sale in Illinois, officials said today.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;In the Albany Cycle, a Deadly Disputed Marriage
description: THE FLAMING CORSAGE By William Kennedy 209 pages. Viking. $23.95.

title: Liberties;Not-So-Splendid Deception
description: In the 30's my father, a D.C. police detective, traveled to the Deep South to bring back a prisoner for trial. As he waited at the railroad station to come home, some nasty-looking vagrants surrounded him.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;More Decisions Loom For Lakers' Johnson
description: The idea was to leave on his own terms, not Hakeem Olajuwon's. Magic Johnson's comeback is about to go on recess, and the question is whether his body, his mind and his ego can handle another subservient season.

title: Designers Offer a Week Of Ideas for All Rooms
description: No room will feel left out at New York Interior Design Week '96, which starts tomorrow. It is really a festival of 56 events, including guided architectural tours, curator-led walks through museums and seminars on coping with clutter or choosing new window treatments. The week is sponsored by the New York chapter of the American Society of Interior Designers.

title: DANCE REVIEW;A Vision of Steps That Often Clash
description: Garth Fagan loves to mix movements and he doesn't always appear to care whether they match. Unexpected and often bizarre juxtapositions of steps contribute much to the visual distinctiveness and emotional unruliness of his choreography.

title: Bystanders Subdue Two Suspects in Upper East Side Mugging
description: Two muggers who were chased down by bystanders on the Upper East Side after beating an 86-year-old woman were charged in a separate case yesterday: the murder of another elderly woman they had mugged in the same neighborhood just weeks before, the police said.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Wheat Prices Surge on Report Of Worse-Than-Expected Crops
description: Wheat prices surged yesterday, recovering from a two-day slide, after analysts touring drought-stricken fields in Kansas found damage to this year's crop was worse than they had expected.

title: Clinton Arms Policy Questioned in House
description: The House Oversight Committee voted today to spend nearly $1 million to investigate President Clinton's decision to ignore Iran's shipments of arms to Bosnia.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Another Outsider At Ogilvy & Mather
description: The Ogilvy & Mather Direct unit of WPP Group in New York has hired its third executive from outside the agency since February, when Wendy Riches joined as chairwoman and chief executive.

title: Editorial Notebook;Republican Talking Points
description: People are picking on Bob Dole. Surely this self-pitying sentence must by now have popped up in third-person reveries of the prospective Republican nominee, and not without good reason. The television shows and political columns are full of people denouncing Mr. Dole as an aging loser whose mismanaged campaign will lead to certain defeat at the hands of President Clinton, and Republican losses in Congress. And that's just the Republicans talking. The Democrats are standing back and enjoying the spectacle of a G.O.P. seized by a widespread epidemic of buyer remorse.

title: Hooters Chain Is Freed of Job Bias Inquiry
description: After four years, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has ended its investigation of the Hooters restaurant chain for refusing to hire waiters to work alongside its scantily clad waitresses.

title: Rosaura Revueltas, 86, the Star Of a Pro-Labor Film of the 50's
description: Rosaura Revueltas, the Mexican actress who starred in the politically inflammatory film "Salt of the Earth," died on Tuesday at her home in Cuernavaca, just south of Mexico City. She was 86.

title: New Season of Home and Garden Tours
description: HOUSE tours, garden tours and show houses begin in earnest this week, and freshly pruned gardens, polished antiques and sparkling skylights await visitors. Here is a sampling, from Delaware to Massachusetts.

title: BASEBALL;Met Killer, Met Savior Enjoy Split At Shea
description: Pedro Martinez might pay to pitch against the Mets. Jason Isringhausen did make the Montreal Expos pay on an evening of shutouts at Shea Stadium last night.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Airbus Tries to Fly in a New Formation;Consortium's Chief Hopes a Revamping Could Aid Its Challenge to Boeing
description: Jean Pierson has two major headaches. One is the Boeing Company, the giant American aircraft manufacturer whose global supremacy Mr. Pierson, the burly 57-year-old chief executive of Airbus Industrie, is challenging. The other is Airbus itself.

title: Who Pays for Air Traffic Control, and How?
description: The lapse four months ago of the 10 percent tax on air fares has given airlines and travelers reason to cheer.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Wider Mental Health Policies Seen as Feasible Requirement
description: With new ways of controlling the cost of mental health care, some experts say, it may now be feasible for Congress to require insurance coverage for mental illness on a par with coverage for other illnesses.

title: HICKS, MUSE TO SET UP ANOTHER RADIO STATION GROUP
description: Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc. announced yesterday that it was committing as much as $100 million to acquire a group of AM and FM radio stations in rapidly expanding medium-size markets. The move comes less than three months after Hicks, Muse, the leveraged-buyout firm based in Dallas, sold a batch of radio stations in large markets in an initial public offering. Hicks, Muse said the new group, to be named Capstar Broadcasting Inc., would be headed by R. Steven Hicks, who recently announced his resignation as chief executive of SFX Broadcasting Inc. Mr. Hicks, who is 46, is the brother of Thomas O. Hicks, the 50-year-old chairman and chief executive of Hicks, Muse.

title: Mexico's Leader Quietly Adopts A Warmer Approach to the U.S.
description: In a series of quiet policy changes, President Ernesto Zedillo has recently reversed some dearly held tenets of Mexico's historically prickly relationship with the United States.

title: Trump's Waistline, From Trump's Perspective
description: To the Editor:

title: Savings Bond Rates
description: New United States savings bonds will earn 4.36 percent interest for the first five years and 4.85 percent thereafter until maturity in 17 years, the Treasury Department said today. The rates apply to Series EE bonds issued over the next six months. The rates will be readjusted Nov. 1 to reflect market conditions. For the last six months, bonds earned 5.25 percent interest for the first five years.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JOHNNY MALDONADO, one of the winners of the 1995 Luciano Pavarotti International Vocal Competition, began his operatic career as a tenor, but from the beginning, he said, he sensed something was not quite right.

title: COMPANY NEWS;UP TO 1,500 JOBS TO BE CUT AT AIRPLANE UNIT
description: The Lockheed Martin Aeronautical Systems Company said yesterday that it would dismiss 1,200 to 1,500 employees because of budget cuts in the F-22 fighter aircraft program and reduced production of C-130 transport planes for the military. The company employs 10,000 workers at a plant in Marietta, Ga., and several hundred at plants in Charleston, S.C., and Clarksburg, W. Va. It is a unit of the Lockheed Martin Corporation, the biggest military contractor in the country. The layoffs will begin in two months and will be split among salaried and hourly employees. The layoffs will complete a plan announced two years ago to cut 2,000 jobs because of reductions in military spending. Since then, about 500 workers have left the company or have been laid off.

title: Kodak Chief Assails Japan's Refusal to Discuss Trade Complaint
description: The chairman of Eastman Kodak criticized the Japanese Government yesterday for refusing to discuss a market-access case filed last year by the United States trade representative's office.

title: Dietary Vitamin E Found to Help Women's Hearts
description: Postmenopausal women who get lots of vitamin E in food cut their chance of heart disease by almost two-thirds, a study has found.

title: Executive Changes
description: DEERE & CO., Moline, Ill., said David H. Stowe Jr., its president and chief operating officer, will retire on May 31, after 28 years with the company but will remain on the board. Hans W. Becherer, chairman and chief executive, will assume the duties and title of chief operating officer.

title: Muslim Visitors Called Mortal Danger by Serbs
description: When Obren joined the Serbian exodus from the Sarajevo suburb of Ilidza more than two months ago, he thought Muslims would be just a bad memory. He wouldn't have to see their children playing in the streets, watch their women hoe in their yards, or their men bow in prayer.

title: A Bit Late, Official Quits Post in Ottawa To Protest Tax
description: In a setback for Canada's two-and-a-half-year-old Liberal Government, the Deputy Prime Minister resigned today over its failure to abolish a detested 7 percent tax imposed by the previous, Conservative administration.

title: DANCE REVIEW;The Thrust of the Instant Makes All the Difference
description: It was anything but business as usual as the New York City Ballet opened its spring season on Tuesday night with an astonishing and electrifying performance by Wendy Whelan and Jock Soto in "Agon."

title: Research Adds 100,000 Years to Peking Man
description: Shedding new light on the evolution of humans in Asia, scientists say a celebrated collection of fossils known as Peking Man is at least 100,000 years older than believed.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: INTERNATIONAL JENSEN INC., Lincolnshire, Ill., which makes speakers and other audio products, has accepted an offer from Recoton Corp., Lake Mary, Fla., to buy Jensen for $52 million in cash and stock and about $45 million in the assumption of debt.

title: Middle Market Steers a $64 Million Art Auction
description: Bidders kept Sotheby's salesroom buzzing for nearly two and a half hours last night as Impressionist and modern artworks sold whether they were important or not.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Y.& R. Names Chief For New York Office
description: Young & Rubicam Inc. yesterday hired J. Steve Davis, executive vice president and general manager of the Chicago office of the J. Walter Thompson Company, as president and chief executive of the Y.& R. New York office. Mr. Davis, 51, will succeed Edward H. Vick, who was promoted in March to chairman and chief executive at Y.& R. Advertising Worldwide. Mr. Davis joined Thompson Chicago, a unit of WPP Group, in 1990 as general manager after working for agencies like Benton & Bowles and Altschiller Reitzfeld Davis. Lisa Wells, a spokeswoman for Thompson Chicago, said a successor to Mr. Davis "has not been named at this time."

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Prices Show Little Change On Treasuries
description: Prices of Treasury securities ended little changed yesterday, retreating from early gains after the Treasury said it would sell some notes and bonds more often.

title: Trump's Waistline, From Trump's Perspective
description: To the Editor:

title: Series of Electrical Blasts Under Subway Shuts Down Lexington Line
