description: A series of electrical explosions under a packed Lexington Avenue subway train last night sent hundreds of panicked riders scrambling for the exits, trapped hundreds more in stalled trains and shut down service on the city's busiest subway line for hours.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;Van Gundy Future on Hold
description: As a wave of support continued to build for Knicks Coach Jeff Van Gundy, the team president and general manager, Ernie Grunfeld, yesterday skirted the issue of whether he would guarantee the coach's contract for the next two seasons before the playoffs end. "Jeff has done a great job," Grunfeld said. "He's got the team headed in the right direction. They're playing well. But we shouldn't be worried about that right now. We should be worried about how this team is doing."

title: World News Briefs;Chechen Rebel Denies Reports He Is Dead
description: Chechnya's separatist leader, Zelimkhan Yandarbiyev, met reporters today to refute reports that he had been killed in a clash with rival rebels.

title: F.D.A. Chief Questions Safety of Proposals
description: Proposed bills to overhaul the Food and Drug Administration would lower safety standards for food, drugs and medical devices, Dr. David A. Kessler, the agency's Commissioner, said at a Congressional hearing today, even as some Republicans who originally supported the legislation appeared to back away from it.

title: Swiss Accord Is Reported Near on Holocaust Victims' Funds
description: Leaders of Jewish organizations and Swiss banking industry officials are expected to sign an agreement today to search for funds deposited in Switzerland during the frantic days of World War II by those who later died in the Holocaust, officials close to the negotiations said.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Inspiring Compassion for a Villainous Fop
description: The Comedie-Francaise, France's most venerable theater company, is supposed to provide the best and most authoritative versions of its country's national classics. Its production of Moliere's "Don Juan," which opened at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Tuesday, does not disappoint even if it is also not utterly dazzling. Moliere, after all, is Moliere, one of the great figures of European literature, and this performance -- in French with English subtitles -- sparkles with his intelligence, is visually striking and at times extremely intense.

title: Immigrant Workers Aren't Stealing Jobs
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Republicans Choose Charity-Care Plan
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and Republican legislative leaders agreed today on a new two-year plan to pay for hospital care for the uninsured. The plan would continue to rely on payroll taxes paid by employers and seek to move the state's uninsured into a managed care program.

title: Defense in Bombing Case Attacks Decision on Death Penalty
description: Prosecutors and defense lawyers tangled today over Attorney General Janet Reno's decision to seek the death penalty for the two men charged with bombing the Federal building in Oklahoma City.

title: Russia's New-Look May Day: Marching Is Out, Politicking Is In
description: The Soviet anthem blared through the loudspeakers. And the old Soviet flag was raised high, as the presidential candidate Gennadi A. Zyuganov sought to use Russia's May Day celebration to tap a wellspring of nostalgia for the Communist cause.

title: Mexico's May Day March Shows Worker Anger at Official Unions
description: Dissident labor unions staged a huge but peaceful May Day march through downtown Mexico City today, in a show of workers' growing rejection of the official labor movement.

title: Economic Scene;A Dole bill to revise tort law may lure some centrist Democrats.
description: THIS week or next President Clinton is expected to veto a bill that would limit punitive damage awards in product liability suits. In response, Senator Bob Dole plans to introduce a new bill to change tort law -- one even more ambitious than the full-blown makeover for civil justice proposed by Republicans last year.

title: Mexico Happy With Response To New Bonds
description: Mexican officials crowed today about the response to a sale of a new 30-year Government bond, though market analysts gave more mixed reviews.

title: A Transformed Mali Deserves U.S. Support
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HORSE RACING;Jockey Draws 10-Day Ban at Belmont Park
description: Belmont Park stewards have suspended the jockey DEAN BUTLER for 10 days for careless riding aboard Lets Rocket, first across the finish line in the seventh race on Saturday. Lets Rocket was disqualified from first place and dropped to fourth in the five-horse field for impeding Procryptic entering the stretch. Procryptic finished fourth. Butler appealed the suspension, which was to have begun yesterday. (AP)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the discovery of the unpublished manuscript of Louisa May Alcott's first novel misstated the location of Orchard House, the Alcott family museum. It is in Concord, Mass., not Concord, N.H. The article also misspelled her father's given name. It was Bronson, not Branson.

title: Canada Backs a Bill Favoring Gay Rights
description: The Canadian House of Commons gave approval in principle today to a bill that would ban discrimination against homosexuals.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Outdoor Advertising Awards Presented
description: The Leo Burnett Company in Chicago and Hunt Adkins in Minneapolis shared top honors, winning the Best of Show awards, at the 54th annual Obie Awards ceremony for creative excellence sponsored by the Outdoor Advertising Association of America.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MRS. SMITH'S TO BE SOLD TO FLOWERS, NOT CONAGRA
description: The J. M. Smucker Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Mrs. Smith's frozen pie business to Flowers Industries instead of to Conagra Inc. Financial terms were not disclosed. Smucker said the sale would result in a charge of 4 cents a share against its 1996 results. Smucker had tentatively agreed in February to sell Mrs. Smith's, which it acquired from the Kellogg Company in 1994, to Conagra. The sale of Mrs. Smith's, which generates $110 million in annual sales, is expected to close at the end of May, Smucker said. Flowers, which is based in Thomasville, Ga., makes food products for retail and food-service customers.

title: U.S. Hearing to Decide Rights of Women Who Flee Genital Mutilation
description: In a band of countries spanning Africa's midsection, more than 85 million women and girls have undergone genital mutilation and two million more are subjected to it each year, health experts estimate.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Earnings at B.A.T. Bolstered by Tobacco
description: B.A.T. Industries reported yesterday that it had a 16 percent rise in profits in the first quarter, led by gains in its tobacco business that surpassed a moderate increase in profits from financial services. The company repeated warnings that this year's increase would not keep up with 1995's 26 percent gain..

title: China's Duck and Cover (Comet Division)
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bankruptcy Begins At Bremer Vulkan
description: Bremer Vulkan-Verbund, once Germany's biggest shipbuilder, said yesterday that bankruptcy proceedings had formally begun, though work would continue at most operations.

title: Stores Are Accused of Food-Stamp Fraud
description: Food-stamp investigators in three parts of the country found that 43 percent of the stores they checked committed acts of fraud, including illegally accepting stamps as payment for liquor, cigarettes and clothing, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Gingrich Said to Vow Wage Vote Soon
description: Under unrelenting pressure from Democrats and facing increasing clamor within his own party, Speaker Newt Gingrich today promised House Republicans who support increasing the Federal minimum wage a vote on the issue within a few weeks, several of them said.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section yesterday about the training of personal trainers described a course at Marymount Manhattan College incompletely. The college's 12-day personal trainer program is an advanced course that must be preceded by a yearlong certification program for basic fitness instructors.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Arrest Made in Linebacker's Murder
description: A phone tip led to the arrest of a 24-year-old man in the murders last month of the Miami reserve linebacker Marlin Barnes and his friend Timwanika Lumpkins in a campus apartment. The 22-year-old students were beaten to death on April 13 with a shotgun by 24-year-old LABRANT DESHAWN DENNIS, who is Lumpkins's former boyfriend and the father of her 3-year-old daughter, the police in Miami said yesterday.

title: Critics See Politics in Economic Policy
description: For a President who professes faith in the free market, Bill Clinton has, in the view of some economists and business executives, been caught this week in some remarkable if politically unsurprising contradictions.

title: Telecast Is Canceled As Pavarotti Bows Out
description: The planned live telecast of Pavarotti Plus -- the annual concert at Avery Fisher Hall at which Luciano Pavarotti sings arias and ensembles with other opera stars -- was canceled last night when Mr. Pavarotti bowed out of the program because of the flu. Mr. Pavarotti's illness had also prevented him from appearing at the Metropolitan Opera's tribute James Levine on Saturday evening. Instead of the live broadcast from Lincoln Center, PBS showed a tape of the 1991 concert, at which Mr. Pavarotti did sing.

title: HERMAN'S INDICATES DESIRE TO LIQUIDATE ASSETS
description: Herman's Sporting Goods Inc., which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection last week, has indicated in court papers that it wants to liquidate its assets, with no apparent plans to reorganize the company. In its filing, the company, which is based in Carteret, N.J., said it had turned to Chapter 11 to provide the means for "an orderly liquidation of assets." Herman's is also asking the court for permission to conduct going-out-of-business sales. Herman's has 117 stores, from Massachusetts to Virginia, which remain open.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Bus Hits Painting Crew
description: A tour bus heading from New York's Chinatown to Atlantic City slammed into a highway painting crew's truck on the Garden State Parkway yesterday, injuring 18 people on the bus and spilling 600 gallons of white paint, the authorities said.

title: In Croatia's Capital, Politics and Democracy Don't Mix Well
description: Voters in the Croatian capital, who turned the city government over to an opposition coalition in October, have just discovered a fundamental rule about democracy in the Balkans -- people have a choice, as long as they choose what the Government wants.

title: Stocks Lower in Tokyo
description: Stocks were lower today at midday. The Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 75.96 points, or four-tenths of 1 percent, to 21,739.05. On Wednesday, the Nikkei dropped 226.29 points to 21,815.01. It was the index's first finish below 22,000 since April 19.

title: Is the Dreaded 'Big Talk' Passe?
description: FOR Doris Velez, the new reality of the birds and the bees hit home when her 7-year-old son did a double take over an advertisement on a bus shelter.

title: BASKETBALL;Thompson Loses One: Iverson Turns Pro
description: Allen Iverson's brief and controversial career at Georgetown University officially came to an end today when the sophomore became the latest underclassman to commit to the National Basketball Association draft.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;G.M. Plans to Close Parts Factory in Ireland
description: The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it would close a money-losing parts plant in Ireland in July and cut 509 jobs.

title: Quilt-Making Traditions
description: To The Home Section:

title: Liberians Keep on Fighting But Avoid the U.S. Embassy
description: Rival militias moved their battles away from the United States Embassy and into the neighborhood of Liberia's main faction leader today, littering the streets with bodies and provoking a strong showing of American military force.

title: Couple Arraigned In Death of Infant
description: A Brooklyn couple were arraigned yesterday on charges that they beat the woman's 9-month-old daughter and failed to seek medical attention that might have saved the baby's life, prosecutors said.

title: Contractor Admits Extortion and Role in Mafia
description: A prominent contractor who helped shape the New York City skyline admitted yesterday that he had led a double life as respected businessman and Mafia capo.

title: Herbert Brownell, 92, Eisenhower Attorney General, Dies
description: Herbert Brownell Jr., who as President Dwight D. Eisenhower's first Attorney General speeded desegregation by encouraging the President to name judges who vigorously carried out the Supreme Court's school integration decisions in the South, died yesterday in his home in Manhattan. He was 92..

title: Facing Bitter Fight, McAfee Withdraws Its Bid for Cheyenne
description: Facing a bitter war of wills between two chief executives, McAfee Associates Inc. has decided to withdraw its $1 billion proposal to acquire Cheyenne Software Inc.

title: Dole Recruiting in 2 Camps For Ad Campaign Leaders
description: Under fire within the Republican Party as lacking focus, the Dole campaign is quietly recruiting on Madison Avenue and among experienced Republican operatives to sharpen Senator Bob Dole's image for the general election campaign.

title: Foreign Horizons WidenFor Savvy Global Investors
description: LONDON  It is thought that the money of rich people is kept locked in solitary financial fortresses, often in countries like Switzerland that themselves are solitary financial fortresses, only bigger. Much of the wealth deposited in private banks stays there only briefly, however, before being sent abroad for investment or business, and the job of managing it is largely one of managing currency flows.

title: DISCREET LOGIC STOCK FALLS AFTER EARNINGS WARNING
description: The stock of Discreet Logic Inc. lost more than 40 percent of its value yesterday after the company warned that it would report a large loss for the latest quarter and announced the departure of a top executive, the second to leave the company in the last few months. Discreet, a maker of image processing systems for audio and video special effects, fell $7.25, to $9.375, in Nasdaq trading of more than nine million shares. The company, which is based in Montreal, said it expected a significant loss for its fiscal third quarter, which ended on Tuesday, and announced that its chief financial officer, Douglas R. Johnson, planned to leave. In February, the stock was also battered after the company issued a warning of lower-than-expected second-quarter earnings and announced the departure of its chief executive and president, David Macrae.

title: Anti-Scalding Device That Is Easy to Install
description: A new device designed to prevent scalding in the shower is so simple that almost anyone can install it in a few minutes. It is part of a line of products called Memry Safe made by the Memry Corporation of Brookfield, Conn., and costs about $15.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;A Return to 'Wiseguy,' With the Original Guy
description: Ken Wahl's shot at big-time stardom in the late 1980's hit a brick wall. As Vinnie Terranova in the series "Wiseguy," Mr. Wahl was the perfect undercover hunk, his street smarts seducing the assorted mobsters he had to destroy, even as he grew perversely fond of them. But citing "differences" with the producers, the actor left that CBS series. With Steven Bauer as a hasty replacement, "Wiseguy" departed quickly in 1990.

title: AT WORK WITH: Cookie Johnson;Moving Forward, With Hope
description: Her face somber, Cookie Johnson recalled that evening in November 1991 when her husband, Earvin Johnson, walked into the den of their Beverly Hills home. She was sitting there with a girlfriend about to watch a Los Angeles Lakers game.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;A Chance to Shoot Down Bulls Is as Easy as 1-2-3
description: One more time. The Knicks had to prove it to their fans and to the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: New Service Is No Easy Ride, Disabled Say
description: One Sunday last month, Catherine Riley, who uses a wheelchair, arranged for a specially equipped van to pick her up at the World Trade Center. After waiting 90 minutes on a deserted street, she gave up on the van and started a three-transfer, two-hour bus trip home to Washington Heights.

title: Dole's Foreign Policy Shows His Humanity
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Makes Arafat's Day In Oval Office
description: A natty, neatly barbered Yasir Arafat, having traversed the path from guerrilla leader to peacemaker, had his turn on the White House stage today, hearing himself praised by the American President for his courage and his commitment to peace.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Nasdaq Stocks Advance For 10th Straight Record The Nasdaq composite index roared to its 10th consecutive record high close, matching a string of highs set in 1992. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 6.14 points, to 5,575.22, while the Nasdaq jumped 9.14 points to end at 1,199.66.

title: HORSE RACING;Small Crowd at Belmont
description: Spectacular spring weather, full fields, a $75,000 stakes featuring 3-year-old fillies and just 7,396 people. Opening day at Belmont Park isn't what it used to be, thanks to the growth of in-home simulcasting and off-site betting. Yesterday's crowd was believed to be the smallest ever for a Wednesday opener at the race track, down from 9,182 last year and from 11,549 in 1991.

title: Muse of Anti-Yeltsin Forces: He Is Feared, Never Ignored
description: Aleksandr Prokhanov seems too bourgeois to be seditious. He speaks with the ironic detachment of a French intellectual. His hair is straggly and graying. His clothes are elegantly faded.

title: Dime Savings Bank Cleared by Officials
description: Dime Savings Bank of New York said yesterday that Federal officials had ended an investigation into one of the bank's loan programs without filing charges.

title: Sports of The Times;Van Gundy Might Sleep After Sweep
description: MIKE FRATELLO has been there. He has sat unobtrusively on the Knicks' bench, taking care of a thousand details, while the head coach made the decisions. He was Jeff Van Gundy once.

title: Mayor Barry, Seeking Quiet, Quits a Retreat for Another
description: Complaining that constant interruptions by friends and reporters were interfering with his quest for "physical, mental and spiritual rejuvenation" at a southern Maryland retreat, Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. of Washington left the retreat today after four days and flew to St. Louis for more privacy.

title: Ross Perot Jr. To Control N.B.A. Team
description: Ross Perot Jr., saying he knows little about basketball but a lot about real estate, agreed today to buy a majority stake in the Dallas Mavericks to make the team and a planned new arena the center of a vast construction project.

title: Bridge
description: Some of the most confusing deals are those that offer several plausible lines of play. In choosing one, there is a danger that one good line will be overlooked altogether.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Party Taps Gingrich and Hyde For Key Jobs at the Convention
description: Republicans today selected Speaker Newt Gingrich to be the chairman of the party's convention this summer in San Diego and picked Representative Henry J. Hyde of Illinois to head the platform committee.

title: Kuala Lumpur Journal;Malaysia Looks Down on World From 1,483 Feet
description: In the afternoons, their twin pinnacles are lost in the monsoon rain clouds. At night they twinkle like parallel columns of stars. Malaysia officially became home recently not only to the tallest but even to the two tallest buildings in the world, the side-by-side Petronas Towers.

title: Itzhak Karpman, 82, an Editor And Chronicler of Jewish Life
description: Itzhak J. Karpman, who spent his life helping to chronicle Jewish history and achievements, died on Tuesday at his home on Riverside Drive on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. He was 82.

title: New Image Is Sought In a Trial
description: For the last year, Alex Kelly has lived in his childhood home here, doing chores, boating on Long Island Sound, mountain-biking, rock-climbing with his fiancee, reunited with his family after eight long years in Europe, a self-proclaimed fugitive in search of justice.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Coyote Hunting Proposed
description: State officials do not expect a stampede, but they think some New Jerseyans might be interested in a coyote hunting season.

title: A Transformed Mali Deserves U.S. Support
description: To the Editor:

title: Essay;The Biggest Election
description: In 1975, when Indira Gandhi assumed dictatorial control of India and threw her opponents in jail, President Ford asked his U.N. delegate, Daniel P. Moynihan, what to make of that.

title: HOCKEY;Russians, Czechs Win
description: Russia defeated Italy, 5-2, and the Czech Republic beat Germany, 6-1, today to advance to the semifinals of the world ice hockey championships in Vienna. The Russian victory sets up a semifinal Friday with Canada that is expected to produce the winner of this 60th annual tournament. The Czechs play the United States in the other semifinal.

title: Stabbing Of a Settler Fuels Debate Over Hebron
description: A Palestinian stabbed and seriously wounded an elderly Jewish settler today in Hebron, fueling a growing debate on whether Israeli forces should withdraw from most of the tense West Bank city, the last still under occupation.

title: Court Backs E.P.A. Authority On Disclosure of Toxic Agents
description: In a victory for the Environmental Protection Agency over the chemical industry, a Federal court ruled today that the agency had not exceeded its legal authority when it greatly expanded requirements for public disclosure of emissions of certain toxic chemicals.

title: Dekalb Sues Rivals Over Patented Seeds
description: The Dekalb Genetics Corporation is suing three rival seed companies, contending they infringed its patent rights to genetically altered seeds.

title: Judge Duckman Returns To Work, in a New Court
description: It's not often that a pack of reporters is on hand for a court case in which a burglar-alarm company sues a client that hasn't paid an $8,800 fee. And seldom in such cases are grief-stricken sobs heard in court in the middle of testimony.

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;Question Marks on Ranger Jerseys
description: The winner of the Ranger-Pittsburgh series could be determined by at least five key factors:

title: Dole's Foreign Policy Shows His Humanity;Bosnia Property
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayor Backs U.S. Takeover Of an Inquiry
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani declared his confidence in the honesty of his top aides yesterday but said the F.B.I. and the United States Attorney's office were correct in taking over an intensifying investigation of his administration's contracting practices to avoid any appearance of conflict.

title: IOMEGA STOCK UP AFTER REPORT OF POSSIBLE I.B.M. DEAL
description: The stock of the Iomega Corporation, a maker of computer storage devices, jumped $4.766, to $59.517, yesterday in Nasdaq trading. Traders said the increase was caused by coverage of short positions and a report that the company's Zip tape drive might be used in I.B.M.'s upgrade of its Aptiva personal computers. Cliff Josephy, an analyst with H. D. Brous & Company, said Iomega's stock rose after a report in the trade magazine Computer Retail Week that I.B.M. might use the Zip drive in new Aptivas. Spokesmen for Iomega, which is based in Roy, Utah, and for I.B.M. declined to comment. One trader said short-covering, when traders buy back borrowed shares that they had sold in hopes of a drop in the price, also contributed to the move in the stock, which traded last week at about $46.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Officer Charged in Robberies
description: A Trenton police officer who is in custody in Ohio was charged yesterday with a string of New Jersey bank robberies, Federal authorities said.

title: BASEBALL;At 1 A.M., Martinez Just Grand
description: The bright scoreboard at Camden Yards continued to fill with more zeros. Neither team could score. Neither team appeared capable of completing another long night of baseball between the Yankees and Orioles, and the rain that began in the 12th inning added a surreal touch to this strange evening.

title: Amerada Set to Sell Oil and Gas Fields
description: The Amerada Hess Corporation said yesterday that it would sell nine United States oil and natural gas fields and use the expected $324 million in proceeds to pay off debt.

title: What Gasoline Crisis?
description: It is not surprising that this week's debate over gasoline prices is occurring in a Presidential election year. Furor over gas prices is part of the American political tradition. In 1923, just as the nation was becoming motorized, the Wisconsin Senator Robert La Follette launched Congressional hearings on rising prices at the pump.

title: David M. Ifshin, 47, Capital Lawyer and Lobbyist
description: David Michael Ifshin, a Washington lawyer who was active in Democratic Party affairs and was a lobbyist for Jewish causes, died on Tuesday at his home in Potomac, Md. He was 47.

title: Market Place;The rise in the stock of Zale, the national jewelry chain, has shown there is life after bankruptcy.
description: THE stock of the Zale Corporation, the nation's largest retail jewelry chain, is starting to regain some of its glitter after the company's fall into bankruptcy.

title: Testing Time for SUNY
description: The resignation of Thomas Bartlett, Chancellor of the State University of New York, is being cast in some quarters as the natural result of a power struggle between trustees appointed by Gov. George Pataki and a Chancellor hired during the time of his predecessor, Mario Cuomo. Power was indeed an issue. But more important was a profound disagreement over proposed budget cuts, which Mr. Bartlett regarded as disabling to the 64-campus SUNY system and damaging to its historical mission.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Contract for Parcells Is One Year Shorter
description: New England Patriots Coach BILL PARCELLS, apparently upset about his dwindling power and frustrated by his lack of success, has been granted permission to walk away from his contract after the coming season. The change, announced yesterday, will very likely have little effect on whether Parcells stays with the Patriots beyond the 1996 season, because he could return in spite of the change and might have left even if he was under contract.

title: Looking Closely At Child Care At Vacation Sites
description: WE were looking for a family vacation this past winter and thought we had found the perfect place: a Vermont ski resort that assured us by telephone that baby-sitting and special children's programs were available. I envisioned our children out on sleds or doing crafts projects, while my husband and I sipped hot toddies by the fire. We eagerly booked the reservation.

title: BASEBALL;Did He Peek Or Didn't He?
description: The Mets say he did. Henry Rodriguez insisted he didn't.

title: Currents;Pretty Spigots All in a Row
description: THERE is jewelry for the body -- why not for the bathroom?

title: HORSE RACING;Unbridled's Song Runs Well, but Draws Difficult Position
description: Unbridled's Song added a startling chapter to his Kentucky Derby saga today when he was fitted with yet another pair of horseshoes to protect his scraped heel and sped half a mile in 46 seconds in the day's fastest workout at Churchill Downs.

title: Orange County Creditors Said To Accept Plan
description: The largest municipal bankruptcy in United States history neared a conclusion today with the announcement that the creditors of Orange County, Calif., appeared to have accepted a recovery plan.

title: New Pastime for Mattingly
description: Nick Zito, training George Steinbrenner's Derby entry, Diligence, had a chance meeting this morning with one of his and his boss's favorite ballplayers, the former Yankees first baseman. "It's an honor to meet you," Zito told Don Mattingly, who strolled the barns with his wife, Kim, at Churchill Downs. "We have the same employer."

title: At Home Abroad;Bombs And Politics
description: Over the last 10 weeks Israel has suffered a series of terrible suicide bombings and had a frustrating military encounter in Lebanon. A country always concerned about its security might have been expected to turn sharply against the political leader in office, Prime Minister Shimon Peres.

title: Victims Can Sue Gun Makers Over Sales, Judge Rules
description: In a novel Federal ruling, a judge in New York has held that victims of handgun violence may proceed with a lawsuit against the firearms industry to discover whether it failed to take adequate steps to prevent weapon sales to illegal buyers like teen-agers.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;Rockets Move On. Magic Might, Too.
description: The regular season was window dressing.

title: Goetz Plans Move to Boston Where Mystery Job Awaits
description: Disenchanted with the city where he has earned both notoriety and a $43 million debt, Bernhard H. Goetz announced through his lawyer yesterday that he is leaving town, perhaps for good.

title: CUNY Misused Fiscal 'Emergency' To Cut Staff and Costs, Judge Rules
description: A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that City University of New York wrongly decided to lay off more than 100 professors, close or merge departments and cut remedial aid last June by using emergency financial authority even after the budget was effectively balanced.

title: Jets Send Willig to Atlanta for Pick
description: The Jets traded one of their former starters yesterday, and all they could get was the Atlanta Falcons' seventh-round draft pick of 1998. Left tackle MATT WILLIG, whom the Jets had cut last week, cleared waivers and was picked up by the team again. Then the Jets traded him to Atlanta. Willig became expendable when the Jets signed the former Giant JUMBO ELLIOTT as a free agent.

title: FILM REVIEW;A Femme Fatale Who Takes Her Calling Literally
description: Punishment is the only thing I understand," declares Eunice, a homicidal drifter portrayed with a transfixing ferocity by Amanda Plummer in Michael Winterbottom's film "Butterfly Kiss." This psychotic waif, who cuts a lethal swath as she travels the highways around the English seaside resort of Blackpool, might be described as a red-hot iron butterfly.

title: Corrections
description: An article by Reuters on March 30 about a jocular proposal to send British cattle to Cambodia misstated the source. The suggestion -- to send British cattle infected with so-called mad cow disease to Cambodia, where they could be set loose in old minefields, eliminating two problems at once -- was made in a letter to the editor published in The Cambodia Times, not devised by the newspaper itself. An E-mail message on Wednesday from the publisher of The Cambodia Times pointed out the error and cited two previous alerts to The New York Times, apparently misrouted between departments.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;North Korea Said to Store Spent Nuclear Fuel Better
description: The United Nations nuclear agency today welcomed a decision by North Korea to start placing spent fuel rods from a nuclear reactor into safe storage.

title: Emile Habibi, 73, Chronicler Of Conflicts of Israeli Arabs
description: Emile Habibi, an Israeli Arab writer whose depiction of the predicament of Arabs in the Jewish state made him one of the most prominent and popular authors in the Middle East, died today in a hospital in Nazareth. He was 73.

title: FILM REVIEW;A Dentist, a Prisoner, Her Rage, His Hunger
description: Until it skids into clanking melodrama, "Captives" is a dank, intriguing study of passion under pressure. The movie, directed by Angela Pope, yanks Julia Ormond off the perfect-woman pedestal on which she perched through "Legends of the Fall" and "Sabrina" to engage in some down-and-dirty thrashing around with Tim Roth.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Alusuisse-Lonza Seeking Wheaton
description: Alusuisse-Lonza Holding A.G., a Swiss aluminum, chemicals and packaging concern, said yesterday that it planned to acquire Wheaton Inc. of Millville, N.J., for more than 400 million Swiss francs, or $320 million. Wheaton produces specialty glass, plastic packaging and science products for drugs and cosmetics. The privately held company has annual sales of about $450 million and employs about 5,750 people in the United States, France, Brazil, Mexico, Puerto Rico and China.

title: Art in Review
description: Alex Katz Marlborough Gallery 40 West 57th Street Manhattan Through May 11

title: Asthma Toll Is Up Sharply, U.S. Reports
description: The rate of reported asthma deaths among young people more than doubled from 1980 to 1993, with blacks hit far harder than whites, the Government said today.

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;Rangers Have 2 Words For Penguins: Let's Go!
description: With five days between the last game of the previous playoff round and the first game of the next, the Rangers might be a little antsy.

title: Home Video
description: Awaiting Oscar's Chosen

title: In America;Radio's Sick Shtick
description: When I first heard that the plane carrying Commerce Secretary Ron Brown was missing I was in a cab, heading down Broadway to The Times.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Bill to Protect Pension Funds
description: A bill introduced in the state Senate yesterday would ban governors from tapping public employees' pension funds to help balance the budget, a practice followed by both Governor Whitman and her predecessor, Gov. James J. Florio.

title: Gay Marriage as a Basic Human Right;No Compromise
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;ZAPATA TO BUY HOULIHAN'S IN CASH AND STOCK DEAL
description: The Zapata Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Houlihan's Restaurant Group Inc. in a cash and stock deal valued at $8 a share, or about $80 million. The Florida businessman Malcolm I. Glazer is chairman of both companies and majority owner of Houlihan's, a restaurant chain based in Kansas City, Mo. Each Houlihan's share will be converted into $4 in cash and $4 in Zapata stock, although shareholders not affiliated with Mr. Glazer might be able to receive all cash for their shares. Houston-based Zapata, co-founded by former President George Bush, is shifting to a food-related business from an oil and gas production business.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Welfare Bill Wins 1st Vote
description: Riding this year's hot issue, lawmakers took a step toward tightening requirements for welfare recipients yesterday. A bill approved by the Senate Human Services Committee and sent to the full Senate would force a welfare recipient to identify the father of her child, except in the case of domestic violence, so that efforts could be made to collect child support.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JAMES DANZIGER, the owner of the photographic gallery in SoHo that bears his name, is getting his diploma from St. Paul's School, the prep school in Concord, N.H., 25 years after his class graduated.

title: Change the Laws, Not the Judges
description: Gov. George Pataki, appearing recently at a ceremony with Chief Judge Judith S. Kaye of the New York State Court of Appeals, politely endorsed "judicial independence." Then he pursued his aggressive attack on judges who release dangerous criminals on bail.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PRECISION CASTPARTS TO ACQUIRE OLOFSSON
description: The Precision Castparts Corporation of Portland, Ore.. said yesterday that it would acquire the closely held Olofsson Corporation for about $52 million. Olofsson, based in Lansing, Mich., has annual revenue of about $40 million and makes precision turning and boring machines, mainly for the automotive industry. Precision Castparts said Olofsson would complement the machines business of its specialty products division, which also performs high-precision boring as well as castings for the aerospace, automotive and medical industries.

title: Major Advertising Company to Bar Billboard Ads for Tobacco
description: In another setback for American cigarette companies, the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company said yesterday that its 3M Media subsidiary, the nation's third-largest outdoor billboard advertising company, would no longer accept billboard contracts for tobacco products after this year.

title: Critic's Choice/Film;A Director Who Made Tough Art
description: Too often overlooked in its own time, Don Siegel's tight, lean professionalism is badly missed today. Go admire its quiet economy at the Museum of Modern Art's impressively thorough Siegel series, which begins today and runs through June 6, and here's a promise: at least one of this summer's big, sprawling action films or meandering detective tales will make you long for this director's expert (and sometimes surprisingly soulful) touch.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: SOCCER;Donadoni Joins the MetroStars
description: ROBERTO DONADONI joined the MetroStars yesterday, will participate in a full practice with them this afternoon and will play tomorrow night when Tampa Bay and CARLOS VALDERRAMA visit Giants Stadium.

title: ART REVIEW;Portraits of an Emerging City
description: ANYONE fascinated by the history of New York City will find much to enjoy in "Metropolitan Lives: The Ashcan Artists and Their New York," a sometimes revealing, sometimes incoherent exhibition at the New-York Historical Society.

title: About Real Estate;Upper East Side to Get Condominium Building
description: The first condominium residence to be built on the Upper East Side in six years is rising on 72d Street and Second Avenue. The new building, the Knickerbocker, will be 22 stories high and will soon be joined by two other condominium structures in an area where development in recent years has been limited to a few rental buildings.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;How Could He Have Been Her Wonderful Father?
description: THE SHADOW MAN By Mary Gordon Illustrated. 274 pages. Random House. $24.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;A Romantic Diehard Who Liked to Let Light Play
description: When the Czech photographer Josef Sudek crawled under the "nun," the black skirt covering the camera, and exposed a sensitive photographic plate to light, he was known to say some incantatory words: "And the music plays . . ."

title: President Meets Moderates on Budget Plan
description: Keeping up his campaign to isolate Senator Bob Dole and other Congressional Republicans and to portray them as roadblocks to a balanced budget, President Clinton summoned a bipartisan coalition of nearly two dozen moderate Senators to the White House this afternoon to discuss their compromise budget proposal.

title: Pataki Supports Two-Train Link to Kennedy Airport That GiulianiOpposes
description: Gov. George E. Pataki today threw his support behind a plan for a railway to Kennedy International Airport, a project that the Port Authority proposed to him two weeks ago but that the Giuliani administration is resisting.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Cie. de Suez Sells Banque Indosuez Stake
description: Compagnie de Suez S.A., the French holding company, said yesterday that it had completed the sale of a majority stake in its investment bank, Banque Indosuez, to Caisse Nationale de Credit Agricole for $1.2 billion. With the sale, Credit Agricole, a French bank holding company, has a 51 percent stake in Banque Indosuez and has the option to increase its stake to 80 percent after July 1, 1997.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Dead Presidents 1995. Hollywood. $101.73. 120 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Tuesday.

title: Wisconsin's Bold, Risky Welfare Plan
description: Gov. Tommy Thompson has signed far-reaching legislation that, if he gets Washington's approval, would make Wisconsin the first state to end its welfare program. Under the law, the state would instantly stop giving cash aid to able-bodied applicants. Instead they would be put to work in private-sector jobs, subsidized if need be, or in community-service jobs.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Colombia Court Orders Attorney General's Arrest
description: Justice officials ordered the arrest today of Attorney General Orlando Vazquez Valasquez on charges of receiving about $200,000 from leaders of the Cali cocaine cartel. The cartel was also said to have paid hotel expenses for Mr. Vasquez.

title: A.S. Woodward, 47, Museum Director
description: Anne Spivey Woodward, a museum director and former administrator of Brandywine Battlefield Park in Pennsylvania, died on Tuesday at Chester County Hospital in West Chester, Pa. A West Chester resident, she was 47.

title: Graduate Students Dispute Idea That Dinosaurs Cared for Young
description: Since 1978, when Jack Horner discovered a fossil assemblage of baby dinosaurs apparently killed in their nest, many paleontologists have accepted his hypothesis that dinosaurs cared for their young long after hatching. But two graduate students have challenged that idea, contending that the domestic lives of dinosaurs may not have differed much from those of modern crocodiles.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;British Phone Concerns End Merger Talks
description: British Telecommunications and Cable and Wireless ended five months of negotiations today as financial and regulatory hurdles forced the companies to call off their plans to merge.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about Russian politics referred imprecisely to the academic background of Grigory A. Yavlinsky, liberal economist and candidate for the Russian presidency. Two readers have pointed out that although he has worked with Harvard professors, he did not attend Harvard University and should not have been described as Harvard-trained. (A profile on Dec. 1, 1995, which served as a source for the latest article, included the same error.)

title: Disney Reorganizes ABC Radio Division
description: The Walt Disney Company has reorganized the management structure of Capital Cities/ABC's radio division.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Strawberry Bound for St. Paul Team
description: DARRYL STRAWBERRY needs a job and cannot find one in the majors. MIKE VEECK is willing to overlook a player's troubled past to improve the reputation of his league. It seems to be a perfect match, and Strawberry will sign with Veeck's St. Paul Saints today as he tries to play his way back into the big leagues.

title: White House Regrets Choice of a Speaker
description: Moving to quell community complaints, the White House apologized today for mishandling the choice of a student speaker at a Presidential event in Florida.

title: Endangered Species Will Gain From Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: GOLF;Sorenstam Isn't Perfect, But a Golfer Can Dream
description: Every now and then, when she feels like letting her mind wander, Annika Sorenstam dreams about perfection. In that realm, she hits every green in regulation, makes every putt and shoots 54.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PLAY BY PLAY TO BUY SOME ACE NOVELTY ASSETS
description: Play By Play Toys and Novelties Inc. has agreed to buy some of the assets and assume some liabilities of the Ace Novelty Company, based in Bellevue, Wash., for $44 million in cash and debt. Play By Play, based in San Antonio, is one of the nation's top makers of stuffed toys. The company plans to buy Ace's four distribution centers in Chicago, Los Angeles, Bellevue and Burnaby, British Columbia. Ace had 1995 sales of $66 million. Play By Play said it expects to complete the acquisition by the end of the month.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;South Africa Court Frees Dealer in Arms for Iraq
description: A judge today freed a former British spy who is wanted in the United States on charges involving illegal arms sales to Iraq before the Persian Gulf war. The judge, Danie Oberholzer, ruled that there was insufficient evidence to extradite the arms dealer, Paul Grecian, to the United States.

title: Would Mrs. Onassis Have Been Chagrined?
description: To the Editor:

title: Horse Racing: Notebook;Lukas Has Five Chances of Keeping Streak Alive
description: Before this year, no trainer had ever run five horses in one Kentucky Derby. But, then, no trainer through the years has run as many horses in this race as D. Wayne Lukas, whose commitment to both excellence and excess reached unprecedented heights this year.

title: Mother's Don'ts and Don'ts;But She Never Told Poet Son, 'Don't Quote Me'
description: Two more divergent audiences a poet couldn't ask for: in the morning a group of second graders at Public School 26 in Flushing, Queens, in the evening a standing-room-only crowd of downtown literature aficionados at Barnes & Noble on Astor Place in Manhattan.

title: Britain Says It Will Not Allow Takeovers of 2 Big Electric Utilities
description: The British Government said today that it would not permit takeovers of the nation's two biggest utilities, National Power P.L.C. and Powergen P.L.C., after the Southern Company of Atlanta said it was considering a bid for National Power.

title: Editorial Notebook;Notes From the Underground
description: Officials spent yesterday trying to sort out whether an errant umbrella or some other vagrant object caused the explosions under a subway train at 51st Street and Lexington Avenue Wednesday night, injuring dozens of people and leaving thousands stranded for hours in hot, stalled trains.

title: Executive Changes
description: COOPER CAMERON CORP., Houston, named its president and chief executive, Sheldon Erikson, to the additional post of chairman, succeeding Robert Cizik, who is retiring.

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;A Broadway Bust Has Become a Smash in Pittsburgh
description: Somehow, the peripheral man has become the pivotal man. Petr Nedved, who evidently needed to become a Pittsburgh Penguin in order to live up to his legend, insisted he's the same man he always was, just a little better understood.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Whitman Talks of Condoms
description: Local school boards, not the state, should decide whether condoms should be distributed to students to help reduce the spread of H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said yesterday.

title: C.I.A., Bunker Free, Is Declassifying Secrets
description: To the Editor:

title: CYCLING;Armstrong Grows Up and Rides High
description: Lance Armstrong is proud, and why not? At age 24, he has achieved more success in bicycle racing than any modern American except the retired Greg LeMond. But his greatest pride comes from the way he has matured as a rider and, more important, as a man.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: HFS Agrees to Acquire Coldwell Banker for $640 Million
description: HFS Inc., which entered the residential real estate market less than a year ago with the purchase of Century 21, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Coldwell Banker Corporation, another of the best-known names in the business, for $640 million in cash plus the assumption of about $100 million of debt.

title: Art in Review
description: James Hyde Paolo Baldacci Gallery 41 East 57th Street Manhattan Through May 11

title: History as Therapy: A Dangerous Idea
description: Being a historian has almost become a dangerous occupation. The public seems to have few inhibitions about passing judgment on the inner business of the historical community. This popular excitement over the use and abuse of history can be both distracting and irritating for historians. But it is also a tribute to the significance of history -- a tribute for which we should be grateful. It would be far worse if no one cared what we said or did.

title: Sanders of Cowboys Elects to Receive
description: The Cowboys found out one thing in their weeklong minicamp and quarterback school: Deion Sanders is a better receiver than he is a baseball player.

title: Even 'Quiet,' Sun Is Found Very Turbulent
description: A new European-American spacecraft has revealed that even when the Sun is relatively quiet, as at the present, it is more violently turbulent than astronomers had realized.

title: FILM REVIEW;Float Like a Butterball, Hit Like a Flea
description: The gloves are definitely off in "The Great White Hype," a happily outrageous satire aimed at big-money boxing and the promoters and hustlers pulling its strings. Racial and ethnic slurs fly everywhere in Reginald Hudlin's scattershot comedy, but the insults are so even-handed they wind up cathartic rather than rude. With a gleeful script by Tony Hendra and Ron Shelton, not to mention a gamely funny cast, this raucous film comes close to what it's after: delivering a race-conscious "Spinal Tap" for the world of sports.

title: COMPANY NEWS;GENERAL MOTORS TO BUILD MISSOURI PLANT
description: The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it planned to build a stamping plant in Wentzville, Mo., that will be connected to its full-size van assembly plant there. The new plant is to include two new press systems for stamping parts for the new van, and represents a $100 million investment to the Wentzville community, G.M. said. Construction is scheduled to begin this fall. The 200,000-square-foot plant is expected to begin providing parts to the assembly plant in the 1997 model year. G.M. said that the new factory would cut transportation costs, reduce inventory and improve communication between the assembly and stamping operations.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Tom and Huck 1995. Disney. $19.99. 92 minutes. Closed captioned. PG.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Antismoking Group Looks for Agencies
description: The National Center for Tobacco-Free Kids, a nonprofit organization in Washington, said yesterday that it had begun a search for advertising and public relations agencies to help the center, which was started recently with a goal of trying to reduce tobacco use among children. Potential billings are estimated at $1 million for advertising and $350,000 for public relations, though the organization may ask that some work be produced pro bono.

title: The Long, Scary Road to the Bridle Path
description: KATHERINE MATHEWS, a physician in her 30's, got so piqued one night at the recalcitrant pony she was riding -- a filly by the name of Bo-Peep -- that she did something she never expected to do. When her riding teacher changed her over to a full-size horse and said, "Canter," she accomplished the gait like a dream, with unerring mastery and perfect form.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Balkan War Crimes: Bosnia Is First to Turn In Its Own
description: The Bosnian Government has detained two Muslims who were indicted by the international war crimes tribunal for the murder of Serbian prisoners, the first time any of the republics from the former Yugoslavia have honored arrest warrants from the special court in the Hague.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: South Africa Losing Battle to House Homeless
description: A year ago, when Maureen Mkhize was brought to this field north of Johannesburg and given a spot for her shack, she was told she would have real housing within six months. Since then, hundreds of families have joined her -- brought here by the truckload from sordid urban squatter settlements, the flimsy bits of their old shacks dumped beside them so they can rebuild.

title: Councilwoman Apologizes for Comments About Asians
description: Minutes after more than 2,000 Asian-Americans rallied outside City Hall to denounce City Councilwoman Julia Harrison for criticizing Asians in her district, the Queens Councilwoman stood before her colleagues in the Council's chamber yesterday and read an apology, saying she never meant to insult immigrants.

title: SENATE VOTES BILL TO REDUCE INFLUX OF ILLEGAL ALIENS
description: Riding a wave of public anger against illegal immigrants, the Senate overwhelmingly approved a bill today that would tighten America's borders and clamp down on millions of illegal immigrants living and working here.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: FILM REVIEW;Young Love at a Funeral
description: The Pallbearer" finds David Schwimmer in the midst of a group of 20-something cronies as he starts a romance with a young woman to whom he was first attracted years earlier. This sounds like "Friends," but the resemblance goes no farther. Instead, this sleepy, charmless romantic comedy is a 104-minute occasion for considering the magic that makes a hit television series click. Expert timing, bright atmosphere and stylish, sympathetic characters are among the sure-fire elements that "Friends" has and "The Pallbearer" lacks.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Cineplex Sets Joint Venture
description: The Cineplex Odeon Corporation is joining with Hollywood and the Japanese to create the ultimate interactive playland at its theaters across North America.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;More Water Tests Urged
description: The city of Newark does not test its water frequently enough to determine the presence of a parasite harmful to people with AIDS, a Washington advocacy group contended yesterday.

title: Business Group Sees Strong Job Creation
description: Contending that public anxiety about job insecurity has been exaggerated, a major business organization argued yesterday in a new report that the economy was creating millions of higher-paying jobs and this "occupational upgrading" should in time ameliorate the fear over layoffs.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;State Gives Up Library
description: Two centuries ago, the State Library occupied a single bookshelf, but now it has two million items, including the state's largest collection of Jerseyana. Yesterday, Governor Whitman signed an order transferring control of the library from the overburdened state Department of Education to Thomas Edison State College.

title: BASEBALL;Yanks Get Laurels at Baltimore Marathon
description: With his matted black hair and sleepy eyes, Joe Torre looked as if he had battled 15 rounds with Riddick Bowe. With his excitable voice, the rookie Jim Mecir sounded thrilled about his 15 minutes of fame. With his fresh appearance after tying a team record with six hits, Gerald Williams looked as if he could have handled another 15 innings. He was in the minority.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It's been a banner week for Sir ANDREW LLOYD WEBBER: his wife, MADELEINE, gave birth to a daughter on Tuesday, and on Wednesday his newest production, "By Jeeves" opened in Scarborough, England.

title: Would Mrs. Onassis Have Been Chagrined?
description: To the Editor:

title: Stocks Lower in Tokyo
description: Stocks closed lower today, ending a holiday-shortened week. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed down 152.63 points, or seven-tenths of 1 percent, at 21,662.38. This week is Japan's Golden Week of national holidays, and the Tokyo market was closed last Monday and will be closed on Friday and next Monday. For its three-session week, the Nikkei was down 572.65 points.

title: 94-Year Term In Firebombing In the Subway
description: Edward J. Leary, a computer analyst who lost his job and took his anger into New York City's subway system, was sentenced yesterday to 94 years for the firebombing of two trains in 1994. But not before a State Supreme Court justice, Rena K. Uviller, expressed her contempt for him.

title: BASEBALL;In a Snap, Cone Puts Concerns On Hold
description: David Cone dipped his right hand into his glove to grasp a baseball 127 times without hesitation. Every time Cone completed this simple routine before actually unleashing the ball, the Yankees exhaled. Everything was fine with Cone's mysterious hand last night. Actually, everything was splendid.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Economy Springs Back At a 2.8% Growth Rate The economy revived in the first quarter, growing at an annual rate of 2.8 percent, the Commerce Department said. The report delighted the White House, where officials claimed credit for reviving an economic expansion that once seemed about to expire.

title: TV WEEKEND;Look Out for Those Bradleys, They're Murder
description: If a list had to be compiled of subjects that have been squeezed dry by television movies, at the top, or very near it, would be the Kennedys and Marilyn Monroe, either separately or, as it were, in tandem. But the mills grind on relentlessly. Monroe will be the subject in a couple weeks of an HBO movie called "Norma Jean & Marilyn." And this weekend, the Kennedys' story is once again reviewed, albeit in thinly disguised fiction, in "A Season in Purgatory," based on Dominick Dunne's novel of the same name.

title: Small Town's Worry: Boys Just Won't Be Boys
description: His brow furrowed, Kaname Ogura sat cross-legged on the floor and confided his deepest anxieties about the incorrigible behavior of his 16-year-old son. The boy is incomprehensibly good.

title: FILM REVIEW;Mean Teen-Age Witches
description: Be careful what you wish for, because you just might get it. That cautionary cliche is reiterated with such bludgeoning insistency in "The Craft," an entertainingly cheesy thriller about a coven of teen-age witches, that the movie ends up turning against itself. Halfway into what starts out as a celebration of adolescent nonconformity and female independence, "The Craft" reverses its attitude and makes the spells cast by its four teen-age witches come back to haunt them. In its final half hour, the movie preaches a heavy-handed sermon about karma and the awful things that can happen to bad girls who dare to vent their evil thoughts.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: * Aspen Skiing Co., Aspen, Colo., to Hal Riney & Partners, San Francisco, to handle advertising for the resort, which had been handled by Cole & Weber, Seattle, a unit of the WPP Group; Riney had handled the account from 1988 through 1992. Billings were estimated at $4 million. * MHN Inc., New York, to Frank Luca & Partners, New York, to handle the creative parts of its MHN/ Men's Hair Now and MHN/Advanced Medical Restoration accounts, previously handled by Baldi, Bloom & Whelan, New York. The media part continues at Media Inc., New York. Billings were estimated at $1.5 million. * Damon's, the Place for Ribs, Columbus, Ohio, to Lord, Sullivan & Yoder, Columbus, to handle marketing communications for the restaurant chain, previously handled by Conrad, Phillips & Vutech, Columbus. Billings were estimated at more than $1 million. * Government of India Tourist Office, New York, to Clark & Pope, New York, to handle print and interactive media and collateral, and Oasis Inc., New York, to handle broadcast and cable media. The account, with combined billings estimated at $1 million, had been at McCann Direct, New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Unilever Profit Rises 3.4% in Quarter
description: Unilever N.V. said yesterday that its first-quarter profit rose 3.4 percent with help from soaring profits in North America, but the results were hurt by mad cow disease costs. Unilever said a write-off in its British frozen beef business related to concerns over mad cow disease wiped out profit in Europe.

title: Giuliani to Propose New Agency To Get Around Borrowing Limits
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani will propose the creation of a public authority that would allow New York City to sidestep a state constitutional limit on the city's debt, increasing the amount of money the city could borrow to build or repair everything from schools to bridges, senior officials said yesterday.

title: Diner's Journal
description: If you're in the market for a moment of eccentric luxury, consider the Library, the latest place to dine at the Regency Hotel. It's a cozy little hideaway where snacks are available from 7 A.M. to 1 A.M.

title: CABARET REVIEW;Songs by a Timeless Trouper
description: If that venerable show business archetype, the tragic clown, is seldom seen on the stage nowadays, he may be just too corny a figure for these cynical times. But don't count him out. As Anthony Newley demonstrated in his thunderous opening-night performance on Tuesday at Rainbow and Stars, the old fellow still has a plenty of juice in him, and facetious humor to boot.

title: Horse Racing;At the Finish, Outsiders Hope to Be Looking In
description: At least Unbridled's Song didn't get his shoes changed today. But the favorite for the Kentucky Derby walked comfortably for an hour in his egg-bar shoes while his handlers tried to minimize the latest indignity pitched into his path: Starting the Derby from the No. 20 position on the far outside of the auxiliary starting gate.

title: F.D.A. Panel Refuses to Clear Heart Drug
description: The SmithKline Beecham drug carvedilol, a beta blocker that has been described as one of the most promising new weapons against heart failure, failed today to win the backing of a Food and Drug Administration advisory panel.

title: Art in Review
description: Tony Oursler Metro Pictures 150 Greene Street SoHo Through May 25

title: COMPANY NEWS;COMSAT TO SPIN OFF WIRELESS SERVICES DIVISION
description: Comsat International Communications, a unit of the Comsat Corporation, said yesterday that it planned to spin off a business unit that would focus solely on personal communications services delivered via satellite. The unit, Comsat Personal Communications, plans to offer wireless mobile communications services using hand-held devices. It will operate Planet 1, Comsat's global phone service, which is to become available later this year. The unit is now part of Comsat Mobile Communications, the American member of Inmarsat, the international satellite consortium.

title: Prosecutor Finds No Wrongdoing By President of Kingsborough
description: The Brooklyn District Attorney said yesterday that his office had found no evidence of criminal conduct by Leon M. Goldstein, the president of Kingsborough Community College and once Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's top choice to become the New York City schools chancellor.

title: Restaurants
description: I don't care."

title: BOXING;Holyfield Can See the Torch at the End of a Title Dream
description: Evander Holyfield's convoluted dream -- the one in which he returns to his hometown Atlanta with the heavyweight championship just as the Olympic Games unfold -- moved closer to reality yesterday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: * Jim White, executive vice president and chief creative officer at Long Haymes Carr, Winston-Salem, N.C., a unit of Interpublic Group, was promoted to the new position of vice chairman. * Nancy Newman, national associate publisher at PC Magazine, New York, which is owned by the Ziff-Davis Media Group unit of the Softbank Corp., was promoted to publisher, succeeding Dan Rosensweig, who was promoted to executive vice president of the Internet Publishing Group. * Reba Palker was named to the new post of senior vice president and group account director at Lowe Direct, New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group, working on the Mercedes-Benz of North America account. She had been a senior partner and account director at Ogilvy & Mather Direct, New York, a unit of the WPP Group. * Howard S. Davis was named president of Baker Hill Radio and Promotions, a new unit of Baker Hill Media Services, Great Neck, L.I. He had been vice president and sales director at MJI Broadcasting, New York.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Careful 1992. Kino. $79.95. 100 minutes. No rating.

title: Husband of Utah Congresswoman Is Indicted
description: The estranged husband of a Utah Congresswoman was indicted today on 27 counts of bank fraud in a scheme in which he was accused of writing hundreds of thousands of dollars of worthless checks.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Throughout their lives, MARK and SCOTT KELLY have followed more or less the same path. On Wednesday, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced that they were the first set of twins selected as astronauts, The Associated Press reported. .

title: S.E.C. Disciplines Company Over Accounting
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered the Sulcus Computer Corporation today to refrain from using improper accounting methods that it used in the past, the commission contends, to create phony profits. An S.E.C. official warned that the commission was keeping a close watch on merger accounting.

title: Rowland Told to Find $147 Million in Savings
description: Unwilling to make stiff spending cuts or rescind next year's tax reduction, Connecticut legislators passed a revised $10 billion budget this evening that would require Gov. John G. Rowland to find $147 million in savings in the state's personnel and operating expenses during the next fiscal year.

title: 25 and Under
description: If you are looking for Elias Corner, the Greek seafood restaurant in Astoria, Queens, and suddenly think you are seeing double, don't worry.

title: Inside Art
description: Out of the Guggenheim's Core

title: TV SPORTS;Ben Wright's Chance At New Self-Awareness
description: Ben Wright will return home this weekend to Flat Rock, N.C., after four weeks of treatment for alcoholism at the Betty Ford Center, almost a year to the day since he made critical remarks about lesbianism in women's golf.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bundesbank Declines To Change Key Rates
description: Germany's central bank, the Bundesbank, left its key interest rates unchanged yesterday. The discount and Lombard rates were each lowered a half-percentage point on April 18, to 2.5 percent and 4.5 percent, respectively. The Lombard rate is the rate at which banks borrow emergency overnight funds from the central bank. The discount rate is the cheapest form of central bank refinancing. (AP)

title: Gay Marriage as a Basic Human Right
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Medical Waste on Beach
description: Another dispute has developed between New York and New Jersey, this time over medical waste. New Jersey officials say syringes and empty pill and vaccine bottles washed up on the Sewaren Beach Peninsula on the Arthur Kill last week, and they smell a culprit in Staten Island's Fresh Kills landfill, less than five miles away.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Pilot Shortage at S.A.S.
description: The Scandinavian Airlines System said today that it would reduce flights because of a shortage of pilots. The Swedish news agency TT quoted an S.A.S. spokesman, Per Lock, as saying the carrier would cut flights starting on Sunday to avoid the daily cancellations it has been forced to impose this week because it does not have enough pilots. TT said about 15 flights had to be canceled today because there was no one to fly the planes.

title: New Satellites For Arianespace
description: The West European rocket company Arianespace S.A. announced plans today to launch satellites for the United States satellite maker Space Systems/Loral Inc., as well as a simultaneous launching for Israel and Indonesia.

title: Whitewater Counsel Should Step Aside
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;TBC TO BUY OUTSTANDING SHARES OF BIG O TIRES
description: The TBC Corporation said yesterday that it had a definitive agreement to acquire all outstanding shares of Big O Tires Inc. for $16.50 a share, or about $56 million. The companies first said they were negotiating a merger in February. The price could be reduced based on the deal's cost and other expenses, the companies said. Big O Tires, based in Englewood, Colo., has approximately 3.3 million shares outstanding, 1995 sales of $142.1 million and net income of $1.5 million. TBC, a Memphis marketer and distributor of automotive products, reported 1995 sales of $536.1 million and net income of $15.2 million.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Misfortunes at Box Office Result in a Loss by Turner
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. said today that it lost nearly $10 million in the first quarter, mostly because of disappointing results at its Castle Rock Entertainment film division.

title: Can Nashville Say No to N.F.L. Team? Maybe
description: For nearly a decade now, the status-hungry boomtowns of the South have sought instant membership in the major leagues through the relentless recruitment of professional sports teams. And in city after city, local governments have raided their treasuries to build expensive new stadiums, with barely a peep of protest from the taxpayers.

title: Political Briefs;CAMPAIGNS AND ISSUES
description: North Carolina First Amendment Vs. Ten Good Rules

title: Market Place: Lowering the Bar For Corporate Earnings;Does Wall St. Forecast Performance or Set the Pace?
description: It all depends on what you expect. If a child comes home from school with nothing but C's on a report card, parental reaction may be outrage and anger. But if the preliminary indications had been for D's and F's, the reaction may be one of relief and even congratulations.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: AUTO RACING;Craven Set to Return to Nascar
description: RICKY CRAVEN, one of two drivers hurt in separate wrecks last Sunday during the Winston Select 500 at Talladega Superspeedway in Alabama, was released from the hospital on Tuesday and will start the next scheduled race, on Sunday in Sonoma, Calif.

title: ECONOMY REVIVED AT PACE OF 2.8% IN FIRST QUARTER
description: The economy sprang back to life in the first quarter of the year, the Commerce Department said today, growing at an annual rate of 2.8 percent after practically coming to a halt at the end of 1995. The Clinton Administration quickly took credit for reviving an economic expansion that once seemed about to expire.

title: Would Mrs. Onassis Have Been Chagrined?
description: To the Editor:

title: Expert Panel Calls Evidence From DNA Fully Reliable
description: Because of recent advances in knowledge and technology, there is no longer reason to question the courtroom reliability of properly analyzed DNA evidence, a committee of the National Academy of Sciences said today.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Bring In da Birds

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Phillies Get Phillips From San Francisco
description: The Philadelphia Phillies acquired first baseman J. R. PHILLIPS from the San Francisco Giants yesterday for a player to be named later and cash. Phillips, 26, a slugger in the minor leagues, has been a mediocre major league hitter. This season, he was hitting .200 in 15 games with 2 home runs. (AP)

title: A More Varied Diet for a Cab-Hungry City
description: Two vehicle models were approved yesterday for use as New York City taxis, prompting a prediction that in a few years the cabs cruising the streets will look a lot different, except for the color.

title: PRESIDENT VETOES LIMITS ON LIABILITY
description: In a move likely to reverberate throughout the election campaign, President Clinton today vetoed a bill that would restrict the amount that people injured by faulty products could win in lawsuits.

title: Accountant Is Indicted on Fraud Charges
description: A certified public accountant was indicted on fraud charges this week and accused of fraudulently persuading five banks to lend $38 million to three of his clients.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Merck Buys Seven Seas From Hanson of Britain
description: The drug and chemical company Merck bought the Seven Seas Ltd. vitamin and minerals business yesterday from Hanson P.L.C. for around 340 million marks ($222 million). Merck said the purchase helped strengthen its position significantly in the British self-medication market and "thereby closes its last real hole in Europe."

title: Paris Journal;At Dinner Table, More Than Beef Falls From Grace
description: Mad cow disease may be changing menus and habits throughout Europe, but in France, beef is not the only thing that is disappearing from the table.

title: Giuliani Shows Caution On New Health Plan
description: A mayoral panel's recommendation that medical care for the indigent be paid by a surcharge on hospital fees and insurance premiums drew a cautious response from Mayor Giuliani, who called the proposal a "beginning" to solving the problem of health care for the uninsured.

title: Mayor Keeps His Distance From New Insurance Plan
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani distanced himself yesterday from a report by an advisory board he appointed, which proposed that the city levy a surcharge on hospital fees and insurance premiums to subsidize health insurance for those without it.

title: Senate Sends AIDS Care Compromise to President
description: The Senate gave final Congressional approval today to a compromise bill that would extend Federal AIDS assistance for five years and would seek to increase voluntary testing of pregnant women for H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PAINE WEBBER IS FINED FOR RAIDING PRUDENTIAL
description: Paine Webber Group Inc. has been ordered to pay a rival, Prudential Securities Inc., a unit of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, a record $2.5 million for raiding a Prudential brokerage branch office in Gainesville, Fla. A New York Stock Exchange arbitration panel imposed the fine last week because Paine Webber had hired almost all of Prudential's Gainesville brokers and sales assistants in 1993, The Wall Street Journal reported yesterday. The arbitrators told Paine Webber to pay Prudential $1 million in compensatory damages and $1.5 million in punitive damages. It was the largest punitive award in a raiding case since at least 1991, the earliest date for which the exchange keeps records.

title: BASEBALL;Mets Hope Isringhausen's Gem Is a Sign of Dazzlers to Come
description: April was not very kind to Jason Isringhausen. The young right-hander entered the second game of Wednesday night's doubleheader against the Montreal Expos with a 1-2 record and a 4.85 earned run average.

title: Chairman Leaving RJR, Tumult Intact
description: The RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation said yesterday that Charles Harper was retiring as chairman after leading the cigarette and food company through three turbulent years.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Warily, Distillers Chip at Commercial Ban
description: American marketers of distilled spirits are taking tentative steps into advertising on television and radio, despite a decades-long voluntary ban on such sales pitches and the bitter opposition of anti-alcohol groups.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Nestle Predicts 1996 Will Be a Good Year
description: Nestle S.A., the world's largest food maker, said yesterday that it expected "good profit growth" in 1996 as sales improve and the Swiss franc weakens after a year in which the currency's strength kept the brakes on earnings. Nestle also said that its sales had increased 4 percent in the first quarter. Nestle's chairman, Helmut Maucher, said he expected profit growth beyond 1996.

title: Would Mrs. Onassis Have Been Chagrined?
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL;Game at Kingdome Suspended by Quake
description: An earthquake rattled the Kingdome during tonight's baseball game between the Cleveland Indians and Seattle Mariners, causing umpires to suspend the contest in the seventh inning.

title: NYC;Changing The Face Of TV News
description: IF it bleeds, it leads. For those unfamiliar with this old TV maxim, it means that a juicy bit of violence -- accompanied, naturally, by gut-wrenching footage -- is a sure-fire candidate to top the late-evening news show.

title: Mortgage Rates Creep Up
description: Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 7.99 percent this week, up from 7.92 percent last week, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said today. The rate was the highest since April 11, when rates averaged 8.05 percent. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 5.76 percent, up from 5.74 percent last week.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DELTA SAYS PILOTS' PACT WILL SAVE IT $760 MILLION
description: Delta Air Lines Inc. said yesterday that a new collective bargaining agreement with its pilots' union would save the company about $760 million in the next four years. Delta said the new agreement, which took effect on Wednesday, would save it about $100 million in the 1997 fiscal year, which ends in June 1997; about $200 million in the 1998 fiscal year and $230 million in each of the next two years. The Atlanta-based carrier said the projected savings did not include payments under the pilots' new profit-sharing program. The four-year contract was ratified by the Air Line Pilots Association last week.

title: Board Hears Asylum Appeal in Genital-Mutilation Case
description: Fauziya Kasinga, who says she fled Togo to escape genital mutilation, sat quietly today in a red leather armchair in a small courtroom as 12 men and women on the highest administrative tribunal in the nation's immigration system considered whether to give her asylum in the United States or send her home.

title: Cocaine Web Broken Up, and Mexican Link Is Detailed
description: Concealed inside the trunks, wheel wells and other crannies of hundreds of nondescript trucks and cars, the cocaine from Colombia rolls across the Mexican border and into Los Angeles, where it is repackaged for distribution to other illegal drug markets around the country.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Knicks Have Been There and They Believe
description: They're underdogs, not upstarts; playoff veterans as opposed to post-season neophytes. The Knicks can be overmatched on paper and in the casino sports parlors, but they do possess a few things that may help them in their Eastern Conference semifinal matchup against the team with the most regular-season victories in National Basketball Association history.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;AST Research Loss Increased In First Quarter
description: AST Research Inc. said today that its net loss widened sharply in the first quarter, hurt by slower sales, lower prices and excess inventory, and that it planned a restructuring.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Carrington 1995. Polygram. $96.99. 120 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Tuesday.

title: Chairman of Gaming Policy Board Resigns
description: Francis J. Muska, the chairman of the State Gaming Policy Board, resigned today after a newspaper report questioned his relationship with the owner of a Bridgeport dog track.

title: Upbeat Data On Economy Hurt Markets
description: Already in a jumpy mood, investors sent stock and bond prices tumbling yesterday after they were spooked by another report that showed the economy is stronger than was expected earlier this year.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Of an Erotic Freak Show And the Lesson Therein
description: There's no denying that it's an exotic world to which the title character in Suzan-Lori Parks's "Venus," which opened last night at the Joseph Papp Public Theater, has been transported. The program defines the setting as 19th-century England and France, but the unmistakable landmarks indicate another place altogether.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Honors
