description: * Jim McCann, founder and president of 1-800-FLOWERS, New York, was named the DMDNY Direct Marketer of the Year at the 31st annual DMDNY Marketing Conference, formerly known as Direct Marketing Day in New York. Also, Jonah Gitlitz, president and chief executive of the Direct Marketing Association, was awarded the Lifetime Achievement Award. * Advertising New York, the annual benefit event sponsored by the Advertising Club of New York, Advertising Women of New York and the American Advertising Federation, named three recipients of its first Good Egg Awards to honor corporate citizenship. They are: the Bozell Worldwide unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt; the Chase Manhattan Bank unit of the Chase Manhattan Corp., and The New York Times. Also, the John A. Riesenbach Foundation will receive a special award for its charitable work. The awards will be presented at the 1996 event, which is scheduled for June 19 in Rockefeller Center.

title: Herbert Brownell Jr., Eisenhower Attorney General, Dies at 92
description: Herbert Brownell Jr., who as President Dwight D. Eisenhower's first Attorney General speeded desegregation by encouraging the President to name judges who vigorously carried out the Supreme Court's school integration decisions in the South, died on Wednesday in his home in Manhattan. He was 92..

title: Soccer in Sarajevo: More Than a Game
description: There was no time to practice -- the field had just been cleared of land mines -- but the thousands of soccer fans who packed into a stadium here did not care that the teams were a little rusty.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Bonds Plunge On Signs of Strong Growth
description: Data indicating a strong economic expansion sent Treasury prices tumbling yesterday, pushing interest rates to their highest level in a year.

title: Gift Ban Isn't Absolute, Senate's Ethics Panel Decides
description: In the fully catered world of the United States Senate, there has recently been growing concern that a newly enacted ban on gifts might interfere with the full enjoyment of this summer's political conventions.

title: INSIDE
description: Muslims Held in War Crimes

title: Art in Review
description: William Tucker McKee Gallery 745 Fifth Avenue, near 57th Street Manhattan Through May 31

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO BASKETBALL;Nets' Edwards Has Knee Surgery
description: KEVIN EDWARDS, the Nets' shooting guard who missed 48 games this season because of injury, has undergone surgery on his right knee in Cleveland. A statement released by the Nets yesterday said that the 30-year-old Edwards, who averaged 11.6 points in 34 games this season, had tendinitis scar tissue and calcification removed from the quadricep tendon above the knee cap. Edwards will need 10-12 weeks to recover but is expected to be ready for training camp in October.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Westinghouse Deficit Wider; CBS Acquisition Cost Cited
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation today reported a wider first-quarter loss, excluding gains and charges, mainly as a result of costs related to its $5.4 billion acquisition of CBS Inc.

title: BALLET REVIEW;'Don Quixote' and Bocca
description: There are ballet performances in which the level of dancing is almost beside the point. That was the case on Tuesday night, when American Ballet Theater presented "Don Quixote" at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: FILM REVIEW;Death Row Diva: A Raw Sharon Stone
description: IT isn't easy to make grand entrances into and exits from a tiny jail house visiting room, but Sharon Stone finds a way. In Bruce Beresford's "Last Dance," she brings impossible sparkle to what is (literally) a dead-end role and proves yet again that in an otherwise floundering film, she can be a lifesaver. Fully transformed from Hollywood cupcake to tough cookie, Ms. Stone has more than proven how persuasively she can act, especially in such bitterly hard-edged roles. But the Death Row drama "Last Dance" proves a futile exercise in more ways than one.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Political Pact With Ex-Film Star May Bring Down India's Premier
description: Since Indira Gandhi was assassinated more than a decade ago, no woman has had a deeper impact on the political consciousness of India than a former movie actress, Jayalalitha Jayaram, who leapt in the early 1990's from a past playing a courtesan in a score of low-budget films to heading the government of a state with 60 million people.

title: Ailing Lindsay Is Given Posts To Get City Health Insurance
description: Former Mayor John V. Lindsay, in declining health, has been appointed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to two city posts to make him eligible for municipal health insurance coverage and eventually, perhaps, to qualify him for a pension.

title: ART REVIEW;Louise Bourgeois on Paper: Unposed, Unmystical
description: The French-born sculptor Louise Bourgeois, now 84, tends to be self-deprecating when talking about her half-century output of works on paper. Drawing, she has said, doesn't have "the power of exorcism" that sculpture offers.

title: Key Ally Gone, Liberia Leader Vows to Fight
description: The leader of Liberia's largest militia, Charles Taylor, vowed in a radio address today to fight "block by block, street by street, house by house" to rid Monrovia, the capital, of his principal rivals.

title: In France: More Piano, Less Forte
description: The French Parliament gave final approval today to a measure limiting the volume on personal stereo players after warning that loud music was creating a generation of deaf people.

title: Seen From Jet, 3 in Ocean Are Rescued
description: Three Maine fishermen clinging to a life raft in the Atlantic were rescued by a Coast Guard helicopter today after their burning boat was spotted by a British Airways jetliner on its way to New York, Coast Guard officials said.

title: David Kennedy, Ex-Treasury Chief, Dies at 90
description: David M. Kennedy, who was Secretary of the Treasury in the first two years of the Nixon Administration, died Wednesday at his home in Salt Lake City. He was 90, and had long suffered from a heart ailment.

title: The Evolution of Mr. Arafat
description: The transformation of Yasir Arafat from sponsor of terrorism to proponent of peace still seems implausible. But there he was on Wednesday, welcomed warmly to the White House by President Clinton for the kind of Oval Office tete-a-tete reserved for Washington's most honored guests. Earlier, Israel's Labor Party dropped its longstanding opposition to a Palestinian state from its election platform. Next Sunday, Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization will open formal talks on the status of Jerusalem and the future of Jewish settlements in the West Bank.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: AMNEX INC., New York, a provider of long-distance services, agreed to buy Capital Network Systems of Austin, Tex., which also provides long-distance service, for about $15 million.

title: Pit Bull Injures 4 in Bronx
description: A pit bull bit and scratched three children and a woman yesterday at a Bronx housing project, then fled into a wooded park nearby, eluding a search that continued into last night, the authorities said.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FOOD LION ANNOUNCES A $100 MILLION STOCK BUYBACK
description: The supermarket chain Food Lion Inc. said yesterday that it planned to buy back $100 million more of its stock. Food Lion, based in Salisbury, N.C., said it had already repurchased about $80.4 million of stock under an earlier plan, which was authorized in 1995. The company said that as of Wednesday, it had repurchased 8.5 million of its class A shares and 4.9 million of its class B shares under the previous program. Food Lion said it has about 470.3 million shares outstanding. Food Lion's class A shares rose 6.25 cents, to $7.50, in Nasdaq trading. The class B shares were unchanged at $7.3125.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-10

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Prices for Wheat Move Lower With End of Drought in Kansas
description: Wheat plunged yesterday as speculation revived that rain last weekend in Kansas had halted the drought damage that sent prices to record highs this year.

title: In a Sign of Changing Times, Shanghai Shelters Battered Women
description: In a country where family problems have traditionally remained behind closed doors, wife-beating has often been endured without relief or outside interference.

title: The Day Is Too Short for Genius, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: CYCARE STOCK JUMPS ON SPECULATION ABOUT SALE
description: The shares of Cycare Systems Inc. rose 9.5 percent yesterday after the company said several companies had approached it with buyout or merger proposals. Cycare, a provider of information processing services and systems to the health care industry, based in Scottsdale, Ariz., did not disclose the names of the companies that had approached it and declined to comment further. Cycare shares rose $4.625, to $44. Miles Russ, an analyst at Wheat First Butcher Singer, said the logical candidate to purchase Cycare would be a hospital company developing an integrated delivery network system.

title: Fordham Helped Apprehend Student's Attacker
description: To the Editor:

title: Art in Review
description: David Baker Postmasters Gallery 76 Greene Street SoHo Through May 18

title: A Shrink-Wrapped Woman of Action
description: Barb Wire" stars Pamela Anderson Lee, the well-known pinup and conversation piece, in a story about a pair of artificial body parts. They are, of course, contact lenses, and they are of vital strategic importance in the futuristic American police state that "Barb Wire" describes.

title: No Headline
description: I still do not understand how I could have hurt so many people. I've spent nights and days trying to think really why I did it."

title: Whitewater Counsel Should Step Aside
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Minnesota Mining Posts a Drop In Quarter's Net Income of 3.7%
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, which is shedding a variety of businesses, said today that net income fell 3.7 percent in the first quarter but that profit from the operations it was retaining rose about 2 percent.

title: David Opatoshu, 78, an Actor Best Known for an 'Exodus' Role
description: David Opatoshu, a versatile character actor best known for his role as Akiva, a scholarly Jewish resistance leader in the 1960 film "Exodus," died on Tuesday at his home in Los Angeles after a long illness. He was 78.

title: Art in Review
description: Arthur Tress 'Along the Edge: The Urban Years, 1968-1972' Houk Friedman Gallery 851 Madison Avenue, at 70th Street Manhattan Through May 11

title: For Children
description: 'Deuces Are Wild' 'Hip-Hop Wonderland' New Victory Theater 209 West 42d Street Manhatta (212) 239-6200

title: American Express Urges Banks to Offer Its Cards
description: In an effort to expand its credit and charge-card operations, the American Express Company announced yesterday that it would actively court banks to issue its cards.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Wireless Account To Richards Group
description: North American Wireless, a wireless telecommunications company in Vienna, Va., has named the Richards Group in Dallas as the first agency to handle its account. The billings were estimated at more than $30 million. David C. Haviland, marketing director at North American Wireless, said the decision came after a four-month review that had been narrowed to Richards and two other finalists: N. W. Ayer & Partners in New York, a unit of Adcom Investors Inc., and Keroff & Rosenberg in Chicago.

title: Transit Chiefs Fault Riders In Shutdown
description: Stung by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's accusation that they had mishandled the shutdown of the Lexington Avenue subway line on Wednesday, transit officials said yesterday that the disruption had been prolonged by passengers who left stalled trains and walked down the tracks to reach exits.

title: Carl's Jr. Gains Stake in Rally's
description: A pair of battling hamburger barons have agreed to a truce that will give executives of Carl's Jr. a management stake in the Rally's chain.

title: Art in Review
description: Thomas Roma 'Come Sunday' Museum of Modern Art 11 West 53d Street Manhattan Through June 18

title: Sports of The Times;Bad Draw A Sad Song For the Derby
description: THESE people are so declaratively happy, so purposefully composed, one might think the oddsmakers had not only made them the favorite but that the historical odds are also in their favor. "He's the best horse, no matter where he is," said Unbridled's Song's owner, Ernie Paragallo. "He'll get out fast. Game over."

title: FILM REVIEW;Love Is Blind as Ever, But the Music Is Nice
description: If you stripped "Madame Butterfly" of its ravishingly beautiful Puccini score, you would be left with the nasty late-19th-century story of a selfish American naval lieutenant who marries a Japanese child bride knowing full well he will never see her again once he leaves Japan. His credulous young wife is so blindingly smitten that she gives up her religious faith for him and is disowned by her family. Even after threeyears of not hearing from Lieutenant Pinkerton, Cio-Cio-San deludes herself into believing he will return and rashly rebuffs a solid marriage proposal to cling to this fantasy.

title: At the Pumps, High-Octane Pain
description: Pulling his thirsty rig into the truck stop, Dave Morisset longed for the good old days of cheaper fuel -- about six weeks ago.

title: Political Poison at the Grass Roots
description: I know it is spring, not because of the burst of daffodils, the lengthening twilight or even the lime-green glow around the trees. I know it is spring because it is the season of the annual town meeting. The people here (pop. 9,000) gather to debate and approve the yearly budget.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Irish's Krug to Quit
description: Notre Dame quarterback TOM KRUG has to quit football because of a potentially dangerous neck condition, the university said yesterday. Krug's condition was discovered after he sprained his neck during a scrimmage on April 20.

title: Agency Files Detailing Family Traumas Found Discarded
description: Two case files listing the names, Social Security numbers and explicit problems of children who had been under the supervision of the city were found discarded on the grounds of a city welfare office this week, exposing the lives of troubled families to plain view and possibly violating state laws on maintaining and disposing of confidential records.

title: Tories Lose Local Elections, But Major Sees a Comeback
description: Somehow defiant, even after his party's second-worst local election defeat in recent history, Prime Minister John Major promised today that his Conservative Government would fight for "the heart and soul and future of this country" and go on to win the next general election.

title: Sunday in the Park With George, Rover and Spot;Leash the Owners
description: To the Editor:

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;Red Wings Grab Series Lead
description: St. Louis showed all the grit and determination Detroit expected. So the Red Wings relied on patience and a confidence born of winning to shoot down the Blues.

description: Oboist Ranges in Recital From Melodic to Microtonal Diana Doherty, oboist 92d Street Y

title: Sunday in the Park With George, Rover and Spot;They Also Served
description: To the Editor:

title: HORSE RACING;Early Upset In Kentucky
description: The California filly Pike Place Dancer scored a 9-1 upset in the $500,000 Kentucky Oaks today, as the 7-10 favorite My Flag finished fifth before a record Oaks day crowd of 91,830 at Churchill Downs. The track's attendance record was 163,628 for the 100th Kentucky Derby in 1974.

title: Subway Shutdown Results in New Position
description: Responding to the assertion that it took too long for top transit officials to react to the shutdown of the Lexington Avenue subway line on Wednesday, the Transit Authority announced that it would create a high-level post to oversee emergencies around the clock. Mayor Giuliani has complained that while senior police and fire officials reached the 51st Street station soon after electrical problems brought three lines to a standstill, high-ranking transit officials did not arrive for more than an hour.

title: In Performance;DANCE
description: New Dancers Take Over Leading Roles in 'Quixote' American Ballet Theater Metropolitan Opera House

title: GOLF;Skinner Is Still Under Par and in the Lead
description: Val Skinner, one of women's golf's strongest and most aggressive players, overpowered the L.P.G.A. International layout once again today, muscling her way to her second straight round of 67 and taking a one-stroke lead in the Sprint Titleholders over Catrin Nilsmark, who shot a 66. The Australian rookie Karrie Webb leapt into contention with a course-record-tying 65 that left her two strokes behind.

title: B+ if You Remember to Smile;Learning From the Conviction of Stew Leonard
description: The star pupil distinguished himself not by handing in a brilliant term paper, but by handing over a dirty coffee cup he had found on the floor. The university's guest lecturer was so impressed that he ended a midmorning seminar by giving the other students a little talk, loaded with superlatives, about how much their classmate had learned. And then, right there in front of everybody, he offered him a job.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Merger to Create 2d-Largest Insurer in Britain
description: Royal Insurance Holdings and Sun Alliance Group said today that they planned to merge, forming Britain's second-largest publicly traded insurer, with combined assets of L55 billion ($82 billion).

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;Mason Accepts Jordan Assignment as Mission: Possible
description: His defensive assignments this year alone have ranged from such awesome forces in the pivot as Hakeem Olajuwon and Shaquille O'Neal to a litany of spry young guns that includes Glenn Robinson and Grant Hill.

title: Senators Parry on Gasoline Tax and Wages
description: Freed of all legislative burdens until Tuesday, the Senate today devoted the first day of its four-day weekend to politics -- and history.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Delays Near Lincoln Tunnel
description: Starting last night, getting to the Lincoln Tunnel took a little longer for drivers using Route 495, as the state Department of Transportation began major repairs on a mile-long stretch near Routes 1 and 9. Motorists can expect weekend and weeknight delays for two weeks.

title: Angel Wallenda, 28, a Flier Despite a Life of Obstacles
description: Angel Wallenda, who defied cancer by walking the high wire on an artificial limb after her right leg was amputated just below the knee, died yesterday at Robert Packer Hospital in Sayre, Pa. Ms. Wallenda was 28, and lived in Mansfield, Pa., about 25 miles southwest of Elmira, N.Y.

title: Sunday in the Park With George, Rover and Spot;Last Time He Saw Paris
description: To the Editor:

title: Look Who's Minding the Shop;California Garment Makers Try to Police Workplace
description: In the latest crackdown on sweatshops in the nation's largest garment center, investigators working in teams of two stand watch outside sewing factories, noting the number of employees and their arrival times.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: SOCCER;Donadoni Will Play, But Meola May Not
description: The MetroStars, still searching for their first Major League Soccer victory, will have Roberto Donadoni to run their midfield for tonight's game against the Tampa Bay Mutiny. But they may have lost goalkeeper Tony Meola for another week.

title: Israelis Deliberately Shelled Post, U.N. Says
description: Hezbollah guerrillas took refuge in a United Nations camp at Qana, Lebanon, last month and Israeli troops deliberately shelled the base, according to a initial United Nations findings on the incident, diplomats said today. The report, which is not yet completed, is expected to be presented to the Security Council on Tuesday.

title: Connecticut Tribe to Invest Casino Profits in a Boatyard
description: The old-salt maritime culture of New London, Conn., has appeared headed for the history books in recent years. The whaling fleets are faded memories, the submarine bays mere shadows of their cold war height.

title: In Performance;JAZZ
description: Urbanity and Sophistication In an Evening of Standards Hank Jones, pianist Iridium

title: National Semiconductor Settles On a New Chief
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation said today that it had named Brian L. Halla chairman, chief executive and president, succeeding Gilbert F. Amelio, who left in February to head Apple Computer Inc.

title: A Top Dissident Flees China And Is Admitted to the U.S.
description: A dissident who ranked third on the Chinese Government's list of "most wanted" student protesters after the 1989 Tiananmen Square demonstrations has been admitted to the United States after fleeing China, the White House confirmed today.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Greene Joining Panthers
description: Linebacker KEVIN GREENE, a mainstay on the defense of the American Football Conference champion Pittsburgh Steelers, agreed yesterday to a two-year deal with the Carolina Panthers.

title: Company Briefs
description: MAIN STREET BANKGROUP INC., Martinsville, Va., a bank holding company, agreed to acquire Hanover Bank, of Mechanicsville, Va., for $24.6 million. Main Street will pay Hanover's stockholders $15.25 for each share held.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;False-Arrest Suit Ends
description: Steven Simonson, a Bordentown chef who said he was falsely charged and imprisoned in a 1993 child-molesting case because he is gay, has settled a Federal lawsuit against Woodbridge Township, Middlesex County, and Middlesex County Prosecutor Robert W. Gluck. Mr. Simonson, arrested and jailed after a boy identified him in a lineup as the man who had sexually assaulted him in Woodbridge, had produced 11 witnesses who swore he was working at a restaurant when the incident occurred. Unable to post bail, however, he spent six months in the county jail before the indictment against him was dismissed when D.N.A. tests implicated another man. In signing the settlement Wednesday, a Federal District Court judge limited the damages to $10,000, The A.P. said yesterday. JOE SHARKEY

title: COMPANY NEWS;WELLCARE STOCK RETREATS AFTER DELISTING REPORT
description: The shares of Wellcare Management Group Inc. fell 28 percent yesterday after the company said the Nasdaq stock market planned to delist Wellcare's common stock. The managed health care company said the delisting planned for May 13 had been delayed pending a May 17 review of the decision. Shares of the company, a health maintenance organization in Kingston, N.Y., were down $3.75 at $9.25. The company's shares have fallen from $23.75 on March 15, when Barron's published an article contending that accounting irregularities in Wellcare's payments to doctors and hospitals might have inflated the company's profits. The company said that the notice of delisting was issued because of its failure to release 1995 results by May 1.

title: PAYROLL GROWTH WAS FLAT IN APRIL
description: A day after the Government reported unexpectedly sharp growth in the economy in the first quarter, the Labor Department said today that the job market during April was lackluster. But the signs of more modest growth failed to dissipate the fears of a rise in inflation that rattled the financial markets on Thursday.

title: Of Hispanic Literature and Not So Equal Opportunities
description: For the talented young writers who have benefited from a growing hunger for Hispanic literature, this is an unlikely time to raise questions about the nagging little secret of New York's literary industrial complex: unequal opportunity.

title: Tim Gullikson, 44, Tennis Coach and Player
description: Tim Gullikson, the effervescent tennis coach who helped transform Pete Sampras from an introverted prodigy to a genuine candidate to become one of the greatest champions to play the sport, died yesterday. He was 44.

title: Peres Hints Israel Will Delay A Full Pullout From Hebron
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres announced today that he intended to "coordinate" a limited Israeli withdrawal from Hebron with the Palestinian Authority, but set no firm date for pulling out of the last West Bank city to remain under Israeli occupation.

title: Sunday in the Park With George, Rover and Spot;Jewel, Not Battlefield
description: To the Editor:

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Taylor Arrested in Sting
description: Lawrence Taylor was arrested tonight when he tried to buy $100 worth of crack cocaine from undercover agents, the police said.

title: Unity Is Paramount for G.O.P. Group in Ohio County, a Chooser ofPresidents
description: Until a few weeks ago, Tom Vignos assumed that he would be elected to another term as vice chairman of the North Canton Republican Committee.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Federal Bribery Admitted
description: Christine Day admitted in Federal District Court court yesterday that she and her husband, Roger, bribed officials to get $400,000 in Federal contracts, The Associated Press said. Three months ago, Mrs. Day admitted in state court that she and her husband had bribed Newark officials to process $500,000 worth of phony bills. Prosecutors said she has agreed to testify against her husband.

title: World News Briefs;Militia Leader Leaves Liberia Under Siege
description: The leader of a powerful militia was airlifted out of Monrovia today to attend peace talks next week in Ghana aimed at ending Liberia's six-year civil war, diplomatic and military officials said.

title: COMPANY NEWS;JOINT VENTURE FOR MALAYSIAN PETROCHEMICAL COMPLEX
description: The Union Carbide Corporation of Danbury, Conn., and Petronas, Malaysia's state-owned oil company, said yesterday that they would form a joint venture to build a Malaysian petrochemical complex to supply Southeast Asia, the world's fastest-growing market for petrochemicals. The companies did not say how much the project would cost. The joint venture is expected to be held equally by the two partners. The partners plan to build an ethylene and propylene plant that will make 600,000 metric tons a year. A second plant will be built to make at least 500,000 metric tons a year of ethylene glycol, an ingredient used in polyester fibers and automotive antifreeze.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Long-Delayed Power Plant Gets Go-Ahead in Mexico
description: The Government announced today that it had resolved financing and other difficulties that for four years have delayed construction of a $647 million electric power generating plant near the northern industrial city of Ciudad Juarez.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Abbey National to Buy Unit of United News
description: Abbey National P.L.C. said yesterday that its consumer finance unit had agreed to buy the Wagon Finance Group from the British publisher United News and Media P.L.C. for L108 million, or $162 million. Wagon Finance is an automobile finance company with about 5 percent of Britain's used-car finance market, Abbey National said. The company is being bought by Abbey's First National Bank unit. Abbey National is a British clearing bank and the country's second-largest mortgage lender. (Dow Jones)

title: Journal;Over the Cuckoo's Nest
description: My first impressions of mental illness were probably the same as most other children of my generation. It was something shameful, forbidden, never to be discussed. Home alone on a Sunday afternoon some 30-odd years ago, I answered the phone to discover that a relative I hadn't met was calling collect. I had been instructed never to accept collect calls, and as I turned this caller away, she screamed over the operator's voice: "They're killing everyone in Baltimore!" Then the phone went dead, and only years later, as this woman neared death, would my parents put her illness and her subsequent, similarly terrifying calls into the comprehensible perspective of a diagnosed sickness with a treatment -- and, today, possibly a cure.

title: Sunday in the Park With George, Rover and Spot;Unequal Enforcement
description: To the Editor:

title: 8-Year-Old Boy Testifies in His Mother's Murder Trial
description: Clutching his little "Star Trek" figure, Rahman Bryant took the witness stand yesterday to testify in the murder trial of his mother, whom he had not seen in two years. The 8-year-old in a green sport coat at least two sizes too big waved at his mother, Sherain Bryant, wiggling each finger of his right hand separately. She waved back the same way.

title: Gas Deal by Snyder Oil
description: The Snyder Oil Corporation has an agreement to sell a 45 percent stake in its Piceance gas development project to Destec Energy Inc. for $22 million. Snyder, a Fort Worth-based oil and gas concern, will continue to operate the project, which is in western Colorado.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Brown Is Giants' Passer For Rest of the Century
description: It was a simple case of two sides needing one another. Dave Brown, a loyal soldier declaring his allegiance to queen and country, said from the beginning that he wanted to stay a Giant. The Giants wanted to watch their New Jersey home boy grow old in a blue uniform, so they never flirted with bringing in another quarterback.

title: Prosecution Rests in the Trial Of the Clintons' Ex-Partners
description: The prosecution rested its case today in the trial of Gov. Jim Guy Tucker and President Clinton's former Whitewater partners after presenting testimony that money from an allegedly fraudulent loan went to benefit the Whitewater development.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Jobless Rate Eased in April, Despite Steady Payrolls The Government reported that the job market was lackluster in April, a day after reporting unexpectedly sharp growth in the economy in the first quarter. But even signs of modest growth failed to dissipate the inflation fears that rattled the financial markets on Thursday. The nation's unemployment rate eased to 5.4 percent in April from 5.6 percent in March and was at the lowest level in 14 months, even though there was no growth in business payrolls.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Ocean Dumping Hearing Set
description: Members of the state's Surfers Environmental Alliance are planning to show up in force at a public hearing on new ocean dumping proposals scheduled by the Environmental Protection Agency for Monday night at the Monmouth Beach borough hall. They are opposing an E.P.A. proposal to expand a large ocean disposal site known as the Mud Dump, five miles off Sandy Hook, where contaminated dredging sediments from New York harbor are buried.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by Reuters in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about a unit of the Comsat International Communications division of the Comsat Corporation misstated the action taken. Comsat International Communications is creating a new business unit to deliver personal communications services by satellite; it is not spinning off the unit.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;After 5 Years of Family Fractiousness, 'Sisters' Exits Elegantly
description: With enough resolved crises under its belt to make a daytime soap envious, "Sisters" comes to a close in a special two-hour episode tonight. The NBC series had its premiere in the spring of 1991 and, the network says, has steadily maintained a loyal audience, especially among women in the important demographic category of ages 18 to 49. Never a blockbuster hit, "Sisters" managed to hold its own nicely, despite the frequent liability of weak lead-in shows.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: In Performance;POP
description: Dreamscapes and Old Loves, In a Voice That's a Groan Joe Henry Mercury Lounge

title: Mayor Unveils Reduced Capital Budget
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced a capital plan yesterday that would cut spending by $1 billion even after accounting for revenues and savings that would require a reversal of a judge's ruling and an unlikely change in a state law.

title: Scrapping the School Elections
description: On Tuesday, New York City holds elections for its 32 community school boards. History suggests that voter turnout will be abysmal, that incumbents in many districts with long records of academic or administrative failure will be re-elected anyway, and that the parents of public school students will wind up with less representation than local politicians with an eye for patronage.

title: Sharp Gasoline Price Rise in New York City
description: Motorists in New York City are getting no relief from the recent surge in gasoline prices. The average price for regular has gone up 5 percent, to $1.43 a gallon from $1.36, since April 25, according to the latest survey by the city's Consumer Affairs Department.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Pearson Says Mindscape Will Have Loss in 1996
description: Pearson P.L.C. of Britain said yesterday that its Mindscape unit would lose L46 million ($69 million) in 1996, most of it in the first half. The announcement follows a larger-than-expected L6.9 million loss in 1995 at Mindscape, a software business in Novato, Calif. "The losses at Mindscape will inevitably cast a shadow over the first-half-year's performance," Lord Blakenham, Pearson's chairman, warned in a statement before the annual shareholder meeting.

title: Temple Assistant Coach Dies
description: Jim Maloney, a Temple assistant basketball coach, had a heart attack while driving, crashed into another car and died today.

title: Sunday in the Park With George, Rover and Spot;  Whose Meadow Is It?
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Cemex of Mexico Buys Colombia Cement Maker
description: Cemex S.A. of Mexico said yesterday that it had acquired control of Cementos Diamante S.A. of Colombia and agreed to acquire control of another Colombian concern, Cementos Samper, paying about $600 million. Cemex said the acquisitions would increase its capacity 6.4 percent, to 50 million tons of cement a year, making it the world's third- largest cement maker.

title: Sports of The Times;The Yankees' Blueprint For Success
description: BOB WATSON is not a basketball fan. He is a baseball man. The first-year Yankee general manager bemoans the fact that baseball, the game he loves, is losing so many of its great younger athletes to basketball, a sport offering more glamour these days.

title: The Invisible Supreme Court
description: On April 24, the last oral arguments of the Supreme Court's term were watched by a crowded chamber of citizens, lawyers, guests and reporters. If the American people had seen the proceedings, they would have benefited. But because of the Justices' antagonism to televising the Court's public work, that day seems far off.

title: HORSE RACING;When Derby Dreams Get Stuck in Traffic
description: Unbridled's Song is the best and the fastest among the 19 runners in Saturday's 122d Kentucky Derby, but he will have to run the race of his life to visit the winner's circle at Churchill Downs.

title: Corrections
description: A dance review on Wednesday about a performance of "Don Quixote" by the American Ballet Theater, at the Metropolitan Opera House on Monday, misstated the given name of the dancer in the role of Espada. He is Maxim Belotserkovsky, not Vadim.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;A Robert Shaw Show Without Him
description: It is surely no disrespect to Norman Mackenzie to say that disappointment hung heavy in the air at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine on Thursday evening when it was reported that Robert Shaw had fallen ill and would be unable to conduct.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Casinos Rake in More
description: Mostly because more people are playing slot machines, the city's 12 casinos hit a collective jackpot in April, reporting the highest revenue ever for that month: $315.5 million, despite snow and other bad weather, the Casino Association of New Jersey said yesterday. The boom comes as part of a trend away from table-game gambling to slot machines, which are more profitable for casinos. In April, the casinos had 29,459 slot machines, 2,000 more than a year earlier.

title: Bridge
description: Everyone knows the bidding hog who is determined to play every hand, convinced that his skill is much greater than his partner's. The converse species is rarer, but one held the North cards not long ago in a rubber bridge game in Hawaii.

title: COMPANY NEWS;EQUITABLE OF IOWA AGREES TO BUY GOLDEN AMERICAN LIFE
description: The Equitable of Iowa Companies said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Golden American Life Insurance Company for $144 million, including repayment of $51 million in debt, in a move to bolster its annuity business. Golden American, based in Wilmington, Del., has about $1.3 billion in variable annuities in force. Equitable of Iowa, which had assets of $10 billion as of March 31, owns the Equitable Life Insurance Company of Iowa, USG Annuity and Life Company, Locust Street Securities and Equitable Investment Services. The Des Moines-based insurer said the deal included the acquisition of Golden American's broker-dealer affiliate, Directed Services Inc.

title: Pact on Land Mines Stops Short of Total Ban
description: An international conference agreed today that within the coming decade, the use of land mines should be curtailed and that eventually mines must be made easily detectable or self-deactivating.

title: Corrections
description: The TV Sports column yesterday about Ben Wright, the suspended golf commentator who is receiving treatment for alcoholism, misattributed a quotation -- "CBS should give him a second chance. But not another." The speaker was Janet Segal, executive director of Four Winds Behavioral Health, a treatment center in Katonah, N.Y.; it was not a spokeswoman for CBS.

title: BASEBALL;The Yankees Get a Glimpse of the Old Gooden
description: It was just one at-bat. A man once considered one of baseball's most dominating pitchers was struggling to re-establish himself in the sport. It was a tight spot, and he was challenging one of the most dominating hitters in the game.

title: Returned Fugitive Prevails in His Bid to Have Separate Rape Trials
description: In 1987, a 19-year-old Alex Kelly flew to Europe instead of appearing for trial on charges of raping two teen-age girls, after a judge ordered the cases tried before the same jury. Today, a year after his surrender in Switzerland and return for trial, a different judge ordered that the cases be tried separately.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 26 previewing the art auctions in New York, and an article in some copies on Thursday about sales at Sotheby's, misstated the surname of one seller, the former wife of the financier Ivan Boesky. She is Seema Boesky; Silberstein was her maiden name.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Astra Inquiry On Harassment
description: The Swedish pharmaceutical company Astra has set up a committee to investigate assertions that the suspended chief executive of its United States unit and other officers engaged in widespread sexual harassment and misused corporate funds, the company said today.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Wrongdoing at Cemetery
description: The operators of a Newark cemetery have admitted that they buried some people under sidewalks, packed too many bodies in some grave sites and misappropriated plots that had been paid for -- actions that critics of the death-and-burial industry said yesterday are disturbingly common. [Page 1.]

title: T.A. Plans High-Level Post To Respond to Emergencies
description: Responding to the assertion that it took too long for top transit officials to react to the shutdown of the Lexington Avenue line on Wednesday, the Transit Authority announced yesterday that it would create a new high-level post to oversee emergencies around the clock.

title: World News Briefs;50 Deaths Are Reported In Plane Crash in Sudan
description: A Sudanese airliner on a domestic flight crashed on Friday night in bad weather, killing all 50 people on board, the official news agency reported today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BOSTON SCIENTIFIC PURCHASES MINTEC FOR $70 MILLION
description: The Boston Scientific Corporation said yesterday that it had bought Mintec Inc. for about $70 million, furthering its strategy of making small acquisitions to help it specialize in devices that limit surgery costs. Mintec, a closely held company based in Freeport, the Bahamas, developed a proprietary technology that repairs diseased arteries without major surgery, said Larry Best, a Boston Scientific spokesman. Mr. Best said Mintec, a two-year-old company, was primarily a research-and-development entity whose revenue was insignificant.

title: CHRISTIAN LEADER WOULD BACK SHIFT ON ABORTION ISSUE
description: As Republicans gird for a convention battle over abortion, Ralph Reed, the executive director of the Christian Coalition, said today that he would accept changes in the party's platform and would "reluctantly" accept legislationthat, while banning abortion, would permitexceptions in cases of rape, incest and danger to the mother's life.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Europe Extends Study Of Ciba-Sandoz Merger
description: The European Commission said yesterday that it would extend its investigation into the $36 billion merger of Ciba-Geigy A.G. and Sandoz A.G. The merged company, to be called Novartis A.G., would have annual sales of $22 billion and a market capitalization of about $80 billion.

title: Prosecutor Says He Won't Seek Death Penalty in a '95 Killing
description: In the first case he has considered for capital punishment, the Brooklyn District Attorney announced yesterday that he had decided not to pursue the death penalty against a man accused of killing a woman in Flatbush last year.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-5

title: SUNY: Grand Vision and Pragmatism Collide
description: The vision was a grand one: a state university system to rival California's, offering inexpensive education to students from Buffalo to Long Island and training a skilled work force to attract business to the state.

title: Deal Is Said to Be Near in Suit on Drug Pricing
description: A number of major drug companies accused of overcharging independent pharmacies are ready to promise not to discriminate between the pharmacies and other purchasers like health maintenance organizations, according to court papers made public here today.

title: The Killer Of 3 Strangers Is Executed
description: A 48-year-old man who had said, "I love to kill," after murdering three strangers, was executed here early today.

title: Sunday in the Park With George, Rover and Spot;No Right to Run
description: To the Editor:

title: Many Wonder if Mayor Barry Will Resign
description: With Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. completing his first week out of the city seeking "physical, mental and spiritual rejuvenation," city officials have begun considering the possibility that he might resign.

title: Sunday in the Park With George, Rover and Spot
description: To the Editor:

title: Bill Byers, 69, a Prolific Musical Arranger for Movies and Shows
description: Bill Byers, a trombonist best known for his work as a musical arranger, died at his home in Malibu, Calif., on Wednesday, his 69th birthday.

title: Progress on Police
description: The newly enacted $27.8 billion spending package for the departments of Commerce, Justice and State contains two significant provisions to strengthen law enforcement. The tense negotiations between President Clinton and the Republican Congress had put both provisions at risk.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;The Spurs Eliminate The Suns
description: David Robinson and Vinny Del Negro delivered an inside-outside punch that knocked the Phoenix Suns out of the playoffs.

title: CYCLING;As Armstrong Wins Again, He Seems to Be Unbeatable
description: If anyone doubts that Lance Armstrong is the best rider in the Tour DuPont and getting better, the 24-year-old Texan is sending a message.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TENNECO IN BID FOR ENERGY PLANT IN HUNGARY
description: Tenneco Energy, a subsidiary of Tenneco Inc., said yesterday that it would acquire a stake of 50 percent plus one vote in a 60-megawatt power plant in Dunaujvaros, Hungary, after winning an auction for the stake. The plant will be expanded to at least 140 megawatts and Tenneco's stake will increase to 75 percent ownership, the company said. Tenneco Energy said the arrangement would be worth more than $100 million. Tenneco will buy its stake in the power plant from state-owned Dunaferr Dunai Vasmu Rt., Hungary's biggest steelmaker.

title: COMPANY NEWS;EDIFY STOCK DOUBLES ON FIRST DAY OF TRADING
description: The stock of the Edify Corporation closed yesterday at more than twice its offering price after its first day of trading. The company, a software concern in Santa Clara, Calif., sold 2.5 million shares at $15 each late on Thursday. The stock opened yesterday at $31 on the Nasdaq stock market, rose to $34.50 and finished the day at $33.75. Edify develops software that lets companies provide automated services through the Internet, Web browsers, telephones and electronic mail.

title: In Rare Move, Justices to Review A New Law That Limits Appeals
description: Moving with unusual speed and over the protests of its four most liberal Justices, the Supreme Court agreed today to decide the constitutionality of some of the limits a new Federal law has placed on state prison inmates' access to Federal court.

title: Newark Cemetery Acknowledges Burying People Under Sidewalks
description: The operators of a Newark cemetery have admitted that they interred some people under sidewalks and illegally took over burial plots that had already been paid for -- actions that critics of the burial industry said yesterday are disturbingly common.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS: KNICKS NOTEBOOK;Rodman Will Start, to Bother Mason
description: Dennis Rodman, who had some less-than-flattering things to say about Anthony Mason in his recently released book, "Bad As I Wanna Be," will have an opportunity to let Mason know face-to-face how he feels about him.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Sibelius's 5th And a Finn Unfazed by It
description: On one level, the mercurial Fifth Symphony of Sibelius, written shortly before World War I, is a last gasp of soaring symphonic Romanticism. But most conductors plumb the music for its compositional oddities: fractured phrase structure, spacey scoring, weird harmonies.

title: In Latest Suicide Trial, Kevorkian Asserts 'Duty as a Doctor'
description: Dr. Jack Kevorkian finally took the stand in his latest assisted-suicide trial today, defiantly asserting that it was his "duty as a doctor" to help two women end their suffering by taking their own lives.

title: Sunday in the Park With George, Rover and Spot;Dusk to Dawn, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: D'Amato Says Gingrich Has Hurt the Party
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato said today that House Speaker Newt Gingrich had misread the voters' mandate in the 1994 Congressional elections and had pressed for policies and oratory that were now threatening Bob Dole's Presidential hopes.

title: German War Crime Inquiry
description: A war crimes investigation has been reopened against a former West German Government minister nearly four decades after he was cleared of previous charges.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Viacom Registers Strong Results Despite a 61% Plunge in Profit
description: Viacom Inc. reported a strong performance yesterday for its first quarter, helped in large part by an alliance with the Kirch Group of Germany.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MCLOUTH STEEL TO BE BOUGHT BY HAMLIN HOLDINGS
description: The McLouth Steel Products Corporation, a struggling steelmaker in bankruptcy protection, said yesterday that it had agreed to be purchased by Hamlin Holdings. Terms were not disclosed. Hamlin is an affiliate of Reserve Group of Akron, Ohio, which invests in industrial companies. Hamlin plans to reopen McLouth's operations later this year and plans to modernize the steelmaker's operations. McLouth, which has annual revenue of about $400 million, is currently not making any steel. McLouth, which is employee owned, filed for bankruptcy protection last September after falling steel prices drove costs higher.

title: COMPANY NEWS;READING & BATES SPURNED IN TRANSOCEAN BID
description: The Reading & Bates Corporation of Houston said yesterday that it had made an offer to acquire Transocean A.S., the Norwegian offshore-drilling concern, for $1.51 billion in stock. But Transocean rejected the offer in favor of an offer made a week ago by Sonat Offshore Drilling Inc. for about $1.43 billion. Reading & Bates, a drilling company, said it had offered 1.245 shares of its own stock for each Transocean share. Reading & Bates said it believed its offer was more economically favorable for Transocean's shareholders and a better strategic fit between the two companies. But Transocean said that after talks with both Reading & Bates and Sonat, it had decided that the Sonat deal would be the best solution for the company.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the economy's growth in the first quarter gave an incorrect figure for Thursday's close of the Dow Jones industrial average. It was 5,498.27; the 5,575.22 figure was for Wednesday.

title: China's Transport Gridlock: Cars vs. Mass Transit
description: Until recently, officials of this port city famous for its Tsing Tao beer and its German architecture boasted that they were investing heavily in basic infrastructure as part of their strategy to attract more foreign industries.

title: Sunday in the Park With George, Rover and Spot;For the Avifauna
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL;Green's Bet Backfires, And Wilson Is the Loser
description: In his 40-plus years in baseball and 8 years as a big-league manager, it ranked as one of the easiest decisions Dallas Green has ever had to make. A virtual no-brainer even though it went against the so-called baseball bible that says never put the winning run on base with an intentional walk.

title: Asmara Journal;In Peace, Warrior Women Rank Low
description: Some days Nuria Mohammed Saleh says she actually finds herself missing the war. Not the fear and horror. Not even the adrenaline kick and camaraderie of soldiering. She misses being treated like a man.

title: COMPANY NEWS;IOCHPE-MAXION OF BRAZIL IN DEAL WITH AGCO
description: Iochpe-Maxion S.A., a diversified Brazilian manufacturer, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its farm and industrial machinery division to the Agco Corporation for $260 million. "The sale of our farm machinery division is in line with the company's strategy to focus its interests in the auto parts sector," Ronald Aldworth, investor relations director for Iochpe-Maxion, said. Agco, based in Duluth, Ga., produces tractors, combines and other agricultural machinery under the Massey-Ferguson and other brand names.

title: Detroit's Sales Pace Slowed in April, With Ford Off 2%
description: In the auto business, April was a lamb to March's lion. Car and truck sales last month dropped to an annual pace of 14.6 million, seasonally adjusted, down from a sizzling 15.9 million in March.

title: The Man Who Spilled the Secrets
description: William Colby, missing and presumed dead in a Maryland boating accident last weekend, was a singular figure in the history of the Central Intelligence Agency. Perhaps more than anyone who served in America's intelligence services during the cold war, Mr. Colby wrestled with the demons that disfigured the C.I.A. In the end he was defeated, but it was a fair fight because he knew the enemy so well. He helped create it.

title: Spendthrift Candidate Yeltsin: Miles to Go. Promises to Keep?
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin was in a beneficent, spendthrift mood on the campaign trail today. He promised a Tatar leader he met on the street $50,000 to open a new Muslim cultural center here. He visited a convent of the Russian Orthodox Church and gave $10,000 from his treasury to help cover the nuns' housekeeping costs.

title: Nebraska Changes Mind
description: The University of Nebraska reversed itself today and decided to renew the athletic scholarship of the basketball player Kate McEwen, who was assaulted by a football player, Lawrence Phillips, her former boyfriend.

title: No Headline
description: I'm getting out of here."

title: NBC Will Buy Rockefeller Center Space
description: They will not even officially take title to the property till later this month, but Rockefeller Center's new owners have already sold a huge chunk of one of the center's 12 landmarked buildings.

title: Preserving History -- Natural and Otherwise
description: Lured by the postcard images etched in their minds, millions of vacationers will soon head to our national parks. Everybody loves the parks. They are the envy of the world, one of America's greatest treasures, home to some precious elements of our heritage. Sadly, they are also a testament to the erosion of our national resolve to keep that heritage alive.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Two British Utilities May Pay New Dividends
description: The shares of Powergen P.L.C. and National Power P.L.C. recovered yesterday from their losses on Thursday on the London stock market as investors speculated that the companies, major British power generators, might pay special dividends. National Power said late on Thursday that it was reviewing its dividend policy and capital structure. The news followed a statement by the Government earlier in the day that it was keeping its special shares in the two, effectively blocking others from bidding for them.

title: Early Retirees From Schools Get Late Pension Payments
description: Brenda and Alan Lavinsky were among the 4,500 New York City educators who took advantage of an early-retirement incentive plan last summer. With the pensions they were expecting after decades in the public school system, the couple, school guidance counselors, planned to winter in Arizona, travel a bit and replace their 1987 Toyota Camry.

title: Sunday in the Park With George, Rover and Spot;Man's Idyllic Friend
description: To the Editor:

title: Sunday in the Park With George, Rover and Spot;Weddings and Funerals
description: To the Editor:

title: HORSE RACING;Questions Still Buzz Around Derby Favorite
description: The tumultuous road to the Kentucky Derby finally neared its destination today: the starting gate at Churchill Downs for Saturday's 122d Run for the Roses. And the sore-footed favorite, Unbridled's Song, got at least a small break when City by Night was scratched with a sore foot of his own, and every horse moved one stall to the inside.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the selloff in the stock and bond markets on Thursday misspelled the surname of the managing director of investment strategy at Salomon Brothers. He is David Shulman, not Schulman.

title: Peter E. Obletz, 50, a Lover of Old Trains, Dies
description: Peter E. Obletz, a dance-company manager and railroad buff who lived aboard two dining cars parked behind Pennsylvania Station in the 1970's and 80's, died on April 23 at Cabrini Hospice in Manhattan. He was 50 and lived in Manhattan.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Musical's Brief Revival Mixes Joy and Contempt
description: Dare the audience to look at you, and then look back at them with murder in your eyes," Bob Fosse reportedly advised the cast of the 1975 musical "Chicago," which has been given a sensational (in more ways than one) concert staging by the Encores series at City Center.

title: World News Briefs;Colombia Law Official Surrenders in Bribe Case
description: Colombia's top judicial official surrendered today, a day after the Supreme Court ordered his arrest on drug corruption charges. A police spokesman said the official, Attorney General Orlando Vasquez Velasquez, was being held by the state security police.

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;Lemieux And Jagr Inflict Damage
description: When Jaromir Jagr first joined the Pittsburgh Penguins, he was polite about allowing Mario Lemieux to monopolize the game-breaking, game-making moments.

title: In Performance;JAZZ
description: Be-Bop as a Gold Mine For Saxophone Improvisation Jimmy Heath Village Vanguard

title: Holy Man Linked to Premier Jailed in Indian Fraud Case
description: In a new embarrassment to Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao during India's general election, a court today jailed a Hindu holy man, Chandraswamy, who has been Mr. Rao's spiritual adviser, political fixer and close friend for a quarter of a century.

title: Observer;Here's What Mad Is
description: After a consortium of auto, asphalt, oil, trucking, garage-mechanic, traffic-cop, used-car-salesman and median-strip-landscaper lobbies, in collusion with the United States Government, made it impossible to live the good American life without a gasoline-powered car, though preferably two or three to show your patriotism, I gave up and went along.

title: William S. Brennen, 72, an Aide In Luring Business to New York
description: William Stuart Brennen, who helped the Beame and Koch administrations to lure businesses to New York City, died on Wednesday at his home on the Upper East Side. He was 72.

title: Beliefs
description: Modern political thinkers, from Machiavelli to Rousseau, from Jefferson to John Dewey, have pondered the relationship between religion and democratic citizenship. Now a sociologist who is also a priest, the Rev. John A. Coleman, has been studying that relationship in practice.

title: Sunday in the Park With George, Rover and Spot;My Bodyguard
description: To the Editor:

title: World News Briefs;U.S. Denies Involvement In a Rape in Guatemala
description: The State Department said today that there was no truth to an American nun's allegation that an American agent was in control of Guatemalan military personnel who raped and tortured her in 1989.

title: Sunday in the Park With George, Rover and Spot;Green Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Highway Death Rate Low
description: New Jersey's motor-vehicle fatality rate ranked far below the national average in 1995, for the second consecutive year. According to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, the state's fatality rate last year was 9.63 per 100,000 residents. The national rate was 15.62. Last year, 776 people died in motor vehicle accidents in the state, and preliminary figures show that the fatality rate is running even lower this year.

title: Sunday in the Park With George, Rover and Spot;Life in the Country
description: To the Editor:

title: Survey Finds Many Unaware of Melanoma
description: Many adults are still unaware of the deadliest form of skin cancer, melanoma, and the role that severe childhood sunburn can play in its development, a survey reported.

title: NYC;In Subway, The Customer Is Blamed
description: AS Reuben Shapiro saw it, the time-honored precept that the customer is always right took it squarely on the chin with the long shutdown of the Lexington Avenue subway line on Wednesday.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Pharmacia & Upjohn Hurt by Weak Sales
description: Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc. said today that first-quarter operating earnings rose 8 percent, which was less than expected, on slow growth in pharmaceutical sales.

title: R. J. Reynolds Told to Yield Files for Suit
description: The R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company must produce documents that a plaintiff in a lawsuit says will prove that cigarette companies knew that smoking was addictive, a Federal judge said on Thursday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PLANS SET TO COMBINE 2 DISTRIBUTION CENTERS
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. said yesterday that it planned to combine two distribution centers in the Los Angeles area and dismiss 300 employees in September. Operations at the former Bullocks distribution center in the City of Industry, just outside Los Angeles, will be moved to a 1.3-million-square-foot center in Pasadena, Calif. Federated acquired the Pasadena center last year when it bought Broadway Stores Inc. The center will service Macy's West and Bloomingdale's in California.

title: Report Released on Crash That Killed 68
description: Eighteen months after an American Eagle turboprop plane crashed in Roselawn, Ind., killing all 68 people aboard, the Federal Aviation Administration issued its answers this week to one series of questions raised by the accident. And on Monday, the agency begins addressing new questions raised by the very same crash.

title: Turner May Sell Castle Rock
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc.'s troubled Castle Rock Entertainment movie and television unit may be sold by the end of September, Castle Rock's chairman, Alan Horn, said today in an interview.

title: Alliant Techsystems Rebounds After Fall
description: Shares of Alliant Techsystems Inc. recovered from a morning plunge today after the company said that allegations that a unit overcharged the Pentagon were "false and without merit."

title: Correction
description: Last Saturday's bridge column erroneously showed West with the diamond king. He held the three, and North had the king.

title: Sunday in the Park With George, Rover and Spot;A Dog's Place
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Defiant in the Face of Defeat

title: Pataki Issues An Ultimatum On Hospitals
description: The Pataki administration today threatened to allow the state's system of setting hospital rates to expire on July 1, potentially throwing the health care industry into chaos, if the Legislature does not agree to deregulate the industry by then.

title: Keep an Eye on El Salvador
description: Since the end of its civil war four years ago, El Salvador has made impressive strides toward building a workable civil society. The United Nations mission to oversee the peace ended officially on Tuesday. But the peace accords have not been fully instituted, and El Salvador's new democratic structures are still wobbly. A small U.N. presence should be maintained through December to continue monitoring the peace agreements.

title: Sunday May 5, 1996: BUG-EYED;The Bionic Cockroach
description: The bionic cockroach has arrived, alive, kicking and hissing in the artificial intelligence lab at the University of Michigan. There, Dan Koditschek, an associate professor, and his colleagues have attached wires to the backs of live cockroaches from Madagascar. The wires send electrical current to their legs and antennae, and Koditschek manipulates them by varying the current. So far, he has only rough control over them, but his "science fiction dream" is to master cockroachian derring-do well enough to clone it in teeny robots called Biobots. "A cockroach can carry up to 80 times its own body weight," he says. "Two or three could carry a small package of screws." He has no plans, however, to turn them into carpenters' helpers.

title: KEEPING TO THE CENTER LANE
description: TWO DAYS AFTER she told Bob Dole absolutely not, thank you very much, the attention is flattering, but I'm very happy right here in New Jersey, Christine Todd Whitman was on her way to North Dakota. It was a messy exercise, starting with a freaky spring storm at home, where the crocuses were buried in slush, and ending with an even freakier storm in Bismarck. Visibility was a half mile, a foot of ice and snow threatened to close the airport's one main runway and Whitman was scheduled to give the keynote speech at the state Republican convention.

title: Mixing It Up for Some Practical Learning

Each player draws cards to decide how to move his or her dog, represented by a marble, around the squares of the board. On each turn, the players switch good dog and bad dog roles.

title: Sunday May 5, 1996: TOASTING THE 70'S;Baaaad Is Back
description: In the early 1970's, a low-cost but highly profitable genre of American movies emerged. It was dubbed "blaxploitation" and its basic black-versus-white revenge motif carried a simple message: Stick it to the Man any way you can. At its best, as in "Soul Vengeance" and the "Penitentiary" prison trilogy, the blaxploitation film was pure Kabuki -- a highly stylized exercise in comic-book hyperbole. Its visuals were large and primal. Its action was fast, brutal, overblown and inventive.

title: Crime

None of us, however, will be able to perform these feats with the exquisite finesse of Jane Whitefield, a Seneca Indian with intuitive perception and extraordinary tracking skills. This heroine is a private agent who finds people who want to be lost and helps other people disappear like smoke. That she remains thoroughly likable while breaking every law on the books has something to do with her fierce -- and very personal -- sense of justice.

title: FILM;Tom Conti and the Tower of Babel

He was lucky, Mr. Conti, 54, admits. His father owned a beauty parlor, and the business did well. "There was money, and there was comfort," he said. "My father was a kind of middle-class Italian Scot. Mine was a silver-spoon immigrant life."

title: Correction

The official -- Kim Byham, not Bynum -- is a man, not a woman; he is director of communications, not the director.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: RENTAL CARS;Ragtop Roundup
description: Ever wonder how rental-car firms suddenly conjure up a fleet of convertibles when summer arrives? Travelers can help answer that question with the See America program from Avis and Preferred Holidays. The seven-night programs, available to June 15, provide air fare to eight Florida cities, Phoenix or Tucson, where participants pick up a Chrysler Sebring convertible. Eight days later, the traveler leaves the car at an airport in any of eight Northeast or Midwest cities (for Florida pickups) or four California cities (for Arizona). Rates start at $299 a person, double occupancy, and include unlimited mileage, seven nights' accommodations and one-way air fare. Sunscreen is extra. Call (800) 508-5454.

Still, other researchers remain skeptical.
