description: Carole Iris Chervin, a lawyer, was married last evening to Adam Joshua Belanoff, a television writer and producer. Rabbi Eric Wisnia, the bride's cousin, performed the ceremony at the Yale Club in New York.

title: When Art Is Imitating Raw Politics In Virginia
description: In the slapdash, sound-bite world of satellite age politics, reflection is rare. But the premiere this week of a behind-the-scenes documentary about Oliver L. North's implausible bid for a United States Senate seat had strategists, ad makers and reporters squirming.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: A Leading Pastry Chef Strikes Out on His Own

title: An Encampment of Crafts At the Bruce Museum
description: EACH year the Bruce Museum's outdoor Crafts Festival seeks to reinvent itself. This year, after having spent two years off site during the Greenwich museum's renovation-expansion, the festival returns to home ground. For its 11th incarnation on May 18 and 19, expect a vibrant tented craft village surrounding the museum and overlooking Bruce Park.

title: Q and A
description: Reunion in Hawaii

title: WEDDING;Kevin McGloon and Katharine Blow
description: Katharine Cooke Blow, the daughter of Marian Bradley of Southport, Conn., and Michael Blow of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Kevin John McGloon, the son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Howard McGloon of Amherst, N.H. The Rev. Craig Reynolds performed the ceremony at the Congregational Church of Easton, Conn.

title: LIVES;The Gilded Cage
description: In 1993 I was found guilty of one count of a five-count indictment of fraud for counterfeiting the works of Mark Kostabi, an artist who pays people to paint his paintings. For this crime, I served five months in a minimum-security correctional facility and five months of house arrest -- the Feds call it home detention, a name that seems too gentle. I was restricted to my one-bedroom apartment on the Upper West Side for 20 hours each day, with a Walkman-size electronic monitor continuously strapped to my left ankle for 152 days.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Pitino on Walker
description: Kentucky Coach RICK PITINO confirmed yesterday that the sophomore forward ANTOINE WALKER intends to make himself available for the National Basketball Association draft, though he said the decision is not yet final.

title: COPING;On Friends, Cult Classics and Small Budgets
description: GRACE HAS MACE," a 30-minute, black-and-white film, was born five years ago on a creepy-dark midtown street. The director/ waitress, Julianne Berg, and the actor/bartender, Patrick Inzetta, were walking back downtown one summer night from their jobs at the old Lone Star Roadhouse uptown. To keep up their courage, they imagined a superhero to save them from the muggers they imagined in the shadows. It would be a woman. Her name would be Grace. One of them laughed and said, "Grace has Mace."

title: HORSE RACING;It's Grindstone, and Lukas (Again), by a Nose
description: Sore heel and all, outside post and all, Unbridled's Song set the stage for a storybook finish to the 122d Kentucky Derby today when he swept into the lead with a quarter of a mile to go. But in the next 26 seconds, he tired and faded to fifth place while Grindstone mounted a gripping duel against Cavonnier and won the Derby by a nose before 142,668 roaring spectators.

title: WEDDING;Esther Winston, Joseph Schreiber
description: Esther Diane Winston, a daughter of Lillian Sadala of New York and the late Donald Winston, is to be married today to Joseph Matthew Schreiber, the son of Charles and Eileen Schreiber of Riverdale, the Bronx. The Rev. Gary Seibert, a Roman Catholic priest, is to officiate with Rabbi Mordechai Genn at the Inn at Central Valley, N.Y.

title: Rebuilding Bosnia Cannot Wait
description: Three and a half years of merciless war have left Bosnia's economy and society shattered. Two-thirds of the country's housing lies damaged or destroyed. Half the prewar hospital beds are gone, along with half the doctors and nurses. Roads and bridges are impassable and some four million hidden mines await potential victims. Gas, electricity and telephone lines are ruptured and three out of four adults have lost their livelihoods.

title: HORSE RACING: NOTEBOOK;Jockeys Could Only Hope at Finish
description: Outside the jockeys' room, after the closest Kentucky Derby finish in 37 years, the winning jockey, Jerry Bailey, spotted a disheartened Chris McCarron.

title: WEDDING;Kristin Naumann, Matthew E. Juros
description: Kristin Ragnhild Naumann, the daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Robert B. A. Naumann of Norwich, Vt., was married yesterday to Matthew Emil Juros, the son of M. Eleanore Juros of Bloomfield, Conn., and the late James E. Juros. The Rev. John T. Bacon officiated at the Nativity of the Virgin Mary Russian Orthodox Church in Chelsea, Mass.

title: ON CAMPUS;State Colleges Facing Sharpest Tuition Increase in Years
description: Last spring, New Jersey's public colleges and universities were trumpeting the fact that their tuitions would increase only modestly -- 5 percent, on average -- for the 1995-96 school year. The mood is not so festive this year, with many schools preparing to vote on increases of 10 percent or more.

title: Tobacco on Trial;Making a Case for Death
description: SO far, it's Taxpayers v. Merchants of Death. Eight states have sued tobacco companies, and more are getting in line, with a new legal theory: since the states incur Medicaid expenses for smoking-related illness, they should be reimbursed by the industry that causes it.

title: ROWING;Northeastern Upsets Harvard
description: Northeastern's unbeaten crew, ranked fourth in the weekly coaches' poll, defeated No. 3 Harvard by half a boat length today on the Charles River. The Husky eight, whose oarsmen average 6 feet 5 inches and 206 pounds, won their fourth race of the season to capture the Charles Smith Cup for only the third time in the 18-race series.

title: SOCCER;MetroStars Storm Back, Then Win in a Shootout
description: After failing to score in their first 180 minutes over two games at Giants Stadium, the MetroStars scored three goals in three minutes in regulation tonight and went on to earn their first victory of the season, 4-3, in a shootout over the Tampa Bay Mutiny before an enthusiastic crowd of 38,621.

title: TELEVISION VIEW;Prime Time, Politics and the Public's Right to Tune Out
description: AS YOU MAY HAVE READ, AN IMPRESSIVE bipartisan batch of politicians (Senator Bill Bradley and Senator Alan K. Simpson), freelance public scolds (Newton N. Minow), broadcasting icons (Walter Cronkite), actors (Alec Baldwin) and several score other personages are calling on the networks to give the Presidential candidates a few minutes of prime time every night through the last month of the campaign to say their say.

title: As Indoor Fights Smolder, Combatants in Smoking Wars Take BattleOutdoors
description: The nation's war over cigarette smoking is being waged on a broad new front: the great outdoors.

title: Some People Who Just Might Be Your Neighbor
description: Literary

title: A Bit of the Old-Fashioned Riviera
description: JUST when you are finally convinced that the French Riviera has been hopelessly spoiled and polluted by the invading crowds, just when you are about to give up and find refuge in the perched villages of the hinterland, you discover a little jewel of an island that revives ancient memories of pristine beaches, secluded coves with crystal-clear waters and wild pine forests. It reminds you that the Mediterranean was once a paradise.

title: DINING OUT;It May Be 25 Years, But It's Still Going Strong
description: TWENTY-FIVE years ago, Capriccio in Jericho was shattering stereotypes. It was one of the first and best of the Northern Italian restaurants that dominated the Long Island dining scene in the 1970's and 1980's. These were not the homey, old familiar Italians, awash in red sauce, but temples of sophisticated, elegant fare. It was here that birthdays, promotions and anniversaries were celebrated.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: JERSEY;It Ain't Sotheby's, but Then $5 Goes Further
description: ON the magazine rack at the Cumberland Farms store up the road near Blackwood, Time magazine had a cover story explaining why a strand of Jacqueline Onassis' fake pearls, worth maybe $500, sold for $211,500 at Sotheby's auction house. "People will pay a premium for history," Time declared.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TRACK AND FIELD;Record Is Official
description: MARIA MUTOLA'S world indoor record in the 1,000 meters has been ratified by the International Amateur Athletic Federation. Mutola, of Mozambique, ran 2 minutes 31.23 seconds at a meet in Stockholm on Feb. 26, bettering her mark of 2:32.08, set 10 days earlier in Birmingham, England. Mutola plans to compete in the 800 meters and 1,500 meters at the Summer Games. (AP)

title: INVESTING IT;Only the Clothes Are Understated: Karan Speaks
description: POTENTIAL investors in the initial public offering of Donna Karan International probably already know that the designer makes popular skirts and pantyhose. But do they know that in her former lives, Ms. Karan trekked thought Egypt and painted with the Medicis?

title: Henry Clarke, 77, Photographer Of High Fashion for Magazines
description: Henry Clarke, whose fashion photographs and portraits of social personalities and royalty graced the pages of Vogue for a quarter-century, died on April 26 at the Anglo-American Hospital in Le Cannet in the south of France. He was 77.

title: WEDDING;Whitney Potter, Basil L. Hurst 3d
description: Whitney Anne Potter, a daughter of Phyllis and Anthony Ross Potter of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Basil L. Hurst 3d, the son of Cordelia Harrison Ward of Richmond and Mr. Hurst Jr. of Newport News, Va. The Rev. James L. Bell performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: EARNING IT;When Americans See Bias and the Boss Is Foreign
description: FOR Beth Goodman, equality in her workplace came down to more than her suspicions that she was not being offered the same perks as the Japanese employees at the United States subsidiary of Tokai Bank.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CHELSEA/FLATIRON;A New Address For Club Vertigo. Or Is It Vertigone?
description: Laura Michaels nearly broke into song when a U-Haul truck pulled in front of her loft on West 20th Street two weeks ago. No, Ms. Michaels was not moving. Her neighbor, Club Vertigo, was leaving the block between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas after a year of battling residents and business owners who wanted the hip-hop dance club to rein in rowdy patrons.

title: Still Running;Is Age-Bashing Any Way to Beat Bob Dole?
description: A new Democratic Party television commercial takes a not-too-subtle swipe at Senator Bob Dole, age 72. After a shot of him side-by-side with Speaker Newt Gingrich, the announcer warns (emphasis added): "Their old ways don't work. President Clinton's plan -- the new way."

title: Mitzvah or Mania, and More;Remember It's the Owner, Not the Broker, Who Sells
description: To the Editor:

title: What's Happening?
description: HE DREAM OF THE UNIFIED FIELD Selected Poems 1974-1994. By Jorie Graham. 199 pp. Hopewell, N.J.: The Ecco Press. $23.

title: Why the Best Doesn't Always Win
description: APPLE COMPUTER, THE COMPANY THAT BROUGHT YOU THE idiot-friendly Macintosh, is staring at bankruptcy. Meanwhile, the great army of technocrats at Microsoft, which only last year managed to reproduce the look and feel of a 1980's Mac, lumbers on, invincible.

title: World News Briefs;Report of Liberia Truce Denied by Militia Chief
description: Warring factions in Liberia have agreed on a new truce in a four-week standoff that has forced thousands of frightened civilians to flee their homes, diplomats said today.

title: IN BRIEFS;Reminder for Voters: A Deadline Approaches
description: On June 4, New Jersey residents will have a chance to vote in primary elections to select candidates for state, county and local offices. The deadline for registering to vote in the primary or changing a voting address is tomorrow.

title: Tara Circle's Move In Another Light
description: Tara Circle Keeps in Step With Its Educational Programs" [March 17] aptly described the wonderful educational and cultural programs of this Irish center, programs that would be an asset to any enlightened community.

title: No Headline
description: There's absolutely no way to compete with Indians. I've found that my own employees shop on the reservations. Enough is enough already."

title: ENVIRONMENT;This Garbage Has a Future
description: Something is rotting in the Borough of Brielle, and that's good news.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER EAST SIDE;Lovely Park, Ugly Struggle
description: For nearly a year, a lovely tree-lined playground in John Jay Park has been off limits to children, locked in an unlovely struggle involving the Parks Department, parents and a contractor who has been dismissed.

title: WEDDING;Nicole J. Moore, Andrew C. Samson
description: Nicole Jeneen Moore, a daughter of Lorene and Charles Moore of Mount Laurel, N.J., was married last evening to Andrew Cohen Samson, the son of Susan Cohen and Dr. Oscar Cohen of Nyack, N.Y. The Rev. William Crawford officiated at the First Baptist Church in Moorestown, N.J.

title: A CELEBRATION OF 100 YEARS
description: As a faithful New York Times reader since my freshman year in high school (1960) and as a history buff, I am savoring the "5,000 Sundays" issue.

title: Bringing Up Baby With Its Parents On the Sideline
description: IN the 1987 movie "Baby Boom," Diane Keaton played a big-city management consultant who moved to small-town Vermont, cooked up homemade baby food, then fended off corporate America's attempt to take over her thriving enterprise.

title: Whose Dominion?
description: QUEST FOR LIFE An Autobiography. By Ian L. McHarg. Illustrated. 430 pp. New York: John Wiley & Sons. $34.95.

title: In the Region: New Jersey;Warehouse and Distribution-Center Demand Rises
description: A RELATIVELY healthy demand for industrial space has given rise to a spate of projects being built for specific tenants or on speculation. Most are focused on big boxy warehouse and distribution centers.

title: L.I. Over 25 Years: Realizing a Dream;Crossing the Island, A Slice of America
description: TO drive the 120 miles from Brooklyn to Montauk, the length of Long Island, is in a strange sort of way like crossing the continent. It is a journey that begins in the great city, moves on and on through what can seem like endless stretches of different landscapes, then culminates in a place of great beauty where the land runs out at the edge of the sea.

title: Case Studies
description: DECISION How the Supreme Court Decides Cases. By Bernard Schwartz. 272 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $25. THE red velour curtain that separates United States Supreme Court Justices from the public before the start of a day's session is more iron than cloth. It symbolizes the secrecy that insulates, isolates and even enhances the Justices' work, a secrecy that apparently suits them just fine.

title: The View From: Watertown;A Dozen Retired Men Knowing Just What to Do With Their Time
description: LIONS CLUBS have an international reputation for service, but a segment of the one in Watertown has taken that concept an extra mile. It's the Lions Old Fellows Project Club, consisting of a dozen retired men with lots of expertise in a variety of areas and plenty of hours to give.

title: Robert Thurman Doesn't Look Buddhist
description: TALL AND IMPOSING, IN A DARK BLUE SUIT and bold red-and-yellow tie, Prof. Robert A.F. Thurman, a former Tibetan Buddhist monk and New Yorker to his bones, marched to center stage at Carnegie Hall. Thurman, who is also the president of Tibet House, was introducing the organization's annual benefit concert. He announced to the sold-out house, with a certain wry hilarity, the Tibetan New Year of the Fiery Rat. He praised the evening's performers, Michael Stipe and Emmylou Harris among them, for "putting a shield of poetry around the heart of a suffering people." Later on, Thurman kicked and shuffled his way across the stage, eyeing his feet nervously, arm in arm with the singers Natalie Merchant and Patti Smith as Dadon, an exiled Tibetan balladeer, led them in a Tibetan New Year's dance. After the concert, Thurman rushed upstairs to introduce reporters to one of his daughters, the actress Uma Thurman, and to Harrison Ford, hosts of the late supper party to come. There, Thurman held forth energetically, in a swarm of rock stars, models, movie stars and other wealthy patrons of Tibet House.

title: Paper Fan, Iron Fist
description: THE MODERN MADAME BUTTERFLY Fantasy and Reality in Japanese Cross-Cultural Relationships. By Karen Ma. 296 pp. Boston: Charles E. Tuttle Company. Paper, $12.95.

title: MANUAL LABOR
description: As "every nation gets the government it deserves," every consumer culture gets the product instructions it demands.

title: SCHOOL;Beyond Pleats and Plaids: Uniforms a Student Might Actually, Like, Wear
description: It seemed a high price to pay for being Catholic.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT/Page 4/ You'd never know Donna Karan, the dressmaker, was in its Government-mandated quiet period from the way its chief executive goes on -- and on. By Jennifer Steinhauer.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: OCEAN HILL/BROWNSVILLE;A Street Fight, With Children In the Middle
description: Play streets, those community concoctions that turn over entire blocks to children's summertime games, are especially important in Brooklyn, the borough with the smallest amount of public space relative to its population. In neighborhoods like Ocean Hill, basketball under portable nets on the hot pavement not only occupies children's time, it also keeps them away from drug dealers.

title: Awakenings
description: TRUTH SERUM Memoirs. By Bernard Cooper. 225 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $21.95.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC;A Weary Maestro Trudges Forward
description: IT WAS Andre Previn's day in New York: the one day he had set aside between conducting engagements in Boston and Vienna to meet with managers, colleagues and record-company executives. By the time he ducked into the offices of Columbia Artists Management on this rainy April afternoon, Mr. Previn, who is 66, was running an hour late, looking slightly wilted and admitting to fatigue.

title: Years Later, Fordham Case Still Haunts Woman
description: It has been six years since Karen Schmidt took what she calls "a trip through Fordham's judicial hell," but the memories still torment her.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the "listed at" price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: SPOTLIGHT;Music and Madness
description: Welcome back to HANGOVER SQUARE (1945), a juicy, atmospheric musician in gaslit London - and to Lair Cregar (above). (The hefty, 28-year-old character actor died the next year.) An unseen co-star - with George Sanders and Linda Darnell - is Bernard Herrmann, whose dazzling, luscious score evokes a Freudian ambiance of danger and sensuality. John Brahm's direction stirs in overtones of Jack the Ripper, but it's Cregar's show as the fierce, jittery composer-pianist nearing madness - his show and Herrmann's. Watch the concert-hall face-in, as able fingers tab the ivories, and hang on for some Victorian chills - SATURDAY at 10 A.M. on MAX.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: PIANO LESSONS Music, Love, & True Adventures. By Noah Adams. Delacorte, $20.95.

title: A Convenient Marriage: East End's Vineyards Come of Age
description: RIPENESS is all," Edgar said in "King Lear." That was precisely the story of the East End's grapes in 1993, 1994 and 1995. And as the North and South Forks' 18 wine producers head into the 1996 growing season -- bud break is expected this week -- their cellar skills, like their vineyards, are steadily maturing.

title: Parole Officers on Patrol
description: ON a recent morning as the first light of day started to spread through the wet, deserted streets here, three men piled into a dark Ford station wagon. They all wore bulletproof vests and carried 9-millimeter automatics, which held 14 rounds of ammunition. The meeting was about a serious crime, but one that had already been committed. The men were officers assigned to the state's Department of Parole Absconder Search Team, and this was the hour they went out to arrest people who had violated conditions of their release from prison.

title: Sunday May 5, 1996: FULL SPEED AHEAD;Praise the Toypedoes
description: Ever tried throwing a ball underwater? You just can't get it from here to there. But dive in with the Toypedo, a new rubber toy that looks like a V-2 rocket, and suddenly there's an unfamiliar thrust to water sports. "A 12-year-old, with some practice, can throw it up to 40 feet," says Jon Warner, its inventor.

title: Correction
description: An answer in the Q&A column on April 14, about rent increases tied to major capital improvements, referred imprecisely to limits on such payments. Major-capital-improvement increases for tenants in rent-stabilized apartments are limited to a maximum of 6 percent a year. For tenants covered by the rent-control program, which applies to pre-1947 apartments in which tenancy has not changed since 1971, the maximum is 15 percent a year.

title: Recycling' Replacing Office Construction
description: RENOVATION and retrofitting may best describe the activity in the county's commercial real estate industry.

title: WEDDING;Heidi Schulman, Bradley Greenwald
description: Heidi Lynn Schulman, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Paul Schulman of Westport, Conn., is to be married today to Bradley Allen Greenwald, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Greenwald of Tustin, Calif. Judge Douglas Mintz of the Fairfield Judicial District of the Superior Court of Connecticut in Bridgeport is to officiate in the garden at Sole e Luna, a restaurant in Westport.

title: WEDDING;Gita Iraj and Christopher Shaari
description: Dr. Gita Marie Iraj, the daughter of Dr. Jasmin Moshirpur Iraj and Dr. Iraj Iraj of Douglaston, Queens, is to be married today to Dr. Christopher Mehdi Shaari, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Mehdi Shaari of Fort Lee, N.J. The Rev. John Gribbon, a Roman Catholic priest, is to perform the ceremony at the Garden City (L.I.) Hotel.

title: News Summary
description: International 3-13

title: WHAT'S DOING IN;Boston
description: Correction Appended

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: ANSWERS TO LUCKY By Howard Owen. HarperCollins, $22.

title: EARNING IT;As Moonlighting Spreads, It Loses Its Blue-Collar Hue
description: FOR Liliana Pumpido, no time is free time. From 8:30 A.M. to 2:45 P.M., Ms. Pumpido, a licensed social worker, is at her job with the West New York, N.J., public schools. In the late afternoons and evenings, she counsels private clients in her Weehawken home.

title: WEDDING;Laura Friedman, David Williams
description: Laura Friedman, a daughter of Carol and Robert Friedman of Larchmont, N.Y., was married last evening to David Allen Williams, the son of Susan Lewis Williams of Chicago and Frank Williams of New York. Rabbi Ari Fridkis performed the ceremony at the Metropolitan Building in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Commercial Property/Worldwide Plaza and Its Neighborhood;In Hell's Kitchen, Retail Is on the Front Burner
description: IN the late 1980's, the first renters at Worldwide Plaza, the condominium and office complex that fills the block between Eighth and Ninth Avenues and 49th and 50th Streets, figured they had the best of all worlds.

title: Make Rejection Work for You
description: Across America recently, high school seniors nervously checked their mailboxes. Many found the dreaded thin envelope -- the rejection letter. I know how they feel. It made me feel a lot better, some years ago, to send a response much like this:

title: Appeals Set Back Kevorkian Repeatedly
description: The trial of Dr. Jack Kevorkian, his fourth for assisting in suicides, frequently resembles an existentialist play in which two sets of the most important characters never actually appear.

title: What Ought (Hint, Hint) the Class of '00 Be Called?
description: HAVING just received their acceptances from colleges, high school seniors across the country now confront the extraordinarily difficult decision of which institution to attend. Come September, they will have to make yet another. As members of the first class to graduate in the new millennium, they will be deciding what to call themselves.

title: Children's Books;Bookshelf
description: ARTHUR AND THE SWORD. Written and illustrated by Robert Sabuda. Atheneum. $16. (Ages 6 to 9) The striking illustrations in this account of how the boy called Arthur found and drew out the sword called Excalibur, thus becoming King of England, are done in the style of sunlit stained-glass windows.

title: MUSIC;Anthems From Mozart and Handel
description: THE Greater Middletown Chorale bids farewell to Christopher Shepard this afternoon at a 4 o'clock concert in the Church of the Holy Trinity. The choir's director is leaving his post (and those he holds at the helm of the Litchfield County Children's Choir and the arts department of the Taft School in Watertown) to take over the vocal department at the Sydney Grammar School in Australia. The program is devoted to Mozart's "Coronation" Anthem, the four coronation anthems that Handel wrote for George II, and the choral dances from "Gloriana," Benjamin Britten's opera celebrating the Coronation of Queen Elizabeth II.

title: WEDDING;Joy Caslowitz, William Weinbaum
description: Joy Caslowitz, a product manager at Hyperion Software in Stamford, Conn., is to be married today to William Weinbaum, the New York bureau producer at ESPN, the cable television sports channel. Rabbi Wayne Franklin is to perform the ceremony at Temple Emanu-El in Providence, R.I.

title: Hinting at Third-Party Run, Buchanan Steps Up Attack on Dole
description: Showing no sign of retreat on the issue of abortion, Pat Buchanan today stepped up his criticism of Senator Bob Dole, the presumptive Republican Presidential nominee, and hinted again that if the Republican Party weakened its stance on abortion he would make a third party run for the Presidency.

title: Dark Prince of the Kremlin
description: STALIN

title: Thunder on the Hill
description: The System The American Way of Politics at the Breaking Point. By Haynes Johnson and David S. Broder. 668 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $25.95.

title: In the Tank
description: Some arresting developments in swimwear.

title: Even After the Holocaust, Their Nightmares Persisted
description: ALTHOUGH IT MAY sometimes seem as if the Holocaust and its aftermath have been thoroughly mined by film makers, now comes another look at the subject.

title: OFF THE SHELF;Swing Low, Sweet Corporation, and All That Jazz
description: FIRST you play jazz; then you betray your country," goes an old Soviet slogan, a bygone warning so familiar to Russians that it was easily satirized when the daily newspaper Izvestia reported Bill Clinton's election victory in 1992. ("First You Play Saxophone . . . ," read the front-page headline, atop a photo of America's new President.)

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: THE ONE-HANDED PIANIST And Other Stories. By Ilan Stavans. University of New Mexico, $22.50.

title: STYLE;The Razor's Edge
description: The other day, while paging through Paris Match, I came across a snapshot of Prince Albert at some ceremony in Monaco. Usual fare for Match. But this picture was quite unusual. Prince Albert had no hair.

title: Officer Shot In Subway Is Arrested
description: Desmond Robinson, who became a symbol of racial mistrust within the New York City police force after he was shot five times by a fellow officer who mistook him for a criminal, has been arrested on charges of sexually assaulting a female police officer, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: HOW WE EAT
description: Betty G. Rose's letter (March 31) about Molly O'Neill's "Tastes Like Chicken" (March 10) was right on! O'Neill's recipes are not for the average American, who doesn't have the checkbook, the time or the inclination to make things like Stuffed Chicken Breast in Phyllo Crust on Green-Lentil Compote (with 28 ingredients).

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CHELSEA;Helping Japanese Nationals Cope in the City
description: For the city's well-established Japanese community, with several generations born in the United States, there would seem to be little need for the social service organizations that have sprung up to serve immigrants from China, Korea and Vietnam.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Tours That Open Up American Indian Culture
description: Two nonprofit organizations, the National Trust for Historic Preservation and Smithsonian Associates, offer tours of American Indian cultural sites this summer.

title: SOAPBOX;Guests With Nests
description: AT first we thought the uninvited guests in the soffit ceiling over our bathtub were rodents. Scrabbling sounds of an unidentifiable work force -- chick-chuzz, chick-chuzz -- had started up each morning on the dot of 7, as though contracted to a union.

title: U.S. Indicts a School Official At Center of Furor in Dallas
description: A school board member who was at the center of a furor here last fall after telephone recordings revealed he had used racial slurs and obscenities in describing school administrators and teachers has been indicted on charges of conspiracy, bribery and extortion.

title: Hammer, Anvil, Iron and Gold
description: IT is Monday, and on Mondays Jaime Pelissier can be found in a back country barn a few minutes' drive from his goldsmith shop on Greenwich Avenue in Greenwich. He has left behind the diamonds and emeralds and custom-designed jewelry that require his attention the rest of the week. At the barn there is none of the animated street life that defines the town's prime shopping district, only billows of smoke rising from the chimney.

title: A CELEBRATION OF 100 YEARS
description: Your celebration, with its discussion of why The Times does not print comics, reminded me of an old radio show that my father always enjoyed. It was called "Duffy's Tavern," and Archie, the manager, once declared that he never read The New York Times because of its editorial policy -- no comics.

title: Corrections
description: The Correspondent's Report on page 3 of the Travel section today, about the museum in Bonn that incorporates Beethoven's birthplace, omits a byline. It is by Alan Cowell.

title: Cities Enlisting Private Companies for Sewage Treatment
description: Garbage pickup was one of the first to go, along with paper recycling, jail operations and, in a few cases, firefighting. Now, in the latest nationwide move toward privatizing public services, scores of municipalities are starting to turn over waste-water-treatment plants to private contractors.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about a leadership training camp for corporate executives misidentified the authors of "The Leadership Challenge," a book about organizational leadership. They are James M. Kouzes and Barry Z. Posner.

title: News Highlights;The Ravages of Rain, Wind, Snow and Fire
description: Wave-battered and wind-beaten Long Island pays for jutting seaward, never more than when hurricanes roar up from the tropics. Three hurricanes in the last 20 years have lent resonance to certain names. First came Belle, striking on a falling tide on Aug. 9, 1976, her timing sparing the coast from heavy flooding. Gloria, a potential killer, swept by high and fast on Sept. 27, 1985. She is remembered for knocking down thousands of trees and causing widespread electric failures, some lasting for days. Bob, a milder hurricane, blew in nearly six years later on Aug. 19, 1991, clipping the East End.

title: WEDDING;Saville Ryan, Charles Marsh

A few days later, Nicolas and I went ot ea gorest of wedwoods and scattered her ashes. Through a veil of tears, I saw that my son had suddenly grown six feet tall adn was wrapping me in his arms, and no words were needed. Looking at this photograph, I realized that Nicolas has been holding me much longer than I ever held him. Paul Kissinger and Henry Kissinger PUALA KISSINGER, avid reader: When Henry went to war, I wrote every other day, and he answered three times a week. When he finally returned, there were parties and, to crown it all, the visits to the White House to meet the various Presidents, the mother proud on the arm of her son. HENRY KISSINGER, former Secretary of State: The happiest times of my childhood were spent at her family's house. Much as been written about how traumatic a period this was supposed to have been in my life. But my mother shielded us from much of what was for her, in fact, traumatic. At every crucial stage of my life I have been lucky to have had my mother at my side.

Sidewalks, public transit and buildings (floors, walls, stairways) are still taboo targets. What has changed is enforcement. Could a hawker do hard time nowadays? Not likely, says Officer Edward Bonny, an eight-year veteran of the New York Police Department's Transit Bureau who has never issued a $25 summons for spitting. And no judge in recent memory has imposed the maximum 10-day jail sentence. Even so, what would Mother say?

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION;Master of Space
description: Frank Stella first caught the attention of the New York art world in 1958, at the age of 22, when his austere "black paintings" marked him as an uncompromising, inventive artist. At 34, Mr. Stella had his first retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art. Both talented and well connected, Mr. Stella got himself included in the canon of American abstraction with precocious speed. Although his later works -- huge, multipart metallic constructions replete with gaudily colored French curves and graffitilike brushstrokes -- are now most visible as fixtures of corporate lobby art, Mr. Stella has secured a legacy as a masterly interpreter of space, someone who pushed the boundaries of painting. This kind of achievement merits more than the treatment it receives in FRANK STELLA: An Illustrated Biography (Rizzoli, $75). Sidney Guberman, an artist and Mr. Stella's classmate at Princeton, is diligent about quoting from the best of what has been previously written about his subject, neither cowed by nor dismissive of what has gone before. But from a close friend -- and well past the halfway mark of Mr. Stella's career -- we expect something extra. Mr. Guberman has plenty of anecdotes from the time he has spent with Mr. Stella over the years, but most of them are not very illuminating. He is at his best when he addresses the art directly, as in his explanations of the relatively complicated working techniques that Mr. Stella used to make his irregular frames and surfaces of serious sculptural depth. Ted Loos

title: For Sure, We Hear Long Island Singing;O! Long Island!
description: Starting from fish-shape Paumanok, where I was born Near the pectoral fin, far from Manahatta's spires in a rude, rough-timber'd cottage Near the teeming, oft-choked artery of commerce, Route 110 Near the Sweet Hollow Diner (sweet indeed are its waffles) Near the mall: yes, the one named for me (I celebrate myself, and sing myself! Wouldn't you?) (Not the mall with Service Merchandise and Filene's -- the next mall down, the one with Macy's) O! frivolous, O! deadly serious Long Island, epicenter of buying, using, consuming, parking! O! Long Islanders: turbulent, fleshy, sensual, eating, drinking and shopping; Coursing in ironclad automotive streams to nail salon, pizza place, Jiffylube, Dairy Barn; Who goes there? hankering, gross, mystical, nude (on some beaches) Is it Joey Buttafuoco, thrower of fire, despoiler of youth, helmet-haired sculptor of auto bodies? Is it Mary Jo, suffering wife, all clenched teeth and stony gaze (I feel so bad fuh huh!) Buttafuocos I scorn you not, nor you Howard Stern, nor you John McNamara; D'Amato, Gulotta, Margiotta, I do not judge you: Dead five score years, yet I, too, vote Republican; For I am of and from Long Island, All its flaws and splendors I embrace -- I accept all and see all: I see the checkout gal at King Kullen, feath'ry nimbus of frosted hair, glittersome nails sullenly punching her register keys; I see the man with the leaf blower, spewing noxious fumes; I see the jerk in the Land Rover, phone to ear on Northern State; I see the Cablevision guy, lost on his rounds, never here by noon, damn him; All these and more I see, and sing, sounding my barbaric yawp over the front lawns and gabled roofs of Nassau and Suffolk As well as at the beaches, swiftly eroding, And in the pine barrens, charr'd abode of deer ticks, engorg'd and pestilential, and the wind-kiss'd dunes and rocky shores, and the Discovery Zones, And do not forget on the train: to Bellmore, Wantagh, Seaford, Massapequa, Massapequa Park, Amityville, Copiague, Lindenhurst and Babylon, (Do I change at Jamaica? Very well then I change at Jamaica!) Missing my train I'll take another I stop somewhere waiting for you, my monthly pinn'd to my slumb'ring breast (Heed me, but wake me not.) LAWRENCE DOWNES

title: Books in Brief: FICTION;Short Takes
description: As an alternative to those trivial compendiums of literary opening passages sold near bookstore cash registers, how about a collection of last lines from Gina Berriault's very short stories, WOMEN IN THEIR BEDS: New and Selected Stories (Counterpoint, P.O. Box 65793, Washington, D.C. 20035, $25)? Consider this stand-alone triumph: "He lay facedown under the tree and bit off some grass near the roots, chewing to distract his smile, but it would not give in, and so he lay there the entire day, smiling into the earth." Or: "She heard his breath take over for him and, in that secretive way the sleeper knows nothing about, carry on his life." Ms. Berriault is nothing if not consistent. In these 35 stories, one struggles to find a sentence that is anything less than jewel-box perfect. And the author uses her gift for language to do more than show us the world through her characters' eyes; we are also forced to think about it from their point of view -- no small feat for someone who favors third-person narration. These are complex characters, and although many stories run only a few pages Ms. Berriault never falls back on cliches: an aging male librarian, for example, is no shrinking violet; instead, he sports "a Borsalino fedora" and "English boots John Major would covet." Most of Ms. Berriault's characters are caught at moments of divergence: in "Soul and Money," a lapsed Communist confronts God and Mammon in Las Vegas; in "Lives of the Saints," the son of a famous religious artist undertakes his own sort of pilgrimage, visiting his father's works, and discovers that life is more lasting than art. Yet in the smooth flow of Ms. Berriault's writing, few of these people manage to register the emotional pitch needed to transcend their crises. It is not a matter of stoicism; instead, most seem dizzyingly unaware of the option to act on their own behalf. Thus the stories, so exquisite to wend through, leave one a little cold. Like their characters, they seem trapped by the perfection of Ms. Berriault's prose. Tobin Harshaw
