description: In the Night," performed by the New York City Ballet on Thursday night at the New York State Theater, was created by Jerome Robbins in 1970, a year after his hit ballet "Dances at a Gathering." Like the earlier, more substantial work, it is set to a Chopin piano score and hints at fleeting emotions and relationships. Who are the three couples in "In the Night"? Mr. Robbins lets us know only that the man and the woman in each have different ways of loving each other and are possibly at different stages of their relationships.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;The Evolution of a Nice Kid Into an Abusive Land Mine
description: Prime time's new message these days is blunt: No more Mr. Nice Guy. Last week, John Ritter, once the goofy comic foil of "Three's Company," popped up in a television movie as a vicious wife batterer. Even Paul Reiser, playing one of television's most hip and amiable husbands in the Sunday-night sitcom "Mad About You," is suddenly giving Helen Hunt such a hard time that the possibility of divorce -- remote, obviously -- looms over Paul and Jamie.

title: Treasury Has Busy Auction Schedule This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week consists of auctions on the first four days of the week, starting today with the regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills. On Tuesday the Treasury will auction a 3-year note; on Wednesday, a 10-year note, and on Thursday, a 36-day cash management bill.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Hemingway, Two Years Before the End
description: If "Papa," John deGroot's unsparing dramatic portrait of Ernest Hemingway in his later years, has any degree of accuracy, the macho titan of 20th-century American fiction was one mean drunk.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Cosmic Allegory From Twyla Tharp
description: A ballet by Twyla Tharp, no matter how muddled, always has a streak of unmatched originality, and "The Elements," her new work about order and disorder for American Ballet Theater, if flawed, is also striking.

title: 2,000 Evacuated in New Mexico As Forest Fire Spreads Quickly
description: A forest fire in northern New Mexico burned out of control today, forcing 2,000 residents to evacuate and later engulfing several homes. No injuries were reported.

title: Move From Viacom to MCA Is Worth Millions to Biondi
description: For Frank J. Biondi Jr., being dismissed as chief executive of Viacom Inc. might prove to be one of the most profitable events of his career.

title: Forbes Attacks Time Warner Debt In a Move It Says Is Not Revenge
description: Almost four months after Fortune magazine scolded its chief rival for soft, uncritical coverage of its major advertisers, Forbes countered this week with a scathing story about the weakened financial state of Fortune's corporate parent, Time Warner Inc.

title: Plight of Kashmir Captives
description: Western tourists, including an American, held hostage by separatist guerrillas in Kashmir have begun their 11th month in captivity with no end to the ordeal in sight.

title: TV Writer's Final Wish: Audacious, Not Plaintive, And True to HisScript
description: It was Dennis Potter's mischievous last wish, announced to the world as he sipped champagne and liquid morphine in a mesmerizing television interview two years ago, soon after he learned he was dying of pancreatic cancer.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in Weekend on Friday showing Adina Porter in "Venus" at the Joseph Papp Public Theater was credited incorrectly. The photographer was T. Charles Erickson.

title: Thousands Join a Mournful Exodus From Liberia's Capital
description: Clouds of dark smoke billowed over the Liberian capital today as 2,500 of its citizens stood on the deck of a freighter, sadly singing a patriotic hymn and waving farewell as the ship inched away from the burning city.

title: Next, Eliminate New York School Boards
description: To the Editor:

title: At Home Abroad;Darkness In Gaza
description: Dr. Eyad R. Sarraj, a psychiatrist trained at the Maudsley Hospital in London, is director of the Gaza Community Mental Health Program. During the Israeli occupation he developed ways of treating children traumatized in the intifada. He was then, and is now, a campaigner for human rights.

title: Essay;The New Casey
description: Whom the political gods would destroy, they first make power-grabbing Directors of Central Intelligence.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9

title: In Performance
description: DANCE Looking Back at the Passions Of Youth and a Long-Ago Love American Ballet Theater Metropolitan Opera House

title: Cornell Battles Anew Over Ethnic Dormitories
description: Last spring, state officials cleared Cornell University of discrimination charges involving dormitories that focus on black, Hispanic and American Indian cultures. Now, a year and a new president later, Cornell is battling accusations that it is trying to phase out those dormitories by barring freshmen, who proponents say support the programs both financially and spiritually.

title: Bear, Stearns Computer
description: Bear, Stearns & Company, the nation's sixth-largest securities firm, is buying a Cray Research Inc. supercomputer that would operate 30 to 45 times as fast as the firm's current computers.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Television Notes column on Wednesday about the competition between two dramatic series -- CBS's "Nash Bridges" and NBC's "Homicide: Life on the Street" -- misidentified the No. 1 show in Nielsen ratings in recent weeks from 10 to 11 P.M. on Fridays. ABC's news magazine "20/20" has been winning that time period overall; "Nash Bridges" has been outperforming "Homicide."

title: Sports of The Times;Self-Made, Made-Up Superstar of the Bulls
description: ON the eve of the big playoff series here, Michael Jordan's back, Scottie Pippen's ankle and Phil Jackson's brains played second fiddle to Dennis Rodman's cosmetics and Dennis Rodman's frocks.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Vietnam Veterans to Gather
description: Friends and survivors of the men and women who served in the Vietnam War will gather tomorrow for the annual New Jersey Vietnam Veterans Remembrance Day. Gen. Alfred M. Gray, who served as commandant of the Marine Corps from 1987 until his retirement in 1991 -- the only New Jerseyan ever to serve as commandant -- will address the gathering. In all, 78,000 New Jerseyans served in the conflict, and 1,547 lost their lives.

title: Immigrants Tell Their New York Stories
description: The 10 immigrants who gathered at the Lower East Side Tenement Museum yesterday spoke of fantastical expectations of New York City: When Rafael Guzman, a Dominican, arrived as a teen-ager 30 years ago, he expected to land in a plush skyscraper, like the ones he saw on Christmas cards his cousins had sent home.

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;Red Wings Hammer Blues
description: Steve Yzerman had two goals and three assists, tying a Detroit record with 5 points in a playoff game, as the Red Wings crushed the St. Louis Blues, 8-3, today and took a 2-0 lead in their second-round series.

title: Hubert Saal, Longtime Critic For Newsweek, Is Dead at 72
description: Hubert Saal, Newsweek magazine's music and dance critic from 1964 until he retired in 1984, died on Saturday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 72 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Next, Eliminate New York School Boards
description: To the Editor:

title: Demise of BBC Arabic TV: Nothing Lost in Translation
description: LONDON  On Sunday, April 21, viewers of the British Broadcasting Corp.'s Arabic-language news channel across the Middle East woke up to find the service gone. In its place glowed a simple on-screen message: Transmission of this channel, it said, "has ceased. Subscribers will be credited."

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Charm and Honesty in Townshend's Greatest Hits
description: Charisma isn't always a good thing, even for pop stars. It lets them get away with gaffs that mortals might have edited out. Pete Townshend performed at the Supper Club on Friday night accompanied by just a keyboardist, and the long show was made bearable by Mr. Townshend and his persona, at times bitter and sarcastic, but fundamentally honest. And charismatic: Mr. Townshend and Elton John are less distant musically than one might think. But Mr. Townshend is worth getting to know, and one excuses his occasional conceptual poverty for his charm.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings this week:

title: F.D.R. Memorial Has Lessons in 'Disability Cool'
description: To the Editor:

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;The Lemieux Rule: Stay Within Two Feet
description: ON the Ranger bench, Colin Campbell would lean toward Mark Messier and say, "Can you still go?" And when the Rangers' captain nodded, the coach would say, "Then go again."

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;New Irvin Accusations
description: The Dallas Cowboys star MICHAEL IRVIN, currently under felony indictment in connection with the seizure of cocaine and marijuana in a March 4 raid on an Irving, Tex., motel room, bought cocaine before and after the raid, KXAS-TV reported last night.

title: At Rosemount Cemetery, With Misplaced Plots Comes Loss of Peace ofMind
description: Toni Mathis always used the maple tree to find her mother's grave in Rosemount Memorial Park -- the gravestone was right across the path from it. Today, however, the stone seemed to have moved 20 or 30 feet back toward the fence, and was facing toward the highway instead of away from it.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: CYCLING

title: Algerian President Promises Elections Early Next Year
description: Algeria's President promised today to hold new legislative elections next year, but did not say whether the country's outlawed Islamic opposition would be allowed to take part.

title: East Germans, in Slap at West, Reject Joining State With Berlin
description: In a stinging rebuke to their political leaders, voters in the eastern German state of Brandenburg rejected a plan today that would have united them in a single state with Berlin.

title: Janet A. Sloane, 82, a Millinery Stylist
description: Janet A. Sloane, a fashion director who helped bring haute couture headware from Europe to upscale American stores, died on April 20 at her home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. She was 82.

title: The Latest Mousetrap: Caffeine-Laced Spring Water
description: Imagine coffee without the coffee, soda pop with just the pop. That's Water Joe, perhaps the strangest New Age beverage yet -- artesian well water mixed with a dollop of caffeine.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a Brazilian trial of a former police officer accused in the killing of homeless youths in 1993 referred imprecisely to the ages of the victims. They ranged in age from 11 to 20; they were not all children.

title: INSIDE
description: Palestinian Peace Talks Open Tough Last Phase

title: Ai Qing, 86, Poet In His Native China
description: Ai Qing, one of modern China's most famous poets, died at a hospital here today. He was 86.

title: Airport Departure Delays Down Sharply
description: Departure delays at all three of New York's major airports were down sharply in the last year, thanks to the addition of more traffic controllers and changes in traffic patterns to ease bottlenecks, according to officials of the Federal Aviation Administration. But the controllers' union said staffing cuts in the last few weeks threatened to reverse these gains.

title: Burundi Slayings Reported
description: The Burundi army killed more than 200 people, most of them women and children, in an operation in central Burundi late last month, aid workers in the area said today.

title: SOCCER;Coach's Quick Moves Give MetroStars Victory
description: How could a MetroStars team that couldn't score in nearly three games suddenly turn into a goal-a-minute club?

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Rights Official Complains
description: The director of the borough and township of Princeton's Joint Commission on Civil Rights contends that his own civil rights have been violated. Ovie E. Lattimore was reduced to part-time status without benefits on March 11. He sued the borough and township last month, maintaining that the action against him was racially motivated, said his lawyer, Edward J. Boccher. In the suit, Mr. Lattimore, who is black, accuses officials of retaliating against him for helping parents of minority high school students who filed discrimination complaints in February.

title: Abortion-Rights Supporters Fight for Their Say in G.O.P.
description: As debate has flared up among the Republican Party's Christian right politicians over how to oppose abortion, no one is more engrossed than Senator Olympia J. Snowe, who could not agree less with the anti-abortion partisans who have long dictated each jot and tittle of her party's position.

title: Metro Matters;Looking Back, And Forward, With Shanker
description: ALBERT SHANKER knows better than most what to expect from tomorrow's election of community school boards. The president of the American Federation of Teachers knows that corrupt school board members will be re-elected, that hardly anybody will vote and that those who do will be flummoxed by the complex ballots.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: First Brands Corp., Danbury, Conn., to the McCann-Erickson New York unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos. as agency of record on its consolidated national media buying account, with billings estimated at $40 million. Those duties had been divided among McCann New York; the Leo Burnett Co., Chicago, and the New York office of Young & Rubicam Inc. * Euro RSCG Dahlin Smith White, Salt Lake City, which is majority owned by Havas Advertising, to SFM Media, New York, to handle the agency's broadcast media buying for accounts with billings that Advertising Age estimated at $30 million to $40 million. Those duties had been handled by Western International Media, Los Angeles, which is owned by the Interpublic Group of Cos.

title: Christopher Bird, 68, a Best-Selling Author
description: Christopher Bird, a writer whose books "The Secret Life of Plants" and "The Divining Hand: The 500-Year-Old Mystery of Dowsing" drew good-natured skepticism and some praise from critics, died on Thursday in a Blairsville, Ga., hospital. He was 68 and lived in Blairsville.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Bus Fuel: Diesel or Gas?
description: While some transit companies in the metropolitan area have been buying buses powered with natural gas, New Jersey Transit added 175 buses powered with dirtier diesel fuel to its fleet in April 1995. But now, two Assemblymen, Anthony Impreviduto, Democrat of Secaucus, and Richard H. Bagger, Republic of Westfield, are sponsoring legislation to force the transit company to give up diesel.

title: Patents;Backyard summer heat got you down? Feeling as if you're in a daze? Hey, get into a fog instead.
description: IF the backyard is too sweltering for a barbecue this summer or the state fair offers no respite from the sun, never fear -- two California inventors have patented a device that can cool a hot day.

title: Donald Fink, 84, Pioneer in TV Technology
description: Donald Glen Fink, an engineer who worked to advance television technology beginning in the 1940's, died on Friday at Northern Westchester Hospital Center in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 84 and a longtime resident of Somers, N.Y.

title: Campaign Attack Ads
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Rachel Cox, 92, Expert on Children
description: Dr. Rachel Dunaway Cox, an emeritus professor of education and psychology at Bryn Mawr College who was a leader in the field of child development, died on April 24 at the Quadrangle, a retirement village in Haverford, Pa. She was 92.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Omnicom Unit Wins 25 Clio Awards
description: For the second consecutive year, Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco has won the most awards at the Clio Awards ceremony.

title: Affirmative Action Is No Bar to Ambition
description: To the Editor:

title: Merchants Dry Out From the Fickle Flood
description: On the morning after, Ingrid Pascual mourned her boutique's soggy stockings, Irene Braunstein wailed over her store's rusting buttons and Rita Zaman squish-squished across the waterlogged carpet in the entrance of her card shop.

title: Journalism Education Less Focused On the News
description: Journalism school graduates are the lowest-paid college-educated workers joining the labor force. They are also increasingly likely to have been trained by people with doctorates, but with little or no experience as reporters or editors.

title: India's 'Avenging Angel': Candidate of Low Castes
description: No candidate in India's current election has stirred more passion than Phoolan Devi, a onetime desperado and jailbird. Her passage from violent banditry in the rugged country of central India to would-be legislator for a lower-caste party -- "from trigger-puller to crowd-puller," as one Indian newspaper put it -- has angered about as many Indians as it has pleased.

title: A.A.R.P.'s Members Can't Trust Its Advice
description: To the Editor:

title: Memorial for Dale Harris
description: Dances by Twyla Tharp, Merce Cunningham and Mark Morris are to be performed in a free public memorial service for Dale Harris, a dance and music writer who died on March 14, today at 5:30 P.M. at the Great Hall at Cooper Union, Seventh Street and Third Avenue, in the East Village. Also to appear are the American String Quartet, the performance artist Valda Setterfield and the song-and-dance team of David Vaughan and Al Carmines.

title: Filling In Cabby's Verbal Pothole;50 Courteous Responses Added to Driver Repertory
description: Madam (sir), is there any particular route you would like today?"

title: World News Briefs;Threats Force Transfer Of Tasmanian Suspect
description: The man accused of killing 35 people in Tasmania a week ago was moved from a hospital to a prison today. Hospital workers had received death threats because they were treating him.

title: Advertising;Goldberg Moser O'Neill joins the Lowe Group in a bozo-free zone.
description: GOLDBERG MOSER O'NEILL, a creatively focused, independent San Francisco agency that boasts the motto "No bozos," has said yes to affiliating with the Lowe Group, a creatively focused, worldwide agency network also known for declaring itself a bozo-free zone.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;One Man Is Fine, If He's Jordan
description: For the Knicks, there was too much from Michael Jordan, too little from John Starks and too many wasted opportunities in the game's final minutes.

title: Discriminating Liberals
description: This month marks the 100th anniversary of one of the most shameful episodes in American jurisprudence: the Supreme Court's decision on May 18, 1896, in Plessy v. Ferguson, which upheld the pernicious "separate but equal" doctrine.

title: Pitfalls vs. Promise in Training by CD-ROM
description: They are driving New Jersey Transit buses, pitching proposals to dour superiors at GE Capital and checking for paint irregularities on cars rolling down Ford Motor's assembly lines -- well, virtually doing those things, anyway, using multimedia technology.

title: San Francisco Radio Deal
description: The Evergreen Media Corporation has agreed to buy the San Francisco radio station KYLD-FM from Crescent Communications L.P. for $44 million. Evergreen, which currently owns 34 radio stations, including 2 others in San Francisco, is operating the station under a special agreement that will remain in effect until the Federal Communications Commission rules on the transaction. Evergreen already owns K-101 and KMEL in San Francisco.

title: BASEBALL;Pettitte Is Sharp, On and Off The Mound
description: Andy Pettitte was extremely calm, incredibly loose and quite humorous while constantly criticizing himself before he had thrown one pitch yesterday. Pettitte poked fun at himself for surrendering nine runs in one inning in his last start in Baltimore, promised reliever Scott Kamieniecki he would get some action and lamented how earned run averages have inflated.

title: Japanese Markets Closed
description: Japanese stock markets were closed today in observance of Children's Day. In a holiday-shortened week last week, the Nikkei index of 225 issues lost a total of 572.65 points, to 21,662.38.

title: Taking In the Sites;Where to Go on Vacation If Granny's Isn't an Option
description: So vacation time is coming up again. Let's see. You've done Disney, run out of relatives and cannot freeload on any more friends. Let's try something different: A quick check of the usual search engines.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;A Top Appointment At Saatchi & Saatchi
description: Joe Cronin, president and chief executive of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising/Pacific in Torrance, Calif., has been named to the additional new position of vice chairman at Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide, which is a unit of Cordiant P.L.C. Mr. Cronin, 51, will also continue to serve as worldwide account director on the agency's large Toyota Motor Corporation of America account. This is the first top appointment by John Fitzgerald since he joined Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising in New York in January as president and chief operating officer.

title: Offerings Scheduled This Week For Equities and Debt Issues
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: House Republican Leaders Return D'Amato's Salvo on Strategies
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich and his loyal No. 2, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, returned fire today at criticism leveled against the policies and practices of the House Republicans they lead. They were not, however, responding to some partisan salvo from Democrats but to the rather blunt criticism last week from Alfonse M. D'Amato, New York's Republican Senator.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It might seem an unlikely cause for the Ambassador of Thailand to the United States to adopt: helping repair the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal in Washington, which was damaged by floodwaters in January.

title: Disturbance Near Campus
description: A street party off the campus of the University of Akron erupted into violence early Saturday when members of the crowd pelted the police with beer bottles and screamed, "Gas us," as officers sprayed tear and pepper gas to break up the group. Twelve people were arrested.

title: FIRST HAGUE TRIAL FOR BOSNIA CRIMES OPENS ON TUESDAY
description: The first international war crimes trials since those that judged German and Japanese leaders after World War II begin on Tuesday in The Hague, part of an effort by outside powers to provide a measure of justice for the thousands of massacred and maimed innocents in the former Yugoslavia.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Great Adventure Grows
description: Tired of its status as a one-day destination, Six Flags Great Adventure Theme Park wants to become another Walt Disney World. Hoping to transform itself into a year-round resort, the theme park is planning a $200 million expansion over the next five years, Mayor Peter H. Carlson of Jackson Township said yesterday.

title: Cellular Spinoff Finds Success Overseas
description: Sam Ginn was startled when the telephone rang in his sprawling corner office here at 5:30 A.M. on April 1. The caller was his former deputy, Philip J. Quigley, now the chairman of the Pacific Telesis Group. And the message was stunning: Pacific Telesis had just announced that it would sell itself to SBC Communications in the first marriage of two regional Bell telephone companies.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the tentative release dates for major economic indicators this week.

title: Legal Services Survives, Barely
description: The budget bill signed by President Clinton last week after months of bargaining between the White House and Congressional Republicans deals two blows to the American ideal of equal justice. It slashes funding for the Legal Services Corporation -- the 21-year-old federally financed program that helps poor people with their civil legal problems. It also imposes restrictions that will further impede the program's effectiveness.

title: Chess? 1,700 Youngsters Show Fervor
description: Josephine Valenzuela, a second-grade girl with an oversized Chicago Cubs hat flopping over her forehead, could barely see over the table edge. She almost had to look up at the pieces on the chessboard in front of her. But that did not keep her from winning her fourth consecutive game at the National Elementary Chess Championships here this weekend.

title: ON PRO BASKETBALL;Their Seesaw Battle: One Team's Star Rises While the Other's Falls
description: There are games in the playoffs when all the analysis, all the post-mortems, add up to a whole lot of noise and the only thing that ultimately matters is which leading man made the meaningful shots and which one didn't. Which one dealt with the pressure and seized the moment and which one bounced it off the rim or out of bounds.

title: HORSE RACING;Just Five Derby Horses Named to the Preakness
description: Only 5 of the 19 horses who ran in the Kentucky Derby were named today as starters in the Preakness, and three of them were trained by D. Wayne Lukas, who flooded the Derby with five colts and won it with Grindstone by the length of a nose.

title: Sympathies Sharply Divided On Beatings of 2 Immigrants
description: Nearly a month after a television news crew here videotaped the clubbing of two Mexicans by sheriff's deputies, the incident continues to transfix Californians, generating extraordinary soul-searching over the issue of illegal immigration.

title: Next, Eliminate New York School Boards
description: To the Editor:

title: Housing Voucher Idea Is Bad for New York
description: To the Editor:

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;Wregget's Playoff Run Hits a Pothole
description: Until today, he had handled the perils of playoff pressure by maintaining picture-perfect goalie vision, eagle-eyed and quick-gloved.

title: In America;Back to the Streets
description: Chris Owen is worried about his son, Richard, who is 38 years old. Several years ago Richard Owen had a mental breakdown. He is unable to work. He slips with alarming frequency into zones inaccessible to those around him. At times, for no apparent reason, he will begin to weep uncontrollably. Sometimes he will rock back and forth, back and forth, unable to stop. He has been hospitalized on a number of occasions.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Black Ministers Plan Rally
description: Nearly seven months after the Million Man March in Washington, the Black Ministers Council of New Jersey is sponsoring a follow-up rally in Trenton today that they hope will attract 10,000 black families from New Jersey. The Rev. Reginald T. Jackson, of St. Matthew African Methodist Episcopal Church in Orange, who leads the council, said the rally would emphasize the black family as a unit. "This march is to be for men, women and children," Mr. Jackson said.

title: Bridge
description: Once a year, in early May, New York City becomes the capital of the international bridge world. Competing in the Cavendish Invitational Pairs next Saturday and Sunday at Loews New York Hotel, at 569 Lexington Avenue, will be 80 players from 11 countries: Brazil, Britain, Canada, France, Israel, Italy, Pakistan, Poland, Sweden, Turkey and the United States. Thirty of them have been first or second in world championships, and 30 others have strong international credentials.

title: An After-School Job That's Not Kids' Stuff;Wanted: Web Designers and Programmers; $25/hr.; Need Parents' Consent
description: When the school day ends at 2:15 P.M., Jascha Franklin-Hodge ambles out of the red-brick edifice of Brookline High School and makes the uphill trek on Tappan Street, heading for work. In another time, his after-school job probably would have been delivering newspapers or pumping gas.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;44-Point Statement: The Stage Is Jordan's
description: He coolly hit his shots, exchanged heated words with Derek Harper and unintentionally gave Patrick Ewing and his teammates false hope, removing himself from the game on occasion to rest his aching body.

title: Fistful of Praise and Clips At Clint Eastwood Tribute
description: There's a rebel lying deep in my soul," Clint Eastwood remarked years ago. "Anytime anybody tells me the trend is such and such, I go in the opposite direction. I hate the idea of trends. I hate imitation. I have a reverence for individuality."

title: GOLF;L.P.G.A.'s Top Rookie Is Special On Sunday
description: Well, a blond golfer from Queensland, Australia, finally won a green jacket today. It wasn't Greg Norman and it wasn't the Masters, but it was the best young Aussie golfer to come along in a long time winning one of the Ladies' Professional Golf Association's biggest tournaments.

title: Do Rivers Have Rights?
description: To the Editor:

title: F.D.R. Memorial Has Lessons in 'Disability Cool'
description: To the Editor:

title: World News Briefs;  Pension Dispute Silences Song of Gondoliers
description: Venice's gondoliers, who usually serenade their customers as they steer them through the city's romantic canals, stopped singing today because of a dispute over pensions.

title: Technology: ON THE NET;With a credit card and a modem, a search for commerce on the World Wide Web. Like a child's story, it could begin, 'Once upon a time . . .'
description: THERE was no way of knowing it back in May 1963. But a science book in the first-grade classroom at the Possum School would color my adult views of Utopian visions of technology in general, and of the World Wide Web in particular.

title: H. van Ameringen, Philanthropist, 95
description: Hedwig Adele van Ameringen, a philanthropist who was a major supporter of the New York Philharmonic, died on April 27 at her home in Manhattan. She was 95.

title: MAJOR CRIMES FELL IN '95, EARLY DATA BY F.B.I. INDICATE
description: Serious crimes dropped across the nation in 1995 for the fourth consecutive year, led by an 8 percent decrease in homicides, according to preliminary figures released yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Race for School Posts In New York City
description: When the polls open at 6 A.M. tomorrow in New York City's 32 community school districts, voters will choose from a field of candidates that is smaller than any since the boards were created in 1969. The elections, with no single issue to lure candidates or voters, come as officials wrestle with how to reinvent what critics call an unwieldy, inefficient and often corrupt system.

title: F.D.R. Memorial Has Lessons in 'Disability Cool'
description: To the Editor:

title: In Performance
description: CLASSICAL MUSIC Flippers and Hangers Ready, A String Quartet Can Begin Le Quatuor Florence Gould Hall

title: Nigeria's Waiting Game
description: Nigeria's military rulers seem to assume that their country's oil and other investment opportunities will give the United States and Europe pause about protesting the suppression of democracy and civil liberties in Nigeria. Regrettably, their strategy is working.

title: Thomas Picks Villanova
description: Tim Thomas, the 6-foot-10-inch basketball standout from Paterson Catholic High School in New Jersey, has given a verbal commitment to Villanova University for the 1996-97 school year, according to his mother, Dorothy.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Midori Shares the Stage but Continues on Her Own Course
description: The time-honored philosophical injunction "know thyself" undoubtedly carries special resonance for prodigy performers as they try to separate mature motivations of their own from the old, familiar urgings of parents, teachers and fans. And although the transition has held bumps for the superb young violinist Midori, 24, she seems to grow with each hearing into a greater self-awareness.

title: Roll Over, Pearl Jam, Classical Radio Lives
description: Before radio had formats or ratings, before drive time, before pop, or rock, or talk or shock jocks, it had classical music. And just as radio has found a quiet place for itself in the cacophony of technological revolutions since 1906, classical music is doing quite nicely in the Arbitron-driven world of radio today.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Jail Unlikely for Taylor
description: The former Giants star LAWRENCE TAYLOR, arrested Friday night after police said he tried to buy crack cocaine from an undercover officer, probably will not go to jail if he is convicted.

title: Rights Panel For Europe Stirs Anger In Britain
description: Seven years ago, the British Board of Film Classification banned Nigel Wingrove's video "Visions of Ecstasy," saying its graphic scenes of Jesus having sex with a Carmelite nun violated Britain's centuries-old law against blasphemy.

title: World News Briefs;18 Killed in Earthquake In Inner Mongolia Region
description: An earthquake in Inner Mongolia has killed at least 18 people, and Chinese rescue workers put up more than 10,000 tents to help shelter an estimated 200,000 people affected by the quake, local officials said today.

title: Service Is Restored on Subway After Water Main Break
description: Subways in Manhattan resumed normal service yesterday and city officials predicted only minor inconveniences in this morning's rush hour as an army of workers mopped up the soggy detritus of a water main rupture in midtown and sought to pinpoint its cause.

title: Media: TELEVISION;Entrepreneurs race big cable companies to get new cable services to viewers.
description: HUNDREDS of new cable services are on the drawing boards, from the privately owned My Pet TV and the Love Channel to Nick at Nite's TV Land and the News Corporation's Fox News Network. The owners of these services have been banking on the arrival of the digital boxes that would let cable operators offer 500 channels.

title: Next, Eliminate New York School Boards
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the disappearance of William E. Colby, former Director of Central Intelligence, gave an incorrect guide to the pronunciation of the Wicomico River, where he took his canoe on a ride. It is why-KAHM-ih-koh, not wic-o-MIC-oh.

title: F.D.R. Memorial Has Lessons in 'Disability Cool'
description: To the Editor:

title: Microsoft's Dealers to Sell Over Internet
description: The Microsoft Corporation plans to make its software products widely available for purchase over the Internet.

title: Behind Some Fraternity Walls, Brothers in Crime
description: No one was supposed to know that John Higdon almost died that night three years ago -- not the national office of the fraternity that nearly killed him, not the University of Georgia, where he was a student, not his parents, and certainly not the public.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Examining the Issue of Priests and Sexuality
description: Nicolas Kent, the producer of "Naked Hollywood" and "Naked News," resisted what must have been a powerful temptation to call his latest documentary "Naked Priests" and settled for the next best thing. "Priestly Sins: Sex and the Church" looks into the matter of celibacy, or lack of it, among the Roman Catholic clergy. Unfortunately, Mr. Kent did not resist using trite television effects (eerie slow motion, peculiar colors, fuzzy pictures and spooky music), which give a tabloid tinge to an otherwise sobering report.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Changing Face Of Supermarket Magazine Sales
description: If this were an article in a supermarket checkout magazine, the headline might read: Mag Business Blowout! Distributors Dumped As Biggies Buy Control.

title: Man Charged in Assault of Brooklyn Couple
description: A 34-year-old man was arrested and charged yesterday with beating and robbing a Brooklyn couple, and attempting to rape the woman, the police said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: A $76 Million Deal For Biondi at MCA Frank J. Biondi Jr., who was dismissed as chief executive of Viacom, has negotiated many big-money deals. Not the least of them is the pay package he is getting from his new employer, MCA; a consultant says it is worth $76 million over five years. [Page D2.]

title: On Time in Full Skies
description: The skies of the New York City region are chronically crowded, but delays at all three major airports are down sharply, thanks to the addition of more air traffic controllers and changes in traffic patterns to ease bottlenecks, according to the Federal Aviation Administration. But the controllers' union says that staffing cuts threaten to reverse these gains.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Schott on Hitler
description: MARGE SCHOTT once again is praising the start of Adolf Hitler's term as German chancellor.

title: CHRONICLE
description: EDWARD BLEIER is a man who certainly knows how to keep a secret -- even from his wife, MAGDA PALACCI BLEIER. Mrs. Bleier is chairwoman of an American Diabetes Association benefit that is to feature the premiere of "Twister," a film produced by Steven Spielberg, followed by a dinner at Tavern on the Green.

title: Copenhagen Journal;Biker Wars in the Land of 'The Little Mermaid'
description: The hum of business at Copenhagen's smoothly efficient airport was broken by bursts of automatic weapons fire one afternoon recently. Members of the Hell's Angels motorcycle gang were ambushing a group of rival bikers returning from abroad. They killed one and seriously wounded two others.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Area Code Plans Are Spurned
description: The Board of Public Utilities is weighing two alternatives for creating additional area code capacity, but the organization representing the state's cities and towns dislikes both of them. "There is absolutely no justification" for requiring residents to dial into another area code to reach numbers in the same municipality, William G. Dressel Jr., executive director of the New Jersey State League of Municipalities, said last week in a letter to the utility board chairman, Herman H. Tate Jr. Bell Atlantic Corporation has proposed adding area codes within the 201 and 908 regions for new customers only. The utility board is also considering a plan to carve up the 201 and 908 regions into four area codes.

title: Program Helping Find Nonpaying Parents
description: A two-month-old statewide program created to track down parents who fail to pay child support has found 17,500 people so far and will probably garner $14 million in payments to children within a year, Gov. George E. Pataki said at a news conference yesterday.

title: Silent Issues And Few Choices Mark Election For School Posts
description: When the polls open at 6 A.M. tomorrow in New York City's 32 community school districts, voters will choose from a field of candidates that is smaller than any since the local boards were created in 1969.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;217 Lawyers Disciplined
description: A total of 217 New Jersey lawyers were publicly disciplined last year for infractions that included theft, bribery, forgery, drug use and making crude gestures in court, according to an annual report by the State Supreme Court's Office of Attorney Ethics. Of those penalized, 32 were disbarred and 102 were suspended. In 1995, 60,648 lawyers practiced in New Jersey, up from 22,000 in 1980, the report said.

title: Getting on Track to the Airport
description: New Yorkers have dreamed for decades of a rail link that would zip airline passengers between Manhattan and the city's two airports both quickly and cheaply. At least 20 schemes for trains to the planes have died over the last 30 years for lack of leadership, cooperation, political support or money. Now the Port Authority proposes to build a light-rail segment that would carry passengers from Kennedy International Airport to the Long Island Railroad, which would then carry them into Manhattan. The plan has been endorsed by Gov. George Pataki but criticized by Mayor Rudolph Giuliani.

title: BASEBALL;Smashing Homer by Sosa Defeats Mets in the Ninth
description: If Sammy Sosa had his druthers, he would probably like to see all 162 of the Cubs' games played against the Mets. Then again, the houses across Waveland Avenue probably could not survive the damage.

title: Higher and Drier, Illinois Town Is Reborn
description: It is a season of firsts in this little town 25 miles from St. Louis. The first school prom. The first church bell. The first community garage sale. The first grass.

title: ON BASEBALL;The Sun Never Sets On the Dodgers' Talent
description: Okotarite migake zariseba hikari

title: In Performance
description: POP Of Dopey, Disingenuous Men And the Power of Rock Lush Irving Plaza

title: I.B.M., in Its Dress Shoes, Chases Software Success
description: When John M. Thompson, chief of software at I.B.M., wanted to let his hair down at a Florida meeting of the company's new Lotus division earlier this year, he donned a canary yellow Lotus polo shirt. But true to his roots, Mr. Thompson, who is 53, wore his standard I.B.M. blue blazer over it. The clashing attire seemed to symbolize the challenge facing Mr. Thompson, a career I.B.M. executive whom many in the industry consider ill suited for the role that has been thrust upon him: to reverse a tide of expensive and embarrassing software flops over the last 15 years and push the company to the fore of the fastest-growing and most lucrative segment of the computer industry.

title: No Headline
description: Some things you didn't want to repeat, like junked cars and people who didn't keep the grass mowed." LAURIE BROWN, village clerk, on rebuilding Valmeyer, Ill., from scratch. [B7:4]

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;Rangers Show Iron And Tie the Series
description: Along with being talented, self-assured and highly paid, the Rangers are also considerate. They must have known that some of their fans wanted to watch the Knicks-Bulls basketball game on television late this afternoon. So they saw to it that their hockey game was decided early.

title: With Fortune Built, Packard Heirs Look To Build a Legacy
description: At the very summit of American philanthropy, where the billionaire donors have dynastic titles like Ford and Kellogg and Rockefeller, the first high-tech mogul is about to add his name to the roster of the world's great family charities: Packard.

title: F.D.R. Memorial Has Lessons in 'Disability Cool'
description: To the Editor:

title: HORSE RACING;Lite the Fuse Takes Carter
description: Julie Krone did not have a mount in Saturday's Kentucky Derby, but she did have a tremendous weekend at Belmont Park, capping a sweep of the weekend stakes by riding Lite the Fuse to a hard-fought victory over Flying Chevron yesterday in the $150,000 Carter Handicap. It was Lite the Fuse's second straight victory in the Grade I race.

title: For Freshmen, Fund Raising Has Yielded Big Results
description: With the fate of their large freshman class crucial to continued control of the House, Republican leaders and friendly political action committees have given the class of '94 lopsided financial advantages over their Democratic challengers.

title: Affirmative Action Is No Bar to Ambition
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A brief article by Bloomberg Business News in Business Day on Friday about a reorganization of the radio division of Capital Cities/ABC Inc., a unit of the Walt Disney Company, omitted part of the name of the president of WPLJ-FM and WABC-AM. He is John Mitchell Dolan, not John Mitchell.

title: Israeli Army Says Mapping Errors Led to Shelling of a U.N. Base inLebanon
description: The Israeli army said today that its investigation had found that mapping errors were behind the shelling of a United Nations camp that killed nearly 100 Lebanese refugees last month. Artillery gunners were relying on incorrect maps and distance estimates when they fired at Hezbollah guerrillas attacking Israeli troops, senior army officers said.

title: For San Francisco Papers, Big Story Proves Elusive
description: This was a time-bomb of a week for employees of San Francisco's two daily newspapers, but the expected explosion -- word that the two papers would merge and hundreds of workers would be laid off -- never came.

title: Psychotherapy and Managed Care Don't Mesh
description: To the Editor:

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Canada Premier Faces Assault Charge, Briefly
description: Prime Minister Jean Chretien was charged with assault Monday for grabbing a protester in February, but Quebec's justice minister swiftly quashed the charge.

title: Jewish Gauchos Had Counterparts in U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: N.H.L. PLAYOFFS;Rangers Cannot Afford To Relax After Victory
description: The Rangers are where they want to be, in the driver's seat and not the back seat, Coach Colin Campbell said this afternoon as his Rangers prepared for Tuesday night's third game of the Eastern Conference semifinal series with the Pittsburgh Penguins.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Seeking Beckett Through His Words
description: Among the pleasures of "Waiting for Beckett" are snatches of Zero Mostel and Burgess Meredith in the first television production of "Waiting for Godot"; Patrick Magee listening with desperate anguish to "Krapp's Last Tape"; Jack MacGowran, as the tramp Molloy, delivering his great soliloquy on the sucking stones, and Billie Whitelaw, up to her chin in sand, ending her "Happy Days."

title: CBS Plans to Offer Time to Candidates In Presidential Race
description: CBS announced yesterday that it would provide free television time to the Presidential candidates for campaign statements in the final days before the November election. The time will be made available during CBS's news programs, network officials said, not during prime-time entertainment hours.

title: Bell Labs Operating System To Be Offered for Networks
description: Lucent Technologies, which was formed by the recent split-up of AT&T, said today that it would soon begin marketing an operating system developed by Bell Labs for use on interactive networks.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Wilkinson Returns to Bengals' Minicamp
description: Defensive tackle DAN WILKINSON, who left the Cincinnati Bengals' minicamp shortly after Coach DAVE SHULA criticized his conditioning, returned yesterday after talking with an assistant coach. TIM KRUMRIE, the defensive line coach, called Wilkinson on Sunday night at his home and urged him to return to the team's workouts.

title: David Lasser, 94, a Space and a Social Visionary
description: David Lasser, an immigrant's son whose vision of the future inspired men to build and fly rockets to the heavens and whose concern for life on earth impelled him to champion and organize the unemployed during the Great Depression, died on Sunday at the Remington Senior Care Facility in Rancho Bernardo, Calif., a San Diego suburb. Mr. Lasser, who lived in Rancho Bernardo, was 94.

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: United States

title: COMPANY NEWS;HORSEHEAD RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT TO GO PRIVATE
description: The Horsehead Resource Development Company said yesterday that it intended to buy all of its common stock held by the public for $5.75 a share, so the company could be taken private. The repurchase would be made through a cash tender offer to public stockholders to begin within the next several days, the company said. Horsehead Resource is currently owned 50.3 percent by Horsehead Industries Inc., 44.9 percent by B.U.S. Berzelius Umwelt-Service A.G. and 4.8 percent by public stockholders. Horsehead Resource has about 36 million shares outstanding. The company's stock fell to $4.125 yesterday, off $1 a share, before trading was halted.

title: Russian Says Crime May Double by 2000Rising Crime in Russia
description: The number of crimes in Russia will more than double by 2000, the country's prosecutor general predicted today.

title: In One Country, Chronic Whiplash Is Uncompensated (and Unknown)
description: IN Lithuania, rear-end collisions happen much as they do in the rest of the world. Cars crash, bumpers crumple and tempers flare. But drivers in cars that have been hit there do not seem to suffer the long-term complaints so common in other countries: the headaches or lingering neck pains that have come to be known as chronic whiplash, or whiplash syndrome.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Dr. Kevorkian Says His Trial Is a Lynching
description: A combative Dr. Jack Kevorkian repeatedly lashed out today at the prosecutor cross-examining him in his latest assisted-suicide trial, denouncing not only the prosecution but also the state of society itself.

title: NatWest in Talks to Buy Greenwich Capital
description: The National Westminster Bank P.L.C. is in talks to acquire the bond trading firm Greenwich Capital Markets Inc., people involved in the transaction, who insisted on anonymity, said yesterday.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Norway's Biggest Bank Posts Improved Results
description: Den Norske Bank A.S., Norway's largest bank, said yesterday that its operating profit after bad-debt charges rose 5 percent over the corresponding quarter last year, aided by a decline in costs. Operating profit after bad-debt charges rose to 783 million kroner ($119.5 million) from 746 million in last year's quarter. Operating costs fell 24 million kroner ($3.7 million), to 1.135 billion ($173.2 million), the bank said.

title: Caracas Journal;After a Beauty Crown, Now the Jewel of City Hall
description: Fifteen years after Irene Saez marched down the runway as Miss Universe, dazzling in her crown and roses, the former beauty queen reigns over a borough of Caracas that is fast becoming a theme park in good government.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;ABC Downsizing Name
description: The Walt Disney Company's Capital Cities/ABC unit will shorten its name to ABC later this year, the president of Cap Cities, Robert A. Iger, said yesterday in an employee newsletter. "As a division instead of a corporation, it probably makes more sense to call ourselves ABC," he said.

title: By Design;For a Silvery Summer
description: Gold is warm. Silver is cool. Which is why the fall collections were filled with glints of gold, while silver is the standard for spring and summer.

title: N.H.L. PLAYOFFS;Chicago Wins In Overtime
description: Sergei Krivokrasov, shifted to the top line after Tony Amonte suffered a third-period injury, scored 46 seconds into overtime tonight, lifting the Chicago Blackhawks to a 4-3 victory over the Colorado Avalanche in the National Hockey League playoffs.

title: U.S.-Mexican Border: A Shifting Line in the Mud
description: Some people in Washington want to seal the border completely, while some in Mexico City want to use it as a pretext for condemning imperialistic brutality. Alton L. Goff and Alfredo Martinez Orantes only want to know exactly where that emotionally charged line between the United States and Mexico really is.

title: Hormone Has Role in Simian AIDS
description: ASEX hormone whose levels normally soar in the second half of the menstrual cycle can vastly increase a female monkey's chances of getting infected with a monkey version of AIDS, researchers report.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Clinton Visits State, Again
description: President Clinton will travel to New Jersey considered a swing state in the November elections -- today for the third time since February. Mr. Clinton will visit Woodbridge High School to deliver an anti-smoking address to 3,000 students and other residents to mark a national event called "Kick Butts" day. Dr. Leroy Seitz, superintendent of schools in Woodbridge, said students would be asked to sign pledges not to smoke. Tonight, the President will attend Democratic fund-raisers in New Vernon and Jersey City. TERRY PRISTIN

title: F.B.I. Scare Tactics
description: Meteorologists add the wind-chill factor to their winter weather forecasts to make the actual temperature seem worse than it is. Likewise, when the F.B.I. reported on Sunday that serious crime had declined slightly for the fourth year in a row, it was still making the statistics sound worse than they actually were. That's because the Government tends to exaggerate the violent nature of crime.

title: Varity and Lucas in Talks To Combine Some Businesses
description: The Varity Corporation and Lucas Industries, responding to demands from auto makers for more efficient suppliers, said they might combine some of their businesses.

title: Clinton Backs Republicans' Bill on Tax Credit for Adoptions
description: Endorsing an element of the Republicans' Contract With America, President Clinton today threw his support behind legislation that would provide a sizable tax credit for all but the wealthiest families who adopt children.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Of Writers, Fickle Fame And the Enemy Within
description: FAME AND FOLLY Essays By Cynthia Ozick 289 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $26.

title: POLITICAL BRIEFS: North Carolina;Close Races to Face Tough Incumbents
description: North Carolina's voters will decide today whether to give Harvey Gantt, the first black Mayor of Charlotte,another shot at Senator Jesse Helms this fall.

title: Unemployment Off in Germany
description: Germany's Federal Labor Office reported today that unemployment fell in April for the first time in nine months.

title: Damage in Trees Tied to Heavy Metals in Air
description: A GROUP of scientists working in the mountain forests of northern New York and New England has uncovered new evidence that toxic heavy metals in polluted air can contribute to the decline and death of some types of trees.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Hong Kong Phone Shares Rally on Takeover Talk
description: Shares in Hong Kong's biggest telephone company, Hong Kong Telecommunications Ltd., rose as much as 4 percent yesterday amid speculation that China might increase its stake. Traders said the company was ripe for a takeover after talks between its parent, Cable and Wireless P.L.C., and British Telecommunications P.L.C. broke down last week.

title: Profits of Immigration
description: To the Editor:

title: Caste Loyalties, Democratic Promises
description: When I was in college in New Delhi in the mid-1970's, I believed, along with most of my peers, that India's caste system was a moldering relic that would soon succumb to the pressures of modernization. Our country was, after all, the world's most populous democracy, and democratic egalitarianism seemed to be the natural enemy of caste and its rigid social hierarchies.

title: Classics By Bolshoi Veterans
description: Deja vu and not bad at all. That, in a nutshell, is one verdict on the program presented on Sunday night by a troupe billed rightly or wrongly (actually wrongly) as "Stars of the Bolshoi Ballet."

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: CURRENCY MARKETS;National Holidays Curb Trading And Dollar Ends Little Changed
description: The dollar was little changed yesteday in light trading caused by national holidays in Britain and Japan.

title: Alaska Senate Passes $1 Cigarette-Tax Rise
description: The Alaska Senate voted 17 to 3 today today to raise the state's tax on cigarettes by $1 a pack, making it the nation's highest tobacco tax. A similar increase would also apply to other tobacco products.

title: BASEBALL;Yankees Concerned as Cone Still Feels Numbness
description: The normally talkative David Cone left Yankee Stadium without a word yesterday afternoon, pondering his baseball future after the Yankees revealed that his mysterious circulatory condition had not improved appreciably and that he would miss at least one start while having critical tests today.

title: First-Ever Re-creation Of New Species' Birth
description: CONTEMPLATING the pageant of evolution, biologists have long wondered how much of a role chance played in determining history's course. If researchers could turn back the clock and allow life to evolve again and again, would leaping frogs and blooming orchids always reappear? Or might evolution's path, punctuated by asteroid crashes and random genetic mutations, meander to produce something altogether different?

title: Assembly Speaker Intensifies Attacks on Pataki Over Budget
description: With the state's budget now six weeks late, the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, stepped up his attacks against Gov. George E. Pataki today, accusing him of trying to undermine public schools and of paying skimpy attention to the stalled budget negotiations.

title: Psychotherapy and Managed Care Don't Mesh
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Kentucky Losing Walker to Pros
description: The sophomore forward ANTOINE WALKER said yesterday that he would not return for his junior season with the national champion Kentucky Wildcats. Walker said at a news conference in Lexington, Ky., that he needed to do something for his family and especially for his mother, who has worked hard to raise the family.

title: Study Details CUNY Successes From Open-Admissions Policy
description: The open-admissions policy that 25 years ago transformed the City University of New York by guaranteeing entry to almost all New York City high school graduates was far more successful in educating needy students than earlier research suggested, according to a new long-term study of thousands of students.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Bodies Burned in Park
description: A motorist on Route 22 called the police yesterday to report a brush fire in Weequahic Park. But firefighters found something much worse: the bound bodies of a man and a woman, burning beneath a pile of leaves. The man had been stabbed several times and the woman strangled, the Essex County Police Director, Martin Hellwig, said, but investigators were not sure if they had been killed before being tied up with wire and set aflame. The bodies have not been identified, but neither was burned badly enough to make identification impossible, Mr. Hellwig said.

title: CHRONICLE
description: For a press agent, MERLE DEBUSKEY was sounding uncharacteristically skittish yesterday over the idea of getting some ink.

title: BASEBALL;The Mets Cannot Get Well In Florida
description: A three-game series with the Florida Marlins figured to be just the thing the Mets needed to erase two stunning defeats in Chicago and begin their climb back to a .500 record. After all, the Marlins had lost five straight games and seven of their last eight. But instead of Florida curing the Mets' troubles, it was the Mets who proved to be the antidote for what was ailing the Marlins.

title: Russia's Communists Have New, Mixed Manifesto
description: Yuri D. Maslyukov took another puff from his cigarette and smiled about his recent meeting with a senior official from the International Monetary Fund.

title: Fierce Struggle in Southwest Tinderbox
description: As drought and hot, dry winds create what are being called the most volatile conditions ever in the pine forests here, hundreds of firefighters converged on northern New Mexico today to help fight the latest major blaze to break out in the Southwest.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Professor Charged in Death
description: A mathematics professor at Rutgers University was charged yesterday with bludgeoning his wife to death. Walter Petryshyn, 67, was arrested after police officers responding to a 911 call from the couple's home found Arcadia Petryshyn dead.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Warnaco Plans Hathaway Sale And a Charge
description: The Warnaco Group said yesterday that it would stop making Hathaway men's shirts and was seeking a buyer for the business.
