description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A
description: Callery Pears

title: It's See No Evil, Have No Harassment in Japan
description: Kiyomi Kikuchi, a new saleswoman for Central Finance, was visiting clients with a male deputy branch manager, when the man suddenly turned their car into the parking lot of a "love hotel," an establishment, common in Japan, that rents rooms to couples by the hour.

title: Former Governor Denies Candidacy
description: The name of former Gov. Richard Lamm of Colorado has become the latest bandied about as a possible Presidential standard bearer for Ross Perot's nascent third party. Butin a telephone interview yesterday, Mr. Lamm said he was not interested in the job.

title: Body of William Colby Is Found on Riverbank
description: The body of William E. Colby, the former Director of Central Intelligence, washed ashore today on the banks of the Maryland river where he made his second home, nine days after he set out in rough waters for a short solo canoe trip.

title: The 90's Version of the Decadent Look
description: While the 1980's will always be remembered as the decade of fashion's gluttonous downfall, gilt leading to guilt, 90's fashion is shaping up to be about a decadence of an entirely different kind. It may well be remembered as the decade when fashion served as a pusher -- a pusher of what appear to be the best-dressed heroin addicts in history.

title: BALLET REVIEW;An Individualistic Debut in the Title Role of 'Apollo'
description: The New York City Ballet, which is featuring four new casts in "Apollo," George Balanchine's seminal 1928 work to Stravinsky's score, presented Ethan Stiefel's debut in the title role on Saturday afternoon.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: BASKETBALL

title: School Elections
description: Polls are open today from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M. At stake are seats on the city's 32 community school boards.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about controversy at Cornell University over dormitories that focus on black, Hispanic and American Indian culture referred incorrectly to a proposal to bar freshmen from those dormitories. It is to be reviewed next year; it is not part of the general housing objectives that the university's board will consider this month.

title: Guatemala and Rebels Reach Peace Accord
description: Guatemala's leftist guerrillas signed an important accord with that country's Government today in talks here that are aimed at ending 35 years of civil war.

title: Records Tie C.I.A. Informer To Two Guatemala Killings
description: Government officials said today that classified documents strongly suggest that a Guatemalan Army colonel who was a C.I.A. informer may be guilty in connection with the 1992 killing of a guerrilla married to an American and the 1990 murder of an American innkeeper.

title: INSIDE
description: The Mummies Wore Plaid

title: Candidates Fight to Get The Attention Of Voters
description: In her bid to win re-election to the board of Community School District 22 in Brooklyn, Anne Mackinnon brought her shoestring campaign on Saturday to the busy shopping corner of Flatbush and Church Avenues.

title: Supervisor of Newark Water Agency Is Indicted in Bribery Scheme
description: As head of Newark's water and sewer agency, Carol Gardner devised a scheme in which he pocketed thousands of dollars from businesses dealing with the city and even used some of the money to buy jackets with the logo of his tavern, according to an indictment announced yesterday.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Psychotherapy and Managed Care Don't Mesh
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the Five Borough Bike Tour in New York City misidentified the scene in some editions. The picture showed cyclists on the ferry from Staten Island after completing the ride, not in Astoria Park, Queens.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS INC., Dallas, the maker of semiconductors, agreed to acquire Tartan Inc., a developer of software development tools. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Neutrinos Have Mass, but Not Enough to Hold the Universe Together
description: PHYSICISTS working with a large particle accelerator at Los Alamos National Laboratory have found fresh evidence that the neutrino -- an abundant but elusive subnuclear particle once thought to have no more mass than a ghost -- probably has some mass after all.

title: Tony Nominations Led By 'Rent' and 'Da Noise'
description: Rent," the exuberant rock opera about the lives of young bohemians on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, continued its remarkable rise yesterday, earning 10 Tony Award nominations, the most of any show in what turned out to be a plentiful year for new Broadway musicals.

title: COMPANY NEWS;INVESTMENT GROUP TO BUY SEVEN-UP PUERTO RICO UNIT
description: The Seven-Up/RC Bottling Company of Southern California Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Puerto Rico unit to an investment group for $74 million. The sale is part of an agreement last November by the bottling company to wipe out its junk-bond debt. The company, based in Vernon, Calif., expects to provide bondholders with about $50 million in net proceeds from the sale, helping it to complete the restructuring of its debt. The business, called the Seven-Up/RC Bottling Company of Puerto Rico Inc., is being sold to a group led by Center Street Capital Partners L.P., a private equity investment fund in Little Rock, Ark. The group also includes some members of the management team of the division. Seven-Up/RC Puerto Rico had 1995 sales of $82.3 million.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;2 Princetons Seek Merger
description: Throughout New Jersey, rising costs of delivering services, a stagnant tax base and cuts in state aid have prompted small towns to consider merging with larger municipalities. In a preliminary report being released today, the Joint Consolidation Study Commission of Princeton is recommending the union of Princeton borough (essentially the downtown area) and the surrounding township, Donald Stokes, the commission's co-chairman, said yesterday. The two entities currently share many services while retaining separate governments, police departments and courts.

title: Barrymore' Closes
description: Jack: A Night on the Town With John Barrymore," a one-man play with Nicol Williamson, closed after the matinee on Sunday at the Belasco Theater, 111 West 44th Street, Manhattan. The show, written by Mr. Williamson and Leslie Megahey and directed by Mr. Megahey, ran for 12 regular performances and four previews.

title: Nigeria and Cameroon Clash Over Peninsula on the Border
description: Nigerian and Cameroonian forces fought all weekend and into this morning in the latest outbreak of violence over the small Bakassi peninsula, which lies between the two countries, officials at Nigerian defense headquarters said today.

title: Veterans of Black Unit Threaten Suit Over Army's Account of TheirService
description: Pursuing a decades-old debate over the legacy of the Army's all-black regiments, a group of black veterans of the Korean War is threatening a defamation suit against the Pentagon in an effort to block publication of an official history describing failures by the Army's last black combat regiment.

title: COMPANY NEWS;UTILITIES WOULD RAISE DIVIDEND AFTER MERGER
description: The Kansas City Power and Light Company and Utilicorp United Inc. said yesterday that they would pay a higher dividend if they merged, but the amount of the proposed payout fell short of a promise from Western Resources Inc., a hostile suitor for Kansas City Power. The projected dividend of $1.85 a share would be 18.6 percent higher than Kansas City Power's current dividend and 15.2 percent greater than Utilicorp's payout. But Western Resources has said it would pay shareholders $1.98 a share if its bid of $28 a share to buy Kansas City Power is completed. Kansas City Power's merger with Utilicorp was valued at $26.77 a share when the deal was announced in January. Shareholders of Kansas City Power and Utilicorp are to vote on the merger on May 22. Both companies are based in Kansas City, Mo.

title: COMPANY NEWS;GREAT LAKES CHEMICAL IN DEAL FOR NOWSCO
description: The Great Lakes Chemical Corporation agreed on Sunday to acquire Nowsco Well Service Ltd. in a deal valued at $502 million. The offer exceeds a competing bid for Nowsco made by the BJ Services Company last month, which Nowsco rejected. Nowsco, based in Calgary, Alberta, provides well services to oil and natural-gas companies. Great Lakes, based in West Lafayette, Ind., offered to buy all 22.5 million outstanding shares of Nowsco, for $30.90 (Canadian) a share. BJ Services, of Houston, offered $27 (Canadian) a share. The shares jumped today past the price offered by Great Lakes, to $31.95 (Canadian), up $2.60 a share. Great Lakes produces specialty chemicals, including flame retardants, water treatments and petroleum additives. It also provides products and services to the oil and gas industry.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: DANCE
description: Simplicity and Surprises, Also Emotions and Quirks Garth Fagan Dance Joyce Theater

title: Chess
description: Winning is the main thing in any competition, but how you win makes a great difference to the frequency with which you will win.

title: Patterns
description: Back From Oblivion

title: BASEBALL;Following Bad Day, Yanks Get A Victory
description: The night was so drab that only about 6,000 fans trekked to Yankee Stadium, the weather was so damp that players constantly blew warm air into their hands and the news about David Cone's circulatory condition was distressing. Fortunately for the Yankees, the opponent on this dreary evening was Detroit. Lame, lousy, lowly Detroit.

title: A Microwave Treatment For Enlarged Prostates
description: Men who have enlarged prostates can now choose a one-hour treatment rather than drugs or surgery: a machine that literally microwaves the prostate to relieve urinary symptoms.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday about recent trends in the financial markets gave incorrect percentagechange figures for two stock market indexes. Through the close of trading on Friday, the American Stock Exchange's Market Value Index was down 0.65 percent last week and was up 7.56 percent so far this year; the Nasdaq composite index was down 0.19 percent last week and was up 12.59 percent so far this year.

title: Sports of The Times;Memories Of Say, Hey In Sugar Hill
description: JESSE WILLIAMS opened the door to his fourth-floor apartment on St. Nicholas Place in Harlem yesterday. We shook hands and made our way down a long, narrow hallway. When I asked how he was doing, Williams smiled. "Some days are better than others," he said, explaining that he was battling diabetes. "If I can make it to June 28, I'll be 83."

title: Tandem Computers to Create Machines With Microsoft
description: Tandem Computers Inc. and the Microsoft Corporation said today that they had set up an alliance to create machines that will be made by Tandem and will run the Microsoft Windows NT operating system. The first of the systems is to be available this summer.

title: N.B.A. PLAYOFFS;No Doubts, Plenty of Questions for Knicks
description: Several of the Knicks were handed videotapes today after practice by an assistant coach, Bob Salmi. One given to Hubert Davis was titled, "Jordan Shots Only." John Starks, who shot alone for nearly half an hour on a far court at the Moody Bible Institute, grabbed one, too, although it was unclear whether his included Jordan highlights or his own lowlights.

title: COMPANY NEWS;EA INDUSTRIES ACQUIRES STAKE IN AYDIN
description: The electronic manufacturing concern EA Industries said yesterday that it had bought 11.7 percent of the Aydin Corporation from its chief executive for $10.75 million and had begun discussing a possible merger. EA Industries, based in West Long Branch, N.J., acquired 596,927 Aydin shares, for about $18 each. The chairman and chief executive of Aydin, Ayhan Hakimoglu, stepped down after the transaction and was replaced by I. Gary Bard, a director at Aydin. Aydin, based in Horsham, Pa., makes wireless and telecommunications equipment. It was unchanged at $15.50 a share.

title: Chernobyl's Voles Live But Mutations Surge
description: AMERICAN colleagues have warned Dr. Ron Chesser, only half jokingly, that radiation exposure might kill him if he keeps going back to Chernobyl to collect rodents for genetic studies. Around Chernobyl itself, local people simply recommend vodka to flush the radioactivity out of one's system. But Dr. Chesser is not fond of vodka, and to his mind, what can be learned at the site of the world's worst nuclear accident is well worth any theoretical risk from radiation.

title: Bishop Accuses Manager of Pension Office of Embezzling $1 Million
description: Bishop Thomas V. Daily, the head of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, yesterday accused the manager of the diocesan pension office -- a woman who had worked for the diocese for 32 years -- of embezzling more than $1 million in church money.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;A Master of the Memorably Atonal
description: There are things both gladdening and depressing in the career of Ralph Shapey, one of the greatest living American composers. Here is a man who has stayed true to the maverick tradition in American music begun by Charles Ives. He has written what he has seen fit to write; he has found a tremendously powerful voice and stuck to it; he has not wasted time lobbying prize committees, inventing gimmicks for marketing departments, or feeding analytic trivia to professional explainers.

title: William E. Colby, 76, Head of C.I.A. in a Time of Upheaval
description: William E. Colby, who as Director of Central Intelligence chose to disclose some of the nation's darkest secrets to save the spy service he loved, drowned on April 27 in a tributary of the Potomac River in Maryland. He was 76 and lived in the Georgetown section of Washington.

title: Praise for G.O.P. Ignites Storm at Union Lovefest
description: The breakfast meeting yesterday between New York City's labor leaders and Congressional Democrats was shaping up as a lovefest, as the two sides praised each other and plotted how to defeat the Republicans this November.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;On Slow Day, Bond Prices Rebound a Bit
description: The prices of Treasury securities rose yesterday, lifted by covering of short positions and by bargain hunting after the sharp selloff on Friday that was prompted by the April employment report. But trading was light, exaggerating the gains, as the market braced for a flood of new securities this week.

title: Patsy Montana, 81, a Pioneer In Country Music in the 1930's
description: Patsy Montana, whose yodeling-cowgirl songs made her a pioneer in country music, died on Friday at her home in San Jacinto, Calif., The Associated Press reported. She was 81.

title: BASEBALL;Schott Draws Fire From Jewish Groups
description: Marge Schott's belief that Adolf Hitler "was good in the beginning but he went too far" apparently has not changed since the Cincinnati Reds' owner first created a controversy with that remark three and a half years ago and fueled anger that led to her suspension from baseball.

title: Leo Joseph Cardinal Suenens, A Vatican II Leader, Dies at 91
description: Leo Joseph Cardinal Suenens, whose public and behind-the-scenes leadership at the Second Vatican Council made him a major architect of 20th-century Roman Catholicism, died yesterday in Brussels. He was 91.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;French G.D.P. Growth Put at 0.4% in Quarter
description: The April report on the leading French indicator of economic activity, released yesterday, put first-quarter growth at four-tenths of a percent, down from the March estimate that gross domestic product would grow five-tenths of a percent.

title: Clinton Reported Close to a Limited Ban on Land Mines
description: President Clinton is close to a decision to ban land mines within several years, but he is expected to approve an exemption that could allow the continued use of the weapons in Korea and for mine-disposal training, Administration officials said today.

title: Fred Bridge, 80, a Designer And Supplier of Kitchenware
description: Fred Bridge, the founder of Bridge Kitchenware, for decades the leading cookware supplier for professional and home kitchens, died on Sunday at Ridgewood Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 80 and lived in Manhattan.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/POP CD'S;Mingling Rhythmic Influences
description: Leon Sam and the Sam Brothers

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Horan Signs New Deal With Giants
description: MIKE HORAN, the veteran punter who has handled that responsibility for the Giants since joining them midway through the 1993 season, signed a new contract with the team yesterday.

title: NYC;On Subways, On Sidewalks, A Few Pleas
description: APPLAUSE, please, where it's due. Subway lines on Manhattan's West Side took a bath, literally, when a geezer of a water main became a geyser over the weekend, yet the Transit Authority resumed normal runs within 16 hours. Not bad.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Maurice Saatchi Gets Mars Work Again
description: Mars Inc. and Maurice Saatchi will work together again, with Mars hiring the M& C Saatchi Agency in London to handle a pet-food assignment in Britain.

title: 2 Sides Begin Settlement Talks In Battle Over Cantor Fitzgerald
description: The two sides battling over the future management of Cantor Fitzgerald L.P., one of the nation's leading institutional brokers of Government securities, began settlement talks yesterday afternoon, just hours after a Delaware chancery court judge began hearing evidence in the bitterly contested case.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SOLA TO PURCHASE AMERICAN OPTICAL FOR $107 MILLION
description: Sola International Inc. said yesterday that it had signed an agreement to acquire the closely held American Optical Corporation, an ophthalmic company, for $107 million in cash. American Optical, with annual revenues of $79 million, is based in Southbridge, Mass. It has units in Britain, France, Switzerland and Singapore. Sola International, based in Menlo Park, Calif., specializes in eyeglass lenses.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Expanded Airport to Open
description: Dedication ceremonies will be held today for a key component in Atlantic City's construction boom -- the newly expanded and upgraded airport, whose capacity has been doubled to 1.3 million passengers a year.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;G.M. Decides on Site For Plant in Poland
description: The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it planned to invest 500 million marks ($329 million) to build a car factory in Gliwice in southwestern Poland. G.M. had said in December that it intended to invest in such a plant but did not provide information then about where the plant would be.

title: Apple Licenses Macintosh System to I.B.M.
description: Apple Computer Inc. said today that it had licensed its Macintosh operating system to the International Business Machines Corporation in an effort to prop up its shrinking market share.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Claim Rejected on Dismissal At Metallgesellschaft Unit
description: Metallgesellschaft A.G. said today that a panel of arbitrators in New York had rejected a claim by the company's former chief oil trader that he was unfairly dismissed after more than $1 billion in trading losses that brought the German company to the brink of bankruptcy.

title: It's Election Day. Really.
description: Campaigning at a busy shopping center for re-election to her local school board, Anne Mackinnon could barely get anyone to stop, listen or take her fliers. She thinks she knows why: critics have branded the board system as ineffective and sometimes corrupt, she says, leaving the public with little interest in today's vote.

title: Corrections
description: A film review on April 10 about "Wallace and Gromit: The Best of Aardman Animation" misidentified the process used by the Aardman Studio. It is called stop-motion animation, not Claymation. Claymation is a trademark of the Will Vinton Studios.

title: Dog Days in the Parks
description: New York City is cracking down on unleashed dogs in its parks -- although Parks Department officials dispute the term "crackdown." "More vigorous enforcement in response to public pressure," amends a department spokesman. But no matter how you slice it, dog owners who let their pets run loose are more likely to get a $100 ticket than they were a few months ago. The change has caused dismay within some doggie circles, and led a few outraged owners to protest so vigorously they wound up in custody.

title: As Strife Rages, South Africa Delays Vote
description: In the remote village of Mpendele recently, about 200 residents gathered in a grassy field for a campaign rally. It wasn't a fancy affair -- a kitchen table with a pink cloth on it was set up to serve as a lectern and two chairs were ready for the guest speakers.

title: Corrections
description: An art review in Weekend on April 26 about an exhibition of works on paper by Clifford Odets at the Michael Rosenfeld Gallery in Manhattan misidentified the project on which Odets was working when he died in 1963. It was "The Richard Boone Repertory Theater Series" for NBC, not episodes of the television series "Have Gun Will Travel."

title: In Naval Academy Sports, No Lapse of Ethics
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICAN TOPICS : British Stewardess Saves Fishermen From Aloft
description: A British Airways stewardess who spotted black smoke in the Atlantic Ocean helped save three American fishermen whose boat was burning.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;Second Acts in Multimedia Life May Disappoint
description: THE package for Toy Story Animated Storybook (Disney Interactive Inc., about $35) advertises "incredible 3-D animation just like in the movie." Just like in the movie, that is, if the movie were limited to lackluster resolution and a mere 256 colors at once and displayed technical quirks that made its sound break up and its characters occasionally disintegrate into the background. And I do not seem to recall anyone at the theater box office demanding that I install yet another new version of Apple Computer's Quicktime for Windows, perhaps the fussiest piece of multimedia software plumbing in all creation.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Theatrical Flourishes In 3 Views of Women Lauren Flanigan, soprano 92d Street Y

title: Criminals of the Balkan War
description: Dusan Tadic goes on trial today in The Hague for war crimes in Bosnia, the first defendant to face the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia. Mr. Tadic, a Bosnian Serb, is accused of specific acts of murder and torture, but not of masterminding the brutal human rights abuses that were the signature of the Balkan war. That distinction belongs to other men, and the work of the tribunal should be measured by whether it is given the support necessary to pursue and prosecute them.

title: Rising Gas Prices Don't Merit Our Tears;  Check Your Calculator
description: To the Editor:

title: N.H.L. PLAYOFFS;Tour of Duty: Getting a Glimpse of the Rangers at Ease
description: Like a classroom or business office, a team's clubhouse has its own peculiar mood and pecking order. It is a home away from home, a place for instruction and relaxation.

title: Witness Against Philip Morris Backs Off Testimony on Nicotine
description: A former manufacturing supervisor at Philip Morris USA has retracted his widely publicized accusations that the company routinely measured the nicotine content of its cigarettes during production at its Richmond factory, according to testimony made public yesterday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: ESAB Welding and Cutting Products, Florence, S.C., a unit of Charter P.L.C., to Sawyer Riley Compton, Atlanta, to handle its account, which had been at Hodges & Associates, Fayetteville, N.C., and the Vandine Group, Pittsburgh, a subsidiary of Hallmark-Tassone Inc. Billings were estimated at more than $2 million. Bayer Corp. pharmaceutical division, West Haven, Conn., a unit of Bayer A.G., to Carrafiello, Diehl & Associates, Irvington-on-Hudson, N.Y., to handle the first direct-to-consumer advertising for Adalat CC Extended Release Tablets, a prescription medication for hypertension. Billings were not disclosed. The agency has advertised the product to health care professionals since 1993.

title: U.N. Extends Iraq Oil Sanctions As a Prod in New Round of Talks
description: A fourth round of negotiations on a deal that would allow Iraq to sell a limited amount of oil to pay for urgent civilian needs opened here tonight, hours after the Security Council extended for 60 days the blanket sanctions that have severely damaged the Iraqi economy.

title: Mummies, Textiles Offer Evidence Of Europeans in Far East
description: In the first millennium A.D., people living at oases along the legendary Silk Road in what is now northwest China wrote in a language quite unlike any other in that part of the world. They used one form of the language in formal Buddhist writings, another for everyday religious and commercial affairs, including caravan passes.

title: Big Bidders Win Auction For the Small
description: It was billed as one of the Federal Government's biggest small-business programs in history, a chance for corporate have-nots to become players in the booming business of wireless communications.

title: Jury Convicts An Ex-Teacher On Sex Counts
description: A New Hampshire jury today convicted a former Massachusetts preparatory school teacher of trying to sexually assault a 12-year-old boy last summer and of possessing and exhibiting child pornography.

title: Ingmar Bergman Drops Plans For 'Misanthrope' in Brooklyn
description: Ingmar Bergman has canceled plans to stage Moliere's comedy "Le Misanthrope" at the Brooklyn Academy of Music early this summer. The cancellation was announced yesterday in a brief written statement by Lars Lofgren, the artistic director of the Royal Swedish Dramatic Theater in Stockholm, where "Le Misanthrope" had been playing in repertory for more than a year.

title: New Rorem Quartet Echoes Many Modern Voices
description: Ned Rorem's new string quartet, his fourth, speaks a shared language with confidence. Composers get attention these days by finding new ways of saying things. Mr. Rorem's naturally expressive and elegantly made piece communicates in terms anyone who has followed music's progress in this century will understand.

title: Resolving Conflicts in Supercomputer Deal
description: Silicon Graphics Inc. and its recently acquired subsidiary, Cray Research, plan to detail on Tuesday how they will go about merging their competing supercomputer designs into a single family of products that will eventually run on one type of microprocessor.

title: Schools Urged to Stop Buying Artworks
description: Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday called on the agency that builds public schools in New York City to stop spending money to buy art for the schools, contending that the $11.3 million that the agency has spent for paintings, sculptures and other works of art over the last five years should have been used for repairs.

title: ON PRO BASKETBALL;Bulling Through Playoffs, Gingerly
description: It came as no surprise yesterday that the Chicago Bulls held a light workout.

title: Sports of The Times;Can Italy's Donadoni Turn Heads in U.S.?
description: THE last customers were leaving the restaurant, but the waiters were setting the table for a private party. By their nods and their smiles, the waiters identified the most special guest of all: the trim, humble man with the prominent jaw and the full head of curls.

title: Berkshire Sets 'Cheaper' Issue
description: Shareholders of Berkshire Hathaway Inc., at $33,800 a share Wall Street's most expensive stock, authorized a new "cheaper" class of stock today. It will become the second-most-expensive issue on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: BOXING;Garden Tripleheader Is an Island of Sanity
description: Away from the lawyers and the courtrooms and the shouting in the boardrooms, an old verity will return to Madison Square Garden on Friday night: May the better man win.

title: Bill Proposes Monitoring Of the Sale Of Pesticides
description: For years, women's groups have charged that extensive use of pesticides may be a factor in the high rates of breast cancer on Long Island. And for years, farmers have rejected such claims.

title: Market Place;Say 'Internet' And Watch Zenith Soar
description: Zenith Electronics has a grand brand name and a lot of red ink. Now it also has a hot stock.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;Why Java May Sound Like Magic
description: SORCERERS have known for centuries that certain words and phrases have magical powers. "Open sesame" makes locked doors swing open, for example. "Abracadabra" makes rabbits appear out of top hats. "I am a computer programmer" causes people at dinner parties to fall into a dazed, zombie-like state.

title: A Better Senate Bill on Immigration
description: The Senate passed a sensible immigration bill last week, providing for strengthened enforcement of immigration laws at the nation's borders and workplaces, tighter requirements for immigrants to receive certain public benefits and the development of a new national database for verifying the immigration status of prospective employees.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PACE INDUSTRIES BEING BOUGHT BY LEGGETT & PLATT
description: Leggett & Platt Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the aluminum die-cast component maker Pace Industries for 5.2 million shares of common stock, valued at $118 million, and the assumption of about $200 million in debt. Leggett, a maker of components for home furnishings and other products based in Carthage, Mo., said that it expected to take a charge of $34 million, or 38 cents a share, in the second quarter in connection with the deal. Pace Industries, based in Fayetteville, Ark., makes aluminum gas-barbecue grill housings and exterior lighting and electric motor components.

title: Stocks Lower in Japan
description: Stocks traded lower here today, after a long holiday weekend. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 167.10 points, or nearly eight-tenths of 1 percent, at 21,495.28. On Monday, Japanese financial markets were closed in observance of Children's Day.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;In a search for innocence, advertisers are reviving songs and styles of the not-so-pure 1970's.
description: BARRY WHITE growls about love again, and consumers are reminded how to spell "Y.M.C.A." Yes, the mirrored disco balls are spinning anew along Madison Avenue in a spate of advertising that recalls the music and fashions of the 1970's.

title: YELTSIN DECLARES ELECTION IN RUSSIA WON'T BE PUT OFF
description: Hoping to stifle growing speculation that he would rather cancel presidential elections than lose them, President Boris N. Yeltsin said today that voting would take place in June as scheduled.

title: Corrections
description: A dance review on Friday about a performance of "Don Quixote" by the American Ballet Theater, at the Metropolitan Opera House last Tuesday, misstated the relationship of Nina Ananiashvili, who danced Kitri, to the Bolshoi Ballet. She is a member, not a former member.

title: School Project Lampooned by G.O.P. Totters but Doesn't Fall
description: Even as the Republicans gave in to most of the Clinton Administration's demands to restore money for environmental programs in the fiscal 1996 budget, they heaped ridicule on one science education program and insisted on eliminating it. But the Administration is vowing to salvage the program by rationing the money previously approved by Congress and seeking private contributions.

title: POLITICAL BRIEFS: Indiana;As Governor Retires, 3 Republicans Joust
description: Of all the Great Lakes states, only Indiana has a Democratic Governor, and he is retiring. Republicans consider the state their natural terrain, which explains why three Republicans are elbowing each other for the nomination in today's primary.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;What Yardstick in Buying a Film Maker?
description: How much is a hot film company that has gone cold worth?

title: San Francisco Journal;A Monument Caught in the Middle
description: In 1906 a great earthquake destroyed much of this city, and the terrible fire that followed finished off most of what was left. Defying nature's fury in front of the rubble of City Hall was the 800-ton Pioneer Monument, a sculptural marker commemorating the history and settlement of California, a tower of civic pride that stood even taller in the wake of disaster.

title: ON BASEBALL;Don't Fret for Tigers: The Only Way to Go Is Up
description: Buddy Bell was talking about his own pitchers when some insensitive person mentioned the starting pitchers his team expected to see in the four-game series with the Yankees this week: Kenny Rogers, David Cone, Dwight Gooden, Jimmy Key.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Atlas Copco Pretax Net Up 24% in First Quarter
description: Atlas Copco A.B., a Swedish maker of industrial equipment, said yesterday that its first-quarter pretax profit had risen a higher-than-expected 24 percent because of strong earnings at companies it had acquired. The pretax earnings are not directly comparable with last year's figures, the company said, because they were not adjusted for the acquisition of the Milwaukee Electric Tool Corporation, which Atlas Copco bought last August.

title: COMPANY NEWS;GENESIS HEALTH TO ACQUIRE 17 ELDERLY CARE FACILITIES
description: Genesis Health Ventures Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire 17 elderly care facilities and certain assets for about $133.6 million. Genesis, which is based in Kennett Square, Pa., provides health care services to the elderly. It is acquiring the businesses through its purchase of six entities controlled by National Health Care Affiliates Inc., based in Buffalo. The 17 facilities, which are in Florida, Virginia and Connecticut, contain 2,519 licensed nursing and assisted-living beds. The purchase also includes a rehabilitation therapy business and a nutritional therapy company.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a report published by the Freedom Forum on trends in journalism education misstated the first name of the author of the report. She is Betty Medsger, not Betsy.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: THEATER
description: Betrayal of Various Kinds In Franco and Lorca's Spain 'Between the Sheets' Gold Room

title: A Half-Price Ticket Booth, Its Business Down, Is Closing
description: The Bryant Park Music and Dance Half-Price Ticket Booth, which has sold cut-price tickets to performances at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the Joyce Theater, the New York City Opera, the 92d Street Y and the JVC Jazz Festival, is to close on June 30 after 13 years.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ASG OF SWEDEN TO SELL FRIGOSCANDIA TO FMC CORP.
description: ASG A.B., a Swedish freight company, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Frigoscandia Equipment unit to the FMC Corporation for about 1.25 billion kronor, or $183 million. ASG, based in Stockholm, plans to use proceeds from the sale to pay off debt it incurred when it bought Frigoscandia A.B. in October. ASG paid 1.8 billion kronor for Frigoscandia to gain access to its refrigerated-transport operations. At the time, it said it would sell the Frigoscandia Equipment unit when it found a suitable buyer. In March, FMC, a maker of machinery and chemicals based in Chicago, said it had tentatively agreed to buy Frigoscandia but did not disclose terms.

title: Judge Throws Out Some Charges for 2 in Whitewater-Related Case
description: A day before the defense is to present its case, the judge in the Whitewater-related trial here today threw out four charges each against Gov. Jim Guy Tucker of Arkansas and Susan McDougal, two of the three defendants.

title: Observer;Unmet by the Gods
description: I have been reading the memoirs of two writers I admire extravagantly, Alfred Kazin and Gore Vidal. Much as I esteem both men as writers, however, their memoirs leave me uneasy. Vidal, I gather, has never met anyone who wasn't famous. Except for his family and wives, neither apparently has Kazin.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Hobson Arrested on Cocaine Charge
description: BUTCH HOBSON, who managed the Boston Red Sox from 1992 to 1994, was arrested on a cocaine possession charge on Saturday afternoon, the police in Pawtucket, R.I., said yesterday. Hobson, 44, was arrested at the Comfort Inn in Pawtucket, where the Phillies farm team he manages, the Class AAA Red Barons of Wilkes-Barre-Scranton, Pa., was staying during a two-game weekend series against the Pawtucket Red Sox.

title: Trenton May Pay Health Cost Of Uninsured by Payroll Tax
description: In the latest attempt to end a five-month standoff over how to pay for hospital care for the uninsured, the State Assembly approved legislation today that would cover the costs by continuing to rely on unemployment payroll taxes.

title: OLYMPICS;Sprinter Carries Torch Of Aboriginal Pride
description: When British and Irish colonists landed on this continent in 1788, the first words they reportedly heard spoken by the Aborigines were "Warra, warra," which meant, quite simply, "Go away."

title: N.B.A. PLAYOFFS;SuperSonics Win on a Score of 3-Pointers
description: The Seattle SuperSonics hit a playoff-record 20 3-pointers, including 13 in a row, to beat the Houston Rockets, 105-101, tonight and take a 2-0 series lead over the two-time defending National Basketball Association champions.

title: BASKETBALL;Former Stars Step Into Hall
description: Two National Basketball Association scoring stars, George Gervin and David Thompson, who were both shadowed by drug abuse off the court, took the final step in their rehabilitation tonight.

title: COMPANY NEWS;P.& G. BUYS EAGLE SNACKS TRADEMARK AND BRAND NAME
description: The Procter & Gamble Company said yesterday that it had bought the Eagle Snacks trademark and brand name from the Anheuser-Busch Companies. Financial terms were not disclosed. The deal does not include the A&Eagle trademark, which is the Anheuser-Busch corporate symbol. The maker of beer and snacks already sold a number of plants that made Eagle Snacks to Pepsico Inc.'s Frito-Lay Inc. Procter & Gamble, based in Cincinnati, said it had no immediate plans to use the trademark and brand name.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Welfare Cuts For Truancy Are Stalled
description: Gov. John G. Rowland's proposal to withhold welfare checks from families whose children skip school has apparently stalled after his own task force concluded there was no evidence that children from welfare families skipped school more than other children.

title: For Indians, An Election Is Honest But Boring
description: Like India itself, Indian elections have always been raucous, free-for-all affairs, full of noise and mayhem and general outlandishness. At election time, the successful politician has often been the one who has proven wilier than opponents at circumventing laws that are supposed to govern election practices, especially spending.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Y.& R. Parts Ways With Holiday Inn
description: Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York and Holiday Inn Worldwide said yesterday that philosophical differences led them to part ways on the Holiday Inn worldwide account after eight years. Billings were estimated at $15 million to $20 million.

title: F.C.C. Auction Has Unexpected Winners
description: It was billed as one of the Government's biggest small-business programs ever, an entry for corporate have-nots into the booming wireless-communications business.

title: Milk May Lower Stroke Risk
description: Middle-age men who drink milk may reduce their risk of the most common type of stroke, a study released today suggests. But the study noted that the milk drinkers tended to have healthy life patterns that could explain their lower stroke risk.

title: Anti-Gay Resolution Repealed in Georgia
description: Commissioners in a rural southeast Georgia county rescinded their two-year-old anti-homosexual resolution tonight amid concerns about losing their leg of the Olympic torch run.

title: Rising Gas Prices Don't Merit Our Tears
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Van Hits Bus Head On
description: A city-owned van drove head on into a New Jersey Transit bus yesterday morning as the bus was dropping off passengers at a downtown intersection, transit officials said. None of the 20 passengers was seriously injured, and the two drivers were listed in stable condition at University Hospital and St. James Hospital, respectively, officials of the two hospitals said. The No. 34 bus from Montclair had not been able to pull over to the curb on Walnut Street because three cars were illegally parked at the bus stop, said Ken Miller, a spokesman for New Jersey Transit. No charges were filed immediately.

title: No Headline
description: What really irks them is, it is true a lot of factories are empty, and it seems illogical to them that a country that once produced 160 million metric tons of steel now produces closer to 80 and 90. They can't see that the reason is nobody wanted all that steel. -- JEFFREY D. SACHS, Harvard professor, on Communist economists in Russia. [A8:5]

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Pulitzer Publishing Will Acquire Privately Owned Scripps League
description: The Pulitzer Publishing Company said today that it had agreed to buy Scripps League Newspapers Inc., a privately owned company that publishes 16 daily newspapers in the Midwest and West and a number of other small publications.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Korean Ex-President Denies Role in Massacre
description: A former President of South Korea, Chun Doo Hwan, denied today that he had sent troops to massacre democracy deonstrators in 1980.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Loses 13.72 Points After Roller Coaster Ride The stock market rode a roller coaster, with the Dow industrials falling 54.91 points before rebounding to close down only 13.72 points, at 5,464.31. The Nasdaq composite index rose 1.71 points, to 1,186.31.

title: Wisconsin's Welfare Boomerang
description: Everywhere I turn, I read the praises of Wisconsin's Governor, Tommy G. Thompson, for the welfare overhaul he has rammed through our Legislature and for which the Federal Government is soon expected to approve the necessary waivers. The plan, called Wisconsin Works, is being hailed as yet another way to "end welfare as we know it."

title: Fire Damages Apartments in Historic Building
description: A fire broke out in the Ansonia apartment building on the Upper West Side last night, damaging several apartments in the Beaux Arts landmark and sending a plume of thick smoke over one of the building's fairy-tale turrets.

title: Psychotherapy and Managed Care Don't Mesh
description: To the Editor:

title: Dole '96 Button Not Necessarily Business Attire
description: As a longtime supporter of President Clinton, John H. Bryan, the chairman of the Sara Lee Corporation, is used to having his politics questioned by other chief executives, most of whom are staunch Republicans. "Every now and then, someone will check in and ask if I still back him," Mr. Bryan said last week. "I always profess my loyalty."

title: Behind the Cloak of Office, Clinton's War Room Hums
description: The settings are tailor-made for Bill Clinton's shadow campaign.

title: Kerkorian Sells Some Shares in Chrysler
description: The Chrysler Corporation's largest shareholder, Kirk Kerkorian, sold some of his shares in the auto maker in April to comply with a truce that forces him to keep his stake at 13.75 percent.

title: Forum on Holocaust Canceled After an Author Withdraws
description: New York University yesterday abruptly canceled a long-planned symposium of Holocaust scholars after an author whose book on the Holocaust has been sharply criticized in Germany withdrew because of fears that the event would attract hostile German press coverage.

title: Joycean Saga With a Cast Of Un-Joycean Characters;From Teamster's Shelves to Dealer's Hands, An Urban Tale of Collecting Rare Editions
description: This is a New York story about a rare book dealer, a Teamsters boss and James Joyce. It includes anxious moments at an auction at Christie's, corruption at the powerful teamsters' union Local 810 near Union Square and brief appearances by Carter Burden, the politician and socialite, as well as Steve Forbes, the publishing heir and short-time presidential candidate.

title: Rising Gas Prices Don't Merit Our Tears
description: To the Editor:

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Israeli Troops Reported To Wound 9 Palestinians
description: Israeli soldiers shot and wounded nine Palestinians today in clashes with demonstrators at the self-ruled enclave of Qalqilya, hospital officials said.

title: Marines at U.S. Embassy in Liberia Again Fire on Gunmen
description: Marines protecting the American Embassy here opened fire on gunmen today as sporadic shooting again erupted throughout the city even after the deadline for a truce had passed.

title: S.E.C. Now Requires Filing by Computer
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission moved a step closer to reducing a paper blizzard today as it formally required some 16,000 public companies to file their financial reports with the agency via computer.

title: Call Eritrea a Failure In Respecting Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: The worst thing anyone could think of to say about DAVID R. HUNTER at his 80th birthday celebration on Saturday was that, in a fit of pique, he once snapped the antenna on a car boxing him into a tight parking spot. Otherwise, it was one glowing, loving accolade after another for Mr. Hunter, who has been called "the godfather of progressive philanthropy."

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Bills Re-sign Reed, Their Leading Receiver
description: ANDRE REED re-signed with the Buffalo Bills yesterday, adding another wide receiver to their solid corps. Reed, the leading receiver in team history, was seeking a three-year contract that would pay him about $1.2 million annually. The terms were not released. (AP)

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Vaughn Will Remain at Kansas
description: JACQUE VAUGHN, the Big Eight Conference's player of the year, said yesterday that he would return to play his senior season at the University of Kansas.

title: Quarrel Over Funds Divides Helmsley Empire's Regents
description: For half a century, the three men had been harmonious and effective partners in the dense thickets of New York real estate. They bought buildings like other m bought slacks.

title: TV Notes;Program Notes
description: *Court TV, the cable network devoted to trials and judicial issues, is carrying live coverage of the first international war crimes tribunal since Nuremberg, the trial of Dusko Tadic, a Bosnian Serb accused of war crimes in the former Yugoslavia. The trial began yesterday in The Hague, and Court TV plans to have live coverage from 8 A.M. to noon each day, as well as highlights and analysis on "Court TV News" at 7:30 P.M. and "Prime Time Justice" at 8.

title: Aurand Harris, 80, Author of Such Children's Plays as 'Androcles'
description: Aurand Harris, a prolific and much-performed playwright who wrote for young audiences, died on Monday at Beth-Israel Hospice in Manhattan. He was 80 and lived in Greenwich Village.

title: Cockburn Town Journal;Rule, Britannia! Outpost of the Empire Is Restless
description: Normally, the only vessels that ply the tranquil turquoise waters of this easygoing British colony are yachts, diving skiffs and other pleasure craft. So when a British frigate bristling with missiles and torpedoes dropped anchor here recently, local residents were not sure whether to be angry or amused.

title: About New York;The Children Of Foster Care Want a Voice
description: THE young people in foster care call it the System. But to hear those who came of age among overloaded caseworkers, rowdy group homes or ill-equipped foster families, there's nothing systematic about it.

title: Heart Patients Need Not Fear Sex, Study Finds
description: HEART patients who engage in sexual activity need not worry that the exertion involved will touch off a heart attack, according to new findings. The chance that sex might precipitate a heart attack even in those who already have had one is only about two in a million, a study of 858 men and women who survived heart attacks indicates.

title: Election Day for School Boards Mixes Apathy, Anger and Disgust
description: It was school board election day in New York City yesterday, and Carmelo Saez Jr., ousted as president of his board by three successive chancellors on charges of corruption and patronage, was making the rounds of polling places in the West Bronx.

title: House Approves Bill to Require Notification on Sex Offenders
description: The House voted unanimously tonight to require all states to notify localities when convicted sex offenders who might still pose a danger to children settle in their area.

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;Turnabout on the Ice: The Penguins Attack Early and More Often
description: Mario Lemieux, who had a hot hand but kept a cool head in Game 3, didn't mince words about the kind of game the Penguins treated the Rangers to at their hometown Igloo in Game 2 of this second-round playoff series on Sunday. Pittsburgh, said Lemieux, put on one of "the worst" playoff performances in his memory. And his memory, which includes two Stanley Cup championship seasons, is tolerably long.

title: Why Some Overcome Trauma and Others Do Not
description: TWO people are mugged, robbed at gunpoint and beaten. Years later one is still haunted by flashbacks and nightmares of the mugging, and is easily frightened by people or events that are in any way reminiscent of the experience. The other hardly thinks about it anymore.

title: Penmanship: Fine Art to Lost Art
description: For more than a decade, Millie Pryles has spent a half-hour each day standing over second graders at the Westminster schools in Atlanta, making them trace and retrace the ovals, loops and humps that will become their cursive handwriting. It is a discipline she knows is fast becoming a lost art.

title: Archeologists in Peru Oppose Loan of Inca Mummy to U.S.
description: Days before the frozen remains of a 500-year-old Inca woman are scheduled to be shipped to the United States for study and exhibit, a group of Peruvian archeologists and politicians has petitioned the Government not to allow the mummy to leave Peru.

title: Theater in Review
description: From Mrs. Astor's City To High-Neurosis Today 'Wally's Ghost' SoHo Rep

title: Who Are True Heirs of Our Racial Divisions?
description: To the Editor:

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;Knicks: Jordan Can Dish It Out
description: Jeff Van Gundy is not saying Michael Jordan is a dirty player, but the Knick coach said today that it was time for some stereotypes to die.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;The Bulls' Big Man Cannot Be Ignored
description: LUC LONGLEY earns his pay primarily by getting in the way of people -- like a bump in the road, or a detour post, or an amplified hobgoblin. He stands 7 feet 2 inches and weighs more than 300 pounds and, in case you've still missed him, he has tomato-red hair.

title: 10-State Swath of West Will Soon Hit 75 M.P.H.
description: Eastern drivers mapping out routes for Western vacations this summer can plan on the shortest driving times in a generation.

title: RANGERS NOTEBOOK;Campbell Finds He Has Some Adjusting to Do
description: Unnerving is the word Colin Campbell used to describe Pittsburgh Penguins Coach Eddie Johnston's tactic of double-shifting Mario Lemieux and Jaromir Jagr as linemates to open last night's game at Madison Square Garden.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: At the Nation's Table: Boston;Top of the Hub Glitters Even More
description: One of the more glittering spots to dine in Boston has always been the Top of the Hub restaurant in the heart of Back Bay. Now, the refurbished restaurant glitters even more. From its perch on the 52d floor of the Prudential Tower, diners can savor commanding views of the city, the ocean and the hills to the west, and an Asparagus Festival Menu that will be served through May 26.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Saint-Gobain to Buy Poliet in Phased Deal
description: A French glass maker, Saint-Gobain, said yesterday that it planned to buy the building materials company Poliet for as much as 15 billion francs ($2.9 billion) over the next three years under a deal with Poliet's main shareholder, Groupe Paribas. Under the agreement Saint-Gobain will buy 4.7 percent of Poliet, which has 20,000 employees, and take management control of the company in the first phase. It also has options to acquire the rest of the 56.6 percent held by Paribas in 1997 and 1998, according to a joint statement.

title: Corrections
description: An entry on Monday in the Business Day listing of new equity issues, about an offering by the Guangshen Railway Company of China, misidentified the lead underwriter. It is Bear, Stearns & Company, not Merrill Lynch & Company.

title: Christian Coalition All but Endorses Candidates
description: To the Editor:

title: Retail Rarity: A Success Not Obsessed By Expansion
description: Urban Outfitters, the apparel company that caters to the young and multiple-pierced, appears to be an antidote to what is wrong with much of specialty retailing today.

title: BASEBALL;Mets Can't Seem to Find Their Struggling Offense
description: A trip the Mets hoped would end with a .500 record has suddenly taken a nose dive into the fourth three-game losing streak of the season after a 3-2 loss to the Florida Marlins tonight at Joe Robbie Stadium.

title: Conde Nast Is to Move to a New Times Square Tower, Officials Say
description: In yet another sign of the fast-paced resurgence of Times Square, city and state officials said yesterday that Conde Nast, the publisher of Vanity Fair, Vogue, Architectural Digest and 11 other magazines, will move its headquarters to a building planned for the northeast corner of 42d Street and Broadway.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Prices for Crude Oil End Higher As Talks on Iraqi Accord Falter
description: Crude oil rose yesterday after Iraq's top negotiator expressed doubts about the possibility of an agreement with the United Nations to allow a limited Iraqi oil sale.

title: PLAIN AND SIMPLE;Citrus Shrimp, Hot and Sweet
description: Shrimp, with its insistent seafood flavor, goes well with an assertive sauce of orange juice, lime, hot pepper and cilantro. Serve with a hearty warm rice salad.

title: Settlement In Fraud Case
description: Securities regulators settled fraud charges today against several men accused of bilking investors out of $18.7 million in a scheme to sell securities of radio stations and wireless cable television companies, including stations controlled by a former radio talk show host, Irwin H. (Sonny) Bloch.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: NOTEBOOK;Top Draft Picks Playing the Negotiation Game
description: What's the the value of a degree from Southern California? More than $17.6 million, apparently. At least that's how much wide receiver Keyshawn Johnson has turned down from the Jets.

title: Consumers Trimmed Debt Rise in March
description: Consumers restrained their buying on credit during March, the Federal Reserve said today, as installment debt grew at the slowest rate in six months.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Taylor Ate the Evidence, Police Say
description: LAWRENCE TAYLOR swallowed the fake crack cocaine he is accused of buying from an undercover officer just before he was arrested, a police report says.

title: Music in Review
description: A Recital in Two Moods, With a Subtle Tribute Jessye Norman Avery Fisher Hall

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Burned Body Is Identified
description: Authorities yesterday identified one of two bodies found burning Monday under a pile of leaves in Weequahic Park as Peter E. Sizemore, 35, of Elizabeth. Mr. Sizemore, whose occupation could not be determined, had been stabbed 14 times. The woman whose strangled and bound body was next to Mr. Sizemore has not yet been identified, said Martin Hellwig, Director of Public Safety for Essex County.

title: Molinari and Water
description: To the Editor:

title: Bowman Clarifies Gretzky Remarks
description: Detroit Red Wings Coach Scotty Bowman is working hard to distance himself from comments attributed to him about Wayne Gretzky.

title: Station Goes Off the Air
description: The radio station WOR-AM went off the air for more than an hour last night because of a transmitter malfunction, a station worker said.

title: Adoption Bill Facing Battle Over Measure On Indians
description: When the House this week considers a major adoption bill that President Clinton supports, lawmakers will also consider a very emotional question: Who decides if someone is an American Indian?

title: Stocks Higher in Tokyo
description: Stocks were higher here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 233.32 points, or 1.09 percent, at 21,728.60. On Tuesday, the Nikkei lost 167.10 points.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Hobson 'Surprised' by Cocaine Delivery
description: BUTCH HOBSON, a former Boston Red Sox manager, was bewildered when he received a packet of in an express delivery, his lawyer said yesterday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;A twist on film product placements: a movie character in a milk ad.
description: HOW do you make a phantom more visible? Paramount Pictures hopes a milk mustache helps.

title: A Hit Season for Broadway;Seems Like Old Times With Influx of Theatergoers
description: Last Wednesday evening, the same night the 33d and final opening-night curtain of the Broadway season went up (on "The Ideal Husband" at the Ethel Barrymore Theater), Arnie and Ronnie Malasky waited beneath the marquee at Royale Theater on West 45th Street, where they would soon go inside to see George C. Scott in "Inherit the Wind."

title: In Unusual Session, Panel Seeks Whitewater Answers
description: In a scene that resembled the drawing room denouement of an Agatha Christie mystery, Republicans on the Senate Whitewater committee presented evidence today to try to clear up the question of how long-sought billing records from an Arkansas law firm ended up in the family quarters of the White House last year.

title: Bill to Limit Farms' Liability Is Expected to Die in the Senate
description: The man was wearing dress shoes when he arrived at the Jones Family Farm in Shelton, Conn., to pick blueberries, but that did not stop him from suing the farm when he slipped and fell.

title: Cleaning Up Stalin's Act
description: Every field of history seems to have its revisionists. Some 15 years ago, for example, a school of German historians began claiming that Hitler in some ways wasn't quite so bad after all. The last few years have seen a curious burst of revisionism about the other great villain of the 20th century, Stalin.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of "further information" with the Personal Health column last Wednesday, about obstructive sleep apnea, referred incorrectly to the book "Snoring and Sleep Apnea." A second edition, published by Demos Vermande, is in print.

title: Judge Tells Town to Alter Synagogue-Zoning Law
description: A Federal judge has ruled that the Village of Airmont in Rockland County must change its zoning laws to permit synagogues in private homes. The case has focused attention on cultural clashes that have flared in some New York suburbs since Orthodox Jews began moving in in the 1980's.

title: Who Are True Heirs of Our Racial Divisions?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Plague of Land Mines
description: An international conference on land mines recently concluded with a weak agreement that the use of these devastating and indiscriminate weapons should be curtailed. The conference recommended that mines be made more easily detectable and self-deactivating. Senator Patrick Leahy, who has sponsored legislation to eliminate the use of antipersonnel mines, called the agreement "a deplorable failure." He was right. But President Clinton has an opportunity to do better by deciding that the United States will stop using antipersonnel land mines, and by encouraging a worldwide ban.

title: A Top Economist Switches His View on Productivity
description: In the endless debate over whether companies in the huge service sector are becoming more efficient and productive, Stephen S. Roach is famous as the economist who says, flatly, they are. No skeptic can challenge that proposition without facing down Mr. Roach. He has preached his case on talk shows, before Congress, in academia and on Wall Street. But now he is changing his mind.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;$2.6 Billion Bid by 2 U.S. Utilities for British Company
description: Facing increasing competition at home, two leading United States power companies joined the rush to expand abroad yesterday as the General Public Utilities Corporation, which serves two million customers in New Jersey and Pennsylvania, joined with Cinergy, a major Midwest utility, in an agreement to acquire a big British energy distributor for about $2.6 billion.

title: Far From Former Yugoslavia, First War Crimes Trial Opens
description: The horrors of the smashed and ransacked villages of northern Bosnia were brought into court today as a United Nations tribunal opened the first trial to deal with war crimes in the former Yugoslavia.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MAX FERGUSON is not the kind of man to sit idly in jail, so when he was arrested Sunday on misdemeanor charges and detained for 30 hours, he decided to do portraits of his cell mates at the Criminal Court building at 100 Centre Street.

title: Dole Says He Has Plan to Win Votes of Women
description: Bob Dole tonight directly confronted for the first time one of his greatest weaknesses in his campaign for the White House -- his lack of support among women.

title: TV Notes;Talking to the People
description: Late last year, while making plans to cover the 1996 Presidential campaign, ABC News producers discussed how to get more depth into the usual polling and interviewing of ordinary Americans on the hot topics of the political season. But there turned out to be no primary season to speak of, as Bob Dole quickly became the Republican candidate opposing President Clinton.

title: Shares of Horizon/CMS Sliding After Multiple Blows
description: Just last winter, the Horizon/CMS Healthcare Corporation still had the glamorous look of a fast-growing nursing home company with an array of promising units.

title: Giuliani Is Said to Be Ready To Postpone Some Tax Cuts
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani plans to scale back significantly his proposed package of tax cuts, postponing a reduction in New York City's property taxes for co-op and condominium owners and calling for an extension of a temporary surcharge on the personal income tax that was to expire in December, officials said yesterday.

title: S.E.C. Backs U.S. as Site for Lloyd's Suit
description: In a setback to the troubled insurance giant Lloyd's of London, the Securities and Exchange Commission told a Federal appeals court today that a fraud lawsuit filed by American investors should be heard in United States courts, not in Britain.

title: COMPANY NEWS;KNIGHT-RIDDER IN DEAL TO SELL ITS FINANCIAL NEWS SERVICE
description: Knight-Ridder Inc. said yesterday that it would receive $275 million for its financial news service from the Global Financial Information Corporation, part of the Welsh Carson Anderson & Stowe investment group. It was suggested on Monday that Welsh Carson would buy Knight-Ridder Financial, which offers "real time" news on financial markets. Welsh Carson was founded by former executives of Citicorp, and is a major investor in Global Financial Information, which has products that include Bridge Information Systems and Market Vision. Knight-Ridder shares fell $1.875 yesterday, to $70.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: U.S. Signs Pact on Telling Mexico About Certain Migrant Cases
description: Secretary of State Warren Christopher signed an agreement here today pledging that American officials will notify Mexican diplomats in the United States whenever pregnant Mexican women or Mexican children are detained as illegal immigrants.

title: BASEBALL;Schott Issues An Apology; No Action Taken for Now
description: Marge Schott, under pressure from Major League Baseball officials, apologized yesterday for making laudatory comments about Adolf Hitler. But her statement left at least some of her critics unsatisfied, and Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, left open the possibility of disciplinary action against the Cincinnati Reds' managing partner.

title: Beat the Clock: Inspired Meals In 10 Minutes
description: SEA scallops and shiitake mushrooms surrounded by a puree of baby peas. Seared duck breast on mixed greens with a raspberry vinaigrette. Red beans and smoked pork over basmati rice. What do all these meals have in common? Sure, they all seem elegant. But they can also be prepared in 10 minutes.

title: Business Travel;A casino operator's dream: potential gamblers who may be bored and are unable to walk away.
description: IT was a sure bet that gambling in the skies would be the next seat-side diversion in airline cabins, and now it is happening -- with computerized gambling scheduled to begin aboard Swissair's 16 MD-11's and 5 Boeing 747's by November. Two small carriers are also going for gambling: Debonair Airways, a London-based start-up carrier that wants its BA-146's to be "the Southwest Airlines of Europe," and Oasis International Airlines, a Madrid charter company that flies Airbus 310's to the Caribbean, South America and the Far East.

title: Weld Joins Move to Drop Abortion Plank
description: Gov. William F. Weld has become the latest Republican governor to demand the removal of the anti-abortion plank from the party's platform, a move that seems geared as much to his own closely contested race for the United States Senate as to Bob Dole's Presidential campaign.

title: Brunch and Sambas for Mother's Day
description: MOTHER'S DAY is samba day at Riodizio, 417 Lafayette Street (near Astor Place). On Sunday, instructors from the Fred Astaire Dance School will give free samba classes from noon to 2 P.M., during brunch.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Murdoch Conglomerate's Earnings Fall Sharply
description: The News Corporation, the Australian media conglomerate controlled by Rupert Murdoch, said early today that earnings fell 69 percent in the third quarter, hurt by a charge stemming from the sale of its educational book-publishing business.

title: Fleet Agrees to Settle Accusation of Loan Discrimination
description: The Fleet Financial Group Inc. agreed today to pay about $4 million to hundreds of black and Hispanic customers to settle United States Justice Department allegations that minority borrowers were charged more for loans than whites.

title: Despite Trial, Kevorkian Is At a Suicide
description: Only hours after Dr. Jack Kevorkian left the stand on Monday in his latest assisted-suicide trial, he was present at the suicide of a 53-year-old Canadian who was a right-to-die advocate.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Cancellation of Article Spurs Resignations by 2 at Premiere
description: The top editors of Premiere magazine, a publication that covers the film business, resigned last night in a dispute over the magazine publisher's order to kill a column.

title: A Teen-Age Boy's Rude Awakening
description: Given the mystique that still surrounds the haute hippie culture of 25 years ago, it is surprising how few Hollywood movies have seriously explored those heady days of pot and incense when the Beatles and Bob Dylan were gods and life was one big cosmic wow. Maybe everyone was just too spaced-out to remember. Griffin Dunne's half-hour film, "The Duke of Groove," comes as close as any movie in recent memory to capturing the mood of the era and its hipper-than-thou pretensions in a way that's accurate and even nostalgic, but by no means overawed.

title: Judge Agrees to Step Aside to Aid Her Son
description: Senator Orrin G. Hatch, the Republican chairman of the Judiciary Committee, has demanded -- and received -- a commitment from a Federal appeals court judge that she will retire from full-time duty if he allows her son to become a judge on the same judicial circuit.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;3 More Collegians Take Aim at the N.B.A.
description: A University of California freshman, SHAREEF ABDUR-RAHIM, and two juniors, JEFF MCINNIS of North Carolina and JESS SETTLES of Iowa, yesterday became the latest underclassmen to try the jump to the National Basketball Association.

title: Cantor Fitzgerald Feud Ended by Accord
description: The feuding partners of Cantor Fitzgerald L.P., one of the nation's leading institutional brokers of Government securities, have reached a peaceful settlement of a bitter succession battle that erupted at the firm early this year.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S., Citing Chinese Piracy, Weighs Retaliatory Action Clinton Administration officials said that they had discovered evidence of previously undiscovered Chinese factories pirating American software, videos and music, and that they were preparing to announce retaliatory action against $2 billion in Chinese imports next week.

title: COMPANY NEWS;S.E.C. IS ASKED TO INVESTIGATE TRADING OF HASBRO
description: The Pacific Stock Exchange asked the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday to investigate trading in Hasbro Inc. options that occurred before Mattel Inc.'s failed bid in January. The exchange asked the S.E.C. to scrutinize trading in 12 accounts, an exchange spokesman, Dale Carlson, said. Unlike the exchange, the S.E.C. has the power to compel individuals to testify. Of the 12, several are Rhode Island residents "who appear to have some connection" to insiders at Hasbro, which is based in Pawtucket, R.I., he said. The value of Hasbro's options soared almost twelvefold in the five days before the public disclosure by Mattel of its unsolicited $5.2 billion bid. None of the 12 individuals appear to be connected with Mattel, which is based in El Segundo, Calif., Mr. Carlson said.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;Sampras Eulogizes Gullikson
description: PETE SAMPRAS gives credit for his seven Grand Slam tournament titles and No. 1 world ranking to his coach. Yesterday, Sampras was one of the pallbearers at Tim Gullikson's funeral, attended by about 650 people at St. Michael's Catholic Church in Wheaton, Ill., a community 30 miles west of downtown Chicago.

title: Many Troops Are Found Seriously Out of Shape
description: The first beads of sweat gathering on his forehead, Senior Airman Mark Barlet recently picked up the pace on his exercise bicycle.

title: U.P.S. Weighs Using Planes for Passengers On Weekends
description: United Parcel Service is preparing a plan for a charter service that would carry passengers on weekends when the company's aircraft sit idle.

title: World News Briefs;African Officials Meet To End Liberia Strife
description: After a West African peacekeeping force's humiliating failure to end weeks of intense fighting in the Liberian capital, foreign ministers from throughout this region began a two-day meeting here today in search of ways to end the crisis.

title: U.N. Report Suggests Israeli Attack Was Not a Mistake
description: A report by European military experts working for the United Nations said today that the Israeli artillery attack that killed more than 100 refugees in a camp in southern Lebanon in April did not appear to be a mistake, as the Israeli Government has insisted.

title: More Time for Candidates
description: Like CBS and Fox before them, NBC and CNN announced they would offer free television time to major Presidential candidates. Page B11.

title: Harlem Store Where 8 Died in an Arson Attack Plans to Reopen
description: Fred Harari, the Jewish businessman whose Harlem store was the target of a deadly arson attack after a racially charged lease dispute with a black record store owner, is planning to reopen in the same location, officials said yesterday.

title: At the Nation's Table: Washington;Kremlin Kitsch At the Mall
description: Karl Marx has left his mark on the American mall. In the food court at the Shops of Georgetown Mall sits the Taste of Russia, a Russian fast-food booth.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Plea in Shooting of Minister
description: A church member who shot an East Orange minister at least five times in a February carjacking pleaded guilty yesterday to attempted murder, robbery and weapons possession.

title: East Orange School Board Studies Purchase of Upsala College Property
description: East Orange's Board of Education is considering a plan to buy the shuttered 37-acre campus and buildings of Upsala College, which closed last May after being forced into bankruptcy, an official involved in the proceedings said today.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Fugard's Salute to the New South Africa
description: The patience of playgoers is sometimes rewarded. There's a rain check available for everyone who missed "Valley Song," which concluded a limited run at the Manhattan Theater Club's small Stage II in January. Athol Fugard's poignant celebration of the new South Africa reopened last night on the theater's main stage with LisaGay Hamilton, still radiant in the role of the 17-year-old farm girl she originated. She has a new co-star, Marius Weyers, the excellent South African actor who takes over the dual role Mr. Fugard played in the first engagement.

title: Journal;Loving Las Vegas
description: If anyone is still wondering whatever happened to the 60's, the answer may be here, in a pristine patch of desert a short drive from the Liberace Museum. The Hard Rock Casino has an autographed Bob Dylan guitar above the window where you cash in your chips, a handwritten Jim Morrison lyric sheet along the corridor where you weave your way to the bathroom, and four slot machines whose profits (a flashing sign announces) are proudly dedicated to saving the rain forest. You hear John Lennon sing "Imagine" while you lose your shirt at craps.

title: INSIDE
description: Israeli Account Challenged

title: TV Notes;Racing to Learn
description: Auto racing is a popular sport, but is it science? And how many teachers could get away with taking their classes to the speedway as a field trip?

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;Pippen Gets a Wake-Up Call and Puts Knicks to Sleep
description: By the time the fourth quarter began and the Knicks again were somehow staying with the world's most celebrated basketball team, Scottie Pippen was hearing jeers and feeling the same old playoff fears.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Bryant Quits La Salle Job
description: JOE BRYANT resigned yesterday as an assistant coach at La Salle University to follow the career of his son, KOBE, who hopes to jump from high school to the N.B.A.

title: Clinton's Partner in Deal Denies Breaking Law
description: Opening his defense, President Clinton's former business partner in the Whitewater land venture insisted today that a series of complex loans and land transactions he arranged more than a decade ago had violated no laws.

title: NBC and CNN Join in Offer Of Free Time To Candidates
description: Two dominoes fell and a third began to teeter yesterday, as NBC and CNN both announced that they would offer segments of free television time to the major Presidential candidates in the weeks leading up to the November election. CBS made a similar announcement on Monday, and Fox did so in February.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Operating Profit Rises 37% at British Petroleum
description: The British Petroleum Company said yesterday that its operating profit jumped by 37 percent in the first quarter, buoyed by gains in oil and gas volume and cost reductions. Profit rose to L633 million ($952 million), before taxes and special items, from L461 million in the first quarter of 1995.

title: Removal of Womb With a Fetus Inside Is Being Investigated
description: The New York State Department of Health confirmed yesterday that it was investigating an incident at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx in which doctors removed a woman's uterus during cancer surgery only to find that it contained a 7-week-old fetus.

description: The staff of the Federal Trade Commission has threatened to try to block the merger between Time Warner and Turner Broadcasting System because of fears that the deal would concentrate too much cable programming and distribution power in too few hands.

title: Judge Delays Proposed Settlement in Duke Estate
description: A proposed settlement in the dispute over the $1.2 billion estate of Doris Duke came under heavy scrutiny yesterday in Manhattan from Surrogate Eve M. Preminger, making it likely that the long struggle over the tobacco heiress's fortune will drag on a bit longer.

title: Nuances on Abortion
description: The flap over what Ralph Reed really believes about abortion had a clear beginning. He was trying to create some wiggle room for his friend Bob Dole on the most divisive issue facing the Senator's party and his Presidential campaign. In that sense, Mr. Reed was offering help with a problem that he and his allies had created.

description: A New York State judge threw out a defamation suit yesterday that had been filed by the former chief executive of Metallgesellschaft A.G., Heinz Schimmelbusch, against the German conglomerate and Deutsche Bank A.G.

description: Nineteen former and current members of the Bennington College faculty have taken the college to court, seeking reinstatement and back pay two years after the college, facing financial trouble, made wide cuts in the faculty and curriculum.

description: Two House Republicans today accused Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt of mixing politics with his official duties on taxpayer-financed trips and not promptly seeking reimbursement for the Government from local Democratic candidates.

title: BASEBALL;Yankees Feeling The Loss Of Leader
description: The clubhouse was somber and subdued although the Yankees defeated the Tigers, 12-5, last night at Yankee Stadium. There was no joy because the Yankees learned about David Cone's aneurysm minutes after the final out was recorded.

title: Personal Health

And they are looking for another 109,500 women from 50 to 79 to join their ranks as participants in the Women's Health Initiative, the largest series of prevention studies ever undertaken to determine how to protect the health of women as they age.

description: New York City is desperately in need of funds to fix its crumbling, overcrowded schools. What it has been getting instead are politicians eager to carp about problems without being part of the solution.
