description: THE FMR Corporation, the parent of Fidelity Investments, is developing a new office complex here as the mutual fund giant continues to expand outside its home state of Massachusetts.

description: Voters in Tennessee approved a referendum today that paves the way to bring the Oilers of the National Football League from Houston to Nashville for the 1998 season, if not earlier.

description: Yesterday was school board election day in New York City, and the president of one board, ousted three times on corruption and patronage charges, was making the rounds. At one polling place, he angrily told poll workers to be sure not to lose the votes cast by himself, his relatives and his friends. At another polling site, one of the few voters who turned out pronounced himself baffled by the whole process. "It's weird," Stephen Schiller said. "It's squirrelly. It's surreal."

description: A tremendous explosion leveled a rattletrap cooking oil factory in a busy industrial neighborhood here today, and the police reported that 39 workers and bystanders were injured.

description: The obsession with crayfish in their native country first brought Mats and Dafne Engstrom to California from Sweden in 1978. Their own obsession with caviar kept them there. description: The Pittsburgh Penguins beat the injury-depleted Rangers last night, proving nothing. Their 3-2 victory at Madison Square Garden in a strange game gave them a 2-games-to-1 lead in the Eastern Conference semifinals. But who can draw any conclusions so early in this amorphous second-round series of the Stanley Cup playoffs?

description: NANCY KERRIGAN, the two-time Olympic medal winner, and her husband and manager, JERRY SOLOMON, are expecting their first child in December. The two were married last year in Boston. (AP)

title: Family Calls Serb a Victim of Mistaken Identity
description: Ljubomir Tadic's family videos are fuzzy from use. But he assures visitors that poor quality does not hide veracity, and as he pops one after another into his recorder, rewinding and re-running them, he says there can be no doubt that a terrible mistake has been made in The Hague.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MITSUBISHI FACES PROTESTS OVER HARASSMENT SUIT
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson is seeking a boycott of Mitsubishi autos, and the National Organization for Women is planning to picket dealerships until the company settles a sexual harassment lawsuit. Mitsubishi issued a statement yesterday expressing regret over any lost business for dealers and said it would "cooperate fully" with the Government to resolve the issue. While NOW had not authorized a boycott, the organization's president, Patricia Ireland, said, "We can't imagine any of the 50 percent of new-car buyers who are women or the men who care about them" buying a product from "this kind of corporation." The Federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has filed a class-action lawsuit accusing Mitsubishi Motor Manufacturing of America, a subsidiary of the Japanese auto maker in Normal, Ill., of permitting sexual harassment of hundreds of women at its assembly plant. Mr. Jackson and Ms. Ireland spoke at a news conference after meeting with E.E.O.C. officials in Chicago.

title: ON PRO BASKETBALL;When It's Crunch Time, Meltdown Begins
description: In two consecutive frustrating losses, the fourth quarter has been the Knicks' undoing.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday with an article about business executives's view of the Presidential election, misstated the title of Drew Lewis at the Union Pacific Corporation. He is chairman and chief executive, not chairman of the executive committee.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;Jazz Routs Spurs in Opener
description: This time, it was San Antonio's turn to be trounced by the Utah Jazz.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TIGER REAL ESTATE TO BUY KAHLER FOR $222 MILLION
description: Tiger Real Estate Fund L.P. said yesterday that it would buy the Kahler Realty Corporation for about $222 million. Kahler, based in Rochester, Minn., said the deal consisted of $77 million in cash and the assumption of $145 million in debt. The bid values Kahler at $17 a share, and the company's stock rose 75 cents yesterday, to $16.25, in Nasdaq trading. Kahler owns or manages 23 hotels, primarily in Minnesota, Utah, Idaho, Montana and Arizona. The company earned $3 million on revenues of $139.9 million in 1995. Tiger, a private New York-based fund, said its portfolio was valued at about $1.5 billion.

title: World News Briefs;140 Are Lost as Boat Sinks Off Sierra Leone
description: More than 140 people were dead or missing today after a boat capsized Monday off the coast of Sierra Leone, the police and rescuers said.

description: Washington may be known as a city of talk, but the actor JAMES EARL JONES says he thinks of it as "a city of great listeners."

description: There couldn't have been a better way for American Ballet Theater to introduce its first "Swan Lake" of the season than with the splendid performance delivered by Susan Jaffe and Jose Manuel Carreno on Monday night.

title: Grunge Outside, But Clean Inside
description: AND now, the ultimate irony about Generation X, the grunge group that has made irony its trademark: 20-somethings are not slackers when it comes to housecleaning. They care more about scrubbing the floors, wiping grease off the stove and washing the windows than graying, stressed-out baby boomers.

title: COMPANY NEWS;JOHN WILEY TO ACQUIRE MAJORITY OF A GERMAN PUBLISHER
description: John Wiley & Sons said yesterday that it would buy a 90 percent interest in the VCH Publishing Group for $100 million. Wiley, a New York-based publisher of scientific and technical books and journals, as well as textbooks and educational materials for colleges and universities, will purchase the stake from the Pallas Investment Group and the German Chemical Society. The German Chemical Society and German Pharmaceutical Society will retain a minority stake in VCH, a scientific, technical and professional publisher based in Weinheim, Germany. VCH has annual revenues of $60 million. Wiley had revenues of $331 million in the year ended April 30.

title: SOFTWARE PIRATES GROWING IN NUMBER IN CHINA, U.S. SAYS
description: Clinton Administration officials said today that they had discovered evidence of a large number of previously undiscovered Chinese factories producing pirated versions of American software, videos and music, and that they are preparing to announce retaliatory action next week against more than $2 billion in Chinese imports to the United States.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HIGHER OFFER IS MADE FOR NORWEGIAN DRILLER
description: The battle for Transocean A/S heated up yesterday when the Reading & Bates Corporation raised its offer for the Norwegian oil and gas driller, which agreed last week to merge with Sonat Offshore Drilling Inc. The $1.56 billion bid reflected a premium over the $1.46 billion deal with Sonat Offshore, which, like Reading & Bates, is a drilling company based in Houston. The previous Reading & Bates offer was valued about $1.51 billion. Transocean said it would study the new offer. Shares of Reading & Bates fell 75 cents yesterday, to $21.125, on the New York Stock Exchange; Sonat Offshore shares fell $1.875, to $48.625.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Sixers to Name a New General Manager
description: BRAD GREENBERG, a former executive with the Portland Trail Blazers, will be named general manager of the Philadelphia 76ers today, it was learned. Greenberg is to replace JOHN LUCAS as general manager. It was not known if Lucas will be retained as coach. The 76ers went 18-64 last season, with only the expansion Vancouver Grizzlies holding a worse record in the league. (AP)

description: Manhattan College, a springboard for basketball coaches in recent years, could become a launching pad for one of its top players.

title: Foreign Affairs;The Real Bosnia Debate
description: For the past few months U.S. and NATO officials have been saying how pleased they are at how well the cease-fire and separation of forces in Bosnia has been implemented, but how upset they are that the political clauses of the Dayton peace agreement -- such as the return of refugees and the holding of elections -- have not been carried out. This is not an accident. This is a structural contradiction at the heart of Dayton. And it may soon become the foreign policy issue in the U.S. election.

description: In one of West Africa's worst outbreaks of infectious disease in recent memory, bacterial meningitis has infected more than 100,000 people in the last three months, killing more than 10,000, international health care workers say.

description: The Food and Drug Administration should revoke the military's ability to give soldiers experimental drugs without their consent because of mistakes made during the Persian Gulf war, consumer and veterans' groups said today.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Elegant Fingerwork by a Pianist Hurt a Year Ago
description: On Sunday night the Brazilian pianist Joao Carlos Martins gave his first major concert in the United States since 1985. He played at Carnegie Hall with the American Symphony Orchestra. That he played at all was remarkable: a year ago, while recording in Europe, Mr. Martins suffered severe hand injuries from a brutal beating during an attempted robbery. Extensive rehabilitation has mostly restored his functioning, as was clear from his formidable performances of concertos by Ravel and Ginastera, conducted by JoAnn Falletta.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FORD SELLS SHARES OF CONSUMER FINANCE UNIT
description: The Associates First Capital Corporation sold 67 million shares yesterday at $29 each to raise $1.94 billion in the nation's third-largest initial public offering. Associates, the consumer finance unit of the Ford Motor Company, initially sought $25 to $28 for the shares, but raised the price range because of investor demand. A group of underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company priced the stock yesterday after the close of trading. Associates, based in Irving, Tex., is the largest publicly owned finance company in the United States.

title: A Summit's Organizers Sue Club Med Over a Blackface Skit

description: A Federal judge yesterday dismissed a sex discrimination lawsuit brought against Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University by a woman who charged that its handling of her rape complaint against two football players had given them preferential treatment in order to benefit the all-male football team.

title: Corrections
description: The "On Baseball" column on Thursday, about baseball's new advertising campaign, misstated the amount of the sport's retail sales of licensed merchandise in 1993. The figure, cited in a quotation by Don Gibson, vice president in charge of the sale of baseball properties, was $2.8 to $3 billion, not 28 to 30 billion. The comment should have read, "We've had a number of licensees tell us they expect to exceed their 1993 numbers, and that's when we peaked at an estimated $2.8 to $3 billion in retail sales."

Cone is expected to be sidelined indefinitely.

According to plans unveiled yesterday by Kajima International Inc., of Englewood, the privately financed project, situated between Giants Stadium and the Continental Airlines Arena, would include an artificial mountain, streams, waterfalls, forests and gardens as well as movie theaters, stores and restaurants.

description: The former president of a bankrupt Japanese credit union and six other former executives were arrested today on suspicion of breach of trust in connection with loans made.

description: Harvey Gantt, former Mayor of Charlotte, earned a rematch against Senator Jesse Helms with a solid victory tonight over a former pharmaceutical company executive in a Democratic primary marked by subtle racial overtones.

description: Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis has revamped its media division.

title: COMPANY NEWS;LAYOFFS AND OTHER CUTS PLANNED BY GEORGIA-PACIFIC
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation announced a major cost-cutting program yesterday that was intended to increase profits by $400 million over three years. The company said it would offer voluntary retirement to 1,400 salaried workers and would make further reductions through layoffs. Georgia-Pacific, a forest products concern, said it would take an unspecified charge in the second quarter to pay for the moves. The company's shares fell 25 cents yesterday, to $77, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Contemporary Art Bounces Back
description: If, as the old adage goes, auctions are an exercise in temperature-taking, it's fair to say the market for contemporary art is running a fever.

title: COMPANY NEWS;LITTON INDUSTRIES REVAMPS ITS OFFER FOR SPERRY MARINE
description: Litton Industries said yesterday that it had amended the terms of its $158 million acquisition of Sperry Marine Inc. to pay all cash instead of cash and stock. Litton, a maker of electronics and military systems that is based in Woodland Hills, Calif., said the initial plan to pay cash and about 2.2 million Litton shares had been based on expectations that the capital gains tax law would change to make such a move advantageous. Sperry, a maker of electronic navigation and guidance systems, is owned by J. F. Lehman & Company, a private investment partnership, and is based in Charlottesville, Va. Its shares rose 75 cents, to $45, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: In Cold War Throwback, Moscow Says London Runs a Spy Ring
description: In one of the most contentious spy cases since the collapse of the Soviet Union, Russia has accused Britain of running a spy ring and threatened to expel as many as nine British diplomats.

title: Lauded Holyoke Must Work to Lure Students
description: Since its founding 159 years ago, Mount Holyoke College has attracted idealistic young women seeking a rigorous education on the way to public service or academic careers. Its officials point with pride to alumnae like Frances Perkins, the nation's first female Cabinet member, appointed by President Franklin D. Roosevelt, and Wendy Wasserstein, the playwright.

title: BASEBALL;Throat Cancer Strikes the Dodgers' Butler
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers' center fielder, Brett Butler, has throat cancer and has said he will not return to baseball. The club said today that a tumor the size of a plum, found when Butler, 38, had a tonsillectomy in Atlanta, was determined to be cancerous.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AMERICAN HOME SEEKS A BUYER FOR ITS FOOD BUSINESS
description: The American Home Products Corporation said yesterday that it was seeking a buyer for its food business, which includes Jiffy Pop popcorn and Chef Boy-Ar-Dee. The company, a diversified health care and consumer goods concern in Madison, N.J., said it was seeking bids in an effort to drive down debt from its $9.6 billion acquisition of American Cyanamid in 1994 and to concentrate on its high-margin pharmaceutical business. Some analysts expect the price tag to be at least $1 billion or as much as twice the unit's 1995 sales of $819 million. Wall Street reacted favorably to the move, which was reported yesterday in The Wall Street Journal. The company's shares rose $2.25, to $53.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;A Top Barings Figure Barred For 3 Years
description: Peter Norris, who ran investment banking at Barings P.L.C. when it collapsed last year after $1.3 billion in trading losses, was banned today by British authorities from working in a senior executive position in the securities industry for three years.

description: IN her kitchen at Il Borghetto, a rustically beautiful country inn in the Tuscan hills 15 miles south of Florence, Francesca Cianchi, the founding chef of the New York restaurant Mezzaluna, opens her weeklong cooking class with an explanation of the traditions and philosophies of the region's cuisine.

description: Inspired by the discovery last March that illegal immigrants were doing maintenance work at the State House, a Democratic State Senator has introduced a bill to bar companies that hire illegal immigrants from doing business with any state or local government agency for three years.

description: A week off certainly did not hurt Shaquille O'Neal, Anfernee Hardaway and the Orlando Magic.

title: COMPANY NEWS;U.S. ROBOTICS SHARES RISE AFTER AGREEMENT WITH AT&T
description: The shares of the U.S. Robotics Corporation reached an all-time high yesterday, rising 6.3 percent after the AT&T Corporation selected U.S. Robotics to make equipment that gives customers high-speed access to AT&T's data and Internet networks. No financial details were released. U.S. Robotics shares rose $10.50, to $177.25, on Nasdaq. AT&T stock rose 87.5 cents, to $60, on the New York Stock Exchange. Rakesh Sood, an analyst at Hambrecht & Quist, estimated the size of the contract at $500 million over the next two to three years.

Our pledge is: Never and never again shall the laws of our land rend our people apart or legalize their oppression and repression."

title: Stars Fail to Shine at Contemporary-Art Auction

As has been true at all the important fine-art auctions of the last two weeks, the middle market -- works priced at $50,000 to $250,000 -- is where the action is.

title: Corrections

The service considers removal of the clit oris to be severe and cutting the hood of the clitoris as "relatively mild."

title: Clinton and Dole Clash on Delay Of Wage and Gas-Tax Measures
description: President Clinton and Senator Bob Dole blamed each other today for gridlock in Congress, as senators from both parties clawed for maximum advantage on obvious election-year issues like raising the minimum wage and reducing the Federal gasoline tax.

description: Eddie Antar, the co-founder of the giant Crazy Eddie discount electronics stores, pleaded guilty yesterday to a Federal charge that he had defrauded shareholders of more than $74 million by manipulating the company's stock.

description: The First Data Corporation plans to move the headquarters of Western Union, its money transfer and messaging unit, to Greenwood Village, Colo., from Paramus, N.J., where 150 jobs will be eliminated.

description: The Knicks did not want to be a part of a coronation. They were tired of hearing about the greatness of the Bulls before the series began. Now that Chicago has won the first two games, the Knicks are quite irritated.

description: In 1979, ALICE TRILLIN wrote a letter in 20 minutes to BRUNO NAVASKY, the 12-year-old son of her friends Victor and Annie Navasky, who had just learned he had cancer.

description: The thought occurred to Dwight Gooden that there was something he could do for David Cone, some gesture in support of a teammate facing surgery. Before Gooden took the mound last night, for a Yankee team trying to fill the void Cone's sudden absence has created, he decided that putting Cone's number on his cap would be the right thing to do.

description: Tracing the evolution of a great composer's style is always fascinating, but there is an extra measure of delight when that development includes the invention of expressive techniques that have retained their power and influence over the centuries. Claudio Monteverdi devoted himself to giving human passion an unambiguous musical vocabulary. In the bargain, he contributed mightily to the birth of opera and its establishment as a durable form. title: Economic Scene;A supercomputer deal pits buying American vs. fair trade.
description: AMERICANS make the best supercomputers in the world. Or at least they did. Two Japanese electronics giants, Fujitsu and NEC, are challenging the supremacy of Cray Research, the Minnesota supercomputer specialist that was recently bought by Silicon Graphics. The three are bidding to sell a supercomputer to the National Center for Atmospheric Research, an agency of the National Science Foundation. Should Washington come to Cray's rescue and lean on the foundation to buy American?

title: Wife of Jailed Nigerian Candidate Charged
description: The wife of the man who is believed to have won Nigeria's annulled presidential elections in 1993 and who is now in prison, was charged today with publishing false documents.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report on April 23 about the selection of Andre Dubus for the Rea Award for the Short Story misstated the selection criterion. The award was given to Mr. Dubus, as it has been to other writers, in recognition of his entire body of work, not just for the short story collection "Dancing After Hours."

title: World News Briefs;Chechnya Opens Inquiry Into Copter Attack
description: Prosecutors in the Kremlin-installed Chechen government began an investigation today into a helicopter attack on the outdoor market of a major Chechen town.

title: Rome Tribunal Opens Trial Of Ex-Nazi in Massacre of 335
description: The case against Erich Priebke, an 82-year-old former Nazi SS officer who is likely to be the last defendant in a World War II atrocities trial, began today before an Italian military tribunal, more than half a century after he took part in the massacre of 335 Italian men and boys in caves outside Rome.

title: Clinton Is Denied More Delay in Suit
description: A Federal appeals court today refused to grant President Clinton a further delay in a sexual harassment lawsuit that he wants put off until he leaves office. But Mr. Clinton's lawyer said later that the case would probaly be delayed further.

title: Clinton Approves Plan for Sanctions Against China Over Piracy
description: President Clinton, meeting with his top foreign policy and economic advisers about rising tensions with China, approved a plan today to go ahead with sanctions on Chinese exports to the United States if Beijing fails to stop producing pirated American software, movies and music, the White House said.

title: THEATER REVIEW;A Fairy Tale Of Laughter, Disguises And Love
description: Encyclopedias identify him as Pierre Carlet de Chamblain de Marivaux (1688-1763). In France, where he's regarded as the most important dramatist to appear between the death of Moliere and the birth of Beaumarchais, it's enough to mention only his last name. Now the playwright's genius is finally being being recognized in the United States, where an increasing number of Marivaux comedies are beginning to turn up Off Broadway and in regional theaters.

description: And now, the newest controversy on the frontier of low-fat food: the battle of the dueling olestra hot lines.

description: Results of 230 tests on the Toms River water supply, including samples taken from 23 schools, found no harmful contaminants, the State Health Commissioner, Leonard Fishman, said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Economic Expansion Is Solid, Fed Survey Finds The economy picked up at a moderate pace in March and April, a survey by the Federal Reserve found, more evidence that expansion is generally solid again, except in the New York area. Furthermore, price increases were subdued, the central bank said.

description: The Israeli political race burst into Israeli homes today as the major parties opened their television campaigns with a slick cascade of doves, babies, jingles and slogans, all focused on a single issue -- security.

description: On the cloudy and chilly eve of the McDonald's L.P.G.A. Championship -- almost a year to the day from what has come to be known as "the Ben Wright incident" -- the Ladies Professional Golf Association has a clear strategy. Simply put, the organization wants to bury the entire issue permanently beneath a blizzard of positive news about its present, bright forecasts for its future and just the slightest hint of levity about its past.

description: South Africa adopted a new Constitution today, officially and peacefully completing the country's transition from centuries of white supremacy to a nonracial democracy.

title: Currents;Classic African Tables On the Internet
description: FORGET Alice's Restaurant. These days you can get anything you want, including intricately carved tables from East Africa, on the Internet. Lamu Industries' chunky tables, in a variety of shapes, sizes and prices ($1,000 to $3,000) can be found at http://www.mmrcorp. com/corporate/lamu/; the E-mail address is lamu@aol.com. The designer, Bo van den Assum, 47, offers photographs to download. The tables are adapted from centuries-old widows' beds found on Lamu, an Indian Ocean island off Kenya. The collection is handmade of mbambakofi, a renewable hardwood that resembles mahogany.

description: There was never much doubt that the Anti-Terrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996 would someday wind up in the Supreme Court. By restricting the ability of prisoners on death row to appeal their sentences, the act sharply challenges the historic authority of the Federal courts. What is truly surprising is that the Supreme Court has chosen to move so fast.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DIANA SHARES RISE ON WORD OF INTERNET DEAL
description: The shares of the Diana Corporation rose by one-third yesterday after the company's Sattel Communications unit agreed to supply communications lines for Internet services to the Concentric Network Corporation for undisclosed terms. With the agreement, Diana became the latest stock investors have embraced amid the frenzy over the Internet. "Breathe the word 'Internet' around a stock and anything can happen," said Tom Pincince, senior analyst at Forrester Research. The shares rose $17.25, to $66, on the New York Stock Exchange before trading was halted. Sattel will supply high-speed communications lines and services to about 21 sites in the United States for Concentric Network, which is based in Cupertino, Calif.

title: Woman Is Arrested in Thefts From Diocese
description: The former pension manager for the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn was arrested yesterday and charged with embezzling more than $1 million in church funds, the Brooklyn District Attorney's office said.

There was considerable grumbling about a penchant for dive-taking that the Rangers feel their opponents have all-too-often displayed in this series. And their feistiest defenseman was at the eye doctor a day after having a puck bounce off his head and into his own goal.

description: A Federal judge gave preliminary approval today to an amended $351 million settlement of a lawsuit over pricing by some of the nation's biggest pharmaceutical companies, but analysts said consumers were unlikely to see a major change in drug prices right away.

description: From pint-sized Jeep Wranglers to Chevrolet Suburbans the size of a garage, sport utility vehicles have been the mainstay of profits at Detroit's Big Three auto makers since the late 1980's. But now a small traffic jam of new models is emerging in the market, and auto executives predict that the profits, while still enormous, will start to erode.

description: Stung by a United Nations report that accused Israel of deliberately shelling a refugee camp in south Lebanon, the Israeli Army released a video today indicating that a reconnaissance plane was not used to target the United Nations base.

description: Concerned that Burundi is again on the verge of widespread violence, the Clinton Administration and peacekeeping officials here are urging that an international contingency force be assembled to restore order, if necessary without the approval of Burundi's Government.

title: COMPANY NEWS;OMNICARE STOCK FALLS ON WORD OF INQUIRY AT UNIT
description: The shares of Omnicare Inc. of Cleveland declined $4.375, to $50, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange after the company said on Tuesday that Government investigators had seized records from Omnicare's Home Pharmacy Services unit. In its statement on Tuesday, Omnicare said that the Government had not informed the company of the purpose of the inquiry but that it was cooperating with it. Omnicare acquired Home Pharmacy, which is based in Belleville, Ill., in 1992. Omnicare, which provides pharmacy services to health care institutions, said the unit accounted for less than 5 percent of sales.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;U.S. Loans for Drought Relief
description: Small businesses in 19 New Jersey counties that rely on sales to farmers may be eligible for up to $1.5 million in disaster loans because of financial losses resulting from last summer's drought, the Department of Agriculture said yesterday.

description: BRAD GREENBERG knows what he wants out of the Philadelphia 76ers next season. He just isn't very forthcoming about how the talent-thin team will get to that point.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CARD SERVICES COMPANY HAS BIG FIRST DAY OF TRADING
description: The shares of the Nova Corporation soared yesterday, their first day of trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The stock of Nova, which processes transactions for credit and charge cards, closed at $29.125 in trading of 3.3 million shares. The company, which is based in Atlanta, sold 3.5 million shares at $19 to raise $66.5 million. The sale represents a 12.5 percent stake.

description: A Dallas Cowboys "hanger-on" said he clandestinely taped MICHAEL IRVIN and got him to talk about drug use because he was upset that the players did not appreciate things he did for them.

description: GEORGE BEST, who walked out of soccer at age 26 and never played in a World Cup, was hailed today as the finest player ever produced by Britain.

Though pop and world music stars like Joan Osborne and Salif Keita performed at the 27th annual festival, which attracted a record crowd of 472,000 from April 26 to May 5, the personality of the event was shaped by the diverse array of indigenous musicians.

title: Begging for Books
description: When New York State's Education Commissioner, Richard Mills, recently announced that high school graduation requirements would be toughened statewide, he asked the Legislature to support the effort with more money for education in general and for textbooks in particular. As things now stand, public schools will lose more than $150 million over all under Gov. George Pataki's current budget proposal, and the schools may not get all of it back. But by making a special plea for textbooks, Mr. Mills underscored an obvious point -- effective education is impossible when students lack the most fundamental learning tools.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Murder in East Anglia, At a Very Chic Clinic
description: Like David Suchet with Hercule Poirot (and Jeremy Brett, before his death last year, with Sherlock Holmes), Roy Marsden has had a marathon career run with Adam Dalgliesh on PBS's "Mystery!" For 13 years, beginning in "Death of an Expert Witness," Mr. Marsden has been shaping to a brilliant fare-thee-well the role of Dalgliesh, the Scotland Yard detective created by the best-selling novelist P. D. James.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;New Marketing Plan Helps Sainsbury Stock
description: The shares of J. Sainsbury P.L.C. jumped yesterday after the British supermarket operator rolled out a new marketing plan that includes loyalty shopping cards and a refocused home-improvement business. The stock, which traded on Tuesday at a two-year low, gained 15 pence yesterday, to 372, or about $5.60.

We have come to understand that once every few years can be enough, especially if there is hope for the future.

Ms. Andrews is angry that her show did not get any other nominations and was passed over for best musical in favor of long-closed, long-forgotten productions like "Chronicle of a Death Foretold." Producers of the televised Tony Awards show are horrified. The popular Ms. Andrews was supposed to be their star.

description: It has become a common ritual at rock concerts: people banging against one another on the dance floor, hurling themselves from the stage into the crowd, tossing one another overhead like beach balls. It is known as moshing, and while some may find the practice mystifying, possibly even violent, few would think of it as life-threatening.

description: The Swiss Government said today that it planned to grant foreign airlines greater access to its domestic market and eliminate Swissair A.G.'s monopoly status.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Brokerage Settles Claims
description: Paine Webber Inc. has agreed to pay the state $149,842 to settle claims that its brokers falsely marketed limited partnerships as low-risk investments from 1986 through 1992, Mark S. Herr, the State Director of Consumer Affairs, said yesterday. New Jersey was among 23 states to settle with the brokerage house after a Federal agreement in January, in which Paine Webber was ordered to pay $175 million to settle claims. Mr. Herr said the company sold 5,131 New Jerseyans a total of $33.7 million in oil, gas, equipment and real estate-related investments.

title: Dominguin, 69, Bullfighter In Hemingway Chronicle, Dies
description: Dominguin, a leading bullfighter in the 1940's and 50's who was a close friend of Picasso, a lover of Ava Gardner and a dueling matador featured by Ernest Hemingway in "The Dangerous Summer," died today at his home in Soto Grande, in San Roque, in Cadiz province. He was 69.

title: William N. Copley, 77, Painter And Collector of Surrealist Art
description: William N. Copley, an American Surrealist painter of sweetly risque images of naked women and men in starchy Edwardian suits, died on Tuesday at his home in Sugar Loaf Key, Fla. He was 77 and had lived in Florida since 1991.

title: Currents;More Than Just a Fence
description: THE designer Constantin Boym, a political refugee of the Brezhnev-era Soviet Union, looks for significance in the familiar and mass-marketed. His design for "Between Fences" at the National Building Museum -- a collaboration with Gregory K. Dreicer, a curator -- ponders the pattern and inspiration of fences. "In Russia, fences might have looked the same, but had a different meaning," said Mr. Boym, 41. "In America they are so familiar they are totally overlooked." To drive home the symbolism, Mr. Boym will install a 15-foot-high white picket fence -- the familiar made to look unfamiliar. Photos and drawings will be mounted on fences and chain link -- "so incredibly ingenious, made virtually of nothing, just two thin wires -- yet so strong." The exhibition opens on May 31 in Washington, at 401 F Street NW.

title: Safir Makes An Insider No. 1 Deputy
description: Choosing a member of the Police Department's old guard as his top aide, Police Commissioner Howard Safir has appointed Assistant Chief Tosano J. Simonetti as first deputy police commissioner, senior police officials said yesterday.

title: Thousands Protest Against Transfer of Nuclear Waste in Germany
description: Demonstrators in northern Germany fought running battles with the police today in an unsuccessful attempt to prevent a container of atomic waste from reaching a storage depot that has become a symbol of environmentalist opposition to nuclear energy.

title: Giuliani Offers A Fresh Budget With New Cuts
description: Discarding the financial plan he submitted only three months ago, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that his 1997 budget would eliminate many of the financial gimmicks and overly optimistic assumptions that led to repeated criticisms from fiscal monitors in the first half of his term.

title: Executive Changes
description: AYDIN CORP., Horsham, Pa., said Ayhan Hakimoglu, the company's chief executive, had resigned. He will be replaced by I. Gary Bard.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MERCURY RECORDS BUYS STAKE IN A ROCK LABEL
description: Mercury Records, a unit of Polygram of the Netherlands, has acquired 50 percent of Capricorn Records, a Nashville rock label. The deal is the first significant acquisition for Mercury since Danny Goldberg, a former chairman of Warner Brothers Records, was named chief executive in October. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. The president of Capricorn, Phil Walden, will own the balance of the label, which he started in 1969. Capricorn found success in the 1970's with a roster that included the Allman Brothers, the Marshall Tucker Band and Elvin Bishop. The label then lay dormant for 12 years, until 1991, when it entered a joint venture with Warner Brothers Records. The two parted ways a few years later, and Capricorn was distributed independently. Capricorn's biggest-selling artist is the rock band 311. Polygram is a subsidiary of Philips Electronics N.V.

title: MORE CHANGES IN CANADA'S PUBLISHING INDUSTRY
description: A shake-up of Canada's publishing industry accelerated this week when the cable television operator Rogers Communications Inc. put its controlling stake in the Toronto Sun Publishing Corporation on the block. In addition, Hollinger Inc. gained a tighter grip on the community newspaper market by buying seven papers in Ontario from the Thomson Corporation. Rogers said on Tuesday that it would sell its 62.54 percent stake in Toronto Sun, whose newspapers include The Toronto Sun and three other popular Canadian tabloids. Rogers gained control of Toronto Sun in 1994 through its acquisition of Maclean Hunter Ltd. Analysts said Hollinger and Quebecor Inc. were the most likely bidders for the stake. The acquisition by Hollinger of the community papers follows its purchase last week of seven newspapers in Atlantic Canada from Thomson.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BANKRUPT BARNEY'S PLANS BONUSES TO KEEP EMPLOYEES
description: Barney's Inc., the retailer, proposed an $8.3 million program yesterday that would use bonuses to keep executives at the company and to guarantee severance packages should employees lose their jobs. Barney's said the bonus plan was needed to combat an "alarming rate of attrition" since the company sought Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in January. Barneys said 52 employees, including 12 so-called key employees, had left the company since the filing. Bankruptcy Judge James Garrity will consider the proposal in a hearing scheduled for next Wednesday in New York. The severance plan would cushion the blow of any firings for 473 Barneys employees. The bonus plan would augment the salaries of 87 top executives by 15 percent to 25 percent. Robert and Gene Pressman, the company's co-chief executives, would not benefit from either plan.

title: ABC Joins Others TV Time
description: ABC joined its network brethren yesterday in offering free television time to the major Presidential candidates, announcing that it would invite them to appear on a live one-hour special in prime time, during the last week before the election.

title: Perfumania to Buy Stake
description: Perfumania Inc. said today that it planned to buy the retail operations of Model Imperial Inc. and a 51 percent stake in the company, a distributor of fragrances and cosmetics, for an undisclosed amount. Perfumania, which is based here, operates 196 perfume stores and distributes fragrances and related products. Model Imperial, which is based in Boca Raton, Fla., has 650 licensed perfume and cosmetics counters in department stores and owns five Cosmetique stores.

title: Students Should Not Be Above the Law
description: In medieval Europe, there were two parallel court systems: the church's and the king's. The big difference between them was that the church courts did not resort to capital punishment.

title: Don't Toast Those Declines in Crime Just Yet;Computing Fear
description: To the Editor:

title: Tape Recalls A Canadian's Gratitude To Kevorkian
description: A Canadian who committed suicide in Detroit with the help of Dr. Jack Kevorkian said in a videotaped message released here today by right-to-die advocates that, had his fate been left to the Canadian Government, his suffering would have lasted " much longer, perhaps indefinitely."

title: Early Returns In Indian Vote Show Setback For Premier
description: Early returns in India's general elections pointed today toward sharp losses for the governing Congress Party in about half of the states, the only ones where counting had begun.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Bill Communications Acquires a Show
description: Bill Communications, part of VNU, has acquired the annual Premium Incentive Show from the Miller Freeman unit of United News and Media P.L.C. in San Francisco. Terms were not disclosed. The 61st annual show, which will be managed by Miller Freeman, is being held through today at the Jacob Javits Convention Center in Manhattan.

title: BASEBALL;Bullpen Burns Up Another Mets Lead
description: The top of Dallas Green's wish list reads like this: 1. Relief pitchers who don't blow leads. 2. A right fielder. 3. Relief pitchers who don't blow leads.

title: 3 New York Subway Veterans Help Restore Transit in Sarajevo
description: In 31 years with the New York City Transit Authority, William Robbins saw the damage that people can do to a city's fleet of buses and trains. Graffiti. Slashed tires. Windshields shattered by rocks or even gunfire.

title: News Analysis;Clinton-Dole Duel: Gridlock Returns
description: Temporarily out of money, Bob Dole thinks he has found a winning issue, one that can help him emerge from a perilous slump. Riding high, Bill Clinton thinks he has found one that can help cement his lead.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;First Lady to Speak at Drew
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton will speak at Drew University's commencement May 18 and receive an honorary degree, officials announced yesterday.

title: Adding Drama to a Musical, Andrews Spurns the Tonys
description: In a gesture worthy of an old-style Broadway melodrama, Julie Andrews, the star of "Victor/Victoria," announced yesterday that she was withdrawing from consideration for the best-actress Tony Award, in protest of what she viewed as the humiliating snub the musical had received in earning just a single Tony nomination.

title: British Airways' Canadian Tie-In
description: British Airways P.L.C. said today that it planned to form a marketing alliance with Canadian Airlines International, that nation's No. 2 carrier. It will be the British airline's second such alliance in less than a month.

title: Agriculture Official Concedes Errors in Food Stamp Survey
description: The goal of a $25,000 poll that the Department of Agriculture commissioned from a leading Democratic pollster last year seemed simple enough: survey public opinion on changes in the food stamp program.

title: Down 78 Before Noon, Up 53.11 at Close
description: Stocks rebounded sharply late yesterday in a rally touched off by a drop in interest rates.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-21

title: Gen. Jean Crepin, 87, Dies; Strong Supporter of de Gaulle
description: Gen. Jean Crepin, a retired French Army officer who oversaw the development of the Exocet missiles, which played a key role in the war in the Falklands, died on Saturday in the French department of Seine-et-Marne, near Paris, where he lived. He was 87.

title: BOXING;Lewis Is Hoping to Earn Some Style Points, Too
description: Oh, no. Another British heavyweight.

title: Did Byrd Reach Pole? His Diary Hints 'No'
description: Seventy years ago, on May 9, 1926, in a decade notable for pioneering aviation exploits, Richard E. Byrd and his pilot-mechanic, Floyd Bennett, won fame as the first to fly an airplane to the North Pole. Or so they claimed. Doubts that they reached the pole have persisted to this day, and a few skeptics have suspected that they never even made a serious attempt.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Protecting a Brainy Idyll
description: Albert Einstein, other scientists and scholars, and the nature-loving public have enjoyed walking the trails of a 250-acre woodland on the grounds of the Institute for Advanced Study. The woods are part of 589 acres of undeveloped land belonging to the institute and bordering the state's Princeton Battlefield Park.

title: Currents;Bathouse as Shrine
description: FOR preservationists, the offense was on a par with bulldozing Stonehenge: a plan to demolish part of the Trenton Bath House (top), the first building by Louis I. Kahn (1901-1974) in his own practice. Its cruciform arrangement includes four open-air cinder block pavilions (bottom), built from 1955 to 1957 in Ewing, N.J. Robert Venturi calls the bathhouse "a shrine" and it has been cited by the National Register of Historic Places for its "transcendent importance." Robert G. Frey, director of the Jewish Community Centers of the Delaware Valley, which operates the bathhouse on its day-camp grounds, says that structural stress to two pavilions could endanger campers who will gather there in June. "It could take $50,000 to $100,000 to restore the pavilions, and we're a nonprofit organization. We let them know that demolition was a direction we might need to go," he said. Responding to protests, the center's staff plans to meet today with a structural engineer. "Ideally, we'd like the pavilions to be preserved," Mr. Frey said, "and for outside funding to cover the entire costs."

title: COMPANY NEWS;ADCO TECHNOLOGIES CONSIDERING A SALE OR MERGER
description: Adco Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it had hired Schroder Wertheim & Company to help the company consider its options, including a merger or a sale. Adco, a maker of sealants, adhesives and other specialty chemicals used in roofing, windows and automobiles, did not provide additional details. Adco, which is based in Michigan Center, Mich., sold two million shares at $7 in an initial public offering in February 1995. The stock closed yesterday at $7.125, down 87.5 cents, on Nasdaq.

title: Florida Executive Is Convicted Of Unregistered Securities Fraud
description: A Florida executive has been convicted of securities fraud in what the Securities and Exchange Commission said today was the first criminal case involving a scheme to avoid registering securities under a regulation governing sales to foreigners.

title: The Wrong Way to Encourage Adoption
description: President Clinton is supporting the House Republicans' plan to give a $5,000 tax credit to many families that adopt a child. In flush times, such a middle-class subsidy might make sense. But today the Government would do much better to use tax dollars to help families that adopt children who are otherwise unlikely to find a permanent home.

title: Militants in Iran Renew Their Attacks on Western Influences
description: Muslim militants in Iran have renewed a campaign of intimidation against what they call corrupting Western influences, shattering the glass doors of a movie theater on Teheran's busiest shopping street and beating patrons in an attack on Sunday.

title: HOUSE PROUD;Home Fires Burn At Sausage Plant
description: FOR an actress with a bent for real estate, all New York is a potential stage. Or rather, as Karen Lashinsky has discovered, enough tenacity and imagination can transform even the grittiest property in Manhattan into a home with as much theatrical flair as a Zeffirelli opera.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: Paul Woolmington was named to the new post of worldwide strategic media director at Ammirati Puris Lintas, New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos. He had been executive media director at Bozell Worldwide, London, and a managing director at 20/20 Media, both units of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt. Coby O'Brien, vice president and creative director at Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Interactive, New York, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C., was named senior vice president and director, assuming responsibilities from Erica Gruen, who had been senior vice president and director at the Saatchi & Saatchi Interactive Resources division before she left to join Merkley Newman Harty, New York, a unit of the Omnicom Group, as media services director.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;The Hands That Feed Defective Sound Bites
description: The next time politicians indulge in the no-risk pastime of charging television with turning public issues into sound bites, they might take a moment to reflect on the effects of instant images, especially when used by themselves.

title: Currents;Discovering The Culture Of Funky
description: A TOBACCO warehouse at 375 West Broadway (between Broome and Spring Streets) has been transformed in a frenzy of blow-torching and sandblasting into the first Manhattan branch of Anthropologie, a retail chain known for remarkably inexpensive yet stylish home furnishings and clothing. The store, which opens tomorrow, offers reproduction French garden chairs for under $100, and a generously scaled summer-ready armchair covered with woven sea grass, right, for $550. The president of Anthropologie is Glen T. Senk, 39, who was responsible for Pottery Barn's dowdy-to-hip shift and who reinvigorated Terence Conran's Habitat stores. A young creative staff displays clever ideas that beg to be borrowed. One example: window shades of thinly sliced dried oranges look like stained glass. Information: (212) 343-7070.

title: Influential Study on Divorce's Impact Is Said to Be Flawed
description: SINCE 1985, the figures of the sociologist Dr. Lenore J. Weitzman showing that women's standards of living decrease by an average of 73 percent in the year after divorce while men's increase by an average of 42 percent have influenced the law and the thinking of Presidents, judges, commentators and other sociologists.

title: Cone's Rare Aneurysm
description: David Cone, the Yankee pitcher, is suffering from a rare aneurysm in an artery in his throwing arm, according to a doctor familiar with his case. The ballooning in the artery developed because of Cone's pitching motion. It is not known when he will be able to pitch again.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Schering Profits Up 16% in Quarter
description: The German drug company Schering A.G. said yesterday that its profit rose 16 percent in the first quarter to 131 million marks, or $85.9 million, helped largely by higher sales of its multiple sclerosis drug Betaferon and a firmer dollar. The company, based in Berlin, makes 85 percent of its sales abroad.

title: In New 6-Year Budget Plan With Gentler Reductions, Republicans EaseToward Center
description: Congressional Republicans moved toward the moderate center in the balanced-budget debate today, offering a new six-year plan to erase the Federal deficit that assumes a far smaller tax cut and gentler reductions in popular programs than they had demanded even six months ago.

title: Turning Elegant Views Into Slices of Paradise
description: ROBERT COUTURIER, a decorator and architect with an appropriately custom-made surname, is known for orchestrating glamorous houses. Voyeurs, therefore, will appreciate the fact that many of the images in "Robert Couturier, Versatility in Design: Architectural Drawings and Renderings" live up to their plutocratic promise.

title: Bond Manager Found Guilty in Oklahoma
description: A Federal jury convicted the former head of the Oklahoma public finance office of Stifel, Nicolaus & Company of fraud and money-laundering in a municipal bond market case.

title: World News Briefs;Bomb Rips Pakistan Bus; 9 Die and 38 Are Hurt
description: A bomb hidden under a seat tore through a passenger bus today, killing 9 people and wounding 38 in Punjab province, witnesses and state-run news organizations said. No one made any immediate claim of responsibility

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;New Help for Hemophiliacs
description: Ending nearly two years of wrangling with the Legislature, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed a bill yesterday that had been eagerly sought by 500 hemophiliacs in the state with AIDS or H.I.V. The measure will give them until July 13, 1997, to sue companies that produced tainted blood products in the early 1980's.

title: Sports of The Times;The Reality Of Athletes And Courage
description: COURAGE.

title: Council Holds Hearing on Term Limits, Looking for Way Out
description: Ever since New Yorkers overwhelmingly approved term limits for their elected officials in 1993, City Council leaders have been quietly meeting and plotting a strategy to repeal or at least postpone them.

title: Computer as Private Photo Lab
description: FAMILY snapshots: keeping them is inconvenient, reproducing them is inconvenient, but parting with them is impossible. Which is why every household has its shoe box or drawer bursting with photographs.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DADE INTERNATIONAL COMPLETES $525 MILLION PURCHASE
description: Dade International Inc. of Deerfield, Ill., said yesterday that it had completed its acquisition of the in-vitro diagnostics business of Du Pont Medical Products, a unit of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, for about $525 million. The price was not disclosed when the agreement was announced in December. Dade, which is closely held, recently raised $350 million in a private junk-bond sale to help pay for the purchase. The company develops and makes medical diagnostic instruments and products. Dade's shareholders include Goldman Sachs Capital Partners and company managers. They bought Dade from Baxter International Inc. in 1994.

title: London Journal;Fickle Dame Fortune: She Smiles, Then Frowns
description: Less than 24 hours ago, Karl Crompton, 23, was called "one of Britain's luckiest people," "the country's most eligible bachelor" and "every girl's dream" as he stepped into the limelight to collect $17 million and change -- one of the largest lottery awards ever in this country.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;French-Swiss Deal to Create No. 1 Temporary Agency
description: Adia S.A. of Switzerland and Ecco S.A. of France agreed today to merge in a deal valued at as much as $2.3 billion that would create the world's largest temporary employment company.

title: House Would Add Stalking To Tougher Crime Measures
description: With little of the fanfare of previous election years, Congress has started to turn its attention to crime legislation, taking up measures like those mandating life without parole for repeat sex offenders and making stalking a Federal crime.

title: Don't Toast Those Declines in Crime Just Yet
description: To the Editor:

title: Richard Rouilard, 43, Journalist And Advocate for Gay Rights
description: Richard Rouilard, a prominent gay-rights advocate and a former editor in chief of The Advocate, a nationally distributed gay and lesbian news magazine, died yesterday at his home in West Hollywood, Calif. He was 43.

title: Russia: Anarchy or Democracy?
description: When a country that has known centuries of tyranny prepares to elect its leader freely for the first time, there is bound to be some political turbulence. The question in Russia is whether the volatility can be contained. Russia's political leaders have not helped by warning of civil war and other extreme consequences if next month's presidential elections leave the country divided.

title: World's Biggest Telescope Has Finally Met Its Match: A Twin
description: With a traditional chant by a Hawaiian elder and speeches by university presidents, the second in a pair of giant telescopes atop the 13,796-foot-high Mauna Kea volcano on Hawaii's Big Island was formally dedicated yesterday.

title: Mingling Two Worlds Of Medicine;Some Doctors Work With Folk Healers In Immigrants' Care
description: Complaining of stomach pains and headaches, 11-year-old Luis entered the dim room of wooden icons, coconuts, candles and dolls where the folk healer practices.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PARKER DRILLING ENDS TALKS ON BUYING RENTAL COMPANY
description: The Parker Drilling Company, based in Tulsa, Okla., said yesterday that it had ended its negotiations to buy Oil and Gas Rental Services Inc. Last month, Parker said it had reached a preliminary agreement to buy Oil and Gas Rental, a privately held company in Morgan City, La., that rents drilling tools to oil companies. Terms were not disclosed, though a Merrill Lynch analyst, Kevin Simpson, estimated the price at about $100 million.

title: Judge Orders Hamas Leader Extradited To Israel
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan yesterday ordered the extradition of the political leader of Hamas, the militant Palestinian group, from the United States to Israel, where he faces criminal charges that he financed and helped organize terrorist attacks.

title: Leelanau County Journal When Winter's Grip Wouldn't Let Go
description: Each fall, the weekly Leelanau Enterprise promises $100 to the reader who comes closest to estimating the final winter snowfall on this peninsula famed for its breathtaking views of Lake Michigan and miles of cherry orchards.

title: BASEBALL;In Yankees' Clubhouse, Waiting on Cone's Fate
description: The manager was retrieving players from the places that surround the home team's clubhouse in Yankee Stadium. It was late Tuesday night and the Yankees had beaten Detroit, but that was not on everyone's mind. When Joe Torre went into the players' lounge to gather players for a brief meeting, the topic was understood. "Joe Girardi said, 'This is about David,' " Torre remembered. "They were waiting for it, but they had no idea what it was going to be."

title: Father and Son Sent To Prison Together
description: A father and son have been given lengthy prison terms for a series of robberies, including one in which they tried to kill a Salvation Army thrift-store manager.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PFIZER INC., New York, said it planned to acquire a 15 percent interest in the Catalytica Fine Chemicals unit of Catalytica Inc., Mountain View, Calif., for $15 million. In return, Catalytica Fine Chemicals will do five years of research for Pfizer, the drug maker.

title: Minding More Than the Bottom Line;Two Companies and Two Different Views of Corporate Responsibility
description: When President Clinton convenes a White House conference planned for next week on the nebulous but politically charged issue of corporate responsibility, the list of those reaping his praise will not include Caterpillar Inc. or its chief executive, Donald V. Fites.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;EQUITABLE COS. (EQ,N)
description: The Equitable Companies reported a rise of nearly 28 percent in first-quarter profit yesterday, citing higher income from insurance products and gains at its investment businesses from a surging stock market.

title: Restyled 'CBS This Morning' Names 3 New Co-Anchors
description: The latest set of new anchors for CBS's morning program will be Jane Robelot, Mark McEwen and Jose Diaz-Balart, CBS News announced yesterday. They will replace Paula Zahn, who will become the Saturday "Evening News" anchor, and Harry Smith, who has been asked to remain as an "Evening News" correspondent but has not signed a contract.

description: To the Editor:

title: Peace Plan for Liberia Seeks to Demilitarize the Capital
description: West African leaders, in a last-ditch attempt to avert full-scale civil war in Liberia, approved a sweeping peace plan today that is intended to demilitarize the capital, Monrovia, and restore the country's fractured governing council.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Joseph Kallinger, 59, a Cobbler-Turned-Killer
description: Joseph Kallinger, a Philadelphia cobbler-turned-killer who terrorized New Jersey suburbs two decades ago and made his own lawyer envision a shadowland where illness and evil live side by side, has died in a Pennsylvania prison. He was 59.

title: No Headline
description: My testimony is that I did not put any pressure on Mr. Hale. That is my testimony. I am adamant about that."

title: SIGNOFF; Wives' Tales: Earthbound And Brave
description: After the third day of filming ''The Original Wives Club,'' the 10th episode in the HBO mini-series ''From the Earth to the Moon,'' the director, Sally Field, lay sprawled on the floor and begged anyone within earshot to ''just shoot me.''

title: BOXING;In Garden Ring, 6 Heavyweights in Search of Comebacks
description: In a setting hardly noted for redemption -- Times Square -- horns blared and pedestrians slowed long enough to stare and hoot at midday as six heavyweights stepped on the scale for their final act before their comebacks.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-13

title: Iraqi Offers Regrets in Killing of Defecting Sons-in-Law
description: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, breaking his silence on the slayings of his sons-in-law in February, says members of the men's own al-Majid clan killed them to wash off the shame that the mens' six-month defection to Jordan had caused the family, Iraqi newspapers reported today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: * Bill Henneberry was named president of the new DWA Marketing Initiatives unit of DelWilber & Associates, McLean, Va. He had been chief executive of Communications Diversified, New York. * Gil Bashe, executive managing director at the Hill & Knowlton New York Health Care Group, a unit of the WPP Group, was promoted to the new post of director for the worldwide health and pharmaceutical practice. * Jonathan Epstein was named president of Spot Media Communications, San Francisco, a new publisher of magazines on the World Wide Web. He had been president of the new-media division of PC World Communications, San Francisco, which is owned by the International Data Group. * Clifford R. Medney was named to the new post of managing director of Fusion 5, Westport, Conn. He had been consumer promotion director at Nabisco Inc., Parsippany, N.J., a unit of RJR Nabisco Holdings. * Scott Westover was named to head a new East Coast office of the Santeler Marketing Group in Ridgefield, Conn., as client services director. He had been marketing communications director at Sony Electronics, Montvale, N.J. * Jeff Haley was named vice president and advertising director for consumer magazines at the Children's Television Workshop, New York, succeeding Gail DeLott, who left. Mr. Haley had been vice president for sponsorship sales at Six Flags Theme Parks, New York, a unit of Time Warner Inc.

title: Judge Dismisses Lawsuit Against Moody's Service
description: Moody's Investors Service, the bond-rating agency, received some good news yesterday when a Federal judge threw out a lawsuit over its unsolicited rating of bonds that a Colorado school district sold in 1993.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WANG LABORATORIES INC., Billerica, Mass., acquired Dataserv, Minneapolis, a provider of computer installation and consulting services, from BellSouth Corp., for about $30 million in cash.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Bears Extend Wannstedt's Contract
description: The Chicago Bears have extended coach DAVE WANNSTEDT's contract four more years, until the 2000 season.

title: NYC;Day to Praise Motherhood And Guidance
description: HERE we are, once again approaching the holiday that benefits florists and greeting-card makers. H. L. Mencken probably got it right when he dismissed Mother's Day as an occasion fit for cads. Who else would need a grand ceremonial to prove that he loved his mother? "It is precisely the mark of the cad," the great curmudgeon wrote in 1916, "that he makes a public boast of what is inseparable from decency."

title: On My Mind;How Did We Get Here?
description: The United States is the ultimate target of the nations that sponsor international terrorism. Yet the U.S. has been strengthening the three countries that are the major practitioners and exporters of international terrorism.

title: Agency Still Has Role In School Construction
description: To the Editor:

title: Garth Williams, Book Illustrator, Dies at 84
description: Garth Williams, the artist who illustrated E. B. White's "Stuart Little" and "Charlotte's Web" and scores of other children's classics, died on Wednesday at his home in Guanajuato, Mexico. He was 84.

title: Bible Backed Slavery, Says A Lawmaker
description: An Alabama State Senator running for Congress has written a speech arguing that slavery was justified by the Bible and that it was good for blacks.

title: What Do Angry Women Want?
description: Faced with the prospect of a mass desertion by female voters in the fall, some Republicans have acknowledged the gender gap and are trying to do something about it, including softening the hard-right anti-abortion language in the party platform. Not even a wholesale revision of that plank seems likely to help. According to the latest New York Times/CBS Poll, President Clinton currently leads Senator Bob Dole among women by a whopping 18 points.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Gold Diggers: The Secret Of Bear Mountain 1995. MCA/Universal. $100.71. Laser disk, $34.98. 94 minutes. Closed captioned. PG. Release date: Tuesday.

title: Apple Plans to Repair Problems Of Some Macintosh Computers
description: Apple Computer Inc., already facing falling sales and big losses, agreed today to repair problems with some models of Macintosh desktop and portable computers.

title: Art in Review
description: Ross Bleckner Mary Boone Gallery 745 Fifth Avenue, at 58th Street Through June 29

title: China Says It Will Retaliate if U.S. Imposes Trade Sanctions
description: China warned today that it planned to retaliate heavily if the United States imposes $2 billion of trade sanctions on China for failing to reduce the piracy of computer software, music and movies.

title: Toyota Is Planning West Virginia Plant
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation announced today that it would build a $400 million engine plant in West Virginia that would employ up to 300 people.

title: In America;Checking Out the House
description: One day last summer Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, chairman of the House Republican Conference, decided to play Santa Claus.

title: FILM REVIEW;Weirdos and Allegory in the Old West
description: Dead Man," Jim Jarmusch's sardonic nightmare vision of the Old West, begins with a display of grotesquerie that is so sensational it sets up expectations that the movie might be the surreal last word on the Hollywood western and its mythic legacy.

title: Barnard Delays Six Diplomas Over Sit-In
description: Adding a new element of controversy at strike-torn Barnard College, administrators have told six seniors who participated in a four-hour sit-in last month that their diplomas would be withheld until disciplinary cases against them are resolved.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: A Month by the Lake 1995. Miramax. $97.51. Laser disk, $39.99. 92 minutes. Closed captioned. PG. Release date: Tuesday.

title: Ford Chiefs Say the Taurus Can't Stay No. 1 at Any Cost
description: The Ford Motor Company will not risk missing its profit targets simply to insure that its Taurus is the nation's best-selling car again this year, a top Ford official said today.

title: For Children
description: A random survey of what mothers in New York City will be doing this weekend for Mother's Day revealed that many were not planning to celebrate. One mother called the day a "Hallmark day." Another laughed and said, "When is it?" All is not lost. Here is one mother's plan for the whole day, along with other suggestions.

title: Russian Candidates Stump Under Different Portraits of Glory
description: In Red Square, President Boris N. Yeltsin reviewed thousands of soldiers today marching before a giant painting of Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov, the Soviet World War II hero, astride a prancing white stallion, that was hung from the same edifice where Lenin's portrait was once mounted.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ANTITRUST INVESTIGATION OF COUPON EXPERIMENT
description: The Procter & Gamble Company's experiment with ending the use of discount coupons in Syracuse, Rochester and Buffalo has prompted an antitrust investigation by the state Attorney General Dennis Vacco. The company began eliminating coupons in February to reduce marketing costs. Mr. Vacco said yesterday that the state had subpoenaed seven manufacturers, three retailers and one food broker to determine whether Procter & Gamble conspired with supermarket chains to eliminate coupons in the three cities. A Procter & Gamble spokeswoman said the company denied any wrongdoing and was cooperating with the investigation. Other companies subpoenaed include the Clorox Company, the Kimberly-Clark Corporation, Wegman's Food, the Penn Traffic Company and Tops Markets, a chain owned by Royal Ahold of the Netherlands.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Cliff Freeman Wins Top Ad Club Award
description: Cliff Freeman & Partners in New York has taken top honors, winning the Grandy Award as well as the most awards, at the 32d annual International Andy Awards presentation for creativity sponsored by the Advertising Club of New York.

title: FILM REVIEW;Of a Boy and an Older Woman He's Hiding
description: It is perfectly understandable that Winona Ryder should want to step out of the goody-two-shoes mode of "The Age of Innocence" and "Little Women" and portray someone wild, with an attraction to danger. Those corsets can get pretty uncomfortable after a while. The need to break free might explain why Ms. Ryder allowed herself to be badly miscast in "Boys," a small, cramped film about an aimless woman in her mid-20's who becomes involved with an innocent prep school student.

title: GOVERNING PARTY IN INDIA IS ROUTED IN NATIONAL VOTE
description: The Congress Party, which has governed India for all but four years since independence in 1947, suffered a devastating rout in the general election, substantial returns showed today.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;McLain Indicted on Pension Theft Charges
description: The former Tigers pitcher DENNY McLAIN was indicted with two other Michigan men in Detroit yesterday on charges stemming from allegations that they stole from a meat-packing company pension plan, then falsified documents to try to cover up the theft.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Patents column of Business Day on April 29 about a new type of golf game misstated the design of the course. Players would shoot from six surrounding tees to a single green, not from a common tee to six greens.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Just Spell Their Names Right

title: Safir, Angered by Article, Bars Reporter From Office
description: Police Commissioner Howard Safir barred a Daily News reporter from attending a briefing for journalists assigned to police headquarters yesterday, explaining that it was his right to invite whomever he wanted into his offices.

title: 25 and Under
description: Like a couch potato, Silver Swan, wedged into East 20th Street facing Gramercy Tavern, is content to look on as more up-to-the-minute restaurants battle to be noticed near bubbling Park Avenue South. That seems right because, no matter how satisfying traditional German food can be, it is unlikely to become the cuisine of the moment anytime soon. As long as "slender" and "lean" are still so desirable, a couple of hulking bratwursts surrounded by mashed potatoes and sauerkraut will always invite a kick in the shins from the trend police.

title: Corrections
description: The mutual funds table in Business Day on Saturday omitted an entry from a listing of the 10 leading single-state municipal bond funds. The Lebenthal New York Municipal Bond Fund ranked as the ninth best performer among single-state municipal bond funds, with a total return of 7.7 percent for the year ended May 3.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Sicola Martin Gets 2 Accounts
description: Sicola Martin in Austin, Tex., was awarded two high-tech accounts with combined billings estimated at $10 million to $15 million.

title: Petrie to Close More Stores
description: Petrie Retail Inc., a privately held retailer operating in bankruptcy, said today that it would close an additional 238 stores as part of its restructuring, reducing its stores to 1,229. The retailer, based in Secaucus, has already closed several hundred stores since it filed for Chapter 11 in October.

title: Horses I Have Known and Learned From
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL;Green Wants Players To Reflect on Season
description: During the All-Star Game break last season, Mets Manager Dallas Green told each player to go home, look at himself in the mirror and consider what responsibility he had for a miserable first half. The self-analysis must have worked because the Mets, 25-44 before the break, were 44-31 in the second half.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AMP ASKS WORKERS TO VOLUNTEER FOR FURLOUGHS
description: AMP Inc., the world's largest maker of electrical and electronic connectors, said yesterday that it had asked its 18,000 United States employees to volunteer to take a week off without pay before the end of June because of slowing demand for its electrical connectors. The unpaid furloughs have been a tradition at AMP during slowdowns, Thea Hocker, a spokeswoman for the company, said. AMP, based in Harrisburg, Pa., doesn't expect all of the employees to volunteer, Ms. Hocker said. AMP shares fell $1.50, to $41.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Cyberspace for All
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: ANNE KAUFMAN SCHNEIDER is going to see one play by her father, George S. Kaufman, tonight, and then another play on Sunday and one more on Monday. If she wished, she could also see one on Saturday. No, it's not a festival; it's just coincidence that a bounty of Kaufman plays are being produced at once.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;Wrenching Turnover, Frustrating Dry Spell
description: Jeff Beukeboom was quite frank in his assessment of the back-breaker.

title: In Lilco, Debate Is About Political Power
description: As 495 Long Island Lighting Company stockholders gathered here today for what may be their last annual meeting, Gov. George E. Pataki forged ahead with his effort to dismantle the 85-year-old utility.

title: Splash Does Not a Tony-Worthy Musical Make
description: To the Editor:

title: Child-Care Task Force
description: Using a $4.7 million Federal grant, County Executive Andrew J. Spano has formed a Child-Care Task force to take ''a comprehensive look'' at Westchester's child-care resources.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The American President 1995. Columbia Tri-Star. $102.31. Laser disk, $34.95. 114 minutes. Closed captioned. PG-13. Release date: Tuesday.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: COMPANY NEWS;ICN PHARMACEUTICALS SAYS INVESTIGATION WIDENS
description: A Federal grand jury in Costa Mesa, Calif., has asked ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc. for documents related to the investigation of the company and its chairman, Milan Panic, the former prime minister of Yugoslavia, ICN said yesterday. The company also said that the jury's request went beyond material requested by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Part of the S.E.C. investigation and shareholder lawsuits concern Mr. Panic's sale of $1.24 million in ICN stock in late 1994, after ICN learned that its antiviral drug Virazole, would not be approved for treating hepatitis C. The setback was not disclosed to investors until February 1995, causing ICN stock to plunge by 42 percent in six days, to $13.25 a share.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Cal Star Transferring to Fresno State
description: TREMAINE FOWLKES, the 1995 Pac-10 freshman of the year at California, has announced that he will transfer to Fresno State so he can play basketball for JERRY TARKANIAN.

title: About Real Estate;At Condos and Co-ops, Top Headaches
description: Collecting maintenance payments and dealing with difficult shareholders are the top two problems for board presidents of cooperative and condominium buildings, a survey of buildings in New York City has found.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Yield Climbs Back Over 7% On Long Bond
description: Concerns that new price data will show a pickup in inflation dragged down Treasury prices yesterday, pushing the yield on the long bond back above 7 percent.

title: Dole Attacks Clinton Asia Policy Although He Supports Part of It
description: In a blistering election-year attack on President Clinton's policy in Asia, Senator Bob Dole lacerated the Administration today as incoherent and naive and said the President's "double talk" had undercut American authority abroad.

title: DANCE REVIEW;New Odette, Prince, Etc., By Way of Ballet Theater
description: Vladimir Malakhov and Julie Kent were the new principals in American Ballet Theater's "Swan Lake" on Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. True to form, each came up with some unconventional touches.

title: Art in Review
description: Georgina Starr Barbara Gladstone Gallery 99 Greene Street SoHo Through May 25

title: ART REVIEW;Humanity And Self: A Nay Vote
description: Ashley Bickerton, an 80's Neo-Geo artist whose talent seemed to fade with the art-market crash, has made one of the more convincing comebacks in recent memory. Although he missed a few beats (two desultory shows, in 1991 and '93), Mr. Bickerton, who is 36, has now segued from Neo-Geo to neo-realism without losing his train of thought. His new confrontational oil paintings on wood, in which the figures are usually depicted at or near actual size, are easy to hate, unsettling to look at and difficult to ignore. Some are unbearably awful, but others home in on an American heart of darkness with unusual accuracy.

title: GIULIANI'S BUDGET PLAN: A NEW COURSE;An Apocalyptic Deficit Doomed the Tax Cuts
description: Ever since the fiscal crisis of the 1970's, New York City mayors have been required to employ a warning system for budget gaps, predicting deficits four years ahead. Those numbers had never been large enough to cause much concern until Jan. 31, the day Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani put out his financial plan for the years leading into the next century.

title: Tornado Brings Havoc to a Town in Nebraska
description: Sue and Gary Epp huddled in their basement bedroom, listening to a tornado suck the windows and their belongings out into the night. Seconds later, the roof of their house was ripped away.

title: Restaurants
description: In New York City, home of the fabulous, the chic, the loud and the exotic, a nice restaurant is a rare thing. So rare that when I encountered the pleasant staff at Aquagrill I was acutely uncomfortable. Don't those people ever stop smiling?

title: Hostess Dismissed
description: The woman who for 10 years has served as hostess at New York's most august lunch club for intellectuals, the New York Institute for the Humanities, was dismissed yesterday for trying to arrange to have Hillary Rodham Clinton address the group later this month.

title: Legislature Acts to Widen Gay Rights In Canada
description: Fulfilling promises by governments over the past decade, the House of Commons today overwhelmingly passed landmark legislation banning discrimination against homosexuals.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: A top Hitchcock thriller, one of Broadway's very best musicals and two provocative plots brighten the films on television this week.

title: Senate Approves Measure Requiring States to Warn Communities About SexOffenders
description: The Senate today passed a measure requiring all states to warn communities when convicted sex offenders who might still pose a danger settle in their neighborhoods.

title: Love Means Tough Choices, Even if You Wrote the Book
description: A DOOMED love affair. A crippling illness that cuts down a beautiful woman in her prime. A stern, disapproving father who attempts to separate two passionate lovers.
