A novel by Erich Segal. No, it's not ''Love Story,'' his 1970 best-selling novel. It's ''Only Love,'' a 1997 novel by Mr. Segal that will appear as a two-part CBS miniseries tonight and tomorrow. Although the miniseries, like the novel, is set in Europe, Africa and New York City -- far afield from the Boston of Oliver Barrett 4th and Jenny Cavilleri -- it does revisit several themes dear to Mr. Segal's heart.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: The Brownstein Group, Philadelphia, was awarded two accounts with combined billings estimated at $4 million to $8 million: Metropolitan Philadelphia Acura Dealers Group, Morristown, N.J., as the first agency to handle its account after Acura allowed local dealer associations to hire their own agencies, and Thriftway/Shop n Bag, Oaks, Pa., as the first agency to handle advertising for the supermarket chain. * Samsung Group, Seoul, South Korea, to Vogt/Wein, Westport, Conn., as the first agency to handle the creative portion of the worldwide corporate advertising account for the marketer of consumer and technology products. The media portion of the account will be handled in-house. Billings were not disclosed. * The Meade Group, Utica, Mich., to Yaffe & Co., Southfield, Mich., to handle advertising for Meade's Cars and Cars Auto Superstore, a used-car dealership, which had been handled by Reinhardt & Lamka, Farmington, Mich. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Fewer File First Claims for Jobless Benefits
description: The number of first-time claims for jobless benefits fell by 12,000 last week to the lowest level in four months, the Labor Department said today. New applications for unemployment insurance totaled a seasonally adjusted 336,000, down from 348,000 in the week that ended last Saturday, when claims fell by 24,000.

title: If History Is Flawed, It Deserves Scrutiny
description: To the Editor:

title: Art in Review
description: Katharina Fritsch Matthew Marks Gallery 1018 Madison Avenue, at 78th Street Through June 8

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;Panthers Tie Series on Controversial Goal
description: Florida had not won a game in overtime in more than two years. The Panthers could not have picked a better time to turn that around.

title: 2 From Hasidic Patrol Group Are Arrested in Attack on Man
description: Two members of a Hasidic neighborhood patrol group in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, who were searching for a stolen bicycle were arrested on assault charges yesterday after they beat a black man with their walkie-talkies, the police said.

title: Excerpts From Clinton's Testimony
description: Following are excerpts from President Clinton's videotaped testimony given at the White House on April 28 and played today at the fraud and conspiracy trial of James B. and Susan McDougal and Gov. Jim Guy Tucker. Mr. Clinton was questioned by Sam Heuer, Mr. McDougal's lawyer.

title: Kevorkian Back at Trial as Talk of Detroit Is of Another Suicide
description: Dr. Jack Kevorkian returned to his latest assisted-suicide trial today, brushing off questions about his most recent assisted suicide, which took place only hours after he finished testifying here on Monday.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Judge Upholds Death Charge
description: It has been a year since Ippolito Gonzalez, a popular Franklin Township police sergeant, was killed during a routine traffic stop. But the authorities still do not know which of the two motorcycle gang members charged in his death fired the .45-caliber gun used in the slaying.

title: New York Political Discourse Reaches New Low
description: To the Editor:

title: Art in Review
description: Pat Passlof Elizabeth Harris Gallery 524 Broadway, near Spring Street SoHo Through May 24

title: House Votes to Alter U.S. Housing Policy
description: The House voted last night to overturn much of the nation's policy of housing for the poor in favor of a grant program that would give more power to local officials. The bill, which passed by a vote of 315 to 107, would repeal the Housing Act of 1937.

title: Diner's Journal
description: At Typhoon Brewery, the menu reads like a map of the human tongue: salty, sweet, sour and bitter, with the addition of spicy. The truth, however, is more complicated: most of the Thai dishes combine a bit of each element.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Belgium Issues Warrant For French Executive
description: Belgium has issued an international arrest warrant for the French businessman Serge Dassault on suspicion of corruption, according to a Belgian court official and news reports. But Mr. Dassault, chairman of Dassault Aviation and honorary chairman of the electronics company Dassault Electronique, denied any involvement in the affair.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Royal Dutch/Shell Has 37% Rise in Profit
description: First-quarter profit jumped 37 percent at the Royal Dutch/Shell Group of Companies, as gains from higher oil prices more than made up for a weaker performance in chemicals. Royal Dutch/Shell earned L1.74 billion ($2.67 billion) on revenue of L26.04 billion for the first three months of 1996, up from earnings of L1.27 billion on revenues of L22.64 billion in the comparable quarter a year earlier.

title: INSIDE
description: Canada Affirms Gay Rights

title: Sports of The Times;This Team Is Sinking, Not Diving
description: DIVING is normally an Olympic Summer Games sport, but the Rangers were suggesting that the Pittsburgh Penguins were belly-whopping on the ice much like real penguins.

title: In Child Care Workers, Let's Value Training
description: To the Editor:

title: Bankers Trust Settles Suit With P.& G.
description: Paying a steep price to end a bitter battle, the Bankers Trust New York Corporation agreed yesterday to forgive most of the nearly $200 million the bank contended it was owed by Procter & Gamble over two complex transactions in 1993.

title: Japanese Stocks Higher
description: Stock prices were higher here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 8.24 points, or .04 percent, at 21,420.12 . On Thursday, the Nikkei fell 316.72 points.

title: Ban on Homosexuals Stays
description: The House of Commons refused today to end a ban on homosexuals in the armed forces, by a vote of 188 to 120.

title: FILM REVIEW;Aiming Satiric Artillery At TV's Sitting Ducks
description: Imagine that the Nielsen ratings system malfunctions, and across the country, public broadcasting stations soar to No. 1 in the television sweepstakes. Suddenly the networks are scrambling desperately for programming with a high-cultural slant. Here comes Tom Selleck as "Rock Maninoff," the cello-playing "classical crime fighter." In "Greek's Company," a sexy sitcom set in ancient Greece, an old philosopher cracks to two young lovers wearing white robes and laurel crowns, "I used to make out under the Parthenon when you kids couldn't read a sundial."

title: ART REVIEW;At the Armory, a Tour of 5 Centuries
description: For the third spring in a row, the International Fine Art Fair has turned the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue into a vast, rich, impeccably cluttered collector's cabinet of European and American art. And even in a city with extraordinary museums of Western art, this armchair Grand Tour of five centuries of work is a priority event.

title: Release the Clinton Videotape
description: President Clinton testified by videotape yesterday in a Federal court in Little Rock, denying accusations of impropriety by the chief witness produced by the Whitewater special prosecutor. The White House opposes release of the tape, saying it contains nothing new and would be used by political opponents. The trial judge, seeing no rush, says he will consider the journalists' applications in about two weeks.

title: Firehouse Contractor
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Tax Rule Change Advances
description: Ten states require a two-thirds vote by their legislatures before a tax increase can be imposed. A measure to ask New Jersey voters if they want the same requirement was approved yesterday by the Senate's State Government Committee and sent to the Budget and Appropriations Committee, which also must approve it. Tax increases now can be imposed by a majority vote of the Legislature.

title: Child in Bag Was Killed, Report Says
description: A 22-month-old Bronx boy whose decomposed body was found last month in a plastic bag outside his parents' apartment was the victim of a homicide, the New York City Medical Examiner's office said yesterday.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Jumanji 1995. Columbia Tri-Star. $19.98. Laser disk, $34.95. 104 minutes. Closed captioned. PG. Release date: Tuesday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;With a new sandwich and a $200 million campaign, McDonald's tries to win back older diners.
description: THE McDonald's Corporation, in its biggest marketing effort since it began flipping hamburgers 41 years ago, is betting $200 million -- the greatest gamble ever in the fast-food field -- that older consumers will want meals under the Golden Arches that are sophisticated enough not to bear the word "happy" or the prefix "Mc" in their names.

title: Alzheimer's Researcher Is Found Slain
description: A noted Alzheimer's disease researcher and his daughter were found shot to death on Wednesday morning at their home in San Diego, the police said today.

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;For Penguins, Exhilaration Instead of Expiration
description: Perhaps the Penguins are teaching the Rangers that there are different ways to die.

title: Wooing the Seniors at the Prom;They're Older and Wiser and Vote on School Budgets
description: Marie Capparelli, 75 years old, joined her four 18-year-old classmates in Pamela Hagerty's word-processing class at the high school today for a lesson in pulling images from the WordPerfect program's memory. A retired secretary, Mrs. Capparelli sits in twice a week to freshen her keyboard skills and update her grasp of technology.

title: Prices and Hopes Rise As Spring Art Auctions Reveal a Robust Market
description: The 1996 spring auctions of Impressionist, modern and contemporary art in Manhattan will not be remembered for their high prices. Nor will many blockbuster paintings stand out in anyone's mind. Still, these sales have made a significant impression on the art world because of the increase in the number and enthusiasm of buyers at every level.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;2 Trump Officials Clash
description: Luciano Pavarotti performed at the Convention Center last Saturday, but he was hardly the only show in town that night. At least, not according to Edwin M. Tracy, who ran the Trump Organization's hotels and casinos until he was replaced in 1991 by Nicholas L. Ribis. In a complaint filed with the Atlantic City police yesterday -- five days later -- Mr. Tracy accused Mr. Ribis of ejecting him from the Scheherazade restaurant at the Trump-owned Taj Mahal hotel after threatening him with "bodily harm and death," said Sgt. Ernest Jubilee, a police spokesman. A friend of Mr. Tracy informed The New York Times about the complaint.

title: HORSE RACING;Winner of Kentucky Derby Is Retired With Knee Injury
description: The racing career of Grindstone, the 3-year-old colt who on Saturday rallied courageously to win the Kentucky Derby, abruptly ended yesterday after a chip was discovered in his right knee. He thus becomes the first horse since Bubbling Over in 1926 to be retired immediately after winning the Derby.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Astra Reports 11% Profit Gain
description: The drug maker Astra A.B., Sweden's largest publicly traded company, reported yesterday that it had an 11 percent pretax profit gain in the first quarter and said it would not postpone plans to list its shares on the New York Stock Exchange in two weeks. Astra's profits were lifted by strong United States sales of Prilosec, an ulcer medication. Astra earned 3.44 billion kronor ($506 million) in the three months that ended on March 31. A year earlier the company earned 3.11 billion kronor. Sales were 9.34 billion kronor, up from 8.65 billion.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;State Audit of City Is Sought
description: A taxpayers group that wants the state to conduct an audit of East Orange's troubled finances began a petition drive yesterday to ask the City Council to invite the state to step in. The city has a projected deficit of $10.7 million for this year, added to a $11.4 million deficit carried over from last year. The projected layoffs of 97 police officers were averted last night when the police union voted to defer accepting 10 days' pay instead.

title: Serge Chermayeff, 95, Architect; Taught at Harvard and Yale
description: Serge Chermayeff, a retired architect and former head of the architecture department at Harvard and Yale Universities, died on Wednesday at his home in Wellfleet, Mass., where he had lived for the last 55 years. He was 95.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Truck Crash Shuts I-287
description: The northbound side of Route 287 was closed for nearly three hours yesterday morning when a disabled tractor-trailer burst into flames after colliding with another truck, the police said. Both drivers suffered minor injuries, said John Hagerty, a spokesman for the state police.

title: BASEBALL;Surgery Set For Cone's Aneurysm
description: David Cone of the Yankees is scheduled to undergo surgery this morning to repair the aneurysm that has suddenly brought his pitching career to a halt.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: COMPANY NEWS;MORRISON KNUDSEN IS IN TALKS WITH INVESTORS
description: A spokesman for the Morrison Knudsen Corporation said yesterday that the company was in negotiations with potential strategic investors. On the Big Board, the company's stock shot up $1.25, or nearly 91 percent, to $2.625, on volume of almost 10 million shares. Morrison Knudsen, a troubled engineering, construction and rail equipment company in Boise, Idaho, said it still planned to proceed with a proposal to swap all of its $386.3 million in debt for new stock. One possible investor might be the Montana business executive Dennis Washington, according to the current issue of Forbes magazine.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Oil Prices Drop as Traders See An Eventual U.N.-Iraq Accord
description: Crude oil prices fell on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday as traders bet that Iraq would eventually agree to a United Nations proposal allowing a limited sale of oil.

title: F.C.C. Proposes Standards for Digital Television
description: Federal regulators formally proposed standards today to govern television broadcasters' transition from analog broadcast technology to high-resolution, digital technology.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in Business Day yesterday about the public offering of Berkshire Hathaway Inc.'s new class B common stock misstated the offering price per share. It was $1,110, not $1,100.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;Bulls Offer Knicks a Lesson in Psychology
description: The Bulls are hand-checking Patrick Ewing's mind, pushing and prodding and poking to see how many licks it takes to get to the center of the Knicks.

title: Reality Check From the Mayor
description: With his new $33 billion budget proposed for the next fiscal year, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has recognized many of the harsh realities that his earlier fiscal plans ignored. As a result, New York City faces more cuts in spending and services as well as the deferral of tax cuts due to take effect at the end of the year. More budget pain was the necessary alternative to more budget fantasy, however. Mr. Giuliani deserves credit for driving city government to try to do more with fewer resources, while acknowledging that neither the state nor Federal government is likely to come to the rescue.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: China Volleys Back In Trade Dispute Beijing warned that it planned to retaliate heavily if the United States imposed $2 billion worth of trade sanctions on China for failing to reduce copyright piracy. A spokesman for the Foreign Ministry said that China would respond with sanctions even bigger than those proposed by Washington. [Page A9.]

title: Nokia Shares Plunge on Sour Quarterly Earnings Report
description: Shares of Nokia Oy, a Finnish telecommunications equipment maker, tumbled today after the company reported an unexpected drop in first-quarter earnings.

title: Clinton Receptive to G.O.P. Budget Plan
description: President Clinton warily lauded Republicans today for a new budget plan that he said moved closer to his fiscal priorities.

title: Belgium Seeks to Arrest Head of Dassault
description: PARIS  Serge Dassault, heir to an aircraft dynasty and chairman of a leading French military-industrial group, was drawn into a long-running Belgian political bribery scandal Thursday when Belgium's judicial authorities announced they had issued an international arrest warrant for him.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;The Spurs Get Physical And Get Even at the Line
description: Meanwhile, back at Dennis Rodman's former residence, somebody got ornery.

title: GIULIANI'S BUDGET PLAN: THE OVERVIEW;Giuliani Offers an Austere $32.7 Billion Budget
description: With New York City's fiscal troubles persisting, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proposed an austere $32.7 billion budget yesterday that would trim overall spending and make sharp reductions on everything from the police force to park rangers, from treatment for alcoholics to subsidies for private buses.

title: Race, Mortgages and Statistics;The Unending Debate Over a Study of Lending Bias
description: These statistics don't lie: Black and Hispanic home buyers have a harder time getting mortgages.

title: Gen. Jean Crepin, 87, Developer of French Missile
description: Gen. Jean Crepin, a retired French Army officer who oversaw the development of the Exocet missiles, which played a key role in the war in the Falklands, died on Saturday in the French department of Seine-et-Marne, near Paris, where he lived. He was 87.

title: Times Names Culture Editor
description: The appointment of John Darnton as cultural news editor of The New York Times was announced yesterday by Joseph Lelyveld, the executive editor. The appointment will take effect in September.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Deutsch Is Awarded Buzz Account
description: Buzz Inc. in Los Angeles has named the Santa Monica, Calif., office of Deutsch Inc. to handle consumer and trade advertising for Buzz magazine, which had been handled by various agencies on a project basis. Billings were estimated at $2 million to $4 million. Deutsch was selected after a monthlong review that also included three undisclosed Los Angeles-based agencies.

title: Dole's Views on U.S. Asian Policy: Lost Credibility and WeakLeadership
description: Following are excerpts from a speech today by Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a nonpartisan research organization, as transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency: I believe America's global future will soon be an important issue in this election. And I believe that President Clinton's foreign-policy track record of weakness and indecision, and double-talk and incoherence, has diminished American credibility and undermined American interests.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CELLULAR COMMUNICATIONS TO CONSIDER SALE
description: The stock of Cellular Communications of Puerto Rico Inc. jumped almost 15 percent yesterday after the company said it would review various strategies, including a sale or merger of the company. The company, which owns and operates cellular telephone systems in Puerto Rico and the United States Virgin Islands, said no decision had been made to pursue any particular alternative. Cellular Communications shares rose $4, to $31.25, in Nasdaq trading. The company's current market capitalization is $400 million.

title: Price Increases: First They Have to Stick
description: Dennis Russell, a home builder in San Diego, has been waiting a long time to charge more. The strong interest in the last three homes in his latest project -- 45 tract houses priced at $118,000 each -- seemed like a perfect invitation to add several thousand dollars to the sale price. But he passed up the opportunity.

title: Norway Oil Strike Ending
description: Leaders of the Norwegian Federation of Oil Workers said today that they had decided to call off their offshore strike because of faltering support from strikers. The federation began the strike by 750 workers at nine installations last Saturday after about 400 service workers went on strike last month.

title: Chip Index Dips for 6th Month in Row
description: The semiconductor industry's leading indicator declined in April for the sixth consecutive month, a trade group reported today.

title: Despite the Low Odds, High Hopes for Knicks
description: To have a realistic chance against the Chicago Bulls, the Knicks must rebound better, improve their offensive execution and avoid another fourth-quarter collapse.

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;Rangers' Hits Keep Coming, but Goals Are Too Few
description: Goodness, gracious. The Rangers have held Jaromir Jagr to four goals in four games in this second-round Stanley Cup playoffs series. Oh, yes, they know how to handle him, and all the other Penguin "crybabies" and "soft guys" whose style seems to offend Coach Colin Campbell and his players.

title: Zenith to Market a TV with a Modem and Ethernet Link
description: The Zenith Electronics Corporation announced today that through a partnership with Diba Inc. it planned to market by October a television equipped with both a high-speed modem and an Ethernet connection to make it possible to connect easily to the Internet without the expense of a personal computer.

title: BASEBALL;Tigers Feast on Key's Uncharacteristic Mistakes
description: For the familiar-looking face on the mound at Yankee Stadium last night, the mistakes that took place would once have been considered uncharacteristic failures. For the one with the surgically repaired rotator cuff, the rules of the game have temporarily been changed.

title: FILM REVIEW;Off-Kilter Adventures in the Land of Opportunity
description: Forget Walter Matthau and Jack Lemmon as a grumpy old odd couple. When it comes to conveying a bumptious charm, Tom Conti and Miki Manojlovic outdo them playing grumpy middle-aged neighbors who live in a shabby corner of Brooklyn.

title: Stolen Gun Found At Officer's Home
description: One of two guns confiscated in a police raid on the home of Desmond Robinson, a former police officer accused of sexually assaulting and trying to rape a female officer, was reported stolen in Florida more than a year ago, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TEJAS GAS OF HOUSTON AGREES TO ACQUIRE TRANSOK
description: The Tejas Gas Corporation of Houston agreed yesterday to acquire Transok Inc., a natural gas pipeline and gas processor in Tulsa, Okla., from the Central and South West Corporation, which did not give details of the deal. Shares of Tejas rose $1.75, to $52.25, and Central's shares fell 12.5 cents, to $26.875. Transok has more than 6,500 miles of gathering and transmission pipelines in Oklahoma, Louisiana and Texas and 2.3 billion cubic feet a day in pipeline capacity. After the deal, Tejas would operate 12,000 miles of intrastate pipelines.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Backstage at the Pageant of Washington
description: The System The American Way of Politics at the Breaking Point By Haynes Johnson and David S. Broder 668 pages. Little, Brown. $25.95.

title: DE KLERK'S PARTY QUITS GOVERNMENT
description: The day after South Africa adopted a Constitution that he called flawed, Deputy President F. W. de Klerk announced that his National Party would pull out of President Nelson Mandela's coalition Government.

title: Wife of Former Intuit Officer Among 6 Fined in Insider Case
description: The wife of William H. Lane, the former chief financial officer of Intuit Inc., agreed today to pay, along with five other people, more than $472,000 in fines for illegal insider trading connected to the company's proposed acquisition by the Microsoft Corporation.

title: Scientists Find Elusive Protein, H.I.V.'s Guide
description: After a decadelong search, scientists today reported finding a protein that is needed to admit the AIDS virus into human immune system cells, beginning a deadly cycle of destruction.

title: Evans Joins Kentucky
description: Heshimu Evans, a 6-foot-6-inch sophomore forward who led the Manhattan Jaspers in scoring last season, is taking his game to the highest rung of the college basketball ladder: the national champion Kentucky Wildcats.

title: L.P.G.A. Is Cut to 54 Holes
description: For the first time in Ladies Professional Golf Association history, one of the four major championships has been reduced from 72 to 54 holes. Tournament officials essentially had no choice. With 2 1/2 inches of rain pelting the already saturated DuPont Country Club in the past week, the golf course was rendered unplayable and today's scheduled first round of the McDonald's L.P.G.A. Championship was canceled.

title: FILM REVIEW;Holocaust Orphans, Tormented By the Past
description: The intense, complicated teen-agers who reside in the Oudim State Boarding School in Eli Cohen's film "Under the Domim Tree" represent Israel's shining youth at the same time that many of them are traumatized survivors. It is 1953, and these students are among the thousands of young people orphaned by the Holocaust whom the Youth Aliyah movement relocated in Israel in kibbutz-like communal villages. While they are helping to build the foundation of the emerging Israeli state, beneath their communal hope and idealism lurk horrifying memories and haunting questions that may never be answered.

title: World News Briefs;Member of New Coalition To Lead Italian Senate
description: At the opening of Parliament today, Italy's center-left election winners voted their own man into the powerful post of Speaker of the Senate, the upper house, after efforts to strike a deal with the opposition fell through.

title: FILM REVIEW;Country Cousins, Feudal And Futile
description: The cows are named Pointless, Feckless, Graceless and Aimless. The old lady upstairs once saw something so dreadful that now she won't come out of her room. The D. H. Lawrence innuendoes are bursting out everywhere, and the dialect is rustic bordering on ridiculous. It's one thing to say "Aye, she's away then, too, wanderin' far from those that loves her and cowdled her in their bosoms when she was a mommet," and quite another to know exactly what it means.

title: The Spoken Word
description: "THE GOLDEN AGE OF GOSPEL SINGING," New York Public Library, Countee Cullen Regional Library, 104 West 136th Street, Harlem. A lecture and slide show by Lloyd Yearwood, a photographer whose works are in the book "How Sweet the Sound: The Golden Age of Gospel," written by Horace Boyer. Tomorrow at 2 P.M. Free. Information: (212) 491-2070.

title: Ramallah Journal;Suitcase No Longer His Homeland, a Poet Returns
description: Staying in a modest hotel room here this week, Mahmoud Darwish seemed no more than a traveler passing through town.

title: Political Briefs;THE STATES AND THE ISSUES
description: Colorado

title: Art in Review
description: Monique Prieto Bravin Post Lee 80 Mercer Street, near Broome Street SoHo Through May 18

title: Hostess of Intellectuals' Lunches Dismissed Over Invitation to Mrs.Clinton
description: The woman who for 10 years has served as hostess at New York's most august lunch club for intellectuals was dismissed yesterday for trying to arrange to have Hillary Rodham Clinton address the group later this month.

title: At Home Abroad;'A Thin Partition'
description: Occasionally in history," Shimon Peres said, "a thin partition is a profound difference."

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article yesterday about stalled legislation in Congress referred incorrectly to President Clinton's actions this week on a bill providing tax relief for those who adopt children. He endorsed the idea of a tax credit, part of a bill now being considered by Congress; he did not sign the bill.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Foster's Unit Sells 1,410 Pubs
description: The Foster's Brewing Group of Australia said yesterday that its half-owned British unit, the Inntrepreneur Pub Company, had sold 1,410 pubs for L262 million ($400 million). Terry Bowe, a spokesman for Foster's Brewing, said the pubs had been bought by a British finance company called Spring Inns, which would probably attempt to sell them at a profit. Inntrepreneur will be left with 2,900 pubs when the sale is completed. Foster's said funds raised from the sale would be used to reduce Inntrepreneur's debt. (Dow Jones)

title: New Mazda President Vows Separate Identity From Ford
description: The former Ford Motor Company executive who will become president of the troubled Mazda Motor Corporation vowed today that the Japanese company would remain independent.

title: Turkey Approves a Second Graft Inquiry Into Ex-Premier's Actions
description: Parliament approved a second investigation today into corruption allegations against a former Prime Minister, Tansu Ciller, increasing pressure on Turkey's fragile coalition Government.

title: Democrats Reject a Dole Plan to Cut Gas Tax
description: Thwarted all week by a Democratic filibuster, Senator Bob Dole today proposed legislation that would reduce the Federal gasoline tax by 4.3 cents, without other provisions of the sort President Clinton has called "poison pills."

title: After a String of Dictators, Ugandans Get to Vote Again
description: For the first time in 16 years, Ugandans stood in line this morning to vote for a new president, ending a bitter race that became a referendum not only on President Yoweri Museveni's tenure, but also on his vision of a democracy without political parties.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;Florida's Wuerffel Spurns Playboy Honor
description: The University of Florida quarterback DANNY WUERFFEL turned down an invitation to Playboy magazine's all-America college preseason football team, citing his religious convictions.

title: 5 Slain; Man Freed 3 Days Earlier Is Held
description: Three adults and two small children were found slashed to death today at a mobile home park, and police officers using a tracking dog arrested a man who was released prison on Monday after serving time for a parole violation. The vicitims' throats were slashed, investigators said.

title: Port Authority Approves a Rail Link to Kennedy Airport
description: After 30 years of false starts and failures that left travelers with few easy options to reach New York's major airport, the Port Authority's commissioners approved a plan yesterday to build a $1 billion rail line that would connect Manhattan to Kennedy International Airport.

title: Foreign Securities Report
description: United States investors acquired $98 billion worth of foreign securities in 1995, according to the Securities Industry Association. The association's Foreign Activity Report, released on Wednesday, said last year's amount was the second largest in history, surpassed only in 1993, when nearly $143 billion was invested abroad.

title: Columbia/HCA to Pay Blue Cross Officials
description: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation will pay as much as $19 million to three top officers and an outside legal counsel of Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Ohio who engineered the insurer's pending sale to Columbia, Blue Cross disclosed today.

title: Nasdaq Market Picks President; He Pledges to Put Investors First
description: Alfred R. Berkeley 3d, a managing director of Alex. Brown & Sons, was named president of the Nasdaq Stock Market yesterday, vowing that investors' interests would take precedence over those of brokers in running the growing and controversial market.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Polar Exploration's Golden Age Is Still a Maker and Breaker ofReputations
description: They were the golden years of polar exploration, the first three decades of the 20th century. While they brought fame and fortune to some, they brought death, disgrace or oblivion to others, and once-glittering reputations are still being buffeted.

title: Yeltsin's Uncertain Health Leaves a Question in the Minds of RussianVoters
description: In his frenetic pursuit of re-election, Boris N. Yeltsin plans 16 campaign trips this month. In April the 65-year-old Russian President's punishing schedule sent him from Moscow to Norway and then across the Asian continent to China. In between, he presided over a hectic summit meeting held for the leaders of the world's richest nations.

title: German Court Begins Hearing Case of American Neo-Nazi
description: Trying to wisecrack with a panel of German judges, an American neo-Nazi leader went on trial here today, accused of mailing anti-Semitic literature, swastika emblems and other material to his clandestine followers in Germany.

title: U.S. and North Korea Agree On Joint Search for Missing
description: The United States and North Korea announced today that later this year they expect to begin their first joint effort to search for the remains of thousands of Americans soldiers missing from the Korean War.

title: House Votes to Overhaul Housing for the Poor
description: The House voted tonight to overturn much of the nation's 59-year-old policy of housing for the poor in favor of a grant program that would give more power and discretion to local officials.

title: TV WEEKEND;Gus and Woodrow: The Early Years
description: Larry McMurtry has parlayed his best-selling 1985 novel into a small industry. In 1989, CBS's eight-hour television version of the book was an enormous success in ratings and reviews. Two sequels followed: the unauthorized "Return to Lonesome Dove," pushed by an eager CBS, and Mr. McMurtry's officially sanctioned "Streets of Laredo," based on his own book. Now "Dead Man's Walk," the author's third book in a planned tetralogy, is being given a two-part ABC adaptation, written by Mr. McMurtry and Diana Ossana. The first two hours can be seen on Sunday, the final three on Monday.

title: Panel Acts to Gain Travel Office Papers
description: A House committee investigating the dismissals at the White House travel office voted today to begin criminal contempt proceedings against one current and two former Presidential aides after President Clinton's top lawyer invoked executive privilege in refusing to turn over documents sought by the panel.

title: GIULIANI'S BUDGET PLAN: THE REACTION;Despite Giuliani's Reassurances, Critics Are Voicing Their Ire Over Service Cuts
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani vowed yesterday that despite his plan to reduce city spending by $1.1 billion, New Yorkers would not notice any service cuts. But his prediction raised only skepticism yesterday among children's advocates and neighborhood leaders, who said that children would be hurt by the proposed cuts and that the city's streets and parks would inevitably become dirtier.

title: Also of Note
description: Critics' choices of some other Manhattan art shows:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Sunday Mobile Home Sales?
description: In New Jersey, mobile homes are classified as motor vehicles for purposes of the state's blue laws, which have long blocked the sale of either on Sundays.

title: April Favored Clothing Sellers For a Change
description: Are clothes back? And are computer and toaster sales waning? The answer to both questions appeared to be yes yesterday when retailers reported their monthly same-store sales. Apparel retailers moved out ahead in April while merchants who deal in hard goods -- microwaves, toys and the like -- seemed to take a hit.

title: FILM REVIEW;Dorothy and Toto Had It Easier
description: EVERYBODY talks about the weather but nobody does as much about it as the makers of "Twister," a gale-force movie with the energy to blow audiences right out of the theater. Or pack them in, since this furiously escapist film tries to turn the killer tornado into nature's most daunting theme park ride.

title: Clear Channel to Acquire 19 More Stations
description: Clear Channel Communications Inc. said today that it would buy the closely held Radio Equity Partners L.P. of Norwalk, Conn., for $235 million in cash.

title: Executive Changes
description: ALLEGHENY POWER SYSTEM INC., New York, promoted Alan Noia, its president and chief operating officer, to the additional position of chief executive, succeeding Klaus Bergman, who will retire on June 1.

title: World News Briefs;U.N. Official Encourages Extending Force in Haiti
description: Peacekeepers may have to stay in Haiti into 1997 to insure stability, even though their mandate expires in June, the United Nations special representative to Haiti said today.

title: 4 Die in Crash of Military Helicopter
description: A helicopter making a test flight before it was to be delivered to the Marine Corps to provide cargo service for the White House appeared to lose its rotors today and crashed onto the flight field of the Sikorsky Aircraft Corporation, killing all four crew members.

title: World News Briefs;Muslim Pleads Not Guilty At War Crimes Tribunal
description: The first Muslim taken into custody by the international war crimes tribunal on Yugoslavia pleaded not guilty today to murders, rapes and torture allegedly committed against Serb inmates at a prison camp he commanded.

title: Mortgage Rates Climb
description: Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 8.24 percent this week, up from 7.99 percent last week, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said today. It was the highest since May 4, 1995, when rates averaged 8.27 percent.

title: GIULIANI'S BUDGET PLAN;Excerpts From Mayor Giuliani's Remarks on His Proposed City Budget
description: Following are excerpts from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's remarks to reporters yesterday at a briefing on his 1997 budget, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: Minimum Wage? As One Man Finds, It's Really a Matter of Perspective
description: Robert Bobbitt Sr. is a past president of the board of the Canton Urban League. For much of his life, civil rights have been the most important political issue for Mr. Bobbitt, who is black.

title: COMPANY NEWS;INSIGNIA FINANCIAL AGREES TO MAKE 3 ACQUISITIONS
description: Insignia Financial Group said yesterday that it had reached preliminary agreements to make three new acquisitions of real estate asset and service companies for a total price of $250 million. Insignia Financial said it did not have the money yet for all three acquisitions, which could contribute $50 million a year in earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization. Insignia Financial provides property or asset management services for more than 2,400 properties. Its stock rose $1 a share, to $22.25.

title: ART REVIEW;Cows, Pigs, Cigarettes: All Dead
description: There are plenty of reasons, in principle, not to like the much-anticipated display at Gagosian Gallery in SoHo of Damien Hirst, the English showman, impresario and bad-boy artist. So why did I like it? I'm trying to figure this out.

title: 2 Astronomy Teams Seeking Consensus on Universe's Age
description: Competing teams using different methods of estimating the age of the universe are moving closer to a common figure, though they remain separated by billions of years.

title: Market Place;Without an economic cycle, those high-flying cyclical stocks may be in for a hard landing.
description: INVESTORS in cyclical stocks have already discovered significant relief from the recent slide in the stock market. Although the broader market has fallen nearly 3 percent since its peak in mid-February, cyclical stocks have withstood much of the turbulence. So far this year the Morgan Stanley Cyclical Index has climbed 13 percent, compared with a 5 percent gain for the Standard & Poor's 500 Stock Index.

title: Court Nominee Steps Down in Gain for Dole
description: Under sharp criticism from Senator Bob Dole, a Miami trial lawyer who was President Clinton's nominee for a Federal appeals court has removed himself from consideration.

title: Art in Review
description: Ann Hamilton Sean Kelly Gallery 43 Mercer Street SoHo Through May 31

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Cannes Focus Turns Back To the Screen
description: BAD news for the starlets who traditionally try anything to attract attention on the beach. This year at Cannes, the excitement is liable to be on the screen.

title: Keep in Mind
description: READINGS, of short stories related to Mother's Day and featured in "Mothers: 20 Stories of Contemporary Motherhood," published by North Point Press. The authors who are to read are Mary Gordon, Jane Shapiro and Ronni Sandroff. Tomorrow, 1 P.M., at Shakespeare and Company, 939 Lexington Avenue, at 69th Street. Free. Information: (212) 570-0201. Children and fathers welcome.

title: Oil Company Profiteering Fuels Price Increase
description: To the Editor:

title: Brooklyn Drug Sweeps Begin to Make Inroads
description: A police unit equipped with a battering ram and a sledgehammer and carrying a search warrant burst into the Jameel Grocery, a bodega under the rusting tracks of the Z train in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and arrested three clerks one day last week on charges that they sold marijuana to an undercover officer.

title: What Happens in Hartford: Time Passes, but Bills Don't
description: When campaigns for the State Legislature heat up this fall, the 1996 legislative session may be recalled more for what it failed to accomplish than for anything it achieved.

title: Parents Convicted for a Youth's Misconduct
description: A jury in an upscale Detroit suburb today convicted the parents of a wayward teen-ager of a criminal misdemeanor for failing to control him. The case has caught the attention of a nation at once alarmed by soaring juvenile crime rates and concerned about punishing parents for their children's misbehavior.

title: U.S. Medical Station Attacked in Burundi
description: Seven people were killed and 32 wounded today in an attack on Hutu who had taken refuge with American missionaries in Burundi, a spokesman for the United States Embassy in Burundi said by telephone.

title: Corrections
description: The Economic Scene column in Business Day on May 2, about Congressional moves to revise the civil justice system, misstated a provision of a new Federal law involving securities litigation. While the new law makes it somewhat easier for courts to impose penalties on lawyers who file abusive lawsuits, it does not include a "loser pay" rule that allows the winner of a lawsuit to collect legal fees from the loser.

title: Home Video
description: Fast Start for 'Exhale'

title: COMPANY NEWS;NESTLE AND BAXTER TO CONSIDER SELLING CLINTEC
description: Nestle S.A. and the Baxter Healthcare Corporation, a unit of Baxter International Inc., have agreed to consider dissolving their Clintec Nutrition Company joint venture, the companies said yesterday. Clintec, based in Deerfield, Ill., makes and distributes clinical nutrition products used by patients who are fed intravenously or who require nutritional supplements. The venture had 1995 sales of about $400 million. Baxter plans to consolidate the venture's intravenous nutrition business with its existing intravenous solutions business. Nestle, the giant Swiss food company, plans to oversee the nutrition supplement business. Clintec employs about 1,000 employees, roughly half in the United States.

title: THEATER
description: The following list, which includes events through September, is selective. Performances rarely occur every day of the week, and programs are subject to change.

title: Mr. Pataki's Balanced H.M.O. Bill
description: Gov. George Pataki has forged a valuable agreement among rival groups of doctors, consumers, health maintenance organizations and employers on consumer protections for the six million New York State residents in managed-care health plans. His proposed bill, the result of months of arduous negotiations, would insure that an anxious public gets the information it needs to make smart choices on health coverage. At the same time, the Governor resisted lobbying by physician and other groups for provisions that could have hobbled managed care.

title: G.O.P. Abortion Plank
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Aide Denies Cover-Up on Files
description: A White House aide who went to the office of Vincent W. Foster Jr. on the night of his death in 1993 said today that she was trying to find a suicide note, not trying to cover up information about the White House travel office or Hillary Rodham Clinton's billing records from the Rose Law Firm.

title: COMPANY NEWS;INVESTOR GROUP ENDS BID FOR HUDSON GENERAL
description: An investment group led by the buyout firm Joel N. Levy/Peter M. Schulte L.L.C. said yesterday that it had withdrawn its bid to acquire the Hudson General Corporation for $44 a share, or about $89.5 million. The investor group said it had withdrawn the offer because Hudson General, an aviation-services company based in Great Neck, L.I., would not meet with the group and was pursuing a transaction with Deutsche Lufthansa A.G.. In February, Hudson General agreed to sell a 26 percent stake in its aviation-services business to Lufthansa for about $23.8 million. Hudson General previously turned down an offer of $41.25 a share from the investor group, which also includes Carl Marks & Company and the Swissair Group.

title: Clinton Denies Any LinksTo Whitewater Case Loan
description: Testifying in defense of his former partners in the Whitewater land venture, President Clinton repeatedly denied in videotaped testimony played today that he once asked an Arkansas businessman to give the partners an improper loan.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Burning Body Is Identified
description: The woman whose bound and strangled body was found burning under a pile of leaves in Weequahic Park on Monday was identified yesterday through dental records as Catherine Brown, 36, of Elizabeth, the authorities said. Martin Hellwig, director of public safety for Essex County, said Ms. Brown had been seen frequently with Peter E. Sizemore, the man whose body was found next to hers.

title: Trudging Up the Flatbush Trail
description: LET'S begin with the worst. Danny and I, old sauntering buddies, had decided to try something new, walking in a straight line. Our past perambulations had been around islands, first Manhattan, then Staten Island, attempts to glimpse truths from the outside looking in. Now we were going to walk the length of Flatbush Avenue, more than 10 miles, in search of nothing less than the soul of Brooklyn, the vast borough Thomas Wolfe said nobody could know "t'roo and t'roo."

title: CHRONICLE
description: LINDA EVANGELISTA does not want to be portrayed as Joan of Arc, at least not by the National Front, the extreme right-wing party in France led by Jean-Marie Le Pen.

title: Oil Company Profiteering Fuels Price Increase
description: To the Editor:

title: South Africa, Reborn Free
description: What was once nearly unthinkable became nearly unanimous Wednesday as South Africa adopted a new Constitution that guarantees racial equality, the rule of law and regular elections based on universal suffrage. This crowns a peaceful transition under the inspired leadership of Nelson Mandela, who eloquently marked the moment. "And so it comes to pass," he said, "that South Africa today undergoes her rebirth, cleansed of a horrible past, matured from a tentative beginning, and reaching out to the future with confidence."

title: Art in Review
description: Richard Phillips Edward Thorp Gallery 103 Prince Street SoHo Through May 25

title: COMPANY NEWS;TCI AND NEWS CORP. IN TV SPORTS VENTURE
description: As part of its deal to create a joint venture in global sports programming, the News Corporation will sell a 7.5 percent interest in Star TV, its satellite-delivered cable programming platform in Asia, to two entities controlled by Tele-Communications Inc. of Englewood, Colo. Tele-Communications said that in exchange for the Star TV stake, Liberty Media and Tele-Communications International, the acquiring organizations, would give sports broadcasting rights to the new venture. Star TV is an attempt to bring cable directly to homes in Asia but losses are running about $90 million a year. The News Corporation has said it would contribute about $350 million to the venture.

title: Pepsico to Run Troubled Argentine Bottler
description: Pepsico Inc. said today that it would assume management control of the troubled Argentine soft-drink bottler Buenos Aires Embotelladora S.A., after the company suffered big losses in Brazil.

title: 45 Arrested in a Nationwide Child Pornography Ring, U.S. Says
description: Using the business's own mailing list, postal inspectors have broken up a child-pornography ring that once netted its operators as much as $10,000 a week, the authorities announced yesterday.

title: Music in Review
description: A Believer in Coexistence With Dance Rhythm as the Glue Pierre Dorge Sweet Basil

title: Justin Finger, 69, Dies; Lawyer Aided Causes
description: Justin J. Finger, who spent three decades as a top lawyer for the Anti-Defamation League and then retired to the courtroom, prosecuting those charged with preying on the elderly, died on Tuesday as he was preparing to deliver the opening argument in an assault case. He was 69 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Lieut. Gen. Calvin Waller, 58, Deputy Commander in Gulf War
description: Lieut. Gen. Calvin A. H. Waller, deputy commander of American forces in the Persian Gulf war and one of the Army's highest-ranking blacks when he retired in 1991, died on Thursday while on a trip to Washington with his wife, Marion. He was 58.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Transocean Urges Merger With Sonat
description: The board of Transocean A.S., a Norwegian oil-drilling company, said today that it continued to support a merger with Sonat Offshore Drilling Inc., and urged shareholders to rebuff an increased bid from the Reading & Bates Corporation.

title: Ziff-Davis Adds Units
description: The Ziff-Davis Publishing Company has acquired two related publishing companies that specialize in video-game magazines. Terms were not disclosed. Ziff-Davis, a publisher of computer-related magazines and journals owned by the Softbank Corporation, said it had bought Sendai Publishing Group and Decker Publications from their founder, Steve Harris. Electronic Gaming Monthly is the flagship publication of the companies, which are both in Lombard, Ill. Sendai also publishes Computer Game Review and Internet Underground.

title: Sports of The Times;This River Is Deep And Wide
description: ONCE again the Knicks are faced with the daunting task of crossing the River Jordan. New York trails Chicago, two games to none, in a four-of-seven-game playoff matchup that is much too bitter to be called a rivalry. This is a feud.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;The Problems of Special Education
description: Special education has been taking some hits recently. In New York and other big cities, classes for disabled children have been described as dumping grounds for the unruly, particularly black and Hispanic boys. Critics say the special classrooms have been turned into welfare annexes rather than places for education, dead ends for many children.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Another Bass Gives Yale $20 Million
description: A year after Yale University returned $20 million to the Texas billionaire Lee M. Bass in a dispute over a Western civilization curriculum he had proposed, the school said yesterday that it had accepted another $20 million Bass gift -- this one from Mr. Bass's older brother Robert.

title: Michael L. Glassman, 56, Economist in Sports Antitrust Lawsuits
description: Michael L. Glassman, an economist who helped pioneer the application of economic analysis to antitrust sports litigation, died of a heart attack on May 2 on a business flight to St. Louis. He was 56 and lived in Bethesda, Md.

title: BOARD APPROVES PLAN TO REPURCHASE 20 MILLION SHARES
description: The Aluminum Company of America said yesterday that its board had approved a plan to buy back as many as 20 million shares, or about 11 percent of the company's 175.6 million common shares outstanding. The Pittsburgh-based Alcoa, the world's largest aluminum producer, said it would buy shares from time to time through open market purchases, negotiated purchases and tenders.

title: Wheat Harvest Will Be Poor, U.S. Forecasts
description: The nation's wheat harvest this summer will be the worst since 1978, the Department of Agriculture reported today, but it raised its estimates of overseas wheat production and of American corn plantings. The mixed forecast reinforced hopes among economists that the nation could avoid a sharp rise in food prices.

title: Helicopters Collide, Killing 14 Marines
description: Fourteen marines were killed and two were injured yesterday when two American helicopters collided during war-game exercises involving American and British troops at Camp Lejeune, N.C.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Increases 43 Points On Calming Inflation Report Capping one of the most volatile trading weeks in recent memory, stocks drove ahead as a benign wholesale inflation report calmed investors' nerves. Producer prices in April posted a smaller-than-expected rise of four-tenths of 1 percent. The Dow jumped 43 points, to 5,518.14. [Page 35.]

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Stolen Goods Seek Owners
description: Hoping for at least some reunions between burglary victims and their lost property, Essex County prosecutors will put on display today more than $1 in stolen merchandise, from jewelry to electronic equipment and baseball cards, at Maplewood Middle School. Prosecutors believe the goods, seized from a pawn shop during a recent raid in Newark, were stolen between 1994 and last month. Anyone reclaiming property must produce a police report as evidence that it had been reported stolen, prosecutors said.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF CISCO SYSTEMS HIT AN ALL-TIME HIGH
description: The shares of Cisco Systems Inc. hit an all-time high yesterday after the company, a computer network equipment maker, reported late on Thursday that its third-quarter earnings were better than Wall Street had expected. Shares of the company, based in San Jose, Calif., closed up $2.25, at $55, in trading of 14 million shares. Earlier, the shares traded as high as $55.141, a record high.

title: GOLF;Nilsmark Takes Lead On Shortened Course
description: Since much of the discussion out here at the DuPont Country Club has been about how to differentiate among squishy, soggy, saturated and soaked -- any or all of the above will do to describe the fairways -- the prevalent thought coming into today's first round of the McDonald's L.P.G.A. Championship was that long hitters would dominate.

title: Yeltsin's Desperation: He May Embrace an Old Foe
description: Things have suddenly become desperate in the election campaign of President Boris N. Yeltsin.

title: BASEBALL;Cone Is Irreplaceable, Yankees Say
description: The news release depicting David Cone's surgery as successful circulated quickly throughout the visitors' clubhouse at Comiskey Park this afternoon.

title: BASEBALL;Right-Field Solutions Might Be Close at Hand
description: Earlier in the week, Dallas Green had questioned Carl Everett's work ethic and attitude. Given a chance to produce last night, Everett may have proved a point off the bench. In a big way.

title: No Headline
description: It's not really a good job, but it's hard to find another job, and this way, I work for me. This is independence."

title: Comparator Admits Some Assets' Dubious Value
description: Under pressure from the Nasdaq Stock Market, the Comparator Systems Corporation disclosed yesterday that some of its largest assets were of dubious value and added that it had not arranged the funding needed to market its latest product.

title: BASEBALL;Pettitte Fails First Audition For Ace
description: Maybe Andy Pettitte was uncomfortable in the chilly temperatures that dropped below 40 degrees and the fierce winds that whipped to 23 miles per hour. Maybe he was uncomfortable being called a possible ace now that David Cone is out indefinitely. Maybe he was uncomfortable watching Kevin Tapani stifle the Yankees.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Barings Bondholders Seeking Compensation
description: The holders of bonds issued by Barings, the collapsed British bank, issued writs yesterday against 17 parties seeking compensation of L100 million. The proceedings have been brought against the issuing company, Barings P.L.C. (now under administration), and its directors as well as nine other individuals. The writ also names firms that managed the issue.

title: INSIDE
description: Inflation Worries Eased

title: New York Writ Small;Sassy Sculpture Casts Whimsical Cityscape in Bronze
description: Did you catch the one on the end -- the rat?" Marie Ricca, a 40-year-old receptionist, asked as she whipped past the sculpture yesterday at lunchtime. "I just caught that one today."

title: Would Pataki Call a Calder Painted Metal?
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;PXRE IS SEEKING ALL OF TRANSNATIONAL RE
description: The PXRE Corporation, a property catastrophe reinsurer, plans to buy the portion of the Transnational Re Corporation that it does not already own just a little more than two years after creating the company. PXRE, which has about a 22 percent stake in Transnational, started the company in late 1993 to take advantage of strong demand for "retrocessional reinsurance," which is reinsurance for reinsurers. PXRE said it would buy Transnational Re in a tax-free exchange of stock that would value Transnational shares at $23.50 each. PXRE said it would exchange 0.98 share of its common stock for each Transnational Re class A common share.

title: A Misguided Adoption Credit
description: President Clinton and House Republicans are pushing legislation that would give a generous tax credit to adoptive parents and make it easier for willing parents to adopt children of a different race. Encouraging adoption is a fine goal, but providing an ill-defined tax credit will not help the most needy children find a home.

title: Jockeying for Control, Dissidents File for Mesa Board
description: A group of dissident shareholders told Mesa Inc. today that it would nominate seven candidates for election to the board, a move that could position the dissidents to gain control of the company.

title: Magellan Fund Adds Stocks In Energy and Cuts Technology
description: The Fidelity Magellan Fund likes energy, and continues to shy away from technology.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-6

title: Joint Chiefs Weaken Proposal For Land-Mine Moratorium
description: The Joint Chiefs of Staff have watered down a proposed American moratorium on land mines, recommending a broad exception that could allow the use of mines anywhere the United States and its allies need protection from an enemy across a demilitarized zone, Clinton Administration officials said today.

title: Music in Review
description: A New Violin Concerto That Flouts Convention Riverside Symphony Alice Tully Hall

title: A Plan to Keep Officers Off the Hotel Banisters
description: Two dozen New York City police officers will be doing some undercover work this weekend at saloons and hotel parking lots in Washington. They will perch themselves at bars and other places where drinking is expected to occur, looking for unruliness. And just in case, they will scribble down every New York State license plate number they see.

title: Colby Probably Collapsed Before Drowning
description: William E. Colby, the former Director of Central Intelligence, probably collapsed from a heart attack or stroke while canoeing, then fell into the water and died, the state medical examiner's office said today.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Ivory Coast Bars Ship With 4,000 Liberians
description: Ivory Coast officials ordered a ship carrying 4,000 Liberian refugees back to open waters today despite concerns that the ship might not be seaworthy, a spokeswoman for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees said.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS: After Battle of Words, Knick-Bull War Returns to Court; Kukoc To Miss Games 3 and 4
description: The nagging back problems of the Chicago Bulls now extend beyond Michael Jordan. Forward Toni Kukoc will miss Games 3 and 4 of the Eastern Conference semifinals this weekend against the Knicks after he sprained his lower back while making what seemed to be a routine jump shot at the end of practice today.

title: 3 Indicted in Culbro Corp. False-Billing Case
description: In the latest troubles for the beleaguered Culbro Corporation, three men have been indicted on charges that they used a false billing scheme to cheat a Culbro cigar plant in Dothan, Ala., out of nearly $1 million.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Clinton Aide Describes Arms Flow to Bosnia
description: By the time the Administration gave its tacit assent to Iranian arms shipments into Bosnia and Herzegovina, weapons already were flowing from Teheran to the Government in Sarajevo, Anthony Lake, President Clinton's national security adviser, said today.

title: COURT TOSSES OUT AN ASBESTOS DEAL
description: A Federal appeals court threw out a landmark $1.3 billion class-action settlement yesterday that would have limited future health claims of hundreds of thousands of workers and their families against 20 major asbestos producers.

title: TENNIS;Hingis Stuns No. 1 Graf
description: Steffi Graf was beaten by 15-year-old Martina Hingis of Switzerland, 2-6, 6-2, 6-3, today in the quarterfinals of the Italian Open in Rome, sending the world's top-ranked woman to her first loss on clay in nearly two years.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Bomb Threat Empties Schools
description: About 13,000 students in all 24 Trenton public schools were ordered out of classrooms yesterday morning after an anonymous caller telephoned Holland Middle School and said bombs were planted in all of the city's schools, according to school officials. The police searched each school and found no evidence of bombs. Students returned to class by early afternoon.

title: Man Is Sentenced to 18 Years In Killing of Anti-Drug Writer
description: After he tearfully begged for forgiveness, a prime conspirator in the slaying of a crusading anti-drug journalist was sentenced yesterday to 18 years in prison for his involvement in that killing and three others.

title: Kompong Speu Journal;Living With Land Mines: Cambodia's Deadly Toll
description: Here in one of the most heavily mined countries on earth, where farmers are regularly killed and maimed in their fields, some villagers have found creative uses for unexploded land mines.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Farrakhan Aide to Speak
description: Khalid Abdul Muhammad, the Nation of Islam official whose anti-Semitic remarks in a 1993 speech at Kean College caused a furor, is scheduled to be the main speaker tonight in a protest against a New Jersey Transit plan to demolish the homes of 29 families in a mostly black neighborhood to make way for a rail link that would speed commutes to Manhattan. Mr. Muhammad's speech is scheduled for 7 P.M. at Eureka Masonic Lodge, following an afternoon march and rally in front of the Township Hall.

title: TEJAS GAS TO PURCHASE TRANSOK FOR $690 MILLION
description: The Central and South West Corporation said yesterday that the Tejas Gas Corporation would pay about $690 million in cash and assume $200 million of debt to acquire its Transok Inc. unit. The sale was announced on Thursday, but no terms were announced then. Central and South West, a Dallas-based utility, said it would use proceeds from the sale to pay off $400 million in debt from its acquisition of Seeboard P.L.C., a British utility. The rest will be used for "general corporate purposes," the company said. Tejas, based in Tulsa, Okla., is one of the country's largest gas pipeline operators, with more than 6,500 miles of gas gathering and transmission pipeline.

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;Messier Says It's Simply a Matter of Missed Scoring Oppurtunities
description: Mark Messier stood at his locker here this afternoon and stated without any reservation that converting all those scoring opportunities they have been creating was what the Rangers had to do against the Pittsburgh Penguins. The problem is that Messier and the Rangers, down by 3 games to 1 in their Eastern Conference semifinal series, have just one game to do it.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Zeneca Group Reports Strong '96 Sales
description: Zeneca Group P.L.C. said yesterday that its first-quarter sales were "well ahead" of expectations, driven by its two biggest divisions: pharmaceuticals and agrochemicals. "This has been something of an exceptional start" to 1996, said Sydney Lipworth, the company's chairman, in a statement released at the annual shareholders meeting.

title: Sanctions on Nigeria Would Deepen Poverty
description: To the Editor:

title: Ban Upheld On Revealing Presence Of Offenders
description: A Federal judge rejected a motion by New Jersey's Attorney General today that would have allowed county prosecutors to resume issuing at least some warnings about the presence of paroled sex offenders.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AGREEMENT SET TO BUY CYCARE IN STOCK SWAP
description: HBO & Company agreed yesterday to buy Cycare Systems Inc. in a stock swap valued at $246 million, helping HBO's health care information-processing business. Cycare's shares were up $1.625 yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, to $47.825, a new 52-week high, a day after rising $3.25 each. The shares of Atlanta-based HBO rose $6.375, to $119.375, in Nasdaq trading. HBO said it would pay about 0.43 share for each Cycare share, issuing a total of 2.18 million shares. Cycare, based in Scottsdale, Ariz., said last week that several companies had approached it with buyout or merger proposals.

title: JAMES RIVER ENDS TALKS TO SELL UNIT TO SUN CHEMICAL
description: The James River Corporation said yesterday that it had ended negotiations to sell its CZ Inks division to the Sun Chemical Corporation and had hired Merrill Lynch & Company to help find other buyers. James River and Sun Chemical, of Fort Lee, N.J., a maker of inks and organic pigments, signed a letter of intent for the transaction in March. James River said the two sides could not reach a final agreement. A James River spokesman said the Richmond-based company had received indications of interest from other parties before it signed the agreement with Sun Chemical. CZ Inks makes inks for packaging applications.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Arrests in Tavern Slaying
description: Two Wildwood men were arrested early yesterday and charged with murdering a customer and beating a bartender during an attempted robbery at the Fire House Tavern hours earlier. The authorities said that John Poteat and Frederick Simmons, both 35, were being held in Cape May County jail on charges including murder, armed robbery and aggravated assault. The slain customer was identified as Robert T. Connors, 38, of West Wildwood. JOE SHARKEY

title: Company Briefs
description: HEALTHCARE CENTERS OF AMERICA INC., Oakbrook Terrace, Ill., said its wholly owned subsidiary HCCA International Research and Development Ltd. had agreed to acquire a 95 percent stake in Viron Corp., a closely held Irish biotechnology company, for about $61.3 million in stock.

title: Sikorsky Identifies Employees Who Died in Helicopter Crash
description: The Sikorsky Aircraft Corporation identified the four men today who died on Thursday when a cargo helicopter destined for the White House fleet crashed on the company's airfield during a test flight.

title: 2 Trains to the Plane? Travelers Don't Mind
description: Travelers at Kennedy Airport said they welcomed a plan by the Port Authority for a light rail system that would connect the airport to the Long Island Rail Road's Jamaica Station in Queens and from there to Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan.

title: Treasury Prices Pushed Higher As Inflation Index Is Barely Up
description: A Government report showing an absence of inflation pressures sent Treasury prices surging yesterday.

title: They Don't Take Just Any Mutt
description: Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern's solution to the perennial problem of leashless dogs in Central Park is the neighborhood dog run. Evidently, he has never tried to join one. In New York, it takes an endless wait and a sizable check to set your dogs free.

title: Plan to Expand Metrocard's Uses Is Put Off
description: A plan to allow commuters to make small purchases with their Metrocards instead of using them just for bus and subway fares, has been shelved for the time being, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced yesterday.

title: Travelers Welcome Kennedy Link
description: For Joe Cowel, a financial consultant who lives in Los Angeles, flies to other large United States cities almost every week and visits New York more than 10 times a year, it was the usual grind at Kennedy International Airport yesterday.

title: Music in Review
description: From Baroque to the Blues, The Subject Is Lust Four Nations Ensemble Miller Theater

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;After Election, Taxes Rise
description: After producing an election-year budget that kept county taxes level in 1995, the Hudson County Executive, Robert C. Janiszewski, announced a 1996 budget in which taxes will rise 17 percent. Mr. Janiszewski, a Democrat, released details of the $323 million budget on Thursday. Tom Gallagher, a spokesman for Bret Schundler, the Republican Mayor of Jersey City, where about half of Hudson County's population lives, said the tax hike came as no surprise. "Typically, the county machine raises taxes the year after an election, then spends the next three years telling everybody they won't do it again," said Mr. Gallagher.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;Sonics Stay Calm and Build 3-0 Lead
description: The Seattle SuperSonics may see the light of June after all. They had nothing to lose -- except their jobs -- yet they are now treating the Houston Rockets worse than they did Sacramento.

title: With Old Political Order Gone, Leaders in India Vie for Power
description: India's rival political groups clamored for power today after a general election that shattered the traditional base of the Congress Party and gave new leverage to a tumultuous assemblage of groups representing the mosaic of castes, regions and languages in this nation of 930 million people.

title: Without a Strong State University, New York Can't Compete;Questions for CUNY
description: To the Editor:

title: 110 Prisoners Are Freed in Exchange in Caucasus
description: Foreign Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov of Russia said 110 people were freed today under a prisoner exchange between Azerbaijan and Armenia as part of a Russian diplomatic effort to end the conflict over Nagorno-Karabakh.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PESICO TO OFFER BEEPERS TO ITS TEEN-AGE MARKET
description: Pepsico is taking an expensive and innovative approach to keeping tabs on the youth market: It's offering 500,000 teen-agers six months of free beeper service. The campaign to promote Mountain Dew soft drinks comes at a time when the use of beepers is a hot issue in school systems nationwide. Pepsico plans to link teen-agers who order $29 Motorola beepers in a network that will beep them weekly with discount offers and prize contests. Those who call back on a toll-free number will hear a recording from sports and entertainment celebrities -- including Ken Griffey Jr., Richard Petty and Evel Knievel. Prizes include personal snowboarding lessons, a trip to MTV's Beach House and recording sessions at Sony studios. The offer will cost Pepsico and its partners $40 million to $50 million, according to people close to the company.

title: Dance in Review
description: A Slow, Elegant Something In Celebration of Nothing Danspace Project St. Marks Church

title: Two Charges Dropped Against Colombia Leader
description: Members of a congressional investigations committee said today that they would dismiss two of the four charges against President Ernesto Samper.

title: William Blackie, 90, Ex-Chairman of Caterpillar
description: William Blackie, a Scottish-born accountant who presided over Caterpillar Inc. as chairman and chief executive during booming years of growth for the manufacturer of tractors and other earth-moving equipment, died on Thursday in San Rafael, Calif., where he lived after retiring from Caterpillar. He was 90.

title: A Policeman Who Rescued 4 in Bombing Kills Himself
description: A police sergeant who rescued at least four people at the site of the Oklahoma City bombing committed suicide this week but left no note, prompting friends and co-workers to speculate that he was driven by guilt at not being able to have saved more lives and by despondency over a troubled family life, the police said.

title: Some Republicans Condemn House Leadership's Attacks on Labor asDivisive
description: The Republican Party is badly split over whether to get tough or get friendly with the newly vigorous labor movement. While House leaders have pressed a stinging attack, many Republicans from New York State and other union strongholds condemn this approach, saying it drives union voters toward the Democrats.

title: 200 Vietnamese Refugees Flee Detention Camp in Hong Kong
description: About 200 Vietnamese boat people, facing a forced return home, fled a detention center in Hong Kong today after battering down the gates.

title: Clinton Calls for Volunteers In Communities and Schools
description: President Clinton summoned Americans to increased community service today, calling for one million volunteers to join neighborhood anti-crime patrols and promising a $500 Federal grant to match local contributions toward a national-service college scholarship at each of the nation's 20,000 high schools.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Trump Aide Sues Predecessor
description: Nicholas L. Ribis, the head of Donald J. Trump's casino-hotel operations, filed a lawsuit yesterday charging his predecessor, Edward M. Tracy, with slander for saying that Mr. Ribis had threatened his life during a May 4 argument at a Trump hotel.

title: Bridge
description: Last week the best players in Europe, with a sprinkling from North America and other continents, were gathered in Paris for the General World Individual, won by a young star, Geir Helgemo of Norway. Now the center of gravity has moved across the Atlantic, and the best of North America with a sprinkling from Europe and other continents is gathered in New York City for two major events: the Cavendish Invitational Pairs, beginning today, and the Cavendish Teams, which ended yesterday afternoon in a victory for an Italian foursome that owns the European team title: Lorenzo Lauria, Alfredo Versace, Andrea Buratti and Massimo Lanzarotti.

title: Religion Journal;Hare Krishnas at 30: Real Changes or Just P.R.?
description: Of the new religious movements that came to flower in the United States in the 1960's, the Hare Krishnas seemed to be the lightning rod. With their distinctive dress and demeanor -- shaven heads and saffron robes, ecstatic dancing and chanting -- they attracted fascination and hostility, almost in equal parts.

title: Congress's Knee-Jerk Helium Giveaway
description: For 35 years, the Government has kept a vast reserve of helium, which when cooled is one of the earth's most technologically vital fluids. Yet from the casual manner in which the House voted overwhelmingly last week to sell the reserve to the private sector, one might have thought it was dispensing with laughing gas.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by Bloomberg Business News in Business Day on Thursday about a recall by the Nissan Motor Company misidentified the manufacturer of a seat belt part that is being replaced on Infinitis in the United States. The faulty part was made by a parts company using material from a Bridgestone Corporation subsidiary; it was not made by Bridgestone itself.

title: Parental Rights Bill Has Dangers and Merit
description: To the Editor:

title: Dance in Review
description: Fantasies of Paper Dolls And Motion as Music Dances by Ornelas and MacFarlane Washington Square Church

title: Treading Water
description: So now it turns out that all the fancy gizmos at the health club, and all the relentless sales pitches for new exercise machines on late-night TV, have got us exactly nowhere when it comes to burning off calories. In fact, those who succumbed to the seductions of the exer-gadgets may actually be worse off, weight-wise, than if they had stuck with what humankind knows best -- walking and running.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;After Much Ado, Japan Passes '96 Budget
description: After months of bitter wrangling, the Japanese Parliament today approved a $715 billion budget for this fiscal year, which began on April 1.

title: Observer;Oh, What Fun It Is!
description: President Clinton goes to New Jersey to warn the young about the evils of tobacco. Senator Bob Dole goes to a northern Virginia gasoline pump to preach the evils of taxation.

title: Would Pataki Call a Calder Painted Metal?
description: To the Editor:

title: FILM REVIEW;Middle-Aged Vigilantes: The Gang Has Grown Up
description: From the macroeconomic and sociological perspective visible through its litter of corpses, the muddled Middle Western "Original Gangstas," which opened yesterday, has a lot to say about what is wrong with America. And when it comes to what's wrong with movies, this tale of generational vengeance also speaks eloquently.

title: For 53, the Promise of America Fits on a Taxicab
description: Fifty-three cab drivers, nearly all of them born half a world away, became entrepreneurs yesterday as the winning bidders in New York City's first sale of new taxi medallions since the Depression.

title: Uganda Leader Looks Set for Election Victory
description: President Yoweri Museveni, the former rebel commander who fought his way to power 10 years ago, appeared headed for a landslide victory today in Uganda's first presidential election. But the main opposition candidate said he would not accept the results.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Daily Briefing column in New Jersey copies on April 24 referred incorrectly to a group of 2,900 people involved in medical training in New Jersey. They are resident physicians in training at New Jersey hospitals -- not medical students in the state. And nearly half of them are graduates of foreign medical schools, but they are not necessarily foreigners.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;A Young Verdi's Bold and Vivid Joan of Arc
description: Giovanna d'Arco" is Verdi's operatic picture of France's warrior-saint, but the most vivid portrait painted here is of a composer's irrepressible energy. This is Joan of Arc reduced to operatic simplicity: moral conflict blown to headline size and printed in boldface, ambiguity reduced to agate type.

title: Missing Adoption Bill Vote, Rep. Molinari Gives Birth
