description: Representative Susan Molinari gave birth last night to a girl, Susan Ruby Paxon, at the Staten Island University Hospital North. It was Ms. Molinari's first child and only the third time that a serving member of Congress gave birth.

title: Mid-Air Copter Collision Kills 14 Marines in South
description: Fourteen marines were killed and two were injured before dawn today when two helicopters collided and plunged into a densely forested marsh in an isolated part of this Marine Corps base in eastern North Carolina.

title: Hard Landing at Denver;The S.E.C. Questions Disclosure on Airport Bonds
description: Way back in 1990, when the Denver International Airport was, literally, just a hole in the ground, local officials were warned by their own consultants that the baggage system that would later shred luggage and become a national joke was horribly flawed and might not work.

title: Waldholtz Pleads Not Guilty to Fraud
description: Joseph Waldholtz, the estranged husband of Representative Enid Greene of Utah, pleaded not guilty to a 27-count bank fraud indictment today in his appearance in Federal District Court.

title: Celedonio Romero, 83, Guitarist Who Formed a Family Quartet
description: Celedonio Romero, who founded the Romeros guitar quartet with his sons, Pepe, Celin and Angel, died on Wednesday at Mercy Hospital in San Diego.

title: Dance in Review
description: Nilas Martins as Apollo In the Balanchine Original New York City Ballet New York State Theater

title: Child Pornography Sent on the Internet Leads to an Arrest
description: A 19-year-old Adelphi University student has been charged with using a university computer to put child pornography on the Internet, the Nassau County police said today.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Peugeot to Cut 1,262 Auto Jobs
description: The auto-making arm of Peugeot Citroen said yesterday that it planned to cut 1,262 jobs at five sites. The reduction would come through voluntary reductions at factories at Sochaux, Mulhouse, Poissy, Sept-Fons and Valenciennes, the company said.

title: Dole Passes on a Chance to Praise Himself
description: Senator Bob Dole spoke today at the commencement of Gallaudet College here, but he passed up the opportunity to discuss his own triumph over disabilities at what is the world's only four-year liberal arts college for the deaf.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Reveling in Ravel's Mercurial Artistic Persona
description: Ravel was two composers, and both of them showed up at Andre Previn's evening with the New York Philharmonic on Thursday night. First there is the master of the touching melody, the maker of soft modal cadences redolent of long ago and far away and ruefully nostalgic for both. Then there is Ravel the genius of contrivance, delicate manipulator of instrumental color, master of the coup de theatre.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Once Again, Jurors Weigh Kevorkian's Fate
description: The common-law charges of assisted suicide against Dr. Jack Kevorkian went to the jury late today, after prosecutors pleaded with jurors not to try to make social policy but to find the retired pathologist guilty of helping two women kill themselves in 1991.

title: Medallion Limits Stem From the 30's
description: Desperate cabbies competing for fares. Reckless driving. Traffic congestion. Run-down taxis.

title: Radio Stations Sold
description: Sundance Broadcasting Inc. has sold nine radio stations to Colfax Communications Inc. of Minneapolis for $95 million. Sundance said Colfax had purchased KOY-AM, KYOT-FM, KZON-FM and KISO-AM, all of Phoenix, plus KIDO-AM, KLTB-FM and KARO-FM in Boise, Idaho, and WMIL-FM and WOKY-AM in Milwaukee. Sundance, of Phoenix, bought the stations for a total of about $20 million in deals as long ago as 1975. Colfax also recently bought KOOL-AM and FM in Phoenix.

title: BOXING;Holyfield Leads Veterans' Victory Parade
description: Evander Holyfield continued his search for his second childhood and third championship last night at Madison Square Garden, despite career earnings of more than $100 million.

title: Burned at the Ballot Box
description: May 7, 7:45 A.M. I arrive at P.S. 130 in Manhattan's Chinatown to monitor the school board elections. My job is to make sure that the city complies with Section 203 of the Federal Voting Rights Act, which requires bilingual ballots and translators. I plan to report any problems to the Board of Elections. But a low turnout is predicted, so I expect a quiet day.

title: Taking Care of Mayors
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about fighting in Burundi misstated the country's ethnic mix. The Hutu, not the Tutsi, are in the majority there.

title: Parental Rights Bill Has Dangers and Merit
description: To the Editor:

title: Without a Strong State University, New York Can't Compete
description: To the Editor:

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;Magic Too Much for Hawks
description: It didn't matter that Atlanta found a way to slow down Shaquille O'Neal. Orlando still had too much firepower tonight and took a 2-0 lead in its second-round playoff series with a 120-94 victory.

title: Attack and Parry: Taxes Set Political Pace
description: Energized by Senator Bob Dole's proposal to repeal the 4.3-cents-a-gallon gasoline tax, Republicans are looking for ways to inject tax cuts often into the 1996 campaign. And President Clinton's announcement this week that he would support the temporary repeal of a tax he pushed through Congress illustrates his Administration's determination to keep Mr. Clinton from looking like a big-taxing liberal.

title: House Endorses Break on Taxes For Adoptions
description: The House today overwhelmingly approved a bill that would make it easier and more affordable to adopt a child in this country.

title: INTERNATIONAL JENSEN ACCEPTS SWEETENED RECOTON BID
description: International Jensen Inc. said yesterday that it had accepted a sweetened offer from the Recoton Corporation, a maker of electronic components, based in Lake Mary, Fla. International Jensen has been the subject of a takeover battle between Recoton and the Emerson Radio Corporation. Recoton is now offering $10 for each Jensen share not owned by its chairman, Robert G. Shaw. Recoton will pay $8.90 for each of the shares owned by Mr. Shaw and the William Blair Leveraged Capital Fund. The offer values Jensen at more than $53 million. Under its previous bid, Recoton would have paid Jensen's public shareholders $9.15 a share, and Mr. Shaw and the Blair Fund $9 a share.

title: Parental Rights Bill Has Dangers and Merit
description: To the Editor:

title: About New York;These Rivals Say Injustice Is Not Blind
description: ON Eastern Parkway yesterday, Joseph Strassberg cradled his daughter, his wrists still chafed, cut and red from the handcuffs slapped on him the night before. There was no burning trash in Crown Heights anymore, just the smoldering resentment felt by him and his fellow Hasidim for what they say was the excessive force the police used to quell a protest.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: THEATER REVIEW;Miller, Mamet and Much in Between in Festival of One-Act Plays
description: When last seen at the Ensemble Studio Theater, less than two months ago, James Murtaugh was an affluent, guarded man locked in an enigmatic, erotic dialogue with a younger woman. Mr. Murtaugh can be found on the same stage these days. He is playing an affluent, guarded man locked in an enigmatic, erotic dialogue with a younger woman.

title: POP REVIEW;Songs of Love And Lovers, Lost and Hurt
description: Love in all its forms was the subject of Bobby Womack's show at the Five Spot on Thursday night. He sang about the pleasures of stolen love, and the deep deprivation of being denied. He sang about how hard it was to maintain a relationship, about the ecstatic nature of love and the charge and bitterness of love's sensuality.

title: BASEBALL;No Timetable Set for Cone After Surgery
description: David Cone underwent a three-hour operation yesterday to repair an aneurysm in the shoulder region of his throwing arm. In the operation, surgeons cut two arteries, removed the aneurysm, then performed a graft using a small piece of vein from the Yankee pitcher's leg to restore the connection and blood flow.

title: New Budget Still Takes Risky Leaps, Critics Say
description: For all Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's efforts to draft a city budget with fewer gimmicks and more realistic assumptions, his latest plan still depends on actions in the unpredictable State Legislature. It also relies on one-time savings that have not yet happened and may never.

title: Hasidic Patrol Group Faces Questions After a Crown Heights Clash
description: Members of a Hasidic patrol group who fought with a black man in Crown Heights on Thursday night violated police rules intended to prevent vigilantism when they chased down a crime suspect instead of simply calling the police, police officials said yesterday.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Olivetti's Quarter Ahead of '95 Level
description: Olivetti S.p.A. of Italy said yesterday that its operating profit in the first quarter of 1996 was above that of the first quarter of 1995. Carlo De Benedetti, the chairman of Olivetti, the information and technology company, said at the annual shareholders meeting in Ivrea, Italy, that the company would be giving quarterly reports only on its PC business in the future.

title: U.S. WON'T PUNISH CHINA OVER SALE OF NUCLEAR GEAR
description: After three months of highly politicized debate, the Administration decided today not to punish China for the sale of equipment used for the production of weapons-grade enriched uranium to Pakistan.

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;Blues Shut Out Red Wings
description: Wayne Gretzky took the weight off his shoulders tonight and placed it squarely on the backs of the Detroit Red Wings.

title: India Spurns the Congress Party
description: Political power in India is changing hands. After ruling for 45 of the 49 years since independence, the Congress Party has been tossed aside by disillusioned voters, and will now hold less than 25 percent of the seats in a Parliament fragmented among three main groups and a diverse array of smaller parties. Indians punished the Congress Party for pervasive corruption, lackluster leadership and the uneven benefits so far produced by bold but wrenching economic reforms.

title: EXCEL SHARES CLOSE AT ALMOST TWICE OFFERING PRICE
description: The shares of Excel Communications Inc., a long-distance telephone service reseller, closed at almost twice their offering price after their first day of trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Excel's stock closed at $29.375 after 11 million shares were traded. Excel, based in Dallas, sold 10 million shares at $15 to raise $150 million in its initial public offering on Thursday. Investors snapped up the company's shares because of the prospects for rapid increases in sales and earnings, said Ryan Jacob, director of research at IPO Value Monitor in New York. Excel's revenue soared to $506.7 million last year from $30.8 million in 1993.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;ABN-Amro in Venture With Rothschild Group
description: The Dutch banking company ABN-Amro Holding N.V. said yesterday that it was merging its equity capital markets activities with those of the Rothschild Group of Britain. The two will cooperate in originating, underwriting and distributing equity transactions, under the name of ABN-Amro Rothschild.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS: After Battle of Words, Knick-Bull War Returns to Court;   Coaches Trade Pre-game Barbs
description: Phil Jackson, often the existentialist, and Jeff Van Gundy, ever the traditionalist, have had three days to cool off, watch film and mellow out. Yet the Zenmaster and the Little Coach Who Could are not big on truces, and neither are their teams.

title: COMPANY NEWS;UROMED GAINS ALL OF FEMALE INCONTINENCE PRODUCT
description: The Uromed Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired all technology and assets related to a Food and Drug Administration-approved female incontinence product for $30 million. The product, called the Miniguard Patch, was acquired from Advanced Surgical Intervention Liquidating Trust, which is selling the assets of Advanced Surgical Intervention Inc., a California urological products company. The purchase price consists of $7 million in cash and $23 million in stock. The product is a disposable prescription adhesive patch placed externally against the urethral opening to help block leakage in women with mild to moderate stress incontinence.

title: Helen Wallenda, 85, the Last Of the Original High-Wire Team
description: She was just 17 when she climbed on the shoulders of Karl Wallenda in the debut performance of the Wallenda pyramid in Madison Square Garden in 1928. The act brought the audience to its feet and stopped the Greatest Show on Earth for 11 minutes.

title: Mother Convicted in 4-Year-Old Girl's Death
description: A Bronx jury convicted a woman yesterday of killing her 4-year-old daughter after many months of cruelty that reached a fatal crescendo two years ago.

title: Tread Carefully With China, Business Leaders Urge U.S.
description: Chief executives in major industries, meeting here with Government officials today, expressed concern that the Administration's looming showdown with China over piracy of American music, movies and software could set off a wider trade conflict and endanger their ability to compete in the vast Chinese market.

title: Music in Review
description: Anger Tempered With Humor From Punk Mingled With Pop Fred Schneider Brownies

title: Miracle on Madison Avenue
description: The New York Public Library system springs from a remarkable history of public-private collaboration. Founded through private philanthropy in 1895 but sustained primarily through public funds, the library has nourished generations of New York City residents and ushered countless immigrants into the mainstream. Andrew Carnegie underwrote the branch system in 1901 "to help those who will help themselves."

title: A Correlation of Age and Great Presidents
description: To the Editor:

title: Women Need Self-Esteem, Not Diet Advice
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Lloyd's Sweetens Offer to Disgruntled Members
description: Lloyd's of London made an offer to disgruntled members today that would lower their share of the cost of saving the world's oldest insurance market from bankruptcy and increase the settlement offered to those members who have sued Lloyd's.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Basketball

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Tuesday about the five companies that spent the most in a Federal Communications Commission auction for wireless communications licenses, misstated the relationship of U S West to one of the bidders, the Questcom Corporation. U S West Communications Group, a unit of U S West, has an agreement to supply network equipment to Questcom; it is not an investor in Questcom.

title: Price Report Eases Worries On Inflation
description: A Government report today eased worries that a reinvigorated economy was pushing up inflation.

title: Perot Group Falls Far Short Of Original Political Vision
description: Just weeks after Ross Perot's unsuccessful run for the White House in 1992, he started what he touted as a citizen-financed, nonpartisan truth squad that would transform the way in which Washington does the people's business.

title: Music in Review
description: Confident and Furious in Songs About Race and Sexuality Skunk Anansie Coney Island High

title: Journal;The Sound of Money
description: In today's exploding Times Square -- where mobs jam the new Virgin Megastore and Conde Nast just joined Disney and Madame Tussaud's on the bandwagon of new tenants -- Julie Andrews's loverly display of primadonnaism this week seemed a quaint relic of the past.

title: F.B.I. Says It Reviewed a Computer Service for Indecency
description: The Justice Department came under fire today from a Federal judge at closing arguments on the constitutionality of the Communications Decency Act, after it was disclosed that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had reviewed complaints of indecent material on Compuserve.

title: In Sick, Crowded Ponderosa Forests of West, Seeds of Infernos LieOminously in Wait
description: Gripping the handles of his steel auger, District Ranger John Peterson twisted the sharp corkscrew tip into the core of a tiny Ponderosa pine, barely three inches in diameter. Extracting a thin, cylindrical cross section of wood from the scraggly tree, which looked as though it must be an infant, he squinted to count the tiny rings, so slight and closely packed that they were barely discernible.

title: Some Plea Deals in Trial of Italy's Fashion Elite
description: As the cream of Italian fashion went on trial here today, several defendants, including Giorgio Armani, agreed to plea-bargain settlements in their tax-bribery cases. Mr. Armani, perhaps Italy's foremost arbiter of elegance, was fined $64,000 and given a nine-month suspended jail sentence.

title: A Divorce of Convenience
description: They had an unerring sense of the photo-op. Whether South Africa was celebrating a new Constitution or a world rugby victory, F. W. de Klerk and Nelson Mandela always seemed to find each other in the crowd. They would walk together, clasping hands, offering the world that warm and fuzzy picture of black and white leaders at work together.

title: Rig Count Jumps by 23
description: The number of oil and gas rigs operating nationwide rose by 23 this week, to 772, Baker Hughes Inc. said today. There were 689 rigs operating in the United States a year ago. Of the rigs running this week, 474 were exploring for natural gas and 290 for oil.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Kvaerner Reports 8% Profit Decline
description: The Norwegian industrial company Kvaerner reported yesterday that it had an 8 percent profit drop in the first quarter on weaker results from its shipbuilding operations. Kvaerner said its $1.36 billion takeover in April of the British engineering giant Trafalgar House P.L.C. "strongly influenced" the beginning of the year, but gave no elaboration. The Trafalgar purchase makes Kvaerner one of the world's largest construction companies of offshore petroleum projects.

title: Laurie Basch, Alexander Nacht
description: Laurie Basch, a daughter of Charles and Sally Basch of Melrose Park, Pa., is to be married today to Dr. Alexander Nacht, the son of the late Pauline and Dr. Arnold Nacht. Rabbi Avi Winokur is to officiate at the Pegasus Suite at the Rainbow Room in New York.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Adultery in Bloom
description: IN a sublime time warp, Centenary Stage is dusting off "Springtime for Henry," the sort of arcane farce no theater devotee imagined could be restored to stage light.

title: The Longest Day
description: Guam, a self-governing territory of the United States 6,000 miles west of San Francisco, bills itself as "Where America's Day Begins." It could also call itself "Where America's Day Ends." When it is, say, midnight on a Tuesday in San Francisco, it is 5 P.M. in Guam. And, since Guan lies on the other side of the international date line, it is 5 P.M. Wednesday.

title: MAY 5-11;Crime Is Down. But Wait.
description: The good news was that the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported last week that serious crimes dropped for the fourth consecutive year in 1995, with an 8 percent decrease in homicides.

title: Board 3 Coverage Distorts Roles of Jews and of Poles
description: To the Editor:

title: The Man Who Freed the Banks
description: Wriston Walter Wriston, Citibank, and the Rise and Fall of American Financial Supremacy. By Phillip L. Zweig. 952 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $40.

title: The Pyrenees
description: To the Editor: "Where Heretics Fought and Lost," made readers aware of a part of France that has enchanted me for years. Each trip I make to Fanjeaux reveals more of the region's beauty and fascinating history. Although I myself have encouraged others to visit this area, I sometimes wonder if an increase of tourists will spoil its charm.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: GUILTY AS SIN By Tami Hoag. Bantam, $21.95.

title: Harry Wald, Ex-Head of Casino And Trade Group, Is Dead at 71
description: Harry Wald, a former president of Caesars Palace, a casino-resort on the Las Vegas strip, who also served several years as president of the Nevada Resort Association, died on Tuesday at the Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington. He was 71.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about high school counselors who visit colleges to help prospective students misstated the name of an institution in Bristol, R.I. It is Roger Williams University, not Roger Williams College.

title: FRUGAL TRAVELER;On the Big Island: Hawaii, Naturally
description: I WASN'T exactly overjoyed by the time I reached Hawaii in late March, partly because the cheapest round-trip air fare I could find (from a consolidator called Cheap Tickets) cost $584. The trip from New York (on T.W.A., with a stopover in St. Louis) took 13 hours, and because I arrived in Honolulu too late to go on to the Big Island that night as planned, I spent the night at the highway-encircled Best Western Plaza Hotel near the airport (for $89), where what I remember most fondly were the free Happy Hour barbecued chicken wings at the bar.

title: Mothers Dream of a Better Life In America
description: TODAY Lillian Rivera, a Puerto Rican, will spend Mother's Day in My Sister's Place, a shelter for battered women -- her hopes and dreams for her own life in the United States shattered but her aspirations for her two daughters, Leeane, 7, and Anelee, 8, firmly intact.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER MANHATTAN;Gang Memories of Cash and Death
description: Raul Vargas was only 8 or 9 when he started training to be a boxer, setting up makeshift rings in the streets of Washington Heights and sparring with other youngsters in the neighborhood around 167th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. "I won the junior Olympics," Mr. Vargas testified last week. "And I won a Golden Gloves trophy."

title: Zambia: In Africa, Up Close and Personal
description: When I toured Keny and Tanzania in the 1980's, I found peerless viewing - except for the gridlocked hordes of my own species surrounding every lion. Last June, when I spent a little more than two weeks farther down the Great Rift Valley in Zambia, the game far outnumbered us gapers. On one unforgettable, five-day streach, my companion, Emily Fisher, and I didn't encounter a single other tourist. Here, in south central Africa, we could still track spoor untrampled by Toyota treads and fancy ourselves back in the pristine bush of Teddy Roosevelt or Ernest Hemingway. Indeed, Papa's 29-year-old grandson Sean was apprenticing there as a guide.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS;FUNDS WATCH
description: Dogs and Cash, In Equal Amounts

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Once Tiny, J & R Music World Keeps Growing and Growing

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SUNSET PARK/BAY RIDGE;Developer Seeks An Alternative To Theater Plan
description: After being bombarded by local opposition, the developer who proposed an eight-screen movie theater has agreed to shelve the project indefinitely and to discuss alternatives.

title: WEDDINGS;Pauline de Laszlo, Nikolas Kornaros
description: Pauline Marina de Laszlo, a decorative and fine arts dealer in New York, was married yesterday to Nikolas Christopher Kornaros, the president of the North State Group, an investment banking concern in New York. The Rev. James Bell performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: Ashley T. O'Brien, Philip W. Moos
description: Ashley Taliferro O'Brien, a daughter of Shannon Collins O'Brien of New Canaan, Conn., and William J. O'Brien 2d of Falls Church, Va., was married yesterday to Philip Wheadon Moos, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Moos of Short Hills, N.J. Canon Leonard Freeman performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Short Hills.

title: Italian's Call For Breakup Stirs Storm
description: Umberto Bossi, the irrepressible bad boy of Italian politics, likes nothing better than to create a stir, which is one way to look at his latest idea -- that Italy's north and south should get a divorce Czech/Slovak style.

title: WEDDINGS;Kathleen Kearns, B.J. Lombardi
description: Kathleen Marie Kearns, a daughter of Mary and Patrick J. Kearns of Hudson, Fla., was married yesterday to Berardino Joseph Lombardi, a son of Catherine Lombardi of Boston and the late Joseph Lombardi. The Rev. Vincent Sullivan performed the ceremony at St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: A GIANT IN MOTION -- Surviving Corporate Reinvention;As AT&T Reorganizes, Its Employees Regroup
description: The metamorphosis of AT&T has begun.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: TOUR;Living Dangerously
description: How many thrills can a traveler take? Extreme Adventures, a tour organizer in Broomfield, Colo., has one way to find out. Its Lifetime of Adventure in a Week tour features rafting on the Arkansas River in Colorado, a simulated dogfight in a military fighter plane, scaling cliffs in Rocky Mountain National Park, skydiving and fly fishing (more of a risk for the trout than the angler).

title: Boy's Last Wish Sets Off Animal Rights Furor
description: A cancer-stricken teen-ager's dream to go bear hunting in Alaska has brought about an unusual clash between the Make-a-Wish Foundation, which is helping the boy fulfill his dream, and animal rights groups.

title: PRO BASKETBALL PLAYOFFS;Knicks Believe, and Withstand a Garden Thriller
description: Anthony Mason, who like many of his teammates had his head shaved before the playoffs began, showed up for work yesterday with a new inscription on his scalp: "We've Got Faith."

title: Saichiro Uesugi Rights Advocate, 77
description: Saichiro Uesugi, who headed an organization that champions the rights of an outcast class in Japan, died on Friday, Japanese news organizations reported. He was 77.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;Ewing and Starks Finally Rise and Deliver
description: They are friends, and they dress side by side in the Knicks' locker room. But Patrick Ewing and John Starks had other things in common entering yesterday's playoff game against the Chicago Bulls.

title: Honor Holland, 79, Official in Ethiopia
description: Honor R. Holland, who served as a British Army officer with the future Queen in World War II and as a high Government official in Imperial Ethiopia, died last Monday in Saratoga Hospital in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. She was 79 and lived in Saratoga Springs.

title: Boston Transportation Chief Doesn't Last
description: Boston's new Transportation Commissioner was driven from office after revelations that he failed to tell City Hall about two recent parking tickets, including one for blocking a ramp for the handicapped while in town for his job interview.

title: YOUNG NEW JERSEY;Summer Salamanders, Winter Memories
description: Austin Carr-Jones is growing up amid the farms and rolling green hills of Hunterdon County, where salamanders scurry in the brook a couple of backyards from his family's house.

title: TELEVISION;Following Capt. McMurtry, Take by Take
description: ON PAPER, LARRY McMurtry can usually get the words right. Now that the nation's leading writer of westerns has turned to rendering his words on film, he is not about to let some groggy, rashly improvising actors get them wrong.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;In-Flight Gambling, But No Sky-High Bets
description: British Airways and Singapore Airlines will start testing an in-flight electronic gambling system within the next year that allows passengers to use their credit cards to play poker, blackjack, roulette and slot games at their seats.

title: The World;  When the Gun Play Kills the Kids' Play
description: WHENEVER the gun battles for control of the downtown streets of this capital grow particularly fierce, the leaders of Liberia's warring militias, like commanders anywhere, decide that the fighting is just too intense to risk the lives of their most experienced men.

title: GOLF;Davies Drives Far, Fast and to Her Own Rhythm
description: On the 18th tee at DuPont Country Club, she held both her driver and the large gallery in the palm of her hand. It was Friday, during the first round of the McDonald's L.P.G.A. Championship, and Laura Davies was playing, the way she always does, with a sort of mischievous abandon, toying with the crowd and with the course and with a golf hole that would daunt lesser players.

title: C. Speed Veal, 78, Advertising Official
description: C. Speed Veal, who helped plant the advertising slogan "Get a Piece of the Rock" in American consciousness, died May 4 at the Florence Nightingale Nursing Home in New York. He was 78.

title: Liberia War: Nation Adrift
description: When an aging cargo vessel crammed with up to 4,000 Liberian refugees limped past this city sometime Friday night on its uncertain route toward neighboring Ghana, much of the history of Liberia's catastrophic six-year civil war traveled with it.

title: DINING OUT;Cool, Crisp and Very Up-to-the-Minute
description: WE'RE having a terrible night" lamented the hostess to no one in particular. Indeed, the Bridgehampton Cafe was packed to overflowing that Saturday with grumbling diners waiting three-deep at the bar.

title: SPOTLIGHT;Apple Juice
description: For bubbly nostalgia - to escape the sex and gore - try THE LADY EVE (1941), from the director Preston Sturges at the eve of World War II. Snugly pairing Barbara Stanwyck as a card sharp and Henry Fonda as a rich dimwit, the picture has rakish style the Sturges way. "My snakes are my life," declares Fonda (an anthropologist). "What a life," drawls Stanwyck. Charles Coburn scores as her crusty con-artist dad. So does their pal, Eric Blore, in a delicious racetrack musing on how Long Island society "laps up titles like whipped cream." To start "Eve," Sturges has a bright-eyed cartoon snake - like an Eden fugitive - coyly slithering through the credits. Come right in - THURSDAY at 1 P.M. on AMC.

title: OUTDOORS;Out of the Mists, A Seal Pops Up In New York Harbor
description: In "A Winter's Tale," Mark Helprin's phantasmagorical novel of New York 100 years ago, there is a band of pirates, savages and renegades that lives in the cattail marshes of Bayonne, N.J., and subsists on the clams and oysters, lobsters and crabs, striped bass and flounder, ducks and geese that inhabit the rich Hudson River estuary.

title: IN BRIEFS;Game Council Proposes Thinning Coyotes' Ranks
description: Seventy years after coyotes were first observed in New Jersey, the State Fish and Game Council has proposed New Jersey's first coyote hunt for Feb. 1 to 17.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CHINATOWN;Need Luck? Try the Cat With the Golden Arm
description: In the relentless retailism that enlivens Chinatown, the opening of one's own store is a rite of passage that calls for a gift -- and these days, the gift of choice is a Jian Jiao Mao, or Bring Fortune Cat.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Ritz-Carlton Opens A Singapore Hotel
description: Ritz-Carlton has joined such other luxury chains as Hyatt, Mandarin Oriental and Shangri-La in expanding its presence in Asia. The 610-room Ritz-Carlton, Millenia Singapore, which opened last month, is the company's third hotel in Southeast Asia and its first in Singapore.

title: WEDDINGS;Megan C. Guder, Brian MacMeekin
description: Megan Claer Guder, a daughter of the Rev. Dr. Darrell L. Guder of Louisville, Ky., and Linda Wreede of Studio City, Calif., was married in Hollywood yesterday to Brian Alan MacMeekin, the son of Alan and Susan MacMeekin of San Luis Obispo, Calif. The bride's father, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Hollywood Presbyterian Church.

title: Teen-Ager Critically Hurt in Nightclub Brawl
description: A Manhattan teen-ager was critically injured during a fracas inside the Palladium nightclub early yesterday, and detectives said they had few clues or suspects.

title: POSTINGS: $5,000 a Month on Bleecker Street, With a Short-Term Lease; Apartments From the Deux Pierres
description: The owners of Pierre Deux Antiques -- the two Pierres who gave the fabric importing company known for its country French cottons its name -- have decided to rent out three large apartments over their West Village shop, and to furnish them with Provencal antiques and fabrics.

title: YACHT RACING;A Bid to Put High Tech on High Seas
description: An unlikely partnership of two paragons, one in sailing and the other in cyberspace, has pledged to win back the America's Cup for the United States.

title: Sharpton Hails Police in Arrest Of Two Hasidic Patrol Members
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton praised the Police Department yesterday for arresting two members of a Hasidic civilian patrol who are accused of beating a black man with a radio in Crown Heights, but Mr. Sharpton questioned the suspects' speedy release from custody by saying it had raised troubling questions of preferential treatment.

title: In Defense Of the Church Hat
description: YOU must be trying to catch God's eye in that hat," an elderly woman said to me recently in playful homage to my Sunday-go-to-church hat.

title: The State of Welfare in Italy;Where Every Day is Mother's Day
description: OVER the last five years, a high school teacher here, 38 years old, has been on the job for only a year and a half, but has drawn a salary for all but a few months. Why? The answer to this riddle, laughably simple for any Italian employer, is: The woman is a mother with two babies who has taken full advantage of every last clause in one of Europe's most generous maternity leave packages.

title: The Annual China Brawl
description: Every year about this time, a donnybrook erupts in Washington over America's relations with China. The fight was shaping up as particularly intense this election year, but thanks to an unexpected congruence of views between Bill Clinton and Bob Dole, this year's action may help produce a sensible China policy.

title: WEDDINGS;Robin E. Brady, Lawrence Mead 3d
description: Robin Elizabeth Brady, until recently a manager in the information technology department at Home Box Office in New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Lawrence Myers Mead 3d, a professor of politics at New York University. The Rev. R. Mark Glidden performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption on April 28 misstated the year of the earliest Games in Olympia, Greece. It was 776 B.C., not A.D. 776.

title: The Long Shelf Life of Medical Myths
description: IT was a rainy afternoon, and Dr. John Sergent had several arthritis patients to see. He knew they were going to mention the weather's negative effect on the pain in their joints.

title: Land of Elves and Trolls and Pretty Ponies
description: Iceland isn't foreign, it's extraterrestrial," a friend of mine once said. There is, when you come right down to it, hardly anywhere as elsewhere as Iceland: suspended in mid-Atlantic at the very fringe of the Arctic Circle, it was for centuries the ultima Thule of the known world. For many of us, it is a place visited but never seen, a mythical place where one refuled on the way to somewhere else.

title: Flight Patterns
description: THE WONDER BOOK OF THE AIR By Cynthia Shearer. 305 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $24. THE start of Cynthia Shearer's first novel comes as a great surprise. Unlike most debut fiction, which often seems tentative and well-behaved, "The Wonder Book of the Air" is fearless and hearty.

title: VICTORY OR DECEIT? -- A special report.;Bribes and Publicity Mark Fall of Mexican Drug Lord
description: Juan Garcia Abrego was among the first Mexican drug lords to forge ties to the Cali cartel in Colombia, helping to transform Mexico's drug business from a backwoods marijuana operation into a $4-billion-a-year industry supplying Americans with tons of cocaine.

title: Minimum-Pay Rise Could Have Vast Effects on the Northeast
description: If Congress approves the new minimum wage proposed by President Clinton, the increase to $5.15 an hour will have powerful effects on the New York region: a mixed bag of consequences reaching far beyond a simple 90-cent raise for workers.

title: Correction
description: A listing of biographical information for the authors represented in the centennial issue on April 14 omitted part of the real name of the artist Grandma Moses. It was Anna Mary Robertson Moses, not Anna Mary Robertson.

title: WEDDINGS;Elizabeth Eubank, Randall P. Stern
description: Elizabeth Ritchie Eubank, a fashion consultant in New York for Harvey Nichols of London, was married yesterday to Randall Peter Stern, a managing director at Burnham Securities, an investment company in New York. The Rev. Dr. Kenneth Ruge, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the Sunningdale Country Club in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Loans Help Even the Smallest Businesses
description: FIVE years ago, when Fransisco Mejias opened his Los Andes Bakery in North Tarrytown, the first few hours were devastating.

title: Science Fiction
description: One good way to take the pulse of modern science fiction is to read the annual collections of stories nominated for Nebula Awards by members of the Science-Fiction and Fantasy Writers of America. Like its predecessors, NEBULA AWARDS 30 (Harcourt Brace, cloth, $25; paper, $13) includes the award winners from the previous year as well as a generous selection of runners-up, chosen by the science fiction author and anthologist Pamela Sargent.

title: WEDDINGS;Susan Paolillo, Steven L. Brown
description: Susan Ann Paolillo, an associate at the New York law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, was married yesterday to Steven Lavern Brown, a lawyer at Morgan Stanley & Company, the New York investment bank. The Rev. Louis Mazza, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Immaculate Conception Church in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Cuttings;A Garden With 40 Years of Character
description: In these days of the instant garden, it's deeply peaceful to wander through one that has evolved over 40 years.

title: ON THE MAP;At Twin Lights, Keeping Memories of Whale Oil Burning
description: It used to be that a lighthouse keeper would spend most of his day lugging 80-pound drums of sperm whale oil up a narrow, winding staircase. And then he had to fight off sleep all night to keep the light burning.

title: Chocolate, Vanilla and Rose Petal;Nice
description: When I contemplate ice cream heaven in France, I imagine strolling through the narrow, winding streets of old Nice, where the crisp white awnings and pale green shutters of Fenocchio greet me like a cool breeze. This shop, on the sprawling Place Rossetti, offers 75 flavors of sorbet and ice cream, each handmade and based on the freshest ingredients of the Riviera.

title: Crimes of Attachment
description: Mother Love/Mother Hate The Power of Maternal Ambivalence. By Rozsika Parker. 299 pp. New York: Basic Books. $26. MotherGuilt How Our Culture Blames Mothers for What's Wrong With Society. By Diane Eyer. 317 pp. New York: Times Books/Random House. $25.

title: Chocolate, Vanilla and Rose Petal;Moscow
description: There are bars, pubs, casinos, fancy restaurants and even a few outdoor cafes in Moscow, but ice cream remains a delicacy of the street. On crowded intersections, outside subway stations and in Gorky Park, fierce-looking vendors sell pale ice cream melting into stiff, papery cones.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MANHATTAN UP CLOSE;Foes Readying A New Attack On Helicopters
description: The air war between helicopter operators and Manhattan residents is likely to heat up as the city gets set to pick a new operator for Manhattan's busiest heliport, at 34th Street and the East River.

title: VOWS;Kate Blow, Kevin McGloon
description: KATE BLOW and Kevin McGloon live in Bethesda, Md., in a neighborhood on the Potomac River that's filled with kayakers, mountain bikers, environmentalists and overgrown rather than manicured yards.

title: SOAPBOX;Dutch Treat for Polluters
description: SHORTLY after she took office, Governor Whitman declared that New Jersey was "open for business." And by that, it turned out, she largely meant finding ways to reduce the regulatory burden placed on businesses by environmental laws that are among the nation's toughest.

title: LESSONS;You've Got to Be Carefully Taught: How to Be a Parent, in Classes Around the State
description: JUST as somebody who wants to lose weight can choose between Weight Watchers and aerobics class, so too are there options for parents whose children are writing on the walls, torturing the cat or simply sulking.

title: The Pyrenees
description: To the Editor: In response to Jason Goodwin's "Where Heretics Fought and Lost" (April 14), about the route of the Cathars in southwest France, I would like to add some comments based on a trip two years ago.

title: Three Girls, Suburban Summer
description: WHEN Susan Buzaid was a little girl in New Milford, every summer her best friend, Tammy Schultz, had a visitor from New York City. The three girls would run through the grass, swim and picnic, sit and talk together, for hours at a time.

title: The View From: North Guilford;A Farm Unchanged Since the 19th Century
description: NORTH of Route 80 in Guilford, hay fields still envelop hills and stretch across valleys. Cows graze and gnarly sugar maples line the roads. The Congregational and Episcopal Churches sit side by side on a hilltop. In spite of an occasional satellite disk or split-level house, one can still imagine oneself in another century.

title: ENCOUNTER;Appreciating Beauty of Time and Place Translated Into Color
description: WHAT is beauty? Is it inner or outer?

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: To Err Is Human
description: We are, after all, only human. So from time to time we do stupid things. That can be pretty harmless at home, but what if you're at work? Maybe you almost operated on the left leg instead of the injured right one. Or, during an audit, you carried the 1, when it should have been a 2. Or you just said something so inappropriate that your business meeting came to a silent halt. Send your story to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Single Mothers, by Choice, On the Increase
description: SHEILA MORRISSEY had always assumed that she would be married and have a family. But by her mid-30's, when she realized that marriage was not in her immediate future, she decided to become a mother.

title: Dole Depicts Himself as Tough on Crime
description: Although the number of murders committed across America has dropped, Bob Dole said today that the country was still not safe because of the liberal oratory and inaction of President Clinton.

title: WEDDINGS;Joan Friedenberg, Jonathan Salant
description: Joan M. Friedenberg, the editor of the Internet site for "The Newshour With Jim Lehrer" in Arlington, Va., is to be married today to Jonathan D. Salant, a political reporter for Congressional Quarterly in Washington. Rabbi Avis D. Miller is to perform the ceremony at Adas Israel Congregation in Washington.

title: WEDDINGS;Shazneen Keyamanesh, E.C. Eisner
description: Dr. Shazneen Jal Keyamanesh, an internist, was married yesterday to Edward Cole Eisner, a Ph.D. candidate in applied physics at Columbia University. The Rev. Cornelius Tarplee, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Madison Hotel in Convent Station, N.J.

title: WEDDINGS;Jennifer Tindall, Timothy Adams
description: Jennifer Lee Tindall, a special events coordinator at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, was married yesterday to Timothy Dees Adams, the managing director of the G-7 Group, a private political and economic consulting firm in Washington. The Rev. Dr. Betty C. Adam, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony at Christ Church Cathedral in Houston.

title: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;Lasorda, the Master Motivator, Will Say Anything That Works
description: This is where Tommy Lasorda earns his million-dollar salary. He can't hit for Raul Mondesi and Eric Karros, but he can talk a good enough game to nudge them out of their seasonlong slumps and insure that their teammates don't give up in the face of totally unexpected adversity.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDTOWN;In Guise of Giver, She Takes
description: If it were a Perry Mason mystery, it would be called the Case of the Charity Chiseler.

title: WEDDINGS;Elizabeth Radin, Gary L. Herman
description: Elizabeth Anne Radin, the daughter of Nancy Radin Tarnoff of New York and the late Ivan E. Radin, was married on Thursday to Gary Lawrence Herman, a son of Lorraine Herman of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Harry Herman. Rabbi David M. Posner officiated at the Harmonie Club in New York.

title: DINING OUT;In South Salem, Splendor in Any Season
description: LE CHATEAU is a grand destination in any season, but our favorite time of year for visiting this Tudor-style mansion is right now, in the wake of daylight saving time, which allows longer looks at the verdant Hudson Valley landscape. These days the kitchen is under the spell of Claude Moreau, whose delicious influence can be enjoyed in subtler, lighter preparations and in colorful, more dramatic presentations.

title: Flight of Fancy
description: I WAS AMELIA EARHART By Jane Mendelsohn. 148 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.

title: Corrections
description: Charts last Sunday with an article about gasoline prices misstated the average number of miles driven per person in 1960 and 1965 and the average number of gallons of gasoline used per person in 1960. Miles per person were 3,357 in 1960 and 3,833 in 1965. Gasoline consumption in 1960 was 237 gallons per person.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GREENWICH VILLAGE;Five Oaks Faces Swan Song
description: For several generations of would-be crooners, the Five Oaks piano bar has been a conservatory of sorts, where even the melodically challenged can grab the microphone and shamelessly belt out an Ethel Merman show tune. In a city that thrives on change, the smoke-filled subterranean cafe on Grove and Bleecker Streets has stood its ground for five decades, greeting an unlikely mix of drag queens, first-date couples and Broadway luminaries mingling and singing without timidity.

title: WEDDINGS;Elizabeth Takiff, Joshua Scheinfeld
description: Elizabeth Ida Takiff, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sanford E. Takiff of Glencoe, Ill., is to be married today to Joshua Baruch Scheinfeld, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Scheinfeld of New York. Rabbi Irving Greenberg is to officiate at the Four Seasons in Chicago. The bridegroom's father, a lawyer in New York who is also an ordained rabbi, is to take part in the ceremony.

title: A Time Capsule: Artworks in the School
description: Last week, Gov. George E. Pataki called for a halt to buying art for new New York City schools, saying the $11.9 million spent in the last five-year plan, from 1990 to 1994, would be better spent on repairs. Mr. Pataki vowed to introduce legislation exempting schools from a 1989 City Charter provision requiring 1 percent of the budget for all public construction and major reconstruction projects be set aside for art. Eight new schools in the current five-year plan would be affected, for which $400,000 has been earmarked, said Michele Cohen, director of the Board of Education's art program. From 1990 to 1994, she said, with 39 new buildings, the program was responsible for the most ambitious art drive since the WPA decorated a Depression-era city.

title: Beef Prices for Ranchers Are at a 10-Year Low
description: As the barbecue season unfolds across America, the low-priced steaks sizzling on backyard grills are the despair of producers at the opposite end of the food chain, the nation's ranchers.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY;Hotels Are Changing Food-Service Recipe
description: GUESTS at the Mansfield, a 129-room hotel at 12 West 44th Street that reopened last month, can get a free breakfast buffet every morning and a free after-theater dessert buffet each night. They can help themselves to free cappuccino in the lobby all day. But if they want to buy themselves a meal, they have to go elsewhere. And the closest they will come to room service is calling a local restaurant that will deliver.

title: 11 College Students Get Churchill Grants
description: Eleven American college students have been awarded scholarships by the Winston Churchill Foundation for graduate study in engineering, mathematics and the sciences at Churchill College, Cambridge University.

title: Chocolate, Vanilla and Rose Petal;Tokyo
description: It takes only 20 minutes by train from mid-town Tokyo to reach Kichijoji, a pleasant suburb with trendy shops, an outdoor market and, nearby, the Inokashira park and zoo. An additional enticement is Sakura Chaya, a stylish basement restaurant close to the railway station that specializes in unusual confections.

title: New Leader For Church That Shares Mormon Roots
description: As one of America's most newly minted spiritual leaders, W. Grant McMurray holds the distinctive title of "prophet," and declares a desire to foster a religious dialogue about global peace. But in a time of sweeping changes within the church he leads, Mr. McMurray's most striking feature may be that his last name is not Smith.

title: Sports of The Times;Knicks Take Their Shot And Survive
description: THE coach was out. He took a shot across the forehead and slid noiselessly to the floor. This was not Friday night boxing at the Garden, it was Saturday afternoon with the Knicks and the Bulls and the refs.

title: Better Not to Know
description: An Un-American Childhood By Ann Kimmage. Illustrated. 260 pp. Athens: The University of Georgia Press. $29.95.

title: Chocolate, Vanilla and Rose Petal;Seattle
description: Leave it to Seattle, the source of so many coffee missionaries, to be developing its own little ice cream culture based on the Italian gelateria. But the trend-aversive should take note: Procopio, halfway up the hill between the Seattle waterfront and the Pike Place Market, was serving gelato well before it became fashionable.

title: Professor Warren's Disciple
description: I first saw Austin Warren one night in the winter of 1953, when he was a visiting professor at N.Y.U., teaching a class for graduate students in the novels of Henry James. The room was a mess of ground-out cigarette butts. Students had heard Warren was good, and every seat was taken 15 minutes before class started. Some students were sitting on the floor. Warren arrived about 15 minutes late, wearing a black suit and vest. He went to the front and faced us and said in a strong voice, while stabbing at the floor with his cane: "Henry James lived here. He walked these streets in Washington Square." As Warren spoke, he smiled with a sort of fierce exultation, and the class was under way. He read some sentences aloud from James's novel "Washington Square," and told us to notice the adverbs. Warren didn't mangle a sentence with analysis, but rather urged us to "get it," and savor the richness of Jamesian implication. He seemed to introduce us, at a very high level, to what might be called literary experience, and in his class it seemed as important or meaningful as religious experience.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Mitsubishi Eclipse Spyder;A Playpen for the Inner Child, But No Place for Adult Baggage
description: YOU'LL forgive me if I sit here gingerly, tap-tapping gently on the keys. See, it's my aching back. My 2-year-old grandson is coming from Germany for a visit, and he needs a sandbox. I've been lugging sand, and, well, I'm getting ahead of myself.

title: New Litters Swell Yellowstone Wolf Counts
description: Around Yellowstone National Park, five wolf dens are alive with new litters, leading biologists to predict that the wolf packs introduced into the park from Canada during the last year and a half will thrive on their own, without more imports.

title: THEATER;Nuns Who Make People Laugh
description: WHY should Dan Goggin care about the conde scenders who say no to "Nunsense"? Or more precisely, "The Nunsenses" -- I, II and III?

title: Sydne J. Didier, John C. Urschel
description: Sydne Jennifer Didier, the daughter of Eileen Newman of New York and Marshall Didier of Huntington, L.I., was married yesterday to John Charles Urschel, the son of Margaret Urschel of San Antonio. The Rev. Tom Fontana, a minister of the American Fellowship Church, officiated at the Galittoire Bed and Breakfast on Whidbey Island, Wash.

title: AIDS and H.I.V. New Subjects for Peer Counselors in High School
description: AT Great Neck North High School seven students presented a skit for a ninth-grade health class. Each student played a different part of the body's immune system, demonstrating reactions to a cold and then to H.I.V. After the skit the students led a discussion.

title: Living on Mother's Prayer
description: In my play "Seven Guitars," near the end of the second act as the characters are preparing to go to the Mother's Day dance at the local blues club, Red Carter is offered his choice of a red or white carnation that Vera has made out of crepe paper. He replies: "I need me a red flower. My mother's still living. Even as I know it got to come to the day I wear a white flower, I hope it ain't no time soon."

title: Peter Gladke, 74, TV Choreographer
description: Peter Gladke, a dancer and choreographer who worked closely with June Taylor, the television choreographer, died last Sunday at a family birthday party at a relative's home in Yonkers. He was 74 and had homes in Manhattan and Miami.

title: SCHOOLS;Tapping Into the Many Ways Children Think and Learn
description: Debbie Lieberman was teaching vocabulary words to her second graders in the same old way -- with blackboard and chalk -- when inspiration struck. The word hustle was on the list, and Ms. Lieberman happened to have a recording of "The Hustle," a disco anthem from the 1970's, on hand. She popped it into a tape player, roused the 7-year-olds from their seats and showed them the moves.

title: PREGNANCY, UNSEATED
description: Your recent spate of letters on Lisa Schiffren's Lives column, "Pregnancy, Unseated" (March 24), reminded me of an incident that happened five years ago. I was a passenger on a crowded city bus in Moscow. A woman carrying a small child and a plastic shopping bag boarded the bus. She was standing near me, so I offered her my seat. She declined my offer but, to my surprise, placed her little girl on my lap. When we reached the Yugo Zapadnaya terminal, she thanked me and took her child.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on April 7 with the What's Doing column, about Chicago, misstated the city's taxi fares. A letter from an official of the Yellow Cab Company, dated April 8 and initially misdirected at the Times, points out that the initial charge is $1.50, not $4, and that the charge per mile is $1.20, not $1.50.

title: VIEWS;For 63 Years, He's Delivered
description: At 2:30 A.M., James Capobianco is already on his way to the Newark Farmers Market, ready to buy today's fresh produce. As he passes Newark Airport, he hears a familiar, reassuring sound: the roar of jet engines.

title: VOICES: FROM THE DESK OF;A Gift From Mom In Her New Career
description: WHEN I was finishing college in the late 70's, the women's liberation movement was in full gear, and many male-centered careers were genuinely beginning to open up to women. My generation had the option of entering the world of business, law, medicine or, indeed, the more traditional women's fields. Always the opportunist, I chose business.

title: Perspective;Sad Refrain of Schott's Rhythm and Blues
description: Imagine a big old drum left out in the rain, wood warping, skin cracking, its booming timbre reduced to nagging thuds. Every so often, someone who is bored or mischievous, someone who wants to raise a ruckus or get attention, wanders by, picks up a drumstick and pounds the drum. Nobody thinks it's music, but it always gets a laugh or a growl to shut up.

title: A LA CARTE;Joining a Line of Predictable Italian Spots
description: MANNINO'S, in Commack, is not an unusual restaurant, at least not on Long Island. Tiny, mid-priced, predictable Italian storefronts, like this one that is half white-tablecloth restaurant and half pizzeria, are commonplace. But some are better than others, and Mannino's is a good one, with its super salads and hefty bowls of often hearty, boldly seasoned Italian standards.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND;Down Home and Down to Earth in East Hampton
description: BACK when East Hampton was just folks, a folk singer named Tom Paxton came to town. He and his wife, Midge, decided to spend the summer of '66 by the shore, away from Greenwich Village and the coffeehouses where Mr. Paxton was making $10 a night singing songs of conscience.

title: WEDDINGS;Ellen M. Soell, Peter C. Forlenza
description: Ellen Maria Soell, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Helmut G. Soell of Manchester, Conn., was married yesterday to Peter C. Forlenza, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Forlenza of Sea Girt, N.J. The Rev. Daniel Degnan performed the ceremony at St. Marks Roman Catholic Church in Sea Girt.

title: WEDDINGS;Kathleen Mara, Mark Morehouse
description: Kathleen Mary Mara, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wellington T. Mara of Rye, N.Y., was married on Friday to Mark Warren Morehouse, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Morehouse of Helena, Mont. The Rev. Mark Connolly performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye.

title: WEDDINGS;Sarah S. Glenn, R.B. Armstrong
description: Sarah Saunders Glenn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Glenn of Atlanta, was married yesterday to Roderick Bartholomew Armstrong, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Quine Armstrong of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Robert Reese performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St. Mark in Brunswick, Ga.

title: OUTER CITY BLUES
description: It's too bad that Prose felt compelled to exchange the "quiet country" life for the "thrill of long brisk walks along the busy streets of Manhattan." However, I'm sure it won't be long before she and her family find their way back to a nice country cottage for summer weekends -- a place, no doubt, that promises "natural beauty" and perhaps a "stunning view of the Catskill Mountains."

title: Idyll By Blue Waters
description: BLESSED with a benign Mediterranean microclimate, spectacular mountain scenery and pellucid waters, Lake Garda was already a favorite resort in Roman times. With an area of almost 143 square miles, it is Italy's largest lake, and its steady breezes make it ideal for sailing and windsurfing. However, even if you don't have (or rent) your own boat, between the end of March and the end of September you can easily get around on the water on the network of public ferries.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: RED HOOK;On the Waterfront, a Snug Harbor for Artists (For Now)
description: When I come here," Kim Faiella says, looking out across the Red Hook harbor, "I feel like I'm in Edward Hopper-land."

title: A CELEBRATION OF 100 YEARS
description: I enjoyed "A Celebration of 100 Years" (April 14) and the contributions made by so many fine writers. However, I was dismayed not to find Walter Sullivan's name on the list. He was certainly an important contributor and his death is a great loss for us all.

title: Moynihan Has Doubts About Stadium Plan
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan said yesterday that it was unlikely that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's dream of a billion-dollar replacement for Yankee Stadium on the West Side of Manhattan will ever be more than a dream.

description: HOW to make an American hooked rug: pull strips of dyed wool or cotton through the weave of a piece of burlap (occasionally cotton) with a special hook. Of course a design or drawing will be outlined on the burlap. It's a process akin to embroidery.

title: Dismissal At Okeanos Mirrors a Split
description: SINCE 1977, Sam Sadove had been aiding stranded seals and sea turtles, leading whale watches from Montauk and making his name seemingly inseparable from the group he co-founded in 1979, the Okeanos Ocean Research Foundation.

title: WEDDINGS;Anna M. Gurvitch, Mark E. Kahn
description: Anna Mikhailovna Gurvitch, the daughter of Svetlana McDonough of New York and Dr. Michael Gurvitch of Stony Brook, L.I., was married last evening to Mark Edward Kahn, a son of Barbro Kahn and Dr. Melvin Kahn of New York. Rabbi Gary M. Bretton-Granatoor performed the ceremony at the University Club in New York.

title: Warhol Decision Draws Conflict-of-Interest Accusations
description: A top New York State appeals judge handed a resounding victory to the Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts in February, even going so far as to scold a lower court judge for refusing to disqualify herself from the case because of a possible conflict of interest.

title: WEDDINGS;Catherine Beldotti, Michael Donlan
description: Catherine Joan Beldotti, the daugher of Mr. and Mrs. David Beldotti of Upper Montclair, N.J., was married yesterday to Michael Carty Donlan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Donlan of Park Ridge, Ill. The Rev. J. Eloise Hally, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony in the Goddard Chapel at Tufts University in Medford, Mass.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LITTLE ITALY;The Tranquil Malling of Mulberry St.
description: Finding consensus among Little Italy's residents and merchants is no small feat. Through three mayoral administrations, plans to create a pedestrian mall on Mulberry Street have crumbled under a cacophony of clashing opinions. But a weekend ban on cars and trucks from the heart of Little Italy is set to begin over Memorial Day.

title: Mama's Girl
description: My mother never talked to me about boys. When I got my period, she handed me a box of Kotex and made me a cup of tea. When I was 8, she'd asked me if I knew where babies came from. I'd told her yes, I'd read about it in a book. That was our last conversation on the topic.

title: JERSEY;A Mother Who's One in a Million
description: IT was the second week of May, so the weather should have been glorious. But it was so cold and wet last Monday that a lot of people stayed home. By 11 A.M., a crowd of only 2,000 -- about a quarter of the turnout that had been expected -- waited in the chilly mist outside St Paul's A.M.E. Zion Church in Trenton for the march to the State House to begin.

description: Correction Appended

title: On Anesthesia For Dental Patients
description: Unfortunately in Dr. Epstein's zeal to receive recognition several misconceptions were fostered.

title: Beginning Early To Make Problems Seem Like Fun
description: A YOUNG boy with a careworn face slapped his paint-coated hand onto a pastiche of colored paper, feathers, glitter and glue. Around him, others in his Head Start class made their own pictures in much the same way.

title: MAKING IT WORK;A Guru Of Little League
description: THERE had been some kind of fight between the umpire and the father. It was 9:30 A.M. on a damp Saturday in May. No one on the ball field in southwest Central Park would say what had happened but words had been exchanged, maybe a push. Then Bobby Hoffman, a commanding presence in black shorts and yellow windbreaker, stepped in.

description: SCARLET WOMEN By J. D. Christilian. Donald I. Fine, $22.95.

description: AFTER selling Mondrian in Manhattan in April 1990, Dennis Foy, one of the leading chefs and restaurateurs in New Jersey, opened Dennis Foy's Townsquare with his partner, Paul Butler.

description: When Rupert Murdoch said it was a good idea, the other network television honchos scoffed. When Walter Cronkite said so, they listened.

description: IT has been called the hardest of jobs, and the easiest, or at least the one that comes most naturally. Motherhood -- being celebrated today with gifts and flowers and breakfast in bed -- can be surprisingly simple or dauntingly complex, say those who are mothers.

title: Bosnian Serbs Find Peace Is Full of Conspiracies
description: In the fading afternoon light, a group of former soldiers sat at a table in a bar along the rutted street that runs through the center of this Bosnian Serb stronghold.

title: Blue Sky, California
description: My father and I are together in the sky. I am 8 and he has taken me up in the Piper Cherokee, a four-seat, single-prop, family sedan of an airplane he rents once in a while. My father's idea is that we will fly over our house and get a look at it from a new vantage point, from high above the Santa Clara Valley on a clear summer morning. We will fly over at an agreed-upon time and my mother will stand in our backyard and wave.

title: WEDDINGS;Elizabeth Perates, Thomas Livaccari
description: Elizabeth Anne Perates, an organizer of conferences on technology and the media, and Thomas Joseph Livaccari, the publisher of Word and other electronic magazines on the Internet, were married yesterday in Providence, R.I. The Rev. John Rainone performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Heartbreak Hotel
description: MARTIN DRESSLER The Tale of an American Dreamer. By Steven Millhauser. 294 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $24.

title: Living in Tongues
description: The first thing you have to understand about my childhood is that it mostly took place in another language. I was raised speaking French, and did not begin learning English until I was nearly 7 years old. Even after that, French continued to be the language I spoke at home with my parents. (I still speak only French with them to this day.) This fact inevitably affects my recall and evocation of my childhood, since I am writing and primarily thinking in English. There are states of mind, even people and events, that seem inaccessible in English, since they are defined by the character of the language through which I perceived them. My second language has turned out to be my principal tool, my means for making a living, and it lies close to the core of my self-definition. My first language, however, is coiled underneath, governing a more primal realm.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In: Piermont, N.Y.;The Boutiquing of a Gritty Mill Town
description: THE deck off Phyllis Lopatkin's master bedroom has a panoramic view of the Hudson River and the Tappan Zee Bridge in the distance. "I like to put mirrors up on the back walls, opposite the windows, so everywhere I look I can see water," Ms. Lopatkin said.

title: Two Budgets, Many Distinctions
description: Viewed purely in dollars-and-cents terms, the six-year plans to balance the Federal budget unwrapped by President Clinton in March and by the Republican Congress on Wednesday have edged toward a compromise. The trouble with this is that a compromise has long been unlikely, and is getting more so as the Presidential campaign heats up.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-10

title: THEATER;On Stages Around The Nation
description: The listings in this section are selective, with emphasis on events in the Northeast, and programs are subject to change. More information on specific events is available through individual ticket offices.

title: OUT OF ORDER;A Man for All Seasons (Except Spring)
description: SPRING has already gone on far too long. It was announced on March 20, when we were still deep in snow and ice. It arrived (metereologically speaking) on April 20, and is scheduled to drag on until the official start of summer on June 20, by which time we will be gasping under the air-conditioners.

title: Turning Old Offices Into New Condo Apartments
description: TWO new residential projects are changing the face of this city's historic Loop business district and its environs while pointing up how eager many cities are to seek out alternative uses for obsolete office buildings.

title: Donald T. Campbell, Master of Many Disciplines, Dies at 79
description: Donald T. Campbell, a nimble-minded social scientist who left his mark on half a dozen disciplines and helped revolutionize the fundamental principles of scientific inquiry common to them all, died on Monday in a hospital near his home in Bethlehem, Pa. He was 79.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;In San Francisco, An Aquarium at the Pier
description: A 400-foot-long transparent tunnel submerged in 16 feet of water is the main attraction at Underwater World, which opened last month at San Francisco's Pier 39 tourist complex. Visitors moving through the tunnel get close-up views of marine life swimming and crawling overhead and on either side. The aquarium expects to attract almost two million people this year.

title: THE GREAT OUTDOORS;Newark Flight Paths Change, but All Isn't Quiet Below
description: When Frank Stanski rides his bicycle down rustic, sleepy roads in western New Jersey, he usually hears things like crickets and frogs, the wind in the trees and the crackle of bubbling tar. But in the last couple of weeks, he has had to adjust to a new, more frequent sound: airplanes.

title: Double Standard?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;Surprise! Wregget Is Working Wonders in Goal
description: PITTSBURGH, May 11

title: Hong Kong Before The British
description: A NARROW causeway leads away from the village of Tai O on Lantau Island across a shallow green bay to the temple of Hua Wong. There, on a terrace overlooking the water, feathery tamarisk trees shelter a pair of stone benches, creating thin shade from the pale spring sunlight in front of the cluster of gray, stuccoed halls, each with its own tiled roof and roof ridge alive with glazed ceramic dragons, lions, fish and phoenixes. Water laps at the seawall; a scruffy orange cat sleeps on the sun-warmed stone of the temple loggia.

title: WEDDINGS;Amy H. Dalton, William Fitzgerald
description: Amy Hamner Dalton, a daughter of Nancy Dalton and James Dalton, both of Brentwood, Tenn., was married yesterday to William Aloysius Fitzgerald, a son of William and Penelope Fitzgerald of Haverford, Pa. Vernon Jackson, a justice of the peace in West Bay on Grand Cayman Island, officiated at the Grand Old House, a restaurant near Georgetown on Grand Cayman.

description: Emily Jane Feffer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Feffer of New York, was married last evening to William Stewart Kogan, a son of Barbara Kogan of New York and the late George Kogan. Rabbi David Greenberg officiated at the United Nations Plaza Hyatt Hotel.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 3/ You'd think they were giving away free Chanel bags with every share of stock by the way investors are snapping up shares in Loehmann's, the retailer. By Doreen Hemlock.

title: The Great Mutiny
description: OUR BONES ARE SCATTERED The Cawnpore Massacres and the Indian Mutiny of 1857. By Andrew Ward. Illustrated. 703 pp. New York: A John Macrae Book/ Henry Holt & Company. $30.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: GETTING AWAY WITH MURDER Weapons for the War Against Domestic Violence. By Raoul Felder and Barbara Victor. Simon & Schuster, $22.

title: ARTS/ARTIFACTS;The Timeless Glory of High Wheels and Handlebars
description: AS A BICYCLE AFICIONADO, Pryor Dodge is part magpie, part scholar. He acquires almost anything emblazoned with images of two-wheelers, from posters and dance cards to toys, games and ice cream molds. He also collects bicycles made mostly between 1820 and 1920, a period when the bicycle evolved from a primitive toy to a highly sophisticated mechanism that influenced the development of the automobile and airplane.

title: Oops! 2 Inmates Steal Jeep of Trusting Sheriff
description: Two inmates in the Wise County Jail drove off with the sheriff's 1995 Jeep Grand Cherokee this week while washing patrol cars as part of a work program here.

title: In the Region/New Jersey;Another Step in Addressing State's Housing Needs
description: AN ongoing and increasingly difficult challenge to this state is how to bolster the supply of housing affordable to low- and moderate-income families.

title: DINING OUT;French Food, Pale Walls and Fieldstone
description: TUCKED into the stone cellar of a 200-year-old building is Chez Noue, the latest of several restaurants to occupy an intimate, romantic space that was once a blacksmith's shop. We hope Chez Noue stays a long time, for it offers Ridgefield a cafe with moderate prices and knowledgably prepared French food.

title: Alaska: The Chilly Charms of Point Barrow
description: Because most of the passenger compartment had been sealed off as a cargo hold for supplies going to Prudhoe Bay, the handful of passengers disembarking at Barrow, Alaska - two Eskimo families, a package-tour group of uneasy Midwesterners wearing "A Day at the Top" buttons on their sweaters and us - had to leave the plane through the exit ramp near the tail. At the bottom, we took our first good look around.

title: HOME CLINIC;Shadows and Subtleties of Lighting
description: LIGHTING in the home serves the obvious purpose of illuminating the interior to see what is occurring. It also performs less obvious functions. It can improve safety, create atmosphere and even influence emotions.

title: Florida's Feast of Tiffany
description: Near Orlando, the gracious old town of Winter Park is home to a treasury of glowing glass.

title: MAY 5-11;A New Political Order Takes Shape in South Africa
description: South Africa added two major elements last week to its new political order, rounding out the nonracial democracy it has been building through years of transition and negotiation.

title: Op-Ed Hothead?
description: To the Editor:

title: Beirut Revisited: A Traveler's Tale
description: AS the plane approaches Beirut I think nervously, "What will it be like?" Will I even recognize the glamorous, cosmopolitan city I remember from 25 years before? It is 10 o'clock at night. I look down and see the lights of the corniche snaking around the edge of the city, but something's wrong: Beirut isn't bright enough. As we dip lower toward the southern suburbs I discover the reason for this. Entire city blocks have been leveled; others contain only a couple of dark and abandoned high-rises and few lighted hovels. I am not as shocked by this as perhaps I should be. After all, New York has contrived similar effects in Harlem and the Bronx without the excuse of 15 years of savage, internecine conflict, involving a bewildering variety of Muslim and Christian factions, murderous private militias and the armies of Syria and Israel. (It ended only in 1990.)

description: In 1969, my father was arrested for his part in organizing an antiwar protest in Boston and was sentenced to a two-year prison term. (He and my mother had split up a few years earlier, but they had remained close, sharing the child-rearing duties and trying to forge a new kind of divorce, one that was in keeping with their progressive politics.) It would take me many ywars before I would understand the times in which this event took place. I'm still trying, and failing, to understand. But before I knew anything of politics, or war, or social movements, I knew my father's enveloping presence. He was more than six feet tall, with huge hands and a laugh that rippled through his chest when he carried me. He crooned me to sleep, twirled me in his arms, and then -- without warning -- he was gone.

title: DANCE;Outside New York, But Still At the Center
description: DANCE ALWAYS CROWDS ITS WAY INTO New York City in the summer. And this year, in addition to the usual seasons of ballet at the New York State Theater and the Metropolitan Opera House, there will be an adventurous selection of dance in the new Lincoln Center Festival. Yet, as ever, dance lovers can feel artistically at the heart of things should they head to two long-established festivals away from the urban ferment: the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in the Berkshire Hills of Massachusetts and the American Dance Festival at Duke University in Durham, N.C.

description: Fancy takeout and catering establishments with fancy French names dot the landscape of up-market Bergen County the way T-shirt and taffy shops dominate the boardwalk at the shore. But the memoirist and the food writer approach their common subject differently. Whereas the food writer starts with the taste and character of, say, a peach and moves on to the telling anecdote, the literary type reverses the process, beginning with a memory.

title: Japanese Schindler' and 2,100 Visas for Jews
description: GROWING up in Manhattan as the child of Holocaust survivors, Dr. Anna S. Kadish often heard the haunting story of her family's escape from Poland in 1939, three years before she was born. Among those who made life, by turns, harrowing and sweet for the family was a hero she knew only as a "mystical Japanese person," who signed visas for her desperate parents once they had crossed into Lithuania.

Engines have grown more sophisticated in the 75 years since troopers and motor vehicles became a twosome, but the basics are still the basics -- parts of this densely packed state sometimes seem to be overlaid with nothing but highways, perfect for getaways.

description: George Bush was the first American President to try to convince China to stop pirating American movies, software and videos and selling them for a fraction of their value around Asia. Then Bill Clinton tried, threatening sanctions if China didn't agree to close down the plants that are churning out more than 200 million fake disks a year, worth roughly $2 billion. China signed that agreement under duress last year, then largely ignored it.

She showed me how to tilt the gin bottle into the tumbler, strain the icy liquid into the martini glass and add the vermouth. "Just pass the bottle over the gin," she explained in her genteel Yankee voice as she twisted the lemon peel with her tiny hands and its oil spread across the surface of the drink. I was 8.
