title: COVER STORY;Sci-Fi Gets Ready for the Millennium
description: SCI-FI fans may have something of a philosophical problem with the movie "Doctor Who" (Fox, Tuesday at 8 P.M.). First, there's the look. "Pretty low-tech," comments the beleaguered heroine, Grace Holloway (Daphne Ashbrook), glacing around a lab lighted by candles and constructed of what look like old bridge girders. Most of all, though, it's the tone, which aficionados of current science faction on television may find, well, slightly off.

title: SPOTLIGHT;Claws and In-Laws
description: In Richard Brooks's version of Tennessee Williams's CAT ON A HOT TIN ROOF (1958), the prospective legacy of a stricken patriarch (Burl Ives) splits a Southern clan. This is a steady, vibrant adaptation of Broadway. As the focal young couple, Elizabeth Taylor and Paul Newman are even more appealing than Barbara Bel Geddes and Ben Gazzara. However, there's one dramatic loophole: Since Hollywood forbade any hint of homosexuality, Newman's moody alienation from Taylor (who looks sensational) is vaguely rooted in past hero worhsip. No wonder Ives bellows: "Something's missing here!" It's still a good picture, though it sidles when it should sizzle - THURSDAY at 10:35 A.M. on MAX.

title: When a Black Unit Battled The British
description: IT is First Rhode Island Regiment Week in the town of Yorktown, and last Tuesday night the Town Council issued a proclamation to that effect. The main observance of the 215th anniversary of the Battle of Croton Heights, however, will not take place until Memorial Day, when Linda G. Cooper, Town Supervisor, leads a parade starting at 11 A.M. from Town Hall in Yorktown Heights.

title: Plain Beautiful

title: Not Making It;We're Leaner, Meaner and Going Nowhere Faster
description: FOR years, Americans have been told to place their hopes for a better standard of living in the huge investments in automation and computers and in the tens of millions of layoffs intended to make the nation more efficient and productive. And now there is a growing acknowledgment among economists and others that this strategy has not worked.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;A Palace Renewed In Denmark
description: The newly restored Christian VII Palace in Copenhagen is being opened to visitors through Sept. 13 as part of the city's celebrations marking its designation as the cultural capital of Europe.

title: EARNING IT;A Study Links Computers to Higher Pay
description: COMPUTERS, it turns out, provide a good reason for employees and their bosses to get along at work. A study by two professors at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania has found that pay goes up for each group when the other's use of computers increases.

title: CLUB FED
description: By criticizing Alan Greenspan's attachment to free markets, Michael Lewis seemingly implies that another form of authority should be used in their place (The Capitalist: "Club Fed," April 21). Despite the imperfections of markets, I am more than willing to put my trust in their power than in the state.

title: BASEBALL;Cone Case Complicated By Armful of Unknowns And His Occupation
description: As Yankees pitcher David Cone's shoulder and leg begin to heal after surgery to repair an aneurysm in his throwing arm, the 33-year-old right-hander is wondering like everyone else whether he will eventually be able to resume his baseball career.

title: INVESTING IT;The Widest of 401(k) Options: Invest It Yourself
description: GIVEN the thousands of flavors that investments come in these days, the situation is hardly unexpected: Many workers chafe at the handful of options that their companies, carefully or not, have selected for their 401(k) retirement plans. "Why is there no bond investment in the mix?" they may ask. "And why not include this delicious foreign equity fund?"

title: ON HOCKEY: NHL PLAYOFFS;A Lemieux-and-Jagr Barrage Finishes Off the Rangers
description: A year ago in the Stanley Cup playoffs, the Rangers played the first round against an inexperienced team from the province of Quebec and the second round against a superior team from the state of Pennsylvania. After beating the Quebec Nordiques, they were routed by the Philadelphia Flyers.

title: ON THE STREET;Spring A la Prada
description: A look at how New Yorkers are wearing the clothes of the trend-setting Italian designer Miuccia Prada shows that most are mixing the pieces with other clothing -- leather jackets or jeans. Others are wearing the designs in matching ensembles, from jackets to shoes, in different colors of the same pattern, giving them a 1950's flavor. But even more eye-catching are Ms. Prada's patterns. The most popular is a soft-edge geometric, top row left, and a woven crosshatching, bottom row, in mossy green, rust and camel colorings that recall 50's Scandinavian home-decorating fabrics. This Prada look for spring has been so influential that copies of the crosshatching pattern in printed fabric, bottom row, second from right, were already being worn in March. The original woven trouser is shown next to it, third from right.

title: Corrections

title: FILM;Summer's Gnats Versus The Behemoths
description: WHEN TOM CRUISE arrives in theaters this Memorial Day weekend as the hero of Paramount's "Mission: Impossible," he will be nearly unbeatable at the box office. The combination of Mr. Cruise's star power and the built-in audience for this big-screen version of the vintage television series sounds irresistible. But as Mr. Cruise contends with terrorists and undercover agents, he will have two unexpected opponents: Heather Matarazzo and Juliette Binoche.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC;When Nature Talks, Beethoven Listens
description: IT IS THE TIME OF YEAR WHEN MUSIC comes out of hiding and takes its chances in the great outdoors. Summer festivals are at hand, and with them the buzz of flies and oboes, the scent of garlic chicken and lilies, the rustle of lilac bushes and arpeggios, the traces of spilled white wine that glint on blades of grass like morning dew.

title: The Fresh Air Fund;Baby Frogs Make Bronx Twins' Summer Special
description: Seth Congdon looks forward to three big things this summer: he's turning 9 in August, his tree fort is getting another level, and Helen and Helena Davis, 6-year-old twins who stayed with his family last summer, are returning.

title: Corrections

The agency is the Federal Department of Transportation, not the State Department of Transportation, and the conservancy hopes that the city will finance rebuilding.

title: A Bright Patch in the Economic Gloom
description: SPRING fever. It's that time of year when thoughts go to vacation plans. And whether it's because of the success of the UConn Huskies basketball teams or a global rediscovery of New England, more and more people are being attracted to Connecticut.

title: The World;The Catch Phrase Is 'Civil War'

title: Bringing Sunshine to a Boy's Life

title: OUTER CITY BLUES
description: In her Lives column, "Outer City Blues" (April 21), Francine Prose echoes the story of the country mouse and city mouse, but with some ironic twists. I am glad to hear that she and her family have moved away from the drug-infested countryside to the city -- no drug problems there! Of course, I was shocked to hear that students in junior high schools out in the country are not always serious about their studies. Again, luckily, a situation not to be encountered in New York City. Likewise, uncaring, burned-out teachers are a phenomenon not to be found in the metropolis. (Why do I have the intuition that her child's city school is not located in Bushwick or the South Bronx?) WENDY C. TURGEON St. James, L.I.

title: COPING;AIDS and the Doctor's Daughter
description: IN the middle of her Ph.D. party eight years ago, Cydelle Berlin found out that her daughter was H.I.V.-positive. Other family members could tell that something was wrong -- the two women were crying and hugging in the garden of Dr. Berlin's apartment -- but it was almost a year before most found out just how wrong. Evan Ruderman swore her mother to secrecy; she was 28 years old and it was enough for her to publicly deal with being a pioneering female construction worker without having to wear the scarlet letter of the 90's.

title: Split Between Aristide and His Successor Imperils Haiti's GoverningParty

But Southeast Asia, including the coastal zone of China, has become the world's major area of growth and development. This region is growing about three times as rapidly as the "Big Three" and the trend is likely to continue.

description: Most Americans are aware, if sometimes vaguely, that Franklin Roosevelt was stricken by polio in 1921 and was unable thereafter to stand unassisted. title: Uncle Chul Gets Rich
description: My father's youngest brother, Uncle Chul, shared the Lees' famously bad reaction to liquor, which was to turn beet-red in the face, grow dizzy and finally get sick. In spite of this, he was always happy to stay up late at family gatherings. After a few Scotches he would really loosen up, and, with the notable exception of my mother, we all appreciated his rough language and racy stories. Only when Mother came in from the kitchen would his talk soften, for he knew he had always fallen short in her eyes. If they were ever alone together, say in the kitchen, after dinner, he would use the most decorous voice in asking for a glass or a fresh bucket of ice, and even offer to help load the dishwasher or run an errand to the store.

title: YOUR HOME;Rules on Lead Paint In Co-ops
description: THE Residential Lead-Based Paint Hazard Reduction Act of 1992 -- which takes effect later this year -- is fairly straightforward as Federal regulations go. The act requires owners of most pre-1978 housing to advise prospective buyers or tenants about any known lead-based paint in the dwelling.

Responding to tough Federal mandates, American science and industry have produced cleaner cars, cleaner power plants and cleaner fuels. Still, it is now abundantly clear that the regulatory noose was not drawn tightly enough.

Loving everything from the glamorous room to the entire pool area, we did it all: worked out, lapped, saunaed, lounged, nibbled on the complimentary fruit and sipped the complimentary Evian water. Susan G. Hauser, we thank you. May your goggles never leak!

title: Books in Brief: Fiction;Mommy Weirdest
description: What William Wegman has done for his dogs, Judy Olausen, a photographer who lives in Minneapolis, has done for her mother. But while Mr. Wegman's subjects, being Weimaraners, look mostly soulful, doleful or moderately embarrassed, Vivian Olausen, a housewife now in her 70's, can personify any affect you can name. And what a game gal she is! In MOTHER (Penguin Studio, $24.95), she allows herself to be dressed up in frumpy housedresses and ratty furs, bedraggled hats and hideous wigs, and, in more than 50 deliriously funny pictures, submitted to any number of indignities. There is a program here: many of the images are a commentary on the lot of women in the 1950's, a period when, Ms. Olausen believes, depressed housewives dragged themselves to the cocktail cabinet or medicine chest for relief (see "Mother's Little Helpers," with Mother spaced out on Valium). Mrs. Olausen, on the other hand, remembers the decade as one in which she had fun pottering around the house and entertaining, and everyone drank (see "Mother as Enabler"). But while the pictures of Mother carrying a huge wooden cross through the supermarket or chained to an ironing board or, best of all, in pink baby-doll pajamas and marabou mules (pace Marabel Morgan) make a feminist point, others transcend dogma to attain an almost Monty Pythonesque lunacy. Only consider "Mommy Deer," in which Mrs. Olausen, antlered and befurred, is tied to the roof of a car. Worth noting, too, that the car is a Plymouth Volare, one of a vast number of authentic, and frequently covetable, props and artifacts that repay careful study. (Remember Ike buttons? Cookie jars in the shape of French poodles? Paint-by-numbers sets?) Pass this book around among your friends, and watch them have conniptions. Sarah Ferrell

title: Books in Brief;A Long Way From Manila
description: Where are you from?" is a question too often asked of the young, American-born Filipino women who populate M. Evelina Galang's stirring debut collection of stories, HER WILD AMERICAN SELF (Coffee House Press, paper, $12.95). Whether the person asking is a bystander at a bus stop, a school classmate wrinkling her nose at the smell of a box lunch of rice and fish, or a film director known for his sleazy attitude toward Asian women, none are satisfied when the answer turns out to be Michigan, Wisconsin or New York. But if the ignorance and insensitivity of strangers is borne with graceful yet sarcastic humor, the pressures of home -- under the zealous gaze of parents eager for their daughters to partake of the "land of opportunity" -- yield a frustrated, rebellious sadness. In "Miss Teenage Sampaguita," a visiting aunt observes her brother's tyrannical hold on her niece, who is expected to become a doctor and is deprived of everyday pleasures like the right to date or even talk on the telephone. And in "Talk to Me, Milagros," a silent child watches as her lawyer father, recently arrived from the Philippines, is reduced to working as a busboy in a diner. While a number of Ms. Galang's stories lack a certain dynamic force, all are told in an elegant, mesmerizing style. The finest, "Filming Sausage," is sharp with tension, while the brief, chantlike monologues that frame the collection are as lyrical as prayers. Abby Frucht

title: Confessing for Voyeurs;The Age of The Literary Memoir Is Now
description: It began, like any revolution, almost imperceptibly. Could it have been the tremendous success of "Darkness Visible," William Styron's memoir of his bout with suicidal depression, that opened the floodgates? Or was it "Girl, Interrupted," Susanna Kaysen's best-selling memoir of life in a mental institution? Or maybe it wasn't until Mary Karr burst on the scene last year with "The Liars' Club" that the full force of this new trend started to make itself felt. But if the monent of inception is hard to locate, the triumph of memoir is now established fact. Consider the evidence: nearly two dozen memoirs are being published this spring, with more to come, supplementing the 200 titles -- by one book review editor's estimate -- published last year. A random inventory of the galleys and review copies that have lately come across my desk: "First Comes Love," by Marion Winik, the tale of a Jewish Harvard-Law-School-bound poet from New Jersey and her marriage to a gay working-class Italian hairdresser doomed to die of AIDS (like any revolution); "The Net of Dreams," by Julie Salamon, about her parents' journey from Auschwitz to a small town in Ohio; "A Message From God in the Atomic Age," by Irene Vilar, the history of a suicide-afflicted family. (They're not all so dark: Daniel Duane's "Caught Inside," an ebullient memoir of growing up in California, is billed as "a cultural history of surfing.")

description: Algeria's President proposed constitutional reforms today, including measures to enforce separation of religion and politics in a country torn by a four-year-old rebellion by Islamic militants.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: MUSIC
description: Taming a Spiky Score Without a Conductor Orpheus Chamber Orchestra Carnegie Hall

title: K. Smith, 104; Worked for Peace And Civil Rights
description: Katharine Gladys Kaufman Smith, a philanthropist and longtime leader of civil rights and peace groups on Long Island, died on May 4 at her home in Riverdale, Md. She was 104.

title: N.B.A. PLAYOFFS;Rockets' Furious Rally Makes Sweep Interesting
description: The Seattle SuperSonics leave Texas with fingernail scratches on their backs.

title: Gas Consumers Have Met the Enemy and ...
description: At a Mobil station in this Philadelphia neighborhood, Cathy Kronmiller pulled up recently at the full-service pump to fill up with regular gas at $1.63 a gallon. The self-service pump, only a few feet away, was selling the same gas for $1.32.

title: And Here's to You, Mrs. McCalister
description: To the Editor:

title: Immigration Policy Should Reflect Concern for Environment
description: To the Editor:

title: Russia Cites Negligence in Raid by Chechens
description: The head of a Government commission investigating the ambush of a Russian military column by Chechen rebels last month said today that Russian military officials might be prosecuted for "criminal negligence" for failing to prevent the attack.

title: Sports of The Times;A Knick Era Is Captured In One Game
description: IF this was the last time in Madison Square Garden for the Knicks as we have known them, perhaps even as Patrick Ewing's team, then New York's most celebrated dysfunctional basketball family went out with its trademark rousing show and a predictably exasperating defeat.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the tentative release dates for major economic indicators this week.

title: Pataki Transit Plan Delivers for Region
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC REVIEW;From Duke Ellington, Themes for the Movies
description: Immersing oneself in the music of Duke Ellington gives the sense that he did everything that could possibly be done in jazz. His body of work, which starts in 1923 and ends in 1974, is so loaded with ideas that new movement after new movement in jazz could be sustained by continuing down avenues where he ventured for just a few blocks but then went on to something else. Mr. Ellington was restless, and it made his music fertile.

title: Richard Bennett, 89, Architect-Teacher
description: Richard Marsh Bennett, a retired architect whose projects ranged from houses of worship and campus buildings to shopping centers and a fire academy, died on May 2 at the Sherrill House in Boston. A former resident of Chicago, he was 89 and lived in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Former Chief Executive Offers Apple Encouragement and Says OldStrategy Can Still Work
description: The financially troubled Apple Computer Inc. has received a vote of confidence from its former chairman, John Sculley, who argues in an article in the current issue of a Silicon Valley magazine that the "hot-product" marketing strategy that made Apple the nation's leading personal computer maker in the late 1980's and early 1990's can still work.

title: On Street Corner Far Away, Dominican Race Is Closely Watched
description: The aged firebrands begin arriving by nightfall, armed with patriotic oaths and bushels of oratory about the virtues of the candidates in the upcoming national election, the future of the country, the wisdom of the voters.

title: Tough Talk for Israel From 3 Mideast Leaders
description: The leaders of Egypt, Jordan and the Palestinians called on Israel today to withdraw from all occupied Arab lands and to renounce what they called its "concepts of expansion, superiority and domination."

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Civil War Museum Opens
description: More than 40,000 New Jerseyans fought on both sides of the Civil War, but the state has never had a permanent Civil War museum -- until now. The Civil War and Native American Museum, with headquarters in an 18th-century farmhouse in Hamilton Township's Veteran's Park, opened Saturday with exhibits of weapons, uniforms and other war memorabilia. Vincent Mercandetti, the museum's director, said future exhibits would focus on black soldiers and the role of women in the war. The museum plans eventually to house a library and a genealogy computer, he said.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;$1.8 Million for Arts Center
description: The New Jersey Performing Arts Center moves another step toward completion today, when it is scheduled to receive a $1.8 million grant from the Federal Economic Development Administration. The money will be used to help build Theater Square, the public plaza adjacent to the center. The $165 million complex, which includes a rotunda and two theaters and will be home to the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, is about 60 percent built and is scheduled to open in October 1997, said Jerome Enis, a spokesman for the arts center. Officials said they need to raise only $5 million more to pay for the center's construction.

title: ON PRO BASKETBALL;The Bulls' Greatest Asset Is Invisible
description: For most basketball aficionados, and certainly most Knicks fans, the reason Chicago is called great is simple: The Bulls have a great record and a great player.

title: G.O.P. to Press Missile Defense As Clinton Test
description: Congressional Republicans, eager to turn defense policy into a major issue in the Presidential campaign, are preparing to present President Clinton with legislation that they will portray as a test of his commitment to national military readiness.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Fast Track for Hospital Bill
description: State Senator Donald T. DiFrancesco said he planned to put the latest measure to end a five-month stalemate on hospital care for the uninsured directly before the Senate on Thursday without going through the committee process. "We have explored every possible option," Senator DiFrancesco said last Tuesday to explain his plan. The measure was approved last Monday by the Assembly; its prospects in the Senate are uncertain. The bill would continue to rely heavily on unemployment payroll taxes to subsidize charity care, distributing $310 million to hospitals this year and $300 million next year.

title: TECHNOLOGY: CONNECTIONS;The Web is a star in soap operas that appear on it.
description: SOAP operas on television only occasionally show characters watching television. They are too busy with incest, infidelity, blackmail and mustache-twirling villainy to bother tuning in to "The Guiding Light."

title: 5 Climbers Missing On Mount Everest
description: Three Americans, including a veteran climber known as Mr. Rescue here, were among five climbers missing and presumed dead on Mount Everest over the weekend.

title: BASEBALL;This Time, Not Much Fight in Mets
description: Dallas Green figured there must have been a letdown. Getting two-hit by a pitcher with an 8.02 earned run average coming in will lead to that conclusion.

title: BALLET REVIEW;A Bolshoi Star at 70, Center Stage
description: Before there was Maria Callas, there was Maya Plisetskaya. There still is. At 70, Ms. Plisetskaya leaves no doubt as to why she was once a Bolshoi Ballet star who did things her way and will always be considered one of the century's greatest ballerinas.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings this week:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about presidential elections in Uganda referred imprecisely to the country's election history since it became independent in 1962. After legislative elections in 1980, the winning party selected the President. There was no direct vote for President until last week.

title: Immigration Policy Should Reflect Concern for Environment;Limit Legal Immigrants
description: To the Editor:

title: So, How Did Gasoline Prices Get This High?
description: As president of Suncoast Resources here, Kathy Lehne trucks gasoline around Texas and the surrounding states. She routinely buys from the region's refineries, then pumps the fuel into storage tanks at gas stations, other businesses and schools.

title: Harry B. Frank, 91, Judge in Giants' Case
description: Harry Bennett Frank, the State Supreme Court justice and ardent New York Giants fan who ruefully decided that the owners of that baseball team were within their rights to leave the Polo Grounds and seek greener turf in San Francisco, died on May 5 at his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 91.

title: Immigration Policy Should Reflect Concern for Environment;Don't Cut Off Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: Queens Man And 2 Boys Die in Fires
description: Two young brothers died yesterday morning when a fire, apparently started by clothing draped over an electrical heater, roared through the basement of their house in Cambria Heights, Queens, fire officials said.

title: Stre-e-e-e-etch Limousine Pulled Off Road
description: A white stretch limousine belonging to an Arab sheik and thought to be one of the longest in the world has been ordered off the roads by the police because it is too long, even for car-crazy California.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9

title: With Campaign Staff in Disarray, Yeltsin Depends on Perks of Office
description: Boris N. Yeltsin took a running headstart last week on the election law that prohibits presidential candidates from advertising on radio, television or billboards before May 15. Beginning Thursday and throughout the long Victory Day holiday, his campaign flooded the airwaves with gauzy television commercials featuring World War II veterans reminiscing fondly about their past and hinting darkly about the future.

title: A Modest Beginning
description: The promise of free air time for Presidential candidates by the four major commercial networks, plus PBS and CNN, is a healthy development. But the networks' move is really just a baby step. The commercial networks could multiply their offer ten-fold and still be paying only a tiny rent on the publicly owned broadcast bands they occupy so profitably. Each offer is different, but the offer of an hour at the end of the campaign -- or a few minutes on a more regular basis -- falls far short of the frequent prime-time sessions with Presidential candidates that make sense from the voters' standpoint.

title: Police Mind Their Manners On Return Trip to Capital
description: As New York City police officers began arriving in the nation's capital today for Police Week, around every corner they were forced to confront harsh reminders that the type of drunken cavorting that marred last year's observances would not be tolerated.

title: THEATER REVIEW;American Dream, Viewed Bitterly
description: All of its absurdist and poetic conceits never disguise the commonplace, essentially sentimental nature of "The Chang Fragments," Han Ong's consideration of the havoc that America wreaks on one family of Chinese immigrants. The play, which opened last night in LuEsther Hall at the Joseph Papp Public Theater (425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village), announces its method in its title.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;If Abuse Is Boring, Try a Little Patricide
description: Abuse in its infinite variety remains at the top of the television-movie hit parade. Recent weeks have brought vivid prime-time depictions of children beating up parents (Fox's "Terror in the Family"), a husband battering his wife (CBS's "Unforgivable"), and a young man wiping out his girlfriend (NBC's "No One Would Tell").

title: Prodigy to Get New Owners And Strategy
description: I.B.M. and Sears, Roebuck finally ended their costly foray into the computer on-line business yesterday when they agreed to sell the Prodigy Services Company to about 40 Prodigy managers and an American start-up company backed by a Mexican billionaire.

title: N.H.L. PLAYOFFS;After Sudden Stop, Questions Start for Rangers
description: The Rangers' abrupt exit from the second round of the Stanley Cup playoffs surprised their general manager, their coach and their best players. Neil Smith, Colin Campbell, Mark Messier, Brian Leetch and other members of the roster thought their veteran group was talented enough, experienced enough and deep enough to contend for a second championship in three seasons.

title: GOLF;Icy Davies Dominates The Crowd and the Cold
description: Cruel conditions and tough-minded competitors. One is made for the other. Rarely do conditions get more difficult than during the final round of a major championship and rarely do competitors get more uncompromising than Laura Davies.

title: BASEBALL;Yankees Hustle Up a 9-Run Comeback
description: Andy Fox's grounder to first base today should have been another routine out in a game the Yankees seemed destined to lose to the White Sox. But Fox did not view it so casually. He hustled out of the batter's box, never hesitated as Frank Thomas waved off pitcher Alex Fernandez and won what started as a lopsided race when a jittery Thomas stabbed his foot inches shy of the base.

title: Search Called Off for Survivors of Crash in Everglades;Loved nes Lost, Perhaps Never to Be Found
description: Rescue workers found no survivors. They found no bodies. When Valujet Flight 592 dropped out of the sky and into the Florida Everglades on Saturday afternoon, it was as if 109 people aboard the DC-9 were just erased.

title: Israelis Suffer First Casualties in Lebanon Since Truce
description: Hezbollah guerrillas and Israeli forces exchanged fire in southern Lebanon today, causing the first Israeli casualties since the United States brokered an end to a major Israeli military operation inside Lebanon two weeks ago.

title: Newspapers Are Reshuffled Across Canada
description: One corporate strategy based on profitability of well-managed small-town newspapers and another based on the higher margins available from electronic media have led to an extraordinary shuffling of assets in the Canadian newspaper industry.

title: Tiger Management Buys USAir Stake
description: Tiger Management L.L.C. and affiliates have acquired an 11 percent stake in USAir Group Inc., the nation's sixth-largest airline company.

title: The Crash in the Everglades: THE COMPANY;  Airline, Frequently Praised, Will Now Get New Scrutiny
description: Valujet Airlines has led the unexpected growth in the 1990's of low-cost airlines, a role that has earned it widespread praise from consumers, investors and the Federal Government.

title: Internet Monitors Can Aim at Workers
description: A software program intended to help network administrators spot anyone using Internet resources to an unusual degree can also be used to monitor an employee's cyberspace activities.

title: Only Bills at Auction This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Michael Herman, 85, Teacher And Folk Dance Authority
description: Michael Herman, a teacher and an authority on folk dance, died on Friday in North Shore Hospital in Glen Cove, L.I. He was 85 and lived in Babylon, L.I.

title: Asian-American Politician in Washington State Looks to Blaze NewTrails
description: The invitation to the fund-raising event for Gary Locke, a Democrat who wants to be Washington State's next Governor, makes no mention of party affiliation or wedge issues. Instead, it says, "Help us make history."

title: Resuming Iraqi Oil Sales
description: Nearly six years of strict international sanctions have prevented Iraq from selling oil. The embargo has crippled Iraq's military, which was the intention, but has also caused hardship for the people of Iraq. Now there is a good chance that injury can be eased. But first Baghdad must accept some reasonable changes in the plan it is working out with the United Nations for limited, supervised oil sales to provide revenue for much needed food and medicine.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;The Madison Avenue consolidation continues, with Young & Rubicam buying Waring & LaRosa.
description: THE Great Agency Buyout Binge of 1996 continues unabated as a newcomer, giant Young & Rubicam Inc., has agreed to acquire Waring & LaRosa, a smaller shop that had been sold once before.

title: Woman Charged With Faking Abduction
description: A woman has been charged with trying to extort $200 from an acquaintance by faking her own abduction, the authorities said.

title: POP REVIEW;Rhythmic Independence Linked to a Sad Languor
description: Nostalgia plays a big part in the singer Cassandra Wilson's new career. In 1993, Ms. Wilson, who had trained as a jazz musician, changed career directions, releasing an album, "Blue Light 'Til Dawn," that gave her free rein over her experiences. She mixed pop and jazz and rural blues, and she and her band played them all from a distance. Using mandolins, violins, guitars and a variety of percussion instruments, the group sounded like an American version of a band from the Caribbean or Africa, with each instrument keeping to its prescribed role, with complete rhythmic independence. There isn't anything like it in American popular music, and Ms. Wilson went from the obscurity of a jazz career to an appearance on David Letterman show, and an invitation to be a permanent member of its band.

title: N.H.L. PLAYOFFS;Lemieux and Co. Mock Rangers When It Counts
description: Their big guys came to play, their backup goalie came out of the shadows and their supporting cast became an established cast. The way Eddie Johnston, coach of the victorious Pittsburgh Penguins, saw it, they took their cue from Mario Lemieux.

title: Winter of Record Snow Is Followed by Mother's Day Shoveling in UpstateNew York
description: The wintry chill that blustered through the New York region over the weekend left some upstate residents shoveling instead of sunning on Mother's Day, adding one more insult after a winter of record snowfalls.

title: Japanese Stocks Up a Bit
description: Stocks were trading slightly higher here today. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 32.95 points, less than two-tenths of 1 percent, at 21,453.07. On Friday, the Nikkei rose 8.24 points.

title: World News Briefs;Pope's Attacker Seeking Vatican Aid to Free Him
description: The Turkish gunman sentenced to life in prison for attacking and nearly killing Pope John Paul II in 1981 appealed to the Vatican today for help in getting set free.

title: Harare Journal;Zimbabwe Opposition: A One-Woman Tempest
description: As a guerrilla, tiny, tough Margaret Dongo took the name Tichaona Munhamo, meaning "We'll sort this out on the battlefield."

title: Liberian Ship Visits Ghana After Mutiny By Refugees
description: After reports that desperate refugees fleeing Liberia's civil war aboard a freighter that had been refused entry to several West African countries had rioted and overwhelmed the ship's captain, Ghanaian officials agreed today to allow the ship to dock.

title: Congressional Memo;As Campaign Heats Up, Senate Just Stops Cold
description: The Senate, embroiled in a Presidential campaign as never before, may be surpassing itself in ineffectiveness. Clear majorities of senators want to vote to raise the minimum wage and to cut the gasoline tax, but the only votes being cast are on motions to limit debate and curtail amendments. And those motions lose.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Rewards for Transit Riders
description: New Jersey Transit will reward its regular commuters and recruit new ones in a promotion called Try Transit Week, which runs from today through Friday. Anyone who rides a New Jersey Transit train or bus during the Wednesday morning rush, for example, will be given free tickets to use this weekend in an effort to boost ridership during off-peak hours.

title: Accord Seen for Oracle, Sun and I.B.M.
description: The Oracle Corporation, the International Business Machines Corporation and Sun Microsystems Inc. will announce next Monday that they have agreed to a set of standards for a new class of network computing devices, an executive close to the companies said.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Mickelson Wins Again

title: DISTRICTS IN DISTRESS;Big Plans for Campus Are Tangled in a Battle for Control
description: When the College of Staten Island moved to another campus three years ago, it left behind a sprawling 43-acre site in the Sunnyside section with several classroom buildings and a large athletic field and auditorium.

title: Bridge
description: Many of the world's best players were gathered this weekend at Loew's New York Hotel, at Lexington Avenue and 51st Street, for the 22d annual Cavendish Invitational Pairs. At the end of Saturday's play, the midpoint of the event, the scores were: first, Neil Chambers of Schenectady, N.Y., and John Schermer of Seattle, 1316.11 imps; second, Lorenzo Lauria and Alfredo Versace of Italy, 1294.11; third, Tony Sowter and David Kendrick of England, 1291.89; fourth, Jeff Meckstroth of Tampa, Fla., and Perry Johnson of Farmington Hills, Mich., 1119.11; fifth, Fred Stewart of Andes, N.Y., and Steve Weinstein of Upper Montclair, N.J., 1110.89.

title: Cuban Journalist Sent to Exile After Threat of a Prison Term
description: Faced with a wrenching choice between prison and exile, one of Cuba's leading independent journalists flew to Madrid last week, denouncing the repression of the Castro Government and defiantly vowing to continue working for its downfall.

title: A Costly Ceiling on City Debt
description: New York City has few needs more pressing than the repair of its schools, roads, bridges and sewers. But its ability to meet these demands is about to be sharply curtailed. The state Constitution limits borrowing for capital projects to 10 percent of city property values, and those values have plunged. To get around the limit, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani wants to create a new financing agency. It is a reasonable idea, though some mechanics may need rethinking. A new agency must also be accompanied by greater budgetary restraint and better control of construction costs.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Sylvia Bills and Others Skewer the Opera World
description: Opera has parodied itself so lustily over the centuries, in bad conceptions, bad productions and bad performances, that there might seem to be little left to spoof.

title: Pregnant Woman Loses Baby as 2 Cars Crash
description: A 31-year-old pregnant pedestrian was seriously injured and her 7-month-old fetus killed when two cars being driven by unlicensed drivers collided at a Brooklyn intersection yesterday, slamming into several parked cars and striking the woman, the police said.

title: At Home Abroad;'Peace, But Not This'
description: Members of the Palestinian Council, elected under the peace agreement with Israel, headed from Gaza recently for a session here in Ramallah. At the Erez checkpoint leaving Gaza, Israeli soldiers told them that they had to submit to strip-searches. The councilors refused. After a stand-off the soldiers finally let them go through with only the standard search.

title: Man Hurt at Club Is on Respirator
description: A Manhattan teen-ager who was critically injured when he was hit with a bottle inside the Palladium nightclub over the weekend remained on a respirator at St. Vincent's Hospital yesterday, hospital officials said.

title: Lynch-Mob Justice Grows in Caracas
description: The people of El Encanto, a hillside ghetto here in Caracas, are no strangers to desperation. More than one has resorted to theft when food was short or opportunity beckoned. But when three strangers attacked some residents on their way to work, stripping them of money, tools and even clothes, the response was swift and deadly.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Sorting Out War Crimes And Tangles Of History
description: Critics of courtroom television and of Court TV as its pre-eminent exponent charge often and correctly that the producers can't resist sensational cases, the O. J. Simpson extravaganza being the eternal example. But these days the critics must do justice to the cable channel for its many hours of coverage, live and taped, of the first war-crimes trial since the end of World War II. What can be more serious than an effort by what is loosely called the international community or, even more wishfully, the civilized conscience to act against atrocities that defy comprehension?

title: U.N. Sees Few Reclaiming Bosnia Homes
description: United Nations officials trying to organize the return of more than two million displaced Bosnians said today that they feared that as many as two-thirds of the refugees would never go back to their homes.

title: Canned Food Is Recalled
description: McCall Farms Inc. has recalled 27-ounce cans of Glory Foods "Southern Style String Beans & Potatoes, Pre-Seasoned" because of the possibility of harmful bacteria.

title: Legal-Services Cuts Mark Beginning of the End
description: To the Editor:

title: N.B.A. PLAYOFFS;Bulls Control Series By Controlling Boards
description: It kept happening, over and over again. The Chicago Bulls would miss a shot. The Chicago Bulls would grab the offensive rebound.

title: World News Briefs;North Italy Secessionists Elect Shadow Leadership
description: Italy's Northern League, which has set up its own self-styled parliament, elected a "shadow government" of the north today in its latest push for secession from the south.

title: A Popular Child-Support Bill Is Being Stalled by Politics
description: Despite its immense popularity in both houses of Congress, legislation to increase child-support collections is languishing on Capitol Hill, a victim of election-year politics and ideological disputes over broader questions of welfare policy.

title: In Central Europe, TV News Unfolds
description: No matter how much the post-Communist governments in Central Europe pledge to free their state-owned television stations from political interference, old habits die hard. From Bucharest to Budapest, government-run television dominates and the programming, particularly in news, remains predictable and safe.

title: Dr. S. P. Martin, 80; Started M.B.A. Plan
description: Dr. Samuel Preston Martin 3d, who started a master's degree program for doctors at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School, died on May 2 at his daughter's home in Gainesville, Fla. He was 80 and had lived in Philadelphia until three months ago.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Gasoline Price Increases Are Benefiting Producers As gasoline prices have risen, the greatest share of the profits have gone to crude oil producers, while gas stations and wholesale distributors are collecting 28 percent more than last year, Cambridge Energy Research Associates said. Pushing up the prices are such industry changes as sharply lower inventories and a new wave of less-polluting, reformulated, oxygenated, seasonal and regional gasolines. [Page A1.]

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: I.B.M. and Hughes Plan Alliance for Chip That Uses New Material
description: A silicon chip that uses a new semiconductor material is edging closer to market as I.B.M. and the Hughes Electronics Corporation plan to announce a collaborative effort today to create high-speed communications products based on the technology.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: MUSIC
description: Angst and Eroticism From the Turmoil of War American Symphony Orcestra Avery Fisher Hall

title: CYCLING;Armstrong Finishes Like a Champion
description: A year ago, when Lance Armstrong won the Tour DuPont, he was beaten in the final day's time trial and was the most despondent champion you could imagine. Today, he won America's most important bicycle competition again, and, like the champion he is, he won it from the front.

title: Prosecutor Might Use Confession To a Priest
description: When a Catholic priest, the Rev. Tim Mockaitis, heard confession last month in a county prison in Eugene from a 20-year-old suspect linked to three killings, he assumed that the session would be private.

title: Frank Hercules, 85, Novelist and Teacher
description: Frank Hercules, whose novels dealt with racial and colonial oppression, died last Monday at his home on Roosevelt Island. He was 85.

title: N.B.A. PLAYOFFS;A Player's Unlikely Garden Renown
description: So often Bill Wennington seems like an extra piece of furniture on the Bulls' showroom floor. A big body to take up space. A planet for Michael Jordan to orbit around.

title: Market Place;Nokia's poor quarter underscores how tough the wireless market is.
description: TECHNOLOGY investors are used to turbulence: shares of high-technology companies often bounce around like a Cessna in a summer squall. But telecommunications investors generally expect a smoother ride.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When IDA KLAUS was a student at Columbia Law School and a member of the first class to which women were admitted, she was not exactly cheered on by her male colleagues.

title: Patents;A device to alert drivers with radar detectors that a police car, fire truck or  ambulance is approaching.
description: POLICE officers in high-speed pursuit of criminals sometimes crash before they can capture their quarry, and end up injuring bystanders or themselves. Indeed, traffic accidents are the leading cause of death among law- enforcement officers in the United States.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Torricelli Backs Ex-Mayor
description: With less than a month to go before the primary election, United States Representative Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of Englewood, has named his choice to succeed him in the congressional seat he is vacating to run for the Senate. Today, Mr. Torricelli will publicly announce his endorsement of Steve Rothman of Fair Lawn, a former Englewood Mayor and Bergen County surrogate, spokesmen for both men said.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Balanchine's 1957 'Agon,' Enlivened By 3 Debuts
description: Agon" never fails to amaze. Created in 1957, it remains one of the treasures of the New York City Ballet's repertory. George Balanchine's choreography to Stravinsky's score is ceaselessly inventive and often surprising without ever being merely freakish. Out of familiar ballet steps, Balanchine has constructed his own startling but eloquent choreographic language. Therefore, whenever new dancers take over solo roles in this work, the performance becomes a special event.

title: ON BASEBALL;Opponents of Smokeless Tobacco Want It Taken Out of the Old Ball Game
description: The last thing that Joe Garagiola, the former major league ballplayer, and Gregory Connolly, a dentist and Massachusetts health official, wanted was another poster child.

title: Indian Center-Left Coalition Gains in Bid to Block Hindu Party
description: The momentum in India's post-election maneuvering appeared today to be working against the formation of the country's first Hindu nationalist government and in favor of a center-left coalition that would govern with the backing of the Congress Party.

title: Bernice Shepard, 74, Private Care Worker
description: Bernice Hanft Shepard, a professional social worker who founded a private-care agency for the home-bound and elderly in Manhattan, died on Monday at her home on the Upper East Side. She was 74.

title: Information Highway Hits the Road
description: John Krachenfels, the manager of business development at the Oracle Corporation, was cruising through Silicon Valley not long ago. He was going a "few miles over the speed limit," he acknowledged, and glancing at his electronic mail at the same time, when a California Highway Patrol officer pulled him over.

title: Essay;Warnings for the Happy Worriers
description: A wave of euphoria is sweeping the White House as some polls show a 25-point Clinton lead over Dole. James Carville, the liberal guru demoted when the President turned to centrist Dick Morris and discovered the glory of followership, just warned the high fliers about the danger of complacency.

title: Search Called Off for Survivors of Crash in Everglades;Infested Swamp Dashes Hope for Rescue
description: With no hope of finding survivors at what officials called the most challenging crash site they have ever encountered, investigators today grappled with the task of retrieving human remains and the wreckage of a jetliner that plummeted into the Everglades.

title: The Real Threat to Russian Reform Is . . . Yeltsin
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC REVIEW;The Pain of Love Burns Just Beneath the Surface
description: The performance of Brahms's "Liebeslieder-Walzer" by the artists of the New York Festival of Song on Saturday night was a chastisement to those who think of these works as lighter fare. Certainly there is a quality of Hausmusik about these 18 waltzing lieder for vocal quartet and piano four hands. And the modest size of the Kaufmann Concert Hall at the 92d Street Y allowed the singers to maintain a quality of family-room intimacy in their performance.

title: In America;Banana Bully
description: The United States, acting on behalf of the multinational Chiquita banana operation, has initiated a proceeding in the World Trade Organization that poses a major -- and wholly unnecessary -- threat to the economies of several banana-producing nations of the Caribbean.

title: Am I Bid Six? Click to Bid Six!;Airlines Are the Latest to Move to On-Line Auctions
description: For Ernie Altvater, April 30 was a banner day. In an auction at American Airlines' site on the World Wide Web, Mr. Altvater submitted a bid of $475 for two first-class, round-trip tickets from Ontario, Calif., to Hartford. He won, and calculated his savings off the full price: $3,701.

title: SOCCER;MetroStars Escape In Shootout
description: The MetroStars were outplayed in the first half and were a man short for the last 13 minutes after Tab Ramos was ejected, but they salvaged another shootout victory, this time against D. C. United after playing to a 1-1 deadlock in regulation.

title: Edwin Kennebeck, A Book Editor, 72
description: Edwin Kennebeck, a longtime editor at Viking Press, died on May 2 at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 72 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Journalism Faculties Have News Experience, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Fraternity House Fire Kills 5 in North Carolina
description: A fire early this morning at a fraternity house killed five people, stunning the University of North Carolina campus just hours before the annual Mother's Day graduation ceremonies.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Trying to Discourage Layoffs
description: Two Assembly committees will join forces today to consider how the Legislature might discourage corporate cutbacks. Members of the New Jersey Industrial Council, A.F.L.-C.I.O., are among those scheduled to appear at the joint session of the Labor Committee and the Commerce and Military and Veterans Affairs Committee. The unions are backing a bill that would require companies with more than 100 employees to pay workers dismissed for economic reasons two months of severance pay for every year of service.

title: Dump Underneath Subdivision Exasperates the Homeowners
description: William Holderby had never seen a coral snake in his backyard before, but then again, he had never thought his backyard would become a gigantic hole in the ground, filled with murky brown water and tons of construction debris. The venomous snake slithered away before it could frighten the Holderby family; the hole remains.

title: The Real Threat to Russian Reform Is . . . Yeltsin
description: To the Editor:

title: Disney Extends Producers' Deal
description: The Walt Disney Company has extended for seven years its contract with the film producers Bob and Harvey Weinstein, who have been responsible for such box-office successes as "The Piano" and "Pulp Fiction." Terms were not disclosed.

title: Faint Praise for CUNY
description: More than half of the students at the City University of New York graduate, and those graduates go on to make significant contributions to New York's economy, according to a study released last week. These figures, should they stand up to statistical challenge, suggest that CUNY is at least a more successful social-service program than some of its critics have been willing to concede.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JOHN FLICKER, who has been president of the National Audubon Society since July, has gone bird-watching all over the country but never in the middle of Manhattan.

title: Incidents in Crown Heights Draw New Calls for Harmony
description: Fed up with television cameras and mortified by their neighborhood's resurgent image as a roiling racial caldron, Jewish and black residents of Crown Heights yesterday expressed both a conviction that they live in harmony and a determination to put a disruption on Thursday night behind them.

title: Composting Dumps: Natural or Nuisance?;Municipal Mulching Is Called Smelly and Worse
description: When he opened his tree nursery and landscaping business here in 1945, Albert Alfredo used an old farmer's trick, brought from his Italian homeland, to supplement his income. On a former dairy farm just north of White Plains, Mr. Alfredo began composting leaves and selling the mulch as topsoil to local gardeners.

title: Richard Kaplan, 60, Fashion Executive
description: Richard M. Kaplan, a leader in the Manhattan fashion industry, died on May 3 in Manhattan. He was 60 and lived on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

title: Mr. Clinton Toughens Welfare Rules
description: President Clinton's recent executive order on welfare delivers a useful message to the states. Under the 1988 Family Support Act, states are supposed to withdraw welfare benefits from teen-age mothers who drop out of school. But states have routinely failed to enforce the school-attendance requirement because they did not want to pay for the mothers' child-care needs, as the law requires. Under the new executive order, Mr. Clinton has told the states they will now be held accountable for enforcing the law and for providing the child care that goes with it.

title: COMMENCEMENTS;Fight Urged To Preserve SUNY Role
description: With the State University of New York facing a battle over its future, the president of the university at Stony Brook urged graduating students today to become warriors for public education.

title: Japan Fund for War's 'Comfort Women' Is in Crisis
description: To some acclaim and self-acclaim, the Japanese Government started a fund last year to make payments to women forced into brothels run by the Imperial Army. The project was supposed to ease criticisms that Japan had shirked its responsibility for wartime atrocities.

title: Unruly Paris Music Scene Relishes the Eclat Of a Boulez Coup
description: Pierre Boulez has so often heaped scorn on the French musical establishment, and vice versa, that it almost comes as a surprise to find him happy for a change with the way one of his pet projects, the stunning Cite de la Musique, or City of Music, complex in the northeast corner of Paris, has turned out.

title: Ex-Publishing Officials Try Out the Writing Life
description: The book business is nothing if not incestuous, so the answer to the question, "Is there life after a top job in publishing?" was traditionally "yes": as a literary agent, marketing consultant or niche entrepreneur.

title: N.B.A. PLAYOFFS;Knicks and Ewing Are All Heart, but It's Barely Beating
description: They lost their starting center and nearly their franchise shooting guard to fouls. Their 10-point lead with seven minutes left? Like everything else, a memory. As Patrick Ewing maneuvered and shot and Madison Square Garden roared, all the second opportunities on offense and all the footwork on defense were drowned out by noise.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;No Union for Casino Dealers
description: By a vote of 301 to 289, dealers at Tropworld Casino and Entertainment Resort decided late Saturday against joining Local 331 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, The Associated Press reported. They would have become the first dealers in the country to be represented by a union in collective bargaining.

title: The Faithful Welcome Back an Old Rite
description: Vocem jucunditatis annuntiate" -- "Declare it with a voice of joy."

title: INSIDE
description: Child-Support Bill Stymied

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Mysterious Vanishings (And Grunting Sounds)
description: NEANDERTHAL By John Darnton 368 pages. Random House. $24.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Too Much Flounder Caught
description: Summer is more than a month away, but for commercial fishermen, the summer flounder season is already over. From May 1 until Aug. 1, these fishermen, who operate from about 30 boats, are allowed to catch 312,000 pounds of flounder off the New Jersey coast, according to limits set by the National Marine Fisheries Service. By May 1, they had already exceeded that limit, weighing in at 318,000 pounds of flounder, the catch from about a week or so of fishing, Bruce Halgern, the administrator of the Marine Fisheries Division, said last week.

title: BASEBALL;Next Time, He'll Wear a Mitt
description: Montreal took advantage of a major league record-tying six passed balls by the backup catcher Jerry Goff today to score five unearned runs and beat Houston by 7-6.

title: Computer Sales Slowdown Falls Short of Indications
description: Call it the slump that wasn't or the analysts who cried wolf.

title: MEDIA: TELEVISION;A generation gap in news viewership is suddenly wider.
description: WE take it as a generational rule of thumb that young people are less interested in news than their elders are. But that gap has grown suddenly wider, according to a new survey that finds the percentage of people under the age of 30 who say they regularly watch network television news has dropped by more than one-third in the last 12 months.

title: Green, Green G.O.P.
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;A Bourgeoisie Blooms And Goes Shopping
description: In the last two years, Piotr and Danuta Jentes, Polish 30-somethings, have bought a second car and splurged on a $3,000 wind surfer. Owners of a small business, they go to a private doctor, send their youngest child to a private day-care center and spend a lot of money fixing up their home. And in rapidly Westernizing Poland, they are no longer a rarity.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Judge Says He Erred in Trial Fleming Lost
description: A Texas judge who entered a $211.1 million verdict against the Fleming Companies recused himself today from post-trial motions and said he would ask that Fleming, a grocery distributor, be granted a new trial.

title: A 2d Strike Hits Norway Industries
description: Nearly 37,000 Norwegian mechanical engineering workers went on strike today, affecting about 500 companies in the first walkout in the sector in 72 years.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SONY TO ACQUIRE SOFTWARE MAKER
description: The American unit of the Sony Corporation agreed yesterday to buy a maker of digital mapping and navigation software from the News Corporation for an undisclosed price. The company being acquired, Etak Inc., will give the Sony Corporation of America the technology to expand its mobile navigation business. Sony introduced its first car navigation system in Japan in June 1992 and began selling it in the United States in 1994. The system, which costs about $3,000, uses small computer monitors that are installed in cars and track a vehicle's position on a computerized map via satellites. Etak introduced the first car navigation system for consumers in 1985, two years after the company was founded. Etak was acquired by the News Corporation in 1989.

description: To the Editor:

title: Designers Put Their Minds to Uniformity
description: There is a certain uniformity to the thinking man's most sinister view of the future, men the caliber of George Orwell, Fritz Lang and Aldous Huxley. When they envisioned the worst that totalitarianism might wreak, there was one overwhelming symbol of it: the uniform.

title: Buenos Aires Journal;Loony Radio's Not So Crazy. It's Great Therapy.
description: Every Saturday at 2 P.M., the activities of the Borda Psychiatric Hospital here come to a halt as fidgety patients gather around portable radios, eagerly awaiting their favorite radio program.

title: Another Rightist Offers Mediation to Freemen
description: A Colorado legislator who champions the states' rights movement plans to travel to Montana on Wednesday to mediate the Freemen standoff, 50 days old today.

title: Arthritis Survey Finds Ethnic Variation
description: The first survey of arthritis sufferers by race in the United States has found the lowest reported rate among Americans of Asian and Pacific Island descent.

title: End the Inequities of Campus Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: Cablevision Acquisitions
description: Cablevision Systems has agreed to acquire cable television holdings from Warburg Pincus Investors L.P. for $183 million. Cablevision is buying the interests it does not already own in A-R Cable Services Inc., which operates in New York, Massachusetts, Arkansas, Missouri and Rockford, Ill.; in A-R Cable Partners, which operates in Massachusetts; in Cablevision of Newark, and in Cablevision of Framingham Holdings, in Massachusetts.

title: Aide Backs Judge's Decision Not to Give Up Warhol Case
description: An aide to a leading New York State appeals judge yesterday defended the judge's decision not to remove himself from a case involving the Andy Warhol Foundation, citing a 1994 advisory opinion that it is not necessary for judges to step aside under some circumstances.

title: THE CRASH IN THE EVERGLADES;On the Plane, an Educator Who Inspired Enthusiasm
description: Dennis J. Sabo left his post as assistant principal of South Brunswick High School 16 years ago. But he made such a lasting impression that today, when news of his death on Saturday in the crash of Valujet's Flight 592 reached his former colleagues, they held a special meeting after school to share their memories of him.

title: Jack R. Osborn, 67, Fervid Popularizer and Champion of Croquet
description: Jack R. Osborn, a passionate popularizer of the venerable sport of croquet, died on Sunday at his home in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. He was 67. The cause of death was cancer, according to his son, John C. Osborn, also of Palm Beach Gardens.

title: SUPREME COURT ROUNDUP;Race Statistics Alone Do Not Support a Claim of Selective Prosecution, Justices  Rule
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that statistics showing that the overwhelming number of Federal crack-cocaine defendants are black are not by themselves sufficient to support a defense argument that the Government is engaged in selective prosecution.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Raiders Trade for Kennedy
description: The Oakland Raiders beefed up their offensive line yesterday by trading an undisclosed 1997 draft choice for Atlanta Falcons tackle LINCOLN KENNEDY, who agreed to a two-year contract.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Universe in Trouble? Just Call Doctor Who
description: Riddled with bullets, the middle-aged doctor dies on the operating table. After some mysterious electrical charges buzz the hospital morgue, the corpse emerges as a much younger man while an unsuspecting orderly watches "Frankenstein" on television. The regenerated creature, temporarily discombobulated, cries, "Who am I?" Doctor Who, that's who, in his eighth transformation since the childlike adventurer in time and space made his debut on the BBC in 1963.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about India included a typographical error that reversed a description of the political situation there after the inconclusive election last week. Many Indians expect a period of political instability, not stability.

title: Josephthal Agrees to Fines And to Repay Investors
description: Josephthal Lyon & Ross Inc., a New York-based brokerage firm, will repay its customers more than $225,000 and pay fines of about $350,000 under an agreement announced yesterday with the National Association of Securities Dealers.

title: For Life Insurers, Trials and Errors
description: AMSTERDAM  Like people in many cultures, "Oriental people hesitate to talk about death," says Michelle Lin, a spokeswoman for Aetna Life Insurance in Taiwan. "It is not a very lucky thing to say."

title: BASEBALL;It Looks to Be a Long Trip: Valenzuela Baffles the Mets
description: Putting the two key phases of their game together has been an elusive quest for the Mets. More often than not, when their starting pitching is good, their hitting fails them. On nights when their offense clicks, the pitching falters. The result is a team struggling to find itself and remain in contention.

title: Next Wave of Electric Cars: Hybrids
description: A motley collection of electric and hybrid vehicles will buzz, whirr and hum their way over 64 miles from Chesapeake to Annapolis in Maryland on Tuesday, about 50 in all, depending on how many have run out of juice, shorted out a component or otherwise broken down along the way in the eighth American Tour de Sol race, which began in New York City and will end here on Thursday.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Ladbroke Tells of Efforts To Reunite Hilton Units
description: The chairman of Ladbroke Group P.L.C., John Jackson, told shareholders yesterday that talks were continuing with the Hilton Hotels Corporation on a "range of ways" of reuniting the international Hilton hotel operations with those in the United States. Ladbroke runs Hilton hotels outside the United States and the Hilton Hotels Corporation, based in Beverly Hills, Calif., operates Hiltons in the United States. Last month, British news reports said Hilton was planning a bid of L3 billion ($4.5 billion) for Ladbroke. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;VW Planning Countersuit Against G.M.
description: Volkswagen A.G. said today that it would file a defamation suit against the General Motors Corporation and its subsidiary Adam Opel A.G., which have accused VW of stealing trade secrets. VW will seek at least 10 million marks -- about $6.6 million -- in the suit, which accuses G.M. of violating German law against unfair competition. The law also forbids defamatory accusations.

title: Japanese Stocks Higher
description: Japanese stocks traded higher here today. At the close, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 129.23 points, or six-tenths of 1 percent, at 21,301.05. On Monday, the index fell 248.30 points.

title: Debating the Benefits and Costs Of Major Surgery for Emphysema
description: An increasingly popular new surgery for emphysema that at first appears to defy logic is at the center of an intense debate among chest surgeons and health care providers concerning its effectiveness and cost.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;At Cannes, Intensity And Auteur Worship
description: What fails to become more delightful in French? There is "Mickey Perd la Tete," the local title for the Mickey Mouse short known in English as "Runaway Brain." Or "Ma belle et tendre poupee d'amour," which is what the song lyric "Oh, you beautiful doll" becomes in the I.R.A. drama "Some Mother's Son."

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Jail Inmates Claim Beatings
description: A Federal judge ordered Sussex County authorities yesterday to meet with lawyers for jail inmates who say that guards routinely beat prisoners, The Associated Press reported.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ALLERGAN-UPJOHN MERGER TALKS ARE ENDED
description: Allergan Inc., a manufacturer of eye- and skin-care products, said yesterday that discussions with Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc. about a possible merger had been terminated because the proposed terms were "not feasible." Allergan made the announcement after The Wall Street Journal reported yesterday that Pharmacia & Upjohn was talking with Allergan about a takeover.

title: Alliance in India Proposes A Communist for Premier
description: With time running out on efforts to stop Hindu nationalists from forming India's next Government, a center-left alliance made a last-minute reversal today and put forward the country's most prominent Communist leader for the post of Prime Minister.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Former Mountaineer to Enter Draft
description: GREG SIMPSON, a junior guard who was dismissed from West Virginia's basketball team after a hit-and-run accident, has applied for the National Basketball Association draft June 26, The Dominion Post reported.

description: Monogamy or Not?

title: God's Stronghold At Mammon's Door;After 150 Years, Trinity's Spire Still Looms Amid Wall St. Towers
description: Nowhere else in New York does God confront Mammon as directly as where Trinity Church meets Wall Street. A landmark Gothic Revival church staring down the canyon of capitalism: what better way for architecture to symbolize the very conflict of urban civilization?

description: Nebraska Republicans Staging A Fierce Senate Race

title: Announcement Is Set on Mitsubishi Case
description: Mitsubishi Motor Manufacturing of America, the Japanese car maker that the Government has accused of allowing widespread sexual harassment at a plant in Normal, Ill., said today that it would make "a major announcement" about the case on Tuesday in Chicago.

title: After a Surge in Vehicle Sales, Executives Predict a Moderation
description: While some investors on Wall Street have worried that auto makers' brisk sales and recent production increases may signal an overheating economy, auto industry officials say they doubt that the recent burst of activity will last.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;U.S. Transfer of Muslims To Serbs Is Defended
description: NATO today defended the decision to hand over seven men, believed to be Muslims, to Bosnian Serb authorities last week after the group had surrendered to American troops.

title: Corrections
description: A report and a picture caption in the Guide column of the Connecticut Weekly on Sunday, about a performance of "A Conversation With Gregory Peck" at 8 P.M. this Saturday, misstated the location. It is the Bushnell, at 166 Capitol Avenue in Hartford. The Hartford Stage Company is presenting the performance but not at its own theater.

title: CRASH IN THE EVERGLADES: THE OVERVIEW;BLACK BOX FOUND AT SITE OF CRASH IN THE EVERGLADES
description: Investigators got their first break this afternoon in the crash of a Valujet DC-9 in the Everglades on Saturday, as a police officer searching the scene for body parts stepped on a 30-pound metal box that turned out to be the flight data recorder, one of the plane's two "black boxes."

title: Paramount Gets New Financing
description: Correction Appended

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Phone Rate Fraud Charged
description: National Accounts is a Parsippany-based company that buys long-distance service at bulk rates and resells it to businesses. Today, the State Division of Consumer Affairs plans to sue the company in Superior Court for violating the Consumer Protection Act, officials said. Telemarketers would misidentify themselves as employees of AT&T or other long-distance companies and offer service at cheaper rates, but sometimes customers would see their rates go up, said Mark S. Herr, director of Consumer Affairs.

title: In the Mideast, U.S. Is Still Honest Broker
description: To the Editor:

description: Sportwear Lines in Talks

title: Washington's Mayor Is Back and Says He's Going to Stay
description: Pronouncing himself spiritually renewed and mentally sharp, Washington's Mayor, Marion S. Barry Jr., returned to work today after two weeks of personal introspection at retreats in Maryland and Missouri.

title: For Killer Asteroids, Respect at Last
description: WITH little fanfare, the Federal Government has assumed a serious role in an activity seen until recently as the province of zealous astronomers and doomsday enthusiasts: scanning the skies for speeding rocks from outer space that could slam into the planet to cause widespread destruction and death.

title: With Hearing on Budget Near, Crew Has Yet to Release Plan
description: The Board of Education has scheduled a hearing tomorrow for the public to discuss Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew's budget proposal for the coming school year. There is only one problem: the Chancellor had yet to distribute the document yesterday to the public, or even to the board.

title: It's Back to the Campuses For the C.I.A.'s Recruiters
description: Back in the cold war, in the Central Intelligence Agency's halcyon days, recruiting on college campuses was elementary.

title: Boy to Get Hunting Wish
description: A 17-year-old Minnesota boy who is terminally ill with a brain tumor will be granted his wish to hunt a Kodiak Bear in Alaska despite protests from animal rights activists, the Make-A-Wish Foundation board of directors announced in a statement released here today.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Oil Leaks Into Delaware Bay
description: About 10,000 gallons of medium-weight crude oil spilled from a leaky ship early Friday, endangering wildlife and dirtying a two-mile stretch of beach along Delaware Bay. But state environmental officials said yesterday that Sunset Beach should be cleaned up within a few days. Some 50 horseshoe crabs were coated with oil, threatening the thousands of birds that eat their eggs, Governor Whitman said while visiting the site yesterday. The ship, owned by France Shipmanagement, sprang a leak while crude oil was being unloaded to make the vessel lighter, said Lieut. (j.g.) Scott Kelly of the Coast Guard.

title: Seeking Feng Shui Harmony
description: LOS ANGELES  Before the Wells Fargo HSBC Trade Bank opened its El Monte branch last fall, the manager, Julius Ting, had the office inspected by an expert.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BANKRUPTCY COURT APPROVES LIQUIDATION OF HERMAN'S
description: Herman's Sporting Goods Inc., the retailer based in Carteret, N.J., won court approval yesterday to hold liquidation sales in all its stores. Gordon Brothers, a liquidation company based in Boston, plans to handle the sales, which should begin sometime after tomorrow, a company spokesman said. Squeezed by competition in the sporting goods industry, Herman's, which operates 117 stores in the Northeast, filed for bankruptcy protection late last month to provide for "an orderly liquidation of assets."

title: Executive Changes
description: COMPUSERVE INC., Columbus, Ohio, a unit of H & R Block Inc., said Alexander Trevor, vice president and chief technical officer, had resigned.

title: NYC;Tony Brawl Is Sideshow In a Boom
description: NO way would the NYC column be written anymore, no sir, not after so many worthy colleagues had been ignored for the Pulitzer Prize. Granted, a better protest would have been to reject one's own nomination for the prize, a la Julie Andrews. (Can there be a more wholesome model than the woman who played Mary Poppins, even if she went on to bare her breasts on screen?) But, sob, no Pulitzer nomination had come this way to be turned down. That left a work stoppage as the only path left for the indignant.

title: Court Reinstates Suit on Sex-Based Pay Increases
description: A Federal appeals court has reinstated a lawsuit brought by male professors at Virginia Commonwealth University who object to pay increases that the university gave women on the faculty to eliminate disparities in salary.

title: EU Votes Early for Yeltsin's Russia
description: BRUSSELS  In another demonstration of Western support for President Boris N. Yeltsin, European Union foreign ministers on Monday approved a plan for closer cooperation with Russia on trade and security issues.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page map on May 4 showing the campuses of the State University of New York, with an article about proposals for change in the system, omitted a campus. It is the State University College at Oswego.

title: Poverty Meets Consumerism in Inland China
description: NINGXIA, China  "Work hard and realize the goal of 0.1 billion yuan sales this year," declared a huge red banner strung across the atrium at Xinhua Shopping City. The staff at the newest department store in Yinchuan, capital of Ningxia province, looked well on course to meet the target  equal to about $12.3 million

title: Court Won't Hear Presidential Primary Case
description: The Supreme Court refused today to hear an appeal of a lower court ruling that threw out the complex petition process for Republican candidates to win a place on the Presidential primary ballot in New York State.

title: 800,000 May Lose Coverage If Mental Benefits Are Added
description: The Congressional Budget Office said today that 800,000 people could lose health insurance as a result of higher premiums if Congress required insurers and health plans to provide coverage for mental illness equivalent to that provided for other conditions, like heart disease.

title: China Bike Race: A Tour de Force
description: BEIJING  The young Chinese reporter looked and sounded defiant when he posed his question at the final press conference of the Kent Tour of China professional bicycle race.

title: Hemophiliacs With H.I.V. Reject an Offer
description: Leaders of H.I.V.-infected hemophiliacs rejected a $640 million settlement offer from four major drug companies during talks today, a lawyer for the hemophiliacs said.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: NOTEBOOK;Smith Promotes League, but Is Silent on Cowboys
description: As controversy swirls around his team, Dallas running back Emmitt Smith is on the road as a goodwill ambassador for the National Football League. Smith spent the weekend in Barcelona, Spain, helping to promote the World League, the N.F.L.'s spring European football league.

title: Apple Unveils Strategic Plan Of Small Steps
description: Anyone hoping to hear a grand rescue plan for Apple Computer Inc. probably came away disappointed.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ALCOHOL SENSORS TO SELL DEVICES WORTH $360 MILLION
description: Alcohol Sensors International Ltd., based in Islandia, L.I., said yesterday that it had reached a deal, worth more than $360 million, for Digital Vehicle Security Systems of Britain to sell its ignition interlock devices in Europe. The devices detect, evaluate and help prevent an intoxicated driver from operating a vehicle. Digital Vehicle plans to buy 1.6 million Sens-o-lock ignition interlock units over five years, starting in November, and sell them in 17 European countries, the company said. Alcohol Sensors' stock closed at $15, up 75 cents a share, after jumping as high as $20 earlier in the day in Nasdaq trading.

title: Man Guilty In '90 Killing In Queens
description: A 25-year-old man, whose murder conviction in a celebrated 1991 "gay bashing" trial was overturned last year, pleaded guilty yesterday to a lesser charge of manslaughter.
