description: To the Editor:

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Storm in Bangladesh Kills 200 and Injures 5,000
description: Nearly 200 people were killed and up to 5,000 injured as a severe storm battered Bangladesh's northern district of Tangail on Monday night, witnesses said today. They said three villages were reduced to ruins by 90-mile-an-hour winds.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;TV Hybrid: Ready for Prime Time?
description: IT'S here, Bart! It's our new Destination Big Screen PC, the Pentium computer that's also a TV! We'll be processing words! Spreadsheeting! Databasing! Joysticking! Coasting on the cobwebs!"

title: Tortoises Get Some Unusual Help From the Military's Spy Satellites
description: WHEN not focused on other nations' military bases, American spy satellites have been studying a dusty habitat of the humble desert tortoise in an effort to help scientists preserve this threatened species.

title: German's Gift to Oxford Revives Memories of War
description: Ever since Winston Churchill told them that fighting Germany would be their finest hour, the British have been reliving the moment -- in comic books that nurtured the postwar baby-boomers, in TV comedy shows that portrayed bumbling Brits prevailing over clod-hopping Germans.

title: A 4-Star First for the Navy
description: The Navy is expected to get its first black four-star admiral.

title: Study for F.D.I.C. Chides Banks On Failure to Cite Fund Risks
description: More than one-fourth of banks in a study did not properly warn customers about the risks of buying mutual funds and other investments that lack Federal insurance, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today.

title: New, Moderate D'Amato: Could It Be Those Polls?
description: As he slid out of the sharp wind and into his sedan here, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato sounded a little surprised.

title: Jail Terms Imperil Talks With Mexican Rebels
description: Stiff jail terms handed down against two men accused of being Zapatista army rebels have imperiled the peace talks in the stormy southern state of Chiapas.

title: One Sings, the Other Doesn't
description: In their first exchange of dueling commencement speeches, President Clinton and Senator Bob Dole conformed to type. Mr. Clinton, speaking at Penn State University, established multiple connections with the school (through his wife's family). Mr. Dole, speaking to deaf students at Gallaudet University, pointedly refrained from the obvious ploy of referring to his own physical disability. One speaker was unembarrassed, almost shameless; the other was too embarrassed to get personal.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;France's Renault Stake To Be Cut Below 50%
description: The French Government announced plans yesterday to privatize the state-controlled auto maker Renault S.A. in the coming weeks by reducing its stake to about 46 percent from 52 percent. The shares will be sold by direct placement with unnamed investors who will be selected on the basis of bids, the Finance Ministry said.

title: Nassau Enacts Weakened Ban on Herbal Stimulant
description: The Nassau County Legislature today unanimously passed a bill to limit the sale of herbal stimulants, but it was a far narrower measure than County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta had proposed two weeks ago.

title: Ghana Refuses to Take In a Boatload of Liberian Refugees
description: A ship with thousands of Liberian war refugees seeking a country to accept them headed back to sea from the port of Takoradi this evening after Ghana refused to admit them, witnesses said.

description: Debt

description: NEW YORK

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Iran Opens Railway Link Along Silk Road to Asia
description: President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran officially inaugurated a new rail link between Iran and Central Asia today. He said it revived the old Silk Road as a symbol of East-West relations.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FORD PLANNING TO REDUCE ITS PRODUCTION OF MUSTANGS
description: The Ford Motor Company said yesterday that it would reduce its production of Mustangs with the start of 1997 model year on Aug. 5, because of lower demand for the sporty car. The move, which would reduce Mustang output to 37 cars an hour on two shifts from 42.5 an hour now, would affect about 290 employees at Ford's Dearborn assembly plant, Ford said. Ford said the affected employees would be relocated to jobs at other Ford factories in the Detroit metropolitan area. Currently, 2,200 people are employed at Ford's 78-year-old Dearborn plant.

title: Corrections
description: A music review yesterday about a performance by La Gran Scena Opera at the Kaye Playhouse at Hunter College on Friday night included an incorrect identification, taken from the program, for the singer who performed "Home Sweet Home." He was Johnny Maldonado, not Ira Siff.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: Web of Patronage in Schools Grips Those Who Can Undo It
description: The revelations began bubbling out of New York City's community school board system more than a decade ago.

title: COMPANY NEWS;NORTHERN TELECOM PLANNING TO TAKE OVER MICOM
description: Northern Telecom Ltd. said yesterday that it planned a $137.4 million takeover of the Micom Communications Corporation, a maker of computer-networking devices based in Simi Valley, Calif. Northern Telecom, a Toronto-based provider of telecommunications equipment and services, offered $12 for each Micom share, below the stock's closing price on Friday. Micom's stock fell $2.25, to $11.75 a share, in Nasdaq trading. Nortel's stock was up $1.625, to $52.375.

title: ON BASEBALL;Can Yankees and Mariners Repeat Their '95 Oscar?
description: The last time the Yankees saw the Seattle Mariners, the Mariners were jubilantly jumping around the Kingdome, celebrating the success of the first post-season foray in the franchise's 19-year history. They celebrated because they had just defeated the Yankees in one of the most scintillating post-season series in baseball history, a series that validated the Mariners' late-season rush to the top of their division, secured the team's place in the Northwest corner of the United States and injected another jolt of juice into the sport cynical undertakers were preparing for burial.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Regulator Orders Cuts In British Gas's Rates
description: British regulators said yesterday that British Gas P.L.C. would have to cut prices by 10 percent next year. The company vowed to fight the proposal and said it would appeal to the Monopolies and Mergers Commission. Shares of British Gas were down more than 11 percent in London and the price of an American depository receipt, representing one share, fell $4.125 in New York, to $30.625. (AP)

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Vote to Decide District's Fate
description: Voters in six Union County communities will decide today whether to preserve their 62-year-old regional high school district. The wealthier communities of Mountainside, Berkeley Heights, Kenilworth and Springfield want to break up the district because they feel they are paying too much while sacrificing local control. Each town's contribution is based on its property values, which means that Mountainside, for example, pays about $21,000 per student, said Mayor Robert Vigliani.

title: On My Mind;  Clinton on The China Road
description: On May 10, the Clinton Administration decided to move along in its China policy. It moved from appeasement of the Communists about violations of human rights to appeasement of the Communists about violations of international agreements against spreading nuclear weaponry.

title: By Design;A Sure-Footed Best Seller
description: With the current emphasis on comfort in fashion, it is no surprise that one of the best-selling styles in stores across the country is the driving shoe. Soft and flexible, it has nonskid pebbly rubber spikes on the sole and heel, which were originally designed for gripping car pedals.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;14-Year-Old Finishes Rutgers
description: Two years ago, Hannes Sarkuni of Cranbury graduated from the eighth grade. On Thursday, Hannes, who is now 14, will graduate from Rutgers, probably the youngest person ever to do so, according to university officials. He has not decided whether he will start graduate school right away, the officials said. TERRY PRISTIN

title: William Hughes Mulligan, 78, Judge and Dean of Law School
description: William Hughes Mulligan, a retired New York lawyer who was dean of the Fordham University School of Law and a Federal appeals court judge, died yesterday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. A Bronxville resident, he was 78.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Slip Hubby a Mickey and Voila! Mr. Mom.
description: Is your husband distant? Cranky? Does he complain about going to your office Christmas party? Maybe he's suffering from Male Disassociative Personality Disorder, a malady that's rampant in the suburban town of Stepford.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;76ers Dismiss Lucas as Coach
description: John Lucas once joked that he demanded three titles when he took the job of rebuilding the Philadelphia 76ers, because friends told him to ask for as many as he could get.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;Cool? Calm? Collected? It Can't Be! Not Him!
description: Dennis Rodman has been all ball. The nerve of him focusing on the game, acting as restrained as a librarian when so many thought he would have burst out of his corset by now.

title: U.N. Says North Korea Will Face Famine as Early as This Summer
description: Hunger in North Korea is growing more intense as the country's economy continues to deteriorate, so that malnutrition could become widespread in the coming months, some experts say.

title: Stokely USA to Sell Unit
description: Stokely USA Inc. said today that it had agreed to sell the assets of its frozen-vegetable business to two buyers. The identity of the buyers and the purchase price were not disclosed. Stokely, which will continue to make canned vegetables, said the sale included processing plants in Grandview and Walla Walla, Wash. A third plant in Green Bay, Wis., accounting for less than 10 percent of Stokely's frozen processing capacity, remains for sale.

title: Attack by Gunmen in Israel Kills Teen-Ager at a Bus Stop
description: Drive-by gunmen opened fire today at Jewish settlers on a bus and at a West Bank bus stop, killing one teen-age seminary student and seriously wounding another.

title: A Fifth Avenue Camping Trip: Bonding in the Beauty Salon
description: In a small white room, a steam jet coaxes beads of sweat from Susan Ciambrone's face as a skin-care specialist applies moisturizer with the gentle, rapid movements of a harpist.

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;Inconsistent Kovalev May Be Expendable
description: In the real estate business, spring brings "For Sale" signs on the front lawns of houses. In hockey, it's the season when general managers decide which players to keep and which ones to shop around.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TALKS BETWEEN FUND AMERICAN AND MELLON END
description: Fund American Enterprises Holdings Inc. said yesterday that it had ended talks with the Mellon Mortgage Company about a potential sale of Fund American's Source One subsidiary. The company said it broke off talks with Mellon after four months of negotiations. A tentative deal worth about $350 million was first disclosed in December. In March, the two sides were still negotiating a possible sale of Source One. Fund American said then that Mellon had revised the terms of the proposed purchase. Source One ended 1995 with a servicing portfolio of $32 billion and $2.8 billion in mortgage origination. Mellon Mortgage is a unit of the Mellon Bank Corporation.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Jets Get Cobb and Boatswain
description: The Jets signed running back Reggie Cobb and offensive lineman Harry Boatswain as free agents today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: LATOYA JACKSON filed for divorce in Clark County District Court in Las Vegas, Nev., on Friday, after obtaining a temporary order of protection from her husband, JACK GORDON, who is also her agent, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: HIGH COURT SAYS LIQUOR PRICE ADS CAN'T BE BANNED
description: In a ruling that strengthens free-speech protection for advertisers and casts doubt on the Clinton Administration's proposed restrictions on cigarette promotions, the Supreme Court struck down today a Rhode Island ban on advertising liquor prices.

title: Brothers in a Fight for (Greek) Life
description: City College, even its own student newspaper concedes, has all the charm of the world's biggest high school. Most of the 15,000 students live at home, shuttling in only for classes and some time in the library and then rushing off to work.

title: Hesperus Descending
description: In Manhattan, the beauty of the night sky is only a faded metaphor, the shopworn verse of an outdated love song. The stars shine no brighter at midnight in midtown than the ones depicted on the time-dimmed ceiling of the main concourse at Grand Central Terminal. But over the last few weeks it has been possible, even in Manhattan, to watch the evening star -- Venus -- descending in the west, presenting her orbit, edgewise, to viewers on Earth.

title: A New York Stop for Leonardo's $30.8 Million Notebook
description: When William H. Gates, the chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, bought the Codex Leicester at Christie's two years ago, he promised to lend the 72-page manuscript by Leonardo da Vinci to museums around the world. It has been shown in Italy, in Milan at the Palazzo Reale and at the Palazzo Mignanelli in Rome, where it will be on view through June 16, but no plans were made for an appearance in the United States.

title: Nnamdi Azikiwe, the First President of Nigeria, Dies at 91
description: Nnamdi Azikiwe, Nigeria's first President and a vigorous champion of African independence from European colonial rule, died Saturday in a hospital in his native eastern Nigeria after a long illness. He was 91.

title: Warhol Judge Defended
description: An aide to a New York State appeals judge defended the judge's decision not to remove himself from a case involving the Andy Warhol Foundation, citing a 1994 advisory opinion that it is not necessary for judges to step aside in some circumstances. Justice Francis T. Murphy Jr. was criticized for failing to disclose that the foundation's lawyer investigated him for a gubernatorial panel that urged his reappointment.

title: The Foreboding Sky, The Rumbling Earth
description: Sometimes it's hard to know what to worry about -- killer asteroids or giant volcanoes. The Federal Government has recently put money on the asteroids, financing the first governmental effort to scan space for objects that could devastate Earth in the distant future.

title: Lawyer Guilty of Bribery
description: In the final trial to grow out of a broad investigation of graft in the agency that maintains New York City's public schools, a Manhattan lawyer was convicted in Federal court yesterday of paying bribes so his clients in the construction industry would win contracts or be paid more quickly.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;Orlando Just Misses A Sweep At the Line
description: Orlando center Shaquille O'Neal had carried the Magic to six consecutive playoff victories. Tonight he was responsible for its first loss.

title: NBC Builds on Its Comedy Strength for the Fall
description: Spreading its comedy strength to even more nights, NBC yesterday announced a new fall prime-time schedule with many of its established hits, like "Third Rock From the Sun" and "Mad About You," in new places.

title: BASEBALL;Harnisch Faces A Suspension
description: Mets pitcher Pete Harnisch is expected to be suspended by the National League for eight games for his participation in the brawl with the Chicago Cubs thi past Saturday at Shea Stadium, according to a person in Major League Baseball familiar with the case.

title: Mobil in Saudi Venture
description: The Mobil Corporation said today that it had agreed with the Saudi Basic Industries Corporation. to begin a $2 billion expansion of their 50-50 joint venture petrochemicals complex at Yanbu, Saudi Arabia. Each company will contribute about $1 billion to the project to more than double the capacity of the complex, which makes ethylene and derivative products.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: High Court Strikes Down Restriction on Liquor Ads The Supreme Court struck down a Rhode Island ban on advertising liquor prices. The ruling casts doubt on the Clinton Administration's proposed curbs on cigarette promotions intended to thwart sales to minors.

title: Court Forbids Tyson Bout
description: Mike Tyson was again denied in his bid to fight the World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, Bruce Seldon, in July.

title: BASEBALL;Newest Mariner Faces Familiar to Yank Fans
description: The Yankees are so revamped this season that five of their nine regulars did not start for the team last year, and the manager who is etching their names into the lineup is different, too.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: F.C.C. Reviews Plan For Free Broadcasts
description: Faced with the major broadcast networks' plans to offer free television time for political statements by the Presidential candidates in the fall, the Federal Communications Commission yesterday announced steps it would take to help the networks avoid prompting equal-time demands from fringe candidates.

title: Farrakhan Defends His World Tour Before a Receptive Crowd in Brooklyn
description: Trying to quell criticism that has dogged him since his world tour that included countries shunned by the United States, Louis Farrakhan spoke after a rousing welcome at a crowded Brooklyn church last night, saying that the purpose of his actions was to guide others rather than to give glory to himself.

title: Heroin Addicts Falling Prey to Tainted Drugs
description: Even with heroin purity up and wholesale prices down, heroin users are still at the mercy of unscrupulous dealers. Just since Thursday, tainted drugs have killed three people and sickened scores of others in two big American cities.

title: Adoptive Parents Deserve Proposed Tax Break
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;British-French Deal To Create Missile Giant
description: The French conglomerate Lagardere Groupe said yesterday that it had an agreement with British Aerospace P.L.C. to merge their missile-making activities into a new 50-50 joint venture, creating Europe's biggest missile manufacturer. The combined company, to be called Matra Bae Dynamics, will have annual sales of slightly more than 10 billion French francs ($1.95 billion), making it the third-biggest missile maker in the world.

title: 4 Nations Back New Jumbo Airbus And Weigh Taking Company Private
description: Ministers from the four member countries of the Airbus Industrie consortium backed proposals Monday to "modernize" the company  perhaps by privatizing it  and develop a jumbo jet airliner to compete with the planned successor to Boeing Co.'s successful 747 jet.

title: Asylum Seeker's Fate
description: To the Editor:

title: It Is Official For Holloway
description: Shaheen Holloway, who announced he would attend Seton Hall in a live cable broadcast last month, has made it official with a national letter of intent.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DAVID GEFFEN, the entertainment entrepreneur and art collector, has donated $5 million to the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, it was announced yesterday.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BOXING;Moorer and Schulz Set for Title Bout
description: The heavyweight championship bout between MICHAEL MOORER and AXEL SCHULZ for the vacant International Boxing Federation title will take place in Dortmund, Germany, on June 22. Schulz's manager, WILFRIED SAUERLAND, made the announcement yesterday, saying Dortmund's Westfalen Stadium was an ideal location for the fight because most of its seats are covered by a roof. The stadium has 42,800 seats for soccer matches, but that could be increased to 60,000 for a fight.

title: Serviced Apartments Cut Into Hotel Business
description: BANGKOK  Andrew McBurnie worries the top brass at Bangkok's luxury hotels. The affable Australian, hired to oversee final construction and opening of the Pan Pacific Hotel Bangkok, broke an unwritten rule of the hotel industry.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;Game 4 Whistles Haunting Van Gundy
description: With his team on the brink of elimination, Jeff Van Gundy did not expound on the dire straits facing the Knicks at the United Center in Chicago on Tuesday night. He was not half as worried about his team's showing up for Game 5 as he was about what happened at the end of Game 4.

title: Apparel Picked As the Target If U.S. Imposes Curbs on China
description: Roughly half the economic sanctions that the United States is preparing to invoke against China later this week will be aimed at clothing imported into the United States, Administration officials said today. The goal, they said, is to focus the penalties on one of Beijing's most lucrative state-owned industries.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Bonds Higher As Economic Data Are Due
description: Treasury securities rose yesterday, in trading that began quietly but gained momentum near the market close while prices were increasing.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Pop CD's;Realities Of Living, Bad and Not
description: Imperial Teen

title: A Performance Shaped by Life
description: Since August Wilson's "Seven Guitars" opened on Broadway in late March, Ruben Santiago-Hudson has been on an emotional roller coaster.

title: THE CRASH IN THE EVERGLADES: THE EQUIPMENT;Fleet Was Old, but Age Alone Is Not Safety Indicator
description: So when is an airplane too old?

title: Merchants Score Off Dodger Pitcher
description: LOS ANGELES  This summer, Los Angeles Dodgers fans will have something in common with merchants in that section of the city called Little Tokyo. Both will be rooting for the continued success of the Japanese pitcher Hideo Nomo.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Standard Life to Trim Bank of Scotland Stake
description: The Standard Life Assurance Company said yesterday that it planned to sell all or part of its 32.2 percent stake in the Bank of Scotland P.L.C. to reduce the concentration of its investment. Analysts said Standard Life, Britain's largest mutual life insurer, would probably retain a substantial stake and sell the remainder to one or more parties.

title: Chess
description: Against a mixed bag of humans, an assortment of some of the best chess computers in the world scored 162 1/2-137 1/2 in the 11th running of the Aegon Tournament in The Hague.

title: COMPANY NEWS;COX TO ACQUIRE OWNER OF 18 AM AND FM RADIO STATIONS
description: Cox Enterprises Inc. said yesterday that its broadcasting unit had agreed to acquire Newcity Communications Inc. of Bridgeport, Conn., for $250 million. Newcity consists of 18 AM and FM radio stations. After the acquisition is completed, the closely held Cox's radio franchise would operate 37 stations. Cox Enterprises, a media company based in Atlanta, is the majority owner of Cox Communications Inc., a cable-television concern.

title: Bulgaria May Close Plants
description: Faced with the worst economic crisis since the collapse of Communism, the Bulgarian Government is debating a plan to close 65 state-run companies employing 29,000 workers.

title: End the Inequities of Campus Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;Avalanche Ousts Blackhawks in Overtime
description: The Colorado Avalanche advanced to the third round of the playoffs for the first time in 11 years, defeating the Chicago Blackhawks, 4-3, tonight on Sandis Ozolinsh's goal 5 minutes 18 seconds into the second overtime.

title: El Popo's Rumblings Draw Volcanologists To Edge of Danger
description: IN 1993, six volcanologists studying the Galeras volcano, a smoky colossus in the Colombian Andes, died when it exploded in a riot of lava, ash and incandescent boulders, some flung miles high. A seventh member of the team gathering data in the crater at the time of the eruption lived to tell about it, though with a fractured skull, crushed ear, broken nose, broken jaw, broken legs and extensive burns.

title: IN PERFORMANCE;POP
description: When the Sun Has Gone to Bed And Only Owls Are Sprightly Merle Haggard Tramps

title: Wasteful Criminal Justice
description: Gov. George Pataki says he is tough on crime and economically conservative. But a big part of his law-and-order program for New York State is not fiscally responsible. He proposes to continue Mario Cuomo's ruinously expensive prison expansion program without seriously testing more cost-effective alternatives.

title: In Washington State, a Candidate Strikes Back at Talk Radio
description: In one of the more extraordinary examples of how talk radio continues to influence political campaigns, Mayor Norm Rice of Seattle today denounced a leading conservative talk-radio station that has been broadcasting rumors that the Mayor was shot by his wife.

title: Everest Takes Worst Toll, Refusing to Become Stylish
description: Around dusk on Saturday, with two American climbers and five others missing and probably already dead atop Mount Everest, a 35-year-old New Zealander made a satellite telephone call to his pregnant wife from a snowhole just below the summit of the world's highest peak.

title: Clinton Thriving in Gentle Glow of TV Lights
description: Lou Young, a reporter for Channel 2 in New York, stood in his trench coat, "live" at Liberty State Park in New Jersey last week, informing viewers at the start of the 6 o'clock news of each tilt and whirl of the Presidential helicopter as it prepared to touch down.

title: Albert Heijn Sets Sights on Jakarta
description: AMSTERDAM  On almost any shopping street in the Netherlands, expect to see an Albert Heijn. This is the Dutch people's supermarket, not the cheapest nor the most expensive but the one intended for the vast middle classes.

title: Panama Amnesty Plan For Abuses Draws Fire
description: It is not every day that Amnesty International feels compelled to oppose a Government's intention to decree a political amnesty. But a plan by Panama's governing party to pardon nearly 1,000 of the worst human rights offenders during the dictatorship of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega has been condemned by human rights groups here and abroad.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day on Wednesday, about an offering of junior shares of Berkshire Hathaway, referred incorrectly to a payment of $10 for each share. It represented a concession paid to the selling group by Berkshire Hathaway; it was not a commission paid by investors when they bought shares through the offering.

title: A Long-Dead German Leftist Has a Rebirth of Sorts
description: Few tears were shed when Germany's best-known urban guerrilla, Ulrike Meinhof, was found dead in her jail cell 20 years ago this month. She had long since lost her personal identity and become a mythical figure, a symbol of either martyred idealism or mindless terror.

title: OLYMPICS: China Produces a U.S. Champion;Kevin Han Is Making the Most of His Second Chance at a Badminton Career
description: Badminton appeared in the United States as a New York society game in the 70's. Unfortunately for Han Qi Chi, it was the 1870's.

title: Butterflies Gain a Fresh Start
description: There were just 17 wild Schaus swallowtail butterflies in existence, all on a small island, when Dr. Thomas C. Emmel, a zoologist, began actively breeding them.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Buccaneers Release Roby and Dawsey
description: The three-time Pro Bowl punter REGGIE ROBY and receiver LAWRENCE DAWSEY were released by Tampa Bay after declining to take pay cuts. Punter TOMMY BARNHARDT and the former Buccaneers receiver CHARLES WILSON were signed to fill the roster spots. (AP)

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Acura Account Put In Review by Honda
description: The American Honda Motor Company said yesterday that it had placed in review the account of its Acura luxury car division, which has been handled for almost 12 years by the Los Angeles office of Ketchum Advertising. Though billings were not disclosed, trade publications estimated them at $120 million to $125 million.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Information Resources takes aim at the ethnic market, and Nielsen.
description: INFORMATION RESOURCES INC., the market-research company, is expected to announce today that it will join forces with Univision, the largest Spanish-language television network in the United States, in an attempt to take the lead in one of the biggest areas of growth in advertising: ethnic marketing.

title: Coke Bottler Expands Role In Europe
description: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc. agreed today to pay $595 million in cash for the Coca-Cola Company's French and Belgian bottling operations.

title: Corporate Secrets
description: Should a company secretly gather personal information about its employees -- including their credit history, what clubs they belong to and their family life? Of course not, but it happens frequently.

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: Major League Soccer

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Dr. Kevorkian on Trial, With Hints of the Future
description: Public crusaders are rarely nuanced thinkers; they can't afford to be. But they usually know the value of drama. "Frontline: The Kevorkian Verdict" opens with the startling image of Dr. Jack Kevorkian walking into the courthouse at his current trial, his head and hands in an old-fashioned wooden pillory. "This is medieval punishment for a medieval concept," he tells reporters, offering an irresistible sound bite and photo op.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Trysts, Seduction, Pursuit and Life's Little Quirks
description: SLOWNESS By Milan Kundera Translated by Linda Asher. 156 pages. HarperCollins. $21.

title: Jury Fails to Decide Florida Mayor's Case
description: Even though it acquitted Mayor Raul L. Martinez of Hialeah, Fla., of a conspiracy charge, a Federal jury in his third racketeering trial today said it had deadlocked on five other counts.

title: IN PERFORMANCE;POP
description: A New and Gentler Voice Prevails in Reggae Fest Buju Banton Theater at Madison Square Garden

title: CUNY Admissions Policy Has a Human Face
description: To the Editor:

title: Star Wars, the Sequel
description: With the movie maker George Lucas working on a new "Star Wars" trilogy, it somehow seems fitting that Washington is locked in a new round of debate about building a missile defense system. Like the last time this fantasy seized the capital under President Reagan, it will be a lot easier and cheaper for Mr. Lucas to equip the rebel alliance and the Galactic Empire with high-tech weaponry to shoot down missiles than for the United States to build the real thing.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about controversy over large-scale composting operations misidentified a neighbor of one such site, in Greenburgh, N.Y. He is Alfred Powell, not Albert Bell.

title: Swedish Deal Is Set for MDT
description: The MDT Corporation has agreed to be acquired by Getinge Industrier A.B., a Swedish maker of hospital and scientific equipment, for about $30.5 million.

title: IN PERFORMANCE;CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: With a Taste for the Arcane And a Flair for Complexity Mc-Andre Hamelin Merkin Concert Hall

title: CHRONICLE
description: Is there a (television) doctor in the house? There will be two on hand this evening at Tavern on the Green when PETER BERG (Dr. Billy Kronk) of CBS's "Chicago Hope" and NOAH WYLE (Dr. John Carter) of NBC's "E.R." appear at a party celebrating a new way to be charitable.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS: NOTEBOOK;Ewing Guarantees a Sixth Game
description: Surrounded by a group of teen-age girls on a field trip from Queens -- many of whom would not let go of him -- Patrick Ewing left SUNY-Purchase today extremely confident. Before he caught a plane to Chicago for Game 5, he was asked about the possibility of the Knicks' returning for Game 6 at Madison Square Garden and said unequivocally that they would.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CANON TO OFFER SOFTWARE AND ANNOUNCE ALLIANCES
description: Canon USA, a maker of copiers and other electronic goods, plans to offer software and announce alliances with other computer makers to link copiers with a host of office systems in a move to compete with the Xerox Corporation. Xerox, the world's largest copier company, introduced systems in October that link printers, scanners and fax machines to a corporation's computer network. A Canon spokesman said yesterday that the company would introduce a standard today for creating digital documents over a network of office systems. Canon also said it planned to introduce software called Netspot. It is also working with others to develop a standard for office systems.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;New Rules for Child Abusers
description: An Assembly committee approved two bills yesterday that were intended to encourage parents convicted of child abuse to seek professional help. One proposal would require abusive parents who are addicted to drugs or alcohol to prove they were in a treatment program before they could get their children back. Under the other measure, the sentencing judge would be required to send an abusive parent to a counselor or order community service to be performed. The bills now go to the full Assembly for a vote.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS;Amid More Rate Talk, Dollar Is Up vs. Mark and Down vs. Yen
description: The dollar fell against the yen yesterday on concern that Japan would raise interest rates in coming months, but it rose against the mark on the view that interest rates in Germany were headed lower.

title: PERIPHERALS;So Simple Only a Child Can Do It
description: NOT having a 6-year-old handy (6 is the suggested minimum age for the Fun With Electronics kit), I had endless trouble setting up the workbench.

title: Caremark and Medpartners Seen Merging
description: Caremark International and Medpartners/Mullikin have agreed to a $2.5 billion merger that would create the nation's largest management company for physician practices, people with knowledge of the deal said last night.

title: Market Place;One way to get a stock moving. Find some bribable brokers.
description: EVER wonder how some brokers decide which small stocks to push to their clients? Federal prosecutors say it is because the brokers get bribed.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Ampolex of Australia Accepts Bid by Mobil
description: The Mobil Corporation said yesterday that Ampolex Ltd. had accepted Mobil's increased offer of $1.78 billion (Australian), or $1.4 billion (United States), to buy Ampolex. For months, Ampolex, an oil company, had been rejecting Mobil's overtures, but it agreed to the latest bid, which represents a 20 percent increase. Ampolex said it would not seek other bids and would urge shareholders to sell to Mobil.

title: No Headline
description: Some of us have been asking: Is it right that an an average climber can order an ascent of Everest out of a catalogue?"

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Japan's Trade Surplus Off 25% in Latest Year
description: Japan's trade surplus tumbled by nearly a quarter in the last year, the Government said yesterday, providing further evidence that Japan's export-driven economy is undergoing a change. The Finance Ministry said the surplus in the current account fell 23.8 percent, to 9.46 trillion yen ($90 billion) in the year that ended on March 31, down for the third consecutive year.

title: COMPANY NEWS;YOUNG AGREES TO BUY TV STATION FROM DISNEY
description: Young Broadcasting Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Los Angeles television station KCAL-TV from the Walt Disney Company for $385 million. The acquisition would more than double the United States television households reached by Young, a broadcaster based in New York, to 9.3 percent from 4.1 percent, and increase its revenue by 40 percent, from $122.5 million last year. Young owns 10 television stations. As part of Disney's $19 billion purchase of Capital Cities /ABC Inc. in February, the company was required by Federal regulators to sell KCAL. It is the only independent TV station in Los Angeles, the nation's No. 2 market after New York. Disney's stock was up $1.50 a share, to $60.75. Young's stock was up $3.375, to $33.125.

title: THE CRASH IN THE EVERGLADES: THE VICTIMS;At the Helm, a Pilot Who Lived to Fly
description: Candalyn Kubeck, the pilot of the Valujet DC-9 whose crash in Florida on Saturday killed all 109 people on board, spent most of her 35 years around pilots, airplanes and airports.

title: Sports of the Times;A No-Name On the Bulls' Hard Court
description: ADAY before Game 3 of the murderous Knicks-Bulls series, Jeff Van Gundy stood in the huge empty gymnasium where the Knicks practice. Practice had been over for nearly an hour, his interviews with the news media had been completed. He'd catch his breath in the gym, then go back to the business of preparing for what some called Mission Impossible: Beating the Chicago Bulls.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TENET HEALTHCARE CORP., Santa Monica, Calif., which owns and operates hospitals, sold its 42 percent stake in Westminster Health Care Ltd. to Cazenove & Co., a London-based brokerage firm, for $120 million.

title: Arbitrators Seek Inquiry Into Prudential Unit's Practices
description: Prudential Securities' problems from its disastrous foray into limited partnership sales in the 1980's are not over yet.

title: Assembly Votes to Scrap 32 School Boards
description: The Democratic-controlled State Assembly passed legislation today that would abolish New York City's 32 community school boards and would restructure the citywide Board of Education.

title: Selling of Yeltsin Hits Obstacles in Heartland
description: The re-election of Boris N. Yeltsin promises to be a hard sell in this downtrodden factory town 200 miles northeast of Moscow.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;Graf Surpasses Navratilova's Reign
description: STEFFI GRAF isn't often impressed by records and rankings, especially her own, but she admitted yesterday from the German Open in Berlin that breaking MARTINA NAVRATILOVA's career record of 331 weeks at No. 1 is a milestone. And a tribute to her tenacity.

title: 'Silver' Starts to Boom in South Korea
description: SEOUL  Many Western families undoubtedly would be pleased to see their elderly parents move into a luxurious retirement village. But for Lee Beom Hong and his wife, moving into La Vie D'Or, a first-class retirement home on the outskirts of Seoul, was tinged with embarrassment.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;The 'Dice' Is Back, And So Is The Act
description: How's this for television delivering the unexpected: feeling sorry for Andrew Dice Clay. This foul-mouthed comic, who made his debut on a 1988 Rodney Dangerfield HBO showcase, ran into a wall of revulsion with the verbal swill he dumped on women, homosexuals, blacks and, it seemed, anyone else who wasn't a swaggering loudmouth from Brooklyn. Mr. Clay was stunned to discover that many viewers and critics were less than thrilled. He wept openly during an excruciatingly memorable appearance on Arsenio Hall's talk show.

title: Inquiry Turns To Chemicals In Jet's Cargo
description: The Valujet DC-9 that crashed in the Everglades on Saturday was carrying as cargo in its forward hold 50 or 60 bottles of chemicals used to make oxygen for emergency masks, the National Transportation Safety Board said tonight, raising the possibility that they caused a fire or explosion. When the bottles make oxygen, by mixing two chemicals, the reaction also produces heat.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AT&T AND UNISOURCE AGREE TO JOIN FORCES IN EUROPE
description: The AT&T Corporation and the Unisource Corporation said yesterday they would combine most of their European activities into one telecommunications and multimedia business. The new company, AT&T-Unisource Services, will have about 5,000 workers and annual revenue of more than $1 billion. Unisource will own 60 percent; AT&T will own 40 percent. Unisource is a joint venture of PTT Telecom Netherlands, Telia of Sweden, Swiss Telecom PTT and Telefonica of Spain.

title: World News Briefs;Lebanese to Hand Over Suspect in Berlin Blast
description: A Palestinian will be extradited to Germany to stand trial in a 1986 Berlin discotheque bombing that killed two American servicemen, Lebanon said today.

title: BASEBALL;'Good Stuff' Is Baffling
description: If it looked as if Dwight Gooden was getting stronger the nearer he came to achieving his no-hitter, that's because he was.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Saturday about a Federal court decision that threw out a huge asbestos settlement misspelled the surname of a New York University Law School professor who was quoted on the case's significance. He is Burt Neuborne, not Newborne.

title: Legal Services Moved Away From Proper Role
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Westdeutsche Bank Says Profits Increased
description: Westdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale, Germany's third-largest bank, said yesterday that its operating profit after risk provisions rose 58.7 percent in the first quarter. Operating profit rose to 400 million marks ($263 million), from 252 million marks in the first quarter of 1995, Friedel Neuber, the bank's chief executive, said.

title: BASEBALL;Mets Needed Wilson. Wilson Needed Help.
description: Sometime in the not so distant future, Paul Wilson will be the life preserver the Mets need to rescue themselves from the type of slump they are currently struggling to escape. But right now, Wilson can't save himself, much less the rest of the tailspinning team.

title: No Headline
description: Americans do want to have these new experiences. They want to eat jalapeno peppers. But they don't want it to hurt." PROFESSOR SIDNEY W. MINTZ, discussing a new, milder salsa. [C1:4]

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Leaving on His Terms, Johnson Retires Again
description: Ending his latest comeback abruptly, Magic Johnson announced his retirement from basketball yesterday, allowing himself and the Los Angeles Lakers to move in different directions after a controversial season.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Favre Says He Abused Painkillers And Will Enter Treatment Center
description: Green Bay quarterback Brett Favre, who was named the most valuable player in the National Football League last season, revealed yesterday that he has voluntarily entered the league's substance-abuse program and will enter a drug treatment facility because of a dependence on painkillers he developed over the last two seasons.

title: Fall of a Shirtmaking Giant Shakes Its Hometown
description: When C. F. Hathaway began making men's shirts out of his house here in 1837, he turned to the farming communities outside the town for cheap labor. The Hathaway shirtmaking company has depended on the labor, and the loyalty, of the women of central Maine ever since.

title: Commercial Free Speech Gets Freer
description: In one of this term's most significant First Amendment cases, the Supreme Court has struck down a Rhode Island ban on advertising liquor prices, thereby strengthening protections for "commercial speech" promoting lawful products. Although it did not address the issue, the Court's decision raises new questions about the constitutionality of the Clinton Administration's proposed restrictions on cigarette promotions.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PHOENIX DUFF & PHELPS PLANS BIG CUTBACKS
description: The Phoenix Duff & Phelps Corporation said yesterday that it planned to sell its money-losing research, financial consulting, investment-banking and retail brokerage businesses to focus on money-management operations. The company will eliminate most of the more than 50 analysts in Chicago and Montpelier, Vt., who provide the stock and bond research it sells to clients. The company will keep only enough researchers to support its own investment-management activities. The investment-management operations became the company's predominant business after the merger of the Phoenix Securities Group and the Duff & Phelps Corporation. Phoenix Duff & Phelps is also negotiating the sale of its financial-consulting and investment-banking businesses to the department's current executives.

title: History Standards Get It Wrong Again
description: In the beginning," wrote the British philosopher John Locke, "all the world was America." In our "beginnings," write the authors of the National History Standards, all of us belonged to pre-Columbia America and Islamic West Africa, and the earliest American settlers were "deeply affected" by the "great convergence"' of Europeans, Africans and Native Americans. Locke believed that America would escape the very conditions of oppression that the standards hail as our "beginnings."

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;Red Wings Stay Alive And Head Back Home
description: Now this gripping and improbable playoff series returns to Detroit for its seventh and final act.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Correction Appended

title: 2.3 Billion Deal Creates Giant In Managing of Doctors' Offices
description: For more than a decade, doctors have complained, to little avail, as employers, managed-care companies and, later, hospitals came together in competing organizations dedicated to squeezing down health care costs -- and, in the process, limiting physicians' incomes and independence.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;Bulls End Another Knick Season and, This Time, an Era
description: Patrick Ewing, a white towel slung over his head like a turban, led a slow funeral procession from the bench, along the sideline and off the floor. Derek Harper, Charles Oakley, John Starks and a lingering Anthony Mason -- slowly working his way through the jubilant people clad in red and black around him -- followed behind.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;ITT Accounts Placed in Review
description: The ITT Corporation has placed in review the accounts of its international lodging and entertainment properties, which include the Sheraton hotel chain and Madison Square Garden. The accounts, with combined billings estimated at $40 million, are now handled by four agencies, including two in New York owned by BDDP Worldwide, Wells Rich Greene BDDP and Moss/Dragoti.

title: The Play's the Thing, for Directors, Too
description: Before he was named artistic director of Lincoln Center Theater, Andre Bishop was head of Playwrights Horizons. The Lincoln Center Theater Directors' Lab, now in its second season, could be, he said, the beginning of directors' horizons.

title: The Safety of Low-Cost Airlines
description: Four days after crashing in the Florida Everglades, an airliner with a long and checkered maintenance history remains a focus of shock, mystery and anxiety to the public and commercial aviation. Sunk in a swamp only minutes from the Miami airport, the wreckage of the DC-9 resists strenuous efforts to recover its remains and learn its secrets. Investigators and officials, some quarreling openly with each other, can promise only that the answers will not come quickly.

title: Rowland Says Hartford Whalers Will Stay
description: Gov. John G. Rowland said tonight that the Hartford Whalers would be staying in Connecticut, honoring their commitment to remain in the state for two more years.

title: Columbia Gives Awards to 2 at The Times
description: Gene Roberts, managing editor of The New York Times, has been awarded the 1996 Columbia Journalism Award, the highest honor given by Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism, the university announced yesterday.

title: The Gift These Greeks Bore: Western Culture
description: It is not clear whether it was war, hunger, natural disaster or oracular edict that prompted the Aegeans to start settling in southern Italy and Sicily around 750 B.C. But it is likely they did so more as Pilgrim Fathers than as Spanish conquistadors, more as colonizers than as empire builders. The evidence suggests they were seeking farming land and greater freedom rather than booty to send home.

title: World News Briefs;Climbers Free of Danger, Everest Rescuers Report
description: Climbers straggled off Mount Everest in clear weather today after a blizzard in which at least eight people died, rescuers and mountaineers said.

title: TV NOTES;Signs of Life
description: Jim Carrey will be the host of this week's season finale of "Saturday Night Live," and the show expects to ride Mr. Carrey's popularity to its biggest rating in many years.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Love-Starved Royalty, Partial to Babushkas
description: No one plays the Princess of Wales nearly as well as the Princess of Wales, and most commoners shouldn't even try. The latest attempt comes in a hideous television movie called "Princess in Love," about her romance with Capt. James Hewitt, who started out as her riding instructor, became her lover and eventually sold the story of their affair to a tabloid. Because the film is based on Anna Pasternak's book of the same name, written with Mr. Hewitt's help, it glosses over that last nasty detail.

title: L.I. Teen-Ager Is Found Slain Near Her Home
description: The body of a 16-year-old high school senior whose family reported her missing after she failed to return home on Sunday night was found shortly before noon today hidden behind shrubbery just down the street from her home on Cedar Road in East Northport.

title: Boom in Ritalin Sales Raises Ethical Issues
description: AFTER 30 years of use, sales of the stimulant Ritalin are booming, and medical professionals say the increased use is causing them to confront an issue that keeps dogging the the age of pharmacology: how far does society want to go in efforts to enhance human abilities?

title: Conoco Talks With Phillips About a Deal
description: Conoco Inc. and the Phillips Petroleum Company said yesterday that they were in talks to combine their gasoline refining and marketing businesses.

title: The Black and the Red Of Goetz's Balance Sheet
description: On the plus side are a $320 wardrobe, some electronic equipment, a pet chinchilla and guinea pig valued together at $130, and about $500 in cash. In all, about $17,000 in assets.

title: PLAIN AND SIMPLE;A Curry That's Flexible
description: When making a curry, you can vary the ingredients as well as the spices. If there is anything in this recipe that is not appealing, just substitute something you prefer.

title: Companies Risk Losing Billions of Dollars, Economic Chief Says : From Beijing, a Forceful Warning
description: JAKARTA  China's top economic policymaker warned Tuesday that if the United States carried out its threat to impose sanctions on Chinese goods, it risked starting a trade war that would cost American companies billions of dollars.

title: Vote Dares Olympics To Reroute The Torch
description: The Olympic torch, an international symbol of peace and nonpartisanship, has once again ignited political discord. This time, it has happened in Spartanburg, S.C., where county leaders on Monday night effectively dared Olympics officials to route the torch relay around the city by passing a resolution that condemns homosexuality.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasuries Up As Inflation Stays Benign
description: Treasury prices surged yesterday after a report on consumer prices showed inflation continuing to be benign.

description: Baseball

title: Okinawan Landlords Seek To Evict U.S. Military Bases
description: One of the most secretive American military installations in Asia is "the elephants' cage," a vast circle of steel towers used to eavesdrop on Chinese and North Korean military communications.

title: Dole to Wait on Naming Running Mate
description: Senator Bob Dole has decided to wait until the Republican National Convention in August to name his running mate, his aides said today. The decision ends weeks of internal discussion in his campaign over whether an earlier announcement would give the Senator a political boost before the convention.

title: In Performance;CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Trio's New York Debut Features Three Rarities Notre Dame String Trio Weill Recital Hall

description: Correction Appended

title: Soldiers, Spies and Statesmen Bid Adieu to Ex-C.I.A. Chief
description: Veterans of wars won and lost, secret and overt, gathered today at the National Cathedral to pay tribute to William E. Colby, the former Director of Central Intelligence.

title: ON PRO BASKETBALL;Huffing Away to Close The Generation Gap
description: On the day that Magic Johnson again said he had enough, Michael Jordan retired another 1980's contemporary from the playoffs one more time. The more things change, the more they remain the same.

description: Added Ice-Cream Starter

description: HOW STELLA GOT HER GROOVE BACK By Terry McMillan 368 pages. Viking. $23.95

title: COMPANY NEWS;ASARCO SELLS REMAINING STAKE IN M.I.M.
description: Asarco Inc., a New York-based mining company, said yesterday that it had sold its remaining 15 percent stake in M. I. M. Holdings Ltd. of Australia to institutional investors for $331.2 million. As a result of the sale, Asarco will record an after-tax gain of $39 million, or 91 cents a share, in the quarter ending June 30. The company said that the sale would cut annual interest expenses by about $21 million. In its second quarter last year, Asarco earned $56.4 million, or $1.34 a share. Asarco took control of M. I. M. in 1930, when the mining company was struggling to develop its lead and copper deposits in Queensland. Asarco has steadily reduced its stake since then. Asarco shares rose $1.375 yesterday, to $34.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: HORSE RACING;Handlers of Unbridled's Song Play It Safe, So He Won't Run in Preakness
description: Saying that "at this point, there is too much risk," the trainer Jim Ryerson announced today that Unbridled's Song, the beaten favorite in the Kentucky Derby, will not compete here Saturday in the 121st Preakness Stakes.

title: Dial Picks Chief For Its New Unit
description: The Dial Corporation named a new chief executive yesterday for its consumer-products business, which will be spun off later this year.

title: World News Briefs;Western Sahara Vote Is Put in Doubt by U.N.
description: The United Nations has begun closing voter registration offices in the disputed Western Sahara, officials said today, making it unlikely that a long-delayed referendum on the region's future will take place.

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;Surprising Panthers Eliminate the Flyers
description: So much for Eric Lindros's guarantee of victory. And so much for the upstart Florida Panthers' glaring lack of playoff experience.

title: Benign Chaos in India
description: The spirited jockeying for power since India's election is proving difficult even for insiders to follow. But as countless political blocs trade votes and float possible candidates for prime minister, it appears likely that an alliance of centrist and leftist parties will try to form a government, shutting the main Hindu chauvinist party out of power even though it received the most votes. For all the confusion, the horse-trading is reassuring. Politics is the force that binds India together.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Hit the Road, Jack Frost
description: Four years ago, frost on May 21 destroyed almost half of New Jersey's blueberry crop. This year, farmers are not taking any chances. At the Atlantic Blueberry Corporation in Hammonton, growers irrigated for 12 hours Monday night in an effort to raise temperatures, The Associated Press reported. Other growers covered seedlings with baskets.

title: Wine Talk;Frank J. Prial
description: AMERICANS drink four times as much wine per person as they did at the turn of the century. But it doesn't amount to much compared with the rest of the wine-drinking world, and it does not seem likely to increase much in the near future.

title: A Lot of Night Music: The Summer Lineups
description: A summer of music has begun to take shape as some of New York City's top concert presenters have announced their schedules.

description: To The Living Section:

title: O.J. Simpson at Oxford: Some Aye Votes by Students, Some Nay
description: It was presented as an effort at public rehabilitation, an attempt to restore some of the old luster to his tarnished image. And when O.J. Simpson came to argue his case before the venerable Oxford Union tonight, he found that as poor as his status is at home after his double murder trial last year, he can still impress an audience abroad.

title: Corrections
description: The About Real Estate column on May 3, about the construction of condominium residences on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, misspelled the name of a company that is helping develop one such project, the Siena. It is Quinlan & Field Inc., not Quilan & Field.

title: Marine Midland Deal
description: The Marine Midland Bank said today that it had acquired two New York branches of Hang Seng Bank Ltd. for $49.1 million. Both Marine Midland and Hang Seng are part of the HSBC Group. The two branches, which have combined assets of $45 million, will continue to operate as Hang Seng Bank USA but will be part of HSBC's Marine Midland division.

description: NOW and then, you make a decision that changes your life. You marry, get divorced, change jobs, take up boxing.

description: Dwight Gooden inhaled, then he exhaled. He wiped the sweat off his forehead, then adjusted his cap. He gazed at Joe Girardi's fingers for a signal, then threw another memorable pitch. Over and over, Gooden repeated this simple yet tense routine. So precise, so powerful, so perfect.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Miller Unit to End BBDO Toronto Link
description: BBDO Toronto and the Plank Road Brewery, a division of the Miller Brewing Company that markets specialty beer brands like Red Dog, have agreed to part ways after working together since September 1994. Billings on the Plank Road account were not disclosed, but Adweek estimated them at $57 million.

description: To the Editor:

title: Defendant in Killing Fails to Appear
description: A Queens man who is to be retried for the 1990 murder of a gay man failed to appear for a court hearing yesterday, and the judge revoked his $350,000 bail and ordered his arrest.

description: TENNIS

title: About New York;Safer City Threatens Unlucky Few
description: DR. MEHMET OZ doesn't always share the newly found sense of elation and security felt by those who take half-empty subways late at night or walk home through sometimes daunting neighborhoods. The 25 percent drop in the city's murder rate last year isn't necessarily good for his profession. No, he's not a gun runner or undertaker.

description: Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania today joined other moderate Republican Governors who want to change the party platform's strict language against all abortions.

title: As Delis Dwindle, Traditions Lose Bite;Kosher Is Hard to Find As Jewish Populations Fall in Neighborhoods
description: At Grabstein's Delicatessen in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn, the pastrami is as moist and peppery as ever and the waiter Harvey Wyler still needles the notoriously demanding customers. But the hustle-bustle days when several waiters pirouetted among the teeming Formica tables and takeout lines would snake along the steamy glass display case are gone.

title: Journal;Choose or Lose
description: If there's one sure-fire way that Bob Dole can jump-start his campaign, narrow the 18 percent gender gap and look like a President, it's to seize control of the abortion issue from the far right in his own party. As James Greenwood, a G.O.P. Congressman from Pennsylvania, puts it: "The plank in our platform represents the most extreme position available on this issue -- that the Constitution ought to be changed to ban abortion. It's a position embraced by a minuscule proportion of the country and a minuscule number of Republicans."

title: Corrections
description: Many of the commodity futures tables in Business Day yesterday included erroneous figures supplied by The Associated Press. The affected futures contracts were those on Eurodollar deposits, all Treasury securities, cotton, crude oil, unleaded gasoline, heating oil, natural gas and all currencies. The futures tables today report changes from the correct Monday prices.

title: Government Gives Millions to Olympics
description: The Federal Government is spending $227 million over five years to support the Olympic Games in Atlanta, mostly for security and transportation, Vice President Al Gore said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 22 about President Clinton's veto of a bill outlawing a form of late-term abortion rendered a word incorrectly in citing a Vatican statement that condemned the veto. The Vatican referred to "an incredibly brutal act of aggression against innocent human life," not "an incredibly painful act."

title: Playing Two Marilyns, The Iconic, the Unloved
description: Marilyn Monroe would have been 70 on June 1. More than 30 years after her death, she remains the quintessential Hollywood icon, a woman of uncommon beauty and tragedy who seems forever young.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: * Flagstar Cos., Spartanburg, S.C., to Siboney USA, Dallas, as the first agency to handle advertising and marketing aimed at Spanish-speaking consumers for the Denny's restaurant chain, which Flagstar owns. Billings were not disclosed. * Swissotel Management Ltd., New York, a division of Swissair, to Yesawich, Pepperdine & Brown, Orlando, Fla., to handle advertising for the hotel chain, previously handled by Leslie Evans Creative, Atlanta. Billings were estimated at $2 million to $3 million. * TCI Communications, Denver, a unit of Tele-Communications Inc., to Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor, New York, as the first agency to handle corporate branding and digital television assignments. Billings have not been determined.

title: Conagra Plan To Shut Plants And Cut Jobs
description: Conagra Inc., the giant food and agricultural company, said yesterday that it planned to eliminate about 6,500 jobs and to close or reconfigure 29 production plants, resulting in a charge against earnings of $350 million.

title: Foreign Affairs;Lebanon's Aftermath
description: It takes only a few hours in the Arab world to sense that Israel has done enormous damage to its standing among moderate Arab regimes by the way it handled the recent war in Lebanon and the shelling of Lebanese refugees at Qana.

title: BASEBALL;Mets' Harnisch Is Suspended
description: Mets pitcher Pete Harnisch was handed an eight-game suspension today for his involvement in a bench-clearing brawl with the Chicago Cubs on Saturday at Shea Stadium. The Mets' bullpen coach, Steve Swisher, received a two-game suspension, which he began serving tonight. Harnisch has filed an appeal.

title: Zagreb Journal;In the Balkans, Three Languages Now Fight It Out
description: The guns have fallen silent and war crimes investigators have begun rooting around in muddy fields. But there remains, in the academies and the press, a fierce and unrelenting war about language.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Corn Prices Retreat on Forecasts Of Improved Planting Weather
description: Corn prices fell yesterday after weather forecasts showed improved conditions for planting, though an Agriculture Department economist warned of isolated shortages before the crop arrives.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Japan Rejects Plan By U.S. on Insurance
description: Japan rejected United States proposals yesterday on measures to be taken by Tokyo to liberalize the insurance market. On the first day of two-day talks in Tokyo, Washington made fresh proposals on the markets for primary life and nonlife insurance and also on so-called third-sector insurance for sickness, accident and nursing, where foreign companies are strong.

title: TEACHERS' UNION AND MAYOR AGREE ON NEW CONTRACT
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the union representing New York City's public school teachers agreed yesterday on a new labor contract that is largely similar to one the teachers rejected in December. The main difference is a few sweeteners that union leaders say will help secure ratification next month.

title: A Supporting Actor Takes Center Stage;But Few People Really Doubt Who Is Boss at Liberty Media
description: Peter Barton has always belonged to what he calls the "squadron of the second bananas." Few outside the cable industry know who he is -- and those inside it know him best as the right-hand man to his mentor, John C. Malone, the most powerful figure in the business.

title: Crash Stirs Safety Debate Within U.S. Department
description: The fatal crash of the Valujet DC-9 near Miami on Saturday has set off an unusual public debate within the Transportation Department over the safety of airplanes operated by Valujet and the other low-cost airlines that have seized a share of the market over the past decade.

title: Barnard Protesters Caused Major Disruption
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;AFTER TWO BIDS, EFFORT TO BUY SCITEX IS WITHDRAWN
description: Davidi Gilo, a high-technology entrepreneur who made a $1 billion offer for the Scitex Corporation, said yesterday that he had withdrawn the bid because directors of the company, an Israeli maker of computer-imaging systems, refused to negotiate. Mr. Gilo, the chairman of DSP Communications Inc., a chip maker, offered in March to buy Scitex for $20 a share, or $856 million. He raised the bid in April to $25 a share. Mr. Gilo said that board members of Scitex had bought more than one million Scitex shares since his offer in an effort to "thwart our proposal." He said he remained open to discussions. Scitex officials were not immediately available for comment. Scitex shares fell 50 cents, to $17.375, in Nasdaq trading.

title: CHRONICLE
description: As a young boy, E. Y. Harburg, the lyricist, spent much of his time in the New York Public Library's Tompkins Square Branch, near his home on the Lower East Side.

title: COMPANY NEWS;WELLCARE MANAGEMENT RESTATES INCOME FOR TWO YEARS
description: Wellcare Management Group Inc. restated yesterday its financial results for 1995 and 1994, following complaints by shareholders who contended that the company's accounting practices were misleading. The move also comes as the Nasdaq stock market is reviewing its decision to drop the company because of its failure to file an annual report with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Wellcare, a health maintenance organization, said on Feb. 14 that it had net income of $7.8 million, or $1.25 a share, in 1995. Yesterday, the company restated that figure as $1.67 million, or 27 cents a share. The restatement reflected, in part, $2 million in licensing revenue that was recorded as revenue before it had been received. Wellcare, based in Kingston, N.Y., also restated 1994 results to show net income of $3.4 million, or 56 cents a share, down from the originally reported figures of $6.2 million, or $1 a share.

title: COMPANY NEWS;STARWOOD LODGING TO BUY 8 HOTELS FROM PENSION FUND
description: Starwood Lodging Trust agreed yesterday to buy eight full-service hotels for $309 million from the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association, a leading pension fund. The eight hotels, which have 3,141 rooms, are the pension fund's entire holdings in that industry. The deal will raise Starwood's hotel holdings to 65 properties with 16,741 rooms. The properties include the Ritz Carltons in Philadelphia and Kansas City; the Westin Hotel Waltham in suburban Boston; Doubletree hotels in Atlanta, Los Angeles, San Diego and Bloomington, Minn., and the Sheraton Fort Lauderdale Airport Hotel in Dania, Fla. Teachers Insurance, in conjunction with the College Retirement Equities Fund, is the largest pension system in the nation.

title: Real Estate;Paine Webber signs up for another tour, complete with tax incentives from New York City.
description: PAINE WEBBER has renegotiated and renewed its lease for 585,000 square feet at 1285 Avenue of the Americas, its world headquarters, where it is the anchor tenant in what is also known as the Paine Webber Building.

title: For Big Tips, Los Angeles Comes In Last
description: THE City of Philadelphia, which once led the nation in democracy, lightning rod production and popular aphorisms, can now claim another first.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Judge Demands TV Tapes
description: Last July, Jeffrey Wolf appeared on Fox Television's "America's Most Wanted" program and said that he accidentally shot and killed his wife, Brenda, during a holdup the previous March at his jewelry store in Franklin Township.

title: U.S.-CHINA TALKS OVER PIRACY FAIL
description: Two days of last-ditch talks ended today without resolving the wide differences that remain between China and the United States over Chinese pirating of software, music and movies, and the discord drew the two nations ever closer to a trade war.

title: Eating Well
description: WHEN someone says, "I'll just have a salad," the implication is that something light and simple is desired. But Americans have a way of adding fat and calories to a once-healthful dish, and a salad is no exception. The base may still be lettuce, but the topping might include loads of blue cheese and bacon bits.

title: Remembrance of Cheap Meals Past
description: TO most Americans, France, and particularly Paris, seems immutable, unchanging, wedded to past glory. In many ways that is so -- but not when it comes to restaurants. A comparison between the Michelin guide for 1996 and the same guide for 1971 shows that the only thing constant on the Paris restaurant scene is change.

title: Personal Health
description: DEPRESSION surrounds people with a life-draining cloud that typically saps their joy, energy and desire for work, play, food and sex. Once recognized and properly treated, depression can usually be relieved, restoring the zest for life and all it has to offer. Depression can be lifted in two-thirds to three-fourths of patients by antidepressant medications, including the tricyclics, like Elavil, Tofranil and Wellbutrin; monoamine-oxidase (MAO) inhibitors, like Nardil and Marplan, and the newer selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (S.S.R.I.'s) like Prozac, Zoloft and Paxil. In February alone, 3.4 million prescriptions were issued for the serotonin-reuptake inhibitors.

title: President Appoints New Board Members For Troubled Fund
description: President Clinton has appointed a new board of directors to decide the future of a troubled Government fund that is supposed to promote capitalism in the Czech Republic and Slovakia by investing in private companies.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Voters Abolish Union District
description: Voters in six Union County communities voted yesterday to abolish their regional high school system and place it in the hands of local school boards.

title: U.S. and Hanoi Agree to Give Boat People One Last Chance
description: The Clinton Administration and Hanoi have reached an agreement to allow several thousand Vietnamese now living in refugee camps in Southeast Asia to resettle in the United States, provided they first return to Vietnam and apply in writing.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bank Lending Rate Is Cut in Belgium
description: The Belgian central bank reduced the central rate, the main lending rate for commercial banks that trade Belgian Government debt, to 3.2 percent yesterday from 3.3 percent. The rate is now below Germany's minimum securities repurchase rate, which has been at 3.3 percent since February.

title: ON PRO BASKETBALL;It's Time for the Knicks to Break Their Pattern
description: The Knicks were close, but yet so far.

title: U.S. and Japan Say No to Any Food Aid For North Korea Now
description: The United States and Japan ruled out today sending immediate food aid to North Korea despite warnings that its food supply is "perilously close to collapse."

title: On China, Sanctions and Scolding Won't Work
description: To the Editor:

title: India Alliance Drops Communist as Its Candidate for Premier
description: Efforts to form a government that can block Hindu nationalists from power took an unexpected turn today when an alliance of centrist, leftist and regional groups dropped India's top Communist leader as its nominee for Prime Minister and selected a little-known regional leader instead.

title: TV NOTES;WB Grows
description: The network known as "The WB," for its Warner Brothers roots, will grow to three nights a week from two next season, its executives said yesterday, adding new shows that stick to its formula of appealing to teen-agers, young families and an "urban-ethnic" audience.

title: Domino' Transplant Fails and a Girl Dies
description: The teen-ager who, in an unusual operation last month, received a transplanted liver and a large and small intestine and then gave her own healthy liver to a third patient, has died.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Chrebet Won't Be Counted Out
description: Forget those million-dollar receivers the Jets acquired in their lust for a bigger passing game.

title: Magellan Fund Chief Explains Cautious Strategy
description: The portfolio manager of Fidelity Magellan, the nation's largest mutual fund, said worries about "considerable speculation in the stock market over all" led him to make a controversial shift last year of nearly one-third of the fund's $56 billion in assets out of stocks and into bonds and cash.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;Robinson Shrugs Off Slump To Lead Spurs to Victory
description: David Robinson recovered from a two-game slump with 24 points and 15 rebounds to lead the Spurs past the Utah Jazz, 98-87, tonight as San Antonio avoided playoff elimination.

title: INSIDE
description: Of Horses and Tax Codes

title: Russian Polls: Mostly Wrong, But the Only Game in Town
description: With one month left before this anguished nation chooses its next President, public opinion polls -- which have never come close to predicting Russian voting patterns -- are now among the country's principal obsessions.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;J. C. Penney's Income Down; Wal-Mart Advances by 3.3%
description: Several retailers reported strong earnings for the first quarter today. But J. C. Penney continued to show weakness, posting its sixth consecutive quarterly drop in earnings.

title: German Court Upholds Laws to Restrict Aliens
description: In a ruling condemned by opponents as a defeat for human rights, Germany's highest court today upheld strict regulations intended to restrict the number of foreigners gaining refuge in this country.

title: Sports of The Times;These Guys Won't Vanish Too Easily
description: I'LL believe it when I see it. That's all I'm saying. It's easy to say this is the end of the New York Knicks as we know and love them, but I'm not convinced.

title: Child-Welfare Caseworkers Stage a City Hall Protest
description: The disciplining of two child-welfare workers for their failures in the case of Elisa Izquierdo, the 6-year-old girl beaten to death last year, has exposed a deep current of bitterness among New York City's 1,300 caseworkers and front-line supervisors, and union and city officials say the anger has the potential to derail efforts to overhaul the badly flawed child protection agency.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When DAVID OTT receives his medical degree today from Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, he will be a physician with a rare professional specialty: fish cuisine.

title: In Performance;CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Schubert and Sondheim In a Lunch-Hour Concert Arianna Zukerman, soprano Neil Michaels, baritone Bryant Park

title: Beyond the Crash Site
description: Saturday's crash of a Valujet DC-9 is raising questions about safety precautions taken by new airlines entering the competition of commercial aviation. A Federal Aviation Administration memo revealed that Valujet planes had previously experienced serious mishaps, including an engine fire last year that burst into the passenger cabin on an Atlanta runway.

title: Clinton Transcript Is as Good as Video
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about the killing of an Israeli misstated the location of the attack. It was in the West Bank, not in Israel.

title: COMPANY NEWS;LOCKHEED MARTIN WINS SUBMARINE SYSTEMS CONTRACT
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation said yesterday that it had received a contract potentially worth $1 billion to provide communications and intelligence systems for the Navy's new attack submarine. The company said that its Lockheed Martin Federal Systems subsidiary, based in Manassas, Va., would deliver the first system in November 2000. The submarine is to begin sea trials in 2004. Subcontractors are the Northrop Grumman Corporation and the Raytheon Company. Lockheed said the contract's base period runs to November 2000, with three options for more systems.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;General Motors retools its corporate advertising to promote itself as a brand worth sticking with.
description: WHO would have thought that advertising for the General Motors Corporation would one day echo an anthem for hippies?

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;Pippen's Offense Is Back, and It's the Final Nail
description: Scottie Pippen just needed to loosen up a little, undo the tie that had been constraining his shot, unknot the pain in his back.

title: Times Co. in Deal to Buy 2 TV Stations
description: preliminary agreement to buy television stations in Oklahoma City and Des Moines from Palmer Communications Inc. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Fake Label Factory Is Raided
description: Federal and Middlesex County agents raided a Perth Amboy warehouse yesterday and seized hundreds of bogus designer items, including fake lambskin Chanel handbags, Nike sneakers and Ralph Lauren shirts, prosecutors said.

title: Nasdaq Weighs Tighter Rules For Listing Small Stocks
description: The Nasdaq stock market, under fire for trading some low-quality companies, said yesterday that it would "undertake a thorough review" of how its listing standards for small stocks should be tightened.

title: TV NOTES;Tesh Moves On
description: John Tesh, who for the past 10 years has been one of the two anchors on "Entertainment Tonight," has told Paramount, the show's owner, that he is not renewing his contract, which expires June 1.

title: In Performance;THEATER
description: Groucho's Body Language And an Irving Berlin Score 'The Cocoanuts' American Jewish Theater

title: Jury Acquits Kevorkian in Common-Law Case
description: Dr. Jack Kevorkian today was found not guilty of violating Michigan common law against assisted suicide, closing two cases that his lawyers said were by far the most significant of the five acquittals he has won at three trials.

title: A Frustrated Dole Temporarily Halts Minimum-Wage Talks
description: Senate negotiators haggling over a vote on a minimum-wage increase hit another snag today when Democrats demanded that House Republicans avoid loading their version of the bill with amendments unacceptable to the White House.

title: Sports of The Times;Struggles Give Way to Gooden No-Hitter
