description: Paul Sorrento swung, the pop-up soared into the sky above Yankee Stadium and on the mound Dwight Gooden soared into the sky with it.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;520 Deadbeat Parents Held
description: When a knock on the door came at 1 A.M., Donald Lawton of Englewood jumped out a window, the Bergen County Sheriff's office said. But like hundreds of others identified by the authorities as deadbeat parents, Mr. Lawton -- who owes $3,460 in child support and was not injured in his foiled escape, according to officials -- was brought to justice yesterday.

title: Class Notes
description: For Beverly Chell, the vice chairman of K-III Communications, the media conglomerate, it took only a few hours as "principal for a day" to decide to form a publishers' movement to give each of the city's one million public school students a new, free book.

title: A Judge Cites New York City For Contempt
description: Four years after New York City was first fined for housing the homeless in a city office in the Bronx, a Manhattan judge said yesterday that the problem appeared worse than ever and she held Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and two city agencies in contempt of court. The judge also levied fines that a lawyer for the homeless said would exceed $1 million.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Man Killed in I-80 Crash
description: A 37-year-old Bayonne man was killed yesterday when his car drifted across three lanes on Interstate 80 and slammed into a stand of trees, the police said. Eastbound traffic was delayed for more than an hour after the 12:10 P.M. accident, said Trooper Al Della Fave, a spokesman for the state police.

title: Music, Song and Even Tennis Are Returning to Forest Hills
description: Forest Hills Stadium once thundered with cheers at some of the finest tennis in the world. For the better part of a decade, only the memories have echoed.

title: F.D.A. Approves Home AIDS Test; Marketing Is to Begin in June
description: The Food and Drug Administration today approved the first home screening test for H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS.

title: AT LUNCH WITH: Juliette Binoche;A Very Private Actress Discovers The Incredible Lightness of Fame
description: FORTUNATELY, it was Juliette Binoche's idea to have lunch in Au Bon Saint Pourcain, because the little Left Bank bistro was not having a good day. Her first choice for each course -- foie gras, cassoulet and mille-feuilles -- was unavailable. "Ce n'est pas possible," she grumbled good-naturedly. "What's going on?" But in truth, she did not care. "I like the place anyway," she whispered. "It's so friendly."

title: Democrats Vow to Block Pataki's Crime Proposals
description: The Democratic leaders of the State Assembly said today that they would block two sweeping proposals that Gov. George E. Pataki had pushed as part of his effort to give more power to prosecutors, and to restrain judges who he believes are too sympathetic to defendants.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Fort Dix Inmate Escapes
description: An inmate serving a 16-year sentence on a drug conviction escaped from the Federal prison Monday afternoon while on a work detail, the A.P. reported yesterday. Gabriel Ramirez-Nazar was the the seventh inmate to escape from the low-security prison since it opened less than four years ago, prison officials said.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Midlands Stake Sold To Rivals by Powergen
description: Powergen P.L.C., blocked in its efforts to buy Midlands Electricity P.L.C., said yesterday that it had sold its stake of nearly 21 percent in the company to the successful United States bidders for L353.4 million ($530.1 million). Powergen said it made a pretax profit of L69 million ($103.5 million) on the sale to the Cinergy Corporation and the General Public Utilities Corporation, which have agreed to buy Midlands for L1.73 billion ($2.59 billion).

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. China-Talks Fail; Trade War Grows Closer Two days of last-ditch talks between Chinese and American negotiators ended without resolving the wide differences over Chinese pirating of software, music and movies.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FACING HARASSMENT SUIT, MITSUBISHI HIRES INVESTIGATOR
description: The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation has hired a former Labor Secretary, Lynn Martin, to investigate charges of widespread sexual harassment at its assembly plant in Normal, Ill., and to devise procedures to improve the treatment of women there. The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission sued Mitsubishi in April, contending that hundreds of women employees were groped and harassed by male co-workers. Ms. Martin, accompanied by the company's chairman, Tsuneo Ohinouye, said she would assemble a team of fact-finding experts and then present Mitsubishi with blueprints for insuring that female workers would be treated properly.

title: POP REVIEW;Sharing Private Thoughts With a Crowd of Intimates
description: Tori Amos's concert on Monday night at the Theater at Madison Square Garden could almost have been one long song: a free-floating reverie set to classical piano arabesques. Her voice drifted through the ages of woman -- girlish and creaky, innocent and jaded, whimsical and bitter, mournful and flirtatious -- as she burbled a stream of memories and fantasies.

title: World News Briefs;London Orders a Review Of Guerrilla Convictions
description: The Government ordered a review of several years' worth of guerrilla convictions today after the discovery that equipment used to identify explosives in a string of bomb cases was contaminated.

title: Batch of Nearly Pure Heroin Causes 8 Overdoses and 1 Death
description: A batch of dangerously potent heroin sold in upper Manhattan during the last week has led to eight overdoses and at least one death, the police said yesterday.

title: Energy Costs Pushed Consumer Prices Up 0.4% in April
description: Energy prices registered their biggest monthly increase in nearly six years during April, the Government reported yesterday. But despite the rise, caused largely by higher gasoline prices, the report showed that the underlying rate of consumer inflation remained in check.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the calendar of events of the Long Island Weekly on Sunday about an exhibition of Civil War paintings and an encampment at Chelsea Center in East Norwich misstated the date. The events will be on Saturday from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M.; they were not held on Sunday.

title: Agriculture Dept. Rebuffed on School Lunches
description: In school cafeterias throughout the United States, the vexing issue of the day has been fat.

title: Corning to Spin Off Labs and Drug Unit
description: Corning Inc. said yesterday that it would spin off its laboratory-testing and pharmaceutical-services businesses to shareholders, creating two additional, independent companies.

title: Making Jalapenos For Tender Tongues
description: IT is the product of a five-year, top-secret research project, carried out in a greenhouse in this remote central Texas town and on a pepper field in Hawaii. The code name was Operation Big Chill.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FOR DISNEY, A SOFTWARE STUDIO AND DEVELOPMENT TOOLS
description: The Walt Disney Company said yesterday that it had acquired an entertainment software studio and proprietary software development tools from the Sanctuary Woods Multimedia Corporation of San Mateo, Calif. Terms were not disclosed. Disney said the studio, in Victoria, British Columbia, became available when Sanctuary Woods focused development solely on the curriculum-based education products produced at its Toronto and San Mateo studios. Disney said most of the 36 employees at the studio in Victoria would be retained. Disney, based in Burbank, Calif., said Disney Interactive, its software unit, would use the studio to develop four to six software titles a year.

title: Correction
description: An editorial on Monday about New York City debt incorrectly described what revenues would pay off the bonds of a proposed new financing agency. The revenue would come from the city's entire personal income tax, not just the income tax surcharge.

title: For Searchers, Sweat and Exhaustion
description: They walk shoulder-to-shoulder tied to a safety line, searching the marsh for fragments of an airplane, any one of which might provide clues to the cause of the crash. They search for human remains, enough to allow each of the 109 victims to be identified so relatives can give them proper burials.

title: In Performance;  DANCE
description: High Heels and Washtubs, Visions and Reality Wyoming Dance Theater Project Merce Cunningham Studio

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;A Camera Examines the Nuances of Vermeer's Genius
description: You would think that Vermeer would be among the last artists whose works would lend themselves to a television special. Even first-rate photography can't recapture the signature style of this 17th-century Dutch master: the astonishing delicacy of his paintings, with their complex play of light and rich use of shadows. But "Vermeer in America: A Charlie Rose Special," a tour of last winter's blockbuster show at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, makes terrific use of what the camera can do to guide the eye and magnify details. Engrossing and lively, "Vermeer in America" offers a vicarious chance to visit a show for which the term "once in a lifetime" is no exaggeration.

title: Barnard Protesters Caused Major Disruption
description: To the Editor:

title: Suburban Snobbery
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Big Swiss Breweries Plan a Merger
description: Two of Switzerland's biggest breweries announced yesterday that they would merge to form a company with yearly sales of more 1 billion Swiss francs, or $800 million. Feldschloesschen Holding A.G. and Huerlimann Holding A.G. said in a joint statement that they hoped to protect their market share from foreign companies.

title: Army Agreed to Consider Black Veterans' View
description: To the Editor:

title: Giuliani Urges His Top Donors To End Cynicism in New York
description: With 1,300 of his biggest campaign contributors arrayed before him in a sea of candlelight and filet mignon, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani last night demanded an end to cynicism in New York City, insisting that the city's problems are solvable.

title: Death Toll in Bangladesh Tornado Rises to at Least 443
description: A tornado that struck northern Bangladesh on Monday killed at least 443 people and injured more than 32,000, local officials said today.

title: Big State Role Is Suggested For Schools In Hartford
description: Two months after Hartford abandoned an experiment with private management of its public schools, the City Council has asked the Mayor to declare a state of emergency in the schools and to encourage more state involvement.

title: Treadmill Beats a Walk on the Wild Side
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Travel;Corporations respond to the Florida crash with concern but no hasty changes in flight policies.
description: EVEN as investigators are trying to determine the cause of the Valujet crash in the Everglades, corporate business travelers are re-examining their policies regarding low-cost airlines. Yesterday, the National Business Travel Association, whose 5,000 members spent $31.7 billion on business travel in 1995, asked the Federal Government to take a close look at such carriers.

title: Subway Cars Perform Better Even as They Age
description: Trains may be slower and graffiti more prevalent, but by one measure, New York City's subway service keeps improving: the cars run longer and longer without breaking down.

title: DOLE WILL REDUCE DUTIES IN SENATE, HIS AIDES PREDICT
description: Senator Bob Dole has decided to remove himself from his day-to-day duties as Senate majority leader, bowing to a growing concern of prominent Republicans that his legislative obligations are undermining his Presidential bid, his aides said today.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Big German Builder Posts Loss for 1995
description: The German construction and engineering company Philipp Holzmann A.G. yesterday reported a loss of 442.8 million marks ($295 million) last year on one-time charges and losses at subsidiaries. The 1995 loss was larger than the company's forecast last month of a 360 million mark loss. A year earlier, the company earned 120 million marks. The company would not provide details explaining the loss. (AP)

title: Harry Hyde, 71, an Auto Racing Engineer
description: Harry Hyde, the stock car racing engineer and crew chief whose life was depicted in the movie "Days of Thunder," died on Monday at Carolinas Medical Center. He was 71.

title: Horse Tax Hurdle Leaped, Owners Finish in Money
description: For horse-racing fans, the big news today was that Unbridled's Song, a potential favorite, had been scratched from Saturday's Preakness Stakes at Pimlico.

title: Netscape and Hewlett-Packard Seek Corporate Network Business
description: Netscape Communications and Hewlett-Packard said yesterday that they had formed an alliance to exploit the growing demand for corporate computer networks based on Internet technology.

title: Man Sentenced to 125 Years for Fire That Killed 5 Children
description: It was 3 A.M. last June 28 when the police say Raymond D. Smith set fire to a stairwell leading to his estranged wife's apartment here on Lincoln Avenue, hoping the flames would force her to turn to him for help.

title: A Nifty Handle To Haul Bags of Groceries
description: A SIMPLE pocket-size plastic handle fitted with hooks, the Bag-Grabber permits a shopper to carry as many as four bags comfortably in one hand. It was invented for plastic supermarket sacks by Andy Haynes of Nashville, who is donating 5 percent of his profits to the American Cancer Society.

title: Japanese Are Making Great Deal Of Music
description: When a bird chirps or an ambulance siren wails nearby, 8-year-old Yurika Ohashi can tell if the sound is a B flat, an F sharp or any other note.

title: Market Place;Nuveen, well versed in bond funds, makes a move into stocks.
description: FIVE years after the start of one of the hottest bull markets in history, and a similar stretch into the biggest mutual fund boom of all time, John Nuveen & Company has decided to start selling mutual funds that invest in stocks. For some institutional investors, who have watched Nuveen's stock price severely trail its peers, the move comes not a moment too soon.

title: Former Lucchese Crime Boss Is to Testify on Russian Mob
description: Two years after defecting with a parcel of underworld secrets, a former Mafia kingpin is expected to surface publicly for the first time today to testify about the mob's alliances with Russian organized crime groups in the New York area.

title: As Smokers Take Refuge Outside, the Butts Pile Up
description: Huddles of smokers puffing away on the doorsteps of their smoke-free office buildings have become a new and ubiquitous feature of the municipal landscape. And, consensus has it, not a pretty one -- particularly after a good rain leaves piles of soggy cigarette butts.

title: Ghana Relents, Docking Liberian Refugee Ship
description: Ending a 10-day odyssey, including two days of crossed signals about whether it would be allowed to dock, an aging Nigerian freighter packed with an estimated 3,500 refugees from the Liberian civil war pulled into the western Ghanaian port of Takoradi today and began discharging its weary passengers.

title: Athena or a Rival's President, Bryn Mawr Has Its Lucky Charm
description: For more than a century, Athena stood in a corner of Thomas Great Hall on the campus of Bryn Mawr. Generations of Bryn Mawr women have turned to the seven-and-one-half-foot statue for luck, bringing poetry, term papers, jewelry, twigs and other offerings to lay at its feet.

title: COMMENCEMENTS;Barnard Ceremony Overshadowed by a Strike
description: Under sunny skies but overshadowed by a seven-week labor strike, Barnard College held its 104th commencement for 530 seniors yesterday, with dozens of seniors standing in silent protest and wearing red armbands and stickers over slate-blue gowns in a show of support.

title: COMPANY NEWS;U.S. LONG DISTANCE BOARD APPROVES A SPINOFF
description: The board of the U.S. Long Distance Corporation approved a plan yesterday to spin off the company's $80.8 million billing-services unit. Shareholders will receive one share in the new company, to be known as the Billing Information Concepts Corporation, for each U.S. Long Distance share they own. The spinoff, announced in February, comes amid speculation by analysts that U.S. Long Distance, based in San Antonio, might be a takeover candidate for regional phone companies seeking to enter the long-distance business. The company's shares rose $1 yesterday, to $30.75, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Explosion in Bag Shuts Part of Airport
description: An explosion in a duffel bag that was about to be loaded onto a Paris-bound plane at Newark International Airport yesterday closed down part of the terminal for two hours, officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said. They said the explosion may have been caused by a ruptured aerosol can.

title: TV NOTES;Questions of Race
description: Nightline" prides itself on dealing with issues in depth. But both Ted Koppel, the anchor, and Tom Bettag, the executive producer, believed there was a topic they had not examined deeply enough: race relations. So next week, the ABC News late-night program will spend all five nights dealing with it, in a series called "America in Black and White."

title: Crew's Plan: Selling Air Rights and Mugs
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew is proposing a budget that would protect classrooms next year by selling vacant school lots, air rights over school buildings, billboard space on school roofs and an array of board-licensed merchandise -- like Erasmus High mugs -- that would be marketed to public-school alumni.

title: Stocks Jump in Tokyo
description: Stocks were up sharply here this morning. At the midday break in trading, the Nikkei index of 225 issues had risen 466.89 points, to 21,767.89, a gain of 2.2 percent. On Tuesday, the Nikkei rose 129.23 points.

title: Editor Quits at Daily News
description: Don Forst, the former editor of New York Newsday, gave up his job as metropolitan editor of The Daily News last night, less than three months after he joined the paper.

title: POLITICS: THE MESSAGE;New Dole Speech Stresses Ideology and Personality
description: Bob Dole's message becomes even more central to his quest for the Presidency, now that he is resigning from the Senate and cannot fall back on his day-to-day legislative accomplishments.

title: General Electric Spreads Its Wings;An Aviation Giant Built on Engines, Leasing and Finance
description: Quick. Who has the most airplanes in today's crowded skies? Not United. Not American. Not British Airways, either.

title: POP;In Performance
description: Looking at the Dark Side Of Bad Experiences Jo Carol Pierce Mercury Lounge

title: Welfare Recipients Lose Benefits Through Glitches in Computers
description: Computer problems and confusion on the part of clients have in recent weeks led to scores of welfare recipients being mistakenly deprived of benefits, according to workers in the city's public assistance centers, as well as city and state officials.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Times National Edition To Expand Sunday Sales
description: edition of its Sunday newspaper, to be printed at midday on Saturdays, for distribution outside the Northeast. The move, starting this weekend, is aimed at making the Sunday newspaper more widely available across the country. The early national edition is expected to be distributed on Saturday afternoons and evenings to some airports and major newsstands and the next morning to many more cities and towns.

title: ON PRO BASKETBALL;Best Shot for Ewing? It's Outside New York
description: This was a good hour after the Knicks took their familiar end-of-the-season walk from the court toward the locker room in Chicago Tuesday night. Michael Jordan had just left the interview room, and now Patrick Ewing maneuvered his long, tired body onto the platform and into the seat behind the table. Ewing said nothing we haven't heard before, mostly with no expression. But then, after all the questions about the game, about the season, about the direction of his team, he was asked if he had any doubts regarding his own return to the hackneyed Knicks.

title: POLITICS: POLITICAL BRIEFS;THE CAMPAIGNS FOR GOVERNOR AND CONGRESS
description: West Virginia A Strong Woman Clears a Hurdle

title: Japan Stocks Keep Rising
description: Stocks continued to trade higher here this morning. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 109.83 points, or half a percent, at 22,165.80. On Wednesday, the Nikkei rose 754.92 points, or 3.54 percent, after Japanese monetary officials said that interest rates would be left unchanged.

title: Protecting Ourselves
description: Opponents of renewing China's most-favored-nation status are regularly accused of sacrificing American economic interests for the worthy but impractical purpose of protesting China's human-rights violations. Yet the privilege needs to be revoked for a practical reason: to help change a largely one-sided relationship that harms our economy and workers.

title: Dreaded Words?
description: To The Home Section:

title: Accord Clears The Last Will Of Doris Duke For Probate
description: The last will signed by Doris Duke, the tobacco heiress, was accepted yesterday for probate in Surrogate's Court in Manhattan, officially ending a 30-month legal drama of sensational charges ranging from misspent millions to murder.

title: THEATER;In Performance
description: A Musical Comic Strip With Political Overtones Elizabeth Swados La Mama

title: BASEBALL;Cone Is Home, Brimming With Hope and Emotion
description: David Cone's usually stern voice wavered, his green eyes watered and his fair complexion turned crimson yesterday afternoon, less than one minute into his first visit to Yankee Stadium since having surgery to repair an aneurysm in his right shoulder area last Friday. Three, four and five times, Cone could have used a tissue to dab his eyes and a stronger microphone to amplify his soft words.

title: CHRONICLE
description: IRINA PANTAEVA, a fashion model who has soared to the top of her field, edged one step closer to a more cerebral goal last night. She brought a touch of her native Buryat culture to the National Arts Club with a discussion of "A Midsummer Night's Dream in Buryatia."

title: Market Place;One epilogue to the budget crisis: free money for the Treasury.
description: THIS is a tale of how the Government managed to borrow $492 million from 23,000 American savers for nine days without paying a dime of interest to them, while more sophisticated investors got interest on their money.

title: BALLET REVIEW;Love, Mayhem, Murder And a Few Pretty Tunes
description: Manon" is a crowded ballet. Kenneth MacMillan choreographically filled it with love, death, sex, violence, seduction, deception, prostitution, gambling, murder, heartbreak and exile. "Manon" also has pretty tunes and some big, meaty roles for star dancers.

title: Medieval Spring Blooms Again In the Cloisters
description: THE quinces bloomed last week at the Cloisters, the Metropolitan Museum of Art's jumble of reconstructed abbeys that perches over northern Manhattan like some kind of medieval mirage.

title: Gay Parents Ease Into Suburbia;For the First Generation, Car Pools and Soccer Games
description: TABLE manners are not yet a priority for Claire Ji Dougherty Covner, who is happy to lunge at a salad bowl, grab a bunch of green beans and eat them with her hands.

title: Imagine Going With Byrd to the North Pole
description: To the Editor:

title: Man in the News: Atal Bihari Vajpayee;A Poet-Politician With a Fondness for 'Lion King'
description: Atal Bihari Vajpayee smiled today at one of the more predictable questions fired at him at his first news conference as India's Prime Minister-designate. When an Indian reporter asked, "What message do you have tonight for Benazir Bhutto?," the Prime Minister of Pakistan, Mr. Vajpayee shot back, "Is there any harm if I send the message tomorrow morning?"

title: Thermo Electron Purchase
description: The Thermo Electron Corporation has an agreement to buy Medical Data Electronics, a private manufacturer of patient-monitoring systems, based in Pacoima, Calif. Financial terms were not disclosed. The purchase of Medical Data, which had 1995 sales of $34 million, is part of a plan by Thermo Electron to expand its biomedical businesses. Thermo Electron, based in Waltham, makes environmental and health monitoring systems. It has annual sales of about $2.2 billion.

title: Courts Rulings Give Homeless Little Comfort
description: The sign hanging in the South Bronx office building said, "Do not remove the mattresses," but it was just a cruel joke, for there were no mattresses to be had.

title: Corrections
description: The Key Rates table on the Credit Markets page of Business Day yesterday misstated Tuesday's yield on municipal bonds. It was 6.00 percent, not 6.37.

title: World News Briefs;U.S. to Send Warplanes To Qatar for Two Months
description: The United States will station 30 Air Force fighter jets in Qatar for two months starting in late June, in what the Defense Department called a show of support for United States allies in the Persian Gulf region.

title: THE POP LIFE;Meeting An Olympic Challenge
description: What is Olympics music? Is it a soundtrack for struggle, victory or peace? Is it a brassy fanfare, thunderous group drumming or streamlined pop? Is it Greek, American, African or global?

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Douglas, Top Jet Pass Rusher, Getting No Time to Daydream
description: What do you want!" Coach Ray Hamilton demanded of Hugh Douglas.

title: Clinton to Act On Banning Many Types Of War Mines
description: President Clinton has decided to impose a ban on American use of a large variety of land mines beginning in 1999, with an exception for their use in Korea, and will commit the United States to the eventual elimination of all mines, Administration officials said today.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Powergen of Britain To Buy Back Stock
description: Powergen P.L.C. plans to buy back up to L400 million ($600 million) of its stock after failing to acquire another British utility. The electricity generator, which also raised its annual dividend more than expected, said it would buy back up to 10 percent of its stock with cash it had intended to use to buy Midlands Electricity P.L.C.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;Gimelstob Takes Shot at the Pros
description: JUSTIN GIMELSTOB, the No. 1-seeded player in singles and doubles at the N.C.A.A. tournament in Athens, Ga., which begins Saturday, has decided to turn professional.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: Anne Melanson, an executive vice president at Bates Worldwide, New York, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C., was named to the agency's worldwide management board.

title: Postcards From a Show House
description: GOING to a show house gives everyone the chance to imagine the life of a cat burglar. One roams through the lives of persons unknown, picking out things one wants for oneself. If, sadly, the objects in the show house must stay put, the sharp-eyed can spot good design ideas, there for the taking.

title: Suspect Pleads Guilty to Murder In Hacking Death of a Scientist
description: The man accused of dumping the body of a Russian scientist into the Passaic River in New Jersey after hacking him into pieces with help from the victim's estranged wife pleaded guilty to second-degree murder yesterday, prosecutors said.

title: Economic Scene;Central Europe is unsettled by a currency union for West Europe.
description: THE 200 politicians, business executives and assorted policy wonks attending the first congress of the New Atlantic Initiative -- a tony pep rally here for trans-Atlantic harmony -- got the good show they no doubt expected.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: House G.O.P., Softening Stance, Issues Manifesto on the Environment
description: House Republicans issued a broad new set of guidelines today for their future environmental proposals, calling for consensus, innovation and a greater role for states, local communities and the private sector.

title: Television Grows a Brain
description: SINCE its birth 57 years ago, the television has been basically unchanged, a friendly, bulky box that brings football games, weather reports and Lucille Ball into our living rooms.

title: INSIDE
description: Nightclub Arrests

title: Clinton Lawyers Ask Court To Delay Harassment Suit
description: Telling the Justices that the question was one of "extraordinary national importance," lawyers for President Clinton filed a Supreme Court appeal today seeking to delay all proceedings in a sexual harassment suit until Mr. Clinton leaves office.

title: POLITICS: FINANCES;Limited Cash Likely to Restrict Dole's Campaign Message
description: For months, senior aides to Bob Dole have brushed off concerns that he was approaching campaign spending limits at an alarming rate. They asserted that the campaign's political strategy until the Republican convention would be a low budget one because it would promote the candidate through the daily news coverage that follows his leadership of the Senate.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;Dream Matchup Is Finally Complete
description: As soon as tonight's game ended, the Orlando Magic turned its attention toward the Chicago Bulls.

title: Executive Changes
description: AMERIWOOD INDUSTRIES INTERNATIONAL CORP., Grand Rapids, Mich., promoted Craig Wassenaar to the positions of chief financial officer, corporate secretary and vice president.

title: She Asks, She Tells
description: HOMOSEXUALITY "isn't a weed that grows up among us," Col. Margarethe Cammermeyer says, sitting in her living room here overlooking Puget Sound.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;British Jobless Rate Unchanged at 7.8%
description: British unemployment fell slightly in April, but the drop was not enough to reduce the overall jobless rate from 7.8 percent, the Government said yesterday. Unemployment fell by 3,200, far less than a drop of 25,600 in March.

title: Move Witness Describes Bomb And Fatal Fire
description: Ramona Africa's eyes filled with tears as she testified in Federal District Court today about the 1985 police bombing in which 11 other members of the group Move were killed in a West Philadelphia row house.

title: Unarmed Norwegian Troops Start Hebron Patrols
description: A contingent of 32 observers from Norway took up their duties today on the streets of this volatile town in preparation for a planned Israeli Army pullout from most of Hebron.

title: JAZZ;In Performance
description: Dramatic Voyages And the Return Home Renee Rosnes Sweet Basil

title: Schools Weigh Impact Of District Breakup
description: Some of the students at Jonathan Dayton High cried today for their school and their friends.

title: Copenhagen Journal;At 25, the Hippies' 'Free City' Isn't So Carefree
description: When a swarm of hippies, squatters and assorted idealists invaded an abandoned military base in the heart of Copenhagen and called it Free City of Christiania, few believed that they would be staying long.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CHANCELLOR AGREES TO BUY 8 RADIO STATIONS
description: The Chancellor Broadcasting Company signed an agreement yesterday to purchase eight Florida radio stations from privately held Omniamerica Group for $178 million in cash and stock. Chancellor, which is based in Dallas, said the deal would consist of one AM and seven FM stations in Orlando, Jacksonville and West Palm Beach. The purchases would bring to 43 the number of radio stations Chancellor owns in 16 markets. Chancellor shares rose $3.25, to $24.75.

title: BASEBALL;Padres Prevail In Bullpen Battle
description: When asked before tonight's game what he needed most to alter the Mets' staggering start this season, Manager Dallas Green promptly replied, "Somebody that can get you three outs once in while." It was a reference to his troubled bullpen.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MAPLE LEAF FOODS INC., Toronto, the food processing concern, agreed to sell its 90 percent stake in Barbados Mills Ltd. and its 100 percent stake in Belize Mills Ltd. to ADM Milling Co., a subsidiary of the Archer-Daniels-Midland Co., Decatur, Ill.

title: Homeless Still Sleep At 'Off-Limits' Office
description: One little boy slept with his cheek pressed against the dirty tile floor. A mother dozed on a row of plastic-backed chairs. Other mothers never slept at all, fearful that mice might crawl on their babies or that strangers might steal their duffel bags.

title: COMPANY NEWS;W. R. GRACE SAYS IT IS UNDER INVESTIGATION BY THE S.E.C.
description: W. R. Grace & Company said yesterday that it was under formal investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission over charges that it failed to disclose a reserve fund set up by its health care business. The S.E.C. investigation is the second now under way into the disclosure practices of Grace. The company, based in Boca Raton, Fla., previously said that an investigation was looking into allegations that Grace failed to disclose $24 million in retirement benefits given to its former chairman. The investigation involving the reserve fund focuses on accusations similar to those made by Grace's former internal audit chief in an age-discrimination lawsuit filed last May. The former auditor, Norman Eatough, contends that Grace set up a reserve fund to avoid paying Federal taxes owed by the National Medical Care Inc. unit, the provider of kidney dialysis services.

title: Western Allies Press Indonesia to Open More Sea-Lanes to Warships
description: JAKARTA  The United States and several allies are pressing Indonesia, whose sea-lanes have long been a key highway for naval vessels sailing between the Asia-Pacific region and the Indian Ocean, to open its waters more widely to free passage of foreign warships, especially submarines.

title: Why Overplay F.D.R.'s Disability in Stone?
description: To the Editor:

title: Essay;White House or Home
description: I didn't tell any senators," Bob Dole joshed his colleagues just before his stunning announcement of leave-taking. "Heh-heh-heh. That's why there weren't any leaks."

title: Corrections
description: A chronology on Tuesday with an article about the 150th anniversary of the Trinity Church building referred incorrectly to Trinity School. It is the oldest continuously operating school in New York City. Collegiate School, founded in 1628 but closed from 1776 to 1783, is the oldest school.

title: POLITICS: NEWS ANALYSIS;Inside: Ties That Bind
description: After six weeks of trying to run for President from the well of the Senate, Bob Dole finally conceded today that his strategy was not working.

title: Cabin in Unabom Case Is Moved 70 Miles
description: The wooden cabin of Theodore J. Kaczynski, the suspect in the Unabom case, was moved about 70 miles early today from a Montana hillside to an Air Force base for safekeeping, the F.B.I. said.

title: Oracle's Low-Cost Computer Gets Support
description: The Oracle Corporation, continuing its crusade for a low-cost "network computer," today released a list of nearly two dozen manufacturers and technology partners that have agreed to produce such machines.

title: Investment Firm Selling Unit
description: The Phoenix Duff & Phelps Corporation said today that it would sell the assets of its Fixed Income Research Group to a management-led group.

title: Stocks Close Mixed as Rally Halts
description: Stocks ended mixed in a seesaw session yesterday, as a three-day rally stalled.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Dismissed by Viacom, $15.5 Million Richer
description: Viacom Inc. will pay as much as $15.5 million in the next three years to its former chief executive, Frank J. Biondi Jr., who was dismissed in January after nine years with the media company.

title: POLITICS: NEWS ANALYSIS;Going 'Outside': Bold, Maybe Perilous
description: After 35 years on Capitol Hill, after more than a decade of leading the Republicans in the Senate, after establishing himself in the eyes of voters and politicians as the very emblem of Congress and its values, Bob Dole sought yesterday with a single dramatic stroke to recast himself as an outsider.

title: New Nintendo Game Faces Internet Challengers
description: Nintendo of America, the longtime leader in the video-game market, gave its first United States preview today of its flashy next-generation game machine, which it is hoping will revitalize the slowing video game industry this Christmas.

title: An Increased Price For Casual Elegance
description: Prepare to pay up -- or wear polyester.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: POLITICS;Rostenkowski Has Cancer, Newspaper Says
description: Former Representative Dan Rostenkowski, who was scheduled to enter prison this month to serve a 17-month sentence on corruption charges, is suffering from prostate cancer, a newspaper reported today.

title: HORSE RACING;Late Rush Brings Preakness Field to 12
description: At dawn, three days before the 121st Preakness Stakes, only one contender occupied a stall at Pimlico Race Course. But with the recent retirement of the Kentucky Derby winner, Grindstone, and the withdrawal of the Derby favorite, Unbridled's Song, all manner of 3-year-old colts began to converge on the track today as a field of 12 was entered for the second jewel in racing's Triple Crown.

title: ON BASEBALL;Gooden's Uplifting Story of Survival
description: Chris Chambliss never saw the Yankees carry a teammate off the field -- until Tuesday night.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Thinking of Great Men, Trying to Know God
description: A LIFETIME BURNING IN EVERY MOMENT From the Journals of Alfred Kazin Selected and edited by the author. 341 pages. HarperCollins. $26.

title: Why Overplay F.D.R.'s Disability in Stone?
description: To the Editor:

title: Politics Is Killing School Reform
description: Anyone who cares about New York City's schools might well despair over this week's events in Albany. The State Assembly passed a serious, ambitious proposal to change the way the city's schools are run. But before the vote was even cast, the majority leader of the Senate said there was virtually no chance reform was going to move any further this year.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;Ewing Is Still Planning His Future With Knicks and Van Gundy
description: Surprisingly realistic and candid, Patrick Ewing bid farewell to his teammates here at SUNY-Purchase today and promptly drove to Madison Square Garden to meet with Knicks management.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;For Trump, Casino No. 12 1/2
description: The boardwalk got its 13th casino yesterday when Donald J. Trump's latest gambling resort opened on the Boardwalk. But perhaps to avoid tainting the 500-room hotel and casino with an unlucky number, officials maintain that it is actually an extension of Trump Plaza, to which it is linked by an enclosed walkway.

title: Virgin Orders Airbus Jets
description: Airbus Industrie said today that Virgin Atlantic Airways had ordered two long-range A340-300 passenger planes. The aircraft, which have a list price of $127 million each, will be delivered in next year's second quarter, Airbus said. Virgin currently flies four such planes. A fifth will go into operation late this week on a new route from Manchester, England, to Orlando, Fla.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Roe Settles in Car Crash
description: A mother and daughter injured in a car crash with a drunken former Congressman from Passaic County have reached a $517,000 settlement with him and the Morristown tavern that served him, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: Chirac, the Anglophile, Revisits the Land of 'Le Fish and Chips'
description: Giant tricolors flap alongside Union Jacks on The Mall this week, part of the ceremonial pomp rolled out for a four-day visit by President Jacques Chirac of France, and for the first time in years the two flags seem to be flying in unison.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TYCO TO PURCHASE CARLISLE FOR $121 MILLION IN STOCK
description: Tyco International Ltd. agreed yesterday to buy Carlisle Plastics Inc., a maker of specialty packaging materials and garment hangers, for stock valued at $121 million. Tyco, a maker of packaging materials and disposable medical products in Exeter, N.H., said it plans to exchange 0.172185 of a Tyco share for each of Carlisle's 17.9 million shares. Carlisle shares jumped $1.75 yesterday, to $6.625, and Tyco's rose 25 cents, to $39.375. Carlisle Plastics, which is based in Phoenix and has annual sales of $400 million, would become part of Tyco's disposable and specialty products business.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Mexico Adds to Aid On Bad Bank Loans
description: In the largest Government-assisted Mexican bank rescue to date, Grupo Financiero Serfin has sold $2.7 billion in bad loans to a bank bailout fund in exchange for a promise to raise $1.35 billion in fresh capital.

title: 2 States Agree: $55 Million for Sterling Forest
description: The drive to preserve Sterling Forest, the 20,000-acre woodland that supplies drinking water to one quarter of New Jerseyans, took a major step forward yesterday when the Governors of New York and New Jersey agreed on a purchase price of $55 million for the property.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-12

title: New Monetary Chief At European Group
description: European central bankers have picked the governor of the Dutch central bank to take over next year as the president of the European Monetary Institute, the forerunner of an intended European central bank.

title: Andrews Shows Courage in Rejecting Tony
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Plead Not Guilty To Actor's Murder
description: Three men pleaded not guilty on Monday to the murder of Haing S. Ngor, the Cambodian doctor who won an Academy Award for his performance in "The Killing Fields."

title: Imagine Going With Byrd to the North Pole
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Federated, Woolworth Post Losses
description: Two large retailers, Federated Department Stores Inc. and the Woolworth Corporation, reported first-quarter losses yesterday, but both showed improvements from the year-earlier quarter that were better than expected.

title: Rookie Award To Stoudamire
description: Fans at the Skydome booed when the Toronto Raptors picked Damon Stoudamire last June in the first round of the National Basketball Association draft. He turned the boos into cheers with a stellar rookie season.

title: U.S. Judge Approves Orange County Plan
description: A Federal Bankruptcy Court judge approved the reorganization plan of Orange County, Calif., today, clearing the way for the county to emerge from bankruptcy proceedings next month.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Dornier Family Members Oppose Sale of Unit
description: Members of the Dornier family said yesterday that they opposed the sale of the aircraft division of Dornier G.m.b.H., a unit of Daimler-Benz. The family members own a minority stake in Dornier and have the right to veto the sale. Dasa, as Daimler's aerospace unit is known, is in talks with Fairchild Aircraft of San Antonio, the only potential partner it has named.

title: World News Briefs;Bangladesh Sends Troops To Aid Tornado Victims
description: The army sent medical teams and soldiers to northern Bangladesh today to help tens of thousands of people injured by a tornado and to search for 500 others who are still missing.

title: No Headline
description: There is no core doctrine prohibiting the ordination of a noncelibate, homosexual person living in a faithful and committed sexual relationship with a person of the same sex." BISHOP CABELL TENNIS, reading the decision of an Episcopal Church court. [A18:3.]

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Sports of The Times;Football's Addiction To Macho
description: SUDDENLY, with Brett Favre having checked himself into the National Football League's substance-abuse program in order to rectify his acknowledged dependency on painkillers, the price of pro football's human damage is not merely the risk of surgical knees, separated shoulders and concussions.

title: Hockey Team Is to Remain, For Now
description: The Hartford Whalers hockey team, Connecticut's only major league sports franchise, announced today that it would remain here for two more years, but probably no longer.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: NOTEBOOK;Esiason Lauds Favre's Courage
description: Citing the macho ethos of professional football, Boomer Esiason said today that he does not know if National Football League players with similar problems will have the courage to follow the lead of Green Bay Packers quarterback Brett Favre and seek help for dependence on painkillers.

title: Our Towns;Tough Advice Gets Tougher To Get Across
description: IT'S an afternoon made for playing hooky, the sun just warm enough, the breeze just cool enough, the sky a topaz blue. But 30 would-be junior-senior high school truants from South Jersey have a better offer: a field trip to East Jersey State Prison. Cool.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Over 40 and Focused on Experiment
description: Since the five performers in Netherlands Dance Theater 3 are at least over 40, it would be easy to say that they get by on presence alone. The truth is they can dance as well.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Hardy Evergreen Ferns

title: COMPANY NEWS;COCA-COLA AGREES TO MERGE 3 BOTTLERS IN GERMANY
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it had agreed to merge three of its independent licensed bottlers in Germany into a company-owned bottler that distributes in eastern Germany. The beverage giant said it expects the merged company, Coca-Cola Erfrischungsgetranke G.m.b.H., to generate $1.6 billion in revenue and produce 265 million cases of soft drinks annually. The three independent Coca-Cola licensed bottlers distribute in Nuremberg, Munich and Stuttgart.

title: Imagine Going With Byrd to the North Pole
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article by Reuters on March 30 about a jocular proposal to send British cattle to Cambodia misstated the source. And a correction in this space on May 3 referred incorrectly to the newspaper involved. The suggestion -- to send British cattle infected with so-called mad cow disease to Cambodia, where they could be set loose in old minefields, eliminating two problems at once -- was made in a letter to the editor published in The Cambodia Daily (not The Cambodia Times). The suggestion was not devised by the newspaper itself.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Lists Chinese Goods For Big Trade Sanctions The Clinton Administration listed $3 billion in Chinese goods that could be subject to the largest trade sanctions in American history if Beijing refuses to close factories that pirate American software and music.

title: O Canada! Ready to Drop the Crown?
description: Born in Trinidad, educated in Saskatchewan and Ontario, Charles Roach, a prominent Toronto civil rights lawyer, refuses to become a Canadian citizen, even though he has lived in this country for nearly five decades. The reason, he says, is that he would have to swear allegiance to Queen Elizabeth II.

title: Call of the Wild, in Stone
description: Antonio Da Motta and Rolando Niella, furniture designers in New York, love semiprecious stones and minerals like onyx, calcite and dolomite. They have turned them into table tops and lamps, but they have not stopped there. They have even made a dress of stone squares held together with brass rings and suspended from the shoulders on brass chains (it may be blithe in spirit, but it is heavy in weight: 35 pounds).

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Sony Signals a Recovery With Upswing in Earnings
description: The Sony Corporation reported its strongest earnings in years today, owing to brisk sales of computer components and its new Playstation video game machine and a return to profitability of its Hollywood studio operations.

title: Crew Suspends Head Of a Bronx Board Over Misconduct
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew removed Carmelo Saez as president of Community School District 9 in the South Bronx yesterday. It was the second action he has taken against the troubled school board in three months.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TCI PLANS TO INCREASE ITS STAKE IN DMX TO 45%
description: Tele-Communications Inc. plans to increase its stake in the digital-music programmer DMX Inc. to about 45 percent from 14 percent through a series of transactions, DMX said yesterday. DMX, based in Los Angeles, plans to complete its purchase of the 49 percent stake in DMX-Europe N.V. held by TCI's Tele-Communications International unit for 10.8 million DMX shares. TCI also plans to buy 4.5 million shares from DMX for $2 a share, and it agreed to buy all 5.7 million DMX shares owned by the casino executive Steve Wynn for $2 a share, or $11.4 million. When all transactions are complete, it is expected that DMX will have 59.6 million shares outstanding. DMX stock fell 43.75 cents, at $1.5625 a share, yesterday in Nasdaq trading.

title: Joseph Barbash, 74, Partner In Manhattan Law Firm
description: Joseph Barbash, a former partner in the law firm of Debevoise & Plimpton, died on Saturday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. Mr. Barbash, who lived on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, was 74.

title: POLITICS;Dole's Comments on Plans to Resign From the Senate
description: Following are remarks today by Senator Bob Dole in which he announced that he would leave the Senate in June, as recorded by The Associated Press:

title: BASEBALL;Mariners' Johnson on D.L.
description: The sight of Randy Johnson, Seattle's menacing 6-foot-10-inch ace, will disappear from view temporarily. Johnson has been placed on the 15-day disabled list with an irritated nerve in his lower back, the Mariners said yesterday before they played the Yankees.

title: Hailing Learned Designers
description: To The Home Section:

title: U.S. Claims 2 Nightclubs Are Drug Bazaars
description: The owner of three of Manhattan's largest nightclubs was accused yesterday of turning two of them -- the Limelight and the Tunnel -- into virtual drug supermarkets, peddling the drug known as Ecstasy to a clientele made up largely of college students and teen-agers.

title: New Trial Opens for Italy's Former Leader
description: A new trial of former Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti on charges related to organized crime started today, with the prosecution asking that 91 new witnesses be allowed to testify against him.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Cable and Wireless, Bruised, Picks New Chief
description: Cable and Wireless P.L.C., searching for direction after a board room battle and failed merger talks, named a top executive of H & R Block as its new chief executive today.

title: American Express Adds Broker Services At a Discount
description: Moving to compete with Charles Schwab and Fidelity Investments, the American Express Company announced yesterday an ambitious offering of no-load mutual funds and discount stock brokerage services to be offered by mail, telephone and soon computer.

title: A Spy Agency Admits Accumulating $4 Billion in Secret Money
description: In a complete collapse of accountability, the Government agency that builds spy satellites accumulated about $4 billion in uncounted secret money, nearly twice the amount previously reported to Congress, intelligence officials acknowledged today.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;More H.M.O.'s for Welfare
description: By this fall, most people receiving public assistance will be required to enroll in a health maintenance organization, state officials said yesterday.

title: N.A.S.D. Fines a Member And Vows Stiff Regulation
description: The regulatory arm of the National Association of Securities Dealers has fined one of its largest brokerage firm members $75,000 for trading ahead of its customers and plans to announce today a big increase in the amount it spends to enforce rules in the Nasdaq stock market.

title: Corrections
description: A book review yesterday about Terry McMillan's new novel, "How Stella Got Her Groove Back," misstated the title of Ms. McMillan's previous book. It is "Waiting to Exhale," not "Learning to Exhale."

title: In Trade Rift, U.S. Outlines Penalties, And So Does China
description: After months of warnings, the Clinton Administration today published a list of $3 billion of Chinese goods that could be subject to the largest trade sanctions ever imposed by Washington if Beijing refuses not to close factories that pirate American software and music.

title: U.S. Judge Wants Re-evaluation Of a Mob Figure's 'Crazy Act'
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that Vincent Gigante, a reputed Mafia boss known for walking Manhattan streets in a bathrobe and pajamas, was putting on a "crazy act" until at least 1991 to avoid arrest and prosecution.

title: Treating Elderly Alcoholics
description: To The Home Section:

title: Merrill Twining, 92; Planned Guadalcanal Attack
description: Gen. Merrill B. Twining of the Marine Corps, who helped plan the landing on Guadalcanal in World War II and later fought in the Korean War, died last Saturday at a hospital in Fallbrook, Calif., where he had been living in retirement. He was 92.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Bishop Cleared of Heresy
description: In a decision likely to reverberate through America's Protestant denominations, an Episcopal Church court ruled yesterday that a bishop did not violate the church's "core doctrines" in 1990 when he ordained a gay man, the Rev. Barry Stopfel, as a deacon in Newark.

title: An Ultimatum on Chinese Piracy
description: A trade war between the United States and China could prove costly to both countries, but Beijing's piracy of American goods has left the Clinton Administration no choice but to threaten a confrontation.

title: Vote for Environment
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Japan and U.S. Fail To Agree on Insurance
description: Two days of talks ended yesterday without agreement on ways to open up Japan's insurance industry to United States competition. No date has been set for the next meeting, but Japan is "willing to meet anytime, anywhere," an official of the Ministry of Finance said.

title: Hospitals Agency to Drop 1,600 Unionized Workers
description: Pounded by budget cuts and intense competition from managed care, New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation announced yesterday that it would lay off 1,600 unionized employees next month, many of them nurses and doctors involved in direct patient care.

title: Rise in Output Doesn't Move Bonds Much
description: The prices of Treasury securities were virtually unchanged yesterday, with the market showing little reaction to a report that industrial production surged in April.

title: A Stock Sale Is Considered By Hambrecht
description: Hambrecht & Quist, which has taken fast-growing technology companies like the Netscape Communications Corporation public, is preparing an initial public offering of its own shares, people familiar with the brokerage firm have said in recent days.

title: Stalin Had Victims And Supporters Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Offering Hope, and Seats, to Pavarotti's Fans
description: When the flu forced Luciano Pavarotti to bow out of his annual Pavarotti Plus concert a few hours before curtain time on May 1, Lincoln Center was left with a hall full of concertgoers who had come to hear Mr. Pavarotti and to attend a black-tie dinner, as well as a national television audience that was expecting to see the tenor on "Live From Lincoln Center." The concert, at which Mr. Pavarotti was to have sung arias and ensemble pieces with other opera stars, went on with Francisco Casanova filling in for Mr. Pavarotti, but PBS showed its viewers a tape of the 1994 Pavarotti Plus concert.

title: BASEBALL;After Night of Elation, Day of Nervous Waiting
description: Eleven hours after pitching an emotional no-hitter against the Seattle Mariners at Yankee Stadium, Dwight Gooden paced in a waiting room today at St. Joseph's Hospital as his father, Dan, underwent a three-hour operation to replace a faulty heart valve.

title: AT HOME-AWAY-FROM-HOME WITH: Robert Bly;Now Banging the Drum Slowly
description: THERE is not a deerskin-covered drum in sight. Nor any papier-mache animal masks to inspire visitors with their fierce primitive maleness.

title: Panel Urging Reform in Selection of Federal Judges
description: A bipartisan commission of leading lawyers and scholars warned today that the process of nominating and confirming Federal judges has become far too cumbersome and must be changed or it could eventually erode the quality of justice in the nation.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bank of Ireland Says Profit Fell 1.8%
description: The Bank of Ireland said yesterday that its pretax profit after exceptional items fell 1.8 percent in the year that ended on March 31 as a provision for merging its United States operations offset increased income from consumer banking. The bank said pretax profit after extraordinary items for the latest year was 315.6 million Irish pounds ($492.3 million), compared with 321.8 million in the previous year. Pretax profit before extraordinary items was 363.7 million Irish pounds, up 13.6 percent from 320.1 million a year earlier. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Police Say Dead Teen-Age Girl Was Strangled, but Not Raped
description: The Suffolk County police said today that a 16-year-old high school senior who was found dead in a neighbor's yard in East Northport on Tuesday was strangled, but that an autopsy had found no evidence of sexual assault.

title: Dull Israeli Election Masks a Race Against Terror
description: Compared with the election campaigns in Russia or India, Israel's might appear a dull affair. Dull, that is, if the campaign is defined only by the tame speeches and glossy television spots.

title: BASEBALL;Back to Reality: Key Takes a Pounding
description: Jimmy Key sat slumped in the Yankee dugout last night, the picture of confusion, dejection and exasperation. It was only the fourth inning and Key was already in his unwanted seat and alone with his thoughts: Would he ever return to being the impeccable pitcher he had once been?

title: Nabisco Chief Leaves Post at Parent
description: The Nabisco Holdings Corporation and its parent company, the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation, moved a step closer to splitting up as Nabisco's chief executive and president, John Greeniaus, resigned today as vice chairman of the parent.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FIRST UNION INVESTMENT PRODUCES $277 MILLION PROFIT
description: The First Union Corporation said yesterday that its investment in the Nova Corporation, a transaction processor in Atlanta, late last year had produced more than $277 million in paper profits. Nova went public last week at $19 a share, and First Union said its profit was based on Nova's closing price of $31 a share on Friday. The stock closed at $36.125, down 12.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday after touching $39.75 earlier in the session. First Union, a banking company based in Charlotte, N.C., said last year that it would buy a 35 percent stake in Nova as part of a plan to combine the merchant bank-card activities of both companies. The combination created one of the nation's largest bank-card processors with about $11 billion in credit-card transactions for 1995.

title: COMPANY NEWS;U.S. FILTER TO BUY DAVIS WATER AND WASTE
description: The U.S. Filter Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Davis Water and Waste Industries in a stock transaction valued at $97 million. Shares of U.S. Filter rose $1.75, to $33.50, and Davis Water shares jumped $3.75, to $28.75. The letter of intent calls for U.S. Filter, of Palm Desert, Calif., to exchange 0.933 of a share for each of the 3.26 million Davis shares outstanding. The addition of Davis Water, based in Thomasville, Ga., would increase U.S. Filter's manufacturing capability of water-distribution equipment, which provides most of Davis's annual revenue of $215 million.

title: Calendar: Plant Project, 2 Exhibitions
description: Plants and Children Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue, off Eastern Parkway, Prospect Heights, (718) 622-4433, extension 416; and the Brooklyn Children's Museum, 145 Brooklyn Avenue, at St. Mark's Avenue, Crown Heights, (718) 735-4400.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the memorial service for William E. Colby, the former Director of Central Intelligence, misstated the source of a reading by his granddaughter. It was from Ecclesiasticus, a book of the Apocrypha that Roman Catholics but not Protestants include in the Old Testament. The reading was not from the Old Testament book of Ecclesiastes.

title: White House Is Avoiding Gay Marriage as an Issue
description: President Clinton, who has long supported gay rights but paid a heavy political price for his failed effort to allow homosexuals in the military, appears determined to keep the issue from roiling his re-election campaign, and the White House is going out of its way to defuse potential Republican attacks.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bundesbank Leaves Key Rates Unchanged
description: The Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, said yesterday that it had left the German discount and Lombard rates unchanged after its regular meeting. The German discount rate remains at 2.5 percent and the Lombard emergency financing rate at 4.5 percent. The central bank's main money market rate, the repo, was also left unchanged at 3.3 percent. German financial markets showed little reaction. (Reuters)

title: COMPANY NEWS;DELL SOARS ON REPORT OF HIGHER SALES AND EARNINGS
description: The shares of the Dell Computer Corporation surged yesterday after the personal computer maker defied gloomy industry-demand forecasts to report sharply higher sales and earnings. Dell shares closed up $2.375, to $49.375, in Nasdaq trading of 9.9 million shares; earlier in the session, it touched $51.75, an all-time high. As recently as early March, the stock was at $28.25 a share. Dell, of Austin, Tex., said that its first-quarter net income rose 32 percent to $82 million, or 84 cents a share, on a 44 percent increase in sales to $1.64 billion.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ABBOTT FORMS AN ALLIANCE WITH SONUS PHARMACEUTICALS
description: Abbott Laboratories said yesterday that it would market Sonus Pharmaceuticals Inc.'s Echogen Emulsion contrast agent as part of a strategic alliance between the two companies. Abbott will pay Sonus $31 million for the rights to the product, a liquid injected into ultrasound patients to improve the quality of imaging technology. Sonus, of Bothell, Wash., will be responsible for clinical development of Echogen, and Abbott will be in charge of United States marketing and sales. Abbott also paid $4 million for warrants to buy 500,000 shares of Sonus common stock, equal to about 6 percent of the stock outstanding. Sonus stock rose $4.125, to $20.50, in Nasdaq trading.

title: COLLEGE LACROSSE REPORT
description: Women's Tournaments

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Ford Interviews With Hornets
description: A former Boston Celtics coach and player, CHRIS FORD, was the latest candidate to interview for the Charlotte Hornets' coaching job. Ford spent four hours Tuesday touring the Hornets' practice facility in Fort Mill, S.C., and talking to BOB BASS, the team's vice president of basketball operations. Others interested in the Charlotte job are BRENDAN MALONE, the former Toronto Raptors coach, and JOHN LUCAS, who was dismissed by the Philadelphia 76ers. (AP)

title: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF ANALOGY FALL AFTER PURCHASES POSTPONED
description: Shares of Analogy Inc. fell 34 percent yesterday after an analyst said that the General Motors Corporation, one of its largest clients, had postponed purchases from the software developer indefinitely. John Barr, an analyst at Needham & Company, also said he had lowered his fiscal 1997 and 1998 earnings estimates for Analogy, of Beaverton, Ore. Analogy shares fell $4.50, to $8.75.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;This Time, He Means It. Seriously. No, Honestly!
description: The jersey is officially memorabilia again.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Voters Ban Leaf Blowers
description: The citizens of Montclair on Tuesday voted 2,815 to 2,096 to retain a seasonal ban on gas-powered leaf blowers. Opponents of the 1994 ban, which forbids the blowing of leaves between June 15 and Oct. 15 and between Dec. 1 and March 1, had argued that it was unfair to single out one piece of noisy equipment.

title: Law Supports Judge In Recusal Dispute
description: To the Editor:

title: Marooned at Sea: Liberian Refugees Tell of Their Ordeal
description: As the hundreds of Liberian refugees whose 10-day ordeal at sea ended on Tuesday with a move to a makeshift camp on the outskirts of this small town recounted their travails, one word recurred with striking consistency.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: GOLF;McCumber to Have Shoulder Surgery
description: Bothered by pain in his right shoulder the past seven months, MARK McCUMBER will try to play through the P.G.A. Championship in August before having surgery to repair a torn rotator cuff. Rehabilitation is expected to take from six to eight months. That could help McCumber, from Jacksonville, Fla., get back in time for the Florida swing and the Masters in April 1997 -- assuming surgery can wait until August.

title: Currents
description: THIS is not the year for earth tones at the eighth International Contemporary Furniture Fair, which opens Saturday at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. Bold reds, blues and yellows show up in upholstered furniture, aniline-dyed woods, and plastic sconces. Kitchen-counter Corian is molded into a springy curvaceous lounge chair. In a nod to the architect Frank Gehry, Joel Stearns, a furniture designer in Venice, Calif., transforms cardboard once again into chairs. The overall spirit is light -- in heart, weight and silhouette.

title: THEATER REVIEW;A Land of Fairy Tales Creepily Come True
description: That fairy tales really do come true in the land of "The Skriker," Caryl Churchill's astonishing new play at the Joseph Papp Public Theater, is hardly a source of comfort. This portrait of a London haunted by unhappy gremlins bears roughly the same relationship to urban living that "Psycho" does to taking a shower, turning the familiar into a hall of terrors.

title: Bridge
description: American experts successfully resisted a strong international challenge in the 22d Annual Cavendish Invitational Pairs, played last weekend at Loew's New York Hotel at Lexington Avenue and 51st Street. Neil Chambers of Schenectady, N.Y., and John Schermer of Seattle led for most of the final session, but were overtaken in the final three deals by Fred Stewart of Andes, N.Y., and Steve Weinstein of Upper Montclair, N.J. Two Italian pairs who own the European team title finished third and fifth.

title: Drug Approved In Bid to Fight Breast Cancer
description: Taxotere, a new drug that has shown strong action against breast cancer in patients who failed to respond to standard treatment, was approved today by the Food and Drug Administration.

title: Andrews Shows Courage in Rejecting Tony
description: To the Editor:

title: Taking Sides at Town Hall: A Standoff for Left and Right
description: It had been billed as an oratorical prize fight, the political left vs. the right -- an effort to breathe new life into the public dialogue on affirmative action in a distracted and entertainment-addled age.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Coca-Cola and Pepsi Plan Big Campaigns
description: The Coca-Cola Company and Pepsico Inc. escalated their continuing marketing battle yesterday by introducing multibillion-dollar promotional programs involving the Summer Olympics and Lucasfilm Ltd., producer of the "Star Wars" movies.

title: World News Briefs;Nepalese Army Rescues 2 Climbers From Everest
description: Army helicopters lifted an American and an Australian from Mount Everest today, ending an ordeal for them that had claimed the lives of eight other climbers.

title: Liberties;This Man Wants a Job
description: Before, Bob Dole didn't have a vision.

title: Henriette Klein, 94, a Professor And an Expert on Schizophrenia
description: Dr. Henriette R. Klein, clinical professor emeritus of psychiatry at Columbia University and a pioneer in the study of childhood schizophrenia, died on May 11 at her home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. She was 94.

title: Queens Prosecutor Bans Plea Bargaining in Felony Cases
description: Prosecutors in Queens will no longer allow plea bargaining for defendants indicted on felony charges, echoing a Bronx policy that continues to provoke debate more than three years after it was introduced.

title: HINDU PARTY HEAD CHOSEN FOR POST OF INDIA'S PREMIER
description: After days of confusion arising from an inconclusive election, India's President chose a Hindu nationalist party today to lead the next Government. The party has pledged to make India a declared nuclear-weapons state, adopt tougher policies on Pakistan and Indian-ruled Kashmir and abolish long-established legal protections for Muslims.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Nickelodeon Programming Planned for Latin America
description: Nickelodeon, the top-rated basic cable network in the United States, announced yesterday that it will expand into Latin America this fall, making its children's programming available in both Spanish and Portuguese.

title: Crash Victims' Relatives Hold a Service Near the Site
description: While the search for the wreckage of Valujet Flight 592 in the Everglades continued, about 100 relatives and friends of the victims visited the marshland for the first time today for a brief memorial service near the crash site.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 4 about the scarcity of Hispanic executives in the publishing industry misidentified the publisher of the novel "Mother Tongue," by Demetria Martinez. It is to be published in September by One World, a division of Ballantine, not by Warner Books.

title: Why Overplay F.D.R.'s Disability in Stone?
description: To the Editor:

title: Killer's Prison Video Sparks Illinois Lawmakers' Outrage
description: Indignant state lawmakers today watched a videotape in the Capitol here showing a mass murderer snorting cocaine, engaging in sex and bragging about living the good life at Stateville prison.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Pitino Plays Down the Rumors
description: RICK PITINO of Kentucky received the first Chase Winged Foot Award at a ceremony in Manhattan yesterday as the winning coach in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: Bye-Bye, Beltway Bob
description: Bob Dole thought that he could best run for the Presidency by staying in Washington and overpowering Bill Clinton with his legislative skills. He has now junked a strategy that bought him plummeting polls and a partywide crisis of confidence. He has chosen to flee the Senate chamber altogether in favor of a national campaign aimed at erasing his image as a Washington insider. He will "look to America" for inspiration. In other words, having failed in his plan to become champion of the Beltway, he will now try to depict President Clinton as its captive.

title: Bit of New Yawk in Vegas;A Virtual City: Glitz, No Grunge and a Casino
description: Should the hotel operators answer the phone, "Yo! Whaddaya want?" and the doormen bid guests goodbye with a "G'wan, get outta here!"? Should the hotel limos be painted like yellow checker cabs? Should the mock subway station be decorated with graffiti, and will the gamblers' cigarette smoke be thick enough to filter faux moonbeams like the Manhattan air?

title: CHRONICLE
description: MELANIE GRIFFITH and ANTONIO BANDERAS were married Tuesday in a private, low-key ceremony at the Westminster register office in London, The Sun reported yesterday.

title: COMMENCEMENT;Columbia's Ceremony Takes Place Peacefully
description: After months of protests over what many students considered insufficient diversity in the curriculum and the faculty, Columbia University's graduation ceremonies proceeded smoothly yesterday as George Rupp, the university's president, urged more than 8,000 graduates to emphasize what they shared rather than where they differed.

title: Stalin Had Victims And Supporters Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Cult Is Done With Terrorism, Guru on Trial in Japan Pledges
description: Seeking to persuade the Japanese Government not to ban his group, the guru of the Aum Shinrikyo religious cult pledged today that it would not commit terrorist acts.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;France Telecom Says Profit Fell 7.3% in Year
description: France Telecom said yesterday that its profit fell 7.3 percent in 1995, hurt by higher corporate taxes and a drop in extraordinary gains. Net income for the state-owned monopoly fell to 9.2 billion French francs ($1.84 billion), from 9.9 billion francs in 1994. Revenue rose to 147.8 billion francs from 142.6 billion francs.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's;Lean Times Are Helping New Music
description: Once upon a time, major artists and major orchestras could join a major label and have their say on the tried-and-true repertory. Such recordings are still made, but they are selling poorly. Reissues and budget labels have taken much of the market. Amid all the doomsaying and dismay is a hopeful sign: labels have increasingly turned to new music for sustenance. Some releases reek of hasty planning and poor judgment; others are significant advances for new music in the minefield of recordings.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Speed Limit of 65 Proposed
description: Defying Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and Transportation Commissioner Frank J. Wilson, two Republican legislators are sponsoring a bill that would raise the speed limit on New Jersey roads to 65 miles an hour from the current 55. Two Assembly committees, Law and Public Safety and Transportation and Communications, are to discuss the issue today.

title: Why Overplay F.D.R.'s Disability in Stone?
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: THE OVERVIEW;DOLE SAYS HE WILL LEAVE SENATE TO FOCUS ON PRESIDENTIAL RACE
description: Declaring that he now has "nowhere to go but the White House or home," Senator Bob Dole announced today that he was resigning from the Senate and forsaking a 35-year Congressional career in hopes of recharging his Presidential campaign.

title: Episcopal Bishop Absolved in Gay Ordination
description: In a long-awaited decision likely to reverberate through America's Protestant denominations, an Episcopal Church court ruled today that an Episcopal bishop did not violate the church's "core doctrine" when he ordained a gay man as a deacon.

title: For Germans, TV Series On Nazi Era
description: At a time of renewed challenge to Germans' perception of the Nazi past, negotiations are under way to produce German television's most comprehensive series about the Holocaust, based on the account of a German Jew who lived through the Hitler era.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Watch Company Chooses Agency
description: Patek Philippe, the marketer of luxury watches based in Geneva, said yesterday that it had selected Leagas Delaney in London to handle its worldwide account, which had been handled for the last decade by the Geneva office of Bozell Worldwide, a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt. Billings were estimated at $15 million. Leagas Delaney was awarded the account after a four-month review that had been narrowed to that agency and two others in London, Bartle Bogle Hegarty and the M& C Saatchi Agency. The new San Francisco office of Leagas Delaney assisted in the review with tasks like market research in the United States.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Suns' Fitzsimmons Is Coming Back
description: COTTON FITZSIMMONS will continue next season in his third head-coaching stint with the Phoenix Suns. Fitzsimmons said yesterday that he and the team president, JERRY COLANGELO, decided months ago that he could remain as coach.

title: Kashmiris Reportedly Kill Four Hostages
description: The Indian police tried today to confirm a report that Kashmiri rebels had killed an American and three other hostages whom they had captured on July 4.

title: Can It Be? Are Paul and Jamie Kaput?
description: You know it's sweep month on television when bad things start happening to good people:

title: 2 Tobacco Giants Seek Anti-Smoking Laws
description: Seeking an alternative to Federal regulation of the nicotine in tobacco as an addictive drug, two tobacco companies proposed yesterday that Congress adopt sweeping laws to reduce teen-age smoking by banning vending sales and restricting advertisements and promotions.

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;Casey Is Aching and the Blues Are Fuming
description: Jon Casey did not practice with the St. Louis Blues today. The goalie wasn't even in sight at Kiel Center as the team prepared for Game 7 of the Western Conference semifinals to be played Thursday night in Detroit.

title: F.A.A. Asserts Valujet Cargo Was Improper
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said today that Valujet was not authorized to carry as cargo the chemical devices that investigators suspect caused a fire or an explosion on one of the airline's planes just before it crashed in the Everglades on Saturday with more than 100 people on board.

title: CHRONICLE
description: YOKO ONO, flamekeeper of the spirit and music of John Lennon, has a new partner: their 20-year-old son, SEAN LENNON. They have been making music together publicly since February, and on Tuesday night, they played to a packed room at Irving Plaza on Irving Place, along with Mr. Lennon's band, Ima.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Mercury goes high tech to sell its first sport utility vehicle.
description: THE Ford Motor Company hopes to make a splash er, crash -- with television commercials for the Mountaineer, the first sport utility vehicle to be marketed under the Mercury nameplate.

title: Factory Output Up in April; Gain Tied to G.M. Reopening
description: Factory output jumped in April, the Government reported today, but the increase was solely a result of General Motors reopening auto plants that had been shut down by a strike.

title: Public Service, or Else
description: President Clinton's philosophy may be enigmatic at times, but his core ideals were on display at a commencement address at Penn State University last Friday. He urged all public schools to make community service mandatory by requiring high school students to volunteer for a certain number of hours in order to earn their diplomas.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Ellis Communications Agrees To a $732 Million Acquisition
description: Ellis Communications Inc. said today that it had agreed to be acquired for $732 million in cash by a new company formed by a merger-and-acquisition lawyer in Boston.

title: Tornado Sightings Soar, But Don't Blame Nature
