description: The number of tornadoes recorded annually in the United States has more than tripled since 1953, a statistic that evokes images of terrifying destruction, of homes ripped apart and cars hurled through the air like baseballs.

title: Work on Escalators to Begin, Disrupting Many Commuters
description: Most of the thousands of bleary-eyed commuters streaming up the escalators at the 53d Street and Lexington Avenue subway station yesterday morning seemed blissfully ignorant of an impending reality: just 24 hours later, their calm rush-hour ritual would turn to chaos. But the Manhattan Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger, was there to remind them.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Food Notes column of The Living Section yesterday about Lioni Latticini, a maker and importer of Italian cheeses, misstated the address of its Brooklyn warehouse, which is opening to retail customers on Fridays and Saturdays from 10 A.M. to 3 P.M. The warehouse is at 7803 15th Avenue, Bensonhurst.

title: Pamela Berdan, 91, Designer of Gardens
description: Pamela R. Berdan, a landscape designer responsible for many gardens in the New York area, died on May 15 at her home in Greenwich Village. She was 91.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Reckless 1995. Evergreen. $96.98. Laser disk, $39.99. 91 minutes. Closed captioned. PG-13.

title: Plan Approved to Let Power Users Pick Suppliers of Their Electricity
description: The State Public Service Commission approved a far-reaching plan today to deregulate New York State's electric industry, a move designed to reduce high electric rates by allowing consumers to choose who will provide their power much as they select a long-distance telephone company.

title: Market Place;Chrysler Lifts Dividend and Splits Its Stock
description: The Big Three auto makers, led by the Chrysler Corporation, which announced a stock split and a dividend increase today, are moving to improve returns to shareholders.

title: Richard M. Clurman, a Leading Editor at Time, Dies at 72
description: Richard M. Clurman, whose passion for journalism brought him to prominence at Time magazine and Newsday and whose passion for New York City made him a leading figure in its cultural affairs, died on Wednesday at his summer home in Quogue, L.I. Mr. Clurman, who lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, was 72.

title: Knudsen Sets Merger With Washington
description: The Morrison Knudsen Corporation said today that it had agreed to merge with Washington Construction Group Inc. in a deal that would erase its $350 million debt by giving creditors a big stake in the new company.

title: FILM REVIEW;Oppression Measured In Suffering
description: On a sunny day in a dusty village, a girl of 8, dressed in a crisp, frilly dress and wearing ribbons in her hair, peers from the attic window of her grandmother's home onto a scene of torture.

title: ART REVIEW;From Sultans in India, Paintings and a Mystery
description: The Deccan is a vast plateau of forest and plain sweeping from coast to coast across south central India. Six hundred years ago, Muslim sultans of Persian and Turkish descent built garrison cities there, replete with lush gardens, domed palaces and workshops for the production of art.

title: SOCCER;Savarese Scores Three In MetroStars' Victory
description: The MetroStars were without Roberto Donadoni and Tab Ramos tonight, but they got a hat trick from Giovanni Savarese -- the only man who has scored in the team's brief history -- in a 3-0 triumph over the Colorado Rapids.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Tougher Sentencing Passes
description: After the mother of Megan Kanka pleaded for its passage, the state Senate unanimously approved a bill that would require people convicted of violent crimes to serve at least 85 percent of their sentences before being eligible for parole. The measure now goes to the Assembly.

title: Some Catholics in Nebraska Face Excommunication Order
description: As of this week, a former priest and nun and perhaps hundreds of other Roman Catholics in the Diocese of Lincoln can consider themselves excommunicated.

title: Freemen Group Talks With F.B.I. Negotiators
description: After tentative handshakes on a muddy road, agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and members of the extremist Freemen group met face to face today for the first time since the standoff between them began on March 25.

title: POLITICS: BEHIND THE SCENES;Bringing Out the Essential Bob Dole
description: Of all those left behind as Senator Bob Dole headed off today into the dawn of a revived campaign, few seem more wistful than Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican who has quietly become Mr. Dole's shadow adviser, surrogate articulator and filial booster.

title: POLITICS: MAJORITY LEADERSHIP;2 Competitors From Mississippi Vie to Lead Senate Republicans
description: The race for Bob Dole's successor as the Senate majority leader narrowed today to his top two deputies, Mississippi's pair of Senators, who share an adherence to conservatism but are vastly different in demeanor and style.

title: Don't Wait to Deploy a Limited Missile Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;School Uniform Bill Passes
description: Like President Clinton, the state Legislature and Governor Whitman think that clothes may make the student. The state Assembly passed a measure yesterday authorizing school districts to require uniforms. The Assembly has already passed the bill, but it will return to that house because a provision that would have allowed parents to request an exemption for their children was deleted by a Senate committee. The governor approves of the idea but has not reviewed the bill, a spokesman said yesterday.

title: For Children
description: Great Small Works Toy Theater Performance and Workshop Gowanus Arts Exchange 295 Douglass Street, between Third and Fourth Avenues Gowanus, Brooklyn (718) 596-5250 Recommended ages: 7 and up Tomorrow and Sunday

title: FILM REVIEW;Friendly, Smart And Wet
description: Traditionally at this time of year something jumps out of the sea and onto the movie screen, asking to be loved. So here comes Flipper, a finny star in the 1960's and now a more technologically advanced, less unself-conscious version of his former self.

title: Diner's Journal
description: It's busier than I ever remember," crowed Wade Sinclair. Mr. Sinclair, who has been a service captain at Gage & Tollner for over 25 years, had stopped by our table to see if we needed anything. "Look at this crowd!" he exulted.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Hanson Earnings Rise Ahead of Split-Up
description: Hanson P.L.C. detailed the spinoff of its chemicals, tobacco and energy businesses yesterday as it announced a 19 percent gain in earnings. Hanson said that beginning Oct. 1, Millennium Chemicals Inc. will be listed on the New York Stock Exchange and Imperial Tobacco Group P.L.C. will be traded on the London Stock Exchange. The company said it planned to complete the breakup in January with the listing of its as-yet unnamed energy company in New York and London. The building and materials group will keep the Hanson P.L.C. name.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HEALTHSOUTH AGREES TO BUY PHYSICAL THERAPY PROVIDER
description: The Healthsouth Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire Professional Sports Care Management Inc., a provider of outpatient physical therapy, for $67 million. Healthsouth, based in Birmingham, Ala., a provider of rehabilitation services for disabled patients, said the purchase would add 36 sites to its network of 900 outpatient centers in 45 states. Professional Sports Care is based in Harrison, N.Y. Under the agreement, the company's shareholders are to receive 0.233 share of Healthsouth's common stock for each share they own. The shares of Healthsouth fell 50 cents yesterday, to $35.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. Professional Sports Care shares rose 12.5 cents, to $7.50, in Nasdaq trading. Healthsouth said that if its stock price were to rise above $38.625 during a specified period, the exchange ratio would be adjusted.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the political connections between Albany legislators and New York City school boards included an outdated reference to James Sullivan, who was indicted last month for ballot fraud in the 1993 school board elections. He is no longer a member of the Ben Franklin Democratic Club in Riverdale, according to a club spokesman, Assemblyman Jeffrey Dinowitz.

title: Clinton Prods Executives to 'Do the Right Thing'
description: Seeking to encourage American companies to take more responsibility for the well-being of their employees, President Clinton presided today over meetings and seminars with business executives that he said offered proof "you can do the right thing and make money."

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Star-Starved Cannes Focuses the Limelight
description: IN the Suite Clint Eastwood at a local hotel, 18-year-old Liv Tyler, the doe-eyed star of Bernardo Bertolucci's "Stealing Beauty," was being readied for a hard day's work. While a makeup artist added nice but needless extra luster to the 5-foot-10-inch knockout, a security guard was parked out in the hall. The previous evening, rampaging paparazzi at the Nice airport had given Ms. Tyler a taste of what high-octane Cannes attention feels like. She was here last year with a small film called "Heavy," but this time she is the Cannes International Film Festival's unofficial 1996 poster girl. Her image is plastered prettily all over town.

title: Bob Dole's Timely Escape
description: Bob Dole had many good reasons to announce his departure from the Senate: to disassociate himself from the numbing technicalities of the legislative process, to shed his image as the ultimate Washington insider, to jolt voters who are bored with him. But the most basic explanation is that he no longer has to preside over a fractured Republican Party.

title: Lesedi Cultural Village Journal;My Hut Is Your Hut: South Africa's New Tourism
description: The amahewu pours cooly, if a bit lumpily, down the throat. The mixture of grits, sugar and cold water tastes every bit as good as it sounds.

title: HOCKEY;Islanders' Goal: a Forward
description: When the National Hockey League holds its second annual lottery on Sunday to determine the order of the June 22 draft, the Islanders will have a 15.1 percent chance of winning the top pick. If they do, the chances are much greater that they would trade the pick, the general manager and coach, Mike Milbury, said today.

title: U.S. PLANS BONDS THAT GIVE SAVERS INFLATION GUARD
description: In an effort to get Americans to save more, the Treasury announced plans today to issue a new type of Government bond that would protect average investors from inflation as well as help the Government finance the national debt.

title: Data Show Rise In Productivity And Housing
description: Fresh statistics pointing to an expanding economy were released yesterday, including an extremely healthy rise in workplace productivity and a surprisingly big jump in home building.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: News Summary
description: International A3-11

title: Higher Calling for a Philippine Entrepreneur
description: MANILA  Lucio Tan is a hero or a tax-evader, depending on your point of view. But by nearly everyone's reckoning here, the tobacco and beer baron is a leading power broker in the Philippines and probably the country's richest man.

title: BOXING;Deal With Lewis Frees Tyson to Seek Title
description: Mike Tyson's march to regaining the unified heavyweight crown was back in step yesterday. And all it took was $4 million.

title: Tough Talker For a Delicate Job;China at Top of Trade Chief's Agenda
description: On the verge of becoming acting United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky faced a particularly delicate negotiating challenge: persuading three hockey fans at a bar to change the channel on the television.

title: British Would Yield to I.R.A. on Arms if Cease-Fire Is Revived
description: Prime Minister John Major of Britain said today that if the I.R.A. restored its cease-fire, the British and Irish Governments would not insist on the group's immediate disarmament when a conference to discuss peace and the political future of Northern Ireland started on June 10.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Edison Site to Get Face Lift
description: By 1993, the Edison National Historic Site, where Thomas A. Edison invented the phonograph and hundreds of other things, had become so run down that the National Trust for Historic Preservation listed it as one of "America's Most Endangered Historic Places." Yesterday, the National Park Service announced it had awarded a $139,000 contract to Princeton-based architects Ford, Farewell, Mills & Gatsch for a plan to restore the site, which includes a laboratory, factory buildings and Edison's home.

title: ART REVIEW;Enter Youth, Quieter and Subtler
description: SPRING, however reluctant, always brings a rise in the number of first shows, those gallery exhibitions by which artists young or unknown first dip into the ebb and flow of the New York art world. Such shows have been unusually abundant recently, and that is fitting, perhaps, for a season that, after a slow start, is concluding with a flurry of interesting shows by older, more established artists.

title: Clinton Uses Loophole in UN Accord to Extend Life of 'Dumb' Land Mines
description: President Bill Clinton on Thursday moved to comply with a recent United Nations accord requiring land mines to be made self-deactivating, and he ordered his administration to work toward a global ban on all kinds of anti-personnel mines.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Powder 1995. Hollywood. Laser disk, $39.99. 112 minutes. Closed captioned. PG-13.

title: Sports of The Times;'Dead Men' Still Live On Newsreel
description: THE baseball season got serious Tuesday night when Dwight Gooden pitched his no-hitter. As word spread at courtside in Chicago, a few basketball reporters inadvertently pumped their fists and smiled, the way we had in the old Chicago Stadium in 1992 when Michael Jordan lobbed in six 3-point shots in one half.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Kikkoman Selects Foote, Cone Office
description: Kikkoman International in San Francisco said yesterday that it had named the San Francisco office of Foote, Cone & Belding to handle its consumer soy sauce account, which had been handled for more than a decade by the Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide unit of Cordiant P.L.C. in San Francisco. Billings were estimated at $6 million.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Playing by the Rules, but Flexibly

title: Inside Art
description: Two Museums Benefit From One Sale

title: His Medals Questioned, Top Admiral Kills Himself
description: The Navy's highest ranking officer, Adm. Jeremy M. Boorda, committed suicide today, shooting himself in the chest shortly after he was told of an impending magazine article suggesting that he wore two Vietnam War combat decorations that he had not earned.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Details of School Plan Due
description: After months of delay, the Whitman administration is scheduled to make public today its closely guarded proposals for complying with a New Jersey Supreme Court order to eliminate spending inequities between richer and poorer school districts. A new law must be in place by September.

title: BASEBALL;No Hits and No Sleep: Reflections by Gooden

title: COMPANY NEWS;NALCO CHEMICAL TO BUY WATER TREATMENT UNIT OF MOLSON
description: The Molson Companies said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Water Technologies business to the Nalco Chemical Company for $112 million (Canadian), or about $82 million (United States). Water Technologies provides water treatment services in Canada, the United States, Britain and Italy. The business had sales of $82 million (Canadian) in the fiscal year that just ended. Nalco is a chemical concern based in Naperville, Ill.; Molson, which is based in Toronto, is best known for its brewing business.

title: Fossil of a Terror That Dwarfed T. Rex Is Found
description: Exploring the Sahara in southeastern Morocco, paleontologists have found the fossil remains of two huge predatory dinosaurs. The discovery is seen as a major step in uncovering Africa's early fossil past and understanding the evolutionary changes in dinosaurs after the breakup of the continents.

description: When "Heavy Metal" is officially released on videotape by Columbia Tri-Star on June 4, it won't be the first time Gerald Potterton's animated cult hit has been popped into a VCR.

description: The countdown began today for a weekend liftoff of the space shuttle Endeavour on a science mission.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;Interpublic continues its spate of major takeovers with acquisition of Draft Direct Worldwide.
description: THE Interpublic Group of Companies in New York, continuing a spate of major acquisitions, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Draft Direct Worldwide in Chicago, which until yesterday had been -- for less than a year -- the largest independent worldwide shop specializing in direct marketing.

description: The Dallas Mavericks, Cleveland Cavaliers, Phoenix Suns and Utah Jazz will play in a preseason tournament designed to raise the National Basketball Association's profile in Mexico.

title: Finding Personal Spaces in Public Places
description: NEW YORK is a city of paradoxes, of vast, public places and hermetic enclaves, of private, almost anonymous spaces that we appropriate as our own. It's as if every walker in the city had his own mental map of the urban zone, engraved with his own private landscape. We fix upon a patch of park, or a room in a museum where few ever seem to venture, or maybe a restaurant in an out-of-the-way spot or an unusual store, and they become sanctuaries that we take possession of as our own. In this way, the city becomes personal as well as public. These are places to which we return again and again, drawn to them as if to say, This city is my own: I claim it here.

title: POLITICS: ON THE ROAD;A New Dole Kicks Off a New Campaign
description: Bob Dole started his campaign all over again today, shedding Washington, the Senate and even his standard Beltway attire to project the image of a new man on a new mission.

title: Jeremy M. Boorda, 57; Rose Through Ranks
description: Adm. Jeremy M. Boorda, the Chief of Naval Operations and the first man in the history of the United States Navy to rise from the lowest rank of sailor to four-star admiral, died today from a self-inflicted gunshot wound at his home in the Washington Navy Yard, Pentagon officials said. He was 57.

title: FILM REVIEW;A Fuming Caretaker's Deadly Idolatry
description: What is it about fame that makes sensible people go gaga and turns unstable fans like Mark David Chapman and John Hinckley into homicidal stalkers? In its sharpest moments, "Homage," a disquieting, superbly acted examination of the circumstances surrounding the shooting death of a television star, closes in on some uncomfortable truths. Many of them have to do with the way celebrity in America can make fragile people feel so empty and insignificant that they lash out.

title: 25 and Under
description: Once, street fairs were exciting. They brought a sense of wonder to New York neighborhoods, replacing for a day the dull regularity of passing cars and buses with dancing, singing, food and laughter. But these mini-carnivals have become devoid of individuality, populated by interchangeable T-shirt booths, cut-rate sunglasses and, of course, the dreaded funnel cake, as generic a collection of goods as ever disrupted traffic.

description: With more than eight minutes left in the game, the crowd was on its feet, the outcome clear.

title: COMPANY NEWS;$1.1 BILLION TO BE PAID FOR OIL STAKE IN KAZAKSTAN
description: The Mobil Corporation announced the terms yesterday of its acquisition of a 25 percent interest in the giant Tengiz oilfield in Kazakstan. Mobil said it would pay $1.1 billion for the stake, with an initial payment of $500 million. The rest is to be paid in installments through the year 2000 if milestones in exports of crude oil from the field are met. Mobil, which is based in Fairfax, Va., said that it had also obtained an option to acquire another production or exploration interest in Kazakstan.

Purporting to search out public opinion about food stamps, she engaged a leading Democratic pollster in a crudely disguised, politically targeted survey of voter attitudes in the Kansas and Illinois constituencies of Bob Dole, the presumed Republican Presidential candidate, and the Congressional Agriculture Committee chairmen.

title: COMPANY NEWS;METROCALL TO BUY A+ NETWORK IN PAGING MERGER

The purchase, the sixth by Metrocall since February, will give it 2.5 million customers. Metrocall, which is based in Alexandria, Va., plans to buy A+ Network in two steps. It plans a tender offer for 2.1 million A+ Network shares at $21.10 a share and intends to buy 2.2 million shares directly from certain A+ Network shareholders. Metrocall said it would exchange each of the remaining A+ Network shares for $21.10 worth of Metrocall stock. The shares of A+ rose $4.75, to $20.25, yesterday in Nasdaq trading. The shares of Metrocall slipped 37.5 cents, to $20.125, also on Nasdaq.

description: In a Solomon-like answer to a prickly question, House Republicans will split the subcommittee that handles telecommunications and finance issues into two panels to accommodate two lawmakers with claims to the subcommittee chairmanship.

description: Japan's four biggest brokerage houses reported today that they had returned to profitability in the latest fiscal year as rallies on the stock and bond markets lifted commissions.

title: COMPANY NEWS;A 3-FOR-1 STOCK SPLIT IS PLANNED BY XEROX
description: The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that it would split its common stock 3 shares for 1. The split will be paid on July 1 to shareholders of record on June 17. After the split, Xerox, a maker of photocopiers and other document processing equipment, will have 1.05 billion shares outstanding. Xerox stock slipped 12.5 cents yesterday, to $153.75 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange. Xerox, which is based in Stamford, Conn., also declared a 29-cent quarterly dividend on the new shares, payable July 1 to shareholders of record on June 17. It is comparable to the current dividend of 87 cents.

title: BASEBALL;Bonds Loses Rage, but Not the Swing
description: If, as they say, the calm at the center of a storm portends imminent danger, let National League pitchers beware. For Barry Bonds is at peace for the first time perhaps since his rookie year. And because Bonds has turned two parts introspective for every one part that remains rebellious, he is more focused and happier than at any time since his m.v.p. days earlier this decade.

title: Station Work Begins, With Free Transfers
description: Work began yesterday to repair escalators at the 53d Street and Lexington Avenue subway station, but riders transferring there between the No. 6 line and the E and F lines were granted a one-day reprieve and allowed to switch trains without paying a second fare.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Profits Increase 6% At British Telecom
description: British Telecommunications P.L.C. said yesterday that its profits rose 6 percent in the year that ended on March 31, showing that its efforts to stimulate demand for telephone services were working despite slack growth in the economy. Pretax profits for the period increased to L3.02 billion ($4.58 billion) from L2.66 billion for the previous year. The report was at the top end of many analysts' forecasts.

title: After 18 Years, Newark Searches for 5 Boys Who Vanished
description: On a hot Sunday afternoon in August 1978, five teen-age boys played basketball on a court in south Newark, went home for dinner and went out again. The five, all good friends 16 or 17 years old, have been missing ever since, as though swallowed by the sultry night.

title: COMPANY NEWS;COMPUSA TO ACQUIRE DIRECT-MAIL COMPUTER SELLER
description: CompUSA Inc., the largest chain of computer stores in the nation, said yesterday that it would acquire PCs Compleat Inc., which sells computers and peripheral equipment through direct mail, in a stock deal worth about $123 million. Under the agreement, CompUSA will offer about three million shares of its stock for PCs Compleat, a closely held company based in Marlborough, Mass. The shares of CompUSA, which is based in Dallas, rose by $5.125, to $44.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

But lack of money is no excuse for holding families with small children at an intake office in the Bronx for eight days in conditions that one doctor described as "worse than any animal housing I have ever witnessed."

title: COMPANY NEWS;CROMPTON & KNOWLES WON'T SELL FOOD INGREDIENTS UNIT
description: The Crompton & Knowles Corporation said yesterday that it would keep its food ingredients business, which it had intended to sell, so that it could acquire the Uniroyal Chemical Corporation. Crompton & Knowles agreed early this month to buy Uniroyal Chemical for $370 million in stock in a deal that is worth $1.4 billion with the assumption of debt. But Crompton & Knowles said it would not be allowed to account for the acquisition as a pooling of interests, which is tax free, if it were to sell the ingredients business. Under such accounting, Crompton & Knowles will not be allowed to sell assets of either company.

title: COMPANY NEWS;QUAKER OATS TO SELL FROZEN-FOOD LINES TO VAN DE KAMP'S
description: The Quaker Oats Company said yesterday that it would sell its Aunt Jemima brand of frozen waffles and pancakes and its Celeste line of frozen pizza to Van de Kamp's Inc. to concentrate on cereals and the Snapple and Gatorade beverages. Quaker declined to say how much Van de Kamp's, a closely held company based in St. Louis, was paying for the businesses, which had about $175 million in sales last year. The combined units, which Quaker put up for sale in March, were valued at $110 million to $140 million at that time by William Maguire, an analyst at Merrill Lynch. Quaker, which is based in Chicago, will retain the Aunt Jemima trademark for its syrup, corn products and pancake-mix businesses. The majority shareholder in Van de Kamp's is the investment firm Fenway Partners.

Mr. Vajpayee, president of the main Hindu nationalist party, portrays himself as a conciliator and plays down his party's pledge to dismantle longstanding protections for the country's Muslim minority. But the party has not repudiated its platform, and if enacted it would tear India apart. To his credit, Mr. Vajpayee says he wants to govern by consensus and accommodation. No prime minister of India can afford to do otherwise.
