title: Where the Land Is Dry
description: It has been so wet for so long in the Northeast that one begins to forget what drought looks like. That has not been a problem for residents of the Southwestern states, who watch with increasing dismay as the fat burns off the land around them. For most of us in the Mid-Atlantic region and New England, drought brings with it images of drawn-down reservoirs, their shorelines pathetically extended. It brings a sudden awareness of the capacity of toilet tanks and unmasks the wastefulness of lawn-watering and car-washing habits.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Profits Are Up 3.2% At Grand Metropolitan
description: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. said yesterday that its pretax profit rose 3.2 percent in the six months that ended on March 31 after gains at its Pillsbury unit offset a drop at Burger King and unchanged earnings at its International Distillers and Vintners liquor division. Pretax profit before one-time items was L455 million ($689 million), compared with L441 million for the corresponding period last year. The Minneapolis-based Pillsbury was responsible for the overall increase, with its profits rising 50 percent, to L247 million, as a result of higher sales and the acquisition of Pet Inc.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Alitalia Discloses Plan To Keep Itself Afloat
description: Alitalia, Italy's national airline, said yesterday that it would split its operations in two and cut its work force in an effort to stay afloat. The revamping plan, the third by Alitalia in two years, was approved by the state holding company IRI, which controls the airline.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Older, and Perhaps Wiser?
description: Young dancers sometimes look like angels, and they can be a joy to behold. But what makes Netherlands Dance Theater 3 special is that its dancers, all over 40, look like interesting people who have lived interesting lives. And they can move with both technical skill and dramatic authority, as they demonstrated when they presented their second program on Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater.

title: An Aging Atlanta Treasure Struggles for Its Survival
description: In little more than 24 hours, the city of Atlanta suffered two architectural disasters.

title: Some Medical 'Myths' Sometimes Turn Red;Mental Health Link
description: To the Editor:

title: Abroad at Home;'A Dangerous Time'
description: A 10-day visit to Israel left me with the impression of people in a conflicted state, torn between anxiety and hope. David Grossman, whose extraordinary novels and nonfiction have illuminated the inner lives of Israelis and Palestinians, said:

title: GOLF;Levi, the Star of 1990, Finds Rare 1996 Success
description: The Texas winds that blew across the Colonial Country Club today were hot and hard, and while they baked the fairways and greens of this historic golf course, they also breathed life into a trio of inert golf games.

title: Dominican Republic Votes, With New Blood in the Race
description: Responding eagerly to a rare opportunity to bring a new generation of leaders to power, Dominicans flocked to the polls today in the first phase in a watershed presidential election.

title: Don't Wait to Deploy a Limited Missile Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Rookie Team Picked
description: The rookie of the year DAMON STOUDAMIRE heads the National Basketball Association All-Rookie team announced yesterday.

title: OLYMPICS;At This 200-Meter Crossing, Sparks Will Fly
description: A cautionary note regarding the Olympic coronation of Michael Johnson: The 200-meter crown will have to be wrested from the shaved head of Mike Marsh, who has run faster than Johnson before and may have developed the consistency to do it again.

title: Real Estate;A new program is rehabilitating some 1,200 rental apartments in New York City.
description: DEVELOPERS using public and private funds under New York City's new Neighborhood Entrepreneur Program are rehabilitating nearly 1,200 rental apartments for low- and moderate-income families.

title: Flooding Closes Yosemite
description: All roads to Yosemite National Park were closed this morning because of flooding.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Police to Get $37 Million
description: The United States Justice Department has awarded grants to enable New Jersey cities like Camden and Atlantic City to put more police officers on the street. Camden will receive $1.8 million to hire civilians and buy equipment, freeing up 25 officers from desk work, officials said Wednesday. A $1.5 million grant to Atlantic City will allow that city to redeploy 20 officers. New Jersey received a total of $37 million in the latest round of police grants -- second in the nation only to California.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Kelly Habib Merges With Duval Woglom
description: Kelly Habib John Advertising in North Andover, Mass., has acquired Duval Woglom Brueckner & Partnersin Boston and merged the two agencies to form KHJ Integrated Marketing Inc. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Corrections
description: Articles on April 5, 6 and 28 about the April 3 crash of an Air Force jet in Dubrovnik, Croatia, included a misspelled version of the co-pilot's surname, supplied by the Defense Department. He was Capt. Timothy W. Shafer, not Schafer.

title: 3 Men Wounded in Shootings At Crown Heights Apartments
description: Three men were critically wounded yesterday in an afternoon shooting at an apartment building in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, the police said.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Identity, and Its Absence, by Way of Sam Shepard
description: CRUISING PARADISE By Sam Shepard 239 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $23.

title: Honda to Expand in U.S.
description: The Honda Motor Company said today that it and its suppliers would spend $300 million and create 1,200 jobs at plants in Ohio and Michigan, part of a plan to increase Honda's United States engine and transmission production. Honda said it would increase United States production of automatic transmissions to 650,000 units beginning in 1997.

title: FILM REVIEW;Romance On the Run As a Plague Closes In
description: All it takes for civilization to explode into a frenzied panic is a rampant cholera epidemic. The madness that attends such a plague is a gripping leitmotif that runs through Jean-Paul Rappeneau's gorgeously picturesque film "The Horseman on the Roof" like a cagey rat skittering across a banquet table. In one scene after another of this sumptuous 19th-century costume drama, an idyllic rural tableau worthy of Corot or Millet is shattered when a character suddenly goes pale, collapses to the ground and succumbs to racking spasms that quickly end in death. The victims attract flocks of crows feasting on human carrion.

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;Red Wings Advance In Overtime Thriller
description: For most of this splendid Game 7, the two captains played on lines that were matched against each other. Steve Yzerman of Detroit and Wayne Gretzky of St. Louis must have skated 40 minutes each amid the precious tension of Joe Louis Arena.

title: Leonardo the Lefty
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL;Harnisch and Mets Catch Their Breath
description: It would be much too optimistic to think one game can turn around the Mets' sluggish season. So today's 6-3 triumph over the San Diego Padres served primarily as a chance for the Mets to exhale and feel good about themselves for a couple of hours before trying to make it a start of something more significant.

title: UPN Is Adding Comedies With Black Casts
description: Looking to bring in new audiences with a batch of new comedies with black casts, the fledgling UPN network announced its fall schedule yesterday. It adds six new series and one new night, Wednesday, making it a three-night network.

title: MCI and BellSouth Agree to Link Networks
description: The MCI Communications Corporation and the BellSouth Corporation said today that they had agreed to link their local telephone networks in five states. It is the first such multistate agreement between MCI and a regional Bell phone company.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CHASE BRASS TO BUY A STEEL UNIT OF UNR INDUSTRIES
description: Chase Brass Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire UNR-Leavitt, a maker of tubular steel products that is owned by UNR Industries of Chicago, for $95 million. UNR-Leavitt had sales of $156 million in 1995. Chase Brass, which is based in Montpelier, Ohio, makes brass rods for plumbing fixtures, as well as heating and air-conditioning parts, industrial valves and other products. Its stock rose $1.25, to $19.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: COMPANY NEWS;WESTINGHOUSE CUTTING STAFF, MOSTLY AT CBS STATIONS
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation has said that it is cutting 129 broadcasting employees, primarily members of the support staff at CBS television stations. Westinghouse disclosed the cuts in documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Wednesday. Most of the cuts have already occurred, and they typically involved financial and clerical employees, company officials said. Severance costs for dismissing the employees will amount to about $5 million and were covered by charges against earnings for the first quarter, Westinghouse said. Westinghouse bought CBS for $5.4 billion last year. CBS has about 8,000 employees.

title: Planetary Perspective
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Justice Status in Doubt
description: This time, DAVID JUSTICE's shoulder injury could keep the Atlanta Braves' right fielder out for the season. The Braves, who placed Justice on the 15-day disabled list yesterday, said the outfielder may be lost for the season if surgery is required on his dislocated right shoulder.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Fund-Raiser for Police Chief
description: Police Director William R. Celester, whose use of police funds is the subject of a Federal investigation, will be the beneficiary of a $100-a-plate fund-raiser May 29 to help pay his legal bills. Former Mayor Kenneth Gibson, who is organizing the dinner, said yesterday that he knew from experience that his friend Mr. Celester would need help. "I was investigated and indicted and tried a long time ago -- and acquitted -- and the whole thing cost the city more than a million dollars," said Mr. Gibson, who faced corruption charges in 1983. The city would only pay Mr. Celester's legal fees if he is tried and acquitted. Tickets to the event are being distributed in the Newark Police Department. Mr. Celester has been reassigned to other duties since Federal agents raided his home and office last November and seized boxes of records.

title: Brazil's President Offers Plan to Curb Human Rights Abuses
description: President Fernando Henrique Cardoso, who has built broad popular support by curbing inflation and bringing economic reforms to Brazil, has turned his attention to rampant human rights abuses with a plan that would extend federal authority to prosecute a wide range of violations.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Chronicle column yesterday about a performance tomorrow evening by the Directors Company to honor Stephen Schwartz, the Academy Award-winning composer and lyricist, misstated the location. The event will be at the Lambs Theater on West 44th Street, not at the Lambs Club.

title: Taylor Is Charged in Crash
description: Two weeks after being arrested on drug charges in South Carolina, the former Giants star Lawrence Taylor has been charged with leaving the scene of an accident and driving with a suspended license, the New Jersey State Police said today. Taylor crashed his car on Route 80 and was not seen for more than five hours after a passing motorist stopped to pick him up, the police said.

title: COMPANY NEWS;J P FOODSERVICE TO ACQUIRE VALLEY FOOD OF NEVADA
description: J P Foodservice Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the privately held Valley Food Distributors of Nevada for $42.2 million plus the assumption of debt. Valley is an institutional food service distributor that serves the Las Vegas market. The company has annual sales of about $126 million. J P, based in Columbia, Md., a distributor of food to restaurants, hotels and cafeterias, will issue about two million shares to Valley Food, subject to adjustments. J P has annual sales of about $1.21 billion.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Arts pages on Wednesday about summer concerts gave an incorrect date for the Boston Pops concert at Forest Hills Stadium in Queens. As noted in an article in The Metro Section about the stadium the same day, the concert is to be on Aug. 2, not July 2.

title: 6.83% Yield As Prices Rise On Treasuries
description: Reports showing a wider United States trade deficit and weaker consumer sentiment eased fears of an overheating economy yesterday and sent Treasury prices sharply higher.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;More Women Cite Sexism
description: Over a quarter of New Jersey female executives cited sexism as an obstacle in their careers -- a 6 percent increase over last year, according to a survey conducted by Executive Women of New Jersey, a professional group. However, a majority of the executives also said that male mentors had been important to their career achievement.

title: Invasion of the Wind Collectors
description: The number of tornadoes sighted each year in the United States has tripled in the last half-century. Experts say this is because there are more people out looking for them. Some particularly accessible tornadoes now draw crowds like fireworks displays. "It ranges from one or two people you might know to dozens and dozens and dozens," a Kansas City meteorologist told The Times. The idea, it seems, is to grab your video camera, find a funnel on the horizon, and film it for posterity and the National Weather Service record books.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Alitalia Unions Reject Plan to Revive Airline
description: Unions at Alitalia rejected a new rescue plan for the troubled Italian air carrier yesterday and accused management of seeking to break up the state-owned company and sell it off in pieces. Thursday, Alitalia's managing director, Domenico Cempella, disclosed his package of staff cuts, reduced costs and a capital increase of 3 trillion lire ($1.9 billion).

title: Real Environmentalists
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Payroll Tax Is Blocked
description: A Superior Court judge in Hudson County ruled yesterday that Jersey City cannot impose a payroll tax on businesses for the fourth quarter of 1995, and must pay back the $2.5 million it has collected. The ruling supported the position of the county Chamber of Commerce and several businesses that filed suit in March to block the 1 percent tax. Mayor Bret Schundler of Jersey City, who said the levy was necessary to hold down soaring property taxes, said yesterday that the decision would be appealed.

title: Chief Justice Offers Advice to Appellate Lawyers: Be Prepared
description: Calling argument before the Supreme Court a form of art, Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist took on the role of critic today and offered appellate lawyers some pointed advice on how to argue a case.

title: 2 Elderly Women Beaten to Death in Brooklyn
description: Two elderly women were found beaten to death in their apartment in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn yesterday, the police said.

title: In Performance;POP
description: Tunes Along With Tales Of Gershwins and Al Capone Larry Adler, harmonica player Village Vanguard

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: COMPANY NEWS;2-FOR-1 STOCK SPLIT SET AS WELL AS HIGHER DIVIDEND
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company announced a 2-for-1 stock split yesterday as well as a 20 percent increase in its quarterly dividend. The announcement comes just one day after Hewlett reported that its second-quarter earnings rose a less-than-expected 25 percent on disappointing sales of work stations and disk drives, sending its stock down 7 percent. Shares of the No. 2 computer maker behind I.B.M. rose after yesterday's announcement, climbing $4.125, to $109.375. Hewlett-Packard raised its quarterly dividend to 24 cents from 20 cents a share. The dividend will be paid on July 10 to shareholders of record on June 19.

title: New Leader In Italy Picks 20 Members For Cabinet
description: Moving in record time to put together Italy's new center-left Government, Romano Prodi, the Prime Minister-elect, announced his Cabinet today. It includes several former Communists, two former Prime Ministers and a former prosecutor who was the hero of a corruption inquiry.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Blades Now Pleads Not Guilty
description: Seattle Seahawks receiver BRIAN BLADES pleaded not guilty to manslaughter charges yesterday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., changing his no-contest plea in the July 1995 slaying of his cousin.

title: Christopher Says He Seeks Regular Talks With China
description: While China and the United States threaten to impose trade sanctions on each other, Secretary of State Warren Christopher, speaking in New York yesterday, called for regular summit meetings between the countries and frequent Cabinet-level exchanges to keep relations from drifting from one crisis to another.

title: In Performance;CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Plunking a Mozart Quintet Into Music of the Americas Quintet of the Americas

title: F.A.A. Cites Problems With Airline and Oversight
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said today that Valujet airlines had been beset by safety problems in the weeks before the Florida Everglades crash on Saturday and that in investigating those problems the agency had discovered deep flaws in its own monitoring of the airline.

title: COMPANY NEWS;POSNER SWEETENS BID TO PURCHASE ALL OF SALEM
description: The Salem Corporation of Carnegie, Pa., said yesterday that its former chairman, Victor Posner, who owns 49.2 percent of its common stock, had sweetened his bid to buy the rest of the company for $20.8 million, or $22 a share. Mr. Posner raised his bid from $20 to match an offer on May 9 from a group of Salem managers, who offered to buy the entire company, including Mr. Posner's shares, for about $41 million. Salem, a maker of industrial furnaces and coal-processing equipment, has been seeking a buyer for more than a year. Mr. Posner, a 77-year-old financier, wants to take Salem private to circumvent a Federal court order in 1993 that bars him from being an officer or director of any publicly traded company. Salem rejected his $20-a-share-bid last month.

title: The Budget Minuet
description: As the City Council opened hearings on Mayor Giuliani's proposed $32.7 billion budget this week, there were striking similarities to budget maneuvering in years past. But Council members say they believe they have already gone beyond their usual scripted role in the process.

title: New Jitters for Hong Kong;In Economics, as in Politics, China Exerts Control
description: It was supposed to be a lift-the-glass rally for the future of Hong Kong business. Beijing's de facto ambassador, Zhou Nan, recently described the paradise that awaits the colony after the Union Jack comes down on June 30, 1997, and the Chinese flag goes up. One after another, tycoons and corporate chieftains raved over his vision.

title: BASEBALL;Justice Out for Season
description: The World Series champion Atlanta Braves will be without one of their top hitters, right fielder David Justice, for the rest of the season.

title: Divorce Given Beleaguered Congresswoman
description: A judge said today that he would grant Representative Enid Greene's divorce request over the objections of her estranged husband, Joe Waldholtz.

title: Art Critics Are Critical Of Each Other's Criticism
description: Although they are silent and nonliterary, the visual arts generate a lot of talk and a lot of writing. The question is, is anyone paying attention? And if they are, can they make sense of what the critics are saying? At the American Craft Museum in Manhattan on Wednesday, a panel of critics and curators addressed the specter haunting art criticism, the nagging sense that arcane language and bad writing are alienating the educated public and perhaps even discouraging interest in contemporary art.

title: Postmodern Gravity Deconstructed, Slyly
description: A New York University physicist, fed up with what he sees as the excesses of the academic left, hoodwinked a well-known journal into publishing a parody thick with gibberish as though it were serious scholarly work.

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;Roy Prepares for Red Wings and Hopes All Bad Things Must End
description: Patrick Roy knows the Red Wings. The Colorado goalie faced them five times this season, and lost five times. The most memorable loss was on Dec. 2, in Roy's last game with the Canadiens.

title: POP REVIEW;Rapping With Hugs And Smiles
description: De La Soul spent part of its set at Tramps on Wednesday night praising original, old-school rap, the music of big boasts and simple drumbeats. The band was on a double bill with the fast-rising rapper Busta Rhymes, another old-school fan, and it was flaunting its longevity. One song asked, "Whatever happened to the MC's?"; De La Soul also shouted verses of Run-D.M.C.'s "It's Like That." The odd thing was that when De La Soul released its debut album in 1989, the group broke away from old-school rap.

title: CUNY's Students Are Worth the Investment
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL;A Pinstriped Curiosity: The Maeda Sideshow
description: It was like a fifth Beatle was discovered. The hysteria was amazing, all caused by someone who had never been seen or heard from before in these parts. All caused when a big unknown kid with an orange-blond flattop walked into a packed room.

title: BASEBALL;Pettitte Victory Good Medicine For Yankees
description: Yankee Stadium needed a glass of warm milk last night, something smooth and calming to settle this place down.

title: Whitman Offers Fiscal Plan for Parity in Schools
description: The Whitman administration released its long-awaited school financing plan today, saying it wants to increase state spending on education by $235 million so that local districts can meet new curriculum standards without resorting to higher property taxes.

title: Federal Aid For Renewal Is Endangered
description: Eighteen months after the Federal Government announced with great fanfare that it was providing $100 million to help revitalize Harlem and parts of the South Bronx, the redevelopment proposal is being threatened by a bitter dispute between city and state officials.

title: Journal;Media Amok
description: It was just another night on the 11 o'clock news. Yes, an admiral had committed suicide, and Bob Dole had restarted his campaign, and Valujet was twisting slowly in the muck. But on WNBC in New York, none of these stories got quite the in-depth treatment lavished upon George Steinbrenner's first in-person appearance on "Seinfeld." Or non-appearance: the Yankee boss, it eventually turned out, had been left on the sitcom's cutting-room floor.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SCHULLER CORP., Denver, which makes foam products for roofing and residential building insulation, agreed to acquire the privately held NRG Barrier Inc. of Portland, Me., another maker of insulation and buiilding products, for an undisclosed price.

title: Look to Britain for Enlightened Policy on Maternity Leave
description: To the Editor:

title: Irma Badillo, 72, an Organizer For the Equal Rights Amendment
description: Irma Badillo, an adviser to Governors Mario M. Cuomo and Hugh L. Carey, died yesterday at the Cabrini Hospital Hospice in Manhattan. Mrs. Badillo, who lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx until she was transferred to the hospice this month, was 72.

title: U.S. Attorney in South Florida Quits After Inquiry Into ReportedAltercation
description: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of Florida resigned today after the conclusion of a Justice Department investigation into allegations that he had an altercation at a topless bar days after losing a major drug case here.

title: Steady Rate Policy Is Seen At Fed's Tuesday Meeting
description: With inflation under control despite low unemployment and a revival in economic growth, the Federal Reserve is almost certain to leave short-term interest rates at current levels when its policy-making body meets on Tuesday, economists say.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Oil Reaches Ocean Beaches
description: Oil from a spill on May 10 in Delaware Bay off Cape May unexpectedly started washing up on beaches from Stone Harbor to Ocean City yesterday, according to the State Department of Environmental Protection, which is coordinating the cleanup effort. The oil is part of a 10,000-gallon spill from the tanker Anitra, whose French owners are paying for the cleanup.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;More School Funds Sought
description: The Whitman administration released its long-awaited school financing plan yesterday, saying it wants to increase state spending on education by $235 million so local districts can meet new curriculum standards without resorting to higher property taxes. Almost two-thirds of the state's 595 districts would receive more aid, while 146 would get less. [Page 1.]

title: TRACK & FIELD;Morceli Predicts Something Special
description: He speaks softly, as if he is slightly embarrassed to draw all this attention to himself. But however modest, Noureddine Morceli of Algeria carries with him a quiet candor. If he says that he might run the fastest mile ever run in the United States, chances are he will.

title: Latin Mass Can Unite Diverse Catholic Groups
description: To the Editor:

title: AUTO RACING;Brayton Killed in Crash During Indy 500 Practice
description: Scott Brayton, the pole-sitter for the 80th Indianapolis 500 on May 26, crashed and was killed yesterday at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway when a blown tire sent his car spinning into a concrete wall while he was traveling at about 220 miles an hour.

title: Blue Cross Lawsuit Filed Against Missouri
description: Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Missouri, the state's largest health insurer, is taking the state to court over its bid to collect hundreds of millions of dollars from the company.

title: F.C.C. Clears Way For City's Sale Of WNYC License
description: The Federal Communications Commission cleared the way yesterday for New York City to sell the commercial license for WNYC, the city's television station, rejecting objections from a coalition of broadcasters who had argued that a sale would eliminate an outlet for their unique ethnic programs.

title: Sam Lopata Is Dead at 54; 'Guru' of Restaurant Design
description: Sam Lopata, whose whimsical and exuberant restaurant designs set the standard for grand cafes in New York City, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 54.

title: POLITICS: BACK HOME;Kansas Ponders the Void Left by Dole's Departure
description: Four years ago, a tornado tore through McConnell Air Force Base here, smashing barracks and leaving the kind of devastation that might have led to the post's closing.

title: Mayor's Ban On Contracts To an Agency Is Questioned
description: A Federal judge said yesterday that she had serious concerns about whether Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had abused his power by ordering that no city contracts be given to a Queens social service agency as long as it was a subject of a criminal investigation.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;2 Bodies for the 2 Marilyn Monroes
description: It has been a long time since we've thought of Marilyn Monroe as a simple sex goddess. Almost from the minute of her death she came to be seen as a sad, lonely victim. Andy Warhol may have captured the flat iconic image of her movie star glamour, but the Monroe who dominates the public imagination is the heroine of Elton John's "Candle in the Wind," the sentimental song that begins, "Goodbye, Norma Jean," and goes on to tell of a vulnerable woman who never found the love she desperately needed.

title: In Performance;THEATER
description: Domineering Lesbians And the Women Who Love Them 'The Killing of Sister George' Willow Cabin Theater Company

title: Tandy Acts to Raise Corporation Sales
description: The Tandy Corporation said today that its Computer City unit had signed an agreement with the computer services company Electronic Data Systems that is intended to improve its sales to corporations.

title: But Will We Watch the Candidates on TV?
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Observer;Ado About Dole
description: Bob Dole's quitting the Senate is the quintessential Washington political story, and the Washington press corps, starved for subject matter ever since Pat Buchanan retired from the field of battle, pounced on it as though it mattered to the rest of the country. It doesn't.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Fish Census to Begin
description: Snorkelers, divers, swimmers and other ocean lovers will start their season-long Fish-O-Rama tomorrow with a day of lectures and exhibits at Sandy Hook. Participants may register to take part in the Fish-O-Rama, which is a summer-long census, sponsored by Clean Ocean Action and the American Littoral Society, to count marine species in New Jersey waters.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Train Late but Show Goes On
description: The show must go on, even if the trains don't run on time. Passage Theater in Trenton had a special 5:30 P.M. performance of Beth Henley's play "Signature" on Wednesday, timed to make attendance convenient for state employees after work. At curtain time, a capacity crowd was in the audience, but three of the six actors were stuck on a New Jersey Transit train stalled in Elizabeth, an hour away. The theater offered refunds, but most of the audience waited. Management ordered out for wine and pizza for all, said Elizabeth Murphy, the show's producer. The show finally went on at 6:40 P.M. JOE SHARKEY

title: Making the World Safe for Diversity
description: Democracy is a process, not an event. But the democratic event of the year so far -- the election, by nearly 60 percent of 590 million eligible voters, of a new Government for India -- was hailed for its reaffirmation of a process. For the 11th time nationally, the Indian people chose their representatives, casting their ballots in more than 800,000 polling places for 14,700 candidates belonging to 522 political parties in an election universally considered free, fair, honest -- and dull.

title: POLITICS: ON THE ROAD;Clinton Signs Bill on Warning of Sex Offenders
description: President Clinton signed legislation today that requires states to warn communities when convicted sex offenders who might still pose a danger settle in their neighborhoods. He then took to the campaign trail to highlight his anti-crime initiatives and raise campaign money for House Democrats.

title: F.D.A. Approves a Biogen Drug for Treating Multiple Sclerosis
description: Biogen Inc. said yesterday that it had received approval from the Food and Drug Administration to begin marketing Avonex, its genetically engineered drug for the treatment of multiple sclerosis. Avonex will be available by prescription beginning Monday.

title: Judge Baer's Exit
description: In January, Federal District Judge Harold Baer Jr. ignited a major controversy when he refused to admit 80 pounds of drugs as evidence against a confessed drug courier in a New York City case. He also said he did not view fleeing the police as suspicious behavior in a neighborhood known for its police corruption problem.

title: Vote in Dominican Republic Forces a Runoff by 2 Leftists
description: The first round of balloting in a watershed presidential election here has ended with none of the three major parties winning a majority, forcing what promises to be a contentious runoff next month between two left-of-center candidates.

title: Look to Britain for Enlightened Policy on Maternity Leave;Dominican Women
description: To the Editor:

title: F. Lee Bailey Yields to U.S. in Fight for Stock
description: F. Lee Bailey today unexpectedly ended his battle with the Federal Government by giving up his claim to millions of dollars in stock that once belonged to a drug smuggler he represented.

title: Times Co. to Pay $226 Million in TV Deal
description: two television station, saying that it would pay $226 million to buy KFOR-TV of Oklahoma City and WHO-TV of Des Moines. The purchase of the stations, both NBC affiliates, was announced on Tuesday.

title: World News Briefs;U.S. Canceling Visas Of Bogota Officials
description: The United States has decided to cancel the visas of some high-ranking Colombian officials under investigation by the justice authorities here for suspected ties to drug traffickers.

title: Bridge
description: When a young man brings a young woman home to mother, the traditional question is, "Can she cook?" But in some circles a much more important question is, "Can she play bridge?" A positive answer is not enough. Proof is needed at the table.

title: HORSE RACING;Preakness Mud May Benefit Skip Away
description: Grindstone will not be there with his Kentucky Derby trophy, and Unbridled's Song will not be there with his cracked hoof. But 90,000 spectators will be there on Saturday jamming Pimlico Race Course on Maryland's grandest day of racing when Cavonnier and Prince of Thieves head a field of 12 horses in the 121st running of the Preakness.

title: North Korean Soldiers Fire Shots in the DMZ, Seoul Says
description: Seven North Korean soldiers entered the tense demilitarized zone between the two Koreas today and fired shots in the air before retreating when South Korean troops fired warning shots, the Seoul Government said.

title: Man Pleads Guilty To Phone-Cloning
description: A man has pleaded guilty to illegally programming hundreds of cellular phones to allow customers to chat without cost while phone companies footed the millions of dollars' worth of phone bills.

title: Military Combat Insignia Are Key to Officers' Image
description: Military people wear their careers over their hearts and on their sleeves. Their ribbons, bars, patches and medals testify to their service. And to have been in combat lends a commander an extra measure of credibility, former officers say.

title: Smaller Is Better: Conde Nast in Times Sq.
description: In architecture, downsizing is seldom a cause for dismay. Four Times Square, a building scheduled to rise on Broadway between 42d and 43d streets, is a case in point.

title: Corrections
description: Picture captions yesterday with an article about the new offices of the Hyperion Software Company in Stamford, Conn., referred incorrectly in some editions to amenities provided for workers. The billiards table and the gym were installed by Hyperion; they were not left behind by the former occupant.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Average Climbs 52.45, As Nasdaq Sets a Record Blue-chip stocks soared but ended just shy of a new high, closing up 52.45 points at 5,687.50, while the Nasdaq composite index set another record, gaining 2.57 points, to close at 1,242.88. Wall Street was soothed by new consumer data showing the economy was just plodding along, not about to overheat.

title: COMPANY NEWS;LIBERTY MEDIA TO GET BIG STAKE IN VIDEO JUKEBOX
description: The Liberty Media Corporation has agreed to acquire a controlling stake worth up to $32 million in Video Jukebox Network Inc., operator of the Box interactive music-video network. Liberty plans to purchase 5.6 million shares of Video Jukebox for $2 each, or a total of $11.2 million, from a shareholder group. The group will grant Liberty an option to buy another 5.7 million shares at $2 each. Subject to board approval, Video Jukebox will also issue Liberty options to buy an additional 4.7 million shares at $2 each. Liberty already holds between 5 percent and 10 percent of Video Jukebox. The shares rose 6.25 cents yesterday, to $1.75, in Nasdaq trading.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: POLITICS: THE DECISION;How Dole's Decision to Resign Was Kept a Secret
description: By the day in late April when Senator Bob Dole called in his Presidential campaign manager to disclose that he had decided to resign from the Senate after discussions with his wife, Elizabeth, the Senate majority leader was under siege.

title: POLITICS: THE AD CAMPAIGN;Republicans' Return to a Tested Weapon
description: This is a revised version of a commercial that the Republican National Committee ran last fall. It is to be broadcast nationwide on CNN and in select markets around the country, beginning Friday or Saturday, as part of a $20 million campaign that the committee said yesterday it would wage until the Republican National Convention in August.

title: Judges' Group Criticizes Pataki For Proposal to Curtail Paroles
description: The association that represents New York State Supreme Court justices passed a resolution yesterday sharply criticizing Gov. George E. Pataki's proposal to eliminate parole for all violent felons, in a move that the judges hope will encourage the Legislature to scuttle the plan.

title: FRAGILE MOSAIC -- A special report.;In a Search for 'Turkishness,' Turks Reveal Their Diversity
description: Few countries honor their gods the way Turkey reveres Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, whose military skills and authoritarian hand reassembled parts of the crumbling Ottoman Empire and fashioned them into the modern Turkish state.

title: New Netscape Software Flaw Is Discovered
description: Computer science researchers at Princeton University said yesterday that they had discovered a new and potentially serious flaw in the Netscape Communications Corporation's Navigator software, the leading program used to browse the World Wide Web of the Internet.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-6

title: From the Rank and File, Little but Praise for a Fallen Chief
description: I've spent 20 years in this Navy," Firecontrolman First Class Bob Mock said, "and I've seen a lot of C.N.O.'s come and go. But none of them was as impressive as Mike Boorda. He was a people person, had his feet down on the deck where the action really is. He was getting things shipshape again."

title: Latin Mass Can Unite Diverse Catholic Groups
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;COGNEX SHARES FALL AS INCOME ESTIMATES ARE CUT
description: The shares of the Cognex Corporation fell 16 percent yesterday after analysts reduced their earnings estimates for 1996 and 1997 because of order delays for its semiconductors. The company told analysts on Thursday that it was experiencing order delays in its semiconductor business, a Cognex spokeswoman said. The company's products are used to automate manufacturing operations where vision is required. Shares of Cognex, based in Natick, Mass., fell $4 a share, to $18.50, in Nasdaq trading of almost 5.7 million shares.

title: Indian Leaders Try to Calm Fears of a Pakistan Conflict
description: Setting out to allay fears it has stirred at home and abroad, India's new Hindu nationalist Government said today that it would seek "the best of relations with Pakistan" and speed market-based economic reforms that have begun to stir the economy out of decades of socialist sluggishness.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SUN TO BUY SOME CRAY RESEARCH ASSETS
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. and Silicon Graphics Inc. said yesterday that they had agreed to a deal in which Sun will buy Sun-related assets of the supercomputer maker Cray Research Inc., which was recently acquired by Silicon Graphics. The deal allows Silicon Graphics to dispose of the portion of Cray's business that was closely tied to Sun Microsystems, which remains a major competitor of Silicon Graphics in the computer work station market. Financial terms were not disclosed. Under the deal, Sun will acquire the Cray CS6400 enterprise server, a computer based on Sun Microsystem's Sparc-Solaris microprocessor chip and operating system, which runs with other large computer systems manufactured by Sun.

title: Inflation Fighters for the Long Term
description: Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin announced on Thursday that the Government plans to issue inflation-indexed bonds -- that is, bonds whose interest and principal payments are adjusted upward for inflation, guaranteeing their real purchasing power in the future.

title: Executive Changes
description: OVATEK INTERNATIONAL INC., Boynton Beach, Fla., named Gaston Oxman president, effective in July. He will replace Frank J. Cooney.

title: Rent Board Proposes Biggest Increases in 7 Years, Citing Costly Winter
description: Reacting to higher fuel costs during the harsh winter, the Rent Guidelines Board has proposed the highest rent increases in seven years, setting the stage for a clash between New York City landlords and tenants.

title: Corrections
description: An article and obituary yesterday about Adm. Jeremy M. Boorda, the Chief of Naval Operations, misstated his age. He was 56, not 57.

title: Camden Gets Financial Monitor
description: Responding to a state audit that found widespread waste and mismanagement in Camden's government, the state appointed a fiscal monitor for the city today.

title: Corrections
description: An article and obituary yesterday about Adm. Jeremy M. Boorda, the Chief of Naval Operations, misstated his age. He was 56, not 57.

title: A 940-Pound Man Is Taken to Hospital
description: A Brooklyn man with a 93-inch waist and an estimated weight of 940 pounds was carried by forklift from his living room yesterday into an ambulance, which took him to the Obesity Research Center at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan.

title: No Headline
description: I didn't know people were using deconstructive literary criticism not only to study Jane Austen but to study quantum mechanics."

title: No Pedigree Required
description: To the Editor:

title: Disney Says His Resignation Bars Bonuses to Katzenberg
description: The Walt Disney Company fired back against Jeffrey Katzenberg today, contending that the former studio chief was well aware of the financial consequences of leaving the company and should not receive millions of dollars in damages.

title: Rig Count Down by 15
description: The number of oil and gas rigs operating nationwide dropped by 15 this week, to 757, Baker Hughes Inc. said today. There were 673 rigs operating in the United States during the corresponding week last year. Of the rigs running this week, 463 were exploring for natural gas and 285 for oil. Nine rigs were listed as miscellaneous. The rig count represents the number of rigs actively exploring for oil and natural gas.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CAPITAL CITIES IN PACT TO BUY OUT SPECTRUM HOLOBYTE
description: Capital Cities/ABC Inc., a unit of Walt Disney Company, said yesterday that it had bought out its partner, Spectrum Holobyte Inc., in a sports video game venture the two companies formed last year. Terms were not disclosed. The equally owned venture, called OT Sports, was formed to develop interactive game software under the ABC Sports brand. Spectrum, an interactive software company based in Alameda, Calif., said it had sold its 50 percent stake to focus on non-sports categories.

title: Helium Legislation Preserves U.S. Needs
description: To the Editor:

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Copper Drops on Stockpile Rise; Gasoline Falls and Wheat Is Up
description: Copper prices tumbled yesterday as an unexpected rise in stockpiles indicated slowing demand from China and Europe, two major sources of global demand.

title: Look to Britain for Enlightened Policy on Maternity Leave;Voting Pocketbooks
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: THE MONEY;Dole's Campaign, With Only $177,000 on Hand, Plans to Sell Some Assets
description: Bob Dole's Presidential campaign has only $177,000 left to spend between now and the Republican National Convention in August, but campaign officials said today that they expected to raise $1.2 million by selling certain assets like computers and telephone systems.

title: Bidder Defaults on F.C.C. License Payment
description: A start-up wireless telephone company that bid more than $800 million for licenses in a recent Government auction has defaulted on a key payment, Federal regulators said today.

title: Israeli Candidates Vie for 'Ethnic Vote'
description: The main event on Benjamin Netanyahu's campaign schedule today was a "meeting with Russian intellectuals," and it gave the Likud Party candidate a chance to try to move away from security issues that have dominated the Israeli campaign.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Prime Rate Is Raised To 20.5% in South Africa
description: South African banks raised their prime interest rate yesterday for the second time in three weeks. Standard Bank of South Africa Ltd., First National Bank of Southern Africa Ltd. and Nedcor Bank Ltd. all raised their prime lending rates to 20.5 percent from 19.5 percent.

title: INSIDE
description: Valujet's Problem History

title: Man Sentenced to 6 Months in Wife's Suicide
description: George Delury, a Manhattan editor who helped his wife commit suicide, was sentenced to six months in prison yesterday, a month after he pleaded guilty to attempted manslaughter.

title: WB Is Setting Up a System That Will Use Cable Stations
description: The WB Television Network, which since its start 16 months ago has had trouble competing with other broadcast networks because of limited distribution, has developed a technology that could allow it to extend its reach through small cable systems.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Power Problem Slows Flights
description: A faulty circuit breaker at an Elizabeth switching station delayed flights at Newark International Airport yesterday morning and knocked out electricity for up to two hours to 31,000 homes in Elizabeth, Roselle, Linden, Roselle Park and Union, Public Service Electric and Gas said. The airport's control tower had a backup power supply, but hour-long delays were caused by inoperable electrical equipment used to service planes.

title: The Hague Journal;A Most Artful Forger Now Beguiles the Dutch
description: Harry Anderson, an American Army captain, was taken aback that day at the end of World War II when he walked into the deserted country home of Hermann Goring, the Nazi leader. Captain Anderson, an art historian in civilian life, had spotted an unknown painting bearing the signature of the 17th-century Dutch master Johannes Vermeer.

title: Corrections
description: The Personal Health column on Wednesday about effects of antidepressant drugs on sexuality misidentified the class of drugs to which Wellbutrin (bupropion hydrochloride) belongs. It is an aminoketone, not a tricyclic antidepressant.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Arrest in Burned-Bodies Case
description: Paul Chissolm, 33, identified by prosecutors as a drug dealer, was charged yesterday with murder in the deaths of the man and woman whose bodies were found bound and burned in Weequahic Park in Newark on May 6. The motive in the killings of Catherine Brown, 36, and Peter E. Sizemore, 35, was a dispute about more than $600 worth of heroine and cocaine, said Edward M. Neafsey, Acting Prosecutor for Union County.

title: GOLF;Mediate Beating Heat in Colonial
description: For the second straight day, the Colonial Country Club was the cure for the ailing golfer. With hot winds blowing steadily, 20 to 30 miles per hour and gusting to 40, with the temperature soaring to 95 degrees, this time it was Rocco Mediate's turn to walk unscathed through the fiery furnace.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Alouettes Get Frazier's Rights
description: The Montreal Alouettes acquired the Canadian Football League rights to Nebraska quarterback TOMMIE FRAZIER, whose chances of playing in the National Football League were hurt because of blood clots in his leg.

title: THEATER REVIEW;3 Women United Only by Solitude
description: It may not be your idea of a searing anthem of human isolation. But Olivia Newton-John singing "Please Mr. Please" on a jukebox is enough to break the liquor-pickled heart of Maggie, the lonely, angry heroine of Keith Reddin's "Brutality of Fact."

title: COMPANY NEWS;REMEC TO ADD MAGNUM MICROWAVE FOR $20 MILLION
description: Remec Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the Magnum Microwave Corporation for stock valued at about $20 million at Thursday's closing price. Magnum Microwave is a privately held company that makes microwave components for commercial wireless and defense customers. The company had revenue of $9.4 million in the year that ended on March 29. Remec, a maker of equipment for microwave transmission systems used in military applications, had revenue of $52.8 million in its year ended Jan. 31. The San Diego-based company will exchange about 1.08 million shares for Magnum. Its stock jumped $2.625, to $21.125, in Nasdaq trading. Magnum is based in Fremont, Calif.

title: Beliefs
description: Under threat of torture," Reynolds Price said cheerfully on Wednesday, "I would describe myself as a renegade Christian."

title: COMPANY NEWS;OLD REPUBLIC IS PLANNING REPURCHASE OF ITS STOCK
description: The Old Republic International Corporation said yesterday that it planned to buy back up to $150 million of its common stock in the next two years. Old Republic, a Chicago insurance holding company, said it believed the recent trading price of its shares did not accurately reflect the company's financial performance. Old Republic stock was up 12.5 cents, at $21.875 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange. The company said the purchases would be made in the open market or in privately negotiated transactions and would depend on market conditions.

title: OPERA REVIEW;How Dance Helps Music Express Itself
description: Dancers have things to tell us about opera, so when Mark Morris and his dance group address "Orfeo ed Euridice," as they did at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Thursday, we do well to pay attention.

title: Security Firm Ousted at Fulton Fish Market
description: For 20 years, Victor Grande has operated one of the largest parking lots and guard services for merchants at the Fulton Fish Market.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;11 Encores for Ravenous Carreras Fans
description: In some ways Jose Carreras's recital on Thursday night at Carnegie Hall was no place for a music critic. By now, the dramatic personal story of this popular Spanish tenor, who turns 50 this year, looms far larger than his artistry. While his Three Tenors colleague Luciano Pavarotti contends with a weight problem, Mr. Carreras has conquered leukemia. He has turned his struggle into impressive activism as the president of a foundation to combat the disease. That he is performing at all is a personal triumph. This lends his singing, even in a breezy Neapolitan song, a quality of gravitas that audiences respond to. His fans at Carnegie Hall, who last had a chance to hear Mr. Carreras in recital four years ago, were tireless and vociferous in their adulation.

title: Act I: Mayor Cuts. Act II: Council Adds.
description: As the New York City Council opened its hearings on Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's proposed $32.7 billion budget this week, Council members could not help noticing several striking similarities to budgets of years past.

title: World News Briefs;U.N.-Iraq Talks On Oil Deal Stalled
description: Talks between Iraq and the United Nations on a plan for Baghdad to sell oil to pay for urgent civilian needs remained suspended today as negotiators waited for President Saddam Hussein to either accept or reject a deal.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Mobil and Royal Dutch To Develop Peru Field
description: The Mobil Corporation and Royal Dutch/Shell Group signed a 40-year agreement with the Peruvian Government to invest more than $2.5 billion to develop the Camisea gas field, Perupetro S.A., the state company negotiating the transaction, said yesterday. The company said the Shell-Mobil venture would invest $200 million in the first phase of the project, expected to last two years. The venture will invest a further $2.5 billion in the second phase, expected to last four and a half years. Perupetro said the Camisea reserves held 12.2 trillion cubic feet of gas, with recoverable reserves of about 9 trillion cubic feet of gas. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Saints Shake Up Front-Office
description: JIM MILLER was dismissed yesterday as executive vice president for administration for the New Orleans Saints. No reason was given for the owner TOM BENSON's dismissal of Miller, who was once part of a front-office triumvirate that guided the Saints after the former team president, Jim Finks, left the team in 1993 because of illness. (AP)

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;China Maneuvers Hurt Growth in Taiwan
description: Taiwan's economy in the first quarter grew at a pace slower than the Government had predicted because of the effects of Chinese military exercises in March, a Cabinet agency said yesterday. Gross domestic product rose 5.3 percent in the first three months of 1996 from a year earlier, less than the gain of 5.8 percent predicted in February. The agency also lowered its forecast of G.D.P. growth from all of 1996 to 6.17 percent from a previous 6.36 percent. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: What Companies Can Do
description: President Clinton deserves credit for what he did not say during this week's White House seminar on corporate responsibility. With polls registering high levels of anxiety over job security and stagnant wages, politicians are drawn to blaming managers. Some criticism is surely deserved, but corporation-bashing is no answer for everything that ails the economy.

title: Olga Marie Madar, 80, Pioneer For Women in Automotive Union
description: Olga Marie Madar, who rose to the top echelon in the United Automobile Workers and fought for women's rights in the labor movement, died on Thursday at her home in Detroit. She was 80.

title: Import Surge Raises Deficit In U.S. Trade
description: The nation's trade deficit widened in March as imports climbed to a record while the 17-day strike against the General Motors Corporation contributed to a small decline in exports, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Some Freemen Are Called Hostages of Their Leaders
description: A mediator in the Freemen standoff in Montana has described the besieged group as ruled by a hard core of leaders who are holding peripheral followers, including three girls, as hostages.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Bradshaw and Payton Honored
description: TERRY BRADSHAW, who won four Super Bowls with the Pittsburgh Steelers, and the National Football League's career rushing leader, WALTER PAYTON were among 10 former small-college stars selected yesterday for the College Football Hall of Fame in South Bend, Ind.

title: Presumed Best Seller;Law Student Wins Top Money for First Novel
description: Glassy-eyed from poring over textbooks, most law school students do not have time for page-turners that command six-figure advances from major publishing houses. But Brad Meltzer, who picked up his law degree from Columbia University on Wednesday, plowed through just such a thriller -- three or four times.

title: The Spy-for-a-Spy Showdown: Russia Expels 4; So Does Britain
description: Eleven days after it claimed to have uncovered a British spy ring, Russia expelled four British diplomats today on accusations of spying and Britain in turn expelled four Russian diplomats, accusing them of espionage.

title: Latin Mass Can Unite Diverse Catholic Groups
description: To the Editor:

title: World News Briefs;Police in India Dig For Westerners' Bodies
description: The Indian police dug for bodies in a Kashmiri village today, apparently to investigate claims that four Westerners kidnapped by Kashmiri separatists last year had been killed.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;National Power Plans A Special Dividend
description: National Power P.L.C., a British electricity generating company, announced a special dividend yesterday of about L1.14 billion, or about $1.71 billion. National Power said investors would get the dividend of $1 a share subject to their approval of a L1.7 billion ($2.55 billion) sale of power plants to the Eastern Group, a regional utility.

title: BASEBALL: METS NOTEBOOK;Mlicki Is Starting To Enjoy Relief Role
description: Dave Mlicki has bounced back and forth from starter to reliever during his one-plus seasons with the Mets, filling whatever need the pitching corps had at the time.

title: Bobbing and Weaving on Issue of Layoffs
description: It was two days before the White House was to convene its long-awaited conference this week on corporate responsibility, and Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich was warming to the theme. Increased political and media pressure recently placed on corporate executives over layoffs, he argued, had forced managers to think twice about downsizing their work forces.

title: GOLF;A Can't-Miss Day for Murphy
description: The galleries crowded around such golfing quarterbacks as Dan Marino and Phil Simms and Boomer Esiason. They watched every move of such golf legends as Arnold Palmer and Lee Trevino and Raymond Floyd.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;Seles Will Return to Action In Madrid Tourney Next Week
description: MONICA SELES will return to competitive tennis next week in the Madrid Open. The Madrid tournament will be Seles's first competition since February, when she lost to Iva Majoli in the quarterfinals of the Pan Pacific tournament in Tokyo.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Mason Is Treated for Migraine
description: ANTHONY MASON was admitted to Beth Israel North Division Hospital yesterday morning for treatment of a persistent migraine the Knicks forward had been suffering from for two days.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Mexico's Economy Shrinks, But Not as Fast as Before
description: The badly bruised Mexican economy continues to show mixed signals with a steady recovery belying a nagging underlying weakness.

title: U.S. COMPUTER BID WON BY JAPANESE
description: Rejecting calls that it select an American computer maker, the National Science Foundation announced yesterday that it planned to buy a supercomputer from the NEC Corporation, the first such purchase by the Government from a Japanese company.

title: About New York;Public Art Helps Create New Artists
description: PUBLIC SCHOOL 4, all red brick and bright colors, is an overdue addition to a block in Washington Heights that once seemed burned out beyond reason or redemption. The strip of West 160th Street off Amsterdam Avenue was once so awash in drugs that the eager dealers gladly sold crack cocaine to a United States Senator and a Federal prosecutor who came to the block camouflaged in macho leather jackets, shades and baseball caps.

title: Fair Access to Public Schools
description: A study carried out in New York City by an advocacy group reveals dramatic differences in how black or Hispanic parents are treated in contrast with whites when they seek information about public schools and their programs for gifted students. Black and Hispanic volunteers posing as parents were routinely brushed off and denied information, while whites were actively wooed. The disparate treatment helps explain why, in a school system that is overwhelmingly minority, the enrollments in gifted programs examined in the study are overwhelmingly white.

title: COMPANY NEWS;U.P.S. GOES AHEAD WITH WEEKEND CHARTER FLIGHT PLANS
description: United Parcel Service said yesterday that it would go ahead with plans to fly people on weekend charter flights. U.P.S. said it would modify five 727-100 jets to carry passengers on weekends. The freight carrier has been considering making some of its planes available to charter operators because most of its Boeing 727's are not used on weekends. A spokesman, Ken Shapero, said the program will not begin until after Christmas. Passengers will book the flights only through a cruise line or tour operator, Mr. Shapero said.

title: Ex-Staff of White House Travel Office Sues
description: Seven employees who were dismissed from the White House travel office after Bill Clinton became President are suing a Clinton friend and his business partner, accusing them of prompting the dismissals.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about homeless people who spend days in a processing center in the Bronx waiting for shelter misstated the scope of a contempt citation arising from the situation. The judge cited the city and two city agencies, not Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Sports of the Times;A Backstop For Gooden To Lean On
description: WHEN Ronald Dock received his daily call from Dwight Gooden earlier this week, he had to muster every ounce of control to contain his emotions. So full of joy and pride, he had to wear his greatest mask of restraint.

title: BID FOR COALITION TO BAR COMMUNIST FADES IN MOSCOW
description: Hopes that Russian democrats had of forging a united front against the Communist Party in next month's presidential election suffered badly today when President Boris N. Yeltsin's main liberal challenger harshly rejected all pleas that he abandon his long-shot quest for the presidency.

title: Edgar Ortenberg, 96, A Violinist Faithful To His Instrument
description: Edgar Ortenberg, a violinist in the Budapest String Quartet in the 1940's and a violin teacher in Philadelphia, died on Thursday at his home in Philadelphia. He was 96.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;Bulls Face a Familiar Challenge in Grant
description: The enduring symbol of last year's playoff series between Chicago and Orlando was Magic forward -- and the former Bull -- Horace Grant being carried off Chicago's home court by his teammates after the final Magic victory. If the Bulls are to put an exclamation point on their record-setting 72-victory season, and return to the N.B.A. finals, they will have to stop Grant, a main component of the Bulls' three-championship run from 1991 to 1993.

title: BASEBALL;Key Placed on 15-Day D.L.
description: Bewildered by his recent performance, Jimmy Key will have time to ponder where his pitches and career are going after the Yankees placed him on the 15-day disabled list yesterday with stiffness in the same left shoulder that underwent rotator cuff surgery last July.

title: F.B.I. Agent Won't Testify At Mafia Figure's Hearing
description: In an unusual turnabout, an agent with the Federal Bureau of Investigation has decided not to testify at a hearing on Monday in Brooklyn for a convicted Mafia boss because the agent is himself under internal investigation for possibly leaking Government secrets to a gangster.

title: Pavarotti, His Illness Continuing, Pulls Out of a Recital
description: Luciano Pavarotti, still fighting the illness that forced him to bow out of several recent performances including his own Pavarotti Plus concert on May 1, has withdrawn from the duet recital he was to have sung with the soprano June Anderson at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday. The recital, which was hastily scheduled as a makeup for the Pavarotti Plus concert, has been canceled.

title: Admiral, in Suicide Note, Apologized to 'My Sailors'
description: In the final minutes of his life, Adm. Jeremy M. Boorda sat down to type a letter of apology to the men and women of the United States Navy -- "my sailors," as he had always called them.

title: CUNY's Students Are Worth the Investment
description: To the Editor:

title: Johnny (Guitar) Watson, Musical Pioneer, Dies at 61
description: Johnny (Guitar) Watson, a flamboyant pioneer of rhythm and blues whose music influenced performers like Jimi Hendrix, Frank Zappa and Stevie Ray Vaughan, died on Friday just after he took the stage for a performance in Yokohama, Japan. He was 61 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Habitats/West 120th Street;In Harlem, With France and Africa on Her Mind
description: WHEN Elaine Evans was living in France, she chose a place on the outskirts of Paris, because she doesn't like living smack in the center of a city.

title: For the Loft Movement, A Defining Moment
description: SOMEWHERE in the not-too-distant past, with a wink and a nod to the landlord, an unknown artist pushed a dolly loaded with large canvases -- or crates full of photographic equipment or, perhaps, a block of raw material clenching an unborn sculpture -- onto the freight elevator of a dank, deserted factory in lower Manhattan. And then, after unloading onto one of those expanses of floor where a platoon of poorly paid workers had once toiled, she or he bedded down for the night.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY;The Processes That Make the Pictures
description: FOR now, it may be little more than the shared obsession of two passionate antiquarians. Tomorrow it may be a new scholarly field, and perhaps a new domain of collectibles as well.

title: IN PERSON;Revise! Revise! Revise! And Then It's a Poem
description: Peter Murphy, who teaches English at Atlantic City High School, starts off his classes by announcing he will say a particular dirty word of four letters. The word, he says, is poem. Boring stuff, pointless and stilted, he says. The Rodney Dangerfield of arts.

title: Facets of Clinton
description: IT IS MIDNIGHT OVER THE ATLANTIC AND the President of the United States is wide awake. He is returning from an extraordinary antiterrorism summit in Egypt and a 24-hour visit to Israel, where he was praised as the peacemaking hope of the world. He has eaten a dinner of grilled shrimp and teriyaki linguine, played five games of hearts, watched a movie and talked to reporters traveling aboard Air Force One for a solid hour on topics from Arafat to Farrakhan, from the V-chip to the N.C.A.A.

title: Children's Books;What Is Dust?
description: THE GOLDEN COMPASS His Dark Materials, Book One. By Philip Pullman. 399 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $20. (Ages 8 and up)

title: MINDING YOUR BUSINESS;Divorce: Can You Get It for Me Wholesale?
description: Q. Is it possible to find a lawyer willing to negotiate a flat-fee divorce?

title: WEDDINGS;Becky Broers, Patrick H. Quinn
description: Becky Broers, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel J. Broers of Akron, Ohio, was married yesterday to Patrick Henry Quinn, the son of Thomas and Lois Quinn of Warwick, R.I. The Rev. Luis Leon performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Lafayette Square in Washington.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC;A Life Stranger Than Art, Even His Eccentric Art
description: A NOVELIST WOULD BE HARD pressed to invent a life more implausible than that of the Brazilian pianist Joao Carlos Martins. It is a story of public acclaim and private tragedy, of traumatic injury and obstinate recovery. In addition to music, it embraces political intrigue and financial scandal. When recounted by the pianist with the same sweeping hyperbole that informs his playing, it seems a panorama too vast to be encompassed within his 55 years.

title: Life-Care Community Planned for the Elderly
description: TO help keep more elderly people on Long Island, the Town of North Hempstead is planning a "life care community" in Port Washington. The center would be the first of its type in Nassau County.

title: YACHT RACING;Adventure Puts Novices In Dangerous Waters
description: Andrew Fernandez, a technician at a photo shop in Newport, R.I., is about to set off on an adventure that he never thought would get past the daydream stage. Along with 12 other amateurs, Fernandez plans to race a 67-foot sailboat around the world.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 28 about the actress Amanda Plummer misstated the nationality of her father, the actor Christopher Plummer. He was born in Toronto and is Canadian, not British.

title: Lo, the Borough Chief
description: To the Editor:

title: Lincoln Idea Could Have Erased a London
description: A NEW view of Lincoln is emerging from information gathered at an archeological dig at the former West Point Foundry on the Hudson River here.

title: Correction
description: A table last Sunday with an article about the new financial planning service of the Vanguard Group misstated the annual advisory fee for another service, the T. Rowe Price Investment Counsel Service. It is 0.25 percent of assets, not 2.5 percent.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: SANDRA NICHOLS FOUND DEAD By George V. Higgins. John Macrae/Holt, $23.

title: WEDDINGS;Cynthia P. Tilley, John W. Cavo 3d
description: Cynthia Parker Tilley, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George P. Tilley of Fayetteville, N.Y., was married yesterday to John William Cavo 3d, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Cavo Jr. of Farmington, Conn. The Rev. But last week I returned from an overseas trip to find that Mr. Dole was proposing to repeal the 4.3-cent-a-gallon gasoline tax, and I've changed my mind about the old guy. Yes, sir, scrapping the gasoline tax. That's the sort of leadership America needs; that's the sort of spirit of sacrifice the country's been missing: a President who's ready to sacrifice the budget, to sacrifice the environment, to sacrifice energy conservation, to sacrifice oil reserves in order to save the American people 4.3 cents a gallon. And when Mr. Dole's sidekick Dick Armey, the House majority leader, suggested that we consider cutting the education budget to make up for the lost gas-tax revenue, well, then and there I knew I was a Dole man. I mean, cutting education to save Americans a few pennies a gallon at a time when their gas is already the cheapest in the world -- that's the kind of thinking that will keep us the world's most competitive nation in the 21st century. I sure hope the Japanese don't get that idea.

title: BOOKEND;No, Really, I Am Anonymous
description: I have a confession to make. No, not that one. Don't be silly. It's this: I am suffering from post-traumatic success disorder. It is an insidious malady. Very disorienting. I feel a little bit like Joanne Woodward in "The Three Faces of Eve," minus a face. Which is not to say that I consider myself two-faced. This is a more subtle bifurcation: there are two of us now. There is "me" and there is "Anonymous." I have come to this realization gradually, grudgingly; for a long time, I simply refused to believe that I had permanently subdivided myself. But the schizzy twinges grew more pronounced as I moved deeper into the work. I began to feel different when I -- or rather, A. -- sat down to write. A. was funnier than I am. A. was more demure. A. was more dignified. A. was more purposeful. Finally, I asked my agent: "Have I changed over the course of this? Am I becoming Anonymous? Am I different now?" She had to think about it for a moment. "Well," she said, "maybe a little." Closer to home, the reaction was less equivocal and more titillating. As publication approached, and the first, surprisingly favorable reviews began to appear, my spouse nuzzled my ear one evening and asked, "Can I, y'know, do it with . . . Anonymous tonight?"

title: Books in Brief: FICTION;Singing a New Tune
description: Rosanne Cash was born with a microphone in her hand. The daughter of Johnny Cash, she released her first album in 1979 and was immediately recognized as one of country music's freshest singer-songwriters. Those familiar with her much-publicized private life (her marriage to the country star Rodney Crowell, which ended in divorce four years ago, was tabloid manna) will spot bits and pieces of it scattered throughout her first collection of stories and sketches, BODIES OF WATER (Hyperion, $19.95), some of which reads more like autobiography than fiction. But there is no angry score-settling in this pensive book, which takes as its subject the landmarks of a woman's life: love, marriage, childbirth, disillusion, renewal. Unusually for a lyricist, Ms. Cash has a straightforward, sharp-eyed prose style ("I was 22 years old, and my feet were a little too big for my body. . . . I had two cats -- a serious mistake -- as I had been looking for an image and thought they might help") and, despite a few awkwardly self-conscious patches, her first book reads like the work of a far more experienced writer. This is not "celebrity" fiction: it is a collection of stories that happens to have been written by a celebrity, and it is very good. Terry Teachout

She had traveled to eastern Ontario for a medical school interview, where I had accompanied her; now she was flying back to the west coast to finish her exams. In between there was a window of opportunity called Ste. Anne's, a country inn and spa in the rolling hills of Northumberland County, an hour and a quarter east of Toronto. Hoping that country air, a full range of spa services, three fine meals and a night in a four-poster bed would reinvigorate us for the fray, we turned off Highway 401 at Grafton and headed north.

title: LIVES;The Age of Beauty
description: I had stood, all eagerness and impatience, while my sister's old evening dress was pinned on me before that fateful dance at the yacht club. I didn't even know enough to look critically at the mirror and see that the strapless gown didn't suit me, especially after the dark brown velvet straps had been added to keep the dress up on my flat chest. I placed no value on looks. Having not had this rite of passage explained to me, I hadn't a clue that beauty was the prerequisite to adolescent stardom. Certainly, this new longing for boys had made me awkward in their presence; but I had noticed that they were awkward, too. Accustomed to being chosen first for any team of girls, I didn't question success that night, couldn't remember failure, so carefully had I buried nursery angers under trophies of recent accomplishments. I'm sure I was prepared to solve any hesitancy the boys might have in approaching us girls by taking the initiative myself. Assuming responsibility was who I was. In recent years my life had been a great adventure, in which there had been no comparisons made to my mother and sister. In my mind, they were boring in their tedious arguing over my sister's looks and her evenings with boys.

Roberts, in a program that includes Beethoven's Ninth Symphony as well as "The American Festival Overture" by Schuman and Strauss's "Don Juan."

title: Around New York The Hard Way
description: I HAVE a small kayak that I've taken out for short trips on the Hudson River, but I'm not a hardy seagoer type. Nonetheless, a couple of winters ago, in the deep funk of February doldrums, I signed up for a 30-mile, 10-hour July kayak trip around Manhattan.

title: Big Government by Popular Demand
description: THE GOOD SOCIETY The Humane Agenda. By John Kenneth Galbraith. 152 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $21.95.

title: Guidebooks
description: To the Editor: After reading Susan Spano's article on travel guidebooks, "The Right Guidebook Earns Its Ticket" (April 28), I decided to go to my bookshelves, pull out all my guidebooks and stack them by series. I, too, had a pretty big stack of Lonely Planets and Henry Holt's Walking Tours Series. Even bigger were my stacks of Access guides (HarperCollins) and Eyewitness travel guides. Although they primarily focus on American and European cities, they both deserve mention.

title: PERSPECTIVES;At Fortress Helmsley-Spear, a Tangled Web
description: A FULL-LENGTH portrait of Leona Helmsley, looking regal, stares down at visitors entering the offices of Helmsley Enterprises at 230 Park Avenue. It seems to say, "Remember who is in charge here."

title: Coping;The Battle Over Gramercy Park
description: Because it blooms like an emerald in the soft palm of the city, privileged, secretive Gramercy Park has a hold even on the imagination of those of us without a key to its locked gates. How else, gentle reader, would I dare set forth a twisty tale about its trees that at first seems so trivial you might be impelled to move on to sterner stuff, the antiques page perhaps, or the pictures of brides?

title: Susan J. Lehnert, Walter P. Smith
description: Susan Jennifer Lehnert, an account supervisor at Ammirati Puris Lintas, the advertising agency in New York, was married yesterday to Walter Patrick Smith, a senior designer and an associate at Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, the architecture firm in New York. The Rev. Mathias Wesnofske, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Joseph in Garden City, L.I.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: BLUE HEAVEN By Elaine Kagan. Knopf, $24.

title: In the Region/Connecticut;The Shore and Litchfield Gain as Summer Rentals
description: IT seems, according to both brokers and seasonal renters, that more and more summer renters from New York City, seeking alternatives to the long drive to the Hamptons, the crowds on Cape Cod and the difficulty of getting to and from Nantucket when the planes are grounded in fog, are winding up on the Connecticut shoreline and in Litchfield County.

title: A Breakthrough in Bonds
description: The Clinton Administration's decision to issue indexed bonds -- Government bonds that protect the purchaser from inflation -- is welcome news for investors, taxpayers and the overall health of the economy. The Administration deserves credit for overcoming obstacles that have blocked this good idea for years.

description: In the following reports, the "listed at" price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Backtalk;Early Entry, Tough Calls: In Defense of the Players
description: In the last several weeks, we have watched scores of college underclassmen and three high school seniors elect to forgo their college eligibility for a chance to play in the National Basketball Association. While they came to the same conclusion -- to play pro basketball -- all the young men apparently struggled with their decisions.

description: Tenant Is No Fan of a Noisy Fan

description: A prototype of a reusable rocket, a possible forerunner of the craft that might replace the space shuttle, burst into flames today after completing its first flight.

description: Rachel Elisa Foster, the daughter of Zelda and Harold Foster of Brooklyn, is to be married today to Alain Kodsi, the son of Georgette and Elie Kodsi, also of Brooklyn. Rabbi Lawrence Raphael is to officiate at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: FOOD;Seaman, First Class
description: THERE IS LESS TO ERIC RIPERT'S COOKING than meets the eye. This amuses the 31-year-old chef, who did not set out at Le Bernardin to reverse the miracle of the loaves and fishes. Still, no matter how complicated his seafood looks, or how intoxicating its aroma, in the end it all comes down to flavors pure and simple.
