title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Everybody Loves a Clown
description: Can you recall the last time you made a really embarrassing mistake at work? Sure you can. Your co-workers had a good laugh at your expense, so why not give the rest of us a chance? We even promise to laugh with you and not at you. Send your story to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Biggest Test Still Awaits India Leaders
description: After a week when political fortunes swung wildly across the ideological spectrum from left to right, India is now awaiting a parliamentary vote that will determine whether the country's new right-wing Government of Hindu nationalists can somehow find the support it will need to survive.

title: Suit Challenges the Financing of Judges' Campaigns in Los Angeles
description: In a lawsuit that might reverberate through all 39 states that hold judicial elections, a coalition of civil rights groups and low-income voters has challenged the way judges' campaigns in Los Angeles County are financed.

title: WEDDINGS;Miss Workman, Mr. Williams
description: Elizabeth Mab Workman, a daughter of Carolan and Peter Workman of New York, was married last evening to Mark Charles Williams, a son of Audine Williams of Falls Church, Va., and the late Dr. Austin T. Williams 2d. Rabbi Albert Sturmer officiated at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. The Rev. Giles Spoonhour, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: A Weatherman Goes Public With Ways to Keep Trim Past 40
description: STORM FIELD, the weatherman for WCBS-TV, is an empathetic guy. When his wife gained 31 pounds with her first pregnancy, he gained a sympathetic 25 pounds. Before long -- like many fortysomethings cresting the baby boom wave -- he found himself huffing and puffing as he chased after his fast-moving toddler.

title: IN THE GARDEN;Compatibility in Design
description: GARDENING is indeed an art. There is the scientific, horticultural part, a knowledge of what to do how and when. But requiring an even sharper skill is the craft of designing.

title: No Headline

title: Robert Mead, 61, News Producer For Networks and Adviser to Ford
description: Robert A. Mead, an award-winning network news producer who also served as an adviser to former President Gerald R. Ford, died on Tuesday at his home in Orange, Va. He was 61.

title: This Caucus Seeks Place At the Table
description: City Councilwoman Priscilla A. Wooten stood at the entrance to the glittering ballroom at the Sheraton New York, greeting banquet guests arriving at what was billed as the first annual legislative weekend of the Black and Hispanic Caucus of the New York City Council.

title: Huckleberry Finn: Keeping a Laden Raft Afloat
description: The enduring power of "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn" and the enduring racism that it explores were evident when a half dozen writers took a fresh look at the novel on Friday night.

title: Wandering Asia
description: To the Editor: What a sense of "been there, done that" my husband and I had on reading "Asia Without Reservations," by Christine Barnes (April 21). We not only traveled, as she and her family did for a month, "like 20-somethings," without reservations at hotels, using every conceivable mode of transportation, but we even stayed at the same enchanting place in Ubud, Bali, the Ananda Cottages, and used the same Lonely Planet guidebooks. Except that we were were 60-somethings at the time (eight years ago) and did it for five months on a trip around the world.

title: SIGNOFF;Between Movies, Time-Slot Jokes
description: DO not adjust your sets -- we're really on this late," Greg Kinnear advised viewers during a recent broadcast of "Later," the 1:37 A.M. interview program Monday through Thursday nights on NBC. Mr. Kinnear, the host, now a cagey two-year veteran of overnights, knows that if there are any constants in his world, one is "Later," and the other is making jokes about "Later" 's place on the television schedule.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on April 28 with an article about door-to-door salesmen was misidentified. It showed the actor Gene Lockhart, not Lee J. Cobb, in "Death of a Salesman."

title: TRACK AND FIELD;Johnson and Torrence Blistering in Atlanta
description: The Olympic Stadium may be bland in design, but there is nothing innocuous about the temporary track inside. Two months before the Summer Games, the 83,100-seat stadium opened today with sprint times as blistering as the heat.

title: Children's Books;A Job for Elliott Baa, Private Eye
description: Sheep in Wolves' Clothing Written and illustrated by Satoshi Kitamura. Unpaged. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $15. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: SPOTLIGHT;Land's End
description: Was there ever another house like the one in THE GHOST AND MRS. MUIR (1947)? It perches high, white and cozy on a Cornish cliff. Therein dwells a wistful, lonely widow (Gene Tierney) oddly comforted by the reappearance of a crusty departed skipper (Rex Harrison). Runner-up show-stealer is Edna Best as a selfless servant. (Spot her late nights as the mother in Hitchcock's "Man Who Knew Too Much," 1934.) There's a third magnet: Bernard Herrmann's haunting score, coiling like mist through the R.A. Dick story. Philip Dunne's script, Joseph L. Mankiewicz's direction and his cast have shaped a tender romance with pulse and flavor. Feel that sea spray? That's the music - THUR. at 10 P.M. and THURS.-FRI. at 3:30 A.M. on AMC.

title: Military Strives to Reduce a Relatively Low Suicide Rate
description: Adm. Jeremy M. Boorda, the Navy's highest-ranking officer, took his life this week at a time when the military is striving, with considerable success, to reduce suicide in the ranks.

title: DINING OUT;At a Purple Landmark in Ossissing
description: DESPITE the kitchen's occasional lapses over the 17 years that we have known it, we have always had a soft spot for this eccentrically painted purple landmark with its subdued, romantic lighting by night and cheery brightness by day. The tables are still grouped comfortably under the skylights; on Thursday, Friday and Saturday evenings live music accompanies conversation, and the food is still just enough out of the ordinary in both style and preparation to make an evening feel like an occasion.

title: Sports of The Times;Belle Needs More Help Before It Is Too Late
description: HE was old, he was small, he didn't know the territory. He was a natural victim. This happened in the Cleveland Indians' locker room during the baseball playoffs last fall.

description: GARDENING is indeed an art. There is the scientific, horticultural part, a knowledge of what to do how and when. But requiring an even sharper skill is the craft of designing.

description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction

title: Buicks in Rome: That's Amore
description: FEW who mourn the passing of General Motors' big rear-drive automobiles do so more passionately than Nicola Bulgari, the international jeweler known for his hefty creations in gold and colored stones, who is particularly distressed by the prospect of roads without Roadmasters.

title: Dolphin Advocates Persuaded 'Flipper' To Change Course
description: IN "FLIPPER," A BOY AND a wild dolphin become friends, save each other's lives, then part when the boy sends the dolphin back to the sea. The boy and his uncle are played by Elijah Wood and Paul Hogan. The dolphin is played by a robot and three captive bottlenose dolphins.

title: WEDDINGS;Lizzie Wood And L.D. Hull

Hull of Centralia, Wash., were married yesterday in New York. The Rev. Hentzi Elek, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Calvary Church.

title: Spiders in Chicago
description: To the Editor: The Field Museum in Chicago is the fourth largest natural history museum in the world, widely recognized for innovative exhibits. In "What's Doing in Chicago" (April 7), it would have been helpful to visitors to learn of "Spiders!" a special exhibit opening May 25. Exhibits highlighting cultural diversity -- on Egypt, Africa, the Maya, the Aztec Empire and others -- are big attractions.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: SPOTLIGHT;Capitol Gang
description: Icy silence followed the premiere MR. SMITH GOES TO WASHINGTON (1939) for an invitational theater crowd of legislators and press corps. No wonder. The film's new, naive young senator (James Stewart) gets gleefully roasted by vulture journalists, and the Senate itself brims with cynics and crooks. However, this was a comedy - an elaborate Frank Capra special - and the rest fo the country savored it. New York critics voted Stewart their man of the year. Starring with Jean Arthur, he made a superbly credible idealist in a nest of vipers. As for Stewart's valiant, agonizing filibuster at the climax, hooray for the Veep (Harry Carey) and his encouraging smile! That's Capra's touch - TUESDAY at NOON on MAX.

title: What Kind of Democrat Is Clinton?
description: He is talented, articulate, intelligent, open and colorful; also undisciplined, obtuse, defensive and self-justifying. Magazine, section 8.

title: The View From: Ridgefield;Contemporary Art Demystified
description: IT is 10 A.M. at the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield and 30 high school seniors clad in jeans and untied sneakers wait patiently for student docents to lead them up the stairs and into the galleries. The talk that sweeps through the lobby is not of MTV or college entrance exams but of which is more virtuous: classical or modern art.

title: Privacy Legislation in Congress Could Wind Up Hindering Research onDrug Use
description: Research into illegal drug use by American adolescents could be stifled by legislation pending in Congress that requires written parental consent before minors are interviewed about their personal habits, social scientists and some anti-drug advocates say.

title: For Orator, Search For Podium He Lost
description: Mario M. Cuomo had finished talking politics in Las Vegas at a convention of shopping center developers who were there for four days of deal-making and gambling, and was walking along the cement floor of a hotel service corridor when he paused to offer a judgment on his morning.

title: VOICES: FROM THE DESK OF;When Pennies Were Gold
description: I'M not in the habit of going around telling people how good things used to be when I was a boy, some 45 to 50 years ago. Things are certainly different now, but not especially better or worse. Yet I have to say it isn't as easy as it used to be for youngsters to be budding entrepreneurs.

title: ART;Old and New From Woodstock Colony
description: KRASDALE FOODS is blessed with two galleries, one at its Bronx headquarters, in Hunts Point, the other in its office building on the outskirts of White Plains. As organized by Sigmund R. Balka, the company's general counsel, the two establishments normally maintain separate schedules. But now they have joined to present a single show, "The 20th Century Artists of the Woodstock Art Colony."

title: ON HOCKEY;A Little Slice of Quebec Is Flying High, a Mile High
description: Officially, there are no Canadian teams in the final four of the Stanley Cup playoffs. But this is just a technicality. Consider the Colorado Avalanche, which will play the Red Wings at Joe Louis Arena this afternoon in the Western Conference opener.

title: B. Meredith-Jones, Dance Therapist, 87
description: Betty Meredith-Jones, a dance educator and a pioneer in the field of movement rehabilitation and community dance in Britain, died last Sunday at her home in Rhosili, Wales. She was 87.

description: For two and a half years Jan R. Martin spent his weekends and vacations building a dream, an abstract outdoor sculpture here in his hometown.

description: Under attack by Senator Bob Dole for having twice vetoed welfare legislation, President Clinton today gave his blessing to the most radical of all state welfare experiments, which would abolish the Federal guarantee of cash assistance for poor children in Wisconsin and replace it with wage subsidies for single mothers who work.

title: ROAD AND RAIL;State Is Trying to Make It Easier to Fix Bridges That Have a History
description: Rich Grocholski has waited a long time to replace the Burnt Hill Road Bridge in Montgomery Township. In 1989, Mr. Grocholski, Somerset County's bridge engineer, was ready to build a new bridge and move the old one to a nearby park. Then, he learned that the bridge probably had historic significance and he could do nothing without state approval.

title: COMMENCEMENTS;Gubernatorial Memories And Thoughts of the Future
description: The commencement at Drew University in Madison, N.J., yesterday was a bipartisan affair, with the school's president, Thomas H. Kean, graciously welcoming the First Lady, Hillary Rodham Clinton, who returned the warmth.

title: The Keys to the Spy Kingdom
description: The management of America's intelligence agencies has long suffered from an awkward power-sharing arrangement between the Director of Central Intelligence and the Secretary of Defense. The director is nominally in charge, but the Secretary of Defense actually controls most of the agencies, people and money. Over the years the two have sometimes tripped over each other, resulting in lax management and a shortage of accountability.

title: OUT THERE: WASHINGTON;Doing the Ambassador Stomp, Solo
description: BALLS!" exclaimed Jaime de Ojeda, Spain's Ambassador to the United States, as he threw open the doors to the vast, unlighted ballroom of his residence. "No one wants to go to balls anymore. They're out of fashion."

description: THERE was not a ripple in the swimming pool nor a rustle in the tall Manila palms. No strollers on the beach and only discreet attendants, in their silk sarongs, disappearing through the doorways of the lobby. Was I the only guest?

description: TODAY is the 19th day of Older Americans Month and many are enjoying longer, healthier lives than ever before. But there is another scenario, one that is sadly repeated nationwide on any given day. The telephone rings with the news that an aging parent has fallen, or had a stroke, or taken ill some other way and suddenly nothing is the same. A formerly healthy person needs medical care, and later a change in living situation, someone to be there to administer the tasks of daily living.

title: May 12-18;Voyage of the Forsaken

title: Crime

Fine, $24.95) warns the jurors that "this case is likely to be more complicated than the others you've had." Well, he isn't just blowing smoke. After a low-key opening in which the legal technicalities of the dope-dealing charges against an elderly Chinese-American couple are presented, Philip Friedman's new courtroom thriller (after "Reasonable Doubt" and "Inadmissible Evidence") vaults the genre conventions and turns into a complex and excruciatingly intense examination of the criminal justice system as it applies to insular emigre cultures.

If its rich colors are to be relished, it is best heard as a solo instrument, in a hall that is not too big, or with a few other instruments of its kind.

title: Connecticut Q&A: Alida Engel;Help When the Gift of Language Is Lost
description: GREETING a friend, making oneself understood, laughing at a joke, reading a book, writing a coherent sentence -- all have one thing in common: language. And when something goes wrong with our ability to communicate, it can be devastating.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER EAST SIDE;TOO POLITICALLY CORRECT?
description: Much of the work of Currier & Ives was Americanalike snow and horse-drawn carriages. But the 19th-century New York lithographers also turned out what now are stereotypes about blacks and Native Americans. A few are in the Museum of the City of New York's new exhibition "Currier & Ives: Printmakers to the American People." Lest modern viewers take offense, the museum included the above commentary written by Bonnie Yochelson, the guest curator, who has taken some kidding about so-called political correctness. "I probably shouldn't have been so heavy-handed," admitted Ms. Yochelson, who said she had been influenced by a 1991 Smithsonian Institution show, which was itself criticized as politically correct. "The underlying facts are correct," she said of the commentary, "but it is a little P.C."

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: MAKING IT WORK 3 FAIR or not? A look at Steven Rendall, a local media watchdog who is becoming the sound bite of choice.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: JACKSON HEIGHTS;Tempest in a P.T.A.: No Apathy in This School Vote
description: Hundreds of parents and teachers came to Public School 149 last week desperate, after weeks of turmoil, to know: Who would lead the people?

title: GOLF;Stockton Stays Close By Tying Club Mark
description: For 26 years, the course record at the Upper Montclair Country Club was 64. On Friday, in the first round of the Senior Professional Golfers' Association Tour's $950,000 Cadillac NFL Golf Classic, Bob Murphy lowered it to 62. Today, Dave Stockton matched that 62.

title: Rid New York City's Schools of Corruption, but Do It Carefully
description: To the Editor:

title: A Progress Report On Low-Cost Housing
description: THE effort to provide affordable housing for residents who are often priced out of the communities in which they were raised or work has been a matter of voluntary compliance for municipalities, whose responsiveness to the issue has ranged from enthusiasm to indifference.

title: WEDDINGS;Dahlia T. Wachs, Keith A. Harmon
description: Dahlia Tamar Wachs, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Wachs of New York, is to be married this evening to Dr. Keith A. Harmon, a son of Bernard Harmon of Roslyn, L.I., and the late Judith Harmon. Rabbi Joseph Sternstein is to officiate at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Guns Fit for a Queen Arrive on 57th Street

title: N.B.A. PLAYOFFS;Five-Year Plan Leaves Knicks Short of Title, but Ahead of 1991
description: There were plenty of empty seats on April 30, 1991, the night Michael Jordan's Bulls swept the Knicks from the first round of the playoffs in three games. Pat Riley had yet to coach his first game and Patrick Ewing could easily have been playing his last game in orange and blue.

title: Who'll Win Russia?;For America, Uncertainty Wraps the Riddle
description: IN divining the Clinton Administration's thinking about the presidential election in Russia next month, consider this: Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott's first draft of a major analysis of Russia policy last January omitted any discussion of what to expect if the Communists won. Only after colleagues drew the omission to Mr. Talbott's attention did he insert a "what if" section in the final version.

title: SOAPBOX;Where Creativity Is Cooking
description: LUNCH on Wednesdays has an unusual ending at the Holy Apostles Soup Kitchen, Manhattan's largest: a writers workshop. The stories are rooted in the gritty realities of the writers' lives. Some are homeless, some are ill, some battle alcohol or drugs. For 12 weeks this spring, a dozen regulars tackled assigned topics and read the results aloud. The workshop was begun last year by Ian Frazier and Bob Blaisdell, who this year enlisted Alec Wilkinson and Susan Shapiro. The windup will be a public reading at the church, at Ninth Avenue and 28th Street, at 8 P.M. on May 29. Here is a sample of the fare:

title: THEATER;Lost Souls of Victims And of Perpetrators
description: JOHN GUARE was already an honored playwright by the time "Landscape of the Body" opened at the Public Theater in Manhattan in 1977, after a world premiere in Chicago two months earlier.

title: May 12-18;The New Slogan: Buy Inflation-Buster Bonds!
description: In announcing that it would issue a new type of Government bond -- an "inflation-indexed" bond -- the United States Treasury last week moved to accomplish a lot of goals: protect the savings of ordinary Americans from inflation, encourage Americans to save more and cut the Government's borrowing costs.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN;Charleston
description: Charleston's grace is its breeze, an ocean offering that elevates spring from a season into a performance. Spring is the highlight of the year, with flamboyant red azaleas, fragrant white magnolias and Spanish moss swaying softly to and fro. When it's over, Charlestonians disappear into air-conditioned retreats. Indeed, that's one reason the Spoleto arts festival is so embraced, for it serves as the city's grand farewell before the long, sullen days of summer.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC;Two Princely Tenors Lay Claim to the Throne
description: THERE IS PANIC IN THE palace. The Three Tenors are old, and everyone is worried over the succession. To calm the populace, some royal youth who looks the part must be pulled from his lessons and games and declared Prince Regent. If he prove a ruler, we'll drink to his health. If not, his fuzzy-cheeked head will roll.

title: Out of the Cradle and Right Into the N.B.A. Draft
description: Spencer Haywood has seen some of the faces on television, young faces of nervous college players as they carefully read or recited that awkward phrase, declaring their intention to apply for the National Basketball Association draft. A quarter-century ago, after an extended and highly publicized legal struggle that took place long before Kobe Bryant was born, Haywood won the right to play in the N.B.A. before his college class graduated. Now, as Bryant and two other high school players, as well as three college freshmen and nine sophomores, wait for the moment their names may or may not be called on draft day, Haywood is one of many voices questioning a system his legal victory helped create.

title: JERSEY;Commencement Ain't Over Till It's Started
description: CRUISING in his cream Jaguar on Route 3 toward the Lincoln Tunnel, Yogi Berra was a worried man.

title: Women's Lives, Women's Roles
description: AMANDA WALLNER first got the idea for a yearlong celebration of the achievements of women after flipping through information she had lying around her office in the music room at Elisabeth Adams Middle School in Guilford.

title: TELEVISION;The Brief, Brilliant Run Of Nichols and May
description: IF IT HADN'T ACTUALLY HAPPENED, Mike Nichols and Elaine May would have had to have made it up. One evening in the early 1960's, moments after the comedy team finished performing at a Florida nightclub, Mr. Nichols was approached by none other than Zsa Zsa Gabor.

title: Sunday May 19, 1996: LEADER OF THE FLOCK;Buy, Buy Birdie!
description: The Original Flamingo Surprise rents pink flamingos. Not real ones. Plastic ones. People don't get them for themselves; they want their neighbors, or a relative, to wake up and find a flock of the things on the lawn with a sign saying "Happy Birthday From the Kids" or "Here's 50 for Your 50th." It's a stealth business. They come in the night and stick the flamingos all over -- however many you want -- and the following night they remove them. These flamingo commandos, located near O'Hare Airport in Bensenville, Ill., will even spread their wings to make raids on Cleveland, Columbus and Atlanta.

title: To Perot Group's Credit
description: To the Editor:

title: ON THE MAP;In Montvale, an Iris Garden Brings a Rainbow Down to Earth
description: Back in 1924, when Charles Gray moved to Montvale, his neighbors in the Bergen County borough were farmers named Foxlee, Van Riper and De Piero. Mr. Gray decided to plant roots himself, but instead of corn and tomatoes, he came to town with irises in his pocket.

title: May 12-18;An AIDS Test for the Home
description: Do-it-yourself medical tests -- for pregnancy, blood pressure, serum sugar levels and other conditions -- are an increasingly popular option for millions of Americans. Last week the Food and Drug Administration moved home testing into new territory, approving the first home test for the AIDS virus. It said the Johnson & Johnson subsidiary Direct Access Diagnostics could sell its Confide kit at clinics and pharmacies and other stores. The company said that after a trial run beginning next month in Texas and Florida it would market the kit nationwide early next year. People using it are to anonymously mail blood samples to a laboratory and use a special code to get the results by phone a week later. Federal health experts estimate that up to a million Americans are infected with the virus, HIV-1, but studies suggest that fewer than 20 percent have been tested. They hope that eliminating the pressure of going to a doctor or clinic will encourage more people to be tested and, if found positive, seek early treatment. WARREN E. LEARY

title: WEDDINGS;Mary C. Belknap, Michael G. McKee
description: Mary Carter Belknap, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Belknap 3d of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Michael George McKee, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David McKee of Toronto. The Rev. Nils Blatz performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church in Brooklyn.

title: WEDDINGS;Ariane de Braux, Thomas W. Lacy
description: Ariane de Braux, the daughter of Leslie Kitchell Bullock of Greenwich, Conn., and Peter de Braux of Singapore, was married yesterday to Thomas William Lacy, a son of Mary Elizabeth Lacy and William H. Lacy of Milwaukee. The Rev. William F. Pauly, an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: Chet Forte, 60, an Innovator in Television Sports
description: Chet Forte, the 5-foot-7-inch Columbia basketball player who won a national scoring title but earned more fame as the director of "Monday Night Football" before a gambling addiction ended his television career, died in San Diego yesterday of a heart attack. He was 60.

title: Once Upon a Time in Albany
description: THE FLAMING CORSAGE By William Kennedy. 209 pp. New York: Viking. $23.95. Katrina Daugherty, born Taylor, of Albany, wife of Edward and mother of Martin, lover for a few weeks in 1898 of the teen-age Francis Phelan. Katrina Daugherty, dying on the sidewalk in 1912, rescued from her burning house only to perish of smoke inhalation in the arms of her playwright husband, who has scandalously memorialized the decline of their marriage in a play called "The Flaming Corsage."

title: Celebrities At Ringside: Better to See And Be Seen
description: RINGSIDE among the rows of fold-out chairs that the boxing historian Bert Sugar likes to call the "$250 seats that weren't even touched by Jackie Onassis," the arena is awash in the roar.

title: SPORTS EXTREMIST
description: HERE ARE BICYCLES, AND THEN THERE IS MISSY Giove's riding machine. Candy-apple red and fireman-poncho yellow, it has tires twice the width of a standard bike's. The front wheel is flanked by two silver bars -- shock absorbers -- the size of baseball bats; under the seat is a canister that looks like a soda bottle but that is, in fact, another shock absorber. It's a perfect bicycle for a spin through the park -- provided, of course, that the park is strewn with boulders and has slopes that drop thousands of feet.

title: INVESTING IT;For Callaway Golf, Even More Balls in the Air
description: THE golf war has begun in earnest.

description: No Commercial Traffic" signs are clearly visible on practically every other corner along West End Avenue, but despite their prominence, residents complain that the ban is among the city's most ignored, unenforced traffic laws.

title: MUSICE;Ravel by Four Hands and Four Feet
description: THE Music Series of South Church in New Britain has announced a "complete four-hand, four-feet performance" of Ravel's "Tombeau de Couperin." James Biery, director of music at the Cathedral of St. Joseph in Hartford, transcribed the piano suite for organ duet for performance by Marilyn Biery, his wife and principal conductor of the Cathedral's archdiocesan choir, and himself. Today's 2 P.M. concert will include an offering. At 12:30 a pre-concert brunch is available for $5.

description: Soldiers took control of the center of this capital city today and surrounded the presidential palace in the second mutiny in the Central African Republic in as many months.

description: MURDER takes center stage in three fine films on television this week, and a fourth puts the spotlight on a legendary Hollywood partnership.

description: PROBABLY THE MOST familiar definition of poetry is one offered nearly 200 years ago in the preface to the second edition of William Wordsworth's "Lyrical Ballads." Poetry, he wrote, is "the spontaneous overflow of powerful feelings: it takes its origin from emotion recollected in tranquillity."

description: Mixing politics and financial speculation, Russia's fledgling futures market is wheeling and dealing over next month's presidential election.

description: Beijing issued a stern warning to the United States today to come to the trade negotiating table, saying a looming trade war over copyright piracy threatened the American position in China's huge markets.

description: Spiros Argiris, the principal conductor and director of operatic and symphonic activities at the Spoleto Festival U.S.A., in Charleston, S.C., for most of the last decade, died yesterday at the Hopital Cimiez in Nice, France. He was 47 years old and lived in Monte Carlo.

title: 5 Years Later, Navy Is Still Reeling From Tarnish of Tailhook Incident
description: As the body of Adm. Jeremy M. Boorda was laid to rest today at Arlington National Cemetery, there was a sense among his friends and adversaries alike that when the Navy's highest-ranking officer took his life, he became another victim of a scandal that was born in the alcohol-soaked hallway of a convention hotel in Las Vegas, the scene five years ago of crimes that still traumatize the Navy.

title: Media: PUBLISHING;A new academic question: Who are the looniest artists of all?
description: SINCE Aristotle observed that "no excellent soul is exempt from a mixture of madness," speculation about the link between art and insanity has been a lingering topic, probed and studied by academics whose laboratory rats are literary biographies.

title: SOCCER;Sluggish MetroStars Can't Get It Together
description: An own goal on top of an awful performance by the MetroStars made today's 2-0 loss to the New England Revolution all the more painful.

title: DANCE REVIEW;A Final 'Apollo' Is Also a First
description: The New York City Ballet presented its final "Apollo" of the season on Saturday afternoon at the New York State Theater. This last performance was also a first, for Igor Zelensky made his company debut in the title role, a part he danced when he was in the Kirov Ballet of St. Petersburg, Russia.

description: A former F.B.I. agent who pleaded guilty to taking kickbacks from a pepper-spray manufacturer was sentenced on Friday to two months in Federal prison.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Boy's Body Found in River
description: The body of a 10-year-old boy who slipped off a rock into the whitewater of the Rockaway River on Saturday was found early yesterday, the police said. The boy, Rick Metzgar, had been walking along the river with two friends, ages 8 and 10, and had apparently tried to clean the mud off his shoes when the accident occurred, said Sgt. Curtis A. James, a spokesman for the Boonton Police Department.

title: Phony Polls That Sling Mud Raise Questions Over Ethics
description: In the 1940's, "midnight fliers" would appear on doorsteps on Election Eve, anonymously accusing candidates of such sins as having Communist friends, dating Negroes, or conspiring with the Pope.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Bill to Make Divorce Easier
description: In other action today, the Assembly Judiciary Committee is expected to take up legislation that would make major changes in the state's divorce laws for the first time in 25 years. One bill would allow New Jerseyans to cite "irreconcilable differences" as a legal ground for divorce instead of requiring more specific causes.

title: GOLF;Challenging Conditions Just Perfect for Pavin
description: Once again, Corey Pavin has come to a place called Hogan's Alley and he has staked his own claim to it. Just as he did last year at the Riviera Country Club, when he won the second of two straight Nissan Opens at the course Ben Hogan dominated, Pavin has taken the measure of one of Ben's old haunts -- this time the Colonial Country Club -- and shown that he fits right in.

title: Bridge
description: There is no doubt that the funniest series of books about the game is English, but beyond that there is room for argument. Some would select the tales written by Victor Mollo about the Hideous Hog, the Rueful Rabbit and other denizens of the Griffins Club. Others prefer the stories by David Bird and the late Terence Reese about the monks of St. Titus. The fifth, and perhaps last, in the monks series, "Divine Intervention," is now available from the Bridge World, 39 West 94th Street, for $16.95 including mailing.

description: To the Editor:

description: Though sales of home computers are beginning to slow, that does not seem to affect the low-priced color printers that connect with them.

title: Technology: DIGITAL COMMERCE;Interactive media must tell a compelling story to draw people in.
description: IF the grunts, thuds and heavy-metal music blaring from hundreds of booths at last week's Electronic Entertainment Expo in Los Angeles are any indication, today's popular shoot-em-up video games continue successfully exploiting certain testosterone-driven adolescent urges.

title: HORSE RACING;Look Out: Unbridled's Song Back In Picture
description: Fit and apparently fresh from his wire-to-wire victory in the Preakness, the colt Louis Quatorze returned to his home stable in New York today to prepare for the Belmont Stakes in three weeks. But even as he was riding in the horse van up the New Jersey Turnpike, the menacing figure of Unbridled's Song was casting a long shadow over the final race in the Triple Crown series.

title: BASEBALL;Saturday's Bats Vanish And Giants Sweep Mets
description: Consistency has been elusive for the Mets through the first quarter of this season. Just when they start to taste success, they quickly revert back to a team that lacks the fortitude and talent to be taken seriously.

title: Lawyer Says Defending A Bosnia Serb Is No Easy Job
description: There may be few jobs less appealing than defending one of Bosnia's suspected war criminals. Yet representing Dusan Tadic, the first man to be tried by a new international tribunal here, is a distinguished Dutch law professor who could be doing far more lucrative work.

description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC REVIEW;The Juilliard's Half-Century Ripening
description: The name is 50 years old, and the name celebrated its anniversary at the Metropolitan Musuem of Art on Friday night. The Juilliard String Quartet played the last of five all-Beethoven concerts. The hall was filled with admirers, many of them young. An overflow nearly circled the performers onstage.

title: Shamed School Looking for a Cheater, Hoping for a Statistical Glitch
description: Since school officials here disclosed that achievement tests at a nationally praised elementary school had been tampered with, former F.B.I. agents have been hired to find the culprit, parents have accused the superintendent of changing the answers herself and the school's pupils have been taunted by children from other areas.

title: GOLF;Murphy Survives Heat As Sigel Comes Up Dry
description: Playing golf in 94-degree heat and walking rather than riding a cart with the sun glaring down can be dehydrating, especially to someone in his 50's. And if you don't drink enough fluids, your legs wobble and the shots don't always go where they should.

title: Taxi Driver Is Found Dead
description: A taxi driver was found dead, with a single shot to the head, inside his yellow cab on a street on Staten Island early yesterday, the police said.

title: Car Space On the Ferry Is a Hot Item For Summer
description: The hardest ticket to come by on Martha's Vineyard last summer was for the James Taylor-Carly Simon reunion concert. This summer's sold-out reservation is for a car on the ferry to or from the island on the Memorial Day and Fourth of July weekends, and other peak days.

title: Question at Olestra's Debut: Is the 'Fake Fat' Truly Safe?
description: For the fourth time in the last month, Kathy Mazzocca, who works as a restaurant hostess here, was buying three large bags of Max potato chips at Randall's, one of the city's better supermarkets. She loves the new chips, she said, because they have no fat, relatively few calories and taste like the real thing.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Oil Spill Closes Beach
description: Only days before the start of a holiday weekend, the beach at Ventnor City was closed to the public yesterday morning after tar balls from a May 10 oil tanker spill in Delaware Bay washed up on shore, officials said. Crews used rakes and shovels to clean up the debris. Lesser amounts of oil and tar balls also turned up on beaches in Atlantic City, Margate City, Longport, Ocean City, Avalon and Stone Harbor, but beachgoers were not asked to leave. New crews were being brought in to work through the night, the United States Coast Guard said. The cost was being absorbed by France Shipmanagement, which operates the tanker, said Jesse Lewis, a company spokesman.

title: Hundreds Line Up to Apply for Casino Jobs
description: Hundreds of job seekers are taking a gamble on the Mohegan Sun Resort -- scheduled to be the state's second Indian casino.

title: THEATER REVIEW;A Drama Critic Reviews His Own Life
description: Forget those rumors that Steve Tesich's new comedy, "Arts and Leisure," which opened last night at Playwrights Horizons, is his revenge on a drama critic who wrote unflatteringly about his work. There are no juicy feuds evident here. No scores are being settled.

title: Infectious Diseases Resistant, Study Finds
description: Infectious diseases, already the world's leading cause of premature death, are increasingly resistant to antibiotic drugs, the World Health Organization warns in its annual report.

title: KENNEDY AIRPORT IN BIG REVAMPING AFTER LONG DELAY
description: In the confident 1950's, New Yorkers would travel to the airport, not to fly but to dine in a glass-enclosed restaurant as airliners lifted into the twilight. The image is almost fantastic now, as harried travelers flee Kennedy International Airport's sagging terminals to fight their way home through the endless traffic on the Van Wyck Expressway.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Air Crash Survivor Returns
description: The day before, he had boarded an airplane for the first time since his American Airlines jet crashed last December en route to Cali, Colombia. Yesterday, Gonzalo Dussan said his biggest priority now that he was back home in Somerville was to visit the graves of his wife, Nancy, and son, Gonzalo Jr., who died in the crash. Mr. Dussan, along with his 6-year-old daughter Michelle, visited his wife's relatives and a brother in Trenton. Beyond that, he said, he has no set plans.

title: Stocks Rise in Japan
description: Stocks were trading higher here today, amid expectations that the dollar's rise against the Japanese yen would help profits at Japanese exporting companies. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 357.11 points, or 1.63 percent, at 22,273.71. On Friday, the Nikkei fell 230.61 points, or 1.04 percent.

title: When the Way Out of the City Is the Fairway;For Newark Teen-Agers, The Golf Team Is a Ticket To a Confusing New World
description: Soon after he joined the golf team at West Side High School, Fuquan K. Brown hefted a bag of clubs over his shoulder, clambered onto a city bus and instantly found himself in an argument with his fellow black passengers.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Three Cinderellas Win Their Princes
description: Cinderella," with which American Ballet Theater has just triumphed in a splendid version by Ben Stevenson, finally makes the company's case for the modern story ballet on an opera-house scale.

title: Advocate Says Poor Are Targets in Closings
description: Saying branch closings by Citibank have disproportionally hit poor and lower-middle-income neighborhoods, the New York City Public Advocate, Mark J. Green, yesterday accused the banking corporation of "financial segregation" and urged the Federal Government to re-evaluate Citibank's performance in struggling communities.

description: GOD HAS NINETY-NINE NAMES Reporting From a Militant Middle East By Judith Miller 574 pages. Simon & Schuster. $30.

description: Aleksandr Y. Basin took a break from the bustle at the commodities exchange the other day to boast how he had profited from President Boris N. Yeltsin's re-election campaign.

title: Girls May Be Focus Of Freemen Talks
description: The two sides in the Freemen standoff met for a fourth consecutive day today, with the negotiations appearing to focus on two of the three children who have been holed up on a remote Montana ranch with nearly 20 other people for more than eight weeks.

title: Republicans Critical of Clinton Welfare Move
description: Republican Congressional leaders today sharpened their criticism of the Clinton Administration's welfare policies, telling the President that his speech endorsing Wisconsin's radical welfare experiment was at odds with his own welfare proposals.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Easier Evictions of Criminals
description: In an effort to rid public housing projects of drugs and weapons, the Federal Government adopted "one strike and you're out" guidelines in March that encourage housing authorities to evict any tenant who commits a crime. But in New Jersey and other states, tenant protection laws make it difficult to evict dealers unless they sell drugs on project property. A bill in the State Senate would make eviction much easier; too easy, say tenant advocates who claim eviction punishes whole families for the action of a relative who deals drugs. Today the bill's sponsors, Senators Wayne R. Bryant, Democrat of Camden, and William L. Gormley, Republican of Margate, will tour the Shore Park housing project in Atlantic City and talk to tenants about their measure.

title: In South Africa, Bringing Theaters to the Townships
description: Hollywood's future in Africa may rest on the shoulders of people like Jerry Phadima.

title: Dole Pledges to 'Bring Fidel Castro Down'
description: Speaking at a Cuban-American festival here, Senator Bob Dole promised today that if he defeated President Clinton in November he would end Fidel Castro's regime in Cuba.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about possible changes in the way small stocks are listed on the Nasdaq market misstated the founding date of that market. It was 1971, not 1974.

title: No Headline

description: THE old jape about people so shallow that all they read are postcards might need updating as a result of a new twist in postcard advertising: a postcard-sized magazine.

title: Cuban Voices of Freedom
description: Encouraging a freer flow of information in Fidel Castro's Cuba has never been easy, but recent developments in Havana and Washington will make it even harder. In Havana earlier this month, the hammer fell on Rafael Solano, a journalist whose realistic dispatches were said to be attempts at subversion. Given a choice between jail and exile, and having already served six weeks in a Cuban prison, he chose exile in Spain, which meant leaving a vulnerable family behind.

title: Police Officers Hurt In Staten Island Clash
description: What started as a routine response by the police to a report of a stabbing near a Staten Island housing project quickly escalated into a melee in which 8 people were arrested and 5 people were injured, including 4 police officers. As many as 100 people then marched on the 120th Precinct station house. The group of protesters, who were orderly and quiet, continued on to the office of the Borough President, Guy V. Molinari.

title: Tupperware Spinoff Is Set for May 31
description: Premark International Inc. said last week that the spinoff of its Tupperware business would be completed on May 31 with the issuance of common stock to holders of record on May 24.

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;Red Wing Star Helps Avalanche Victory
description: Colorado's Mike Keane scored the overtime goal to beat the Red Wings by 3-2 today, but that's not what everyone wanted to talk about after Game 1 of the Western Conference finals in Joe Louis Arena.

title: Supremacist Told to Pay Black Family
description: A Federal jury in North Carolina concluded last week that a white supremacist group had sold off land to avoid having to turn it over to a black family that won a court case against the group.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Drunken 'Driver' Wins One
description: New Jersey's drunken driving laws are so strict they even apply to a driver sitting behind the wheel of a parked car. But they can apparently be beaten, as a Haddon Heights man learned.

title: Political Memo;How Things Can Change: Pataki's Move To the Middle
description: For much of last year, his first as Governor, George E. Pataki played the part one might expect from a candidate born of the New York Republican Party's resurgent conservative wing and the first Governor elected on the state Conservative Party line.

title: U.S. Set to Link 2 Retailers To Sweatshop-Made Goods
description: Continuing to press retailers to police their apparel suppliers, the Labor Department plans to announce today that two prominent department store chains, the J. C. Penney Company and Talbots Inc., had bought goods from three factories made under sweatshop conditions.

title: Ecuador Vote Narrows Race To Privatizer And Populist
description: In the first round of presidential elections Ecuadoreans voted today for two men with sharply different visions for Ecuador, a country that has become a reluctant convert to free-market reforms. They are Jaime Nebot, a Social Christian who would forge ahead with plans to privatize key sectors of the economy, and Abdala Bucaram, a populist who would retain some of the state's biggest holdings and who opposes reform of the bloated social security system.

title: Music in Review
description: JAZZ Swinging Through History And the Southwest Jay McShann Village Vanguard

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: F.A.A. Files Show a Trail Of Valujet Safety Lapses Federal Aviation Administration inspectors found many safety violations at Valujet Airlines in the 18 months before the May 11 crash outside Miami of one of its flights, according to internal F.A.A. documents. The documents, in addition to records at other Federal agencies, portray a rapidly growing airline that was repeatedly found to have shortcomings in safety matters in such areas as record keeping, maintenance, training and cockpit discipline.

title: For Some, Steady Job Isn't the End Of the Road
description: As a Web-page developer, Jayson Elliot could have his pick of permanent jobs in the San Francisco Bay area. But that's the last thing on his mind.

title: Bronx Youth Is Fatally Shot in Fight After a Party
description: A 14-year-old boy was fatally shot early yesterday outside an apartment building in the South Bronx, the police said.

title: The Grateful Living
description: To the Editor:

title: Congress Shows Its Contempt
description: For the first time, the House of Representatives is set to vote on criminal contempt charges against a senior White House official who refused to hand over papers demanded by a Congressional subpoena.

title: Essay;'Wrapping Himself in the Rings'
description: Never in the history of the modern Olympiad has a head of state made such political capital out of a sporting event. "Clinton is wrapping himself in the rings," says an Olympic official.

title: Sports of The Times;We Have Entered the Rodman Zone
description: WELCOME to Planet Rodman, where power forwards dress in drag and muscle Goliath, pump serious iron and outsmart eggheads.

title: War Crimes Suspect Succumbs to Cancer
description: A Bosnian Serb army general, Djordje Djukic, who was released by the United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague last month for ill health, died here on Saturday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Gov. WILLIAM WELD of Massachusetts, the Republican Senate candidate, was released from a hospital in Waltham yesterday, a day after he collapsed on stage during a college commencement ceremony.

title: No Headline
description: There's no such thing as getting by on the milk check and what the hens can lay you. That's ancient history. DENZIL WILMOTH, 81-year-old farmer in Beaver, Okla. [B8:1.]

title: Turkish Leader Reaffirms Secular Tradition
description: The President of Turkey indicated today that an assassination attempt by a gunman seeking to usher in Islamic law would not change his commitment to a secular state.

title: Shuttle Begins 10-Day Technology Flight
description: The space shuttle Endeavour, beginning a 10-day mission to explore new technologies, on Monday was to deploy and test a large antenna that inflates like a balloon to tennis-court size.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;Rodman and Bulls Send Magic Up in Smoke
description: For the Chicago Bulls, today's performance was worth the wait.

title: Abroad at Home;The Despised and Rejected
description: A poor woman trying to divorce a husband who beat her nearly to death. A Vietnamese who escaped from a re-education camp and seeks asylum in this country. Three women in prison who want to stop sexual assaults by male guards. A man on death row who has new evidence that he is innocent.

title: BASEBALL;Kamieniecki's Struggle Brings Down the Yanks
description: You woke up yesterday morning thinking it was spring, and all of a sudden it's summer. You scrambled last week to get a good seat, anticipating the drama of Dwight Gooden's first start since his no-hitter, only to find out he's pitching Tuesday. You stood in the batter's box searching for that Chuck Finley fastball, only to swing at a split-fingered fastball in the dirt. "You feel like you're on it," Paul O'Neill said. "Then you're not."

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the expected release dates for major economic indicators this week.

title: Bid to Auction Killer's Tools Provokes Disgust
description: Nothing hints of the macabre about the items stored in a warehouse for auction: used hardware that includes a drill, four knives, a handsaw, an 80-quart kettle and a freezer.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Domecq Reviewing Beefeater Account
description: Domecq Importers in Old Greenwich, Conn., a unit of Allied Domecq P.L.C., has placed in review the American account of Beefeater gin. That account had been handled forthree years by the FCB/Leber Katz Partners unit of True North Communications in New York, until that agency resigned in February; estimated billings on the account, recently inactive, were $6 million to $8 million.

title: For History on Cable, The Time Has Arrived
description: In cable television, where viewers once cried out for their MTV, they now seem to be clamoring for something a bit different: history.

title: In America;Bird & Max
description: Max Roach, smiling and shaking his head, pointed to the elaborately carved straight-back chair in the living room of his apartment on Central Park West. He was telling a story about Charlie Parker that went back to the 1940's.

title: Patents;Four Kodak engineers are honored for the development of a new consumer camera system.
description: A CAMERA that can send instructions to printing equipment about a photograph's size, the conditions under which it was taken, and dates, titles and details of its subjects has won two patents and an invention award for its designers.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Company News column of Business Day on Wednesday about a planned acquisition by the Commercial Bank of New York misidentified the company to be acquired. It is United Mizrahi Bank and Trust Company, a New York-based unit of United Mizrahi Bank, an Israeli bank holding company; it is not the Israeli company itself.

title: After an Arrest, Melee Erupts Near S.I. Project
description: What started as a routine response by the police to a report of a stabbing quickly escalated yesterday to a melee near a Staten Island housing project in which 8 people were arrested, 5 people were injured -- including 4 police officers -- and as many as 100 people marched on the 120th Precinct station house.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Sixers Win the Jackpot And Iverson or Marbury
description: He was the new guy. He didn't know. So Pat Croce, part owner of the 76ers, shrugged off the remain-seated sign like an overeager plane passenger, leaping to high-five a reluctant panel of also-rans when Philadelphia won the right to the No. 1 pick at the National Basketball Association draft lottery today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Doner Gets Account Of U.S. Cellular
description: The United States Cellular Corporation in Chicago, the wireless communications unit of Telephone and Data Systems Inc., has named W. B. Doner & Company to handle its account, which for the last five years had been at McConnaughy Stein Schmidt Brown in Chicago. Billings were estimated at $25 million.

title: Whose Attention Disorder Does Ritalin Treat?
description: To the Editor:

title: Larry P. Levis, 49, Poet and Professor
description: Larry Patrick Levis, a poet and professor of English at Virginia Commonwealth University in Richmond, was found dead at his home there on May 8. He was 49.

title: Sony Cuts Machine's Price
description: The Sony Corporation has cut the price of its Playstation video-game machine to $199, making the price $50 less than comparable machines from rivals like Sega Enterprises and Nintendo. The move is intended to help Sony sell an avalanche of its game machines before next-generation products from its rivals take off. On Wednesday, Nintendo displayed its Nintendo 64 game player, which it plans to sell in the United States starting Sept. 30. The Playstation previously cost $299.

title: AUTO RACING;Ongais to Replace Brayton
description: Danny Ongais, a 53-year-old driver who hasn't raced an Indy car in nine years, will replace Scott Brayton in the Indy 500.

title: AUTO RACING;One Man's Fierce Fight For Indy Racing's Future
description: May is never an easy month for the most important man behind the world's most important auto race.

title: INSIDE
description: An Admiral's Albatross

title: About All Those Perks Dole Will Relinquish
description: To the Editor:

title: Chet Forte, 60, Is Dead; An Innovative TV Director
description: Chet Forte, the tiny Columbia basketball player who won a national scoring title but earned more fame as the director of "Monday Night Football" before a gambling addiction ended his television career, died in San Diego Saturday of a heart attack. He was 60.

title: Wal-Mart to Sell AST Computers
description: AST Research Inc. said last week that it would begin selling $1,000 multimedia computers at Wal-Mart stores this month to create a new market for low-price machines. AST said it had begun shipping the machines to the stores under an exclusive marketing agreement with Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the nation's largest retailer.

title: Worst Drought Since 30's Grips Plains
description: Since last October, an average of 2.32 inches of rain has fallen on the wheat fields and cattle ranches that dominate the landscape here in the Oklahoma Panhandle -- the second driest such period since the Oklahoma Climatological Survey started keeping records 101 years ago.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article Saturday about the sentencing of George Delury for helping his wife, Myrna Lebov, to commit suicide omitted part of a quotation from Beverly Sloane, Ms. Lebov's sister. Ms. Sloane, who maintains that Mr. Delury coerced his wife into killing herself, said, "He anointed himself as the judge and proclaimed that she was euphoric if she wanted to live and accomplish and write a book, and he proclaimed it 'reality' if she wanted to take her life."

title: No Headline
NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Justice and Mental Health
description: Last March, a commission appointed by Robert N. Wilentz, Chief Justice of New Jersey, cited a breakdown in communication between the criminal justice and mental health systems as the reason that Conrad Jeffrey, a former mental patient, was able to win his freedom and murder a 7-year-old Passaic girl. A package of bills scheduled for their first legislative hearing today before the Assembly Judiciary Committee would force mental health officials to supply the courts and parole officials with more information. One of the bills would require that a defendant's psychiatric history be included in reports used to determine sentencing or parole.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Blacks' Vague Prime-Time Future
description: Ending a six-season run tonight, NBC's "Fresh Prince of Bel-Air" enters the television record books as still another moderately successful sitcom exercise, not very innovative but reasonably diverting. Its survival weapon: the series has been especially popular with youngsters and teen-agers.

title: Barton Heyman, 59, Actor on Stage and Screen
description: Barton Heyman, an actor whose last three words uttered in front of a camera brought him more acclaim than 30 years on stage and screen, died last Wednesday in his Manhattan home. He was 59.

title: Homeless in San Francisco: A New Policy
description: In 1994 Robert Kahn was sentenced to 60 days in jail for giving soup and bagels to the homeless near City Hall.

title: Met Is Given 13 Works Worth Over $60 Million
description: Thirteen works of 20th-century art by masters like Picasso, Modigliani, Braque and Leger -- a collection experts believe to be worth $60 million to $80 million -- have been given to the Metropolitan Museum of Art by Klaus G. Perls and his wife, Amelia.

title: A Day for Many Diplomas, And for One Famous Frog
description: Adelphi University, which had a tumultuous year because of questions about the spending practices of its president, Peter Diamandopoulos, gave diplomas to 2,443 students yesterday, and the controversy over the president drew hardly a mention.

title: BASEBALL;Umps Accused Of Getting Even
description: John Smiley said umpires are getting back at the Cincinnati Reds owner Marge Schott by giving her pitchers a smaller strike zone.

title: Taking In the Sites;Take a Tip From Mystic Molly On Ways to Win the Lottery
description: Why brave the lotteries unaided? Dozens of World Wide Web sites offer data bases of "hot" and "cold" numbers, archives of past winners and lucky combinations picked by psychics, planets and pets.

title: Fight Widens On Aid Zone For New York
description: A top Federal housing official called on New York State yesterday to back down in an increasingly bitter feud with New York City officials that he said could kill a $300 million plan to revitalize Harlem and parts of the South Bronx.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: WOMEN'S LACROSSE

title: Soccer Hero Voices Liberia's Anguish
description: From the very outset of an interview conducted in the near-dark of his hotel room here, where heavy curtains blocked out the dazzling late afternoon sun, George M. Weah wanted to make one thing clear.

title: Rangel Phrase Stirs Tempest Amid Layoffs
description: Amid citywide rallies yesterday to protest the planned layoffs of hundreds of workers at New York City public hospitals, another tempest surged to the fore: Representative Charles B. Rangel's steadfast use of the term "gang-raped" to describe what he believes the Giuliani administration and Republicans in general are doing to labor unions.

title: Search Yields New Evidence Of Cargo Role In DC-9 Crash
description: Federal crash investigators said today that they had found a partly burned aircraft tire that was carried as cargo by the Valujet DC-9 that crashed near Miami on May 11, a likely source of the smoke that the co-pilot urgently reported just before the crash. Embedded in the tire, the investigators said, were parts from at least one oxygen generator, a device that can generate tremendous heat.

title: Barnard's Students Meet Gandhi's Principles
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by The Associated Press in Business Day on Tuesday about a consortium of companies formed to finance large-budget movies made by Paramount Pictures included one company erroneously. Polygram is not a member.

title: Howard Shapiro, 40, A Writer With AIDS
description: Howard Aaron Shapiro, who chronicled his four-year battle with AIDS through a series of newspaper and magazine articles, died of its complications on Saturday at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan. He was 40.

title: Prosecuting Juveniles as Adults
description: States across the country are cracking down on juveniles who commit serious crimes by allowing them to be tried in the adult criminal justice system, where they will presumably get stiffer sentences and be jailed under harsher conditions. Some stronger action is indeed warranted to cope with vicious youngsters whose crimes may be every bit as heinous as those committed by adults. But much of what the states are doing may have the perverse effect of making society less safe. Pushing juveniles into the adult system may provide no greater punishment but breed tougher criminals who will be more difficult to handle upon release.

title: Whose Attention Disorder Does Ritalin Treat?
description: To the Editor:

title: Four Win Hot Rod Titles
description: Joe Amato, John Force, Jim Yates and Dave Schultz won today at the National Hot Rod Association Mopar Parts Nationals. Amato (4.782 seconds) won in Top Fuel, Force (5.087) in Funny Car, Yates (7.134) in Pro Stock and Schultz (7.628) in Pro Stock Motorcycle.

title: Hindu Die-Hards Seizing Their Day in the India Sun
description: The sun was barely over the smoggy horizon today when a group of men and boys in khaki shorts, brown belts and white shirts lined up on a stretch of scrubland on this capital's outskirts, then turned to face the dawn.

title: Palestinians In Gaza Arrest Rights Activist
description: A prominent Palestinian human rights advocate has been arrested in Gaza, after accusing the Palestinian Authority in a newspaper interview of dictatorial rule and of torturing prisoners, his associates said today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Rogge Effler Gets A New Partner
description: Rogge Effler & Partners, the former Los Angeles office of Lord, Dentsu & Partners that is now owned solely by Dentsu Inc., has named Paul Katzka, an executive with automobile advertising and marketing experience, as a partner and executive vice president.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings this week:

title: Can You Trust the A.A.R.P.?
description: The credibility of the American Association of Retired Persons will be at stake if the organization proceeds with efforts to license its name to managed care plans for a fee. The 33 million-member organization is a powerful lobbying group that tries to sway Congress on issues important to the elderly and provides services that are supposed to benefit its members. But A.A.R.P. also earns substantial income -- amounting to about 40 percent of its $345 million budget -- by charging fees for endorsing selected auto, health and homeowner insurance policies. That raises a potential conflict of interest because the policies that might be best for the elderly are not always the policies that are best for the bank account of the A.A.R.P.

title: Reveling in Sizzling Heat, for Now
description: In a few weeks, they will be grousing about days like this. In a few months, they will be vowing pilgrimages to the North Pole.

title: Carolina County Reverses Anti-Gay Vote
description: The Spartanburg County Council voted 4 to 1 on Friday to rescind its anti-gay resolution, probably preserving the county's participation in this summer's Olympic Games.

title: A Fire-Scarred Tire, An F.A.A. History
description: Investigators say a partly burned tire from the cargo hold of the Valujet DC-9 that crashed in the Florida Everglades has parts from an oxygen generator embedded in it. The finding strengthens a leading theory on the cause of the crash: that one or more of the oxygen generators being carried as cargo somehow ignited the tire.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Stern Questions the Outrage Over Early Entry to N.B.A.
description: There was a little steam coming off David Stern, enough to unseal a lottery envelope, enough to reveal his dismay at the soap-box stands taken over the college underclassmen and high school players declaring themselves eligible for this year's draft.

title: About All Those Perks Dole Will Relinquish
description: To the Editor:

title: ON BASEBALL;As Bad as Things Look, Torre Still Likes Staff
description: In the four games since Dwight Gooden pitched a no-hitter against the Seattle Mariners, Gooden's fellow Yankee starters have gone 2-2 with an alarming earned run average of 8.68, having allowed 18 runs in 18 2/3 innings.

title: Advances in Asia Propel Wider Use of Flat-Panel Displays
description: For decades engineers have been promising television sets that would hang on the wall like a picture. That fabled day may finally be coming, based on evidence from a technical conference last week in San Diego, where engineers demonstrated so-called flat-panel displays with screens big enough to begin rivaling television monitors -- and with costs low enough that flat screens may soon become a viable alternative to the bulky cathode-ray tube, or CRT, monitors now standard on desktop computers.

title: Rent' and 'Guitars' Win Critics' Awards
description: Rent" and "Seven Guitars" have been named best new musical and play of the season by the New York Drama Critics Circle, a 60-year-old group made up of 17 critics from newspapers and magazines in and around New York City. The awards are to be presented today at Sardi's restaurant in Manhattan.

title: Offerings Of Equities For the Week
description: The following equity and convertible-debt offerings are expected this week:

title: For Journalism Graduates, Opportunities in New Media
description: When Addie Butt enrolled in the journalism school at the University of Missouri here two years ago, her goal was to become a newspaper sportswriter. But one of the school's newest courses -- new media, an intensive study of on-line publications -- changed her plans.

title: F.A.A. Files Show Early Lapses by Valujet
description: On Sept. 26, 1994, Valujet Airlines discovered a leaking hydraulic line on one of its DC-9 jets. Federal rules required immediate repair of the leak, but the airline waited. The line, part of a system that retracts the front landing gear, was replaced 23 days later, after 148 flights.

title: A Temporary Force To Be Reckoned With;Wanted: High-Tech 'Hired Guns' And Agencies to Provide Them
description: The hiring hall of the Information Age is a fourth-floor office encased in glass and granite, just a few blocks from a waterfront that once buzzed with temporary workers of an entirely different sort.

title: Suicide Over a Medal? An Ex-General's View
description: His sin was venial, but the consequences were mortal. By his own hand last Thursday, the Navy's most senior officer put a .38-caliber bullet into his chest, ending his life. Adm. Jeremy M. Boorda, Chief of Naval Operations, killed himself when faced with disclosure by a magazine article that he had claimed two Vietnam War decorations to which he was not entitled.

title: Diller to Find New Rivals As He Updates An Old Dream
description: Barry Diller, who almost single-handedly started the interactive-television rage three years ago by investing in an obscure home shopping channel named QVC, still can't resist spinning dreams. And last week, Mr. Diller spun a new one: He said that he intended to transform the profitable but dowdy business of home shopping by sending it into cyberspace.

title: Taiwan President Says He Would Go to Beijing for Talks
description: To the cheers of some 50,000 flag-waving guests, Taiwan's first democratically elected President, Lee Teng-hui, declared in his inaugural address today that he was willing to travel to Beijing to talk with China's leaders.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ANDREW YOUNG, the former Mayor of Atlanta and now co-chairman of the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games, and his wife, CAROLYN WATSON, could not agree on what to call their wedding on Sunday at Union Baptist Church in Atlanta.

title: Shuttle Deploys Inflatable Satellite
description: The astronauts aboard the space shuttle Endeavour watched today as an inflatable antenna was unfurled from a satellite as part of a NASA experiment to find cheaper ways to build orbiting structures.

title: Executive Changes
description: EGGHEAD INC., Issaquah, Wash., named Peter Grossman executive vice president for customer offers and Ron Smith senior vice president in charge of Egghead's customer delivery system.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;School Strip-Search Bill Gains
description: A school principal in Plainfield angered local officials in April 1995 when she ordered third graders to disrobe so that teachers could search for $20 that a student had reported missing. The money was not retrieved. Under a bill approved yesterday by the Assembly Judiciary Committee, school officials could no longer conduct strip searches.

title: The Chicken With a Duck's Feet: It's All in the Biochemical Signal
description: AS scientists piece together the complex biochemical origami through which a blank sheet of undifferentiated cells is folded into a fully developed creature, they are learning a striking lesson: context is everything. What counts as a deformity in one organism can be one of evolution's gifts for another.

title: Blast Damages Texas Building That Houses Small F.B.I. Office
description: A bomb exploded this morning outside the building that houses the Federal Bureau of Investigation here, but F.B.I. officials said they could not immediately determine whether the agencywas the target.

title: Blame for Violence Is Disputed on S.I.
description: A day after a confrontation left five people injured in the Stapleton housing project on Staten Island, police officials and residents offered sharply different accounts of the scuffle yesterday. Residents said the officers used excessive force, while police officials accused several people of inciting the violence.

title: Secrets and Lies' Wins the Top Prize at Cannes
description: Secrets and Lies," Mike Leigh's film about a struggling white Englishwoman who is reunited with the half-black daughter she gave away in infancy 27 years earlier, was named the winner of the Palme d'Or at the Cannes International Film Festival today. Brenda Blethyn, who plays the mother, was named best actress, and switched from her own polished elocution to her character's Cockney accent in accepting her prize. "Oh, this is livin,' ain't it!" she told the audience at the Palais des Festivals. "Thank ye, sweet'art."

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;4th Award Special to Jordan
description: Michael Jordan called his fourth most valuable player award today "more meaningful" than the first three he won, saying he felt more appreciated as a complete player and claiming to better understand the game.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: COLLEGE ATHLETICS;Big 12 Presidents Pass Tough Standards
description: Presidents of the fledgling Big 12 Conference, overruling most of their football coaches, voted yesterday to proceed with initial eligibility standards that are tougher than the N.C.A.A.'s and those of most other conferences.

title: Dispute at Club Tied to N.Y.U. Exposes Leadership Rift
description: It began with a flap over an invitation to lunch. The guest was to have been Hillary Rodham Clinton. Now it has blown up into a state of high-wattage Sturm und Drang within New York City's most venerable intellectual club.

title: U.S. History Standards Explore Connections
description: To the Editor:

title: NYC;For Addicts, A No-Hitter That's Theirs
description: THE cheers never last, but they continue to reverberate unusually long for Dwight Gooden since his no-hitter at Yankee Stadium last week, that near-epic tale of failure and redemption. Few, however, have taken the Yankee pitcher's turnaround to heart as much as the 300 people trying to put shattered lives back together at the Phoenix House drug-treatment residence in Long Island City.

title: City to Drop Longtime Child Abuse Programs
description: Correction Appended

title: COMPANY REPORTS;First-Quarter Net Up 39% At the Limited
description: The Limited Inc. reported today that its first-quarter profit rose 39 percent on strong sales in its Victoria's Secret and Abercrombie & Fitch divisions.

title: Man Sentenced In Jordan Case
description: Larry Martin Demery, who helped send his friend to prison for life for killing Michael Jordan's father, also received a life sentence today.

title: Partners Vote For Changes At Goldman
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company took action yesterday to strengthen its capital base and to limit the liability of the firm's partners.

title: THE GAY RIGHTS RULING: REDISTRICTING;Justices to Review the Reduction of Black Districts in Georgia
description: Adding an important new redistricting case to its docket, the Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a Federal District Court in Georgia violated the Voting Rights Act last December when it reduced the number of majority-black Congressional districts in the state to one from three.

title: The Consensus Is for Pants, Long, Lean and Leggy
description: Each season, out of all the styles shown on designers' runways, one look often emerges as the fashion look off the runway. This seems to be especially true in the summer, or perhaps it's more obvious then because you see people on the streets without coats.

title: Chess
description: The top players in the post-World War II era often complained about the stress accompanying a last-round struggle for a tournament first prize. But nowadays the best players take the problems of a closely contested tourney finale in good stride.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;British Airways Posts Profit Rise of 29.4%
description: British Airways P.L.C. said yesterday that its full-year pretax profit rose 29.4 percent. The carrier also said that it plans to cut L1 billion, or $1.52 billion, of costs in the next three years, a move that drew a strike threat from its pilots' union.

title: Japanese Stocks Ebb
description: Stocks traded slightly lower here this morning. At the midday break, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 19.70 points -- slightly less than one-tenth of 1 percent -- to stand at 21,959.30. On Monday, the Nikkei gained 62.40 points.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Citigate Leads Portfolio Awards
description: Citigate Albert Frank took top honors, winning the most awards, at the second annual Portfolio Awards ceremony honoring financial advertising, which is sponsored by the Financial Communications Society.

title: Britain to Expel Three Sudanese Diplomats
description: Britain ordered the Sudan today to reduce its diplomatic staff by three people because of its refusal to surrender suspects in an assassination attempt against President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt.

title: Sweetened Bid From Utilicorp In Kansas City Takeover Fight
description: Faced with losing a shareholder vote on its original offer to merge with the Kansas City Power and Light Company, Utilicorp United Inc. has sweetened its bid.

title: A New Star In Constellation Of Art's Giants;Queens Landmark Wins A Coveted Cultural Title
description: The Museum of Modern Art is not part of this club. Neither is the Guggenheim or the Whitney. Not even the Metropolitan Opera or the New York Philharmonic.

title: Ex-Nassau Official Again Charging Abuses
description: A former Nassau County official who helped uncover a patronage scandal in the Republican Party here in the 1970's is making new charges of patronage abuses against the current Republican county administration.

title: Q&A
description: Caimans, Not Alligators

title: COMPANY NEWS;ANOTHER ACQUISITION FOR REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES
description: Republic Industries said yesterday that it planned to buy Continental Waste Industries of Clark, N.J., in a transaction valued about $240 million. Under the deal, Continental shareholders are to get two-fifths of a Republic share for each share held. Republic, a provider of solid waste and electronic security services that is based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., has been aggressively making acquisitions since August 1995, when H. Wayne Huizenga invested $27 million in the company and became its chief executive. Its shares rose $3.25, to $43.875, in Nasdaq trading; Continental's shares rose $2.875, to $16.25.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Bangladesh Army Chief Ousted, Stirring Unrest
description: The President of Bangladesh dismissed the leader of his army today. Loyal soldiers moved to guard the President, but troops in some provincial barracks were reported to be showing signs of unrest.

title: Market Place;As Dow Breaks Through 5,700, There's a Shift in Its Best Sellers
description: It's the consumer who has turned around this stock market.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Recife Journal;The Decorated Veterans of Brazil's Stark Streets
description: At 19, Elilde da Pinha Alves looks down her forearm at a series of slashes, the record of a brief, turbulent life she has carved in her flesh.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;Looking for a New Home on the Internet
description: IN Moscow, desperate people must sometimes wait years, or pay exorbitant bribes, to get telephone service that is expensive and unreliable. By those standards, Internet access in the United States is pretty good. But recent events and trends in the on-line access business have led some Internet customers to reassess their service providers and begin shopping around for new homes in cyberspace.

title: Mr. McConnell, Still Fighting Reform
description: Senator Mitch McConnell is a persistent man. A year ago the Kentucky Republican tried to insert language in the Republican budget bill that would have abolished the public campaign financing system for Presidential races. His provision was soundly defeated. Now he is back with a crafty new plan to destroy a valuable, if imperfect, mechanism that has done much to reduce the political influence of powerful special interests.

title: No Headline
description: It's making me more unsettled than I normally am. There was all that snow. There's been no spring. You don't know what to expect." -- GEOFFRY HALL, on the record heat in New York. [A1:1.]

title: The Hindu Majority Can't Run India All Alone
