description: To the Editor:

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Pop CD's;Rappers On Loving And Living
description: 'Kollage'

title: Links Sought in an 'Epidemic of Terror'
description: On the eve of a Congressional hearing into a rash of church burnings across the South, Federal officials are continuing to investigate whether there are any links between the fires at dozens of black churches over the last six years.

title: The Chiropractors' Bailout Bill
description: Chiropractors are again pressuring the New York State Legislature to give them through the political process what they could never achieve in the marketplace. They have pushed a bill through the Senate that would require health plans in the state to cover unlimited chiropractic services. The bill, which the Assembly could take up at any time, would amount to a full-employment act for chiropractors, but a health-care tax on everyone else -- forcing up insurance premiums to offset increased use of often unnecessary treatments.

title: Iomega Share Price Surges
description: Shares of the Iomega Corporation soared 19 percent yesterday amid optimism that the company's 2-for-1 stock split, to take effect today, would increase demand for the stock. Shares in Iomega, a maker of storage disk drives for computers, rose $13.375 each, to $82.625, in trading of 9.9 million shares. Shareholders of record as of the close of trading yesterday will receive an additional share for each share they own. Iomega's share price will be halved from yesterday's closing price at the market's opening today. The company, based in Roy, Utah, said last month that it had earned $10.1 million, or 16 cents a share, in the first quarter, in contrast to a loss of $1.5 million in the first quarter of 1995.

title: Colombian President May Be Cleared of Charges
description: Dismissing evidence in 3,200 files from Colombia's chief prosecutor, the chairman of the congressional committee investigating whether President Ernesto Samper financed his electoral campaign with $6.1 million from Cali drug dealers will reportedly recommend dropping all charges.

title: A Deal by Wellpoint Creates a Health Provider and Two Charities
description: In what could be a harbinger of other such transactions, a deal was completed today creating one of the country's largest charitable foundations as well as a big health care company that is likely to pursue numerous acquisitions as it grows.

title: Japan's U.S. Trade Surplus Plunged 56% Last Month
description: Japan's merchandise trade surplus with the United States recorded its steepest drop in 17 years in April, mainly because of rising technology imports from Intel, I.B.M. and other producers.

title: COMPANY NEWS;COURT REFUSES APPEAL ON TERMINATED PENSION PLAN
description: The Supreme Court turned down an appeal yesterday from former executives of Zeneca Inc. who were seeking to revive a lawsuit regarding the termination of the company's deferred executive compensation plan. A Federal appeals court had ruled that the executives could not seek money damages, saying uncertainty about future tax rates and investment returns made it difficult, if not impossible, to calculate the impact of the termination. Zeneca, a pharmaceutical and agri-chemical unit of Zeneca Group P.L.C., ended the plan in 1991. The company, then known as ICI Americas Inc., said it did so after a hostile takeover bid raised questions about whether a buyer would have honored the underfinanced plan's obligations.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Property Tax Battle Looms
description: A study to be released today on the tax consequences of a property revaluation is expected to bring bad news to thousands of Newark homeowners. Newark has gone longer than any other municipality in the state -- 39 years -- without bringing assessments up to current market value. The state is now pressing the city to conduct a revaluation, but many local officials and residents say the move would increase the tax burden on residential properties, driving out homeowners and crippling the city's recovery. A preliminary study by William Merdinger, the appraiser who prepared today's report, showed that taxes could more than double in some areas.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SAKS INCREASES PRICE FOR ITS FIRST PUBLIC SHARES
description: Saks Holdings Inc., the New York-based retailer, has raised the estimated price for common stock to be sold through an initial public offering. The company now plans to sell 16 million shares at $23 to $25 each, according to an amended registration statement filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Saks initially projected that it would sell the shares at $20 to $23 each. Saks said it planned to use the proceeds from the sale to repay debt. Goldman, Sachs & Company leads the underwriting group for the sale. Saks also reported yesterday a net loss of $3 million in its first quarter, compared with a loss of $16.5 million in the corresponding period last year.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Now, when Visa U.S.A. says 'everywhere you want to be,' that includes Baltimore, too.
description: VISA U.S.A. has long proclaimed that its credit cards are accepted "everywhere you want to be." That is now particularly appropriate if you want to be someplace where people affectionately call you "hon" and insist on pouring gravy over their french fries.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Making Fine Print Larger
description: We beat their price!" scream the two-inch-high letters in an ad for an electronics superstore -- that is, the fine print says, as long as the competitor is an "approved retailer" and his price does not include "bonuses, free offers, special financing, manufacturer's rebates or other limited-time offers." Such misleading boasts would become harder to make under a bill approved yesterday by the Assembly Consumer Affairs Committee and sent on to the Assembly. The measure would require any exceptions to a price guarantee to be listed in the type of the same size as the guarantee itself.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Academic tributes, Part 2: Don't assume that you can give a dinner honoring LEONARD M. MARKS, a Manhattan lawyer whose clients include Billy Joel, Eddie Murphy and Elton John, and leave it at that.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Toyota and Matsushita To Make Batteries
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation, Japan's largest car maker, and the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, the consumer electronics giant, said yesterday that they would set up a company in September to develop, manufacture and sell nickel-metal hydride rechargeable batteries for use in electric cars. The company, to be called the Panasonic EV Energy Company, will be capitalized at two billion yen, or about $18.6 million. Matsushita will own 60 percent; Toyota will take the rest.

title: ON BASEBALL;Game's Big Problem: Futile Tigers
description: On a daily basis, people say Major League Baseball should do something about Marge Schott, should do something about Albert Belle. What baseball should do something about, though, is the Detroit Tigers.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Supreme Court Rejects A Punitive Damage Award The Supreme Court has overturned a $2 million punitive damage award to an Alabama man who bought a new BMW with a touched-up paint job.

title: Frosty Daffodils, Then 96degrees, All in the Scary Month of May
description: What gives with this weather?

title: COMPANY NEWS;ITHACA INDUSTRIES RECORDS CHARGE AND REVAMPS DEBT
description: Ithaca Industries of Wilkesboro, N.C., said yesterday that it would record a substantial loss for the year ended Feb. 2 because of a one-time charge of $51.6 million for consolidation, revamping and asset write-downs. The company, which designs, makes and markets private-label and branded underwear, hosiery and T-shirts, said that it had reached agreement in principle with an unofficial committee of holders of its 11.125 percent senior subordinated notes on a revamping of its outstanding debt under the notes. Under the terms, the note holders will exchange all outstanding notes for 100 percent of the company's stock in a move that will eliminate more than 50 percent of the company's debt and result in an improved balance sheet.

title: THE GAY RIGHTS RULING;Excerpts From Court's Decision on Colorado's Provision for Homosexuals
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today in Romer v. Evans, declaring unconstitutional a Colorado state constitutional provision that nullified civil rights laws singling out homosexuals for protection. Justice Anthony M. Kennedy wrote the majority opinion, which was joined by Justices John Paul Stevens, Sandra Day O'Connor, David H. Souter, Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Stephen G. Breyer. Justice Antonin Scalia's dissenting opinion was joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justice Clarence Thomas.

title: Computers Don't Educate. Good Teachers Do.
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Nikon's Annual Profit More Than Triples
description: The Nikon Corporation announced sharply higher annual profit yesterday that exceeded its own forecasts, and credited strong growth in sales of equipment used to make semiconductors. The camera maker said its unconsolidated pretax profit soared 221 percent, to 18.85 billion Japanese yen, about $177.8 million, in the year ended March 31, up from 5.88 billion yen the previous year. Nikon's pretax profit beat company forecasts by 7.7 percent. Sales rose to 259.56 billion yen from 229.19 billion yen.

title: Airman Guilty in Okinawa
description: A United States Air Force enlisted man was found guilty today of having sex with a 14-year-old American girl at an air base on Okinawa.

title: Oil Spill Is Expected to Be Cleaned Off South Jersey Beaches byWeekend
description: New Jersey officials said yesterday that an oil spill from a tanker that fouled beaches along more than 40 miles of the South Jersey shore during the last few days would probably be cleaned up in time for the arrival of tourists on Memorial Day weekend.

title: Tsongas Discharged After a Bone Marrow Transplant From Twin
description: Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts was discharged from a hospital in Boston yesterday where he underwent a bone marrow transplant for a complication of the cancer therapy he has received intermittently for a decade, the hospital said.

title: Montgomery Ward May Consider Selling Its Retail Stores
description: The Montgomery Ward Holding Corporation is seeking to raise cash and may consider the sale of its retail stores, people close to the company said yesterday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Golden Corral Reviewing Account
description: The Golden Corral Corporation, a unit of the Investors Management Corporation that operates 450 buffet grill-style restaurants, has placed its account in review after parting ways with the Richmond office of Earle Palmer Brown, which had handled its account for two years. Billings were estimated at $7 million to $8 million. Stephen Fortlouis, marketing director at Golden Corral in Raleigh, N.C., said the review was in a preliminary stage, adding that a decision is expected by Aug. 1.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Reich Backs Up Quarterback and Coach
description: For most of his 11 pro seasons, Frank Reich has been described as the best backup quarterback in the National Football League. For 10 years, behind Jim Kelly with the Buffalo Bills, he played 93 games, but started only 8. Last year, after starting the first three games, he became the backup to a high-priced rookie, Kerry Collins, with the expansion Carolina Panthers and never took another snap.

title: More Layoffs At Electric Boat
description: The Electric Boat unit of the General Dynamics Corporation said today that it would lay off 2,000 workers in Connecticut over the next four months, expanding planned cutbacks as submarine work continues to shrink.

title: Moratorium on Protecting Species Is Ended
description: Ending a 13-month moratorium imposed by Congress, the Federal Government complied with a court order today and granted protection under the Endangered Species Act to a California frog.

title: Barbra, Gorgeous! You Have a Shrine
description: Peo ple, people who need people maybe those people need a museum, too, a place where memories light the corners of their minds.

title: Robert Hearn, 92, Priest in the Army
description: The Rev. Robert Hearn, a priest who was wounded twice in World War II, died on Thursday at the St. Patrick's Manor nursing home in Framingham, Mass. He was 92.

title: Insurance by Phone Is Offered in Britain
description: Richard Branson's Virgin Group said today that it would take on British insurers with new low-cost life and health insurance products sold directly by telephone.

title: Move to the Web Is in the Works For Compuserve
description: Deciding to flow with the relentless tide of the Internet rather than fight it, Compuserve Inc. is expected to announce today that it is rebuilding its entire on-line service on the standards of the World Wide Web, people briefed by the company said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A book review yesterday about "God Has Ninety-Nine Names" by Judith Miller misspelled the surname of a journalist hailed as a great foreign correspondent of the past. He was Vincent Sheean, not Sheehan.

title: Pataki and Giuliani End Squabble Over an Economic Renewal Zone
description: Breaking an impasse that had held up $100 million in Federal aid for two of New York City's poorest neighborhoods, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that they had overcome their differences over how to share control of the board that will dole out the money.

title: Israeli Airport Closed 3 Hours
description: Ben-Gurion International Airport was shut for three hours today when pirate radio stations broadcasting on air traffic frequencies blocked control tower communications.

title: BASEBALL;Sunday's Missing Bats Are Back
description: The Mets had what they called a bust-out game in San Francisco Saturday when they scored 14 runs on 15 hits to beat the Giants. They were a bust the next day when they scored two runs in two games and were swept in a doubleheader.

title: Sports of The Times;Element of Surprise Favors Gooden in A.L.
description: NOW, for his next trick, Dwight Gooden will try to equal what is arguably baseball's rarest pitching feat: Johnny Vander Meer's two consecutive no-hitters.

title: COMPANY BRIEF
description: ADOBE SYSTEMS INC., Mountain View, Calif., bought closely held Ares Software Corp., acquiring a software product that allows laser printers to print more typefaces. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Views Clash on Admiral's Right to Wear Pins
description: Navy officials and military historians said today that they might never be able to resolve the issue that helped drive Adm. Jeremy M. Boorda to suicide last week: Was the Navy's highest-ranking officer entitled to wear two Vietnam War combat decorations?

title: Judge Bars Foe of Abortion From Harassing Clinic Head
description: A judge, using a year-old law to protect people from stalkers, has ordered one of the nation's most outspoken foes of abortion to stay away from the head of a Portland clinic after he had repeatedly harassed her and picketed her house.

title: For One Celebrated Frog, a Leg Up
description: The name of Calaveras County's newest celebrated frog says it all: Three Legs Are Better Than None.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Beckett's Stories Map a Route to His Main Themes
description: SAMUEL BECKETT The Complete Short Prose, 1929-1989 By Samuel Beckett Edited and with an introduction and notes by S. E. Gontarski 294 pages. Grove Press. $23.

title: POLITICAL BRIEFS;THE CAMPAIGNS FOR THE SENATE
description: Arkansas Optimism at Last Among Republicans

title: I.R.A. Ally Might Accept Disarmament Terms
description: Sinn Fein, the political arm of the Irish Republican Army, said today that if it was permitted to take part in Northern Ireland peace talks scheduled for next month, it would abide by stipulations for disarmament recommended by an international commission headed by former Senator George J. Mitchell.

title: GE Capital to Acquire Ameridata Technologies for $490 Million
description: The General Electric Company's Capital Services unit agreed yesterday to buy Ameridata Technologies Inc. for $490 million to expand its computer equipment leasing and consulting business.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BEC GROUP MAKES AN OFFER FOR ILC TECHNOLOGY
description: BEC Group Inc., which makes Foster Grant sunglasses and electronics and lighting equipment, said yesterday that it had offered to acquire ILC Technology Inc., a maker of high-intensity lamps and other lighting equipment, for $75 million. BEC Group, based in Rye, N.Y., said the proposal called for ILC shareholders to receive two BEC Group common shares for each ILC common share. The offer values ILC, which is based in Sunnyvale, Calif., at $15 a share. ILC shares rose 12.5 cents yesterday, to $12.875, in Nasdaq trading. Shares of BEC Group fell 12.5 cents, to $6.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: OLYMPICS;Atlanta Ready, I.O.C. Says, Despite Some Rough Edges
description: The International Olympic Committee today gave final approval to Atlanta's preparations for the 1996 Olympic Games, the largest and most costly in the 100-year history of the modern Olympics.

title: Pulsing Magnets Offer New Method Of Mapping Brain
description: A PSYCHIATRIST presses a small, hand-held device over a patient's skull. There is a clicking sound and the patient feels what has been described as a "clawlike" sensation or skin being "drawn up." Usually it is not uncomfortable.

title: Canadian Picks Kentucky
description: After hundreds of phone calls and countless letters from college coaches, the bidding war for the Toronto high school basketball sensation Jamaal Magloire is over.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the New Jersey section on Sunday about the 25th anniversary of the New Jersey Network misstated the dates of two events. The premiere of its documentary "Domestic Violence: Faces of Fear" will be at 9 P.M. next Tuesday, not tonight. The anniversary gala will be on May 29, not tomorrow.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SONAT DRILLING SWEETENS OFFER FOR TRANSOCEAN
description: Sonat Offshore Drilling Inc. has virtually locked up an acquisition of Transocean A.S. of Norway by raising its bid and winning support from Transocean's largest shareholder, the Tiger Management Corporation, analysts said yesterday. Sonat, a Houston-based drilling company, increased its offer to 0.53 share of its stock, for each share of Transocean. At Sonat's current stock price, the offer is worth about $27.83 for each Transocean share. The previous offer had been valued about $27.08 a share in cash and stock. Based on yesterday's closing stock prices, the revised Sonat offer values Transocean at $1.43 billion. A rival offer, from the Reading & Bates Corporation, another Houston-based drilling company, values Transocean at $1.49 billion. A spokesman for Reading & Bates could not be reached for comment.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Cavs Will Not Take Suns' Pick This Year
description: The Cleveland Cavaliers said yesterday that the team will not exercise its option to take the Phoenix Suns' first-round pick in the 1996 draft. The Suns have the 15th pick in the June 26 draft.

title: On My Mind;The Last Laugh
description: It is Election Day. Millions of Americans who would not have voted for Robert Dole are so moved by his decision to quit the Senate that they decide he is their man after all -- enough to make him the President of the United States.

title: A Worm's Life: Right Mutation Makes It Long But Very Dull
description: MUTANT worms that live five times as long as their normal counterparts are yielding clues to the genetic control of life span -- and lending new credence to the old idea that one way to live longer might be to live less.

title: SCIENTIST AT WORK: Joseph Rotblat;Still Battling Nuclear Weapons 50 Years After Manhattan Project
description: JOSEPH ROTBLAT was a loner when in 1944 he quit the secret project in the wilderness of New Mexico that was seeking to build the world's first atomic bomb. Among the thousands of scientists laboring in the mountains behind barbed-wire fences, most of them enthralled with unlocking the atom's secrets, he was the only one to quit the Manhattan Project who cited moral reasons. Federal agents were skeptical, fearing the Polish-born, British-based physicist was already a spy or might soon give Moscow some of Washington's top secrets.

title: 3 Upstate Eighth Graders Admit Plot to Bomb Junior High School
description: Three youths admitted today that they had plotted to set off a homemade bomb in their junior high school.

title: For First Time, Justices Reject Punitive Award
description: Overturning a $2 million punitive-damage award to an Alabama man who bought a new BMW with a touched-up paint job, the Supreme Court set new standards today for determining when an award of punitive damages is so "grossly excessive" as to violate the constitutional requirement of due process of law.

title: Picasso Show Is Using Timed-Entry Tickets
description: The Museum of Modern Art is introducing timed-entry tickets today for its highly popular exhibition "Picasso and Portraiture: Representation and Transformation," which has been drawing crowds since it opened on April 28. The tickets admit visitors to the exhibition every hour on the half-hour, distributing crowds more evenly throughout the galleries of the Picasso show.

title: ABC to Introduce 8 New Fall Series
description: Looking to end a two-year drought of new hit shows, ABC yesterday announced a fall prime-time schedule that adds eight new series, moves six others and resurrects last season's biggest hope, "Murder One," with a new format and a new star.

title: THE GAY RIGHTS RULING: IN COLORADO;Ruling Signals More Fights to Come
description: Ordinarily, Suzanne B. Goldberg, a lawyer with the Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund, measures her words painstakingly and pronounces them softly. Yesterday, she allowed herself some jubilation.

title: Bus Drivers Win Sabbath Dispute
description: The Transit Authority and the Transport Workers Union have reached an agreement to accommodate four city bus drivers who were disciplined or dismissed after they refused to work on the Sabbath.

title: ACCORD REACHED BY IRAQ AND U.N. FOR OIL EXPORTS
description: Iraq and the United Nations signed an agreement today allowing the Iraqis to sell oil for the first time since their 1990 invasion of Kuwait in order to pay for the urgent needs of a civilian population suffering from six years of tight international sanctions.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: Steve Albertini, executive vice president at Earle Palmer Brown, Philadelphia, was promoted to general manager, assuming responsibilities held by J. Scott Franks, president and general manager, who will leave after two months to join Tierney & Partners, Philadelphia, a unit of True North Communications, in the new post of executive vice president and chief operating officer. Fred Zuckerman was named to the new position of executive vice president and media services director at Harris Drury Cohen, Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He had been senior vice president and media director at Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor, New York.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Japanese Make Music, and We Step Back
description: To the Editor:

title: ON TENNIS;Wilander Bound for Paris, Despite the System
description: Mats Wilander has always had an uneasy relationship with "the system." Now he claims the system, in the form of the International Tennis Federation, is out to smear him with a trumped-up drug charge.

title: One Less Hurdle for Caller ID in California
description: California regulators lost an effort today to get the Supreme Court to pass judgment on issues regarding the display of unpublished telephone numbers on caller ID systems.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;Getting Your Mail Sent to a New Virtual Home
description: THE Internet access provider Psinet Inc. recently announced that it would soon double the monthly minimum charge for those subscribers to its Pipeline service who have been paying the least. No doubt many of those subscribers found themselves wondering: What happens to your E-mail when you change your on-line service or Internet provider?

title: Germany Is Tied Up by a 'Warning Strike' of Public Workers
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's proposals to pare down Germany's public spending came under mounting pressure today as public workers in many cities staged warning strikes that brought streetcars, buses, garbage disposal, mail and other services sputtering to a halt.

title: INSIDE
description: Flames and Questions

title: The Hindu Majority Can't Run India All Alone
description: To the Editor:

title: Fake Cabby Tied to Rapes
description: A man posing as a gypsy-cab driver has been charged with several rapes in Queens over a six-week period, the police said yesterday.

title: BASEBALL;Gooden Alters Delivery And Career
description: In the sterile setting of the Metrodome in Minneapolis one morning last month, Mel Stottlemyre and Dwight Gooden stood in the empty bullpen talking mostly about tinkering with Gooden's delivery, but essentially about salvaging his disappointing season. There were no fans in the dome and no other Yankees on the field. It was pitching coach and pupil.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Corn Prices Post Steep Decline As Dry Weather Aids Planting
description: Corn prices fell sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday as dry weather in the Midwest over the weekend allowed farmers to resume planting crops.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Toys 'R' Us Reports 1.6% Profit Rise
description: Toys "R" Us Inc. reported today that its earnings edged up 1.6 percent in its first quarter on strong sales of dolls, juvenile furniture and video-game hardware.

title: Despite Tensions, Clinton Urges Renewal of China's Trade Status
description: Despite a conflict with China over pirated American computer software, movies and music, President Clinton called today for unconditional renewal of preferential trade status for China, saying the step would be "a vote for America's interests" and "not a referendum on all China's policies."

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Prices Mixed On Treasury Securities
description: Treasury securities turned mixed yesterday, as investors displayed caution ahead of today's meeting of the Federal Reserve's policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee.

title: Safir Warns Civilian Patrols On Avoiding Confrontations
description: Less than two weeks after members of a Hasidic patrol group were arrested in the beating of a black man in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, Police Commissioner Howard Safir met with representatives of patrols from throughout the city yesterday and emphasized that they were not to become involved in physical confrontations.

title: Grants Are Free, Right? Ask Symphony Space
description: O ye of little faith," said the phone message to Joanne Cossa, managing director of Symphony Space. "We've got an N.E.A. challenge grant!" Ms. Cossa and Peter Shavitz, Symphony Space's director of development, had despaired of getting a grant from the National Endowment for the Arts. The Federal Government closed down in December, the endowment had lost 40 percent of its appropriation, three-quarters of its staff had been laid off. Then there had been a decision-delaying blizzard in Washington.

title: COMPANY NEWS;RAYTHEON BUYING ASSETS FROM RUST INTERNATIONAL
description: The Raytheon Company said yesterday that its Raytheon Engineers and Constructors unit would buy the pulp and paper, industrial process engineering and construction assets of Rust International Inc. for $118 million in cash. Rust, based in Birmingham, Ala., is a wholly owned subsidiary of WMX Technologies Inc. Raytheon, based in Lexington, Mass., said that businesses being acquired had annual revenue of about $400 million. Subject to regulatory approval, the purchase is expected to close within two months. Shares of WMX fell 25 cents yesterday, to $35, on the New York Stock Exchange; shares of Raytheon rose 25 cents, to $52.25.

title: North Korea Is Paid for Help on War Dead
description: The United States paid $2 million to North Korea today for its past help in recovering remains of American soldiers killed in the Korean War.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ACCORD IN ORACLE'S LOW-COST NETWORK COMPUTER
description: The Oracle Corporation said yesterday that it had gained support from large high-technology companies -- including Apple Computer, I.B.M., Netscape Communications and Sun Microsystems -- for technical standards involving its planned network computer, a $500 machine that would allow customers without personal computers to surf the Internet. The so-called NC machines are expected to be available this fall. Oracle, based in Redwood City, Calif., is said not to have plans to make the NC's, but would allow other companies do so.

title: Patterns
description: Is Fur Coming Back?

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the suicide of Adm. Jeremy M. Boorda, the Chief of Naval Operations, and the integrity of military awards among members of the armed forces misstated the date of Virgil's "Aeneid" in some copies. It was written in the first century B.C.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;New Internet Search Engine Said to Ease Hunt for Sites
description: As anyone who has gone foraging on the Internet knows, the best way to find anything useful or amusing is to know where you are headed from the outset. Get the precise address, or URL (uniform resource locator), and go directly to the World Wide Web site you want.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about the conductor Spiros Argiris misstated the specialty of Gian Carlo Menotti, the founder of the Spoleto festivals, for which Mr. Argiris was a music director. Mr. Menotti is a composer, not a conductor.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;Grant's Absence Will Hurt Orlando
description: The Orlando Magic hoped things would get better after Sunday's embarrassing loss. Instead, things got worse.

title: Yeltsin's Rival Tries to Temper Communist Party Message
description: In a vivid display of anxiety over President Boris N. Yeltsin's gains in the polls, the Communist candidate, Gennadi A. Zyuganov, implored party members today to tone down their remarks about nationalizing private property.

title: Indonesia Moves Toward Gas-Power Plants
description: JAKARTA  Enron Development Corp. of the United States and Pertamina, the Indonesian state-owned petroleum company, are close to an agreement that will help clear the way for development in Indonesia of large privately owned power plants fueled by natural gas, executives with the companies said.

title: How Nerve Meets Muscle and Begins to Talk
description: FOR the first time, scientists report, they have been able to eavesdrop on a biochemical conversation that occurs during the wiring of nerves to muscles, deciphering a fundamental step in development. The findings may one day help scientists develop new treatments for nerve injuries and neuromuscular diseases like myasthenia gravis.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Ex-Militia Chief Guilty Of Murder in Lebanon
description: Samir Geagea, once Lebanon's most feared Christian militia leader, was convicted today of murdering a rival.

title: Fund Investors Favor Simpler Prospectus
description: Mutual fund investors have responded positively to a proposed shortened and simplified form of the mutual fund prospectus, the basic sales document that lays out the risks and potential rewards of a fund investment, according to a survey of recent fund investors conducted by an industry trade group.

title: Look for Oil Prices to Fall, but Not Gasoline Prices
description: The return of Iraq into the world oil market is expected to push crude oil prices down by $2 to $3 a barrel by the summer, analysts said yesterday.

title: Move to Patent Cancer Gene Is Called Obstacle to Research
description: When Myriad Genetics, a Utah biotechnology company, announced in 1994 that it had found a gene linked with breast cancer, scientists and women's health groups alike hailed the discovery as an important breakthrough.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Sounding Like a Racist Without Feeling Racist
description: One of this week's most gripping television series is a real-life drama from an unexpected source. "America in Black and White," a five-part "Nightline" series (ABC each weeknight at 11:35), asks: What do black and white Americans think about one another? Don't expect calm, diplomatic answers. "I don't need all these hateful people around me," says a black woman who found racial slurs on her doorstep. "I'm better than them."

title: Congress Reflecting Southern Shift to the G.O.P.
description: With the Senate prepared to elect a Mississippian as the next majority leader, both houses of Congress may soon be led by Southern Republicans for the first time, an occurrence that would give symbolic emphasis to the political realignment sweeping the region.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;Sonics in Control of Series As Jazz Strategy Backfires
description: Time didn't stand still, but the Utah Jazz did.

title: B-2's No Longer Grounded
description: The Air Force today ended a 10-day precautionary grounding of B-2 bombers that had been imposed so the planes could be checked for cracks in engine exhaust clamps.

title: Willi Daume, Prominent Figure In German Sports, Is Dead at 82
description: Willi Daume, a longtime German sports official who was instrumental in bringing the Olympic Games back to Germany in 1972, died yesterday in Munich. He would have been 83 on Friday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-10

title: A Good Oil Deal With Iraq
description: Tough-minded American bargaining, unaccustomed realism by Saddam Hussein and six years of steadfastness by the United Nations have produced the first positive diplomatic agreement with Iraq since the end of the Persian Gulf war.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Downsizing That Offers An Upside
description: Milwaukee has the unwelcome distinction of being PBS's favorite case history of economic dysfunction. A few months ago "Frontline" brought home the travails of two of the thousands of workers laid off by Briggs & Stratton, once the city's biggest employer. And tonight it is back with another woman set adrift by Briggs & Stratton and a man who was among the 5,000 workers let go by Chrysler when it "downsized" its Kenosha plant, south of Milwaukee. Both programs grow out of a study begun by the producers Tom Casciato and Kathleen Hughes in 1991.

title: Whitman Steps Cautiously Into 25-Year Legal Battle Over SchoolFinancing
description: The spending gap between New Jersey's poorest and wealthiest school districts has bedeviled every governor from Brendan T. Byrne, who enacted the state's income tax in 1976, to Jim Florio, whose $1.1 billion tax increase to help close the gap in 1990 led to his defeat.

title: By Design;The Tubes Have It
description: One way to wear the currently fashionable long, lean look is the ankle-length tube skirt.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Heir to Build Golf Course
description: Barbara Piasecka Johnson, the heir to the Johnson & Johnson fortune, and the golf star Gary Player will break ground today on construction of a $15 million championship golf course on Mrs. Johnson's estate. In February, Mrs. Johnson received permission from the Princeton Regional Planning Board to convert the 226-acre estate (known as Jasna Polana or "bright meadow") into the 18th club of the Tournament Players Club network, a subsidiary of the P.G.A. Tour. The club is scheduled to open in autumn 1997, said Scott Ferrell, director of marketing for Tournament Players Club at Jasna Polana.

title: Test of Wills in Strike by Barnard Clerical Workers
description: After the sit-in, picketing and demonstrations, after the disruptions at commencement and weeks without paychecks, the 41-day-old strike at Barnard College has left the school's administration and the 150 striking clerical workers badly bruised, but hardly closer to a settlement.

title: Computers Don't Educate. Good Teachers Do.
description: To the Editor:

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Rebels and French Army Clash in Central Africa
description: French troops trying to end an army revolt in the Central African Republic clashed with the rebels today, with casualties on both sides, witnesses said.

title: BASEBALL;Even Toledo Can Rip Tigers
description: Even minor league teams beat up on the Detroit Tigers. Eric Wedge hit two of Toledo's six home runs tonight as the Class AAA Mud Hens routed Detroit by 14-1 in an exhibition game.

title: Computers Don't Educate. Good Teachers Do.
description: To the Editor:

title: Victory for Fairness
description: When a case involving gay rights in Colorado came before the Supreme Court last October, it was clear from the questioning that six of the nine justices were deeply troubled. What bothered them was a voter-approved amendment to the Colorado Constitution that repealed ordinances in three cities protecting homosexuals against discrimination in employment, housing and public accommodations. The amendment also barred the state and every local jurisdiction from adopting or enforcing any such protections in the future.

title: Companies Likely to Seek Federal Court Reviews
description: Companies and their allies cheered the Supreme Court's decision yesterday to set new legal standards for determining whether punitive damages were excessive. But some plaintiffs' lawyers disputed the scope of the decision's effect on product-related cases.

title: Computers Don't Educate. Good Teachers Do.
description: To the Editor:

title: PRO FOOTBALL;No Longer a Raider, and No Longer Miserable
description: It takes only a couple of seconds to see that Patrick Bates is a tall and talented free safety, that he is a big man with a clear and resonant voice. It takes only a couple of minutes to see that Patrick Bates is an intelligent, independent thinker. Independent thinking is everything with Bates.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the Senate Judiciary Committee's approving the nomination of William A. Fletcher for a seat on the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, provided that his mother, Betty B. Fletcher, retire from active duty on the same court, misstated the vote. It was 12 to 6.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Phillips Questioned in Battery Case
description: A prosecutor in Milwaukee questioned Chicago White Sox outfielder TONY PHILLIPS for two hours yesterday and said she had not decided whether to file charges against him for punching a heckling fan last week.

title: Veteran Israeli Hawk Tries Out Wings of a Dove
description: Israel's finest men, Foreign Minister Ehud Barak says in the didactic tone of a guide explaining local fauna to a visitor, are those who lead its security services -- the Mossad, the Shin Bet, the special Army and the police commandos.

title: G.M. Wants China's Trade To Be Favored Permanently
description: The chairman of the General Motors Corporation declared today that the best growth opportunities for the American automobile industry lay in Asia, and he called for the United States to extend full trading privileges to China permanently.

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: Major League Soccer

title: CHRONICLE
description: Academic tributes, Part 1: Once again, the Shapiro twins -- HAROLD T. SHAPIRO, the president of Princeton University, and BERNARD J. SHAPIRO, whose position, principal of McGill University, is the Canadian equivalent of president -- will step up to the podium to receive degrees together. They will receive honorary Doctor of Humane Letters degrees tomorrow at the Yeshiva University commencement at Madison Square Garden.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FPA MEDICAL TO ACQUIRE STERLING HEALTHCARE GROUP
description: FPA Medical Management Inc., a manager of doctor networks in San Diego, said yesterday that it would acquire Sterling Healthcare Group Inc. for about $200 million in stock. Sterling, a manager of physician practices that is based in Coral Gables, Fla., said three weeks ago that it was discussing a merger. The deal values Sterling at about $24.85 a share, based on FPA Medical's closing stock price Friday. Sterling shares rose $1.625 yesterday, to $20.875, in Nasdaq trading; FPA shares were unchanged at $17.75. Under the agreement, each outstanding Sterling common share will be exchanged for 1.4 FPA Medical common shares, subject to adjustment.

title: For Warblers, More Songs Lead to More Extramarital Flings
description: A LESSON from the birds that sing in the spring: if you wish to entice a female away from a committed relationship, you had better have a lot of tunes in your repertoire.

title: Best-Selling Author, but Not at Home
description: The peculiar publishing tale of Noah Gordon ends happily, with millions of devoted readers, wealth and prizes, and gala dinners in his honor.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Trooper Hurt in Crash
description: A state trooper was critically injured yesterday when he crashed his cruiser into a stand of trees while pursuing a stolen motorcycle on the Garden State Parkway. Trooper Francis J. Bellaran suffered broken bones and internal injuries and underwent surgery at Jersey Shore Medical Center in Neptune, said Trooper Al Della Fave, a spokesman for the state police. Northbound traffic on the parkway was delayed for about two hours.

title: Giant Smokestacks To Be Demolished
description: Four towering smokestacks, the most visible monuments to the mining industry that dominated this area of the Idaho Panhandle for a century, are set to tumble on Memorial Day weekend.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Too Hot? Not for Farmers
description: Some people may be wilting in the hot weather, but New Jersey farmers say it could not have come at a more auspicious time. "It's definitely pushing things along quite well," Bob Matarazzo, who raises fruits and vegetables on his farm in Belvidere, said yesterday. Fortunately, he said, the nights have also been warm, preventing the kind of stress that occurs when temperatures drop precipitously after a hot day.

title: THE GAY RIGHTS RULING: THE RULING;GAY RIGHTS LAWS CAN'T BE BANNED, HIGH COURT RULES
description: In a significant victory for gay rights, the Supreme Court today struck down a provision of the Colorado Constitution that not only nullified existing civil rights protections for homosexuals in the state but also barred the passage of new anti-discrimination laws.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Business Side of Game: Camby Gets Agent
description: The last, scant hope has vanished that the N.B.A.-bound MARCUS CAMBY might change his mind and play again for Massachusetts; he has signed with an agent.

title: TV SPORTS;Reporter or Celebrity Pal? Rashad Is Giving Jordan a Free Ride
description: I get the willies when NBC calls on Ahmad Rashad to "report" from the sidelines of National Basketball Association games, notably Chicago Bulls games. Rashad eagerly paints himself as Michael Jordan's up-close and personal reporter, "I just spoke to Michael" being his opening line. The Rashad-Jordan relationship has always seemed too cozy and decidedly unjournalistic.

title: COMPANY NEWS;REPUBLIC ENVIRONMENTAL TO SELL A MAJORITY STAKE
description: Republic Environmental Systems Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell a majority stake to the Alliance Holding Corporation, which is to contribute its Century Surety Group in exchange for 7.5 million new Republic common shares and options to buy 2.1 million more. Republic's chief executive, Michael G. DeGroote, and H. Wayne Huizenga will each invest $5.25 million, receiving one million newly issued common shares apiece and options to buy up to three million more. Republic, a waste cleanup company in Blue Bell, Pa., said it would move its headquarters to Cleveland, where Century is based. Alliance Holding is controlled by a group that includes Joseph E. LoConti, a director of Republic. Mr. Huizenga, chief executive of Republic Industries, does not currently have a stake in Republic Environmental, which was spun off by Republic Industries last year. Republic Environmental shares rose $5.375 yesterday, to $10, in Nasdaq trading.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Programming Deals By Interpublic
description: A recent spate of deals by the Interpublic Group of Companies will continue with what Philip H. Geier Jr., chairman and chief executive, called "a new relationship in the television and Internet programming area," which he said would be announced later this week.

title: Observer;The College Nightmare
description: News from the education front is often the most depressing stuff in the paper, but the present flurry of stories about college admissions is enough to make patriots fear for the future of the nation.

title: Effort to Weaken Bosnian Serb Leader Seems to Have Failed
description: The international campaign to weaken Radovan Karadzic's grip on power, and perhaps even drive the Bosnian Serb leader from office, appears to have ended for now in failure.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;Sampras Is Tops, but Muster Is Favored
description: PETE SAMPRAS, the top-ranked player in the world, who is still seeking success on clay, yesterday was designated the top-seeded player in the French Open, but THOMAS MUSTER, the defending champion, is still the favorite.

title: 264 Needy Graduates Receive Aid for College
description: It was after one of his increasingly violent fights with his mother that Camara Barrett finally made up his mind to leave home. In the last year, Mr. Barrett, 18, has been moving from one youth shelter to another, studying for Scholastic Assessment Tests on subway trains.

title: Pianist, Convalescing, Cancels Bach Concert
description: Joao Carlos Martins, the Brazilian pianist who came to prominence in the late 1960's but whose career has been derailed several times because of injuries, canceled his performance of Bach's "Well-Tempered Clavier" Book I on Sunday evening at Carnegie Hall. A spokesman said Mr. Martins had not yet recovered from surgery on May 16 to remove a benign tumor from his neck.

title: Sports of the Times;The M.V.P. Of Dealing Deserves It
description: HE accepted his most valuable player award yesterday, and Michael Jordan said he was grateful to be recognized as more than the most celebrated scorer in basketball history.

title: Give Prosecutors Right to Appeal Sentencings
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Computers Failures in Air Traffic Control Delay Flights
description: The computer that helps guide high-altitude air traffic in the New York region failed twice last night, delaying hundreds of flights and once again raising questions about the reliability of the air traffic control system.

title: Reservoir of Living Fossils May Lie Below Ice
description: PROBING the glacial depths of Antarctica with radio and seismic waves, scientists have mapped the locations of more than 70 lakes that lie buried under thousands of feet of ice. The largest of these, some 140 miles long and 30 miles wide, is a body of apparently fresh water more than two miles beneath the ice, next to Russia's Vostok research base in East Antarctica.

title: With Dole Soon to Be 'Citizen' Staff Must Rethink Strategy
description: Senator Bob Dole completed his first full-length foray as a soon-to-be ex-Senator today -- a preview, his aides said, of what Mr. Dole might be like as a full-time Presidential candidate. But Mr. Dole's campaign schedule was sparse and cobbled together, as his staff sought to adjust to the candidate's sudden new status, which has forced them to rethink their entire approach.

title: Women Striving To Make It Rain At Law Firms;Bringing in Business is the Best Path to Partnership
description: Back in 1952, Eleanor Engle signed on as shortstop with the minor league Harrisburg Senators for exactly two days. Then, a horrified league commissioner called the contract a travesty and said any club that signed a woman would suffer severe penalties.

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;Barrasso's Return Sparks Penguins
description: Mario Lemieux was on his back, and the Pittsburgh Penguins were on the critical list. Just as quickly, Lemieux got well -- and the Penguins got even.

title: Professor Sokal's Bad Joke
description: When the editors of Social Text accepted an essay purporting to link developments in quantum mechanics with the formulations of postmodern thought, they could not have anticipated that on the day of its publication the author, Alan Sokal, a physicist at New York University, would be announcing in the pages of another journal, Lingua Franca, that the whole thing had been an elaborate hoax.

title: Consumer Stocks Lift The Dow Over 5,700
description: It's the consumer who has turned around the stock market.

title: BASEBALL;Ripken at Third? Maybe
description: It's as much a part of Baltimore as crab cakes and the Inner Harbor: Cal Ripken at shortstop for the Orioles.

title: Let the Tribunal Do Its Job
description: The success of the war crimes tribunal at The Hague is of utmost importance to the future of international law. By the same token, the failure of this court, now conducting its first trial, would be disastrous -- not just for jurisprudence but for the prospect of peace.

title: Top Pataki Official Got Aid From Fund Meant for Inaugural
description: Financial disclosure forms filed with the State Ethics Commission show that a top official in Gov. George E. Pataki's administration received personal travel expenses for months after she took office last year from a fund that had been established solely to finance the Governor's inauguration and transition.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF SAKS FIFTH AVENUE BEGIN TRADING TODAY
description: Saks Fifth Avenue raised $400 million yesterday in an initial public offering of its shares, which are expected to soar when trading begins on the New York Stock Exchange this morning. Saks Holdings Inc., whose largest holder was Investcorp, sold 16 million shares at $25 each, a price analysts expect to increase as investors cash in on its cachet and a booming market for luxury goods. The sale of a 26 percent stake values the entire company at $1.52 billion. At $25, Saks is valued at 57 times its fiscal year 1996 earnings estimate of 44 cents a share, according to the lead underwriter, Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: POLITICS: THE THIRD PARTY;For Backers Of Perot, A Long Day In the Sun
description: Every time Betty Mathys tried to lure a visitor at the Collier County Library over to the card table that she had covered with literature about Ross Perot's nascent Reform Party, she tacked an emphatic "sir" or "ma'am" to her question: "Are you a Florida registered voter?"

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Bryant Becomes a Pitchman Before He Turns Pro
description: He reveres his parents, wants to attend college via the Internet and speaks fluent Italian. He is a lean 6 feet 6 inches, possesses darting, slashing moves to the basket and averaged 31 points a game last season.

title: BASEBALL;Harnisch Is Humbled By Homers In Sixth
description: Pete Harnisch started serving his suspension tonight in an unusual place: the sixth inning.

title: ON PRO BASKETBALL;With Money on Line, Jordan Gets It Done
description: One day after Michael Jordan said he is worth not a penny less than $18 million a year, Shaquille O'Neal scored 26 first-half points and grabbed 11 rebounds to boot. Add those totals together, divide by two years, and what you get is $18.5 million per.

title: Concept of Managed Care Doesn't Need Fixing
description: To the Editor:

title: FILM REVIEW;A Superhero Lethal With Chopsticks
description: If you infused a distant cousin of Columbo with a dash of Jim Carrey, the result might well resemble Harry Griswold (Rick Gianasi), the sad-sack New York police officer who becomes a ludicrous comic superhero in "Sergeant Kabukiman N.Y.P.D."

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Ever Wicked and Witty on the Wing
description: It was a miraculous mesh. Back in the 1950's at the University of Chicago, Elaine May met Mike Nichols. Soon, in acting classes, they started playing around with comedy improvisations. They got so good at beaming into each other that they headed for New York and pitched the act to Jack Rollins, who became their manager. In the "American Masters" special tonight on PBS, "Nichols and May: Take 2," Mr. Rollins recalls being bowled over by their ability for "writing hilarious." And winging it on their feet, yet. Ample evidence, taken from their early television work, is on display this evening.

title: Princeton Is Accused of Fronting For the Turkish Government
description: A group of prominent scholars and writers contends that Princeton University is allowing itself to be used by the Turkish Government as a center for propaganda about Turkey's role in the massacre of a million Armenians during World War I.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the Supreme Court decision striking down an amendment to the Colorado Constitution barring anti-discrimination laws for homosexuals misattributed a statement from the dissenting opinion in some editions. The statement -- that the amendment was an "eminently reasonable" means of preventingthe "piecemeal deterioration of the sexual morality favored by a majority of Coloradans" -- was by Justice Antonin Scalia, who wrote the dissent, not by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, who joined in it.

title: Senators Question Bar Association's Role in Selecting Judges
description: The American Bar Association, which has long played a semi-official role in screening candidates to be Federal judges, found itself on the defensive today as it was pummeled at a Senate hearing over whether it had become too liberal to retain that job.

title: Colorizing the Oreo. Pastel, No Less.
description: Oreo is about to have a dye job. The cookie, the country's most popular, will turn 85 next year, so the style-setters at Nabisco, the company that created the Oreo in 1912, have decided to tint the filling. Like the recent M & M contest to determine a new color for the candies, the choice of a pastel color for Oreo's new filling, to be announced next spring, will be by popular vote. From now through June 15, anyone can vote for a color by calling (888) 328-6736.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Selling Barbie With Milk and Cookies
description: For decades, the Barbie doll sold by Mattel Inc. has had careers from flight attendant to nightclub singer to nurse. Now Barbie is entering the world of advertising with a doll created and named for the award-winning "Got milk?" campaign by the Goodby, Silverstein & Partners unit of the Omnicom Group in San Francisco.

title: At the Nation's Table: Providence, R.I.;A Meat Market Turned Restaurant
description: Rozann DiGiglio Buckner lived out her father's dream by transforming his butcher shop into a restaurant. Joe's Quality Market had been a landmark on Federal Hill, the heart of the Italian quarter, since 1947. "My father didn't look to me to carry out his dream, because I was a daughter," said Mrs. Buckner, 48. Mrs. Buckner, Mr. DiGiglio's only child, started making sauces and other takeout items in the butcher shop in 1976. In 1990, she added tables and served lunch.

title: Poland Keeps Eye on Vote To Its East
description: Outwardly at least, Polish officials say they are not panicked but instead are taking a pragmatic view about the prospect of the Communists' winning the Russian election next month.

title: BASEBALL;Butler Undergoes Surgery
description: Brett Butler could return to the field with the Los Angeles Dodgers next year if he recovers from cancer as expected, Butler's doctor said today after removing a cancerous lymph node from the outfielder's neck.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Lufthansa Narrowed First-Quarter Loss
description: The chief executive of Deutsche Lufthansa A.G., Jurgen Weber, said yesterday that the airline company's first-quarter loss narrowed by 10 percent. The pretax loss in the quarter was 49 million marks ($32 million), compared with 55 million marks in the first quarter of 1995. Lufthansa said that it usually posted a loss in the first quarter of a year.

title: TV Notes;Hail From the Chief
description: When the broadcast networks introduce their fall prime-time schedules to advertisers, as they have been doing in New York this week and last, they haul out every bell and whistle, with eye-popping audio-visual presentations on gigantic screens in a major concert hall or hotel ballroom. NBC went first, on Monday, May 13. The two mini-networks, WB and UPN, followed on Tuesday and Thursday last week. ABC gave its show on Monday, Fox yesterday, and CBS is to make its presentation today, at Carnegie Hall.

title: PLAIN AND SIMPLE;Pasta in a Mediterranean Key
description: This filling one-dish meal with a Mediterranean feeling combines pasta and black beans, swordfish, peppers, olives and orange dressing. Any firm-flesh fish can be used, and if you do not have olive paste, you may substitute olives.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Rival Bid by Swissair For Duty-Free Retailer
description: A unit of Swissair A.G. says it has offered to pay L145 million ($220 million) for the worldwide duty-free retailing business of Allders P.L.C., topping a L130 million offer from BAA P.L.C. Allders, a British retailer, said on Friday that it had agreed to sell the business to BAA, an airport operator, in a transaction that is subject to approval by shareholders in June.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Judge Backs Settlement in Archer Lawsuit
description: A Federal judge gave preliminary approval today to a $45 million settlement of a civil lawsuit accusing the Archer-Daniels-Midland Company and its competitors of fixing prices for an animal feed supplement that speeds muscle growth.

title: GOVERNORS' PLAN TO REFIT MEDICAID STARTS TO ERODE
description: The bipartisan consensus among the nation's governors on Medicaid and welfare, announced with much fanfare in February, appears to be crumbling, reducing chances that the programs will actually be overhauled in this election year.

title: INSIDE
description: A Vote to Repeal Gasoline-Tax Increase

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Waldman Sues Hospital
description: SUZYN WALDMAN, the first woman to announce Yankees games, sued Mount Sinai Hospital and two of its pathologists on Monday for misdiagnosing her as being free of breast cancer.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Crude Oil Prices Hold Steady As Traders Assess Iraq's Return
description: Crude oil prices ended little changed on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday, as the market weighed the impact of an infusion of Iraqi oil.

title: Personal Health
description: IF you are 60 or over, you may not be eating enough protein -- or fiber, calcium, zinc, B vitamins, vitamins A, D, C and E, selenium and carotenoids.

title: Thou Shalt Reduce Salt Intake: True? False? Choose Your Study
description: IT is an article of prevailing dietary faith that when it comes to salt, less is better. The Federal Government recommends that Americans reduce their average salt consumption by a third, to six grams a day, about one and a quarter teaspoons.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Lynam's Contract Extended
description: Coach JIM LYNAM, whose team made an 18-game turnaround this season, received a two-year contract extension yesterday from the Washington Bullets. The new contract will keep Lynam with the team through the 1998-99 season. The Bullets went 39-43 last season after going 21-61 the year before. (AP)

title: COMMENCEMENT;New School Confers Tips And Degrees
description: A second day of record-breaking heat in New York could not dampen the spirits of the 904 graduates at the New School for Social Research's 60th commencement yesterday morning. Their spirits were helped in part by the setting, the cool sanctuary of Riverside Church.

title: Enough Fighting Over Harlem
description: The economically battered community covered by the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone got a scare this week as a fight between Albany and City Hall threatened to scuttle a badly needed redevelopment plan. Now that Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and Gov. George Pataki seem to have settled the dispute, they need to submerge political rivalries and put their full energies to the task at hand.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Concept of Managed Care Doesn't Need Fixing
description: To the Editor:

title: Boy Is Awarded $30.6 Million For Negligence by Maimonides
description: A jury has ordered Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn to pay $30.6 million to a 10-year-old boy left severely retarded and unable to learn to talk by what the jurors found to have been negligent treatment as his mother gave birth.

title: Burmese Foe Of Military Says Backers Are Arrested
description: At least 80 supporters of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, Myanmar's pro-democracy leader, have been detained by authorities in advance of a major meeting of her opposition party planned for this weekend, one of her assistants said today.

title: Shanghai Journal;It's a Lucky Day in May, and Here Come the Brides
description: Upstairs at the Hujiang Beauty Salon, as hairdressers fussed over eight women seated regally before the mirrors and bright lights, two dozen other women waited anxiously on a long puffy sofa, in a various stages of preparation for the big day.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Peter Offers an Apology
description: The former Nebraska defensive tackle CHRISTIAN PETER yesterday acknowledged his drinking problem and apologized to the woman he was accused of grabbing by the throat.

title: Mummy Tells Story of a Sacrifice, Scientists Say
description: Five centuries ago, in the waning years of the Inca empire in Peru, a girl with long black hair and a graceful neck, dressed in fine alpaca wool, knelt on a cold, windswept summit in the Andes. She was in the presence of Inca priests and surrounded by offerings of pottery, coca leaves and golden figurines. As she bent her head, a powerful blow was delivered, cracking her skull above the right eye and causing death by intercranial bleeding -- one more ritual sacrifice of a virgin to the mountain god of Nevada Ampato.

title: POLITICS: POLICY;Drug Users Should Be Denied Welfare Benefits, Dole Says
description: Accusing President Clinton of defending the status quo, Senator Bob Dole today repeated his call for state control of welfare, and said he supported withholding benefits from welfare recipients who use drugs.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Porsche Ads Win At Kelly Awards
description: Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco took top honors, winning three awards including the $100,000 prize for general excellence, at the 15th annual M.P.A. Kelly Awards competition sponsored by the Magazine Publishers of America.

title: John Bernadino, 79, an Enduring Soap Opera Star
description: John Beradino, who played Dr. Steve Hardy on the soap opera "General Hospital" for 33 years, died on Sunday in Los Angeles. He was 79.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;Van Gundy Guaranteed 2 More Years
description: For the last few weeks, there was a hollow ring to the Knicks' insistence that they had Jeff Van Gundy under contract as their head coach; that there was no reason to keep poking around the bushes for another retread or for a bright, young mind with no National Basketball Association experience.

title: The Death of an Admiral
description: Washington bid farewell to Adm. Jeremy Boorda yesterday at the National Cathedral with pomp and pageantry befitting a military hero. Admiral Boorda surely was that, though in ways that could never be measured by the ribbons and medals that apparently led to his suicide last week. As President Clinton said so eloquently at the memorial service, Admiral Boorda brought quiet leadership and a human touch to a troubled Navy. He inspired men and women sailors by his concern for their welfare and the example of his own career as the first enlisted man to become the Chief of Naval Operations.

title: Blue Cross to Combine New Jersey and Delaware Operations
description: In the latest example of a fast-growing national trend, Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey and its Delaware counterpart announced yesterday that they would combine operations by the end of August.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;Eighteen-Point Lead Not Enough for Magic
description: In a city that fully believes a championship parade permit is nothing more than paperwork with a date to be filled in, the Chicago Bulls took a loud, convincing step toward the National Basketball Association finals tonight.

title: COMPANY NEWS;WYNDHAM HOTEL STOCK RISES AS 2.9 MILLION SHARES TRADE
description: The shares of the Wyndham Hotel Corporation, an operator of upscale hotels based in Dallas, moved sharply higher yesterday after the company began trading. Late Monday 3.65 million shares of the company were sold for $16 each, up from the originally planned 3.35 million shares at $15 each. The stock ended yesterday at $22.625 on the New York Stock Exchange as 2.9 million shares were traded. The company plans to use proceeds of the offering to repay debt, acquire a hotel and provide working capital.

title: Fat Substitute May Compromise Eye Health
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Drug Raids Net 14 Students
description: For six months, prosecutors say, a baby-faced undercover officer would make connections and buy drugs from teen-agers and adults across Hunterdon County. Yesterday, police officers swept through the county's schools and arrested 14 students. They also arrested 10 adults at their homes and workplaces.

title: Massage Finds New Believers
description: SUE SMITH, a 42-year-old marathon runner from Irvington, N.Y., would not consider tackling serious mileage without a body-limbering sports massage as part of her regimen. "It's great before and after you run," she said. "It makes you nice and loose."

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Russian Fund Agrees to Settle S.E.C. Charges
description: A Russian investment fund has agreed to settle charges by the Securities and Exchange Commission that it offered Americans unregistered investments, the commission said today.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Clerk Guilty in Postal Fraud
description: A former clerk at the Hackensack Post Office who had been accused of embezzling $108,000 pleaded guilty yesterday to tampering with postage meter records.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;A Stormy and Amorous Feminist of the 1500's
description: The Burgermeister's Daughter Scandal in a 16th-Century German Town By Steven Ozment Illustrated. 227 pages. St. Martin's Press. $23.95.

title: A LOSS OF CONFIDENCE: A special report.;Questions of Privacy Roil Arena of Psychotherapy
description: Dr. Arnold Holzman, a psychologist in Hamden, Conn., thought he was making progress with his patient, an upper-level manager in his 50's, who came into therapy only after his wife threatened to leave him if he did not learn to control his temper.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday about Frances L. Loeb, who served for years as New York City's liaison to the diplomatic corps, misstated the location of the home of her grandfather, Adolph Lewisohn, where she was married in 1926. It was on Fifth Avenue, not Park Avenue. The obituary also misstated the number of Mrs. Loeb's great-grandchildren. She had 22, not more than 30.

title: About New York;Life's Act II, Wherein Angelo Sings
description: ANGELO TRUGLIO daydreamed of being an actor when he was growing up in Canarsie. But the closest he came to the stage as an adult was at a grammar school auditorium in Patchogue, L.I., where he presided as principal.

title: AT LUNCH WITH: Julie Salamon;Growing Up in Ohio In the Shadow Of the Holocaust
description: FOR a moment, Julie Salamon seemed to be speaking in contradictions.

title: CHRONICLE
description: M. SCOTT PECK, the best-selling author of "The Road Less Traveled" and other books fusing religion and psychology, is getting the birthday gift of his dreams tonight: a lullaby sung by CARLY SIMON.

title: U.N. Official Urges a Rebuilding Role for Peacekeeping Forces
description: A Pakistani diplomat who led a United Nations mission in Rwanda says traditional peacekeeping operations should be revised because they often fail to meet the most urgent needs of countries recovering from civil war.

title: POLITICS: FINANCES;In Dole Campaign, The Party's Money Serves as a Lifeline
description: A year ago, when Senator Bob Dole decided to accept Federal tax money to help finance a tough primary campaign, he agreed to one major condition: that he would spend no more than $37 million.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;What's the Beef With the Jets? Baxter Reports Late to Camp
description: After weeks of hauling cattle to market and worrying about the price of beef, Brad Baxter returned to the Jets today and was worrying about hauling the pigskin.

title: Toys 'R' Us Is Expecting Antitrust Case by U.S.
description: Toys "R" Us, the country's largest toy retailer, said yesterday that it expected that the Federal Trade Commission would bring antitrust charges against it today, and that the company would vigorously contest any action challenging its buying practices.

title: Ethnic Dorms at Cornell Teach Wrong Lesson
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the continuation of an article in the Metro Section yesterday about the Flushing Town Hall was omitted in some editions. Readers wishing copies of the correct page may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or telephone (212) 556-1992.

title: House, 301 to 108, Approves Rollback in the Gasoline Tax
description: Correction Appended

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Camden to Enforce Curfew
description: For about four decades, Camden's curfew for residents under 18 has largely been ignored. Now, city officials hope that enforcing the curfew between 10 P.M. and 6 A.M. on weekdays (with an 11 P.M. start on weekends) will help them cut down on juvenile crime.

title: Ethnic Dorms at Cornell Teach Wrong Lesson
description: To the Editor:

title: President Eulogizes an Admiral With 'a Big Heart,' a Vision and a DeepSense of Honor
description: As his friends and colleagues in the Navy struggled to understand what had driven Adm. Jeremy M. Boorda to suicide, President Clinton today remembered the Navy's highest ranking officer as a devoted sailor whose "deep sense of honor" should never have been questioned.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Shoveling Away Oil Spill
description: The beach at Ventnor remained closed yesterday while workers continued to clean up oil that washed up on shore after an oil tanker spill earlier this month in Delaware Bay. Officials of the State Department of Environmental Protection said they were hopeful that the beach could reopen today. By yesterday, most of the oily sand that marred beaches from Cape May to Atlantic City had been removed, but 120 workers were continuing to shovel in Ocean City, said Loretta O'Donnell, a spokeswoman for the D.E.P.

title: THEATER REVIEW;A Simply Charming Couple Headed for a Dead End
description: You have probably encountered, or at least overheard, a couple like Ruth and Jack, perhaps while waiting in line to see a foreign movie on the Upper West Side. If so, you have probably also experienced a sincere and dangerous urge to strangle them.

title: ON BASEBALL;Counting the Ways To Lose a No-Hitter
description: Several years ago, Fran Healy, one of the Mets' broadcasters, was talking on the air about no-hitters. More no-hitters, he said, are broken up in the ninth inning. A viewer disagreed and called the ball park to pass on a message to Healy. More no-hitters are broken up, the caller suggested, in the first inning.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: FILM REVIEW;Young, Alienated and Looking for the Exit From Nowheresville
description: Take an unhappy young man from a town in the middle of nowhere, add a motorcycle, a pistol and a young woman with reason to flee. Stir with an aspiring film maker and what results, all too often, is the movie equivalent of a prepackaged meal in a jiffy: bland and undistinguished.

title: TV Notes;  Dialing for Discord
description: Paul Reiser said he was not worried about viewers accepting his idea of introducing discord into the previously happy marriage of the Buchmans on NBC's "Mad About You," and viewers backed him up with enthusiasm on Sunday night. The season finale of that comedy drew a 15 rating and 26 share, the show's second-highest rating and highest share of the season. (Each rating point represents 959,000 homes; the share is the percentage of all homes watching television at a given hour.)

title: Sabatini Withdraws From French Open
description: Gabriela Sabatini, a six-time semifinalist at the French Open, withdrew today from this year's tournament, which begins Monday.

title: Don't Make a Deal With Philip Morris
description: SKILLMAN, N.J.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS;German Banker's Remark Lifts The Dollar to a 16-Month High
description: The dollar rose to a 16-month high against the mark yesterday after a German central bank official suggested that a weaker mark could help the nation's sagging economy.

title: Food Notes
description: Lutece at Home

title: France's Army Keeps Grip in African Ex-Colonies
description: Week in and week out for years, French sentries have manned the lookout towers at a military base here, and French soldiers have drilled behind high concrete walls topped with barbed wire.

title: Vibrant Streets Yield to Dark
description: The busiest intersection in downtown Flushing was pitched into darkness last night, turning the streets into eerie corridors where stores and restaurants fell silent while a battery of police officers shrilled their whistles as they tried to unsnarl a seemingly endless stream of traffic.

title: Time Is Changing The Model S.& L.;Home Savings Pushes Ahead Into Full-Service Banking
description: The bright California sun filters through the stained-glass windows, creating a reverential mood in this cavernous edifice. Decorated with elaborate mosaics, bronze statues and lots of marble, it is a stolid temple of thrift -- one of many erected by Home Savings of America in affluent suburbs like this one, outside Los Angeles, in the years after World War II.

title: A Defensive McCaughey Ross On Offensive Against Accuser
description: First came reports of Gov. George E. Pataki's displeasure with her. Then came more open slights like the removal of her security detail. And now, Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross is facing problems much closer to home -- a former housekeeper has accused her of harassment and of neglecting to pay some taxes on her wages.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;The networks try to sell advertisers after a bad ratings season, but cable is nipping at their heels.
description: AS the broadcast television networks begin their annual spring ritual of selling commercial time in advance of the coming season, they are scrambling -- despite a generally strong advertising market -- to match the record-breaking success they enjoyed a year ago.

title: Olympics and Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: THE AD CAMPAIGN;Democrats and 'American Values'
description: This is a new 30-second advertisement that the Democratic National Committee began broadcasting in selected markets nationwide last night

title: Fox Adjusts Fall Lineup, Aiming at Young Adults
description: Trying to spread its core audience of young-adult viewers to more nights, Fox announced yesterday that it would move "The X-Files," its most popular show, to anchor a new night, while bringing back 12 series and adding 5 new ones to its fall prime-time schedule.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Courting of Teams Restricted by N.F.L.
description: Commissioner Paul Tagliabue said today at the meeting of National Football League owners that he was enacting a ban until the end of the regular season on any team's engaging in discussions with another city that might be looking to land a franchise.

title: Inquiry in Failure Of Air Traffic Computer
description: The air traffic control computer that failed twice on Monday night, delaying hundreds of flights around the New York area, was running normally again today as technicians tried to determine what had gone wrong.

title: TV Notes;Program Note
description: The cable network C-Span has started a weekend evening program block called "About Books," from 9 to midnight on Saturdays and 9 to 11 on Sundays. It will include authors speaking or reading from their work at public appearances, interviews with people in publishing, news about books and literary criticism, book reviews and occasional live call-in discussions with authors. This Sunday at 9, Tom Wolfe will be seen speaking at Brown University on "The End of the Century and the Spirit of the Age." LAWRIE MIFFLIN

title: German Economy Shrinks; It's a Recession
description: Unusually cold winter in the first quarter of 1996 drove Germany into economists' formal definition of recession, and the Government said today there were few signs of imminent recovery.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: New Product to Improve Satellite Navigation
description: Harnessing military-navigation capabilities of the United States and Russia, a Silicon Valley company today plans to introduce the first satellite receiver for business use that can utilize the signals of both nations' global-positioning satellite networks.

title: 2 Big Retailers Exceed Earnings Estimates
description: Two of the nation's largest retailers, Dayton Hudson and Kmart, reported better-than-expected financial results yesterday for the first fiscal quarter.

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;Devils' Coach Plans to Be All Talk
description: The Devils have been working since the last day of the regular season to avoid the pitfalls of this past season so as not to repeat the travesty of failing to make the playoffs. Since lack of communication was the biggest obstacle that denied the team the opportunity to defend the Stanley Cup, that is the area the Devils have made a priority.

title: War Crimes Prosecutor Vents Frustrations
description: The chief prosecutor at the United Nations war crimes tribunal said today that NATO's refusal to order its troops to arrest Bosnian Serb leaders accused of atrocities threatens to undermine the fragile peace in the Balkans.

title: Television's Shifting Marketplace
description: Failing to fetch its price, Viacom Inc. has dropped its plan to sell its 75 percent stake in the Spelling Entertainment Group, the producer of television shows like "Melrose Place," above. Article, page. D3. (Fox Broadcasting Company)

title: U.S. Budget Surplus Set Record in April
description: The United States budget surplus in April widened 45.6 percent from a year earlier as strong tax receipts flooded Federal coffers, Treasury Department figures showed today.
