title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ITT CORP., New York, the hotel, gaming and entertainment concern, said its Caesars World Casinos subsidiary had won approval to build and operate an 80,000-square-foot riverboat casino that plans to cruise the Ohio River in Harrison County, Ind.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Pretax Profit Up 7.2% At Marks & Spencer
description: The British food and clothing retailer Marks & Spencer reported yesterday that pretax profits rose 7.2 percent in the year that ended on March 31. It cited a surprising improvement in its Brooks Brothers clothing unit in the United States. Marks & Spencer's pretax profits from continuing operations were L993.7 million ($1.5 billion) compared with L926.6 million a year earlier. Revenues for the year grew to L7.23 billion ($10.9 billion) from L6.8 billion the previous year.

title: PERFORMANCE ART REVIEW;Saxophones as the Partners In Acts of Impish Invention
description: Dan Froot is both imaginative and unclassifiable. He served as writer, choreographer, stage director and composer for "Blow Molding," the program of new short works he presented on Sunday night at Performance Space 122. He appeared onstage as a dancer, a storyteller and an actor who could be puckish one moment and poignant the next. He also played a mean saxophone.

title: Woolworth to Shut Jewelry Store Chain
description: The Woolworth Corporation said yesterday that it would close its Accessory Lady chain and take a charge against its second-quarter earnings, as the retailer moves to shed some specialty units.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TANDY TO CLOSE 2 INCREDIBLE UNIVERSE STORES
description: The Tandy Corporation said yesterday that it would close two of its 16 Incredible Universe stores and eliminate 320 jobs as part of a streamlining that would result in a pretax charge of $25.5 million in the second quarter. The company, which is based in Fort Worth, said Incredible Universe stores in Potomac Mills, Va., and Charlotte, N.C., would be closed immediately because they had not generated enough revenue. After the announcement, Tandy's stock rose $1.125, to $58.125, on the New York Stock Exchange. Tandy also sells consumer electronics through 6,800 Radio Shack and 101 Computer City stores.

title: Sports of The Times;Before Doc, There Was Super Chief
description: DWIGHT GOODEN had only a remote shot at matching Johnny Vander Meer, the only major league pitcher ever to throw consecutive no-hitters, with the 1938 Cincinnati Reds. That chance vanished in the first inning last night when Jason Giambi of Oakland slugged a double.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Famine Aid to North Korea
description: Near-famine conditions in North Korea pose a moral and political challenge to the United States and its allies. America's goal should be to feed the hungry without reinforcing the already dangerous military capacities of an erratic, belligerent and poorly understood regime.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Engineers Get Overtime Pay
description: A Federal appeals court ruling handed down Monday could lead thousands of state workers to claim that they were improperly denied overtime pay, a lawyer representing 37 New Jersey Department of Transportation engineers said yesterday.

title: FILM REVIEW;Mission Accepted: Tom Cruise as Superhero
description: Having held the patent for more than a decade on Hollywood's notion of a yuppie conquerer with a gold-plated conscience, Tom Cruise has found the perfect superhero character on which to graft his breathlessly gung-ho screen personality. In "Mission: Impossible," a sleek, whooshingly entertaining update of the vintage television series, he plays Ethan Hunt, an American spy who dashes frantically around the globe risking his life to keep a computerized list of secret agents from falling into the wrong hands.

title: A Catch to Inflation-Indexed Bond: Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: In New Challenge to Peace Plan, Bosnia May Pull Out of Election
description: In a new challenge to the American-brokered peace in the former Yugoslavia, the Bosnian Government threatened today to withdraw from elections unless voting rules were drastically changed and NATO arrested the most prominent Serbian war criminals.

title: Palestinian Ordered Held for 15 Days
description: A Palestinian human rights activist who was arrested on Saturday was ordered today to be held for 15 days, the Palestinian Authority's Attorney General said.

title: Wine Talk
description: TWENTY years ago this week, an Englishman staged a competitive tasting of French and American wines in Paris, and the Americans won.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Simple Pensions Planned For Small Businesses Small businesses could more easily offer retirement savings plans for their 36 million workers under a bill that House Republicans plan to approve today.

title: G.O.P. Bill Would Extend Pensions in Small Business
description: House Republicans plan to pass legislation on Wednesday that would make it easier for small businesses to offer retirement savings plans for their 36 million workers. And in a break from decades of pension policy, the bill would let owners reap tax benefits for themselves even if their workers do not participate.

title: A Shareholder-Rights Leader Is Leaving Calpers
description: The California Public Employees Retirement System, the largest and most prominent player in the shareholder-rights movement, is about to lose its voice for a while.

title: Julius Marmur, 70, Biochemist Who Helped to Unravel D.N.A
description: Dr. Julius Marmur, a biochemist and geneticist whose early D.N.A. research helped unravel the mysteries of heredity, died on Monday at the Jack D. Weiler Hospital of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx. He was 70 and lived in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: Angry Stockholders Confront Leaders of Troubled Utility
description: With the company's stock price tumbling and three of its four nuclear power plants in Connecticut shut down because of safety concerns, Northeast Utilities officials today faced a banquet room full of shareholders who questioned whether management could lead the utility out of trouble.

title: At the Nation's Table: Davenport, Calif.;Cookery Lived On Long After Pottery
description: When Bruce and Marcia McDougal were scouting out a site for their pottery school and gallery, they settled in Davenport, Calif. (population 200), on Highway 1 between San Francisco and Monterey.

title: COMPANY NEWS;APPLE NAMES LANDI AS EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT
description: Apple Computer Inc. yesterday named Marco Landi, an Apple executive in Europe, to the post of executive vice president and chief operating officer. Mr. Landi, 52, is currently president of Apple Computer Europe, Middle East and Africa. He plans to assume his new position on June 1, overseeing four newly formed product divisions, worldwide sales, marketing and manufacturing operations. Analysts said Mr. Landi would be a welcome addition to the management team because of his solid reputation in Europe and his familiarity with the company and its woes.

title: A New Approach to Punitive Damages
description: Taking a swipe at excessive jury awards, the Supreme Court this week overturned a $2 million punitive-damage award to an Alabama man who bought a new BMW with a touched-up paint job that was undisclosed at the time of sale. In the process, the Court set some vague but reasonable "guideposts" for courts to use in determining when an award of punitive damages is so "grossly excessive" as to violate the constitutional requirement of due process of law.

title: COMPANY NEWS;A CONSORTIUM AND HOUSTON INDUSTRIES BUY LIGHT
description: Houston Industries said yesterday that it and an international consortium of investors paid $2 billion for a majority interest in Light, the electricity distribution system serving Rio de Janeiro, in a privatization by the Brazilian Government. Other members of the consortium include Electricite de France; the AES Corporation of Arlington, Va.; the CSN Brazilian industrial group, and Bndes, a major Brazilian financial institution.

title: School Board Vote Tally Lags, Despite Computers
description: The hand-counting of paper ballots cast in New York City's school board races has always been a tortured affair that dragged on for weeks. But this year was supposed to be different: for the first time, the Board of Elections is employing computers to help tabulate the results of the May 7 elections.

title: Reluctantly, Arab Parties Favor Peres
description: Israel's 850,000 Arab citizens can recite ample reasons for displeasure with the Government of Shimon Peres, including the bombardment of Arab civilians in neighboring Lebanon, the cutoff of West Bank Arabs from their jobs in Israel, and the crackdown on Arab settlements suspected of harboring terrorists.

title: Pataki Aide Used Inaugural Funds
description: A top Pataki administration official received personal travel expenses for months after she took office last year from a fund that had been established solely to finance the Governor's inauguration and transition, state records show.

title: Real Estate;A generic drug maker spends $5 million on renovation of a 100-year-old plant in  Philadelphia.
description: AFTER the Global Pharmaceutical Corporation, a publicly held producer of generic drugs, acquired Richlyn Laboratories Inc., it considered moving into a new plant, but given the Federal regulatory hurdles to getting a new plant certified, it chose instead a $5 million renovation of Richlyn's century-old manufacturing plant here.

title: Heat Forces Halting of Power to 40% of Queens
description: Caught off guard by an early heat wave and hampered by a transformer fire, Consolidated Edison was forced yesterday to cut off electricity to 115,000 customers, mostly in Queens, for more than five hours because New York City's power system was severely overtaxed.

title: Mary Perot Nichols, 69, Who Led WNYC, Dies
description: Mary Perot Nichols, the strong-willed former head of the television and radio stations operated by New York City, and a former columnist and city editor of The Village Voice, died yesterday in the hospice of the Cabrini Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 69.

title: Journal;A Gay-Rights Victory Muffled
description: It's hard to say which was more moving: Anthony Kennedy's majority opinion in Romer v. Evans or the joy in my friend's voice as he cited it over the phone. My friend, a gay man and a Democrat, couldn't quite get over the fact that a conservative judge, a Reagan appointee to the nation's highest court, had pronounced a gay-bashing amendment passed by Colorado voters illegal. So illegal, Justice Kennedy wrote, that "the amendment seems inexplicable by anything but animus toward the class that it affects."

title: A Harvard Dean Retires
description: The dean of Harvard Medical School is stepping down, saying it will take a younger leader to guide the school through the changes rocking health care and medicine today.

title: New Lines of Light, Cool Clothing Protect Against the Sun
description: FOR years, people who worry about skin cancer have been covering themselves with sunscreen. Now, another tactic is gaining favor: special clothing that promises to cut down on harmful rays.

title: TV Notes;'Murder One,' Contd.
description: Steven Bochco, the creator and executive producer of "Murder One," admitted that with three episodes left in this season's run, "we were dead in the water."

title: Freemen Break Off Talks With Mediator And Begin Patrols
description: The Freemen sent out armed patrols around their farmhouse today for the first time in the 58-day standoff after talks with a mediator broke up in anger.

title: Jet Had Problems in Flight Before Crash
description: Just hours before Valujet Flight 592 crashed into the swampy muck, Pamela S. Hettinger was sitting on the same DC-9, looking out her window high above the Everglades and imagining a similar fate, because she thought the plane was in trouble.

title: Victor/Victoria' Snubs the Tonys, Again
description: Victor/Victoria" will be the only new musical not to be represented by a production number on this year's awards telecast, Tony officials announced yesterday.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BOATING;Baird Named Cup Skipper
description: PACT 2000, the America's Cup yachting syndicate being sponsored by the New York Yacht Club, has chosen ED BAIRD to be its next cup skipper. Baird, a 38-year-old sailor from St. Petersburg, Fla., was coach for New Zealand's Black Magic team in its successful bid to win the America's Cup from San Diego last year.

title: ABC's Disney Report Was a Legitimate Story
description: To the Editor:

title: Too Hot Out of the Kitchen;Pie Man Told World About His Pizza, Not His Past
description: Nobody ever doubted that Andrew Bellucci was a pie man. In fact, he was a pizza fanatic's dream. Possessed with the desire to create the perfect pizza pie, obsessed with the history and lore of pizza, and blessed with the hustler's gift of gab, he seemed like a man destined to inspire a pizza renaissance.

title: Family of Dr. King Cedes Tomb Control
description: The family of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. has agreed to turn over management of the civil rights leader's tomb to the National Park Service.

title: Fugitive Mafia Boss Arrested By the Italian Police in Sicily
description: In the four years since Italy's top anti-Mafia prosecutor was killed by a bomb, his successors have kept the Sicilian Mafia on the run. Underworld bosses, lieutenants and ordinary soldiers have been tracked down, arrested and put in the dock in numerous trials now clogging the Italian courts.

title: Few Links in Church Fires, Panel Is Told
description: A rash of fires at black churches across the South is motivated overwhelmingly by hate and prejudice but apparently does not stem from a regional or national conspiracy, the Government's top civil-rights enforcer said today.

title: No Headline
description: We will not participate in these elections unless the rules change. The danger of these elections, if they are not done correctly, is that they will verify ethnic cleansing."

title: Digital Cell Phone vs. Pacemaker
description: People with heart pacemakers should be aware that carrying a digital cellular telephone could cause the devices to shut off, causing the heart rate to speed up, a researcher says.

title: Africa Ferry Sinks; 500 Believed Dead
description: Some 500 passengers were believed to have drowned yesterday when a ferry on Lake Victoria in Africa hit a rock and capsized.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CHARTER COMMUNICATIONS TO ACQUIRE OVERLOOK
description: Charter Communications International Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Overlook Communications International Inc., a closely held long-distance provider, for about 40 percent of its stock, worth about $55 million. The merger would give Overlook access to the Latin American market through Charter's satellite links and would allow Charter to expand its domestic Internet-access business to Atlanta, said David Olson, chairman and chief executive of Charter. Charter's shares jumped $2.75, to $9.25, in Nasdaq trading. The shares, 92 percent of which are held by insiders, have risen from a low of 37.5 cents in December, when Mr. Olson and other investors activated the shell company by purchasing an Internet service provider. Overlook buys long-distance service in bulk.

title: After 'L.A. Law,' a Pursuit of Passions for Food and Life
description: IT was about two hours before dinner, and Michael Tucker, the actor best known for his eight-year run as Stuart Markowitz on the television series "L.A. Law," carefully peeled enough garlic to offend an entire courtroom. Then, at methodical medium speed, he chopped it. Not a shred flew onto the floor.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PSC TO ACQUIRE SPECTRA-PHYSICS SCANNING SYSTEMS
description: PSC Inc., a maker of laser-based bar-code scanners, agreed yesterday to buy Spectra-Physics Scanning Systems Inc. from Spectra-Physics A.B. of Sweden for about $140 million. PSC, based in Webster, N.Y., said Spectra-Physics Scanning manufactures bar-code scanners used in stores. Spectra, based in Eugene, Ore., anticipates sales of about $115 million in 1996. Shares of PSC were up $1.61, at $11.75, yesterday in Nasdaq trading.

title: No U.S. Arms Role in Bosnia, Holbrooke Says
description: Former Assistant Secretary of State Richard C. Holbrooke testified today that the Clinton Administration did nothing wrong -- in fact, did nothing at all -- with respect to Iranian arms shipments to Bosnia's Muslims in 1994 and 1995.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Further Inquiry on Phillips
description: A decision on whether to charge Chicago White Sox outfielder TONY PHILLIPS for punching a heckler is being delayed, the Milwaukee District Attorney's office said yesterday. If a decision isn't made by Thursday, it won't come until late next week because some of the participants in the case have previous commitments, a source close to the investigation said.

title: S.I. Becomes Too Small For 2 Feuding Leaders
description: The three Staten Island officials used to be, if not the best of friends, then at least friendly. Each year they broke soda bread together and sang Irish songs when one of them held a St. Patrick's Day party, an affair that would draw Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Executive Changes
description: JALATE LTD., Los Angeles, which designs and markets women's apparel, named Frederick A. Findley vice president for finance and chief financial officer, succeeding Phillip Levin, who resigned in January but has remained with the company on an interim basis.

title: Labor Leader Abandons Re-election Campaign
description: Jan Pierce, the leader of the communications workers' union in New York and a powerful force in Democratic politics, informed union officials this week that he was abandoning his re-election campaign after concluding that he was going to lose.

title: Drug Court Seeks End to Revolving-Door Justice
description: It was a morning like any other earlier this month in the downtown Brooklyn court some lawyers call The Mill, one of two Kings County courtrooms dedicated to speeding drug cases through the system. Sleepy-eyed but dressed neatly in jeans and a striped shirt, Ada Jones stood stoically before Judge Muriel Hubsher, who had already handed out seven sentences in half an hour, calling "Next!" after each. Ms. Jones, 30, had pleaded guilty to trying to sell drugs to an undercover police officer in March. In her purse at the time, the police said, was a crack pipe.

title: Small, Low-Fare Airlines Shaken by Valujet Crash
description: Mark W. McDonald has weathered almost every storm imaginable since he started Nations Air last year. The small airline, which has served Boston, Philadelphia and Pittsburgh, was shut down for a week last July by the Federal Aviation Administration for a paperwork violation. A few months earlier, a bank pulled its commitment at the last minute to lend him $1 million. A company that leased him a plane took it back in the middle of the night because of a mix-up.

title: Strike Shuts Eiffel Tower
description: The Eiffel Tower has been closed to visitors until further notice because of a strike by the staff protesting the withdrawal of car parking rights for night workers.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Krieg Is a Bear for a Year
description: The Chicago Bears signed quarterback DAVE KRIEG to a one-year, free-agent contract. Terms of the agreement for the 16-year National Football League veteran were not released. (AP)

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Bonds Mixed As Fed Keeps Policy Steady
description: Treasury prices were mixed in light trading yesterday as Federal Reserve policy makers left interest rates unchanged, as expected.

title: Triple Flip
description: A SERIES of cookbooks called "1,2,3 Dinners," introduced by Clarkson N. Potter, is a truly clever concept, particularly for cooks in a hurry who want good, simple recipes that use fresh foods.

title: Mud City Journal;129 Dairy Cows, and a Way of Life, on the Block
description: New York had the Sotheby's auction of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis' pearls and other personal belongings last month. Vermont had its equivalent today in Mud City, at the auction of the Lepine sisters' 129 prized Jersey cows.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Rise On Big Board and the Amex
description: Open positions of short sales continued their record-setting pace on the New York Stock Exchange in the latest reporting period, reaching a record level for the fourth consecutive month. On the American Stock Exchange, short interest was at its highest level since its record high in October 1994.

title: Atlanta 1996: Olympic Profile;For Czech Athlete, Payoff Is on Field
description: They told the building manager they wanted the apartment for only six months, but Robert Zmelik and his fiancee were fighting a losing battle. They were from the former Czechoslovakia, the manager said, without employment. They could be drug dealers. Their application was turned down.

title: Bangladesh Generals Held
description: At last five generals, including the dismissed army chief, have been placed under house arrest in Bangladesh for their involvement in a failed revolt, military sources said today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ACER PLANS AN INTERNET-READY PERSONAL COMPUTER
description: Acer Inc. plans to introduce an Internet-ready personal computer with a disk drive for less than $500, the first computer at that price with storage capacity, a spokeswoman said today in Taiwan. The inclusion of a storage drive would set Acer's machine apart from network computers planned by I.B.M., Apple Computer Inc. and others, which plan to market their computers as inexpensive hook-ups to the World Wide Web. The Acer Basic is to be equipped with the Intel Corporation's Pentium processor, four megabytes of random access memory and the Iomega Corporation's 100 megabyte zip drive, the spokeswoman said. Acer, the seventh-largest personal computer maker, plans to introduce the PC next month.

title: E. R. Feinberg, 64, Psychiatrist Who Treated Violent Children
description: Dr. E. Richard Feinberg, a psychiatrist who specialized in treating delinquent and violent children, died on Monday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 64 and lived in Mount Vernon, N.Y.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: CHRONICLE
description: If you can't beat them, join them. PHILIPPE PAUL CEZANNE, a great-grandson of the French painter, disapproves of the way his ancestor's work has been used for all sorts of commercial products, so he is planning to market his own line of wares.

title: Business Travel;The Atlanta airport is being all spruced up for this summer's Olympics, and beyond.
description: HARTSFIELD INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT in Atlanta and Delta Air Lines, its biggest tenant, are spending millions on improvements before the Summer Olympics -- changes that will also make life easier for travelers long after the Olympics have gone.

title: Corrections
description: A chart of financial indicators at the bottom of the Business Digest yesterday misstated Monday's close of the Dow Jones industrial average in some editions. It closed up 61.32 points, at 5,748.82.

title: KITCHEN BOOKSHELF;For Summer, Outdoor and Indoor Adventures in Cooking
description: A PLATE of grilled sausage, pasta tossed with a handful of freshly picked herbs, lush berries and the unfettered enjoyment of messy barbecue and lobster whet summer appetites in the pages of some new cookbooks. In the best of these books, there is an emphasis on simplicity and vibrant flavors that is perfect for summer. GRILL ITALIAN by Clifford A. Wright (Macmillan, $25) hooks the cook in the introduction. Who would not want to light the grill after reading the author's description of an alfresco dinner in Sicily? The recipes are generally on the simple side, relying on fresh ingredients and herbs for flavor rather than on heavy marinades and bastings. I loved the frequent trick of alternating items on skewers with cubes of oil-soaked bread or that of sprinkling on bread crumbs to add texture. Sausages, onions and oranges skewered together offer a delightful change of pace.

title: California Leads Revival Of Teaching by Phonics
description: In the 1980's, California was among the first states to adopt a philosophy that children could learn to read, faster and better if encouraged to experiment -- to guess at words and invent their own spellings and grammar.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TOSCO LOWERS OFFER FOR CIRCLE K AFTER VERDICT
description: The Tosco Corporation said yesterday that it would lower its offer for the Circle K Corporation after a Texas jury awarded $18.2 million to former managers at the convenience store chain who claimed racial discrimination. Tosco, an oil refining and marketing company, said it would reduce the amount it would pay Circle K's largest shareholder, Investcorp S.A., to cover damages in pending legal cases. A spokesman for Tosco said the decision would not affect the amount Circle K's public shareholders would receive. In February, Tosco agreed to buy Circle K for $427.5 million in cash, 6.5 million common shares and the assumption of $190 million in debt. Shares of Tosco rose $1.125 yesterday, to $51.25.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Arizona Coach Retires
description: JERRY KINDALL, who coached Arizona baseball teams to 861 victories and three National Collegiate Athletic Association titles in 24 seasons, announced his retirement yesterday. Kindall, 60, and his Arizona program has turned out 43 all-Americans and sent more than 200 players into the pros, including KENNY LOFTON, TERRY FRANCONA, J. T. SNOW and SCOTT ERICKSON. (AP)

title: Study Ordered On Ingredients In Laxatives
description: The Government told manufacturers today to study the long-term safety of five common laxative ingredients after animal research raised questions of a possible, though unproved, threat of cancer in cases of chronic use.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;The Greenest Lawmakers
description: Correction Appended

title: U.S. Warns 3 Nations Against Sale of Soviet Missile Technology
description: Worried by information that China was seeking to buy SS-18 strategic missile technology from Russia or Ukraine, the United States has recently warned all three countries against such a sale, Defense Secretary William J. Perry said today.

title: The Chain of Events That Ended in a Blackout
description: On an ordinary day in May, a fire at a single transformer in a Con Edison substation in Queens would not have led to a forced blackout of 115,000 customers. But yesterday was no ordinary day.

title: COMPANY NEWS;NEWS OF A STOCK SPLIT SENDS SHARES OF ZOLTEK HIGHER
description: The shares of the Zoltek Companies rose 9 percent yesterday after the company said it would split its stock for the second time in a year. Shares of the maker of carbon fiber climbed $7.25, to $84, after rising $2.25 on Monday. The 2-for-1 split would be payable on June 17 to holders of record on June 3. Last July, Zoltek, which is based in St. Louis, split its shares 3 for 2. Lightweight carbon fibers are used to reinforce materials in industrial products like airplane brake pads. Analysts predicted that carbon fibers would be used increasingly in consumer products like fishing rods and golf-club shafts as production and selling costs fall through new technology.

title: Japanese Stocks Lower
description: apanese stocks traded lower here today. At the close of trading, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 133.74 points, about six-tenths of 1 percent, to 21,958.00. On Tuesday, the index gained 112.74.

title: Market Place;A food distributor rides an Internet stake to new heights.
description: A YEAR ago, the Diana Corporation was a sleepy distributor of meat and seafood, with a small telecommunications business. The company, which is listed on the Big Board, had last paid a dividend in 1988, and its shares traded for less than $5. It was losing money, and no Wall Street analysts followed the stock.

title: JAZZ REVIEW;Five Saxophones and Drums in a Night of Improvisation
description: The Saxemble celebrated the release of its new album, "Saxemble" (Qwest), on Monday night with a house-rocking show at Sweet Basil that owed its conception to the New York jazz scene of the early 1980's. The group, five saxophonists and a drummer, drew on pop forms, one-chord vamps and rhythm-and-blues horn figures to create an intense emotional environment, one that at times had the sort of passion you find in religious music.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;MCA Acquires Equity Stake In TV Producer Big in Comedies
description: MCA Inc. acquired an equity interest yesterday in Brillstein-Grey Entertainment, a television and motion picture production company, for a price in excess of $100 million.

title: COLLEGE LACROSSE REPORT
description: What Rule?

title: BASEBALL;Bernie Williams Goes on D.L.
description: Bernie Williams, the center fielder of the present, was placed on the 15-day disabled list with a stiff left calf muscle yesterday and Yankees Manager Joe Torre said that Ruben Rivera, the center fielder of the future, could be summoned from Class AAA Columbus.

title: Haft Is Awarded Family Business
description: Herbert Haft, patriarch of the feuding Washington real estate family, was awarded control today of its business empire.

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;Hold the Octopus: Roy Halts Red Wings
description: There are times when Patrick Roy is so superb that his own teammates find themselves standing back in awe. This was one of those nights.

description: Stocks retreated yesterday in a decline led by oil and computer companies.

title: The British Strike Back At Europe On Beef Ban
description: His back up because Britain's European partners refused on Monday to approve even a slight easing of the ban on beef exports, Prime Minister John Major announced a policy of "noncooperation" today, aimed at bringing all important European Union business to a standstill.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Honda Group Yearly Pretax Profit Up 22%
description: The Honda Motor Company said today that group pretax profit rose 22 percent in the latest fiscal year, aided by increased sales of recreational vehicles in Japan and motorcycles in Asia.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: Sass & Associates, Annapolis, Md., was awarded three accounts with combined billings estimated at $4 million to $5 million: Ryka Inc., King of Prussia, Pa., a women's footwear marketer; KPR Sports International, King of Prussia, for the Yukon footwear brand, and Myer-Emco, Washington, a consumer electronics specialty-store chain. Cole & Weber, Seattle, a unit of WPP Group, was awarded two accounts with combined billings estimated at $3 million: K2 Corp., Vashon Island, Wash., for K2 skis, and Turner Classic Movies, Atlanta, a unit of Turner Broadcasting System.

title: Fire Investigation Focuses on 5 Teen-Agers
description: Investigators today questioned five teen-age campers suspected of accidentally starting a fire in the Pike National Forest that scorched 10,000 acres, officials said.

title: Telephone Rackets Disrupting Service to Caribbean Nations
description: The list of items that divide the many islands of the Caribbean is long: language, culture, race and religion, for starters. Any index of unifying features, on the other hand, is bound to be brief, embracing little more than a common tropical climate and, for nearly 40 years, the 809 area code.

title: Safir Backed in Reporter's Ouster
description: Faced with a flurry of criticism from news organizations, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday reaffirmed his commissioners' right to exclude individual reporters from group news briefings if their coverage was deemed too critical.

title: 500 Are Believed Dead as Tanzania Ferry Sinks in Lake Victoria
description: Some 500 passengers, many of them teen-agers, were believed to have drowned today when a ferry hit a rock and capsized in Lake Victoria, state-run radio and local journalists said.

title: Foreign Affairs;Calm in Palestine
description: Traveling through the West Bank two weeks ago, I drove from Hebron to Bethlehem, through Ramallah and up to Nablus. What you see is a region racked by soaring unemployment among Palestinian youths and an economy sapped by the security measures imposed by Israel and Yasir Arafat. What you see are growing Israeli settlements around Jerusalem and new Israeli roads dissecting the West Bank more than ever. What you see is a grim picture -- and I couldn't be more optimistic.

title: BASEBALL;Victory Is Sweet, if Short on Suspense, for Gooden
description: Ever since the wonderful scene last Tuesday, when Dwight Gooden retired Paul Sorrento on a pop-up to Derek Jeter to miraculously no-hit the Mariners and catapult himself into one of the biggest sports stories in the country, the anticipation about his next start had grown and grown. Could Gooden do it again? Could he match Johnny Vander Meer by pitching another no-hitter?

title: Making New Opera Unstylishly Melodic
description: Since opening in 1879, the Opera de Monte Carlo has presented the world premieres of no fewer than 78 operas, including works by Puccini, Massenet, Ravel and Faure, yet never anything by an American composer. In that sense, then, Lowell Liebermann's "Picture of Dorian Gray," which had its first performance here in May, has already won itself a place in local record books.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about an oil spill from a tanker that has fouled beaches in southern New Jersey misstated the number of birds affected by the spill. According to state environmental protection officials, the number is about 1,300, not 6,500.

description: The war over who sets accounting standards is heating up, with the Financial Accounting Foundation, the parent organization of the Financial Accounting Standards Board, rejecting yesterday a major change proposed by Arthur Levitt Jr., the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

description: JAMAAL MAGLOIRE, a 6-foot-11-inch center who became the most heavily recruited high school player in Canada, is going to Kentucky.

description: After failing to fetch the price it sought, Viacom Inc. said yesterday that it had dropped its plan to sell its 75 percent stake in the Spelling Entertainment Group, the television production and distribution company whose programs include "Beverly Hills 90210" and "Melrose Place."

description: A 50-foot robot arm on the space shuttle Endeavour reached out today and plucked from orbit a small satellite carrying the results of a test of cheaper space structures.

title: Car Bomb Kills 16 in India
description: A car bomb killed at least 16 people in New Delhi today, and a Kashmiri militant group took responsibility. The bomb caused a fire in a building that contained at least 30 stores and a dancing school.

title: Report Warns of Security Threats Posed by Computer Hackers
description: Government investigators warned today that computer hackers posed a serious and growing threat to national security, with the Pentagon suffering possibly up to 250,000 "attacks" on its computers last year.

description: Acting on their own, or with at least the tacit consent of doctors or families, one of five nurses in intensive-care units reports deliberately hastening a patient's death, according to a national survey.

title: Jail Term for Judge For Taking Bribes
description: A Manhattan Housing Court judge convicted of accepting bribes from landlords, tenants and lawyers was sentenced in State Supreme Court yesterday to between two and a half and seven and a half years in prison.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bass Profit Up 9.9% On Pub and Hotel Gains
description: Bass P.L.C., a British brewer and Holiday Inn owner, said yesterday that its profit rose 9.9 percent in the six months that ended on April 13 on strong gains at the hotel chain and tavern business. Pretax profit for the first half of the fiscal year rose to L289 million ($437.9 million) from L263 million a year earlier. Sales rose to L2.521 billion from L2.24 billion. The gain was greater than expected.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Fanfare, Colors and the Almighty 12 Tones
description: There has never been a shortage of first-rate performers to maintain the standard classical repertory. Compelling performances of new works are rarer and ultimately more important: old masterworks are indestructible, but new music needs involving advocacy. The valuable American Composers Orchestra, which has championed contemporary music with consistent excellence, was in top form on Sunday afternoon for a concert at Carnegie Hall in which the dynamic German conductor Ingo Metzmacher was making his New York debut.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AGREEMENT TO SELL J. BAKER SHOE UNIT IS ENDED
description: An agreement by J. Baker Inc. to sell a division, the Shoe Corporation of America, to Bain Capital and the division's management has been terminated, J. Baker said yesterday. It did not say why the sale had been canceled. In April, J. Baker had said it planned to sell the division to concentrate on other retail units, but terms were not disclosed. The company said yesterday that it would continue to try to sell the business, which runs leased footwear departments in 500 specialty and department stores. The shares of J. Baker, which is based in Canton, Mass., fell 62.5 cents yesterday, to $8.875, in Nasdaq trading.

description: SOFIA and her deadly whip battled Chaos, while Jill Valentine annihilated Raccoon City zombies. Smoke swirled; laser lights pierced the fog. An Italian plumber sailed through the skies.

title: Executive Changes
description: ANHEUSER-BUSCH COS., St. Louis, said it had named Randolph Baker to succeed its chief financial officer, Jerry Ritter, who will retire at the end of the year. Mr. Baker was vice president for corporate planning; Mr. Ritter will serve as a consultant to the company once he retires.

description: IT was a day of heavy-duty sitting and reclining. Call it the Stickley Olympics.

title: Bob Dole on the Road
description: Bob Dole: He's tanned, he's rested and he's reading from the Teleprompter. "Too often President Clinton's statements are like the tornadoes in the movie 'Twister' -- it looks like a lot is happening but in reality it's all just special effects," he tells a group of Wisconsin Republicans, speaking slowly, making eye contact, keeping to the script.

title: Economic Scene;The Czechs are doing well, with luck and without Slovakia.
description: WORN down by the long, hard road to capitalism, Poland and Hungary have elected Communist leaders -- politicians with decent haircuts and tailored suits, but the children of Lenin, nonetheless. Meanwhile, unemployment in the Czech Republic is running at just 3 percent, its largely privatized economy is widely expected to post a second consecutive year of 5 percent growth in 1996 and the conservative Vaclav Klaus -- in the recent words of Margaret Thatcher, "my other favorite prime minister" -- seems a shoo-in for re-election next week.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Senators Back Beach Aid
description: In an effort to head off a policy change proposed by the Clinton Administration, United States Senators Bill Bradley and Frank Lautenberg, both Democrats, introduced a bill yesterday that would require the Army Corps of Engineers to continue to carry out beach restoration work, giving priority to projects that previously received Federal funds.

title: Currents;A Bedstead Of Your Dreams
description: SLEEPER sofas, Murphy beds, Dad's recliner: convertible furniture generally emphasizes practicality over style. Happily, Patrick Gallagher, a decorator in Stonington, Conn., has designed a convertible bed, above, that accommodates the mind as well as the body. The centerpiece of Mr. Gallagher's new line of home furnishings is the Quai Voltaire bed. It features a half-dozen removable mahogany posts, whose three-piece, twist-on construction allows it to morph into the bed of your dreams -- minimalist pallet, simple four-poster or a campaign-style lair with enough filmy fabric and gilt finials to please even Napoleon. The bed, which is handmade by Connecticut artisans, is available in queen ($4,900), full ($4,700) and twin sizes ($4,500). It can be ordered from Patrick Gallagher at (860) 535-1330.

title: Preki Helps Wiz Edge MetroStars
description: Preki scored on a header with three minutes to play tonight, helping the Kansas City Wiz break a four-game losing streak with a 2-1 victory over the MetroStars.

description: The Whitman administration's latest proposal for financing schools does not comply with a State Supreme Court order aimed at achieving parity between New Jersey's richest and poorest districts, the Educational Law Center contended in documents filed with the court yesterday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HITACHI SEEN CANCELING PLAN TO RAISE OUTPUT OF CHIPS
description: Hitachi Ltd. of Japan will abandon plans to increase production of computer chips with 16 megabits of dynamic random access memory, or D-RAM, because of an oversupply on the global market, The Nihon Keizai, Japan's premier financial newspaper, reported today. The company had planned to increase production to 15 million chips a year by the end of 1996 from 9 million. The price of a 16-megabit D-RAM chip, the most powerful memory chip widely in use, is expected to fall to 2,000 yen, or about $19, in June, about a third of the price at the start of the year, the newspaper said.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasury Prices Jump In Light Day
description: Treasury prices rose sharply yesterday, but light trading exaggerated the gains.

description: A driver who attacked a woman over a fender bender, forcing her to jump to her death off a bridge, was sentenced today to 16 to 40 years in prison.

description: President Clinton mounted a broad defense of his foreign policy yesterday, arguing that in military deployments in Haiti and Bosnia and in his fight for free trade, he had chosen the unpopular course and left America better off for it.

description: A dozen Division II colleges from Massachusetts, New York and Connecticut found a solution yesterday to a common problem.

description: Survivors from a ferry that sank in Lake Victoria on Tuesday said today that the boat was heavily overloaded with passengers and listing to one side before it capsized, taking hundreds of high school students and other travelers to their deaths inside the flooded hull.

description: The Lojack Corporation in Dedham, Mass., which manufactures an electronic tracking system that helps in the recovery of stolen vehicles, has named Greenberg Seronick & Partners in Boston to handle its account, which had been handled in-house. Billings were estimated at $6 million. The decision came after a two-month review that began with 15 agencies and had been narrowed to Greenberg Seronick and the Boston and Stamford, Conn., offices of North Castle Partners.

description: President Clinton accused Republicans today of cluttering up a proposal to increase the minimum wage with a provision he said would promote sweatshops. He called their proposal "a giant fraud on the American people" and said he would veto it if it reached him.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Agencies use zippy Dr. Seuss-style rhymes and comics to sell Ford Escorts and Mercury Tracers.
description: THE agencies helping to introduce two redesigned small cars for the Ford Motor Company are borrowing techniques from children's books and comic strips to convince buyers the cars are more than mere "econoboxes."

description: In droves, television stars are making the leap into movies. For many of them it's been more like falling off a cliff.

title: Donations to Charities Rose 11% Last Year, Report Says
description: Buoyed by a stronger economy, charitable donations jumped nearly 11 percent last year to $143.9 billion, the biggest increase since 1986, according to a report released yesterday. After inflation, the real increase was 7.8 percent, also the largest gain in a decade.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;India Bus Bomb Kills 14 As Kashmir Vote Nears
description: A powerful bomb killed 14 people and wounded 33 on a bus today in the northwestern state of Rajasthan, the day before the nearby strife-torn state of Jammu and Kashmir was to vote in elections.

title: In New Guide, U.S. Retreats On Contracts For Minorities
description: Inching toward an overhaul of Federal affirmative action programs, the Clinton Administration today issued tentative guidelines that would scale back the ability of Federal agencies to set aside contracts for minority-owned companies.

title: Hoffenberg Gets A Delay Again
description: Sentencing for Steven Hoffenberg, the jailed financier, has been put off once again, and is now planned for September.

title: Most School Districts Approve Budgets in Nassau and Suffolk
description: Residents of Nassau and Suffolk counties approved 113 school budgets totaling nearly $4.5 billion on Tuesday and rejected 13 other budgets. It was the first time that all 126 school districts on the Island held elections on the same day.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: CIT Group Holdings Inc., Livingston, N.J., is selling $100 million of medium-term notes due in 2001 through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The medium-term notes are priced at 99.845 to yield 6.737 percent. The issue is rated Aa3 by Moody's Investors Service, A+ by Standard & Poor's and AA- by Duff & Phelps.

title: Vote Canceled on Dole's Bill For a Costly Missile Defense
description: In a political retreat, House Republicans have canceled a vote set for Thursday on a bill demanding a national anti-missile defense -- an important element of Bob Dole's Presidential campaign -- after the Congressional Budget Office said the system could cost $60 billion, 12 times what the Republicans had said.

title: School Cafeterias: As Clean as Restaurants
description: New York City public schools, which serve some 130 million meals a year to children, keep their cafeterias about as safe and clean as restaurant kitchens, the city's Department of Health said yesterday. "What we found was pretty comparable to what we see in restaurants," a department spokesman said. A nine-month inspection by the Health Department covering 1,047 school cafeterias in all five boroughs was prompted by allegations a year ago that rancid beef, turkey and chicken had been delivered to some cafeterias. A spokesman for Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew said the findings show that most schools were doing a good job.

description: Astronauts aboard the space shuttle Endeavour released a lopsided satellite today to test whether small spacecraft can fly straight using their weight and Earth's magnetic field rather than steering jets.

description: The Yankees could field a team in a disabled list league.

I. Joes, through warehouse clubs that offer steep discounts.

title: Tax Revenue Falls Short Of Prediction
description: The Whitman administration acknowledged today that over the next 14 months, the state would collect about $300 million less in tax revenue than anticipated. Such a shortfall would make it difficult for legislators to restore many of the budget cuts proposed by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Japan Seeks to Spur Trading on Exchange
description: Finance Minister Wataru Kubo of Japan announced the creation yesterday of a group to stimulate stock trading on the Tokyo exchange. "We are concerned that the Tokyo Stock Exchange is losing competitiveness compared to the New York and London stock markets," Mr. Kubo said at a news conference.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Granada to Retain Meridien Hotel Chain
description: The Granada Group said yesterday that it had finished appraising the hotel assets it acquired with its takeover of Forte P.L.C. and had decided to retain the Meridien chain for now. Granada will sell the Exclusive chain of 17 hotels independently valued by Christie's at about L910 million ($1.4 billion).

title: President Would Sign Legislation Striking at Homosexual Marriages
description: The White House said today that if Congress passed a bill to deny Federal recognition to same-sex marriages, President Clinton would sign it, although such unions are not yet legal in any state. The announcement, intended to remove any potential controversy with Republicans over a divisive social issue, infuriated gay rights groups.

title: Paper Product Subpoenas
description: Five companies that sell toilet tissue and paper towels to schools, hospitals and other institutions said today that they had received Federal grand jury subpoenas seeking documents in connection with an antitrust investigation. Kimberly-Clark, James River, Fort Howard, Chesapeake and Georgia-Pacific said they had received the subpoenas on Monday. The companies said they would cooperate.

So did Michael Romano, an owner of the Union Square Cafe, and Patrick Clark, the executive chef at Tavern on the Green. About 80,000 other CUNY graduates sent letters to Albany.

But now, ornamental plasterers like Ken Wildes are again creating these heavenly spirits and their accouterments -- acanthus leaves, flowers, bows, harps and lovebirds.
