description: As the United States and Israel grow ever more vocal in accusing Iran of trying to disrupt the quest for Middle East peace, the Iranian Government is responding by accusing them of making Iran a scapegoat for their own failures in the region.

title: COMPANY NEWS;WATKINS-JOHNSON STOCK FALLS ON LOWER PROFIT OUTLOOK
description: The stock of the Watkins-Johnson Company fell 14 percent yesterday after the company, a maker of computer chip manufacturing equipment and electronic products, said its earnings for the second quarter and the full year would not meet expectations on Wall Street. The concern, based in Palo Alto, Calif., cited lower-than-expected orders and requests by customers to extend delivery times. It noted that demand for chips had slowed and that prices for some popular chips had fallen sharply. As a result, the company said that shipments for the second half of 1996 were likely to be below those of the first six months and that it would have to cut costs. The stock fell by $5.125, to $29.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CABLETRON TO BUY NETWORK EXPRESS FOR $116 MILLION
description: Cabletron Systems Inc., a maker of computer networking equipment, agreed yesterday to acquire Network Express Inc., a provider of high-speed computer network switches, in a stock swap valued at more than $116 million. Cabletron Systems, which is based in Rochester, N.H., said it would exchange 0.1388 common share for each of Network Express's 10.7 million shares outstanding. Based on Cabletron's closing stock price on Tuesday, the deal values the stock of Network Express at $10.95 a share, below its close of $11.75 on Tuesday. Investors responded yesterday by pushing Network Express stock down $2, to $10.25, in Nasdaq trading. Cabletron's stock was down 62.5 cents, at $78.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. Network Express is based in Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;News Worsens For the Magic: No Confidence And No Grant
description: Does confidence just vanish or can it be forcibly removed? The distinction followed the Orlando Magic home, two losses into the Eastern Conference finals against the Chicago Bulls that could easily have been even and yet may already be slipping away.

title: Market Place;Valujet's fate is hard to predict, but many see revival by year-end.
description: HISTORY has shown that predicting an airline's future can be tricky. Some analysts recommended the stock of Continental and America West a few days before they filed for bankruptcy protection. Predictions a few years ago of the imminent demise of Trans World Airlines have been replaced by recent talk of a turnaround.

title: ATLANTA 1996 -- Olympic Profile;A Weight Lifter Prepares for Act II
description: It was nearly eight years ago that Naim Suleymanoglu -- you can call him Pocket Hercules -- was celebrating his first (but not his last) Olympic gold medal.

title: Protest Leads Crew To Rethink a Plan
description: Hundreds of parents kept their children home from a Brooklyn elementary school yesterday for the second consecutive day to protest a plan by Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew to move the seventh grade out of a troubled junior high school and into their elementary school building.

title: COMPANY NEWS;NEW WORLD COMMUNICATIONS TO SELL 2 STATIONS
description: NBC agreed yesterday to acquire two television stations, in San Diego and in Birmingham, Ala., from New World Communications Group Inc. for $425 million. NBC, which is owned by the General Electric Company, will buy KNSD in San Diego and WVTM in Birmingham, both of which are NBC network affiliates. In addition to the $425 million, NBC will provide an undisclosed amount of working capital. After the sale, New World, which is based in Atlanta, will operate 10 television stations, all of which will be affiliated with the News Corporation's Fox network. New World expects pretax earnings of about $225 million from the sale. Its shares rose 68.75 cents yesterday, to $17.4375, in Nasdaq trading.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Oil Prices Surge After a Report Showing Low U.S. Inventories
description: Crude oil prices surged yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange after a report showed that United States inventories fell to 19-year lows last week, heightening concern that rising demand around the world would continue to keep supplies tight.

title: Japanese Stocks Lower
description: Japanese stocks ended lower here today. The benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 233.92 points -- just over 1 percent -- at 21,724.08. On Wednesday, the Nikkei index lost 133.74 points.

title: These Culture Wars . . . They're Serious Stuff;A Service Rendered?
description: To the Editor:

title: Exhibits Aflutter At the Bronx Zoo;Butterfly Tent Will Allow Visitors To Mingle With Winged Residents
description: People go to the Bronx Zoo to ogle more than 4,000 treasures of the animal kingdom, including 4 polar bears, 6 elephants, a 22-foot-long python and 15 snow leopards, one of which is thought to be pregnant.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Dole to March in Clifton
description: Bob Dole will make his first visit to New Jersey since he became the presumptive Republican Presidential nominee, his campaign announced yesterday.

title: Iconoclastic Weekly Grabs Attention on Right
description: Can you guess which national magazine last week ridiculed Bob Dole's efforts to "woo" women voters, comparing him to "a tired roue whose pick-up lines keep falling flat"?

title: COMPANY NEWS;CANADIAN OPERATIONS OF PRUDENTIAL TO CHANGE HANDS
description: The London Life Insurance Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Canadian branch operations of the Prudential Insurance Company of America for about $100 million (Canadian), or $73 million (U.S.). London Life will acquire Prudential's Canadian life insurance, group life and health, pension, annuity and mutual fund businesses, which have total assets of $4.2 billion (Canadian). London Life, a financial services concern based in London, Ontario, will have assets of $19.4 billion (Canadian) after the transaction.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SHAREHOLDERS APPROVE INCO'S DEAL WITH DIAMOND FIELDS
description: Inco Ltd.'s $3.1 billion takeover of Diamond Fields Resources Inc. was approved by shareholders of both companies yesterday, despite a lawsuit pending against Diamond Fields. Edward Mercaldo, executive vice president and chief financial officer of Diamond Fields, a mining company based in Vancouver, British Columbia, said he expected the deal to close next Wednesday. He called the suit, which was filed against Diamond Fields by the Exdiam Corporation of Texas, "nothing but a nuisance." The suit, filed on May 14 in state court in Dallas, contends that Exdiam, a small company once controlled by a Diamond Fields executive, had a right to participate in the company's Voisey's Bay discovery in Canada, one of the world's largest deposits of nickel. Inco is a Toronto-based mining company.

title: Essay;'Ish' vs. Issues
description: What if Bill Clinton's blatant intervention in the Israeli election on the side of the left wing's Shimon Peres backfires? What if the right wing's Bibi Netanyahu -- to the consternation of the media and most leaders of the Jewish community in America -- brings off an upset?

title: Moonface Bear Is Dead at 35; Led a Tribal Uprising in '93
description: Moonface Bear, a Golden Hill Paugussett Indian who led a faction of that Connecticut tribe in an armed standoff with state officials in 1993, becoming for a time a symbol of American Indian defiance of authority, died on Tuesday in a hospital in Norwich. He was 35.

title: Heinz Buys Mareblu Tuna
description: The H. J. Heinz Company has bought the Mareblu brand of canned tuna from Kraft General Foods, a unit of Philip Morris. Terms were not disclosed. The Mareblu brand is sold exclusively in Italy, a country that accounts for 25 percent of tuna sales in Europe, Heinz said.

title: Case to Settle Charges on Exports to Libya
description: The Case Corporation has agreed to pay $2 million to settle criminal charges that it violated customs laws by exporting construction and irrigation equipment to Libya.

title: Top Professionals In Layoffs Steered To Temporary Jobs
description: America's largest job-finding company for laid-off white-collar workers has reached an agreement to channel such workers -- particularly managers, engineers, accountants, lawyers, bankers and the like -- into temporary work when it cannot place them in permanent, well-paying jobs.

title: AT HOME WITH: Jon Krakauer;Back From Everest, Haunted
description: At sea level in the verdant tangle of a Seattle spring, Jon Krakauer is sorting through things he brought back from the top of the world: summit rocks, pictures that will always haunt, the moon gear needed to walk at an elevation known as the Death Zone.

title: Burmese Police Said to Detain 90 Supporters Of Democracy
description: The Burmese military reportedly seized 10 more opposition politicians on Wednesday in a continuing crackdown intended to scuttle a meeting sponsored by the country's leading dissident, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi.

title: With Gasoline Prices Steady, Some Foresee Slide
description: With Americans preparing to hit the road for the Memorial Day weekend, it appears that gasoline prices are stabilizing and the prospect for lower prices is improving as suppliers begin to rebuild their very low inventories.

title: TENNIS;Seles Manages to Pass Emotional Test on Clay
description: Playing her first match on red clay since she was stabbed three years ago at a clay-court event in Germany, Monica Seles put her sore shoulder and wounded psyche to the test yesterday in Madrid and came away encouraged.

title: E. J. Gurney, 82, Senator Who Backed Nixon
description: Edward J. Gurney, the Florida Senator who became President Richard M. Nixon's staunchest supporter on the Watergate committee only to see his own incandescent political career turn to ashes over corruption charges of which he was later acquitted, died on May 14 in a hospital in Winter Park, Fla. He was 82.

title: New Stars and Series In CBS's Fall Lineup
description: Counting heavily on expensive star power, some of it lined up back to back, CBS yesterday announced a fall schedule introducing 10 new series, more than any other network.

title: Report Criticizes Port Authority
description: Reiterating what New York City officials have been saying all along about the Port Authority, a report commissioned by the city says that the authority mismanages several of its operations and wastes millions of dollars each year through excessive overhead.

title: Appeals Court Lets Insiders Keep Profit
description: A few days can make a big difference when it comes to filing a lawsuit. And because of that, former insiders at the Tristar Corporation will not have to repay profits to the company on sales of its stock.

title: Seymour Knox 3d, 70, N.H.L. Team Owner
description: Seymour H. Knox 3d, who along with his brother founded the Buffalo Sabres and served as principal owners of the National Hockey League team, died today. He was 70.

title: County Vote Sets Up Olympics Showdown
description: Saying values are more important than the Olympic torch, county leaders here passed a measure condemning homosexuality that is identical to one that prompted officials to reroute the torch around a Georgia county.

title: Shifting Campaign Strategy to Tax Cutting, Dole Meets With Forbes
description: Bob Dole met today with Steve Forbes, his former primary opponent, as part of Mr. Dole's effort to move closer to the tax-cutting economics that he has spurned most of his political career but now may need to revive his Presidential candidacy.

title: Health Inspectors Find Most School Cafeterias Clean and Their FoodSafe
description: New York City public schools, which serve some 130 million meals a year to children, keep their cafeterias about as safe and clean as restaurant kitchens, the city's Department of Health said yesterday.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Bankers Trust To Acquire Wolfensohn
description: In search of investment-banking skills and a gold-plated reputation, the Bankers Trust New York Corporation said yesterday that it would buy Wolfensohn & Company, a Wall Street firm that specializes in advising large companies on mergers and acquisitions. The purchase price was not disclosed.

title: China's Fickle Rivers: Dry Farms, Needy Industry Bring a Water Crisis
description: The one time this spring that there was actually enough water in the Yellow River to flow all the way to its mouth on the Bohai Sea, the peasants in this village of brick and mud homes were not allowed to use it.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FTP SOFTWARE CUTS PRICE FOR FIREFOX COMMUNICATIONS
description: FTP Software Inc., which agreed to acquire Firefox Communications Inc. in January, said yesterday that it had reduced the price it would pay to $60 million, 28 percent less than the amount originally negotiated. FTP Software's chief executive, David Zirkle, said that slower growth in the markets served by Firefox had prompted the companies to lower the price. The shares of both companies, which produce computer software, fell yesterday in Nasdaq trading. The shares of FTP Software, which is based in North Andover, Mass., lost $1.875, to $11.75, while the stock of Firefox, which is based in San Jose, Calif., fell $2, to $9.25.

title: Domino Effect Left Queens In the Dark
description: A blackout that left 115,000 Queens homes without power Tuesday night was caused by an extraordinary string of mechanical failures that eventually incapacitated four of the seven electrical routes into the northeastern section of the borough, officials at Consolidated Edison said yesterday.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Nintendo Profit Surges
description: The Nintendo Company, a leading Japanese maker of video game machines, said yesterday that its earnings surged 44 percent in the year ended on March 31, and it attributed some of the gains to the flattened exchange value of the yen. Nintendo earned 59.87 billion yen ($560 million) in the latest year, compared with 41.66 billion yen the previous year. The profit gain came despite a 15 percent drop in sales to 354.15 billion yen ($3.31 billion) from 415.68 billion yen. (AP)

title: Peres Is Winning the Hearts Of the Non-Violent Students
description: The rally began exactly on schedule when a cluster of bodyguards ushered Prime Minister Shimon Peres into the gym, to a deafening shriek from several hundred high school students gathered there.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Trade Organization Formed by Agencies
description: More than 40 agencies that specialize in advertising aimed at Spanish-speaking consumers have formed a trade organization named the Association of Hispanic Advertising Agencies.

title: POP REVIEW;Orderly Plan: Steal Widely And Cleverly
description: Round silvery reflectors, 99 of them, were hanging in a grid behind Stereolab when the six-member band performed on Monday night at a sold-out Irving Plaza. Orderly, artificial, vaguely futuristic and comfortably tacky, the backdrop matched every aspect of the music but one: its built-in exhilaration.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Killer Sleepwalkers? Scary Squid? That's News?
description: Here's a crime epidemic waiting to happen: People who kill in their sleep. That was the subject of a recent, heavily hyped, two-part "Fox News Investigative Report: The Sleeping Killer." Even the reporter on the story admitted that sleepwalking murderers are not the cause of overcrowded prisons. The point of this so-called news report actually came in the introduction, when the anchor said with a straight face, "Sounds like 'The X-Files' tonight, doesn't it?" The report did echo the plot of the show that had just ended on Fox. What better way for local news to piggyback on the success of an entertainment hit?

title: G.O.P. Submits New Bill to Revamp Welfare and Medicaid
description: Republican leaders of Congress kicked off a new effort to overhaul welfare and Medicaid today by introducing legislation to meet some of President Clinton's objections to their earlier proposals, but members of both parties said the process would probably end in a Presidential veto.

title: U.S. Topples Italian Water Polo Champs
description: The United States water polo team withstood a late rally by Italy and beat the defending Olympic and world champions, 11-10, tonight in the United States Open.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Surgery for Saberhagen
description: Pitcher BRET SABERHAGEN will undergo reconstructive surgery on his right shoulder next week, the Colorado Rockies said yesterday. The surgery will be performed May 28 in New York by DAVID ALTCHEK, the Mets' team physician, who performed arthroscopic surgery on the same shoulder last October.

title: Mall Is Backed for Pennsylvania Ave.
description: A year after a two-block section of Pennsylvania Avenue was closed to protect the White House, the National Park Service recommended today that the street be turned into a pedestrian mall.

title: Currents;Room-in-a-Box
description: SOME companies try to entice young consumers with painfully hip commercials. Decorating Den is appealing to Gen-X wallets. The Maryland-based company, home decorating's answer to Avon since 1969, is offering six living-room ensembles-to-go, priced from $3,800 to $7,800, in styles from frankly formal to beach bungalow.

title: Summer Travel Boom Expected, Despite Hitches
description: Against a backdrop of high gasoline prices, a spring that seemed more like autumn and unanswered questions about the crash of a Valujet airplane earlier this month, the summer travel season kicks off this weekend, almost a month before the official start of summer.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;House Moves to Prevent Use of Journalists as Spies
description: The Central Intelligence Agency would be prohibited from using journalists as spies under a House proposal passed overwhelmingly today. But the C.I.A. could still use its own agents in the guise of journalists.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Business Digest yesterday, referring to a Market Place column about the stock of the Diana Corporation and the company's ownership of an 80 percent stake in the Sattel Communications Company, misstated the details of a stock sale by Sattel Technologies. As the column reported, Sattel Technologies recently reduced its stake in Sattel Communications to 5 percent from 20 percent, selling the 15 percent stake to the management of Sattel Communications; no insiders in either company sold stock in Diana.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Courtalds Profit Falls
description: The British chemical company Courtaulds P.L.C. said yesterday that its pretax profit fell 13 percent in the year than ended on March 31 as wide swings in raw-material prices hurt performance. Courtaulds earned L131.5 million ($199 million) in the year, down from L151.1 million a year earlier. An upswing and subsequent collapse in price of Courtaulds two main raw materials, acrylonitrile and wood pulp, have had a "profoundly destabilizing impact" on acrylic and viscose fiber demand, and the market remains fragile, Courtauld's chief executive, Sipko Huismans, said. (AP)

title: No Headline
description: We cannot wipe the tears from the eyes of the people. We have lost our relatives. We have lost our citizens. We have lost the richness of their future."

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;A Response to Lyme Disease
description: Hunterdon County reported 565 cases of Lyme disease last year, one of the highest rates in the country. The Senate Health Committee will meet in Flemington today to consider legislation to require health insurance companies to cover treatment for the disease for as long as medically necessary.

title: Sports Of The Times;Will Ewing Help Knicks Get Howard?
description: IN announcing 34-year-old Jeff Van Gundy's return as coach, the Knicks also indicated that Patrick Ewing would return.

title: 160 Reportedly Killed in Chechnya Battle
description: Up to 40 Russian troops and 120 separatists were killed today in a fierce battle near Bamut, in western Chechnya, the Itar-Tass news agency reported.

title: Officer Dies After Falling on Glass in Scuffle on Domestic-DisputeCall
description: It was a domestic-violence call, the kind that many police officers dread: emotional, unpredictable and potentially dangerous. And in the end -- after a struggle, a freakish injury and an all-night effort by doctors to save him -- it cost Officer Vincent Guidice his life.

title: Japanese Talk of Shuffling Party Alliances for Next Election
description: As a general election approaches in Japan, the talk is not of vicious campaigning and dirty tricks. Instead, the whispers are of something more devious: the possibility that the main political parties might decide to cooperate.

title: 2 G.O.P. Legislators Attack Clinton on Legal Brief
description: Two Republican House members attacked President Clinton today for a suggestion in a legal brief that his status as Commander in Chief could be grounds for delaying a sex-harassment suit against him until after he leaves office.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Oilers May Stay Put
description: In recent months, BUD ADAMS could not wait to get out of Houston and claim a promised pot of gold in Nashville. Now, Adams, the Oilers' owner, thinks he may have to extend his National Football League team's stay in Houston through 1999, a year beyond the term of his Astrodome lease. "I'm not ruling anything out," Adams said yesterday from Charlotte, N.C., where N.F.L. owners are meeting. "What if we were the Super Bowl champions and they didn't want us to leave?"

title: NBC Extends Ebersol's Pact
description: Dick Ebersol will remain the president of NBC Sports until 2004 under a new eight-year contract that will take him partly through the five Olympics that NBC will televise from 2000 to 2008.

title: Death-Row Inmate Seeks Return to Trial Court
description: Lawyers for a death-row inmate, Mumia Abu-Jamal, today asked the Pennsylvania Supreme Court to send his case back to the trial court for more testimony from a defense witness, saying "irrefutable evidence" showed that police threats had caused that witness to change her testimony at the first trial.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;U.S. and French Aid Central Africa Pullout
description: United States marines and French paratroopers shielded Westerners awaiting evacuation today as heavy shooting erupted here after talks to end an army mutiny in collapsed.

title: Nobody Flunks Out At Walt Disney U.
description: THE sky is turning pale pink in the late afternoon sun, Andrew Lloyd Webber's "Memory" is soaring over the sound system, and Mark Mattern is bubbling with excitement.

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;Torrey Turns Florida Into Hot Hockey Property
description: Bill Torrey sat back in his chair at the Florida Panthers' practice arena, trademark bow tie neatly in place, and let out a hearty laugh.

title: These Culture Wars . . . They're Serious Stuff;Scientific Priesthood
description: To the Editor:

title: Gunman Flees After Killing 2 in Harlem
description: A gunman who had quarreled with his former girlfriend wounded her and killed two other people in a Harlem apartment building yesterday morning, the police said.

title: BASEBALL;Mets Cling To Victory Over L.A.
description: Most of the people in the crowd of 33,716 at Dodgers Stadium had never heard of Mark Clark. Nearly all of them had come to see the Dodgers' Japanese pitching sensation, Hideo Nomo.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;40 Years Holding Forth Before a Nation
description: There must have been some important event between 1940 and 1980 that Walter Cronkite did not bring to the nation's attention, but maybe not. He caught America's eye as a combat correspondent in World War II and never lost it. For his 19 years as anchor and managing editor of the "CBS Evening News," he was the person millions of Americans counted on to deliver the day's disasters and achievements. With the glory years of CBS News just a memory and with network news departments facing competition on all sides, there may never again be a Walter Cronkite.

title: The $5.15 Question
description: Some self-evident truths are neither self-evident nor true. Elementary economic theory insists that a higher minimum wage must reduce employment. On this basis, many people dismiss recent scholarly evidence suggesting that higher minimum wages may not cost the country jobs. But perhaps the elementary theory is, well, too elementary.

title: Currents;A Vote for 'More Is More'
description: AFTER a decade of (sometimes) heartfelt restraint, esthetes are anticipating opulence redux. When that moment comes, Wolfgang Thom, a lanky blond Municher who trained with the master French florist Christian Tortu, will be ready.

title: Berlin Journal;In Germany, Vietnamese Terrorize Vietnamese
description: In the concrete jungle of Marzahn, one of the toughest neighborhoods in what was once East Berlin, neighbors call the towering cement building at 3 Marchwitza Street "the death house."

title: Antitrust Suit Goes Against Big H.M.O.
description: U.S. Healthcare was ordered by a Federal jury yesterday to pay $1.2 million in damages to a smaller company that had accused the big health maintenance organization of violating antitrust laws by forcing retail pharmacies to buy employee coverage from it.

title: BASEBALL;Berroa the Yankee Slayer Has a Night to Savor
description: He had just played perhaps the best game of his life, as he himself said afterward. He hits the Yankees as if he owns them. Still, Geronimo Berroa said he really does not like New York.

title: U.S. Says Brooklyn Lawyer Stole Millions Using Property Schemes
description: A lawyer with a reputation for charitable deeds was charged yesterday with swindling victims out of nearly $14 million using bogus real estate schemes, and a Federal court complaint said that he had told another lawyer that his swindles had totaled more than $50 million.

title: BASEBALL;William Paterson Routinely Gets Another Berth in Division III Tourney
description: It happens every May.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Olympic Group And Florida Settle
description: A settlement has been reached in a dispute between the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games and the Florida Division of Tourism over 60 billboards in downtown Atlanta that promoted Florida vacations, which the Olympic committee complained had used symbols and words that too closely resembled Olympic trademarks.

title: Calendar: Exhibitions, Tours and a Conference
description: Pucks and Racquets American Institute of Graphic Arts, 164 Fifth Avenue, at21st Street; (212) 807-1990.

title: Legislative Leaders Join to Fight Budget Cuts Proposed by Pataki
description: Facing election-year pressures, state legislative leaders from both major parties told Gov. George E. Pataki today that they would not accept most of the sharp cuts in his proposed budget for state colleges, public education, health care and welfare programs.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Knicks Are Placing Their Faith in the Regular Guy
description: The "name guy" everyone at Madison Square Garden sorely coveted motored his Honda Civic down to the team president's office by himself on Tuesday. He brought with him neither an agent nor a list of demands, but merely the same desire he has always had: to stay employed in the coaching profession.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a special court in Brooklyn that has been set up to handle nonviolent drug cases described incorrectly the defendants the court will handle. While one of its goals is to focus on the problem of female offenders, it will handle both women and men.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CHASE TO CUT 600 JOBS IN ROCHESTER BECAUSE OF MERGER
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation will cut 600 jobs in Rochester in the next two years because of its merger with the Chemical Banking Corporation, the company said yesterday. Chase now has 2,000 employees in Rochester. The cuts will be in back-office support functions, a spokesman, Ken Herz, said. Officials of Chemical and Chase predicted in March, when the merger was completed, that the combination would result in the loss of 12,000 jobs over all.

title: Liberties;No Bridge Too Far
description: As a society, we haven't preserved our sense of shame. But Bill Clinton is doing his best to preserve our sense of shamelessness.

title: Approval Given For Cancer Test
description: The Cytyc Corporation said this week that the Food and Drug Administration had cleared its Thinprep 2000 system for cervical cancer screening.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JEAN-LOUIS MISSUD, the owner of La Reserve, a luxury restaurant on West 49th Street, said he had long wanted "to show the boys in Bosnia that they are not forgotten."

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Recruiter for Klan Suspended
description: The Department of Corrections has suspended a senior officer who recruited members for the Ku Klux Klan while on the job at Bayside State Prison, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: Weighing Divorce
description: To The Home Section:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Placement Firm Will Steer Clients to Temporary Jobs The nation's largest job-placement company reached an agreement to channel laid-off white-collar workers -- like upper-level managers, engineers, accountants and lawyers -- into temporary work when it cannot place them in permanent, well-paying jobs.

title: Designing Boutiques Like Palaces
description: LAST Wednesday, amid feverish preparations for the imminent opening of the luxurious Chanel boutique on East 57th Street, an improbable ballet occurred: workmen in construction gear and French-speaking women in turquoise Chanel suits rushed across a lush, sand-colored carpet in protective blue booties.

title: Corrections
description: Because of editing errors, an article in some editions yesterday about United Nations peacekeeping operations misstated the timing of remarks by a diplomat who led a United Nations mission to Rwanda, and of a Security Council action on assembling a peacekeeping force for neighboring Burundi. The diplomat, Shahryar Khan, spoke last week, just before a meeting at which the Rwanda mission was reviewed, not this week; the Security Council action was two weeks ago, not last week.

title: Little Harm Found on the Day After
description: When the power flicked off in Queens on Tuesday, Michael Stone, the manager of Petland Discounts in Flushing, had a dual vision of what could come: "Dead fish," he said yesterday, "and possibly looting of the store."

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;In a Legal Thriller, Big Tobacco on the Defensive
description: THE RUNAWAY JURY By John Grisham 401 pages. Doubleday. $26.95.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SUMMIT BANCORP TO ACQUIRE CENTRAL JERSEY FINANCIAL
description: Summit Bancorp will buy the Central Jersey Financial Corporation for $90 million in stock, the companies said yesterday. Summit agreed to swap 0.875 share for each Central Jersey share. At Tuesday's closing price, the offer is worth $33.80 per Central Jersey share. Central Jersey's stock jumped $3.875, to $30.375, yesterday in Nasdaq trading. Summit's shares fell $1.375, to $37.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. Central Jersey, which is based in East Brunswick, N.J., operates Central Jersey Savings Bank, which has six branches in Middlesex County. Summit, based in Princeton, is the biggest bank based in New Jersey.

title: He Loved the Job and More
description: If anyone had asked Vincent Guidice if he was a city boy or a country boy, he might have answered, "Both."

title: These Culture Wars . . . They're Serious Stuff
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Barriers to a Bosnian Peace
description: Six months after the Dayton peace agreement was signed and 10 months since they were indicted as the master criminals of the Bosnian war, Radovan Karadzic and Gen. Ratko Mladic still rule Serbian-controlled Bosnia. They present a clear danger to the future of the Bosnia peace.

title: New Species of Early Human Reported Found in Africa
description: A new species of early human has been found in a central African desert, so far from traditional ancient fossil sites that it may change the understanding of where human ancestors originated, French scientists said today.

title: Corrections
description: A caption on May 10 with the obituary of the illustrator Garth Williams misidentified the pig shown with Charlotte, the spider, in a drawing of his from "Charlotte's Web" by E. B. White. The pig was Uncle, not Wilbur.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: Jeff McKay Inc., New York, was awarded two accounts from home furnishings manufacturers with combined billings estimated at $2.25 million: J. Robert Scott, Los Angeles, and Hokanson, Houston.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Select Experimental Styles In a Nearly Obsessive Focus
description: In a 20-year run of concerts at the Paula Cooper Gallery in SoHo, the S. E. M. Ensemble has put forward a fiercely focused perspective on contemporary music. It has joined the radical wing of New York music with a more prickly European avant-gardism characteristic of its founder, the Czech-born composer, conductor and flutist Petr Kotik. Sometimes playful, sometimes forbidding, S. E. M. represents the best of what is left of the experimental tradition, as an anniversary concert on Tuesday night testified.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Officer in Car-Theft Trial
description: This is the auto-theft capital of the country, and the cops are stealing cars," Robert H. Codey, a deputy state attorney general, said yesterday as a trial began for the first of four Newark police officers who were accused last year of taking part in an automobile theft ring.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: ON BASEBALL;Players' Wives Are Stepping Up to Bat for Cause
description: In baseball marriages, there has traditionally been little question about who was the truly significant other. It has always been the player.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Mazda to Furlough 4,000 at Two Plants
description: The Mazda Motor Corporation will furlough 4,000 workers at two plants to cut production temporarily and reduce excess inventory. The Japanese auto maker, partly owned by the Ford Motor Company, said yesterday that it would close its Ujina plant in Hiroshima state for 11 days in the next three months, idling 3,500 workers. Five hundred workers at a second plant in Hofu will stay home four days. Workers will receive partial pay, company officials said.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CADMUS COMMUNICATIONS CORP., Richmond, said it had acquired Lancaster Information Group Inc., Lancaster, Pa., a printer of scientific, technical and medical journals, for $57 million.

title: Mercury Poison Case Ends
description: Japan today brought to a close one of its most notorious pollution cases, the mercury poisoning of thousands of villagers in Minamata, which focused international attention on the dangers of industrial pollution four decades ago.

title: Free the F.A.A. of Its Conflicts
description: The crash of the Valujet airliner in Florida, still a long way from being explained, has exposed a fundamental flaw in the Government's role in commercial aviation. The Federal Aviation Administration has long been assigned the dual tasks of policing air safety and promoting aviation. That works fine when the two roles are in harmony. But when they conflict, as can happen in the aftermath of an aviation tragedy, the flying public is shortchanged.

title: An Open-Skies Deal Gets an Approval
description: The United States Transportation Department gave tentative antitrust approval on Tuesday to a plan to allow Swissair, Delta Air Lines Sabena and Austrian Airlines to collaborate more closely.

title: Wacky World of Russian Politics: It's All in the Altered Genes
description: At a news conference billed as the outlining of the Communist Party's definitive economic program, the economist in charge of formulating it instead spoke spookily this week about attempts by the Yeltsin campaign to tamper with the Russian gene pool.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Goodby, Silverstein Wins Top Honors
description: Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco has taken top honors for the second consecutive year, winning the most awards, at the One Show for creative advertising sponsored by the One Club for Art and Copy in New York.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on May 11, about the indictment of three men on charges that they used a false-billing scheme to defraud a Culbro cigar plant in Dothan, Ala., omitted the company's response to the indictments. Culbro says that the indictments support its previous statements about the case and that they are not a sign of further trouble for the company.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday, about a proposal by the Securities and Exchange Commission's chairman to change the membership of the Financial Accounting Foundation, misstated the reaction of Representative Christopher Cox, a California Republican. Mr. Cox sent a letter to the S.E.C. chairman, Arthur Levitt Jr., expressing concern about the proposal; he did not denounce it.

title: Liberia's Tragedy Is of International Proportion
description: To the Editor:

title: Dole Discusses Taxes After Meeting Forbes
description: Senator Bob Dole, the presumptive Republican Presidential nominee, met with Steve Forbes, his former opponent, as Mr. Dole tried to move closer to tax policies he has spurned most of his political career.

title: Few Price Changes Seen for Buyers
description: Even if consumers have been harmed by any anti-competitive actions of Toys "R" Us Inc., as the Federal Trade Commission contended yesterday, they will not be paying less for toys for a long time.

title: These Culture Wars . . . They're Serious Stuff;Power of Ridicule
description: To the Editor:

title: Army Panel to Review Accuracy of Book on All-Black Regiment
description: The Army said today that it would form a panel of historians and soldiers to review the accuracy of an official history of the Army's last all-black regiment, a book that has drawn threats of a defamation suit from black veterans of the Korean War.

title: A Sale at Saks, and Buyers Come Running
description: Saks Fifth Avenue opened on Wall Street yesterday, and investors proved to be eager shoppers.

title: Levitt Asks Funds to Look At Managers' Own Trading
description: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission encouraged mutual fund executives today to revisit one of the industry's most controversial issues: whether fund managers should be allowed to make investments for their personal benefit at the same time they manage the public's money.

title: These Culture Wars . . . They're Serious Stuff;Lighten Up, Guys
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;Becker Won't Play In the French Open
description: BORIS BECKER is pulling out of next week's French Open because of a thigh injury.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;For Computer Associates, Sales and Net Rise Again
description: Five years ago, Charles B. Wang, the chairman and chief executive of Computer Associates International, watched in disbelief as the technology world read the last rites over the mainframe computer. Now Mr. Wang is having the last laugh.

title: FILM REVIEW;A Much-Conquered Area Of Few Jews, Many Stories
description: Yale Strom's documentary film "Carpati: 50 Miles, 50 Years" begins with a story, told by Leonard Nimoy, about a gypsy who asks a Jew from the Carpathian Mountains of southwestern Ukraine how it is that he knows so many languages.

title: POLITICS;Excerpts From Dole Speech: 'Referendum on the Basic Values of the Country'
description: Following are excerpts from a prepared text of Senator Bob Dole's speech yesterday at the Catholic Press Association's annual convention in Philadelphia:

title: American Banknote Gets Into Pachinko
description: The American Banknote Corporation said yesterday that it was developing optical-reading technology for a group of Japanese companies to help prevent counterfeit prepaid cards in the pachinko business.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;The Magic Knows Exactly What Game 3 Means
description: Nobody was ready to concede. Nobody was ready to panic. But nobody had to tell the Orlando Magic that time is running out.

title: Embattled Chief of Largest U.S. Mutual Fund Passes Baton
description: NEW YORK  Jeffrey N. Vinik, manager of the largest mutual fund in the United States and probably in the world, parachuted out of Fidelity Investments on Thursday to run a smaller and more nimble portfolio for rich investors instead of managing money for the masses under relentless pressure to outperform the stock market.

title: Man Held in 2 Deaths
description: A Harlem man was charged yesterday with wounding a woman who had broken off their relationship, then killing two bystanders.

title: BASEBALL;After Aneurysm Surgery, There's Hope
description: In 1991, doctors told Roberto Hernandez's wife and sister that he had little chance of pitching again. Hernandez, a hard-throwing 26-year-old minor leaguer at the time, had just undergone surgery for an aneurysm in his right armpit and a blood clot in his forearm and faced the end of his career before it really began.

title: ART REVIEW;A Master Best Known For His Chair
description: WILLIAM MORRIS is an eminent Victorian (his life roughly spanned Queen Victoria's reign) whom everyone understands to be a pivotal figure of modern times, though most people nowadays don't actually know much about him beyond his namesake chair or his chintz designs. He is like his hero Ruskin in that regard, a household name yet, oddly, obscure.

title: Home Video
description: A Debate Over 'Killers'

title: Art in Review
description: Elizabeth Murray Pace Wildenstein 32 East 57th Street Manhattan Through June 8

title: Veterans Get Their Doughboy Back
description: For men who once fought wars, victory came this week with the return of a statue.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES FALL AFTER OAK TECHNOLOGY ISSUES A WARNING
description: The shares of Oak Technology Inc. fell 24 percent yesterday after the company, a multimedia computer chip maker, said late on Wednesday that it expected fourth-quarter results to be significantly lower than expected. The shares fell $4, to $12.50, in Nasdaq trading of 9.6 million shares. The company, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., said it expected a loss of 4 cents to 8 cents a share on revenues of $20 million to $25 million in the quarter ending on June 30. In last year's fourth quarter, the company earned $9.3 million, or 47 cents a share, on revenues of $42.5 million. Oak Technology said shipments of its CD-ROM controller chip were unexpectedly low.

title: London Journal;This Calls for Beefeaters: British Cudgel Europe
description: It is not quite World War III, at least not yet: no shots have been fired, no air-raid sirens sounded, no blackouts imposed. But fighting is in the air in Britain's capital, where John Major has thrown down the gauntlet in the country's latest offensive, the 1996 Battle of the Beef.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Thai Airways to Buy 6 Jets From Boeing
description: Thai Airways International P.L.C. said yesterday that it had signed contracts to buy four Boeing 737-400/500 aircraft and two Boeing 747-400's worth 11.8 million baht ($472 million). Thai Airways said in a filing to the Stock Exchange of Thailand that it would take delivery of the six planes between October 1997 and May 1999.

title: Small Schools Put With Best, and Worst
description: When it comes to the New York City public schools, smaller is not necessarily better, according to test scores released yesterday by the Board of Education.

title: School Service Requirement Isn't Like Slavery
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayor's Stalled Plans Leave Public Hospitals in Trauma
description: Ever since he was elected, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has derided New York's public hospitals and vowed to turn some of them over to private hospitals, which he says will provide the poor with better care and save the city money. Three hospitals are on the auction block and the administration predicts a deal this summer.

title: Keep in Mind
description: CHILDREN'S MUSEUM OF MANHATTAN, with Memorial Day celebrations that include a quilting bee throughout the weekend for ages 5 and up and a folk-music sing-along for preschoolers on Sunday at 10:30 A.M. At 212 West 83d Street. Saturday through Monday, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission (includes all performances and activities): $5; under 2, free. Information: (212) 721-1234.

title: Recalling the Meaning Behind Memorial Day
description: Millions of winter-weary and spring-deprived people are hauling barbecue grills out of garages, packing provisions for country homes and filling picnic coolers with beer and soda as they prepare for Memorial Day and the first long weekend of the warm season.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;German Wage Talks Go to Arbitration
description: Wage talks collapsed yesterday between the German Government and the nation's largest public-sector union, sending the matter to arbitration. Union officials rejected as too meager the Government's offer to raise wages one-half of 1 percent through April of next year and another 1 percent in the rest of 1997.

title: Astronauts Repair Their Soda Fountain
description: Two astronauts aboard the space shuttle Endeavour spent nearly two hours repairing the craft's new soda fountain today while taking a break from a hectic schedule of satellite work.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Jordan a Unanimous All-Star Again
description: The Chicago teammates MICHAEL JORDAN and SCOTTIE PIPPEN made the All-National Basketball Association team yesterday with ANFERNEE HARDAWAY of Orlando, KARL MALONE of Utah and DAVID ROBINSON of San Antonio.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Phillips Will Not Be Charged
description: Chicago White Sox outfielder TONY PHILLIPS will not face criminal charges for punching a heckler during a game last week the Milwaukee (Wis.) County District Attorney's office said yesterday.

title: Youth Violence Requires Adult Penalties
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL;Owners Make a Peace Offering to Players
description: If two sides in a labor dispute move toward each other's position, no matter how painstakingly slowly, they should ultimately be able to arrive at a compromise and a new collective bargaining agreement. Baseball negotiations, however, defy such labor logic, so it remains to be seen if the moves the owners' representatives made yesterday will lead to labor peace.

title: Investors Bid Up Internet Stock
description: Shares of Open Market Inc. more than doubled yesterday in the first day of trading for the developer of software to expedite Internet commerce.

title: In America;A Church Destroyed By Hate
description: You can walk up the stone steps and into the vestibule of St. John Baptist Church in Dixiana, S.C., but the rest of the church is gone.

title: Sports of The Times;The Ex-Mets Thrive While Mets Wallow
description: IN the hours before the Mets' opener at Shea Stadium on April 1, their executive vice president for baseball operations, Joe McIlvaine, walked into Dallas Green's office and shook hands with the manager.

title: Huge Tobacco Lawsuit Is Thrown Out on Appeal
description: In a major victory for the beleaguered tobacco industry, a Federal appeals panel in New Orleans unanimously dismissed a giant class-action lawsuit brought against the nation's cigarette makers on behalf of millions of smokers.

title: With $7,500 in Cash, Giffords Scramble to Save Face at Sweatshop
description: Perhaps the last place anyone would expect to find Frank Gifford, the sports broadcaster and former football star, would be in a 17th-floor sweatshop in the garment district.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;American Indians, Posing and Not
description: It was a sweet-looking picture postcard that inspired Lucy R. Lippard to put together "Partial Recall: Photographs of Native North Americans." On the card was a portrait of a Stoney Indian family in the northern Rockies, taken in 1907 by Mary Warren, a Quaker from Philadelphia. In the picture, Sampson, the father, is sitting cross-legged on the ground and smiling -- it seems genuinely -- at the photographer. The little girl, Frances Louise, is standing in moccasins and playing impishly to the camera. The mother, Leah, kneeling, looks relaxed.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Trooper Dies of Crash Injuries
description: The state trooper who was critically injured when he lost control of his cruiser during a chase died yesterday, the State Police said. The trooper, Francis J. Bellaran, 32, was the 58th trooper to die in the line of duty in the 75-year history of the State Police, said John Hagerty, a spokesman for the department. Trooper Bellaran crashed into a clump of trees Monday while chasing a speeding motorcycle that may have been stolen, The A.P. reported. A suspect, Louis D. Goodman, 19, surrendered Wednesday and was charged, before Trooper Bellaran's death, with aggravated assault, a Monmouth County Assistant Prosecutor, Alton Kenney, said.

title: CHRONICLE
description: VANESSA WILLIAMS, the Miss America who lost her crown in 1984 because she had once posed nude, will return in triumph to her alma mater, Syracuse University, to receive its highest alumni award. She was a member of the class of '85 but did not graduate.

title: North Korean Fighter Pilot Defects to South With Jet
description: A North Korean Air Force captain defected to South Korea today in his MIG-19 fighter plane, setting off air raid sirens before arriving on a South Korean air base with his aircraft and a mountain of intelligence about the North Korean military.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Vinik Quits as Manager Of Fidelity Magellan Fund Jeffrey N. Vinik, the embattled portfolio manager of the Fidelity Magellan fund, the country's largest mutual fund, resigned, sending some tremors through the mutual fund industry.

title: Pipeline Concern Draws $22 Million Fine
description: After years of saying the natural gas pipeline it built from the Canadian border to Long Island was safe and environmentally sound, the company that operates the Iroquois Pipeline pleaded guilty today to four felonies for violating Federal environmental laws.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Matsushita Posts a Loss On MCA Sale
description: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, the giant Japanese electronics concern whose brands include Panasonic, said today that a foreign-exchange loss from the sale of a stake in MCA Inc. pushed it into a loss for its latest fiscal year.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ESCO ELECTRONICS IS SELLING HAZELTINE UNIT
description: The Esco Electronics Corporation of St. Louis, a maker of military and commercial systems, said yesterday that it would sell its Hazeltine Corporation subsidiary to the GEC-Marconi Electronic Systems Corporation for $110 million in cash. Hazeltine, which makes advanced military electronic systems, had sales of about $114 million in its latest fiscal year and about $55 million for the first half of the current fiscal year. GEC-Marconi, based in Wayne, N.J., is a unit of the General Electric Company P.L.C. of Britain.

title: Tribunal Plans To File Warrants
description: The head of the United Nations war crimes tribunal for Bosnia was quoted as saying today that arrest warrants for the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, and his military chief, Ratko Mladic, would probably be issued in July.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: What to Do Until the Fireworks Arrive on Memorial Night
description: Memorial Day falls on Monday, and holiday activities are planned all weekend. Here is a sampling of events in the three-state region.

title: FILM REVIEW;That's Agent 007? No, It Must Be 000
description: When Agent WD-40 (Leslie Nielsen), a k a Dick Steele, receives an assignment on a tape programmed to self-destruct within three seconds, it doesn't extinguish itself in a discreet little fizzle but sets off a thunderous blast that blows up the helicopter in which Mr. T is piloting him to a top-secret operation. So begins "Spy Hard," the anything-goes spoof of espionage movies that arrives just in time to cleanse the palate from the pseudo-serious action-adventure of "Mission Impossible."

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Wednesday with the continuation of a front-page article about the erosion of consensus among the nation's governors on reshaping the Federal-state health program for the poor referred incorrectly to that program. It is Medicaid, not Medicare.

title: Senators Offer Bipartisan Plan To Cut Taxes in the District
description: In an effort to reverse years of population and economic decline in the District of Columbia, two Senators said today that they would introduce a bill on Friday that would substantially cut the Federal taxes paid by District residents.

title: 2 Agents Infiltrated Arms Ring, U.S. Says
description: Posing as arms dealers with ties to the mob, two Federal agents at the center of a sting operation spent the last 16 months infiltrating an arms ring that was funneling automatic weapons produced by China's two main state-controlled arms exporters to the streets of the United States, Federal officials said yesterday.

title: ART REVIEW;60's Minimalism, Looking Handmade
description: Tina Turner sang, "We don't need another hero," a sentiment later echoed by the artist Barbara Kruger. But heroines are another matter, especially when it comes to the star-studded, male-dominated 1960's. Add Yayoi Kusama to the list of women who contributed to that decade's heady mix of ideas, and don't miss the exemplary exhibition of her work at the Paula Cooper Gallery in SoHo. A Warholesque Minimalist who favored understated paintings and overstated Happenings while also setting the stage for Post-Minimalism and feminist art, she has art-star credentials to burn.

title: Self-Mutilation Carries Many Messages
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Airbus Industrie Gets Order From Vietnam
description: Vietnam Airlines ordered 10 Airbus Industrie A320 aircraft, the European airplane consortium said yesterday. Terms of the deal were not disclosed, but Airbus has said in the past that the A320 has a list price of close to $50 million. The aircraft are scheduled for delivery between June and early 1997, and will be operated on routes linking Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City with destinations across Asia, as well as on some domestic routes. (Dow Jones)

title: SOCCER;Italian Team to Test MetroStars Tonight
description: The MetroStars will face Fiorentina of Italy and its scoring superstar, Gabriel Batistuta of Argentina, in the team's first international soccer game tonight at Giants Stadium.

title: Art in Review
description: Leandro Katz 'Two Projects: A Decade' El Museo del Barrio 1230 Fifth Avenue, at 104th Street East Harlem Through June 16

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Disney and McDonald's as Double Feature
description: The entertainment giant that convinced the world that mice can talk and elephants can fly is joining forces with the fast-food giant that convinced the world that adding a "secret sauce" to a hamburger sandwich makes it big and adding a toy to a children's meal makes it happy.

title: Cargo Suspected in Crash Is Barred From Passenger Airplanes
description: The Transportation Department today temporarily banned passenger airplanes from carrying the kind of oxygen generators that were in the cargo hold of the Valujet DC-9 that crashed in the Florida Everglades, killing all 110 people aboard.

title: Restaurants
description: A great waiter makes all the difference.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: CYCLING

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Edward J. Gurney, the former Senator from Florida, misstated Edmund S. Muskie's alma mater. Mr. Muskie, who died in March, was a graduate of Bates College, not Colby College, which was Mr. Gurney's alma mater.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Troopers to Leave Camden
description: State Police troopers will begin pulling out of Camden before the week's end, a spokeswoman for Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said yesterday evening. The State Police were sent in Jan. 5 to beef up patrols in high-crime areas of the impoverished city. In a letter to the Mayor of Camden, Arnold Webster, the Governor wrote that the troopers would be withdrawn as Camden officials begin to put new crime-fighting suggestions from the state into effect, The Associated Press said. Several state task forces will remain in the city after the State Police leave, the Governor wrote. Mayor Webster did not immediately return a call seeking comment.

title: BASEBALL;Everett Plays to His Own Beat Despite Criticism from Green
description: Dallas Green looked into Carl Everett's eyes and wondered where the fire had gone. A baseball man for 41 years, Green knows only one way to play the game -- hard-nosed, intense, combative. He sees none of that in the player he expected to be his starting right fielder, creating one of the more frustrating subplots of the Mets season.

title: U.S. and Allies Fail to Strip Top Bosnia Serbs of Power
description: The United States and its NATO allies have failed this week in an effort to remove from power the Bosnian Serb political and military leaders, who have been indicted for war crimes.

title: HORSE RACING;Unbridled's Song May Miss Met Mile
description: Just when Unbridled's Song seemed poised for a dramatic return to the races against older horses in the Metropolitan Mile on Monday, his owner reconsidered and said yesterday that he now favored entering the colt in the Peter Pan Stakes on Sunday and the Belmont Stakes two weeks later.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook yesterday about television news reports tied to prime-time shows misidentified the weatherman on WNYW, the Fox-owned station in New York. He is Nick Gregory, not Nick Gomez.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Agency Named For Sega System
description: Sega of America, the video-game marketer owned by Sega Enterprises Ltd., said yesterday that it had selected Ingalls Moranville in San Francisco to handle the broadcast creative part of the account of its Sega Saturn system, with billings estimated at $20 million to $30 million. That assignment, along with all other national broadcast creative duties for Sega of America, had been handled for the last five years by Goodby, Silverstein & Partners, a unit of the Omnicom Group in San Francisco, until that agency and Sega agreed to part company in March over creative differences.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Toyota Sold Fewer Cars, but Its Earnings Rose
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation, continuing its aggressive effort to cut manufacturing costs, reported today that net income had improved in its last fiscal year despite a decline in vehicle sales.

title: Subway Construction Yields No Free Transfer
description: To the Editor:

title: Increase in Teen-Age Smoking Sharpest Among Black Males
description: More high school students are smoking, with use of cigarettes climbing especially sharply among young black males, according to survey results reported yesterday by Federal health officials.

title: CHRONICLE
description: There will be a certain poetic justice when MICHAEL A. CARDOZO becomes president of the New York City Bar Association on Tuesday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HOUSE OF FABRICS SECURES FINANCING TO END BANKRUPTCY
description: House of Fabrics Inc., based in Sherman Oaks, Calif., said yesterday that CIT Group Holdings Inc. would provide $60 million in financing as of the end of July, enabling the company to complete its restructuring and emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy. CIT, which is controlled by Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank Ltd., is to provide the credit line for an initial period of three years. House of Fabrics, which sells sewing supplies through 427 stores, filed for bankruptcy protection in 1994.

title: World News Briefs;Burmese Activists Plan To Meet Despite Arrests
description: The country's leading democracy advocate, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, said today that she would go ahead with a planned party congress this weekend despite the arrests of nearly 200 opposition politicians by the Burmese Government.

title: NGC and Chevron Reach Accord on Gas
description: The NGC Corporation and the Chevron Corporation said today that they had signed a final agreement that would make NGC the largest natural gas and gas liquids wholesaler in North America.

title: No Headline
description: We have the army at our front, and the militants at our back. What can we do?"

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Rutgers Drops Provost Job
description: The president of Rutgers University has decided to abolish the position of provost of the New Brunswick campus, a move that will eliminate about 25 jobs. Some faculty members said that President Francis L. Lawrence was trying to consolidate his own power, but the ousted provost, Joseph Potenza, described the decision yesterday as "an efficiency move." Many of Dr. Potenza's duties in overseeing Rutgers' colleges will be assumed by Joseph Seneca, university vice president for academic affairs, and Richard Foley, dean of the faculty of arts and sciences.

title: On My Mind;The Covenant Caper
description: Twice in a month, the American and Israeli Governments have collaborated in serious cover-ups of truth and reality in the Mideast.

title: French Marchers Demand a Shorter Workweek
description: Thousands of workers took to the streets of Paris and disrupted passenger train service today to demand a shorter workweek to reduce France's 11.8 percent unemployment rate at a time when the Government has made budget-cutting a priority.

title: Injury Forces Johnson to Rest
description: Experiencing soreness in his right hamstring, the world champion Michael Johnson has withdrawn from the 400-meter race at Sunday's Prefontaine Classic in Eugene, Ore.

title: New York Brokerage Is Accused of Fraud
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission accused a New York brokerage firm yesterday of defrauding New York University and other clients by making unauthorized stock trades and refusing to execute sales orders.

title: J.F.K. Trove Available For Love, Not Money
description: Robert White just hates it when someone picks up one of the treasures of his collection and asks, "So, what's this worth?"

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;Stellar Vanbiesbrouck Accentuates Positive
description: John Vanbiesbrouck was pulled from his goal five times over a 14-game span earlier this season. Paul Henry, a psychologist and scout for the Florida Panthers, sensed that Vanbiesbrouck was rapidly losing his confidence as one of the National Hockey League's premier goalies.

title: Inside Art
description: Money Spent and Collected in London

title: COMPANY NEWS;JLG SHARES SURGE AFTER EARNINGS DOUBLE
description: The shares of JLG Industries rose nearly 16 percent yesterday after the company reported higher-than-expected earnings, set a 3-for-1 stock split and raised its dividend. JLG's shares rose $11.25, to $82.25, in Nasdaq trading of 1.3 million shares. JLG, a maker of elevating aerial work platforms based in McConnellsburg, Pa., said its third-quarter earnings more than doubled, to $12.5 million, from $6.1 million a year earlier. The stock split, the third in 16 months, takes effect on July 1. JLG increased the quarterly dividend by 50 percent on a pre-split basis, to 5 cents a share after the split. Separately, the company sold a division that makes truck-mounted cranes to Powerscreen International P.L.C. of Northern Ireland. Terms were not disclosed.

title: 34 Mexicans Endure A Harrowing Trip
description: Thirty-four apparently illegal immigrants from Mexico spent three days crammed inside a horse trailer towed from Arizona before they were discovered here by the authorities early Wednesday. The driver was found sleeping at a motel nearby.

title: India Sends In Troops to Make Sure Kashmiris Cast Votes
description: Indian troops moved into villages and urban neighborhoods across the Vale of Kashmir at dawn today, rousing Muslims from their beds to vote in the first election to be held in the only Indian state with a Muslim majority since a Muslim separatist rebellion began in 1989.

title: HOUSE APPROVES INCREASE TO $5.15 IN MINIMUM WAGE
description: After eight weeks of Democratic pressure, the House today overwhelmingly passed legislation to raise the Federal minimum wage to $5.15 an hour from $4.25.

title: AUTO RACING;With 17 Rookies, Caution Flag Is Waving at Indy
description: The five drivers seated on the podium at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway spanned the spectrum of motor racing and, at the same time, symbolized what the 1996 Indianapolis 500 is about: rookies, of all sorts and of all levels of experience.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;For '60 Minutes,' New Dueling Voices
description: Long-term fans of CBS's "60 Minutes" may remember or be forgiven for not remembering the guest commentators -- James J. Kilpatrick, Nicholas von Hoffman, Shana Alexander and others -- who have served a term on the Sunday program during its 28-year run. Now, more than a decade after getting along nicely without extra voices, Don Hewitt, a producer who doesn't mind fixing what works, has hired three writers known for their snappy styles. Molly Ivins, who writes a syndicated column for The Fort Worth Star-Telegram, is on for a minute or so each week and is joined, in alternating two-week stretches, by the essayist Stanley Crouch and the political satirist P. J. O'Rourke.

title: World News Briefs;Chinese Government Strips Monk of Post
description: A crackdown on independence movements in Tibet gathered momentum today when a top Buddhist monk was removed from his post.

title: Big Business Takes a Beating
description: About 3,500 business executives came to the Theater at Madison Square Garden last night to see, as one observer put it, "A couple of C.E.O.'s getting beaten up."

title: About Real Estate;Deal Shows Banks Ease Loan Rule For Co-ops
description: The East New York Savings Bank closed a $10.7 million mortgage loan to a cooperative apartment building in Queens last week even though only 14 percent of the apartments were owner-occupied. The percentage was well below the 50 percent generally considered the norm for writing mortgages, either for co-op corporations or for individual co-op or condominium buyers.

title: The Communist Makeover
description: The revival of the Russian Communist Party so soon after the demise of Communism in Russia is a conundrum that seems to defy common sense and the lessons of history. But the Communists are knocking at the gates of the Kremlin again, promoting the fanciful notion that the descendants of Lenin and Stalin are now democrats and capitalists.

title: FILM REVIEW;Humiliation Wherever She Turns
description: Welcome to the Dollhouse" was shown as part of this year's New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 22. The film opens today in Manhattan.

title: FILM REVIEW;Tales of an Occult Tyrant
description: Guimba" was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 7. The film opens today at Cinema Village, 22 East 12th Street, Greenwich Village.

title: Abroad at Home;Where Freedom Ends
description: Many Palestinians spoke to me, when I visited the area recently, about the repressive character of Yasir Arafat's Palestinian Authority: its use of arbitrary arrests, torture, secret trials. A courageous Gaza psychiatrist and human rights advocate, Dr. Eyad Sarraj, said people feared a "dictatorial, oppressive" regime. I quoted him in a column.

title: Adm. Lewis B. Combs, 101, Seabee Founder
description: Adm. Lewis B. Combs, a Navy engineer who helped create and direct the vast island-hopping force of Seabees, who dodged bombs and bullets as they built floating drydocks and airstrips and more across the Pacific during World War II, died on Monday at his home in Red Hook, N.Y. He was 101.

title: Peres Maintains a Slim Lead in Israeli Polls as Election Nears
description: With only three days of active campaigning left before Israeli national elections, polls today showed Prime Minister Shimon Peres maintaining a slim but consistent edge over Benjamin Netanyahu.

title: Stocks Flat in Japan
description: Stocks were trading in a narrow range here today. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 1.91 points, or one-hundredth of 1 percent, at 21,722.17. On Thursday, the Nikkei fell 233.92 points, or 1.07 percent.

title: A Newly Clean Hudson Awaits Swimmers
description: In a sign that the Hudson is again a bountiful, swimmable river and no longer an open sewer and convenient dump site, Westchester County officials have announced that the county's only public beach on the river, at Croton Point Park, will open for swimming for the first time since 1987, starting on the Fourth of July.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;In Money Race, It's Zimmer
description: Federal Election Commission records released yesterday showed that in the heated race to fill Bill Bradley's United States Senate seat, Dick Zimmer raised more money than his fellow Congressman, Robert Torricelli -- $571,948 in the reporting period from April 1 though May 15, compared to $536,040 for Mr. Torricelli. But Mr. Zimmer, a Republican who unlike Mr. Torricelli has to contend with a June 4 primary, outspent the Democrat by a margin of $382,858 to $214,233, The A.P. reported. Mr. Torricelli's spokesman said the figures do not include $500,000 from a Jersey City fund-raiser attended by President Clinton.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Kennedy and Nixon: An Uneasy Relationship
description: KENNEDY AND NIXON The Rivalry That Shaped Postwar America By Christopher Matthews Illustrated. 377 pages. Simon & Schuster. $25.

title: World News Briefs;Lebanon Hands Suspect Over to German Court
description: A Palestinian man was flown to Germany today to stand trial on charges that he masterminded a 1986 Berlin disco bombing that killed two United States servicemen.

title: COMPANY NEWS;COOPER INDUSTRIES TO SELL STAKE IN COOPER CAMERON
description: Cooper Industries said yesterday that it would sell its 14.4 percent stake in the Cooper Cameron Corporation and use the proceeds to reduce debt and finance possible acquisitions. Cooper Cameron shares rose 50 cents yesterday, to $45.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. At that price, the more than 3.6 million shares owned by Cooper Industries would be worth more than $164 million. Cooper Industries retained the stock when it spun off Cooper Cameron last year. Cooper Industries has filed a shelf registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the stock sale. The filing gives it until June 30, 2000, to sell the shares. Cooper Cameron makes and services equipment used in oil and gas wells and in power generators.

title: Apology For Taping Inmate's Talk
description: A District Attorney who last month ordered the jailhouse taping of a conversation between a crime suspect and Roman Catholic priest announced on Wednesday that he would not use the tape in court.

title: Mayor Criticizes Manslaughter Charge in Officer's Death
description: Bronx prosecutors filed manslaughter charges yesterday against a man whose domestic dispute led to the death of a city police officer this week, prompting Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to complain that the charges were too weak.

title: 7 Suspects Accused Of Smuggling Guns Into California : 'Sting' Case Further Tests U.S.-China Relations
description: WASHINGTON  Adding to already serious strains in relations with China, U.S. agents have arrested seven people allegedly linked to arms companies run by the Chinese government, charging that they smuggled 2,000 AK-47 assault rifles into the United States.

title: Chess in Black and White: 2 Emigres, Father and Son;Pugnacious Manager and Shy, Brilliant Player
description: In chess, in which the arcane, intense battles on the board often pale beside the rivalries away from it, the most controversial figure may not be the 33-year-old world champion, Garry Kasparov, a globe-trotting Muscovite businessman and political commentator whose charismatic, camera-friendly arrogance and hubris are matched only by his demonstrated superiority as a player.

title: POLITICS: THE CHALLENGER;Heatedly, Dole and Clinton Escalate a Split on Abortion
description: In an extraordinarily intense and personal cross-country exchange, President Clinton and Senator Bob Dole challenged each other's values and personal integrity today, focusing on the issue of late-term abortion in a daylong series of increasingly vituperative attacks.

title: Camping Out Under the Trees
description: ARE we outside?"

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Cable and Wireless Profit Increases 59%
description: Cable and Wireless P.L.C., which over the last six months has ousted its chief executive and resumed and then ended merger talks, said today that pretax profit rose 59 percent in the latest fiscal year, aided by a one-time gain.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Corn Prices Surge on a Forecast Of Rain That Could Hurt Crop
description: Corn prices surged on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday after a rain forecast for the Midwest. Heavy rain could delay planting and reduce the size of this year's harvest.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ROPER INDUSTRIES ACQUIRES FLUID METERING
description: Roper Industries said yesterday that it had acquired Fluid Metering Inc. for $30.4 million. The purchase price was paid 80 percent in cash and 20 percent in stock, Roper said. Fluid Metering, based in Oyster Bay, L.I., makes a line of patented metering pumps designed for low- pressure fluid metering. For the 12 months ended April 30, the company had revenue of $15 million. Roper, a maker of fluid handling and industrial control products based in Bogart, Ga., had 1995 revenue of $175.4 million.

title: Americans Flunk Science, a Study Finds
description: Less than half of American adults understand that the Earth orbits the Sun yearly, according to a basic science survey. Nevertheless, there is enthusiasm for research, except in some fields like genetic engineering and nuclear power that are viewed with suspicion.

description: Robert E. Stansky is a man with a plan, and that is likely to mean big changes for investors in the nation's largest mutual fund, Fidelity Magellan.

title: 25 and Under
description: E and O qualifies as a great first-date restaurant. What does that mean, you may ask?

title: COMPANY NEWS;ABRAXAS PETROLEUM AGREES TO BUY WYOMING PROPERTIES
description: The Abraxas Petroleum Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire natural gas producing properties in Wyoming's Great Divide Basin for $47.5 million. The properties include total estimated reserves of about 87 billion cubic feet of oil equivalent -- a combination of natural gas and oil. That amount would double the company's current average daily output. The company, an energy concern based in San Antonio, did not disclose the seller.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CASTLE HARLAN IN DEAL TO MERGE 2 MAKERS OF CLASS RINGS
description: Castle Harlan Inc., a New York-based commercial bank, agreed yesterday to acquire the class ring businesses of the Town and Country Corporation and CJC Holdings Inc. for about $180 million. The combined businesses, which include the Balfour and Art Carved lines, had combined revenue of about $155 million in 1995 and would be the second-largest United States maker of class rings. Town and Country, based in Chelsea, Mass., will have a minority equity interest in a new holding company to be called Class Rings Inc. Jostens Inc. has about a 45 percent share of the class ring market. Town and Country and CJC each have about 20 percent.

title: Art in Review
description: George Maciunas 'More Than Fluxus' Ubu Gallery 16 East 78th Street Manhattan Through June 22

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: COLOR GRAPHICS, Moorestown, N.J., a maker of direct-mail products, signed an agreement to be acquired by Anthony Nardiello, its chief executive, and an investment group headed by Eric L. Blum of Philadelphia.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;ABC's All-News Cable Channel Is Shelved
description: In a decision that marked a full-blown retreat for the leading network news division, ABC announced yesterday that it was indefinitely postponing its plans to begin a 24-hour all-news cable channel.

title: THE AD CAMPAIGN;Labor Takes on Its Congressional Foes
description: This is a version of a new 30-second television commercial that the American Federation of Labor began broadcasting on Monday in the districts of 20 Republican members of Congress. After Republican complaints that the commercials are misleading, a handful of stations pulled them, asking that they be modified or that their assertions be further documented. At least two stations have refused to broadcast the commercials again.

description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Suspect Traced by New Car
description: Acting on a tip from a witness, police officers rousted a Ford dealer from his bed early yesterday and tracked down a suspect accused of fleeing the scene of a fatal car accident, the authorities said. Enrique A. Gonzalez, 48, was hit by a green Ford Aerostar bearing a temporary license plate and a decal from Loman Ford, a dealer in Parsippany, on Wednesday night while walking on Route 46, said Capt. Christopher Linne of the Morris County prosecutor's office.

title: TV SPORTS;Who Will Take Checkered Flag in Ratings Race?
description: When 2 P.M. tolls on Sunday, will the Indianapolis 500 maintain its ratings strength on ABC as it did last year, or will a couple million racing fans switch to the upstart U.S. 500 on ESPN with all the top drivers on display?
