description: David Cone said he does not want to become a distraction. That is why, he said, he has been keeping a low profile since holding a news conference nine days ago to address his situation upon his release from the hospital.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TOTAL-TEL REJECTS A TAKEOVER OFFER AS INSUFFICIENT
description: Total-Tel USA Communications Inc. rejected yesterday an unsolicited takeover bid of $46 million from Tel-Save Holdings Inc., calling the offer insufficient. Tel-Save, based in New Hope, Pa., had offered $26 in cash and stock for each of Total-Tel's 1.8 million outstanding shares. Both companies provide long-distance telephone services to small and medium-sized businesses. Total-Tel, based in Little Falls, N.J., had 1995 revenue of $50 million. Tel-Save had revenue of $194.5 million in the 12 months ended March 31. Total-Tel's shares rose $2 yesterday, to $27, in Nasdaq trading; Tel-Save's shares fell $1.50, to $22.25.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a resolution by the Association of Justices of the Supreme Court of the State of New York, criticizing Gov. George E. Pataki's proposal to eliminate parole for violent felons, misstated the authorship of the resolution. It was drawn up by the association's executive committee, not by Justice Burton B. Roberts of the Bronx.

title: U.S. Expands Status Checks On Job Seekers
description: Stepping up its assault on illegal immigration, the Clinton Administration today announced a nationwide expansion of a pilot program in California that requires participating employers to verify the legal status of job seekers.

description: Arms Sting Detailed

title: Manager of Biggest Mutual Fund Quits After Recent Subpar Gains
description: Jeffrey N. Vinik, the embattled portfolio manager of Fidelity Magellan, the country's largest mutual fund, resigned yesterday, stepping out of the spotlight as Wall Street's most closely watched investment manager.

title: ART REVIEW;Chinese Ceramics Hold History's Intimate Details
description: For many Westerners, it takes a leap of faith to put craft-based art like pre-Columbian textiles, Islamic calligraphy or Chinese ceramics on the pedestal reserved for painting and sculpture. Yet that leap can prove effortless in the right circumstances.

title: India's Ethnic Pathos
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about Sam Lopata, who designed a number of New York restaurants, gave an incorrect date for the opening of one of them. The restaurant, Joanna, was opened in 1980, not 1978.

title: Art in Review
description: David Hockney Robert Miller Gallery and Andre Emmerich Gallery 41 East 57th Street Manhattan Through June 15

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Taub Approved as Nets' Chairman
description: The board of directors of the New Jersey Nets held their annual meeting last night in East Rutherford, N.J., and approved the selection of HENRY TAUB as the new chairman.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HORSE RACING;Mott Is Fined $1,000 by N.Y.R.A.
description: New York Racing Association stewards have fined the trainer BILL MOTT $1,000 for allowing a horse he trains, Sir Cat, to arrive in the paddock for a recent race at Belmont Park wearing shoes prohibited by the N.Y.R.A. The stewards said that Mott had failed to heed a previous warning from them on the subject. Mott also trains Cigar, the 1995 Horse of the Year. (AP)

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Pickets on 42d Street

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Deutsche Telekom In Malaysia Purchase
description: Deutsche Telekom said yesterday that it would buy a 21 percent stake in Malaysia's biggest mobile phone company, TRI, and was discussing alliances with companies in Thailand and the Philippines. Herbert Mueller, Deutsche Telekom's Asia Pacific managing director, declined to say which Asian companies Deutsche Telekom was talking to. He said the company was "most likely to concentrate" on the Philippines and Thailand.

title: POLITICS: THE PRESIDENT;Clinton Says G.O.P. Aims to Divide
description: President Clinton today defended his stand on same-sex marriage and sharply accused Senator Bob Dole and the Republicans of using highly charged social issues to divide the country.

title: Pioneer Electronic Losses
description: The Pioneer Electronic Corporation said today that lower margins on key products resulted in deeper losses for the year ended in March. Pioneer's net loss widened to 9.99 billion yen, or $93.4 million, compared with 1.19 billion yen a year earlier. Sales were 506.60 billion yen, or $4.73 billion, down from 509.79 billion yen a year ago. Pioneer said tougher competition globally, a trend toward lower prices for home electronics products and slow domestic sales of commercial video products contributed to the greater losses.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Spanish Airline Finally Turns a Profit
description: Spain's state airline, Iberia, said yesterday that it had an operating profit of 2.9 billion pesetas ($22.55 million) in the first four months of the year, the first profitable showing in this period since 1989. Juan Saez, president of Iberia, forecast the company would have net income of 20 billion pesetas this year, after a loss of 44.9 billion pesetas in 1995.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasury Prices Decline In Slow Day
description: Treasury prices fell yesterday, weighed down by concerns about new supply coming to market and speculation about hedge funds liquidating some of their Treasury holdings.

title: An 'Epidemic of Terror'
description: This week's Congressional hearing on the wave of arson attacks against African-American churches in the South was both timely and necessary. But the proceedings offered little solace for the worshipers who have been burned out of their churches -- or the thousands of others who fear that they will be next. Though some cases have been solved, Federal officials say most of the perpetrators will be difficult to find and punish.

title: 7 French Monks Reported Killed By Islamic Militants in Algeria
description: The Armed Islamic Group in Algeria said today that it had killed seven French monks who were kidnapped two months ago from a monastery south of Algiers.

title: Market Place;Big Tobacco's Victory Creates Joy and Profit On Wall Street
description: A sweeping victory by the tobacco industry in a Federal court yesterday set off a buying spree on Wall Street for cigarette companies, helping the stock market recover much of its losses for the day. The Dow Jones industrial average, which had been down as much as 73.88 points, ended the day at 5,762.12, off 15.88.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;Borg Resting After Collapsing on Tour
description: The former tennis star BJORN BORG was resting yesterday in his parents' home outside Stockholm after collapsing before a seniors tour final last weekend. Borg, who turns 40 on June 6, collapsed before he was to play JOSE-LUIS CLERC of Argentina last Sunday at Mook, the Netherlands. He was taken to a hospital and released after being examined. MARGARETA BORG, his mother, denied reports that Borg had suffered from epilepsy. (AP)

title: Republican Senate Passes Budget Blueprint
description: Senate Republicans passed their six-year road map for a balanced Federal budget on a party-line vote late today, as everyone expected. What no one expected was an uncommon spate of bipartisan good feeling that very nearly swept a different blueprint to passage in its stead.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AN INVESTOR GROUP LOOKS TO SAVE HATHAWAY
description: Warnaco Group Inc. said yesterday that it had entered an exclusive agreement with an investor group headed by John R. McKernan Jr., the former Governor of Maine, to develop a proposal to buy the Hathaway trade name and the manufacturing plants in Waterville, Me., and Prescott, Ontario. Warnaco, the New York-based maker of women's intimate apparel, wil keep the plants open for three extra months to enable the investor group to propose and complete the deal, and to bring about a smooth transition. Warnaco said this month that it would stop making and marketing its Hathaway men's dress shirts and sell the business or close the plants where Hathaway shirts are made. According to a statement from Warnaco, Mr. McKernan said he was looking for more investors.

title: Pataki Outlaws Herbal Stimulant Linked to Deaths
description: Gov. George E. Pataki has announced an immediate statewide ban on the sale of so-called Herbal Ecstacy and other herbal products containing the stimulant ephedra, which has been blamed for 15 deaths nationwide.

title: Yeltsin and Chechen Leader Plan Peace Talks
description: In a surprise move with powerful implications for President Boris N. Yeltsin's effort to win re-election, the Kremlin announced today that Mr. Yeltsin and the leader of the rebels in Chechnya plan to hold talks in Moscow.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Trucks Flee the Turnpike
description: Ever since truck tolls on the New Jersey Turnpike doubled in 1991, to $20 for the turnpike's full length, many truck drivers have been avoiding the turnpike and using secondary roads to cross the state. Critics say that big rigs are causing road wear, noise and safety problems in central New Jersey. Yesterday, Carl J. Mayer, a Princeton Township committeeman who is running for Congress, led a 10-car caravan from Lawrence to Montgomery Township on Route 206 to push for a Federal ban on long-haul trucks from state non-toll roads except for local deliveries. Sam Cunninghame, executive director of the New Jersey Motor Truck Association, called instead for toll reductions, including volume discounts, to lure truckers back to the turnpike. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Art in Review
description: 'The Art of Peter Voulkos' The American Craft Museum 40 West 53d Street Manhattan Through June 9

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 16 about attempts to improve the safety record of the taxi fleet in Nairobi, Kenya, misstated the etymology of the Ki-swahili colloquialism for the minivans that make up the bulk of the fleet. Matatu, literally meaning threes, derives from the fare of 30 cents (mateni matatu, or three 10-cent pieces) originally charged by drivers, not from the practice of people banding together to operate the taxis. This correction was delayed for consultation with authorities on Kiswahili.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Faithful To Its Past, A Troupe Is Reborn
description: A dance troupe rose like a phoenix from its ashes on Tuesday night at St. Mark's Church. Reorganized after a two-year hiatus, the Joyce Trisler Danscompany offered a program that affirmed not only its own past but also a whole modern-dance tradition. And the performers looked ahead to the future, as well.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Get Shorty 1995. MGM/UA. $103.91. Laser disk, $34.98. 105 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Tuesday.

title: Fire Damages Stage of Old Paradise Theater
description: The old Loew's Paradise Theater, once the showplace of the Bronx and the jewel of the Grand Concourse but more recently a symbol of the decline of the neighborhood around it, suffered another indignity yesterday when fire heavily damaged a vaudeville-era stage.

title: San Francisco Housing Authority Serves as a Model of Decay
description: Residents of the Plaza East housing project in central San Francisco have a nickname for their crumbling high-rises: "O. C.," for out of control.

title: Hundreds Flee School in Bronx As Lab's Fumes Sicken Dozens
description: Nearly 800 children were evacuated from a Bronx elementary school yesterday morning after a nearby chemical plant spewed throat-burning, eye-watering fumes into the school's open windows, leaving some children vomiting and struggling for breath, city officials said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Warwick Baker Gets Used-Car Account
description: Driver's Mart Worldwide Inc. in Grand Rapids, Mich., a new company that plans to open a national chain of used-car stores this year, said yesterday that it had named Warwick Baker O'Neill in New York to handle its account, which will include advertising, direct marketing, point-of-sale materials and event marketing.

title: Midwest Utilities Amend Merger Plan
description: The electric utilities IES Industries, Interstate Power and WPL Holdings said today that they had amended the stock ratio of their planned $2.1 billion three-way merger agreement.

title: Judah Wattenberg, Technion Executive, 96
description: Judah Wattenberg, the first executive director of what is now the American Technion Society, a group that raises money for Technion, a technical university in Israel, died on Tuesday at his home on the West Side of Manhattan. He was 96.

title: Ballot-Fraud Investigation
description: More than 1,600 ballots cast for a write-in candidate seeking re-election to a Bronx community school board are being examined for possible fraud and tampering, officials said yesterday.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;New York Not in Jordan Plan
description: The Knicks have Jeff Van Gundy, and as a result they won't be getting Michael Jordan. Jordan today ruled out playing in New York without Coach Phil Jackson next season after the Knicks gave Van Gundy a two-year contract extension on Wednesday.

title: New Jobless Claims Drop by 7,000 in Week
description: The number of first-time claims for jobless benefits dropped by 7,000 last week.

title: BASEBALL;Yanks' Center-Field Phenom Off to Promising Start
description: It was about as auspicious a beginning as the Yankees could possibly have hoped for.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Cowens Will Coach Hornets
description: DAVE COWENS will be hired as coach of the Charlotte Hornets next week, according to a published report.

title: ART REVIEW;Architectural Dreams From Britain's Age of Greatness
description: As a title, "Soane: Connoisseur and Collector" may not be a grabber in the class of "Faberge" or "Splendors of Imperial China." Nor is Sir John Soane's Museum in London a mandatory stop on the tour bus circuit. But in its quiet and civilized way, the current show at the Frick Collection will be irresistible to anyone who cares for a great age in English architecture and decoration.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Carmen Miranda: Bananas Is My Business 1995. Fox Lorber. 90 minutes. In English and Portuguese with English subtitles. No rating. Release date: Tuesday.

title: Agency Head Erased Files After U.S. Inquiry Began
description: The executive of a Queens nonprofit agency who obtained $43 million in city welfare contracts now under investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation deleted dozens of files from his office computer in the hours before he was dismissed in March.

title: FILM REVIEW;Tormentors' Cruel Acts, In the Bedroom and Out
description: Equating imperious sexual cruelty with a totalitarian mind-set, Nicolas Roeg's film "Two Deaths" makes one of the riskiest comparisons that a serious movie could formulate between private behavior and public deportment. Yes, we know power corrupts, and we've all heard stories about pedophilic dictators and sadistic generalissimos. But how reasonable is it to assume that organized political oppression has its corollary in the imperial bedroom? This alternately talky and gory allegory about the fall of Communism and sexual power games makes a vivid if somewhat muddled argument for the existence of such a relationship.

title: Ford Selling Rail Business To Unit of First Union Bank
description: The Ford Motor Company, which said last fall that it intended to get rid of its nonautomotive finance operations, took a step in that direction yesterday, announcing that it had agreed to sell its rail-services business to a unit of the First Union Corporation for about $900 million.

title: Anger at French Troops Grows in Central Africa
description: A mutiny by unpaid soldiers in the Central African Republic showed signs today of turning into a popular uprising against French intervention in the country, after French soldiers came to the aid of the Government.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When JOSEPH H. FLOM joined Skadden, Arps & Slate in 1948 after graduation from Harvard Law School, he became the first associate hired by the three-man law firm.

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;Wings on Top In a Paradise For Scorers
description: They say the thin air of this Rocky Mountain city does wonderful things to batted baseballs. It makes them jump over fences for home runs. Could it have a similar effect on hockey pucks jumping into goals?

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;At Japanese Banks, Looks Are Deceiving
description: For Japan's banks, 1995 was the year of the $150 billion reckoning.

title: Diner's Journal
description: New Raw Bar

title: THEATER REVIEW;Film-Noir Culprits, Pursuing the Loot
description: IT'S night on a hillside in northern California. The puttering sound of helicopters can be heard overhead. Also the muffled whooshing noises of distant explosions. Wisps of smoke drift across the scene. Two men are illuminated by the flickering light of a giant, out-of-control brush fire, common in California in the dry season. One man wears dark glasses and is as bald as a bowling ball. The other is lean and sinewy, his angular features smudged with new ash. As they stare out over the audience, both men are transported by the spectacle they're witnessing.

title: Percy Klingenstein, 100, Surgeon And Professor at Mount Sinai
description: Dr. Percy Klingenstein, who was associated with the Mount Sinai Hospital and Medical Center for more than 75 years, died Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. The Mount Sinai Alumni Association commemorated his 100th birthday -- along with its own centennial -- in January.

title: Westinghouse Seeks Purchase
description: The parent company of CBS, the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, has been talking with the owners of Telenoticias, a Spanish-language cable news channel, about the possibility of buying it.

title: P.& G. to Acquire a Baby Products Unit of Scott
description: The Kimberly-Clark Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell the Scott Paper Company's baby wipes business to the Procter & Gamble Company for $220 million.

title: For the Leader of Colombia, Clouds Lift
description: Three months ago the world was closing in on President Ernesto Samper.

title: High-Risk Optimism in Albany
description: Faced with demands for painful spending cuts by Gov. George Pataki, Republicans and Democrats in New York's State Legislature have reverted to election-year irresponsibility. They want to close the projected budget deficit this year by imagining it away.

title: Free (Not) to Farm
description: Drought in the Plains states, along with spiraling grain prices and the specter of inflation in food costs, is drawing needed attention to farm policy.

title: For Children
description: Hsiao Hsi Yuan Puppet Theater Taipei Theater McGraw-Hill Building 1221 Avenue of the Americas, at 48th Street (212) 373-1850 Recommended ages: 8 and up Tonight through Sunday

title: 7 Suspects Accused Of Smuggling Guns Into California : 'Sting' Case Further Tests U.S.-China Relations
description: WASHINGTON  Reports that Treasury agents had arrested seven people allegedly linked to two arms companies run by the Chinese government  for smuggling 2,000 automatic rifles into the United States  touched off an angry response here Thursday, with one Democratic congressman saying he would re-examine his support for renewal of China's favored trade status.

title: A Fund to Bail Out Countries in Crisis Is Doubled, to $50 Billion
description: The big industrial nations agreed today with a group of smaller countries to double the money available for dealing with a severe international financial crisis, to $50 billion.

title: Max Rubin, 90, Lawyer, Dies; Headed Board of Education
description: Max J. Rubin, a lawyer who took his first step toward becoming president of the New York City Board of Education when his wife sent him to a suburban Parent-Teacher Association meeting in 1946, died on Wednesday at the Fairhaven Life Care Community, a retirement facility in Sykesville, Md. He was 90.

title: Profit at NEC Surges in Year
description: The NEC Corporation, Japan's biggest chip maker, said today that group profit more than doubled in the latest fiscal year amid a global surge in the sale of personal computers. NEC said it expected net income to grow a further 10 percent in the current fiscal year as interest heightened in the Internet and multimedia. But with chip prices weakening, some analysts said the company's outlook was too optimistic.

title: NYC;Jackson's Son Makes Points In Old Arena
description: WE are not each other's problem," the Congressman said. "African-Americans and Jewish-Americans need to build coalitions not for social niceties but for mutual survival and because our mutual commitment to social justice depends on it." Sure, there are differences, he added, but "we can honestly agree or disagree without becoming disagreeable."

title: Of Executive Honor
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;GUESS TO RAISE $188 MILLION IN PUBLIC OFFERING
description: Guess Inc., the well-known designer of blue jeans and other types of casual apparel, said in a filing yesterday that it planned to raise about $188 million through an initial public offering. The company plans to sell 9.2 million common shares at $21 to $23 each, according to its filing. Founded by the Marciano brothers in 1981, Guess markets its apparel under the trademarks Guess, Guess U.S.A. and Triangle Design. Guess expects the offering to raise about $188 million after expenses if the stock sells for $22 a share. The company will use the proceeds to repay notes.

title: BASEBALL;Griffey Rips Kamieniecki And Yanks
description: A cynic would claim Scott Kamieniecki made progress tonight, because he pitched twice as long as he had in his previous two starts and still allowed the same sum of six runs. A realist would correctly insist that Kamieniecki made no progress against the Mariners and seriously damaged his precarious status in an injury-ravaged starting rotation. Laugh with the cynic and agree with the realist.

title: After 2 Big Losses, Mazda Reports Razor-Thin Profit
description: The Mazda Motor Corporation, whose two years of heavy losses led to its effective takeover by the Ford Motor Company last month, reported today that it had returned to profitability, barely, in the latest fiscal year.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Pitino Nears a Decision on Nets' Extravagant Offer
description: Rick Pitino sounds as if he is coming home again, for what that is worth. The Kentucky coach came up with another crossover move yesterday when he said he was considering a new offer from the Nets that would make him head coach, general manager and a part-owner.

title: COMPANY NEWS;WASHINGTON WATER POWER UNIT ADDS MARKETING CONCERN
description: The Washington Water Power Company said yesterday that its Pentzer Corporation unit, the corporate investment arm, had acquired F. O. Phoenix Inc., a marketing concern, for an undisclosed amount. Washington Water, an electric and natural-gas utility, said the purchase would help Pentzer's growth in the consumer-product promotion industry. F. O. Phoenix, which has annual sales of $40 million, provides displays, promotional packaging and similar services for consumer products companies. F. O. Phoenix, based in Sussex, N.J., will continue to operate independently.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Gagne Placed on Disabled List
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers have placed shortstop GREG GAGNE on the 15-day disabled list retroactive to May 18 because of a sprained left ankle. Gagne, 34, who signed as a free agent with the Dodgers on Nov. 30, is hitting .250 with 4 homers and 13 runs batted in. He is hitless in his last 18 at-bats.

title: PROGNOSIS: POOR -- Second of Two articles.;Managed Care for Needy: Giuliani's Unrealized Plan
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's ambitious quest to save the city hundreds of millions of dollars by shepherding most of New York's 1.2 million Medicaid recipients into managed-care plans has not met the administration's forecasts.

title: Music in Review
description: A Singer With Raw Anguish And Stories to Tell Patty Griffin Fez

title: DANCE REVIEW;Portraying Tender Love As 4 Saxes Call the Tune
description: Twilight," which Ulysses Dove has choreographed as the first premiere in the New York City Ballet's current season, is the mellow companion piece to "Red Angels," his explosive hit for the company in 1994.

title: City Cancels 26 Contracts For Agencies
description: The Giuliani administration yesterday canceled more than two dozen city contracts awarded to agencies to provide services for immigrants and ordered that the contracts be put out for bid again, citing concerns about how the deals -- worth a total of $2.5 million -- were made.

title: Home-Care Attendant Held In Deaths of Elderly Women
description: A home-care attendant who had cared for two elderly women found beaten to death last week was charged with murder last night in the Brooklyn killings.

title: U.S. Hints About a Withdrawal From Talks on Maritime Trade
description: The United States signaled today that it was withdrawing from the negotiations to liberalize world trade in maritime services, diplomats said, dealing another blow to the fledgling World Trade Organization.

title: A Family Is Found Slain 6 Hours After '911' Calls
description: The bodies of a 31-year-old woman and her two young children were found in their Brooklyn apartment early yesterday, six hours after officers responding to two anonymous 911 calls from the building found nothing amiss.

title: Ariel Sharon Keeps Talons Very Sharp
description: Not one for chasing after the "floating vote" with dovish posturing, Ariel Sharon has published a hard-line article in the Israeli press just as the conservative Likud Party candidate, Benjamin Netanyahu, is trying to soften his image before elections next week.

title: Toward a Less Perfect Union
description: There is more than a little irony in the so-called Defense of Marriage Act, the proposed Federal law that would allow states to deny recognition to same-sex marriages that might be accorded full legal status in other states.

title: INSIDE
description: Pressure Builds in Siege

title: New Jersey Daily Briefings;A Cause Takes to the Air
description: Those advertising banners that airplanes tow lazily along the seashore will show more than pitches for beer, bars and suntan oil this weekend. A coalition of environmental groups has hired a plane to tow a banner reading, "Say No to E.P.A. Toxic Ocean Dumping." The coalition, Clean Ocean Action, said yesterday that it is seeking public support in its opposition to the Federal Environmental Protection Agency's proposal to expand a sludge-dumping site in the ocean six miles southeast of Sandy Hook. The expansion is one of several options being considered to dispose of contaminated sludge dredged from shipping channels in New York Harbor.

title: Patients Turn to Chiropractors for Both Pain and Financial Relief
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;SPRINT AGREES TO CUT ON LONG-DISTANCE CONTRACT
description: The Sprint Corporation said yesterday that it agreed in principle to cut by $86 million its bill for the last two and a half years of a contract to provide long-distance phone service to the United States General Services Administration. The volume discounts eliminate cost differences on long-distence contracts among Federal agencies, John Okay, deputy commissioner of the G.S.A.'s Federal Telecommunications Service, said.

title: Sighs Sum Up D'Amato's Verdict As Whitewater Panel Nears End
description: After 53 public hearings, 264 depositions and $1.3 million in costs, the Senate's intensive year of Whitewater inquiry is wending to an anticlimactic close with Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato still presiding, but with his poll ratings on the wane and his humility noticeably on the rise.

title: April Orders For Durables Down 1.9%
description: Orders for durable goods fell 1.9 percent in April because of slack demand for aircraft, the Government said today, as the sluggish recovery in manufacturing crept forward.

title: At Annapolis, a Speech on Integrity
description: A troublesome school year at the United States Naval Academy here ended today with Gen. John M. Shalikashvili, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, telling the 1996 graduating class that as naval officers, they have chosen to live by "a higher code of conduct."

title: News Summary
description: International 2-6

title: COMPANY NEWS;MAY STORES PLANNING A $4 BILLION EXPANSION PROGRAM
description: The May Department Stores Company said yesterday that it would spend almost $4 billion in the next five years to open 125 new stores and expand and remodel another 70. The department store company also plans to modernize its distribution centers and equipment. The announcement of the expansion comes at a time that many other retail chains are cutting back store openings to reduce costs. In 1996 alone, May will invest more than $750 million to open 29 new stores. Its chains include Lord & Taylor, Filene's and Robinsons-May. May, based in St. Louis, currently operates 347 department stores in 30 states and the District of Columbia, with annual sales of more than $10.5 billion.

title: Once Bitten, Twice Shy;Jumpy Suburbanites See Rabies Lurking All Over
description: In Mahopac, N.Y., a fox jumped through the window of a patrol car and attacked a policeman. A disoriented squirrel scattered a screaming kindergarten class in Greenwich, Conn. And in backyards around the metropolitan region, lawmen armed with rifles and trappers with cages are dispatching raccoons, foxes and skunks as if they had a price on their heads.

title: Sports of The Times;Calm Shaq In the Eye Of the Storm
description: There is a mysterious cycle in human events. To some generations much is given. Of other generations much is expected. This generation of Americans has a rendezvous with destiny."

title: Two Dismissals at the Roundabout
description: Officials of the Roundabout Theater Company said yesterday that its "Thousand Clowns" had been postponed because the star, Robert Klein, and the director, Gene Saks, had been dismissed from the show.

title: Actress Collapses in 'Ideal Husband'
description: An actress collapsed onstage last night during the second act of "An Ideal Husband" at the Ethel Barrymore Theater.

title: Piltdown Man Hoaxer: Missing Link Is Found
description: It was one of the great hoaxes of the 20th century, bigger than the famous photograph of the Loch Ness Monster, the Hitler diaries and the mysterious crop circles that appeared in farmers' fields, evoking thoughts of energy fields, aliens and sprites. But when the Piltdown man, a pile of bones found in Sussex and hailed in 1912 as the "missing link" in the evolutionary chain, was declared in 1953 to be an elaborate ruse, another beguiling mystery remained. Whose ruse was it?

title: Journal;I Got You, Babe
description: Who says this has been a do-nothing Congress? I can't speak for your household, but my wife and I were delighted by the news that Republicans and Democrats alike in the House and Senate are lining up to support the Defense of Marriage Act. At last bipartisanship rules within the Beltway. Bob Dole is a lead co-sponsor of the bill. President Clinton this week announced that he'd sign it the moment it reached his desk. Banished from the language forthwith is the question "Can this marriage be saved?" Thanks to our Congress, every marriage -- yours, mine, Larry Fortensky's -- will be defended from harm, till death do us part.

title: POLITICS: THE AD CAMPAIGN;Attacking Dole, Not by Name
description: This is a 30-second commercial, called "Empty," that was released on Friday by the Clinton/Gore '96 Primary Committee and is to be broadcast in about half the country, starting today.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Memorial Day will be observed on Monday.

title: Three Found Slain Hours After '911' Calls
description: The bodies of a 31-year-old woman and her two young children were found in their East Flatbush apartment, six hours after officers responding to two anonymous 911 calls found nothing amiss.

title: Burmese Crackdown May Be Tactical Victory for Opposition
description: With a sweep of more than 200 arrests around the country, the military Government of Myanmar has succeeded in preventing a full-scale meeting this weekend of the democratic opposition party that won a parliamentary election six years ago but was never allowed to take power.

title: Circumcision Is a Human Rights Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;CLINTRIALS IN BID FOR BIO-RESEARCH LABORATORIES
description: Clintrials Research Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the closely held Bio-Research Laboratories for about $65 million plus an unspecified amount of debt. Clintrials said it intended to sell stock to pay for the acquisition. The combined companies will offer pre-clinical and full clinical development services, Clintrials said. Clintrials is based in Nashville and Bio-Research is based in Senneville, Quebec. Clintrials stock edged down 12.5 cents yesterday, to $43.75, in Nasdaq trading.

title: For Shuttle Crew, a Few Hours of Time Off
description: After repairing a $1.5 million on-board Coke machine, releasing two satellites, retrieving one and revisiting the other, the six astronauts aboard the space shuttle Endeavour took a six-hour break today.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefings;Court Date for Sign Laws
description: Bergen County towns that require commercial signs in a foreign language to give equal space to an English translation have a date in court to defend their positions. On Thursday, Judge William G. Bassler of Federal District Court here scheduled a June 24 hearing on the constitutionality of the sign laws in Ridgefield, Englewood Cliffs, Leonia, Cliffside Park, Palisades Park and Fort Lee, which have been challenged by Korean business people in the area.

title: Jay Allen, 79, Agent and Creator of Celebrities
description: Jay Allen, a publicity agent who turned authors into celebrities and their books into best sellers by cultivating a mass audience, died on Wednesday at Cedars Sinai Medical Center. He was 79.

title: Circumcision Is a Human Rights Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Japan's Steelmakers Report Strong Results
description: Led by the Nippon Steel Company, profits at Japan's top five steelmakers rose in the most recent fiscal year as cost-cutting offset slow sales. Nippon Steel, the world's largest steelmaker, said its pretax profit quintupled to 64.7 billion yen ($606.9 million) in the year that ended in March. Sales were 2.09 trillion yen, up four-tenths of a percent.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Billions of Losses at Some of Japan's Big Banks
description: For decades, Japan's banking industry had strictly observed a taboo against loan provisions that led to corporate losses. But in a remarkable departure today from tradition, most of the nation's biggest banks announced huge provisions and a resulting river of red ink.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the crash of Valujet Flight 592 referred incorrectly to a statement by Lewis Jordan, the airline's president and chief operating officer, at a news conference in Atlanta about oxygen equipment carried as cargo on Valujet planes. Mr. Jordan said that the airline shipped and refilled oxygen bottles that were used to supply emergency masks on certain airplanes; his answer did not refer to oxygen generators, the small chemical reactors suspected of having caused the crash on May 11.

title: 3-Hour Annual Checkup Finds President to Be in Good Health
description: President Clinton was pronounced in good health today after his annual physical examination, although doctors removed a precancerous skin lesion from the tip of his nose.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;New Organ With an Early Baroque Sound
description: If a Colonial Dutch settler could be zapped from New Amsterdam of the 1620's to St. Thomas Church on Fifth Avenue today, he would recognize the new Loening-Hancock Organ as similar to the magnificent instruments of his native country. This instrument is now one of the most authentic early Baroque organs in the city. It took 14 artisans 20,000 man-hours to assemble it at the workshops of Taylor & Boody Organbuilders in Staunton, Va. On Tuesday night, the organ was dedicated in a concert by Frederick Swann.

title: World News Briefs;Albanians Sentence Ex-Leaders to Death
description: Five top officials of the former Communist Government were found guilty today of crimes against humanity; three were sentenced to die.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday showing smoking rates among teen-agers reversed the labels for white, non-Hispanic girls and boys. More girls smoke than boys, with the rate rising from 31.7 percent in 1991 to 39.8 percent in 1995; the rate for boys rose from 30.2 percent in 1991 to 37 percent in 1995.

title: When Memorial Day Was No Picnic
description: Tomorrow is the legislated Memorial Day, and the thoughts of most Americans turn to the price of gasoline or the sale at the local furniture store. School will soon be out and the summer driving season will begin, to end on the next legislated three-day holiday weekend, Labor Day. In hundreds of towns, Memorial Day parades may wind up at the local cemetery to pay tribute to the community's war dead, but most spectators will not follow along.

title: Financier Pleads Guilty in Banking Fraud
description: Michael Carlow, the financier who once owned the companies that make the Clark candy bar and Iron City beer, pleaded guilty in Federal District Court today to a $31 million fraud against the PNC Bank of Pittsburgh.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SANDOZ OFFERS TO PURCHASE REMAINING STAKE IN HOLDING
description: The Swiss drug company Sandoz A.G. said yesterday that it was offering to buy the rest of the majority-owned Systemix Inc. for about $70 million, sending stock of Systemix soaring 69 percent. Sandoz already holds a 71.6 percent stake in Systemix, which researches gene therapies for cancer, AIDS and genetic diseases. Sandoz is offering $17 a share for Systemix, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif. Systemix's shares jumped beyond that price yesterday, gaining $7.625, to reach $18.625 on the Nasdaq stock market.

title: Abbott Agrees to Settle Baby-Formula Suit
description: Abbott Laboratories said today that it had agreed to settle, for $32.5 million, lawsuits brought by 17 states that contended it had fixed the price of baby formula.

title: SUNY Selects 6 Educators As Chancellor Candidates
description: The trustees of the State University of New York are considering six longtime educators, including the former heads of public university systems in Texas, Connecticut and Indiana, to take over the 64-campus system when Chancellor Thomas A. Bartlett leaves next month, according to a person familiar with the search.

title: Admiral's Suicide Notes Will Be Kept Private
description: The Navy said today that it had no plans to make public the two suicide notes left by Adm. Jeremy M. Boorda, the Chief of Naval Operations, who shot himself last week after questions were raised about the legitimacy of two Vietnam War combat decorations that he had worn.

title: Water Main Breaks, Disrupting Midtown
description: A 67-year-old water main ruptured yesterday in midtown Manhattan, shutting off water service for the day and blocking traffic in the largely commercial area around 58th Street and Park Avenue.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MEDAPHIS SET TO ADD HEALTH DATA SCIENCES
description: The Medaphis Corporation, a provider of business management services to the health care industry, agreed yesterday to acquire the Health Data Sciences Corporation in a stock deal worth about $255.2 million. Under the agreement, Atlanta-based Medaphis will offer 6.13 million shares of its common stock for Health Data Sciences in a pooling of interests. Medaphis will also assume or issue stock options for an additional 556,000 shares of its common stock. Medaphis rose $1.5625, to $40.9325, in Nasdaq trading yesterday. Health Data Sciences, a closely held company in San Bernardino, Calif., supplies a patient-centered health care information system.

title: The Bronx Is Up, the Battery's Down and the Fleet Is in Town
description: In his crisp dress whites, Lieut. Paul Durso plunged into the sea of pin stripes at the wood-paneled bar.

title: Sensing a Shift by Constituents, Legislature Stands Up to Pataki
description: Martin H. Luster, a four-term Democratic Assemblyman from Ithaca, had a sudden political conversion more than a year ago when his constituents voted overwhelmingly in favor of placing George E. Pataki, a Republican, in the Governor's mansion.

title: Okinawa Journal;Angry Islanders Dig In For a Battle Over Bases
description: This verdant little seaside town seems a better site for a beach party than for a battlefield, but local officials are warning that they may have to fight it out with the United States armed forces.

title: Everest Is Mighty, We Are Fragile
description: Over the past few years, I have watched the public perception of Mount Everest drift from awe of the greatest mountain on earth and respect for anyone who succeeds in scaling it to an assumption that now things have changed.

title: DANCE REVIEW;A Choreographer Unafraid to Evoke Life's Dark Side
description: David Parsons is often a genial choreographer, but because he knows that the world is not always a carefree place, he can also suggest that he has weighty matters on his mind and strong feelings in his heart. The program his Parsons Dance Company presented on Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater had all the zip and bounce one expects from him, yet was basically serious in tone.

title: Qaddafi Goes to Egypt to Meet Mubarak
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, drove across the border with Egypt today on his way to meet President Hosni Mubarak for talks on the United Nations sanctions against Libya.

title: Corrections
description: The Movie Clock in Weekend yesterday misidentified the film scheduled this weekend for screen No. 1 at the Sony Lincoln Square Theater, Broadway and 68th Street, in Manhattan. At the times listed, the film will be "Twister," not "Mission Impossible."

title: COMPANY NEWS;HAWKER SIDDELEY AGREES TO SELL STAKE IN CGTX
description: Hawker Siddeley Canada Inc. agreed yesterday to sell its 55 percent interest in CGTX Inc., a rail-car-leasing business, to the GATX Corporation for about $83.6 million, in accord with a judgment issued by an Ontario court. GATX, Hawker Siddeley's partner in the concern, offered to buy the stake late last year. But Hawker, based in Mississauga, Ontario, rejected the bid and agreed to sell the stake to Procor Ltd., a company owned by Chicago-based Marmon Group Inc. GATX sued to stop the transaction, saying it had a right of first refusal on the CGTX interest. The Canadian court ruled in GATX's favor. GATX is a Chicago-based leasing, transportation, financial-services and bulk-storage concern.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article yesterday about CBS's "60 Minutes" program misstated the given name of one of its reporters. He is Tom Fenton, not James.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Commerzbank Says Profit Surged in Quarter
description: Commerzbank A.G., Germany's third-largest commercial bank, said yesterday that its profits surged by 57.8 percent in the first quarter of 1996. Commerzbank said its operating profit before deduction of provisions for bad debt soared to 874 million marks ($566.9 million).

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;Panthers Outshoot, and Outslug, the Penguins
description: The star-studded Pittsburgh Penguins came into Game 3 of the Eastern Conference finals against the Florida Panthers with a gaudy 5-0 playoff road record and with boasts of being more focused as a visiting team than at the Igloo.

title: Circumcision Is a Human Rights Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: Evading the Doctor
description: Eighteen months ago, I had reason to believe I might be H.I.V.-positive, and decided to get tested. My therapist made an appointment for me with a doctor who performs an AIDS test that gives the result in 15 minutes.

title: Deep in Kashmir, a Hunt for Hostages
description: Thick, swirling mists envelop the forbidding vastness of the Himalayas above this trekking village where an American, two Britons and a German have disappeared after being seized last July as hostages in Kashmir's guerrilla war.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: New Jersey Daily Briefings;New Charge in Trooper Death
description: Louis D. Goodman, 19, accused of being the motorcyclist who led a state trooper on a chase that caused the trooper's death, pleaded not guilty yesterday to manslaughter. The charge was upgraded from aggravated assault after Trooper Francis J. Bellaran, 32, died Thursday night of injuries suffered Monday when his cruiser, pursuing a motorcycle he believed to be stolen, crashed on the Garden State Parkway. Mr. Goodman's lawyer, Steven E. Nelson, refused to comment.

title: No Headline
description: You know what this region is called? It is called Leningrad. That place for the liberals and the foreigners is called St. Petersburg now. They changed the name. But the peasants here never did change the name. And we never will. Because there is really no reason to be like them."

title: The Deal Offered by Philip Morris
description: The dismissal this week of a huge class-action lawsuit against the nation's major tobacco companies eases the biggest liability threat to the industry. That makes it all the more imperative to look critically at a proposal by Philip Morris that seeks to remove the biggest regulatory threat as well. Essentially, the company is offering to accept some legislative restrictions to curb smoking by teen-agers in exchange for a legislative ban on regulatory intervention by the Food and Drug Administration. But with the rate of smoking among teen-agers continuing to rise, this is no time to hand over a regulatory club that could drive the entire industry toward more responsible behavior.

title: Holiday Closings
description: All financial and commodity markets and banks in the United States will be closed on Monday in observance of Memorial Day. A number of European markets, including those in Germany and Britain, will also be closed for local holidays.

title: Ralph Harper, 80, Priest Who Explored Existentialist Themes
description: The Rev. Ralph Harper, a philosopher and theologian who wrote more than a dozen books exploring existentialist themes in modern literary classics, in fairy tales and even in spy thrillers, died yesterday at the Stella Maris Hospice in Baltimore. He was 80 and lived in Monkton, Md.

title: POLITICS: THE CHARACTER ISSUE;NEW ADS TO INJECT ISSUE OF INTEGRITY INTO THE CAMPAIGN
description: In the kind of broadside attacks usually reserved for the waning days of summer, the Clinton campaign and the Republican Party are preparing to broadcast commercials directly assaulting the character of the opposition candidate.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefings;Gasoline Prices Up Again
description: Gasoline prices rose an average of about 1.5 cents a gallon during the first 20 days of May, the State Board of Public Utilities said yesterday. That was smaller than last month's 9.2-cent-a-gallon jump.

title: Man's Body Found In Bay Near Airport
description: A dead man found floating in a Long Island marina near Kennedy International Airport may have fallen from a jet after stowing away in the plane's wheel well, the authorities said yesterday.

title: College Needn't Be the Impossible Dream
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;TAKEOVER IS DENIED AS SYQUEST STOCK PRICE TUMBLES
description: The shares of Syquest Technology Inc. plunged yesterday after the company's chief financial officer punctured takeover rumors. Syquest fell $7, to $10.875, in Nasdaq trading of 13.9 million shares. The shares nearly tripled in the previous five days of trading, but in an interview on Thursday, the chief financial officer, John Luhtala, denied that the company had been approached about a takeover. "We're not engaged in talks to sell the company," he said. Earlier this month, the company hired the investment banker Needham & Company to find a buyer or new financing. Syquest makes computer disk drives with removable cartridges, which greatly expand the amount of data that users can save.

title: Psychologist Accused of Billing Fraud
description: New Jersey authorities have accused a Bergen County psychologist of masterminding a medical-insurance scam that was said to involve about $3 million in fraudulent claims and kickbacks to public employees, including teachers, officials said today.

title: A Few Miles Apart, 2 Russias Contend for Nation's Future
description: Andrei Valenko decided to buy some art this week. First he thought about a painting but they all looked too abstract to him. Then he settled on a pretty famous print.

title: Stores Say Kodak Is Slow With New Camera
description: The Eastman Kodak Company is falling short on delivering to retailers its new Advantix camera, part of an easy-to-use photo system that was intended to help raise sales industrywide, camera sellers said today.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefings;Four Hurt in Jail Fight
description: Two guards and two inmates were injured during a fight that broke out Thursday night at the Camden County Jail, Warden David Owens said yesterday. One of the injured officers was at Cooper Medical Center with a dislocated ankle and possible broken leg. Another officer and two inmates were treated and released, The A.P. said. The jail held 1,494 inmates yesterday -- about 1,000 above its capacity.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about charges filed in the death of a police officer in the Bronx referred incorrectly in some copies to an event that led up to his death. According to the police, the man charged with manslaughter in the case, Anthony Richard Rivers, threw a mirror at his girlfriend, Gloria Virgo, in a domestic dispute. She was not accused of having thrown one at him.

title: BALLET REVIEW;Bolshoi-Trained Dancers Join 'Romeo and Juliet'
description: Romeo and Juliet," in Kenneth MacMillan's version of Prokofiev's ballet score, returned to American Ballet Theater this week with two half-new sets of principals.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefings;What's in a Name? Money
description: When Continental Airlines bought the rights to name the former Brendan Byrne Arena after itself in January, people joked about what might come next: the Lincoln Continental Tunnel? the Trump Turnpike? Yesterday, the State Highway Authority wasn't kidding when it said it was negotiating to sell the right to rename the Garden State Arts Center, the 10,000-seat amphitheater on the Garden State Parkway. A spokesman for the authority wouldn't estimate a price or identify companies involved in the talks.

title: Federal Court Bans Student Prayer at High School Graduation
description: A Federal appeals court in Philadelphia ruled yesterday that a regional high school board in Camden County could not allow student-led prayers at its graduation.

title: Religion Journal;Helping Modern Readers Discover Ancient Voices
description: Since sundown on Thursday, Jews have been marking a festival of some significance, Shavuot, or the Feast of Weeks, celebrating the anniversary of when the biblical Hebrews received the Torah, or divine instruction. According to the Book of Exodus (19:1), three days after the Hebrews reached Mount Sinai, God gave his revelation to Moses, an act that helped distinguish the children of Israel as his holy people.

title: Chief of U.P.S. Will Retire
description: United Parcel Service of America Inc. said today that Kent C. Nelson, the chairman and chief executive, would retire at the end of the year.

title: Music in Review
description: On Black Life and Death In New York, 1794 to Now 'The Negros Burial Ground' 'A Cantata for the Departed' The Kitchen

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the observance of the Jewish holiday of Shavuot, the Feast of Weeks, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Computers Can Help Schools Find Solutions
description: To the Editor:

title: Sharon of Israel: Hawkish Talons as Sharp as Ever
description: A scarred veteran of many wars, military and political, Ariel Sharon is not for mincing words or chasing after the undecided vote with dovish posturing.

title: Mediators Lose Sympathy For Beleaguered Freemen
description: As the second month of the Freemen standoff in Montana ended today, no tangible results remained from weeks of negotiations by two right-wing mediators.

title: Clintons Pay Back Taxes Stemming From Whitewater
description: The White House disclosed today that President Clinton and his wife, Hillary, paid the Government $2,910 in back taxes and interest earlier this month as a result of incorrect income tax filings in the 1980's relating to their Whitewater real estate investment.

title: In Post-Cold-War Washington, Development Is a Hot Business
description: While foreign-policy makers have trouble even defining the post-cold-war era, Washington deal makers have already figured out how to make millions in it.

title: Scottsville Journal;After 3 Decades, a Local Legend Loses an Election
description: The posters, some handwritten and some stenciled, appeared one by one this spring in the window of Coleman's Mercantile, at the Silver Grill and on lampposts, pickup trucks and cars: "Write In A. R. Thacker for Mayor."

title: SOCCER;MetroStars' Firmani Steps Down As Coach
description: Eddie Firmani resigned today as coach of the MetroStars after meeting with Charlie Stillitano, the team's vice president and general manager.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Texas Drought Sends Cotton Up As Wheat and Copper Decline
description: Cotton futures prices rose yesterday on concerns that a drought in West Texas, where almost 20 percent of the American crop is grown, could cut production.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Thursday about a study of whether nurses in intensive care units ever deliberately hasten a patient's death referred incorrectly to the group surveyed. The survey comprised a national sample of 850 nurses who practiced exclusively in adult critical care units, not nurses generally.

title: Canadian Newspaper Empire Is Expanded
description: Conrad M. Black, the flamboyant newspaper entrepreneur, is moving to increase his already sizable stake in the Canadian newspaper industry.

title: Company Briefs
description: VESTRA TECHNOLOGIES INC., San Ramon, Calif., which provides radioactive-waste services and specialized engineering services, agreed to sell its nuclear engineering, government services and power services businesses to privately held Duke Engineering and Services Inc. for $27.5 million in cash.

title: A New Lesson in Hate Intrudes at One School
description: The pupils at the Keller Regional Gifted Center here were hustled into the building this morning as soon as they got off of their yellow school buses. Usually, they linger a few minutes before the bell rings. But the principal, Cynthia B. Dougal, did not want the children outside.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Talks With Varity On Track, Lucas Says
description: Lucas Industries said yesterday that its negotiations aimed at a merger with the Varity Corporation of Buffalo were proceeding well, though an announcement might not come until early June at the earliest. The two makers of auto parts are discussing a $4.6 billion stock swap, analysts say. They confirmed on May 6 that they were discussing a "strategic combination" of their businesses, although Lucas later ruled out a cash bid from Varity.

title: Croatia Has Rejected Official Language Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Lear to Buy Car-Parts Maker As Industry Consolidates The Lear Corporation, a large supplier of car seats and other car parts, plans to acquire the Masland Corporation, a maker of car interior carpets, in a $384 million deal that reflects the changes and consolidation in the international auto parts industry.

title: For Widow In Shootings, A Candidacy For Congress
description: Carolyn McCarthy, a nurse who became outspoken on crime issues after her husband was killed and her son grievously injured in the 1993 Long Island Rail Road shooting, said yesterday that she would run for Congress as a Democrat, even though she has been a Republican all her life.

title: Merrill to Curb Indiana Activity Because of Political Donation
description: Merrill Lynch & Company will refrain from selling securities for some Indiana agencies for two years because an official of the firm donated $1,000 to the state's Lieutenant Governor, a company spokesman said yesterday.

title: Lear Is Buying Manufacturer of Car Rugs
description: The Lear Corporation, a large supplier of car seats and other car parts, announced today that it would pay $384 million for the Masland Corporation, a maker of carpets for cars, in a deal that reflects the changes and consolidation in the international auto parts industry.

title: 2 Wounded by Shots Through Their Door
description: A man fired through the door of his former girlfriend's house, hitting her and critically wounding her son, then led the police on a chase for nearly 100 miles, the authorities said.

title: BASEBALL;Mets to Trade A Right Fielder
description: During the telecast of last night's game between the Padres and Mets, the broadcaster Tim McCarver reported that Mets General Manager Joe McIlvaine had told him that he was trying to trade one or more of the Mets' current right fielders -- Carl Everett, Butch Huskey, Chris Jones and Kevin Roberson-- in the next five days to make room for the team's No. 1 minor league prospect, Alex Ochoa, who is at Class AAA Norfolk.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;Sampras Draws Stiff Test at French Open
description: PETE SAMPRAS's path to the French Open title is packed with former champions. The top-seeded Sampras could face four French Open winners in this year's tournament, which begins Monday at Roland Garros.

title: The Burmese Crackdown
description: Nobody knows for certain how many backers of democracy have been arrested recently in Myanmar, formerly Burma, but the tally so far is more than 200. The crackdown comes as the Burmese military junta is seeking better relations with Japan and America. Its behavior is the best argument against granting trade or diplomatic concessions to an impenitent violator of human rights.

title: Unions Leave Yale on Edge With a Plan to Protest Graduation Rites
description: With Yale's 295th commencement three days away, this campus is on edge over who is going to be in town. Along with the thousands of proud parents and family friends, there may be hundreds of angry union members who are coming here, but not to celebrate the students' accomplishments.

title: Bridge
description: The usual rewards for success in American tournaments are prestige and masterpoints, but not cash. May in New York City offers three rare exceptions. The Cavendish Teams and Pairs, during the Mother's Day weekend, use a Calcutta format, with players and nonplayers buying shares in the contestants.

title: POLITICS;Clinton and the Military, Again
description: This is a 30-second commercial, called "Stripes," that was released on Friday by the Republican National Committee. It will be broadcast nationally on CNN as well as local Washington stations, starting on Monday at the earliest.

title: Prosecutor Is Berated By Giuliani
description: In an unusual outburst of emotion, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani lashed out at the Bronx District Attorney yesterday for filing manslaughter instead of murder charges against a man whose domestic dispute led to the death of a city police officer earlier this week.

title: March Fed Meeting Unanimous for Steady Rates
description: Federal Reserve policy makers voted unanimously at their March 26 meeting to keep the overnight bank lending rate unchanged, according to the minutes of the session, released today.

title: Central Africa Leader Vows To Govern With His Critics
description: With hundreds of French troops patrolling the streets of this devastated city to enforce a 6 P.M. curfew, the embattled President announced today that he would form a new government that would include his critics, so as to blunt opposition to his rule.

title: HORSE RACING;Unbridled's Song Is Entered in Peter Pan
description: He did not say absolutely, positively, cross-my-heart-and-hope-to-die, but Ernie Paragallo fixed the immediate agenda for Unbridled's Song yesterday when he entered the 3-year-old colt in tomorrow's Peter Pan Stakes and said, "We want to end up in the Belmont Stakes."

title: World News Briefs;U.S. Lawmaker to Meet North Korean Leaders
description: Representative Bill Richardson of New Mexico plans to fly to North Korea on Sunday in an effort to entice North Korea to accept President Clinton's proposal for peace talks.

title: Court Is Urged to Consider Race in College Admissions
description: Asserting that racial diversity in higher education is an important goal and that some form of affirmative action is necessary to accomplish it, the Clinton Administration asked the Supreme Court today to overturn a Federal appeals court's ruling that barred any consideration of race in admissions to the University of Texas Law School.

title: ROCK REVIEW;A Songwriter's Odyssey to Points of View He Once Observed
description: At the second of two concerts on Wednesday night at the Supper Club, Elvis Costello structured his performance as meticulously as he writes his songs. He opened his two-and-a-half hour set with a song that promised "showtime is almost here" ("King Horse") and ended demanding "give me a rest" in "I Want to Vanish." When he interrupted "Little Atoms" to tell a story about an encounter with a hostile interviewer, he resumed the song with the lyric in which he wishes damnation on those who don't like his music.

title: A Bigger Window on Science
description: New Yorkers of a certain age will recall the Museum of Science and Industry in the Daily News Building and later in Rockefeller Center. It folded. Boomers will recall the New York Hall of Science at the 1964 World's Fair. That one was shuttered in 1979. Its building languished until 1984, when the city hired the physicist Alan Friedman and pumped in funds to bring it back to life.

title: Observer;The Joy of Fear Itself
description: All day yesterday it was the Venetian blinds that had me terrified. The previous day it had been air bags on the passenger side of automobiles.

title: U.S. Examines Competition in Snack Industry
description: The Justice Department said yesterday that it had begun a preliminary investigation of possible anti-competitive practices in the salty-snack industry, a $14 billion business.

title: About New York;How to say 'Grass Roots' In Russian
description: WHAT is 'chimichanga?' " asked the puzzled Russian visitor, who studied the menu at Los Tres Aztecas Restaurant on Rivington Street as if it were a nuclear test ban treaty.

title: New Appointee Will Oversee Juvenile Justice
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani named Marta Moczo-Santiago the new Juvenile Justice Commissioner yesterday, putting her in charge of the city's system for handling juvenile delinquents and offenders.

description: Correction Appended

description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL;Mets Leave Isringhausen Still Looking for a Run
description: Excuse Jason Isringhausen if he feels lonely out on the mound these days. It has been 14 innings since the Mets have scored a run for him.

title: G.M.'s Chief Conciliatory Toward Labor
description: The chairman of the General Motors Corporation offered an olive branch today to the United Automobile Workers union, seeking to mend a relationship strained by two bitter strikes this year, a lawsuit and G.M.'s dismissal of an influential shop steward.

title: POLITICS: THE UNIONS;A Call to Arms, or at Least Faxes
description: National labor leaders have vowed that unions will play a historic role in this year's Presidential and Congressional races, and indeed there is evidence here that a sizable grass-roots push has begun.

title: Re-elected: Six Members Of Ousted School Board
description: Six members of a Bronx community school board who were suspended in February by Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew have won re-election to new, three-year terms, according to results of the May 7 school board balloting released last night by the Board of Elections.

title: World News Briefs;First U.S. Envoy Named To Reunified Vietnam
description: President Clinton announced today that he was nominating a former American prisoner of war in Vietnam, Representative Pete Peterson of Florida, as the first Ambassador to the reunified Socialist Republic of Vietnam.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Sharp's Pretax Profit Up by 5.2% in Year
description: The pretax profits of the Sharp Corporation rose 5.2 percent in its most recent fiscal year on a rebound in sales of appliances. The electronics maker said pretax profit for the year ended March 31 was 70.53 billion yen ($661.6 million) on sales of 1.281 trillion yen, up 1.6 percent. Net income for the Sharp group, which includes overseas subsidiaries, rose 4.1 percent, to 46.32 billion yen. Group sales were 1.65 trillion yen, up 2 percent.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;Kemp Vanishes, and Jazz Crushes Sonics
description: Shawn Kemp is still calling for the basketball.

title: AUTO RACING: NOTEBOOK;A Racing Team, and a Town, Remember Brayton
description: Even without any extraordinary efforts, the Team Menard racing shop is a memorial to Scott Brayton.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Beyond Sonatas for the Philharmonic
description: An increasingly nervous symphonic culture has started looking beyond its boundaries. The American orchestra is, after all, a European creation, a musical machine invented to reproduce the European sensibility. Americans imported this sensibility whole, with German, Italian and French repertories -- green cards firmly in hand -- setting up shop around the land. Outposts quickly consolidated into a kind of Fortress Europa. Aspiring supplicants have gained admittance; the great American unwashed have been kept at bay.

title: Bond Prices Lifted by Weak Orders for Durable Goods
description: A report on manufacturing in yesterday's shortened trading session bucked the trend of higher estimates of economic growth, and gave bond prices a pre-holiday lift.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefings;Troopers Urged to Stay
description: Not so fast, some South Jersey politicians are saying, criticizing Gov. Christine Todd Whitman for abruptly ending state police patrols in Camden, the state's most crime-ridden city. Governor Whitman notified city officials this week that the patrols, which began in January, would end, The Associated Press reported.

title: Patients Turn to Chiropractors for Both Pain and Financial Relief
description: To the Editor:

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;Colorado's Lemieux Suspended For a Game
description: Claude Lemieux of the Colorado Avalanche was suspended for one game tonight by the National Hockey League for punching the head of Detroit's Slava Kozlov from behind during Game 3 of their contentious Western Conference finals.

title: An American Place;Unions Gear Up For Political Fight
description: National labor leaders have vowed that unions will play a historic role for Democrats in this year's Presidential and Congressional races and indeed, there is evidence in northeast Ohio that a sizable grass-roots push has begun.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Japan's Phone Company Says Pretax Profit Soared
description: Japan's telephone monopoly, the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, said yesterday that profits more than doubled in the year ended March 31, helped by rises in basic phone charges. N.T.T. said its pretax profit was 328.92 billion yen ($3.07 billion).

title: Nasdaq Uncovered Short Sales Increased During Latest Month
description: Investors who bet on lower Nasdaq stock prices added to their bets in the most recent monthlong period.

title: G.M. Locomotive Order
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that its Electro-Motive division had received an order to supply up to 250 freight-hauling locomotives to English Welsh & Scottish Railway Ltd. Financial terms were not disclosed. The G.M. unit will provide 3,000-horsepower locomotives under the agreement, which requires delivery of 25 to 100 locomotives a year. An Electro-Motive spokesman said initial deliveries would likely begin in 1998. English Welsh & Scottish Railway is owned by the Wisconsin Central Transportation Corporoation of Rosemont, Ill., and American and New Zealand investors.

title: Insurance Queries And the Regulators
description: Consumers who turn to their state insurance regulators for help when shopping for health or automobile insurance may be getting bad information, a survey suggests.

title: Still Life, With Tourists;Can Visitors Revive the Economy for Philadelphia?
description: The promoters of this city's summer blockbuster art exhibit, which opens May 30, aren't missing a trick. Already, tourists can buy neon-hued, vinyl-covered baseballs plastered with Paul Cezanne's signature, or see the sights on a bus decorated with a 40-foot-long copy of a Cezanne still life of fruit. The exhibit is even being touted in a 20-page special-advertising section in Business Week magazine.

title: Moderate Chosen to Fill Dole's Seat
description: The Lieutenant Governor of Kansas, Sheila Frahm, a leader of the moderate wing among her state's Republicans, was chosen yesterday to fill the Senate vacancy left by the resignation of Bob Dole.

title: Computers Can Help Schools Find Solutions
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press on Thursday about the creation of a commission to oversee trash hauling in New York City misstated the number of zones that would be set up to monitor competition. It is two zones for the city, not for each borough.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BIG B EARNINGS EXPECTED TO FALL BELOW ESTIMATES
description: Big B Inc., based in Bessemer, Ala., said yesterday that its earnings in the quarter ended on May 11 would fall below analysts' estimates because of higher expenses and weak sales. Sales for the quarter rose 7 percent from a year ago, but not enough to meet estimates of 22 cents a share from three analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research, the company said. A year ago, Big B posted net income of $4.81 million, or 31 cents a share, on revenue of $195.2 million. Shares of Big B were unchanged at $10.75 when they were halted for the announcement and they never resumed trading. Big B operates 384 drugstores in the Southeast.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;The Magic Fades With Anderson And Scott
description: Before he left the practice floor today, Dennis Scott made 19 consecutive 3-pointers. If only it were that easy to shoot against the Chicago Bulls.

title: Putting Heat on Corporate Bosses
description: Chairman Arthur Levitt Jr. of the Securities and Exchange Commission is fighting to diminish the influence over accounting standards enjoyed by corporate executives -- whose performance those standards are supposed to judge. His proposals, which have caused a storm, deserve White House and Congressional support.

title: F.A.A. Worker Held In Air Base Thefts
description: A Federal worker faces charges in a plot to steal more than $1 million worth of Defense Department property from Griffiss Air Force Base.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY;Devils Sign Three Prospects
description: The signing of SERGEI VYSHEDKEVICH, a defenseman from Russia and the Devils' third choice in the draft last June, was the most significant of three signings announced yesterday by LOU LAMORIELLO, the team's president and general manager. The 21-year-old Vyshedkevich is an offense-minded defenseman who spent the last two seasons with Moscow Dynamo. BOBBY HOUSE and KRZYSTOF OLIVA, right wings who played for the Devils' top minor league affiliate, the Albany River Rats of the American Hockey League, last year, were also signed to multiyear contracts.

title: Report From North Korea;Flood Waters Come and Go. Misery Endures.
description: North Korea's perpetual economic crisis may be turning into famine. Earlier this month, two United Nations agencies reported that "without emergency food imports the consequences are likely to be devastating for large segments of the population." This week, Representative Bill Richardson, Democrat of New Mexico, is scheduled to travel to North Korea, where few visitors are allowed. Trevor Page last week returned from six months there as country director for the World Food Program, one of the United Nations agencies. This article expresses his personal view of what he saw.

title: How Main Street Cafe Got in the Movies
description: WHEN Paul Janos, a restaurateur here, invited a small group of "window shoppers" into his Main Street cafe for freshly brewed coffee one morning last October, he unwittingly landed a supporting role in a movie.

title: Royal Pains
description: THE UNRULY QUEEN The Life of Queen Caroline. By Flora Fraser. Illustrated. 537 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $35.

title: DINING OUT;Exciting and Soul-Satisfying Offerings
description: PAOLO PENATI'S culinary fireworks lighted up the East End in 1990 at Fresno in East Hampton. But starbursts are shortlived. Mr. Penati soon left and the restaurant eventually closed.

title: MUSIC;Ensembles Fill a Seasonal Gap
description: IN the lull before summer festivals, some ensembles with husband-and-wife teams or other pairings are making memorable chamber music. Today at 1 P.M. the restored Carriage House at Lyndhurst is the setting for an afternoon of 18th-century music. Loretta O'Sullivan plays a Baroque cello, Virginia Brewer a Baroque oboe and her husband, Edward Brewer, a harpsichord for performances of works by Handel, Delavigne, Boismortier and an obscure English composer of the period, Thomas Vincent.

title: The First Freedoms
description: Freedom's Law The Moral Reading of the American Constitution. By Ronald Dworkin. 404 pp. Cambridge, Mass: Harvard University Press. $35.

title: Robert J. Joedicke, 73, Airline Industry Analyst
description: Robert J. Joedicke, an airline industry analyst at Lehman Brothers for 30 years who was known for his yearly seminars, died on May 18. He was 73 years old.

title: ART;Tribute to Shows Linked to the Bronx
description: THE Bronx Museum of the Arts here celebrates its 25th anniversary by focusing on the careers of four younger institutions. Hence, "Bronx Spaces" is a show of shows -- by the Bronx River Art Center and Gallery, the Longwood Arts Gallery, En Foco and the Lehman College Art Gallery.

title: FILM VIEW;At Cannes, The Star Was Quality
description: A HOT-TEMPERED CREATURE IN AN incrediible red dress came storming out of the hotel elevator one evening, throwing a celebrity conniption. Sure enough, there she was looking famous on television several days later, as a few dozen people eagerly watched her on one monitor at the Palais des Festivals, action central for the Cannes International Film Festival. The crowd was hypnotized, but nobody had the faintest idea who this woman was. The answer, supplied succinctly by a newspaper the next day: "Czech model."

title: SPOTLIGHT;Day of Destiny
description: With a lean script (by Daniel Taradash) culled from James Jones's sprawling best seller, FROM HERE TO ETERNITY (1953) came alive on film -- its soldiers, their women and Peal Harbor. The picture copped eight Oscars. Praise pelted Fred Zinnemann's direction and his cast: Burt Lancaster, Frank Sinatra (in a legendary comeback), a surprisingly earthy Deborah Kerr and Donna Reed. Curiously, Montgomery Clift's cutting portrayal of Prewitt (above), the story's central figure was skimmed past. Or was he just taken for granted? Even with Jones's iron-fisted realism and scathing talk toned down, this "Eternity" packs a wallop -- THURSDAY at 8 P.M. on TNT. Howard Thompson

title: RESIDENTIAL RESALES
description: In the following reports, the "listed at" price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: A DESERT OF PURE FEELING By Judith Freeman. Pantheon, $24.

title: NEIGBORHOOD REPORT: MANHATTAN VALLEY;Toll of the No-Name Pay Phones
description: Along some blocks of Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues in the low 100's, it is not unusual to see as many as five to ten no-name pay phones hooked up at bodegas and other stores. But far from feeling blessed by this surfeit of street amenities, some Manhattan Valley residents say the pay phones are a blight on the neighborhood, little more than field offices for the drug trade.
