description: To the Editor:

title: PERSPECTIVES/OUTDOORS: FISHING;Not-So-Secret Spot (Hudson) Has Big-Time Striped Bass
description: Knock wood, but between now and June 1, the striped bass fishing in the Hudson River promises to be sensational, or, as Tom Gentalen of the River Basin Sports Shop in Catskill, N.Y., puts it, "absolutely world class." For sure, the fish are present, an estimated one million to two million of them coming in from the ocean to spawn, according to a fisheries scientist, Andrew Kahnle of the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation.

title: Liberties;Fillet Of Soul
description: I once knew a Washington Post reporter who liked to shake up politicians in the Maryland suburb we covered by asking, "What does your soul look like?"

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Sunday about the media watchdog group Fairness and Accuracy in Reporting misspelled the names of several advisers. They are Studs Terkel, Frances Moore Lappe, Gloria Steinem and Casey Kasem.

title: FOOD;Strawberries Warming Up on Sidelines
description: SUMMER? Not quite. But strawberries from nearby farms are ripening and will be ready for picking soon.

title: LIVES;The Hollow Man
description: I am going to level with you: I hate the war. I have hated the war since the day I walked off the battlefield. I hate it now even as it works its way up my throat and slips across my tongue -- to you.

title: N.H.L. PLAYOFFS;Panthers Enjoying The Year Of the Rat
description: By day, Dan Platt is a 41-year-old service technician for a phone company. On Florida Panthers' game nights, the Hollywood, Fla., resident changes into a walking advertisement for the team.

title: WEDDINGS;Anne H. Driscoll, Robert F. St. Peter
description: Anne Halpin Driscoll, a daughter of Drs. Yvonne Driscoll and John Driscoll of Oradell, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Robert Francis St. Peter, a son of Kayleene St. Peter and Donald St. Peter, both of Wichita, Kan. Bishop Coadjutor John Mortimer Smith of Trenton performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: Map 19-25;Area Codes, Caribbean Style
description: Tarnished by high-tech telephone hijinks, the 809 area code, an old Caribbean standby familiar to tourists for nearly 40 years, has quietly begun making its exit. Nineteen countries, colonies and territories share the designation, but the emergence of flourishing phone sex and gambling services in the Dominican Republic, combined with the trafficking there of stolen calling card and cell phone numbers, has made others in the region eager to acquire area codes of their own.

description: To the Editor:

title: WEDDINGS;Wendy Braun, James Muschett
description: Wendy Elizabeth Braun, the daughter of Nancy and David Braun of Greens Farms, Conn., was married there yesterday to James Oakley Muschett, the son of Penny and James L. Muschett of Frederick, Md. The Rev. Kevin Pleas performed the ceremony at the Greens Farms Congregational Church.

title: THEM;Arrogance, Order, Obesity and Other National Traits
description: ANY traveler knows that people are different from country to country -- from the way they build their roofs to the hour they eat dinner. Russians drink vodka, Germans drink beer and the French drink wine. Americans are gregarious and overfed. The British are prudish and indirect. Germans are orderly.

title: Separation Anxiety
description: Talking in Bed By Antonya Nelson. 275 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $22.95.

title: DINING OUT;Where Brews and Hearty Servings Meet
description: FANS of microbrewery beers will rejoice in The Brewery in New Haven. The bustling new brew pub is on the vast second floor of the New Haven Brewery, which has been turning out Elm City beers since 1987.

title: BASEBALL;Griffey's Homers Sink Yanks
description: Minutes after Ken Griffey Jr. had scorched three different Yankee pitchers for three homers and a single, driven in six runs and scored five runs Friday night, his biggest problem was preventing his son, Trey, from interrupting interviews.

title: WEDDINGS;Edith M. Shine, Mark Sherman
description: Edith M. Shine, a lawyer, and Mark Sherman, a journalist, are to be married today in Decatur, Ga. Rabbi Leila Berner is to perform the ceremony at the Mary Gay House, a historic site.

description: School's been out three days and the kids are already bored?

description: To the Editor:

description: BRIAN HARRIGAN did not know it, but he had the one thing that Officer Vincent Caporale of the police in Yorktown needed. A Dare T-shirt.

title: Too Busy for Briquettes;Charcoal Grilling Is Going Up in Smoke
description: AS a milestone in American demographics, it may not rank up there with the Westward Migration or the Baby Boom. But with the onset of Memorial Day, the traditional kickoff of the barbecue season, it's worth pondering the Great Grill Conversion.

title: Rollicking Lessons in Whales and Chanteys
description: ZACHARY GROSS, age 3, was pretty excited as amazing creatures appeared before his eyes. "I see whales!" he said.

title: F.Y.I.
description: The Story of Sixth St.

title: DOWN THE SHORE;New in '96: Rides, Rooms and Even Bigger Crowds
description: You thought last year at the shore was crowded? Tourism officials expect that the recent increases in gasoline prices will make summer 1996 the most crowded season ever, as more and more New Jerseyans, New Yorkers and Philadelphians scale back plans to drive their sport utility vehicles farther away.

title: Map 19-25;Mafia, 0; Carabinieri, 1
description: With the capture last week of a high-ranking Mafia boss in southwestern Sicily, the Italian police were able to rack up another victory in their fight against organized crime. Not only was Giovanni Brusca, 39, one of the few remaining Mafia chieftains still on the lam, but he is also wanted for the bombing death four years ago of Giovanni Falcone, the legendary prosecutor who has become an icon for those involved in the anti-Mafia struggle. But no sooner was the arrest announced than veteran Mafia experts were issuing their standard note of caution: As an organization, the Mafia has proved time and again that none of its members are irreplaceable. CELESTINE BOHLEN

title: What's Ahead For the Class of '96?
description: FOUR years ago, when Alison Slavin first passed under the imposing clock tower at New Rochelle High School here, she felt like most of the other freshman entering that fall -- awkward and overwhelmed. Today, the gargoyles on the clock tower are like old friends to the 17-year-old class valedictorian, but the picture gallery of distinguished alumni inside the school building still sends a chill down her spine.

title: ON THE STREET;For Taking a Walk on the Wild Side
description: Just when the minimalists appeared to have stripped fashion of its fantasy, the wilder forces arrived with arty jeans. Their prints often evoke 1960's Pop Art imagery, at times mixing snatches of Tom Wesselmann and James Rosenquist. At Gucci, the designer Tom Ford has combined the soak-stained technique of Helen Frankenthaler and Morris Louis for shirt and jeans ensembles. At other times, Mr. Ford combines geometrics that recall early Frank Stella canvases.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: IT was a bet the president of the Suffolk Offtrack Betting Corporation could not pass up. Before becoming head of O.T.B., Howard C. DeMartini was head of the Suffolk Republican Party.

title: Potion That 'Cures' AIDS Divides Kenyans
description: Every morning there are dozens of desperate people outside Arthur O. Obel's office in downtown Nairobi. They wait for hours in sad-eyed silence, hoping to get a bottle of the herbal potion that Mr. Obel claims will rid them of AIDS.

title: BOOKEND;The People's Publishers: China's Book Scene
description: Our publishing house would like you to export a car for us from Boston to China," said my Chinese editor in Beijing in the summer of 1992. I pointed out that I was a writer, not a car salesman. "We want to build a long-term relationship with you," Wang Yaming bore on, an expectant look on his face. Hebei People's Publishers was cultivating an author in the spirit of China under Deng Xiaoping.

title: Festival Of Dancing And Light
description: STEADY and rhythmic, the drumbeat rumbled across the lighted outdoor dance grounds into the darkness of the summer night. A gong sounded, flutes chirped, and several hundred women, men and children weaved and bobbed, arms sweeping to the right, to the left and up toward the hidden moon. Our feet never stopped moving; periodically, we clapped in unison.

title: INSIDE THE MERITOCRACY MACHINE
description: My impression is that most applicants, their parents and college consultants are playing the "Guess What Harvard Wants" game ("Inside the Meritocracy Machine," by Bruce Weber, April 28).

title: A Foreign Affair
description: WILDER TIMES The Life of Billy Wilder. By Kevin Lally. Illustrated. 496 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $30.

title: Cultivating The Genuine Kauai
description: SURROUNDED by mountains with peaks as sharp as sharks' teeth, the Limahuli Valley on Kauai's wild northwestern coast is one of the garden island's sacred sites, sheltering rare plants, archeological ruins and a vivid lore passed down from the early Hawaiians.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;USAir Now Offers 'Ticketless' Flying
description: USAir has begun allowing its passengers to travel without a ticket on USAir and USAir Express flights within the United States.

title: He Had Pataki's Ear; Now It's Netanyahu's
description: In this ancient, sacred city, Tower Records and Blockbuster Video are just the latest flashy outposts of American commerce. So it is not surprising that another American import, the political consultant, should have created a stir as the campaign for prime minister heats up toward election day next Wednesday.

title: SIGNOFF;Vroom? Gentlemen, Begin Your Cat Fight.
description: A power struggle in auto racing will culminate this afternoon when the venerable Indianapolis 500 on ABC-TV goes virtually head to head against the new U.S. 500 on ESPN. The upstart race is starting its engines barely two hours after the Indy 500 revs up at noon.

title: Travel Advisory: PERSONAL GROWTH;Rockies Relationships
description: Hikers in national parks are told to take out everything they take in with them, but there's nothing wrong with leaving some emotional baggage behind. A back-country tour, the Rocky Mountain National Park Personal Growth Getaway, is a six-day hiking and rafting trip, accompanied by a psychotherapist who will lead discussions on stress, self-esteem and relationships.

title: False Prophets
description: THE KING OF BABYLON SHALL NOT COME AGAINST YOU By George Garrett. 336 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace & Company. $24.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: OF TIGERS AND MEN Entering the Age of Extinction. By Richard Ives. Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $24.95.

title: Sunday May 26, 1996: STORING UP MEMORIES;Survival Course
description: Steven Spielberg's Survivors of the Shoah Visual History project is an ambitious effort to record testimony from all Holocaust survivors and to create an archive for television and CD-ROM. It is a real challenge to the interviewers, though, to elicit candid accounts without interrupting the tape with sympathetic hugs and tissues. Ongoing training sessions in cities with large survivor populations are meant to prepare volunteers for the rigors of prompting painful memories. At one session, held recently at Temple Emanu-El in New York, 210 would-be interlocutors took a crash course in Holocaust etiquette.

title: THEATER;For Goodspeed, a Noble Departure
description: BEFORE "Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street" bedevils, beguiles and transforms the audience at the Goodspeed Opera House, members of the chorus, representing London's underclass in the 1840's, lurk in the aisles and on the sidelines, signifying terror and derangement. One is on stage hammering the slabs of a coffin into which a corpse is to be hurled.

title: WEDDINGS;Emily Mathes, Jeffrey Kuvin
description: Emily Ruth Mathes, the daughter of Barbara and Sorrell Mathes of New York, is to be married this evening to Dr. Jeffrey Townsend Kuvin, the son of Gabrielle Kuvin and Dr. Sanford Kuvin of Palm Beach, Fla., and Jerusalem. Rabbi David Posner is to officiate at the St. Regis in New York.

title: MAKING IT WORK;Someone to Watch Over Us
description: LIKE sentinels frozen in time, some dozen forts still dot New York City's waterfront, their histories as complex as their futures are uncertain.

title: BOOKSHELF;To Read All About Us
description: For a state that supposedly gets no respect, New Jersey certainly gets a lot of ink. The New Jersey shelves in the Barnes & Noble bookstore on Route 17 North in Paramus have a total of 79 titles, from "Jewish Agricultural Colonies in New Jersey, 1882-1920" to "Garden State Golf Guide."

title: Speaking For the Majority
description: WHEN a lawyer for the state of Colorado began his Supreme Court argument defending a state constitutional provision that nullified civil rights protections for homosexuals, he was interrupted almost immediately by a Justice who was clearly troubled by the state's position.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article last Sunday, about efforts by states to restrict health plans' cost-cutting practices, referred incorrectly to such laws in Georgia. And a map with the article, summarizing such restrictions nationwide, reflected the error. Georgia's requirement that health plans accept any physician with appropriate credentials applies only to insurer-based "preferred provider" organizations; it does not apply to all health networks.

title: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;In the National League Central, Even Winning Teams Are Losers
description: The teams known collectively as the National League Central are beginning to look a lot like the 1994 American League West. There's not a winning record to be found. But the '96 version is outdoing the '94 model; the N.L. Central has five losing teams instead of four.

title: WEDDINGS;Nina A. Korelitz, Robert H. Matza
description: Nina Ann Korelitz, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Burton I. Korelitz of New York, is to be married today to Robert Howard Matza, a son of Marilyn Matza of Lawrence, L.I., and the late Harry Matza. Cantor Bruce Halev is to perform the ceremony at the Lotos Club in New York.

title: WEDDINGS;Yvette B. Fromer, Philip Hirschkorn
description: Yvette Barbara Fromer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Fromer of Kings Point, L.I., is to be married this evening at her parents' house to Philip Evan Hirschkorn, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Hirschkorn of New York. Rabbi Mordecai Waxman is to perform the ceremony.

title: Where Wild Things Find a Home
description: MERLIN the cat, one of the newer and more exotic additions to the Science Center of Connecticut in West Hartford, is aptly named. With his long tufted ears and inscrutable expression, he has a magical look about him, almost as if he had emerged from a mosaic in a pharaoh's court in ancient Egypt.

title: N.B.A. PLAYOFFS;Bulls-Magic Thriller Becomes a Flop
description: Say goodbye to the Orlando Magic until next season. And if either Shaquille O'Neal or Horace Grant leave as free agents this summer, the Magic basketball kingdom may be about to crumble.

title: In Chicago, Law Speeds The Saving Of History
description: After leaving some of Chicago's architectural treasures in a legal nether world for up to 16 years, city officials must decide within the next 10 months whether to designate them as landmarks or let bulldozers knock them down.

title: Norman Rene, 45, Director, Dies; He Elicited Naturalistic Acting
description: Norman Rene, a director closely associated with the playwright Craig Lucas and a founder and the artistic director of an Off Off Broadway group, the Production Company, died on Friday at New York University Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 45.

title: Cuttings;A Soft Spot for Scraggly Late-Blooming Lilacs
description: I now have a lilac growing on my roof in Brooklyn: Syringa patula Miss Kim. It doesn't look like much now. Just a three-foot shrub with skinny branches that reach up more than out and glossy dark green leaves that turn burgundy in the fall.

title: MUSIC;Listen Up! (And Maybe Sing Along, Too)
description: THE answer is, a summer festival. The question? What would you call the three-month surfeit of concerts coming up in New Jersey, encompassing classical music, jazz, folk, vocal, instrumental, sacred, pop, dance, indoor, outdoor, daytime, evening, large orchestra, intimate setting, series, one-time events, sing-alongs and celebrity turns?

title: Our Towns;Sometimes, Crime Solving Takes Visions
description: DOROTHY ALLISON stands under 5 feet tall, wears seriously thick glasses and has her hair done in a brunette pouf at the beauty parlor. Her health could be better, but at 71, she is not one to complain. It would distract her from the task of solving murders.

title: ART VIEW;The Gallery Doors Open to the Long Denied
description: Correction Appended

title: Travel Medicine
description: To the Editor: As head of the new travel medicine program at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in New York, I was particularly interested in the Practical Traveler column, "Pesky Parasites and Nasty Bites" (April 28), dealing with serious and relatively unknown diseases confronting international travelers.

title: Rum on the Rocks: A Broken Family
description: LIKE a moth caught in amber, the happy family smiles out from the old photograph: four generations of the Bacardi family, gathered on a lush Cuban terrace in the late 1950's, looking forward to a wealthy future nourished by an ocean of rum.

title: Firefighters Rescue A Family in Queens
description: Firefighters rescued a woman and two children from a burning house in Flushing, Queens, yesterday, a spokesman for the Fire Department said.

title: No Shrinking Violets And No Slackers
description: RUGBY, that brutal slashing sport played without padding or safety equipment, has numerous fervid supporters -- and players -- on Long Island. One regional team, the Montauk Rugby Club, recently won a divisional title and qualified for semifinal playoffs in Dallas, where it lost to Utah International, 25 to 15.

title: Streetscapes/Metropolitan Life at 1 Madison Avenue;For a Brief Moment, the Tallest Building in the World
description: THE Metropolitan Life Tower, the tallest in the world when it was built in 1909, defined both Madison Square and New York City. Stripped of its ornament in a curious remodeling in the early 60's, the tower is again undergoing change, this time a multimillion dollar cleaning and stone repair.

title: 19th-Century Spirit Behind a '96 Bike Race
description: WHEN an expected 1,000 people take to the streets of Hartford on bicycles next Saturday, forgive Georgette Yaindl if she sounds as though the spirits of the city's great 19th-century leaders touched her.

title: Against the Tide
description: NEAR THE END OF A RECENT LECTURE, MY EYE CAUGHT A coastal redwood outside the window, and I couldn't help but notice its branches. If they'd been showing the usual northwesterly breeze, the surf would have been a mess. But those deep green sequoia mops hung so still -- meaning the surf might be tremendous -- that I lost track of a point I was making about Antonio Gramsci's "Prison Notebooks."

title: COVER STORY;Heather Locklear, From 'Melrose' Vixen To 'Shattered' Victim'
description: It was kind of tough and I was going back and forth and I thought 'You know what, Heather, if you don't take this you are being a baby. You need to challenge yourself. If you think you can do it, then do it. Show yourself.' "

title: WEDDINGS;Adrienne Haubert, Matthew C. Heist
description: Adrienne Rose Haubert, a daughter of Marthe and John Haubert of Alexandria, Va., was married yesterday to Matthew Clark Heist, a son of Mary and L. C. Heist of Old Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Thomas Magri performed the ceremony at St. Bede Roman Catholic Church in Williamsburg, Va. The Rev. David VanDyke, a Presbyterian minister, participated.

title: How Can Lilco Be So Wrong, or Right?
description: It is patently untrue that "Lilco had entered into what had turned out to be a disastrously expensive and failed nuclear plant investment." Lilco built, completed, obtained an operating license and was prepared to put on line a nuclear power plant that Long Island needed.

title: FOOD;Happy Meals
description: FOR PEOPLE WHO NEED TO PLEASE OTHER people, throwing a simple summer party can be agony. Take Rachel J., a 40-year-old publicity consultant from Los Angeles. After the initial flush of generosity -- ah, she thinks, a Memorial Day supper -- there follows a palpable pain in her chest before she even gets to the guest list.

title: WEDDINGS;Stacey Grundman, Owen Herrnstadt
description: Stacey Gayle Grundman, a daughter of Sondra and Neil Grundman of Harrison, N.Y., is to be married this evening to Owen Edward Herrnstadt, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard Herrnstadt of Tucson, Ariz. Rabbi Daniel Wolk is to perform the ceremony at Lyndhurst, the historic house in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Conjugating the Birds

title: The Price of Gaming Success
description: THERE are no sure bets, certainly not about the future of the Indian gaming business in Connecticut, or anywhere in southeastern New England, in the wake of a Supreme Court decision in March.

title: WEDDINGS;Leah B. Welsh, Douglas A. Kass
description: Leah Bourne Welsh, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald E. Welsh of New York, is to be married today to Douglas Andrew Kass, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Kass of Bedford, N.Y. Louis Pressman, a justice of the peace in Salisbury, Conn., is to perform the ceremony at Lake Wononskopomuc in Lakeville, Conn.

title: Corrections
description: An article last week on circumcision misstated a requirement for being a mohel, the person who specializes in circumcisions. A mohel need not be a rabbi.

title: SOAPBOX;The Car That Crashed Into History
description: THIS year, the United States auto industry has been enjoying its 100th birthday. No surprise, then, that we are coming up on the 100th anniversary of the nation's first documented auto accident. That dubious distinction belongs to New York, where a city bicyclist was struck by an out-of-town driver.

title: Map 19-25;Set-Aside Programs Set Aside
description: Sometimes it's done for political reasons, sometimes for legal considerations. For whatever reason, the Clinton Administration's rightward list continues.

title: TELEVISION;Inside 'The X-Files' With a Deadline to Meet
description: NOW THAT THE PRIME-TIME season is over, regular viewers of most television series will become regular viewers of something else, whether it be baseball, movies or the pages of a book. Not so followers of "The X-Files," consistently one of Fox's top-rated shows.

title: Congress Likely to Repeat Many Environmental Disputes as New BudgetTakes Shape
description: Once again, the Federal budget is turning into an environmental battleground as Congressional Republicans offer their proposals for spending in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1.

title: Critics of Big Bar Mitzvahs Should Loosen Up a Bit
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE THE MERITOCRACY MACHINE
description: One searches in vain for a sign of youthful enthusiasm on the grim faces of the Harvard aspirants. Small wonder. This cynical account of the admissions process leaves no room for exuberant achievement. It is Harvard reduced to educational cash card.

title: HOME CLINIC;Steps to Take for a Brick Walkway
description: A BRICK walkway can be a handsome addition to any home. Most people assume that laying a brick walk is a difficult task, requiring the skills of a seasoned mason. Actually, there is a relatively easy way built a beautiful walkway without having to mix concrete or trowel mortar.

title: Graft Case In Colombia: Democracy On Trial Too
description: If the Colombian Congress remains true to expectations here, its impending debate over charges that drug dealers bankrolled President Ernesto Samper's election promises great political theater, replete with posturing, high-minded oratory and double-jointed twists of evidence.

title: Commercial Property/The New York Information Technology Center;Leasing Real Space to Denizens of Cyberspace
description: THE creative types running N2K knew what they wanted in their office home. They wanted to be among people to whom computer jargon and Internet-speak sounds like plain English, and who do not differentiate between 9 A.M. and 9 P.M. when a project is in the works. And they wanted an almost oxymoronic physical combination: a building replete with high technology and plain old funk.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: EQUATION FOR EVIL By Philip Caputo. HarperCollins, $25.

title: WEDDINGS;Alison Schecter, S.E. Kesselman
description: Dr. Alison Dee Schecter, a cardiologist, was married last evening to Stephen Edward Kesselman, a lawyer. Rabbi David H. Lincoln performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York.

title: N.B.A. PLAYOFFS;Bulls Whip Magic Soundly and Close In on Sweep
description: They shackled Shaquille O'Neal, stifled Anfernee Hardaway and completely discombobulated the only dimension of Dennis Scott's game. The Chicago Bulls have come to be known as a great offensive machine in the open court, but they get their hands dirty, too.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: MAKING IT WORK 3 The forts of New York: they defended our honor.

title: ON POLITICS;Is This Really Parity, Or the Same Old Debate?
description: Governor Whitman's school financing proposal is likely to fare well in the opinion polls: it wouldn't force most taxpayers to dig deeper into their pockets to pay for public education. But will it satisfy the State Supreme Court and end the 25-year debate over the disparity between the state's wealthiest and poorest districts?

title: New Crisis at an Arts Center
description: THE resignation of Jeffrey Rosenstock as executive director of the Northern Westchester Center for the Arts only two months after his arrival has brought new turmoil to the 18-year-old center here. The 42-year-old Mr. Rosenstock said he would return to his previous job as executive director of Queens Theater in the Park.

title: NEIGBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE;Seller of Incendiary Book Takes a Few Direct Hits
description: At 81st and Broadway, Shakespeare & Company Booksellers sits in the heart of the liberal Upper West Side, but enough people were requesting copies of the white supremacist novel "The Turner Diaries" that the bookstore decided to stock it.

title: PRISONER OF RAGE;The Tortured Genius of Theodore Kaczynski
description: Breaking his public silence, David Kaczynski described in an interview how he had reluctantly come to the "horrible" realization that his older brother, Theodore, could be the Unabomber. He recounted his anguished decision to turn him in to prevent more lives from being lost, and he pleaded that his brother, if convicted in the fatal bomb attacks, be spared the death penalty.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD: PARK SLOPE;Hiii-yah! Hong Kong Action Coming at You
description: HONG KONG action films have been influencing Hollywood in a big way -- and developed a cult following of their own -- and 10 of the best examples are in a 10-week series that started this weekend at the Plaza Twin Cinema in Park Slope.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Caldwell, N.J.;A Downtown Struggles Against the Malls
description: MAYOR PAUL G. JEMAS of Caldwell is upset that the Dunkin' Donuts on Bloomfield Avenue closed a short while ago and says he has asked the parent company for a new franchisee.

title: Map 19-25;Most-Favored Flouter: China
description: If you were a Chinese official set on angering Congress just as it was considering renewing Beijing's preferential trade status, it would be hard to top this strategy: Tell the Americans demanding the closure of factories producing pirated software, music and videos that they are cultural imperialists bent on limiting the Chinese and transmitting propaganda. Then let the Pentagon discover that you are trying to buy nuclear technology from the poor Russians, giving China intercontinental ballistic missile capability. Finally, get caught shipping 2,000 AK-47's from a state-owned factory to San Francisco, pushing them as the perfect weapon for gangs.

title: JERSEY;One for All, All for One, on the Beach
description: A SHORE mayor talking about something that sounds even remotely inclusive? Oh my God!"

title: Sports of The Times;Black Coaches Hear A Plea From Farrakhan
description: WHEN word spread that Louis Farrakhan would address the Black Coaches Association, members reacted with the mixed emotions that characterized ambivalence toward the Nation of Islam's 63-year-old leader.

title: Managed Care and the Vacation;When Are We Gonna Get to the Doctor's?
description: VACATIONERS, beware. As you take to the roads and skies this Memorial Day weekend or in the summer months ahead, you could be in for a shock more real than any encountered in this season's cinematic nail-biters. When the American traveler meets the bean-counters of health insurance, the results can be unsettling.

title: Big Victory for a Small Frog
description: It was especially fitting that the California red-legged frog should be the first creature granted protection under the Endangered Species Act when a 13-month moratorium imposed by Congress ended last week. Though not nearly as important to the national psyche as the bald eagle, the frog is a minor cultural icon, having reportedly inspired Mark Twain's yarn about a "celebrated jumping frog." The frog's dwindling numbers also signaled a larger problem, the deterioration of the California streams and wetlands that provided its habitat.

title: THEATER;The Amazing Technicolor Theatercoat
description: ON THE OPENING NIGHT OF every Broadway musical, a constant flow of flowers, balloons and gifts swirls past the stage door and into the theater. As the presents begin to spill into the corridors outside the dressing rooms, the oldest and most beloved gift arrives: the Gypsy Robe.

title: Belated Remembrance of the Forgotten War in Korea
description: IT has been called the forgotten war. Sandwiched between World War II and the Vietnam War, the conflict in Korea was relatively brief and the fighting fierce. Nearly as many Americans (54,259) died in the three years of fighting in Korea as in nine years of the Vietnam War (58,002), but Korean veterans have remained a comparatively silent and unrecognized group.

title: The Art of the Critique
description: WHEN I was 21 and still susceptible, I enrolled in a fiction-writing class taught by the writer Reynolds Price during my senior year at Duke. The class was populated by wealthy, intelligent, sophisticated young men and women (among them a young man with the same last name as the university) already affecting a certain world-weariness. They had been writing for years; some had already been published in small magazines. But I, also, had long scribbled, and believed I could hold my own.

title: ON THE MAP;In Hamilton, a Museum Where It's Always Memorial Day
description: Two weeks ago, New Jersey's first museum devoted to Civil War memorabilia opened its doors.

title: WEDDINGS;Lisa J. Marber, Eric T. Rich
description: Lisa Jo Marber, the daughter of Dina Marber of Boca Raton, Fla., and Lloyd Marber of New York, was married last evening to Eric Tenneson Rich, a son of Winthrop and David Rich of Mission Viejo, Calif. Rabbi Samuel Silver performed the ceremony at the Boca Raton Resort and Club.

title: Music Notes;Delsener Takes On 2 Summer Concert Projects
description: IN the 18 years that Ron Delsener, the rock promoter, has owned a second home in East Hampton he has kept what he calls "a low profile."

title: TENNIS;He's a Man Of a Thousand Faces And Few Friends
description: Feats on clay: He has already defended five titles on the surface this year. Or feet of clay: He has already lost six opening-round matches in nine events not on clay. Will the real Thomas Muster please stand up?

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Celebrating the Arts In New Hampshire
description: For the next six months, the state of New Hampshire will be taking note of the MacDowell Colony, the renowned artists' retreat in Peterborough.

title: BEST SELLERS: May 26, 1996
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction

description: To the Editor:

title: MINDING YOUR BUSINESS;A Way to Make Money, and Help Close the Budget Gap
description: Q. I've heard you can make money reporting tax violations to the Internal Revenue Service. Is this true?

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: CITYWIDE A Week of Events To Aid Communities

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TRACK AND FIELD;Suspension Is Upheld For American Sprinter
description: The American sprinter KEVIN BRAUNSKILL must serve the four-year suspension imposed after he tested positive for a steroid in 1994, track's world governing body ruled yesterday. The I.A.A.F. said Braunskill, 28, tested positive at the New York Games on May 22, 1994. His case went to an I.A.A.F. arbitration hearing after U.S. Track and Field, the national governing body, said that the correct procedure wasn't followed in the urine testing at an International Olympic Committee-accredited laboratory in Los Angeles.

title: INSIDE THE MERITOCRACY MACHINE
description: I wish you had included the child of a Harvard alum among the students profiled. As it is, you fuel the idea that African-Americans have an edge in admissions, when in fact no one has more of an edge than whites of a certain class.

title: WEDDINGS;Felice A. Kramer, Douglas S. Levy
description: Felice Amy Kramer, a daughter of Helga Kramer of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., and the late Dr. Rubin Kramer, is to be married today to Douglas Scott Levy, the son of Louis Levy of Commack, L.I., and the late Carol Levy. Rabbi Neil Kurshan is to perform the ceremony at Temple Beth El in Great Neck, L.I.

title: YOUR HOME;Coming to Terms With Termites
description: IF you look closely at the floor of your patio, you might see the gossamer remnants of their once-in-a-lifetime nuptial flight.

title: LACROSSE;Princeton to Face Virginia in Title Game
description: Princeton shut off a remarkable rally by Syracuse in the second half and Virginia neatly disposed of Johns Hopkins as each won semifinal games of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I lacrosse tournament today at Maryland's Byrd Stadium.

title: WEDDINGS;Ms. Hicks, Mr. de Peyster
description: Julia Robinson Hicks, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Hicks of Rye, N.Y., was married at her parents' home yesterday to Nicholas Lindsay Morris de Peyster, a son of James de Peyster Jr. of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., and Margaret Lindsay of Irvington, N.Y. The Rev. Edward Johnston performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: THEATER;'Mundy Scheme' In Croton Falls
description: LEE POPE is crazy for Brian Friel. How else to explain the unearthing of "The Mundy Scheme," a trifle by the Irish playwright, which ran on Broadway in 1969 for 13 previews and 4 performances.

title: World News Briefs;Bulgarian King Returns After a 50-Year Absence
description: King Simeon II, who fled a Communist takeover in 1946, returned to Bulgaria today to a festive pealing of Church bells and an enthusiastic welcome from royalists.

title: 15,000-Mile Olympic Torch Route Gives Lots of People Reasons to FeelGood
description: Somebody shouted, "Here it comes!"

title: WEDDINGS;Maura B. Henry, Robert G. Barbour
description: Maura Beth Henry, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis F. Henry of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Robert Galen Barbour, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Galen L. Barbour of Arlington, Va. The Rev. Edward M. Connors, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Immaculate Heart of Mary Church.

title: Westchester Q&A: Connie Hogarth;22 Years as a Champion of Political Causes
description: VIETNAM, Indian Point, disarmament, South Africa, South America -- the list of causes that Connie Hogarth has fought for and been arrested for seems almost endless.

title: POSTINGS: $10 Million, 30,000-Square-Foot Project;School Building to Rise Next to 96th St. Mosque
description: A $10 million, 30,000-square-foot concrete-and-granite school building set to go up next to the East 96th Street Mosque began as a small project, a weekend religious school for Moslem children, the architect says.

title: EARNING IT;Getting Legal Advice, Without Billable Hours
description: THE legal-service plan, which provides advice and other services for routine legal matters, was born 20 years ago as a prepaid benefit for union auto workers. Now such plans are expanding rapidly among middle-income workers and retirees, many of whom pay to enroll.

title: HORSE RACING: NOTEBOOK;Cigar, Out of Spotlight, Is Ready to Run Again
description: While the 3-year-olds have been hogging the headlines in recent weeks because of the Triple Crown series, racing's best horse, Cigar, has been training quietly at Belmont Park. But he is ready to step back into his rightful spot at center stage.

title: World News Briefs;Seoul Officials Arrested After Jet Crosses Border
description: Four civil defense officials were arrested today for failing to sound air raid sirens in the capital when a defecting North Korean pilot flew his jet into South Korea.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on page 29 of the Arts and Leisure section today showing Suzanne McClelland's painting "Zohnalfloh (3596f)" is reproduced upside down. The line of letters and words should appear at the lower right.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Butler Leaves Hospital
description: BRETT BUTLER was released from Emory University Hospital in Atlanta yesterday, four days after the Los Angeles Dodgers outfielder had a cancerous lymph node removed from his neck.

title: PERSEPECTIVES/OUTDOORS;Doing the Continental One Peak at a Time
description: To hear the mountain climber and adventurer Phil Buck tell it, his successful two-year expedition to reach the highest peak in each of South America's 13 countries was, well, a lot of fun. He respects the risks and hardships of the climbing life, certainly, but he doesn't dwell on them.

title: WEDDINGS;Julia M. Flesher, David H. Koch
description: Julia Margaret Flesher and David Hamilton Koch were married yesterday at the bridegroom's house in Southampton, L.I. The Very Rev. James Parks Morton, the Dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York, performed the ceremony.

title: Ecologists Criticize First Steps in Latin River Plan
description: Plans to begin blasting rock formations in the Paraguay-Parana rivers this June, a preliminary step in a proposed 2,000-mile water highway linking five South American countries, have prompted sharp criticism from environmentalists. They say this violates pledges that the waterway's construction would depend on the outcome of environmental studies.

title: MINNESOTANS;Doncha Know
description: To the Editor:

title: UNDER THE STARS;Getting Back to Nature (Maybe) in a Tent or a Trailer
description: So you don't like to get sand between your toes or shake salt water out of your ears. That doesn't mean you have to stay indoors all summer. You could always try camping.

title: FUNDS WATCH;Ratings for Newcomers
description: Morningstar Inc., the fund research firm in Chicago, is finding itself in the unusual position of supplying information but warning investors not to rely on it.

title: Porquerolles
description: To the Editor: The excellent coverage of Porquerolles did not say whether, given the steep prices, the pension and demi-pension meals at Le Mas du Langoustier are identical to or lesser than, the meals served in the hotel's one-star restaurant. A further query is whether Michael Sarran, the chef who caused the restaurant's rating to be elevated by Michelin, still presides over the kitchen.

title: Sfogliatella
description: To the Editor: We enjoyed Paula Butturini's informative article on Naples, especially the opening paragraphs that so vividly described the sounds, the beauty and decay and morals of Naples.

title: THE GILDED CAGE
description: Andy Behrman's description of the restrictions he experienced under house arrest felt oddly familiar (Lives: "The Gilded Cage," May 5). I, too, know what it's like to be confined to the house for days and have another person control my daily routine.

title: Dole's War Injury
description: To the Editor:

title: SOAPBOX;Memories of a Lost Saloon
description: ANOTHER small piece of New York's soul has died, the victim of an expired lease and a landlord's whim. The original Runyon's, a venerable East 50th Street saloon, has closed its doors for the last time. It might be trite to say that Runyon's was more than just another bar, but for anyone who ever passed through its dark, narrow, smoky space, the closing, on May 3, was heartbreaking beyond belief.

title: KEEPING TO THE CENTER LANE
description: I noted the picture of Whitman posed in riding duds, alongside a mountain bike. She calls herself a cyclist and an environmentalist. But as the editor of Cycling Times, I have seen little to justify these claims.

title: The Casablanca Theory
description: CULTURAL SELECTION By Gary Taylor. Illustrated. 325 pp. New York: Basic Books. $26.

title: NEIGBORHOOD REPORT: MANHATTAN UP CLOSE;Police Ticket Frenzy Summons Up More Than Fines
description: Paul Nadler thought picking up his new stereo from a midtown electronics shop would be simple enough. But every time he tried to stop in front of Harvey Electronics on West 45th Street last week, a summons-book wielding police officer would appear from nowhere, he said. After three trips around the block, Mr. Nadler came up with a resolution to his shopping dilemma: he called the store from his cellular phone and arranged for a clerk to bring the stereo out to the sidewalk.

title: ON LANGUAGE;Downsized
description: YOU SHALL MARK many a duteous and knee-crooking knave," says Iago in "Othello," "that . . . wears out his time, much like his master's ass, for nought but provender, and when he's old, cashiered." Such is "the curse of service."

title: FRUGAL TRAVELER;On Maui, Free Splendor On the Outskirts of Luxury
description: THE famed 50-mile highway that winds around the northeastern coast of Maui to the town of Hana strikes many who drive it as more an amusement park ride than a road -- one hair-raising lane most of the way, with 600 tight curves and 56 battered bridges spanning fast-flooding streams that course down the rain-forested flanks of the Haleakala volcano. Roadside barricades don't look formidable enough to keep a grocery cart from crashing over the sea cliffs to the breakers below; sweeping vistas of the coast tempt drivers to take their eyes off the road, and frequent rain squalls slick the pavement, leaving behind a litter of bright orange African tulip blossoms.

title: Psychotherapist Has Duty to Maintain Privacy
description: To the Editor:

title: A Word of Praise
description: To the Editor: I'd like to share my experience with Finnair during a recent vacation. I arrived at the Kennedy ticket counter, and imagine my surprise when the airline representative told me that I had brought my expired passport.

title: Did I Really Do That?
description: I'm wowing them," Doolittle thought as he wrapped up his speech to the marketing group. He clicked on his last slide -- the sales chart -- and hoped for a zingy finale. But just then, he detected a wisp of white near the floor, and looking down, he saw why his rival, Carothers, had been smirking all day: there were three sheets of toilet tissue stuck to the shoes he had polished so furiously the night before.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW;Celebrations Of Psalmody, New England-Style
description: THEY ARE AS quintessentially American as corn on the cob or hominy grits, dating from the first years of Colonial life. But after decades as a staple of musical life, New England psalmody and its close relative "fasola" singing (named for three consecutive notes in solfege) were eclipsed in the 19th century, surviving only in pockets of the rural south and the Appalachians.

title: At Sea The Hawaiian Way
description: IN approximately 400 A.D., waa kaulua, or double-hulled sailing craft, took Polynesian settlers, their domestic animals and staple plants from the South Pacific to Hawaii. For the last 20 years, the study and painstaking reconstruction of these traditional canoes has come to symbolize the revival of Hawaiian culture. This resurgence is widely apparent, from museum programs on the history and revival of Polynesian voyaging, music and crafts, to viewings of traditional canoes and a five-month schedule of outrigger races. There have been four "voyages of rediscovery," sponsored by Hawaii's Polynesian Voyaging Society, to prove that Hawaii was settled, not by accidental drifting from South America but through an advanced science of celestial navigation. The seminal voyage from Hawaii to Tahiti and back in 1976, was that of Hokulea (Arcturus, or Star of Joy), designed after traditional craft and built from modern materials. In the most recent expedition, in 1995, the Hokulea sailed in record time from Hawaii to Tahiti and Micronesia, accompanied by two new canoes, the Hawaiiloa and the Makalii (the Pleiades).

title: DIARY

In spite of his opposition, though, the House, after a two-month battle, voted last week to lift the wage to $5.15 from $4.25. So, if the bill passes the Senate, low-wage workers will be able to buy a little less food than they could 20 years ago. For by not building an inflation adjustment into the wage, Congress has essentially, almost every year, voted a pay cut for the poor.

title: How To Get To Mars (And Make Millions!)

A second motive is curiosity, for it is also man's nature to see the things he has heard about, and thus learn whether they are as he has been told or not. The third is the desire for gain, for men seek wealth wherever they have heard that gain is to be gotten. -- FROM "THE KING'S MIRROR," A 13TH-CENTURY NORSE TREATISE WHEN HUMANS FINALLY ACQUIRED the technology to travel to another planet, it occurred to them that they didn't really want to go. A manned mission to Mars, the fantasy that had paid the mortgage for generations of science-fiction writers, lost its appeal as soon as NASA plotted the itinerary. The $400 billion price tag seemed absurdly high to a nation bored with the sight of astronauts lumbering around craters. We already had enough extraterrestrial rocks, thank you.

At the summit some 25 centuries ago, Confucius proclaimed the world small, and in this century Chairman Mao pronounced the East Red. In post-Mao China, the world view from the top of Taishan has been altered once again.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION;Another Part of the Forest
description: Once a barefoot beggar child, the heroine of the poet Marly Youmans's second novel, CATHERWOOD (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $20), is brought to live with a noble family in the years after the English Civil War. Something between an indentured servant and an adopted daughter, Catherwood is eventually married off to Gabriel Lyte, who takes her across the Atlantic to a world "fresh and curious" that appears to be "just league after league of woods and swamp and wild river." Feeling herself "the newest of all created things," the young woman confronts her new home, outside Albany, with a keen eye for the "lovely-fierce" sensuousness of nature. Then one day she and her infant daughter become lost in the wilderness, and for months they wander about, trying to find their way. Through her harrowing ordeal, Catherwood learns to divest herself of sentiment and fear, including the fear of "man judgment," until she comes to understand that there are "many roads through wilderness, many paths to the city." In describing this process, Ms. Youmans's language is trenchant, graceful and, in places, sumptuously archaic, filled with a richness that provides more than just period color. Her prodigious powers of description render with acuity both small moments and large: the sea crossing, childbirth, snowfall, the slitting of a fawn's throat, the "rammish" stench of a trapper. Ms. Youmans has written a subtle, intelligent novel about one of the most enduring issues in the American experiment: how to embrace "the world and God" as "better" than men dream. Philip Gambone

Kolata, first set foot on the altiplano, beginning a long journey back into Tiahuanaco's past. Through 17 seasons of excavation and life among the ruins, he has become attached not only to ancient Tiahuanaco but to its modern descendants, the Aymara, who inhabit the austere plateau surrounding the earth's highest lake, Titicaca. In "Valley of the Spirits," he weaves together the threads of history that tie the Aymara to the glorious past of Tiahuanaco.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION;Coming Attractions
description: Compared to today's special-effects-laden blockbusters, early cinematic efforts seem like a yawn. But their eerie realism was so startling to audiences a century ago that their viewing often incited panic. In FROM PEEP SHOW TO PALACE: The Birth of American Film (Columbia University, $29.50), David Robinson, a film historian, provides a diligent overview from the moment cinema was just a flicker in a magic lantern to the golden years between 1893 and 1913, when scientists and technicians laboriously fitted together the "pieces in a puzzle" and created feature films. Mr. Robinson's chronology is painstakingly thorough, if at times tedious, and he dissects the various stages of motion picture development with scholarly zeal. His portrayals of the great cinematic innovators Thomas Edison, the Lumiere brothers and Georges Melies provide some vivid accounts of publicity mongering, patent wrangling and ego interference as the race for notoriety accelerated. But, finally, the book seems to need a slightly more humorous approach to a subject brimming with pratfalls, and leaves the casual reader craving more anecdotes about the personalities that catapulted the entertainment into the pre-eminent American art form. Kathryn Shattuck
