title: Choices and Smiles for New York Consumer
description: From the window of his small stationery supply store at the Avenue of the Americas and 18th Street in Manhattan, Michael Jacobs saw his world transformed as giant retail stores, one after another, moved into the once vacant and grimy strip of warehouses where he had operated his store since the mid-1970's. The new stores, with their employee uniforms and their emphasis on smiling, suburban-style service and vast selection, changed everything -- the buildings, the neighborhood and, in the end, Mr. Jacobs himself.

title: HAUNTED NEIGHBORS -- A special report.;Side by Side Now in Cambodia: Skulls, Victims and Victimizers
description: When the air grows still and heavy here in this pretty village far from any paved road, people say they sometimes hear the sun-bleached skulls of Cambodia's holocaust, piled nearby in the ruins of a schoolhouse, talking to one another.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;From the War on Drugs, Horror Stories and the Case for Peace
description: SMOKE AND MIRRORS The War on Drugs and the Politics of Failure By Dan Baum 396 pages. Little, Brown & Company. $24.95.

title: Gay Rights Victory Is Not Without Hitches;Who Are Unworthy?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: A quarter of a century ago, Barbara Rappaport and Alvin Roth successfully defended the prestigious Life Master Pairs title, the only time that has been done in the event's 66-year history. Mrs. Rappaport has been semiretired for two decades but is now back, remarried, as Barbara Haberman. On Friday, she won the Augusta Cantor Women's Pairs with Dorothy Truscott at the Eastern Regional Championships, played at the Sheraton New York, at Seventh Avenue and 52d Street.

title: Patents;For the prospective muggee on his bicycle, a pepper sprayer with the access and  look of a wristwatch.
description: AN inventor's combination wristwatch and pepper sprayer probably won't ever become a staple in James Bond's cache of sophisticated covert weapons. But William W. Moseley of Mertztown, Pa., is hoping that it will have broad appeal to ordinary people.

title: From West to East: What They Are Buying
description: What are they listening to in Tokyo? What are they watching in France and reading in Russia? A survey of the most popular movies, TV shows, magazines, books and CD's in nine countries.

title: Updated, Drive to Cut Taxes Regains Currency in G.O.P.
description: After years in the political wilderness, while official Washington focused on deficit reduction, Republican proponents of deep tax cuts are once again getting a serious hearing within their party.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Maybe It's Not Pork After All
description: He had called the legislation "pork" in a letter to a colleague, but now an important Federal lawmaker is willing to reverse his position on a bill to provide $3.25 million for preserving the Great Falls Historic District in Paterson, an official of the House Resources Committee said last week. Dan Kish, the committee's majority staff director, said the committee's chairman, Representative Don Young, Republican of Alaska, agreed to finance the project if the money were earmarked specifically for restoring the Colt Company's gun factory and to reconstruct the raceways at the falls, which provided the power for the country's first manufacturing center. TERRY PRISTIN

title: TENNIS;In Paris, Love, Hate, Aches And Pains
description: It's raining, it's pouring, but the French Open won't be boring.

title: In America;Turning Children's Rights Into Reality
description: If we could have but one generation of properly born, trained, educated, and healthy children, a thousand other problems of government would vanish."

title: Two Missions in Africa, but a Common Complaint
description: In the space of two months, two foreign military interventions, one American, the other French, have been mounted to extract Westerners from violence that has all but destroyed two African capitals.

title: Orange County To Issue Debt
description: Orange County has said that it plans to issue about $900 million of recovery debt on June 6 and barring unforeseen complications will close the deal on June 11 and emerge from bankruptcy.

title: Essay;The Devil We Know
description: There are two devils," says Grigory Yavlinsky, the democratic reformer presumably running third in the race for president of Russia. "One is a small devil -- that is Yeltsin. One is a big devil -- that is the Communist Zyuganov."

title: Gay Rights Victory Is Not Without Hitches
description: To the Editor:

title: The Media Business: What They're Buying in 9 Countries: Argentina;Gossip Takes Priority
description: Browsing through magazines at newsstands is a favorite pastime for Portenos -- as the residents of Buenos Aires are called. Kioscos, or newsstands, are as much a part of the city as sidewalk cafes or the multicolored buses that rocket down the streets barely missing pedestrians.

title: How Easily We Killed Them
description: We killed 170 people in Lebanon last month. Most were refugees. A good number were women, children and the elderly. Nine civilians, including a 2-year-old and a 100-year-old man, were killed at Sachmor, a village. Eleven civilians, including seven children, were killed at Nabatiyeh, a town. At the United Nations compound at Qana, a village, 102 were killed. We killed all these people not in a fit of inflamed passion, not because of messianic extremism or nationalist fervor.

title: The Media Business: What They're Buying in 9 Countries: Russia;Where Pushkin Still Lives
description: Culturally haughty visitors who are sick of their own low standards love to sneer about the declining state of Russian literature -- and literacy. Yes, Sidney Sheldon and Stephen King are far more popular here than Pushkin or Dostoyevsky.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 15 about an exhibition in Venice devoted to the colonization of the Mediterranean by the ancient Greeks misidentified the capital of the Mycenaean culture. It was the city of Mycenae on the Greek mainland, not the island of Crete.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Daily Briefing column in New Jersey copies on Wednesday about a public interest group's ratings of state legislators on major environmental legislation omitted one name. The group, the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group, listed State Senator Richard J. Codey, Democrat of West Orange, among the state senators who received a rating of 70 percent or better on environmental bills.

title: N.B.A. PLAYOFFS;Rodman Shoots Back at Shaq
description: The Diesel and The Worm have tangled one too many times inside the paint during the Eastern Conference finals. Judging by their words today, Shaquille O'Neal and Dennis Rodman are one forearm shiver away from trading blows.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Hunters Bag 1,772 Turkeys
description: The wild turkey hunting season that ended last week was the most successful since the state reintroduced the bird two decades ago. Hunters bagged 1,772 gobblers during the five-week season, according to preliminary figures by the State Division of Fish, Game and Wildlife. The harvest, said a state wildlife biologist, Robert Eriksen, reflects a turkey population that now stands at 12,000 to 14,000. New Jersey's wild turkeys were wiped out by 1977 by hunting and deforestation, but the state brought in turkeys from Vermont and gradually built their numbers back up. Turkeys are now found in 20 of the 21 counties.

title: Brooklyn Museum Chief Resigns After 13 Years
description: Robert T. Buck, who as director of the Brooklyn Museum for 13 years has led it through a period of great expansion and severe budgetary cutbacks, has resigned. He will leave the post on July 1.

title: G.E. Wins Taiwan Nuclear-Plant Contract
description: The General Electric Company has won a contract to supply two nuclear reactors and related equipment for Taiwan's fourth nuclear power plant with a bid of $1.8 billion, the state-run Taiwan Power Company said today.

title: BASEBALL;Jones Rides To Rescue For the Mets
description: Two short months ago, Bobby Jones was the overlooked starter on a Mets staff of promising if inexperienced young arms. Who knew then that he would emerge as the team's stopper?

title: Supporters Mob the Bulgarian King on His Return
description: King Simeon II of Bulgaria was mobbed by supporters today as he toured the lavish Orthodox churches of the capital, Sofia, on the second day of his return from 50 years of exile.

title: Editorial Notebook;India's Agonies
description: The growing alienation between Hindus and Muslims in India may seem difficult for outsiders to grasp. But consider the story of a destitute Muslim woman who, two decades ago, dared to file for alimony in an Indian court when her well-to-do husband divorced her after 43 years of marriage. Her case provides a window into the agonies of modern India, demonstrating why it is often hard to reconcile the ideals of civil society with the anxieties of a beleaguered minority community.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Putting New Twists On Ancient Celtic Airs
description: Flying fingers and poker faces, self-deprecating drollery and steadfast love songs filled a quadruple bill of Celtic music on Saturday night at the Bottom Line, as Green Linnet Records celebrated its 20th anniversary by presenting some of its Irish and Scottish mainstays. The musicians were steeped in tradition, but not purists.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about New York City's decision to terminate contracts with private agencies for child abuse prevention misstated the number of programs affected. A total of nine contracts were terminated. (Twenty-two other programs were not included in the Mayor's budget for the coming fiscal year, but have not been terminated.)

title: BASEBALL;Kamieniecki Sent to Minors
description: Battered for 18 earned runs and 20 hits in his last six and two-thirds innings and carrying an 11.12 earned run average, Scott Kamieniecki was optioned to Class AAA Columbus today so the Yankees could activate Bernie Williams.

title: TECHNOLOGY: CONNECTIONS;Describing intelligence through a virtual symphony.
description: IN a large black room, two stories high, on the ground floor of the Media Lab of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, the composer Tod Machover is working on the model of a brain.

title: Falling Prices For Newsprint
description: Newsprint producers in North America are lowering prices for their biggest clients by roughly 6 percent, to about $660 a metric ton, people in the industry said.

title: PERES AND HIS FOE DO VERBAL BATTLE IN SOLE TV DEBATE
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres and Benjamin Netanyahu squared off today for their first and only direct showdown of the Israeli election campaign, a televised debate in which Mr. Peres pitted his experience, decorum and vision against his challenger's youth, television skills and aggressiveness.

title: AUTO RACINGSomething Old and Something New at 230 M.P.H.; Vasser Uses Spare Car To Win First U.S. 500
description: Billed as the race with the best cars and with the best drivers, the first U.S. 500 did not begin in the best way. In fact, for some, it began in sheer embarrassment and sheer horror.

title: COMMENCEMENTS;Wesleyan Senior Leaves a Bit of Himself Behind: His Hair
description: At a school known for political rallies and protests, the president of the graduating class at Wesleyan University made yet another symbolic gesture yesterday during his commencement speech: He cut off his ponytail.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a House vote on a measure to repeal a 4.3-cent-a-gallon Federal tax on gasoline referred incompletely to its provisions. The repeal would expire on Jan. 1.

title: POP REVIEW;Going From Thoughtful To the Corny and Carnal
description: Watching Rod Stewart perform his hits in roughly chronological order on Thursday night at Madison Square Garden was like witnessing a slow death. The show, the second of two sold-out nights that were rescheduled from February, when Mr. Stewart came down with the flu, began with a sensitive and sardonic tale of a schoolboy being used as a sex toy ("Maggie May"), a highlight of Mr. Stewart's years with the Faces ("Stay With Me") and a rock-and-roll oldie well suited to Mr. Stewart's scratchy pipes ("Twistin' the Night Away").

title: In Mini-Repeat Uptown, Pipe Bursts in Manhattan
description: A 92-year-old water main on Manhattan's Upper West Side broke early yesterday morning, briefly sending a stream down Broadway and marking the second time this month that a burst pipe in Manhattan has closed streets and disrupted subway service.

title: HORSE RACING;Unbridled's Song Finds the Right Race. Then He Loses It.
description: After all the talking and balking about where he would run next, Unbridled's Song finally ran yesterday at Belmont Park. He led four rivals for one mile in the Peter Pan Stakes but then wearied of the battle and surrendered to the less well-known but faster-closing Jamie's First Punch in the last eighth of a mile.

title: Abroad at Home;Mr. Arafat Relents
description: At 11 o'clock last night in Gaza, Dr. Eyad Sarraj was released from a Palestinian prison. It was the end of a personal drama with implications for all Palestinians -- and for Israel.

title: When Teaching Reading, Think History
description: To the Editor:

title: Marion S. Kirk, 92, Advocate of the Arts
description: Marion Sands Kirk, a supporter of the arts in New York, died on May 17 at the Auburn Manor nursing home in Washington Court House, Ohio, where she had lived for the last decade. She was 92.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about the writer Joseph Mitchell referred incorrectly to his marriage, and the list of survivors omitted his siblings. He was married only once, to Therese Dagny Jacobsen, who died in 1980. A sister, Linda Mitchell Lamm, lives in Wilson, N.C., and a brother, Harry Mitchell, in Fairmont, N.C.

title: No Headline
description: You know those dreams you used to have about failing math? Well, I always have these terrible dreams that it is May 10 and I don't have a graduation speaker."

title: Europe's Monetary Union Poses No Traps
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Hospitals Chief to Lead Tampa General
description: Dr. Bruce Siegel, who resigned as president of New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation following allegations of sexual harassment, has tentatively agreed to be the president and chief executive officer of Tampa General Hospital in Florida.

title: In Season of Commencements, Words of Wisdom Heard Anew
description: Yogi Berra, the former Yankee great, might describe this year's commencement speeches (and his own at Montclair State University in New Jersey) as deja vu all over again. Few speakers focused on major news events or looked ahead to the Presidential election. Most recycled popular themes: unity, family, public service. Among the speakers: a frog named Kermit. These excerpts were taken from transcripts provided by universities and colleges.

title: N.H.L. PLAYOFFS;Penguins Use Finesse To Even Their Series
description: When it was over, Jaromir Jagr waved off reporters. "Too much pain," the Pittsburgh Penguins' right wing said, pointing to his mouth. His fellow star, Mario Lemieux, had gobs of sweat rolling off his face as he sat exhausted at his locker, talking in a whisper.

title: Ripken at the Hot Corner Would Put Johnson in the Hot Seat
description: There's an axiom that the baseball manager, like the customer, is always right. Davey Johnson of the Baltimore Orioles will want people to remember that if, and more likely when, he moves Cal Ripken Jr. from shortstop to third base.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Another First-Time Winner on PGA Tour

title: A Separate Peace?
description: Gov. George E. Pataki entered office with a promise to end the historical conflict between the executive branch and Legislature. But he now finds himself locked in an all-but-declared war with legislative leaders over the budget, a testy fray that is isolating him from his fellow Republicans and placing much of his agenda at risk.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the tentative release dates for major economic indicators this week.

title: World News Briefs;Shaky Government Stays in Turkey for Now
description: Prime Minister Mesut Yilmaz of Turkey said today that his weak conservative Government would remain in power for now despite losing the support of his coalition partner.

title: AUTO RACING;Car No. 96 Where Are You?
description: Car No. 96 avoided the disgrace of finishing last in the Indianapolis 500 today -- just barely. Paul Durant, its driver, completed nine laps (out of 200) before his Lola's Buick engine blew up. That was good for 32d, just ahead of Johnny Unser, whose car broke a gearbox on the pace laps.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings this week:

title: In the Rockaways, Drafting Birds and Bats In War on Mosquitoes;Battling Survivors of Swats and Sprays
description: With the nervous cackles of laughing gulls overhead and the bright blue waters of Jamaica Bay glinting in the middle distance, the Rockaways would appear to be the perfect place to spend the summer -- a swatch of the Hamptons in the borough of Queens.

title: For Rosemary Harris, A Delicate Balance Of Her Art and Life
description: Sitting gracefully on a couch, with her silvery hair swept neatly back from her forehead, Rosemary Harris is a portrait of carefully measured repose. But as she moves into her opening speech in "A Delicate Balance," she reveals an underlying concern, even a dread, that she will be overcome by incipient madness. Ms. Harris is radiant in capturing the diverse aspects of Agnes, the wife and mother in the Edward Albee play, revived on Broadway by Gerald Gutierrez.

title: Mario Braggiotti, 90, Pianist of Radio Era
description: Mario Braggiotti, a pianist and radio personality for more than 40 years, died on May 18 after a long illness. He was 90.

title: The Media Business: What They're Buying in 9 Countries: India;The Heroes Can Dance
description: Going to the movies in India is an interactive experience. Audiences often jeer and make catcalls, sing along to the tunes and yell warnings to victims-to-be. "Indian cinema enables Indians to dream with their eyes open," says Shashi Tharoor, author of "Show Business," a novel about the Indian film industry. They can dream of palatial homes and fancy cars, of glamorous parties and foreign travel.

title: Black Box' Is Recovered At Everglades Crash Site
description: Police searchers today found the cockpit voice recorder of the Valujet DC-9 that plunged into the Florida Everglades on May 11, providing investigators with the second of the "black boxes" that often yield crucial information on the cause of a crash.

title: Gay Rights Victory Is Not Without Hitches;No Honeymoon
description: To the Editor:

title: N.B.A. PLAYOFFS;The Sonics Head Home Breathing a Lot Easier
description: A cherubic man put a curse on John Stockton today.

title: Holiday Today
description: Memorial Day is observed today.

title: Gay Rights Victory Is Not Without Hitches;Kulturkampf's Spite
description: To the Editor:

title: SOCCER;MetroStars Close to Naming a New Coach
description: The man who turned down the job of coach of the United States national soccer team is expected to be named coach of the MetroStars. Carlos Queiroz of Portugal arrived in the New York area last night from Lisbon and could be named as Eddie Firmani's replacement on the Major League Soccer team within a day.

title: Fiery Protest By Inmates At Rikers
description: About half a dozen inmates on Rikers Island staged a protest by igniting their blankets yesterday and throwing them onto the floor outside their cells, creating a plume of smoke that overpowered seven corrections officers and seven inmates who had to be treated for smoke inhalation, prison officials said.

title: Travelers' Boon Is Smugglers' Bane
description: Many a jet-lagged traveler has felt the joy of journey's end dampened by the exasperation of having to line up at the Customs counter for a uniformed inspector's standard question, "Have you anything to declare?"

title: School Equity in New Jersey
description: After decades of litigation, New Jersey remains tied up in knots over court demands for fairness in school spending. The New Jersey Supreme Court has repeatedly called for funding parity between rich and poor districts, and repeatedly rejected the reforms enacted by the Legislature as inadequate. The latest leader to wrestle with the issue is Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, who has presented her own broad changes in the way schools are financed. There is no guarantee that she will be any more successful than her predecessors.

title: POLITICS: THE STRATEGY;California Staff Shake-Up Signals Big Push by Dole
description: With evidence building that he may seriously contest President Clinton for California's huge trove of 54 electoral college votes, Senator Bob Dole plans to campaign the length of the Golden State in the coming week and, aides say, also will shake up the top of his California campaign staff.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about Shelley List, a television producer, misidentified the character who struggled with alcoholism in an episode of "Cagney and Lacey" written by Ms. List and her husband, Jonathan Estrin. The character was Cagney, not Lacey.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Enfants Terribles of the Opera Stage
description: One English opera administrator speaks of them as "a force outside human ability." Another sniffs, "There are moments when, I assure you, they are definitely not worth the trouble, and I would happily boot them down Floral Street." They, these singers who can be, as one admirer says, "glamorous, vexing and all too human," are the subject of "Divas," tonight's "Great Performances."

title: MARKETS CLOSED
description: All financial and commodity markets and banks in the United States are closed today in observance of Memorial Day. A number of European markets, including those in Germany and Britain, are also closed for local holidays.

title: Despite Compromises, India's Hindu Nationalist Government Seems Headedfor Defeat
description: India's new Hindu nationalist Government appears headed for defeat in Parliament this week even though it has dropped parts of its election platform that have alienated Muslims and others who see the nationalists as a threat to India's secular political traditions.

title: For Some, Graduation Is Sweeter
description: Sarah Tarsis

title: MEDIA: TELEVISION;For the networks, the most recent season could have been called 'Storm Watch.'
description: THE 1995-96 television season was dominated so thoroughly by NBC that even rival network executives resorted to comparing the network to the Chicago Bulls.

title: Despite Arrests, Burmese Democrats Meet and Vow to Press On
description: Although many of its leaders have been arrested in recent days, the Burmese opposition vowed today to increase the pace of its struggle for democracy as thousands of supporters turned out at the beginning of a party meeting.

title: Dr. Katsuma Dan, 91, of Japan; Was a Leading Marine Biologist
description: Dr. Katsuma Dan, a Japanese developmental biologist who made fundamental discoveries in studies of marine organisms, died on May 18 at the home of his eldest daughter in Osaka. A former resident of Tokyo, he was 91.

title: World News Briefs;China Officials Say They Freed Dissident Official
description: Chinese prison authorities said today that they had freed Bao Tong, the only senior official jailed for backing the 1989 pro-democracy protests, after a seven-year prison term, but the family said he had disappeared.

title: 5 Injured as Police Chase Drug Suspect
description: Five people, including an undercover police sergeant and three bystanders, were injured yesterday when a drug suspect led officers on a car chase across two boroughs, officials said.

title: Girl, 13, Pleads Guilty in Clinton Threats
description: A 13-year-old girl pleaded guilty to mailing threatening letters to President Clinton, his family and other officials, while a second girl denied taking part and demanded a trial.

title: World News Briefs;U.S. Lawmaker Arrives In North Korea for Talks
description: An American Congressman arrived in North Korea today to try to persuade officials to accept proposed four-nation peace talks.

title: Albania Democrats Rejoice
description: Thousands of jubilant supporters of the governing Democratic Party took to the streets early today in the biggest celebration seen here since the fall of Communism six years ago. They were anticipating an official announcement that the pro-Western Democrats had held on to power in Sunday's election.

title: Doctor Quoted as Criticizing Arafat Is Freed
description: A Palestinian human rights advocate detained after he was quoted as criticizing Yasir Arafat's self-rule administration was released today, his brother said.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Fox to Turn Over Tape
description: Fox Television plans to comply with a court order on Wednesday by turning over a taped interview in which a Franklin jewelry store owner, Jeffrey Wolf, said he accidentally killed his wife while the store was being robbed, a lawyer for the network said last week. The tape was subpoenaed by Harry Insabella, who is being tried for felony murder in the death of Mr. Wolf's wife, Brenda.

title: Trevi Fountain Can Be Plucked
description: Legend says a coin tossed in the Trevi Fountain will guarantee a return trip to Rome. Now a prosecutor says plucking the coins from the fountain does not mean a trip to court.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Tobacco-Free Funds Sought
description: In yet another move against the tobacco industry, a State Assembly member plans to introduce a bill this week to prohibit the state from investing employee pension funds in cigarette companies. Under the legislation by Shirley K. Turner, Democrat of Ewing Township, the state would have to sell off $426 million in tobacco company investments. Comptroller H. Carl McCall of New York announced in March that he would halt future investments in tobacco interests.

title: Wanted: Graduation Speakers; Need Fame, Presidents Preferred
description: Graduation might be a cause of celebration for college students, but lining up a suitably grand commencement speaker has increasingly become a source of anxiety for many college presidents.

title: Mortgage Rates Dip Again
description: Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 8.01 percent last week, down from 8.08 percent the previous week, according to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. The average was the lowest since May 2, when rates averaged 7.99 percent.

title: New Twist in Cultural Saga
description: What started as a cultural tug-of-war over a small statue of a Japanese folk hero at Rollins College in Winter Park, Fla., has led to the signing at this year's commencement of what amounts to a peace treaty between the college and the statue's new owners in Okinawa.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Defining Ill-Defined Yearnings
description: A scary, unspoken and all too familiar question grips the audience in the opening seconds of one of the new one-act plays in the Ensemble Studio Theater's Marathon series: Just how bad is this going to be? There's a blue-collar lug in a T-shirt staring blankly out a window; there's the shrill little wife clamoring for attention. Oh, please. Didn't this kind of thing go out in the 1950's?

title: Scaring Up New Business With a Twist
description: At a time when the entertainment world seems maddeningly complex, consider the refreshingly simple way the Six Flags theme park here will amuse customers this summer: they will be strapped in a car, shot 415 feet in the air, then dropped along a track at 100 miles an hour.

title: Metro Matters;  Is It Murder? Playing Tough Against Crime
description: NOW, New York City's chief executive is not only the city's putative police commissioner and sometime judge, but he also seems to insist on being prosecutor in chief as well. After the Bronx Distict Attorney filed manslaughter instead of murder charges against a man implicated in the death of a police officer, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani angrily told the television cameras that "if the District Attorney would like to swear me in and turn the case over to me, I'll take over." This weekend, he even carried the argument all the way to the funeral service.

title: Computer Age Dream: Laptop on Every Desk
description: Mayor Walter D. Long and friends in the New Jersey suburb of Summit have a dream for the coming millennium: providing personal laptop computers for all of Summit's high school students and teachers by the year 2001.

title: Jacob Druckman, 67, Dies; A Composer and Teacher
description: Jacob Druckman, a Pulitzer Prize-winning composer, teacher and conductor who, through his work as a consultant to major symphony orchestras and a president of foundations, became an influential proponent of contemporary music, died on Friday at the Yale Health Service in New Haven. He was 67 and lived in Milford, Conn.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on May 19 about Willis Conover, the Voice of America disk jockey, gave an incorrect date for Duke Ellington's tour of the Soviet Union. It took place in 1971, not 1954.

title: Debate at Home Mirrors One on TV
description: There were two debates at the Ellenblum home tonight. One, on television, was between Prime Minister Shimon Peres and his Likud challenger, Benjamin Netanyahu. And one, in the living room, was between Ronnie Ellenblum and his mother-in-law.

title: Hot Spell Gives Cities Chance to Prepare for Sizzlers to Come
description: A spell of unseasonably hot weather last week has focused renewed attention on heat emergency programs in some Eastern and Midwestern cities that were revised after more than 1,000 people died in last July's devastating swelter.

title: N.B.A. PLAYOFFS;Bulls, and Everyone Else, Thinking Sweep
description: Never mind the injuries, the 3-0 deficit that no team has overcome or even the larger picture, in which Shaquille O'Neal and his basketball cartoon playland are about to be deadbolted for the season.

title: BASEBALL;Seattle Sees Gooden Again and This Time Says No to a No-Hitter
description: The question was simple. The answer was revealing. Dwight Gooden was asked how he felt about opposing the Mariners only 12 days after having twirled a memorable no-hitter against them and his face and his voice suddenly turned serious. Gooden seemed almost solemn.

title: The Media Business: What They're Buying in 9 Countries: France;Television vs. The Bistro
description: Few cities in the world offer a richer fare of movies and restaurants than Paris, yet the number of movie-goers has slumped and neighborhood bistros continue to close. The culprit? Television. The French now spend an average of three hours each day watching television -- principally between 7 P.M. and 10:30 P.M. -- compared with about four hours of daily viewing in the United States. Just as TV Guide is one of the United States' top-selling magazines, France's three top-selling magazines are voted to television.

title: POLITICS: THE ISSUES;Many Disillusioned Liberals See No Alternative to President
description: A couple of months ago, Tina Podlodowski, a member of the Seattle City Council, an accomplished fund raiser, a Democrat and a lesbian, accepted an invitation to be a co-chairwoman of President Clinton's re-election campaign in Washington State.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-7

title: Raceway That Siphoned Off Aggression
description: Xavier King, a self-described gang leader, used to spend hours under the hood of his souped-up Corvette preparing for the weekend races at the Brotherhood Raceway Park, where he would challenge everyone from rival gang members to law-enforcement officers.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Republican Tax Cutters Being Heard in Their Party After years when many in Washington focused on deficit reduction, Republican proponents of deep tax cuts are once again getting a serious hearing within their party.

title: AMERICAN TOPICS : The Latest in a Long Line Of Presidential Golfers
description: Compared with some other presidential golfers, Bill Clinton is only so-so. But what he lacks in skill he makes up in zest.

title: TRACK AND FIELD;Second-Place Finish No Laughing Matter for Lewis
description: Before the 200 meters at today's Prefontaine Classic, Jon Drummond turned to Carl Lewis and said, "I'm here to keep you honest."

title: Taking In the Sites;Visit the Parks On-Line Before Going
description: The Internet offers many sources of information on national parks, monuments and hiking trails, and net surfers with fast connections can even get virtual tours.

title: Sports of The Times;Sweet Lou Turns Sour on Gooden After He Plays a Little Chin Music
description: LOU PINIELLA was saying such nice things about Dwight Gooden after his fellow Tampa, Fla., native had tossed a no-hitter against the Mariners 13 days ago. But the lyrics were a little different last night when Gooden heaved two pitches close to Dan Wilson during the Mariners' 4-3 victory over the Yankees.

title: Japanese Stocks Down
description: Stocks were trading lower here today. In mid-afternoon trading, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 240.65 points -- or 1.10 percent -- to stand at 21,557.78. On Friday, the Nikkei index gained 74.35 points.

title: John Laurance Dunning, Radio Free Europe Executive, 83
description: John Laurance Dunning, a former vice president of Radio Free Europe and a retired Foreign Service officer, died on May 19 in St. Andrew's Hospital in Boothbay Harbor, Me. He was 83 and lived in East Boothbay.

title: A Web Entree For Peruvians Without PC's
description: Jessy Contreras, a 23-year-old cosmetology student, had long dreamed of logging on to the Internet to view the latest fashion and beauty trends from Paris that she hoped to use in a start-up salon.

title: When Teaching Reading, Think History
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times;Sitting In Front Of a Broom
description: PEOPLE say a lot of fascinating things when they lose. I suppose that's why, over the years, the loser's locker room has become more intriguing than the winner's, and is more a laboratory of thoughts and feelings.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Yearning for Old Ticket Law
description: When tickets went on sale May 18 for the Garden State Arts Center's summer concert series -- featuring performers like Ozzy Osbourne, Meat Loaf and the Beach Boys -- many of the people standing in line were paid representatives of scalpers who planned to resell the tickets for a considerable markup, said State Senator Richard J. Codey, Democrat of West Orange. That experience, Mr. Codey said last week, demonstrated the value of the old state policy under which resellers could add only $3 or 20 percent, whichever was less, to the face value. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed a bill establishing an 18-month trial period that began Oct. 4 during which licensed ticket brokers could resell tickets for concerts and sports events for any price the market would allow.

title: BALLET REVIEW;All Tchaikovsky, Intensely Classical
description: Good old Tchaikovsky came through as expected in the new "All-Tchaikovsky Program" that American Ballet Theater introduced over the weekend, but there was also considerable help from his friends onstage.

title: Independent Newspapers Protest in Algeria
description: Editors of Algeria's 16 independent newspapers refused to publish their papers today to protest the state monopoly on printing presses.

title: French Grip in Africa Extends to Comoros

title: Wireless Systems Put Out Their Antennas
description: The race is on for the high ground: buildings, trees, water towers, church steeples, any place with a clear view and a sturdy spot to anchor an antenna.

title: AUTO RACING  Something Old and Something New at 230 M.P.H.; From a Broken Back To an Indy Victory
description: Most of this month, Buddy Lazier was feeling pained and very grouchy. Today, after making good on a great chance to win the Indianapolis 500, Lazier was still in pain, but in a much better mood.

title: U.S. Seeking Options on Pollution Rules
description: In this desert boom town just south of Phoenix, where springtime temperatures run into three digits and it almost never rains, the environmental managers of the Intel Corporation's newest integrated-circuit plant are treating their water in ways that no pollution control law requires.

title: The Media Business: What They're Buying in 9 Countries: Japan;Music All Day Long
description: Tower Records, in the funky Shibuya district, is the largest music store in the world -- eight floors of music heaven, where hundreds of young people scour through 600,000 titles of rock, pop, soul, rap, jazz and Japanese popular songs.

title: Florence Journal;Overrun by Tourists, 'David' Puts His Foot Down
description: For anyone who has had to jostle their way across the Ponte Vecchio into an oncoming wave of tourists armed with guide books and ice cream cones, the city of Florence has come up with a new plan for regulating the flow of visitors.

title: 7 'Dead' Bosnians Alive, But Just Who Are They?
description: It has been two weeks since American peacekeeping troops on an artillery exercise on the outskirts of town heard bursts of automatic weapons fire, then saw seven men running up to surrender to them.

title: 1.2 Million Award In Agent Orange Suit
description: A man who said he contracted cancer from using Agent Orange to remove foliage from around power lines has been awarded $1.2 million by a jury.

title: 2 Riders Hurt on Coney Island Coaster, Renewing Safety Fears
description: A wheel fell off a Coney Island roller coaster on Saturday night, slightly injuring two riders and once again raising questions about the safety of rides at New York City amusement parks.

title: N.B.A. PLAYOFFS;Kentucky And Nets Waiting on Pitino
description: Rick Pitino was above it all yesterday, out of reach at 35,000 feet, with the tranquillity of the clouds around him and a muted world below him. But what turbulence he left behind when he took off for Ireland.

title: Cereal That Says 'You've Won' Instead of 'Snap, Crackle, Pop'
description: The company that tried to convince us that its rice cereal says "snap, crackle, pop" has now succeeded in putting a voice in some of its breakfast-food boxes.

title: Gulls Are Cast as Threat to Avian Neighbors; Agency Is Cast in a BadLight
description: The gull has long been a symbol of Cape Cod. Swooping, flying, feeding gulls. But as the Memorial Day weekend began in this usually bucolic resort town, the talk was of dying gulls -- and the Federal Government.

title: Half-Truths on Gas Taxes
description: Fill 'er up, America, this is the Memorial Day holiday and the start of the "summer driving season." We are a road-running, gas-guzzling people and Bob Dole, Newt Gingrich and Bill Clinton all say our Federal tax should be lowered 4.3 cents a gallon. But the tax relief, if it ever comes, will be trivial -- and will have a negative impact on public policy. It is, in short, something of a political fraud.

title: Gay Rights Victory Is Not Without Hitches;Vote No Evil
description: To the Editor:

title: AN AMERICAN PLACE -- Shifting Allegiances;Backers of Bush in '92 Are Turning to Clinton
description: Judith Snow, 57, is the voter Bob Dole must win over if he is to take the Presidency. Mrs. Snow is a Republican, she voted for George Bush in 1992, she runs a small clothing shop in the Republican suburb of North Canton and she is winnable. "I just keep listening to Dole and Clinton," she said. "Some days, you think no, some days yes." But if she cast her vote today, it would be a yes, for Bill Clinton.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;No Parade in Princeton
description: As municipal budgets tighten and veterans' groups gray, the money and volunteers needed for Memorial Day parades get scarcer. For the first time in more than 70 years, Princeton is having only a commemorative service today and not a full parade. The parade's cost had risen to $4,000, much of it for three marching bands, but local governments could contribute only $1,400 and American Legion Post 76, which organized the parades, was unable to make up the difference, said Henry Frank, the post's adjutant. Ray Zawacki, the state American Legion adjutant, said that public enthusiasm for the parades peaked during the Gulf War.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;For Eastwood, Honor And Embarrassment
description: On Feb. 29, Clint Eastwood became the 24th recipient of the American Film Institute's Life Achievement Award. It was conferred before an all-star formal gathering by Steven Spielberg, last year's honoree. An hourlong version of the evening's highlights can be seen on ABC tonight; the complete two-hour program will be shown on A&E later this year. ABC's "American Film Institute Salute to Clint Eastwood" follows the standard script for these generally classy occasions. An announcer intones, "Ladies and gentlemen, Mr. Clint Eastwood"; the star enters to a standing ovation, sits with loved ones, in this case his mother and new wife, and then proceeds to smile gamely as his life and career are reduced to film clips and sound bites. (Mr. Eastwood had a similar experience several weeks ago when he was honored by the Film Society of Lincoln Center.) Still, this event has a smidgen more dignity than most televised award shindigs, even when the zany Jim Carrey is one of the hosts.

description: Baseball

title: County's New Stance
description: In Stark County, Ohio, a political bellweather, voters say they have been disatisfied enough by the Republican-led Congress over the last four years to move toward President Clinton for now. In a recent survey, economic matters were by far the biggest concern among those polled, and on a whole, people seem to feel they are not doing badly.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Fleet Week activities in New York City misspelled the surname of the photographer who took the famous photo of a sailor kissing a woman in Times Square on V-J Day in 1945. It is Alfred Eisenstaedt, not Eisenstadt.

title: AUTO RACING;Jarrett Closes In on a Million
description: Dale Jarrett set himself up for a run at a $1 million bonus by running away from the field in Nascar's longest race.

title: Japan Seen to Finance Fiber Optic Project
description: The Japanese Government has decided to spend a total of 7 trillion yen, or $64.8 billion, to support private companies' efforts to construct passageways for an underground fiber optic network, the Nihon Keizai newspaper reported today.

title: Arona McHugh, 71; Set 2 of Her Novels In Her Native Boston
description: Arona Lipman McHugh, the author of four novels, two of them set in her native Boston, died on Wednesday at St. Vincent's Medical Center in Staten Island. She was 71 and lived in the West Brighton section.

title: End Near for 179-Mile Bus Trip to High School
description: For years, high school students in southern Brewster County, a vast West Texas outback of desert and mountain along the Mexican border, have laid claim to an odd and generally unwelcome title: commuters on the longest school bus ride in the United States.

title: LACROSSE;The Princeton Formula Is Fast and Fail-Safe
description: Jesse Hubbard, who has perhaps the hardest, fastest shot in lacrosse, scored Princeton's first and last goals today during a three-goal performance against Virginia. His final one, a rocket from 10 yards out, went by the knee of goalie Chris Sanderson 34 seconds into overtime and gave the Tigers a 13-12 victory and the national championship for the third time in five seasons.

title: Dam Said to Threaten Ancient Lungfish
description: THE Australian lungfish, which can use its one lung to breathe air, is one of the planet's strangest and hardiest survivors. It is one of the last remnants of the Dipnoi, a group of fish that has swum the world's rivers for more than 400 million years, managing to hang on as countless contemporaries, including the dinosaurs, died out and other creatures, like Homo sapiens, took their first steps. But conservationists say this species, now restricted to a handful of rivers in northeastern Australia, is being threatened in one of its last strongholds.

title: New Designers Bestow a Fresh Elegance on Fur
description: The new designers who have swept onto the fur scene in the last year are clearly having an impact. In the runway shows that concluded last week, more than a dozen newcomers showed collections for fall, and their presence measurably lifted the design standard and the level of excitement in the fur industry.

title: Corrections
description: A chart Saturday about New York City's efforts to shift Medicaid recipients into managed-care plans misidentified the sources of the data. They were the State Department of Health and the State Department of Social Services, not their city counterparts.

title: All-Night Parties and a Nod to the 60's (Rave On)
description: The following snippets of conversation were overheard on Memorial Day weekend at the Eagle Cave and Mountain Campgrounds here: "Dudes, my last brain cell is already hanging on the edge, and it's only Friday -- or Saturday." "Is everyone here a D.J.?" "I hate brushing my teeth when I'm wasted." "Does anyone have some milk or vitamin B12?" "I can't find my car. Man, I don't even know if I drove it here."

description: Philip B. Healey, a New York State Assemblyman who espoused the cause of the elderly, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at Massapequa General Hospital on Long Island, moments after he finished marching in the town's Memorial Day parade. He was 72.

title: Pilots Alerted To Cabin Fire, Jet Tape Shows
description: The pilots of Valujet Flight 592 were some six minutes into a routine flight out of Miami when someone apparently burst through the cockpit door to warn of a fire in the passenger cabin, according to investigators' first analysis of the tape from the jet's battered cockpit voice recorder.

title: ON BASEBALL;Young Owner-on-the-Go's Task: Revive the Pirates
description: What gave Kevin McClatchy the first clue that his schedule was too busy? "I was going to take this girl out to dinner," the managing general partner of the Pittsburgh Pirates said yesterday. "I looked at my schedule and I couldn't get an open date for five weeks. I knew something was wrong."

description: Because of the Memorial Day holiday yesterday, the Treasury's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills was rescheduled for today. This week the Treasury will also be selling two- and five-year notes on Wednesday and Thursday, respectively.

description: At the close of the 1988 Republican National Convention, the Bush-Quayle ticket was trailing Dukakis-Bentsen by 17 points. So James Baker, Vice President George Bush's friend and fellow Texan, went home to assure the state's Republicans that victory was still in reach.

title: Salaries in Japan Down by 4.7 Percent
description: The average pay of Japanese professional baseball players declined for the first time, partly because club owners released some high-paid veterans to help cut costs, the Japanese Professional Baseball Players Association said today.

title: Strictures on Legal Immigrants Jeopardize Bill on Illegal Aliens
description: As House and Senate negotiators prepare to iron out the last details of a bill whose chief target is illegal immigration, a battle with the White House is looming over provisions that would drastically restrict public assistance to legal immigrants.

title: 2 Afghan Factions Agree to Share Power
description: Two Afghan factions that became allies when the Communist Government was ousted four years ago but later became enemies have signed a peace accord and are forming an interim administration.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Top Judge Is Hospitalized
description: Robert N. Wilentz, Chief Justice of New Jersey, spent the Memorial Day weekend at Mount Sinai Medical Center, where he was admitted last Wednesday for problems with his legs. It was not certain when the 69-year-old judge would be released from the hospital, his housekeeper, Araminta Mustafa, said yesterday.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Still Pondering the Myth Of Custer's Last Stand
description: CUSTER The Controversial Life of George Armstrong Custer By Jeffry D. Wert Illustrated. 462 pages. Simon & Schuster. $27.50.

title: Pro-Western Albanian Chief Claims Victory in Chaotic Election
description: In the most chaotic election in Eastern Europe since the fall of Communism, the Western-backed Albanian leader, Dr. Sali Berisha, claimed victory for his party of former Communists today despite concerns by international monitors about fraud and intimidation at the polls.

title: Critic of Arafat, Free Now, Says He'll Keep Speaking Out
description: A Palestinian human rights advocate who was jailed after he was quoted as criticizing Yasir Arafat's self-rule administration said today that he planned to continue speaking out.

title: Cruise's Thriller Breaking Records
description: Maybe it's that classic theme music. Maybe it's Tom Cruise. Maybe it's just that moviegoers over the Memorial Day weekend wanted to see an action film besides "Twister."

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;A Molester Beyond Reach
description: In 1981, a judge had labeled Jesse K. Timmendequas a "compulsive, repetitive sexual offender." In 1994, Mr. Timmendequas confessed to strangling and raping Megan Kanka, a 7-year-old who lived across the street, the police said. The crime has become part of the national psyche. Public records and interviews with people who knew Mr. Timmendequas and professionals who dealt with him draw a picture of a man who resisted therapy and whose impulses over many years could not be treated or controlled by the state. [Page A1.]

title: Stock Sale Set For Chadwick's
description: The TJX Companies has filed to sell 61 percent of Chadwick's of Boston Ltd., a women's clothing catalogue business, in an initial public offering that is expected to raise $130 million to $148 million. TJX, a discount retailer, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell 9.26 million shares of Chadwick's, which it said on Friday that it expected to have priced at $14 to $16 each.

title: Events in Burma Threaten to Fracture ASEAN Regional Forum
description: SINGAPORE  Less than two years after it was established as the only organization dealing with Asia-Pacific security problems, the ASEAN Regional Forum is in danger of being fractured and bypassed by events in Burma and other parts of Asia that it cannot handle, analysts say.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It looks as if the sons of Sophia Loren and Carlo Ponti are following in their parents' footsteps, heading for careers in show business.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Web Magazine at a Halt And Seeking Readers' Aid
description: The Web Review, one of the best- known of the magazines found only on the Internet, has stopped publishing and has issued an unusual appeal for financing that draws on two models of voluntary contributions.

title: China Frees Official Jailed After '89 Revolt
description: The only Communist Party official jailed in the 1989 Tiananmen Square uprising was released from prison today after serving seven years for opposing the Government's military assault on pro-democracy demonstrators and the imposition of martial law.

title: Sports of The Times;Photos, a Scam and the Police at Yankee Stadium
description: THEY would enjoy the best and endure the worst of what baseball in New York can be.

title: Johannesburg Exchange Shifts
description: South Africa's stock exchange announced today that it would close the old Johannesburg trading floor on June 7, and put the building up for sale.

title: Meeting of Burmese Dissidents Is Denounced by Government
description: The Burmese military rulers denounced the opposition today for going ahead with its most important meeting since the junta crushed elections in 1990.

title: Charles S. Dennison, 78, Adviser To Governments on Many Issues
description: Charles Stuart Dennison, an executive who advised governments from Washington to Senegal on economic development, the environment, science and technology and other policy issues, died last Wednesday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 78.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;For Steel-Wool Maker, Chinese Lessons
description: Peter N. Neustadter was drawn to China in the late 1980's, as were so many other American businessmen eager to participate in its booming economy and reap the benefit of cheap Chinese labor. He arranged for a company in the Guangzhou region of China, close to Hong Kong, to manufacture the shards of steel wool that have replaced asbestos fibers in automotive brake pads.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Awards, Awards And More Awards
description: The advertising awards season continues with three separate sets of honors.

title: Sam Shepard Is Happy To Be on Broadway, But It's Just a Visit
description: At a window table in the roped-off V.I.P. section of that quintessential Broadway hangout, the coffee shop in the Edison Hotel, Sam Shepard sat down and ordered a cup of coffee. All around the restaurant were telltale signs of the alien world he had invaded: Broadway producers and press agents gabbing over bagels and eggs; European tourists poring over listings for the splashy musicals they want to see.

title: Dole Echoes Holiday's Martial Tone as His Campaign Emphasizes HisCombat Service
description: His right arm limp from a war injury, Bob Dole today saluted with his left as he praised American veterans at a Memorial Day ceremony as "the best darn kids in the world."

title: Five Decades Later, a Fighter Pilot's Final Flight Ends
description: Flight Officer Frank D. Gallion was buried here near his home in Amish country today, Memorial Day, more than 52 years after his P-47 Thunderbolt fighter plane was downed by German machine gun fire and crashed into the waters of the Zuider Zee.

title: Constance Carden, 86; on Music Boards
description: Constance Sullivan Carden, who helped plan Alice Tully Hall and was on the boards of the New York Philharmonic Orchestra and the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, died on Thursday at her Manhattan home. She was 86.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Advertising Federation Attemps to Raise Its Profile
description: The American Advertising Federation is seeking to raise its profile with measures that emulate those taken by its marketer members when they want to woo consumers: a new slogan, a new logo and an advertising campaign.

title: Corrections

title: By Design;Into a Shell for the Summer
description: The shell -- a sleeveless cropped top -- is shaping up as a wardrobe staple for summer. It looks neat under a jacket and cool when it comes out from under wraps to pair with pants, and is available in a wide range of colors and fabrics.

title: Vatican View of Marriage
description: The Vatican issued a document today that urged priests to prepare couples better for a life together, contending that permissive laws and the news media had created a climate that favors the breakdown of marriages.

title: Bosnia Serbs Again Block Entry by Muslims
description: Bosnian Serbs stoned a busload of Muslim women trying to enter Serb-held land over the weekend to plant a tree of peace where some of the war's worst atrocities occurred, a NATO spokesman said today.

title: Critical Days for Northern Ireland
description: The next few weeks are critical to the prospects for peace in Northern Ireland. Elections there this week will produce delegates to attend all-party peace talks that are scheduled to commence on June 10. With the help of some good will on all sides, the days ahead could bring real progress toward ending this long and tortured conflict.

description: International A3-11

description: The Battle for Peace: Shimon Peres" is an infomercial for the Israeli Prime Minister, who faces a close election tomorrow. If he were running in this country, you would suspect tonight's hourlong biography at 8 on PBS was paid for by his party's national committee.

title: No Headline
description: As the years go by, the numbers are falling. But we've still got to carry on, no matter who shows up. We have to carry on even if we just get together and eat lunch."

description: As Israelis prepare to make one of the most important choices in their history, they are finding that a lot of the world is staring over their shoulder.

LeBow was again calling for the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation to immediatly spin off its food company from its tobacco operations.

title: TENNIS;For Seles and Sampras, Victories and Tears
description: For one player, it was a happy reunion with the Grand Slam tournament that had launched her career, the one where she'd been untouchable since 1990 but where she was unable to pursue a fourth consecutive championship in 1993 because of a stabbing that derailed her career.

title: Great Plains or Great Desert? The Sea of Dunes Lies in Wait
description: AS devastating as the present drought in the southern Great Plains has been, scientists who study ancient climates are finding that droughts, floods and severe cold far surpassing anything in the modern era have punctuated the 10,000 years since the last ice age.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: A Top Property Developer Is Arrested in Japan A leading Japanese real estate developer has been arrested in a growing investigation into the roots of Japan's debt crisis. The arrest of Kichinosuke Sasaki, president of Togensha, comes as big property debtors and the banks that lent them billions of yen face increasingly sharp public criticism.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;Color Scanners: Get the Aspirin
description: IN 1981, scanners were people in David Cronenberg's horror film of the same name who could blow up other people's heads. In 1996, scanners are electronic devices that can produce headaches almost as horrible as those. Installing the Hewlett-Packard Scanjet 4p and the Epson Actionscanner II and their peculiar interface cards and software are almost enough to make your cranium burst from sheer frustration.

title: A New Coach For MetroStars
description: The MetroStars, as expected, officially named Carlos Queiroz of Portugal as their head coach yesterday and will introduce him at a news conference at Giants Stadium this afternoon. The MetroStars' first game under Queiroz will be Thursday night against the visiting D. C. United.

title: A Debate Spells Likely Defeat for India's Hindu Nationalists
description: Unable to shake off a reputation as a narrow, rabble-rousing movement with a vision for India that threatens Muslims and other minority groups, the Hindu nationalists who took power less than two weeks ago acknowledged today that they face inevitable defeat in a parliamentary confidence vote on Tuesday.

description: Rick Pitino may become part owner of the Nets, but the coach of the Seattle SuperSonics has done him one better.

description: Few Republican freshmen in the House had a path to Washington so smoothly cleared for them as Jon D. Fox.

title: Kearny Link Is Finished, Reducing Trip by Rail
description: On Jan. 1, 1838, the Morris and Essex Rail Road began passenger service between Newark and Morristown. More than 158 years later, on June 10, passengers on that line will finally be able to ride into Manhattan without changing trains.

title: ON PRO BASKETBALL;Jordan Puts Bulls on His Shoulders
description: It took about five minutes for Michael Jordan to sense that the Chicago Bulls were in trouble. So Jordan did what he usually does. He responded to the challenge. And his teammates followed him all the way to the finals.

description: For half a century, one of the great taboos of public life here has been any discussion of a Japanese military role beyond Japan's shores.

title: Sports of The Times;Too Much Too Soon; So Long?
description: FROM the time you deplane in Orlando, you're enveloped in a child's wonderland. They've fashioned an industry here built on dreams: Disney World, Universal Studios and all the water worlds.

description: A research team plans to exhume seven bodies from permafrost in hope of finding what caused a global epidemic that killed 20 million people in 1918 and 1919.

title: PERIPHERALS;Some Short Cuts to the Big Picture
description: MANY people prepare presentations on a computer, perhaps to propose a new business strategy or introduce a product, but lack the time or inclination to master one of the full-featured programs offered for that purpose. I just prepared a handsome little presentation in not much more than 15 minutes without even opening the tiny manual or "Evaluator's Guide" booklet that came with ASAP Wordpower version 1.95. And a few of the 15 minutes were spent installing the program.

title: Vitamin E May Slow Age Damage in Rats
description: COULD vitamin E really help resist the ravages of age? Recent evidence has suggested the chemical can protect the tissues against the oxidative damage that results in such hallmarks of age as clogged arteries, cancer, wrinkles and liver spots. Now a new study in mice suggests that supplements of vitamin E may also slow the decline of the brain and immune system.

title: Machine Tool Orders Fall 9.6% As Foreign Demand Weakens
description: Orders for American-built industrial tools fell 9.6 percent in April from the month before as foreign demand dipped, a trade group said today.

title: Eyes of the World On Israel's Election
description: As Israelis prepare to go to the polls on Wednesday for one of the most important elections in their history, they are finding that a lot of the world is staring over their shoulder.

description: What's a gay person to do here in Colorado Springs, painted as a hotbed of homophobia after it gave birth to a ballot initiative curbing homosexual rights?

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Birdwatchers In; Birds Out
description: Thousands of people have built new homes in the Cape May area in recent years, drawn in large part by natural attractions that include some of the best bird-watching on the East Coast. Now state wildlife officials say development has destroyed so much natural habitat that the birds are disappearing.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Senators to See Boot Camp
description: Members of two State Senate committees who are weighing a plan to expand a six-month-old boot camp for young offenders will tour the detention center today. Senator Robert E. Littell, Republican of Franklin Township and chairman of the Senate Budget and Appropriations Committee, said the boot camp, now home to 60 residents between 14 and 17, may be expanded to accommodate offenders from 18 to 26.

title: AUTO RACING;IndyCar And CART Will Keep Battling

title: HORSE RACING;'Song' Ailing As Lukas Colt Wins Met Mile In Record Time
description: Unbridled's Song was back in his barn at Belmont Park yesterday nursing a lung infection, the latest in a never-ending series of miseries that have disrupted his career and damaged his standing as America's leading 3-year-old colt.

title: Japan Is Open to Semiconductor Trade Talks With U.S.
description: A senior Japanese Government official left the door open today for negotiations with the United States about semiconductor trade before the upcoming expiration of the two nations' existing computer chip trade agreement.

title: Corrections

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Hal Riney Names 2 to Top Posts
description: Hal Riney & Partners in San Francisco has appointed two executives to top creative positions in a restructuring.

title: Somber Memories of Death, and an Afternoon of Renewal
description: It was chilly and wet yesterday morning, on the day the summer season was supposed to begin, and Harold Mattes, 73, was explaining why he was marching, with some stiffness, in a Memorial Day parade. He spoke of the "strafing, machine guns, bombing" that had gone along with his job as an Army signalman in Europe and North Africa, but said things had been much worse for the infantry. Many died and that was why he marched.

title: A Memorial Day Picnic With Its Own Press Corps
description: It was a typical Memorial Day picnic: hamburgers and hot dogs on the grill, chips in the bowl, a huge homemade cake with white icing, and a half dozen television cameras perched on the backyard fence, recording the guests' every mouthful.

title: Sport Supply Plans To Drop Golf Unit
description: Sport Supply Group Inc., the maker of Voit and MacGregor sports equipment, plans to sell or spin off part or all of its golf operations.

title: Girl Drowns in Hot Tub
description: As a 16-year-old New Jersey girl sat with friends in a hot tub early Saturday, savoring memories of her prom night hours earlier, she dipped her head below water to wet her hair. Just then, someone threw the switch to bubble the water, and a moment later the girl was pinned on the suction grate at the bottom. The next several minutes were a nightmare as a police officer, a lifeguard and the girl's classmates struggled to pull her free. The girl, Tanya Nickens of Lakewood, died on Sunday.

title: Evidence Mounting for Role of Fetal Damage in Schizophrenia
description: A DRAMATIC change is afoot in the scientific understanding of schizophrenia, a devastating mental illness with 2.5 million victims in the United States alone. The first symptoms usually appear when people are in their late 20's, but neuroscientists now believe that the seeds of the disorder are often sown during fetal development.

title: Wisconsin Shuffle
description: In the debate over Gov. Tommy G. Thompson's welfare reform plan, one thing is clear: There is a distressing gap between what Governor Thompson practices at home in Wisconsin and what he advocates for the nation.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Glamour And Power: The Edge
description: In Massachusetts, Kennedys run for office as favorite sons; in neighboring Rhode Island, they're favorite cousins. Their name is so magical that Patrick J. Kennedy, Senator Edward M. Kennedy's youngest child, was elected to the Rhode Island legislature when he was still a 20-year-old junior at Providence College. Observers who yelled carpetbagger just didn't get it. Rhode Island voters welcomed him as if he were a rich, distant relative who had finally invited himself to dinner.

title: Threat to Turkish Coalition
description: With the Turkish governing coalition in trouble, an Islamic party moved today to hold a no-confidence vote in Parliament.

title: Changing Trains
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Arnold to Create Playskool Ads
description: Arnold Communications in Boston has been awarded a large account and has made an acquisition.

title: Don't Jeopardize Food Safety
description: With "mad cow" disease barely faded in the headlines, it seems an odd time for Congress to consider weakening America's food safety laws. Yet that is the threat of a package of proposals intended to "reform" the Food and Drug Administration.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Mexico Awards TV Concession
description: A unit of Grupo Televisa S.A. said today that it had won a Government concession to provide direct-to-home television.

title: Rebuilt Rocket Tests Space Technologies
description: THE Delta Clipper, the experimental rocket that takes off and lands on its tail, is flying again to test new technology that may be applied to the next generation of satellite launchers.

title: Health Costs Are Growing More Slowly, Report Says
description: Health care spending grew more slowly in 1994 than in any year since 1960, the Government reported today.

title: Physicists Put Atom In 2 Places At Once
description: MANY a suspect has escaped the noose by arguing that he could not have been in two places at the same time. But no such grounds for an alibi exist for the tiny inhabitants of the realm of quantum mechanics: a team of physicists has proved that an entire atom can simultaneously exist in two widely separated places.

title: CHECHENS' LEADER SIGNS PEACE PACT WITH THE KREMLIN
description: After 18 months of a war that has left Chechnya in ruins and imperiled the presidency of Boris N. Yeltsin, leaders of both sides signed a treaty at the Kremlin today intended to end the fighting in the secessionist region in southern Russia on June 1.

title: Lights! Camera! Action! But Not Here!
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY BALLET REVIEW;Mozartean Elegance and Gritty Street Life
description: The New York City Ballet displayed its versatility by presenting George Balanchine's "Mozartiana" and Jerome Robbins's "West Side Story Suite" on Friday night at the New York State Theater.

title: For Bronx Teacher, A Winning Tactic;Even in a Crowded Classroom, Each Student Has a Major Role
description: Jocelyn R. Rodriguez can see it already. In the school she dreams of opening in the Bronx someday, a lifetime supply of loose-leaf paper and No. 2 pencils overflow from the cabinets. Tall piles of up-to-date textbooks teeter precariously on the shelves.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Could Gertrude Stein, an icon of liberation for many women, really have believed that motherhood is the highest goal to which a woman can aspire?

title: Satellite Orients Itself, Shuttle Astronauts Find
description: Astronauts aboard the space shuttle Endeavour crept up on a small self-orienting satellite for a final check today, taking precise laser measurements before abandoning the craft to burn up in Earth's atmosphere.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Water Trap for a Stolen Car
description: A 27-year-old Hillside man was arrested yesterday after he tried to escape from the police in a car that had been reported carjacked Sunday, the police said. The man, Christopher Garrison, was taken into custody after he drove the front end of a 1990 Toyota Corolla into the lake at Branch Brook Park, said Detective Daniel Collins of the Newark police. Two Newark women said a man matching Mr. Garrison's description had pulled one of them from the car, punched her and sped off after the other woman got out, Detective Collins said. He said the women would be asked if they could identify Mr. Garrison.

title: BASEBALL;Angels Trade Smith to Reds
description: The major league career saves leader, Lee Smith, is bound for Cincinnati's bullpen, but not as the Reds' closer. Smith, who has 471 saves, was traded today to the Reds -- his seventh team -- by the California Angels for the left-hander Chuck McElroy.

title: BASEBALL;Everybody Is a Hitter As Yanks Rout Angels
description: Joe Torre was reluctant to reveal his lineup early tonight because of a slightly controversial choice to start Ruben Rivera over Gerald Williams in left field. What did Torre have to hide? Every lineup the manager devises should be as powerful as the one the Yankees used against Jim Abbott and the feeble Angels.

title: Easy Mark? Think Again, Mr. Bad Guy
description: The victim was easy enough to pick from a throng of tourists coursing through busy Times Square yesterday evening for two pickpockets on the make. And removing $300 from his pocket was simple, but getting away was another story.

title: On My Mind;To the Clintons and the Doles
description: Some day, through my will and heart, I will help end the suffering of millions of people. That will make the world a better place for everybody. How lovely that will be.

title: BASEBALL: METS NOTEBOOK;No Offense Intended, Franco Says of Gesture
description: When Joe McIlvaine and Dave Howard arrived at a party on Staten Island on Sunday night, they got an earful from John Franco. Franco, the Mets' reliever, could not wait to tell the two Mets executives that the gesture he made after a shaky ninth inning against San Diego that afternoon came of frustration and was not meant as a derogatory response to fans.

title: Candidates Respond Rapidly, Picking 'Gotcha' Over Debate
description: More than five months before the election, the Presidential campaign is already racing through issues at dizzying speed, in part because of the churning of proposals and counter-proposals, charges and counter-charges generated by the campaigns' "rapid response" strategies.

title: Giuliani Disputes Rikers Guards' Criticism
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday defended his decision not to go to Rikers Island or visit correction officers who were injured on Sunday after about a dozen inmates ignited blankets and threw them into a corridor, spreading smoke throughout the maximum-security ward.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;I.B.M. Taps Spinal Tap Actors to Sing Its Olympic Praises
description: The members of the world's most inept rock-and-roll band, who always insisted that no one would ever want them for a commercial, have of course been proved wrong. And in case they have not caused enough hearing damage through traditional media, they are pushing their way into cyberspace.

title: Markets to Reopen
description: Financial and commodities markets in the United States will reopen today after being closed yesterday in observance of Memorial Day. Most European markets were also closed yesterday for holidays, as were some in Asia. Markets in Japan and Hong Kong did trade. [Page D6.]

title: NYC;Full Measure Of Devotion, In Memoriam
description: Israel was my last port of call, a place that takes its Memorial Day seriously. At 11 A.M. on that day, the country stops. Have you ever seen an entire country stop in its tracks? It is a sight to behold, a remarkable display of solidarity.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Thursday about new evidence in the case of Mumia Abu-Jamal, who is on death row for the 1981 shooting of a Philadelphia police officer, misstated the request made by Mr. Abu-Jamal's lawyers to the Pennsylvania Supreme Court. They want the case sent back to the trial court for more testimony from a defense witness; they did not ask for a new trial.

title: Stop Letting Turks Call It 'So-Called Massacre';Defining the Ties
description: To the Editor:

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Portrait of a Rebel, on Screen and Off
description: In "Marlon Brando: The Wild One," an hourlong documentary on American Movie Classics tonight at 8, the most measured comment on the Brando phenomenon comes from, of all people, Shelley Winters. Taking a bead on his entire career, she sums it up as "a few moments worth all the millions."

title: Reynolds to Expand Test of Low-Smoke Cigarette
description: R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company plans to expand a market test of Eclipse, its nearly smokeless cigarette, by actively promoting and selling it in Chattanooga, Tenn., the company said today.

title: Wage Study Was Based on Faulty Research
description: To the Editor:

title: STRANGER ON THE BLOCK -- A special report.;At Center of 'Megan's Law' Case, a Man No One Could Reach
description: Her name was Megan. Most people do not know his name.

title: Pipe Replaced in Most Recent Water Main Break
description: A day after a 92-year-old water main ruptured on Manhattan's Upper West Side, workers have replaced the pipe, but city officials predict that the work that has closed two blocks of Broadway will take about a week to finish.

title: Dorothy Hyson, 81, Actress in Britain
description: Dorothy Hyson, a Chicago-born stage and screen actress of the 1930's and 40's who was famed for her beauty, died on Thursday in a London hospital. She was 81 and had moved to London with her parents as a child.

title: At Yale's Commencement, Protest Stays Beyond Wall
description: On one side of the wall, the music was classical, the attire a sea of blue blazers, floral dresses and caps and gowns and the mood festive yet restrained as Yale University's president, Richard C. Levin, uttered words in Latin to a crowd of 13,000 at the school's 295th commencement.

title: N.H.L PLAYOFFS;Red Wings Get a Lift Out of Lemieux's Comeuppance
description: Sometimes a single moment seems to symbolize an entire game. This doesn't happen every night, but it certainly did tonight at raucous Joe Louis Arena when the Red Wings defeated the Colorado Avalanche by 5-2. It remains to be seen whether it will eventually come to symbolize this entire series.

title: South Africans' Everest Climb Ends in Death and Mystery
description: South Africans have been glued to radios for three days listening to a distant drama of national triumph crumble into an inexplicable tragedy. At dawn on Saturday, they heard that the South African flag had been planted atop Mount Everest for the first time -- a successful end to a much-publicized trek. But the last member of the shattered team, which straggled one by one to the top, has now been missing for 48 hours after trying to descend in the dark and is presumed dead.

title: CITY BALLET REVIEW;Festive Occasions Followed by a Storm
description: The New York City Ballet presented strongly danced programs on Saturday afternoon and evening at the New York State Theater. The matinee paired Jerome Robbins's "Goldberg Variations" with George Balanchine's "Symphony in Three Movements."

title: Konstanz Journal;Old Catholic Church Offers New Catholic Ways
description: For many centuries, history has been punctuated here with turbulent questions of faith that seem to contrast with the placid waters of Lake Constance nuzzling the inns and churches of this medieval town. Today was no exception.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;BJ Services Extends Its Bid for Nowsco
description: The BJ Services Company said today that it had extended a takeover bid of $27 (Canadian) a share for Nowsco Well Service Ltd. through June 7.

title: Enron Joint Venture
description: The Enron Corporation said today that it had concluded negotiations on a joint venture to build a $300 million regasification plant in the Jordanian Red Sea port of Aqaba. Rebecca Mark, chairwoman of the Enron Development Corporation, said that negotiations with its Israeli and Jordanian partners had ended and that she expected the parties would sign an agreement in the next couple of weeks. The plant would supply Jordan and Israel with liquefied natural gas from Qatar, on the Persian Gulf, beginning in 2001.

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: Major League Soccer

title: DANCE REVIEW;The Waiting For Action Is the Action
description: When dancers were first seen onstage on Thursday night at La Mama E.T.C., they appeared to be waiting. They waited dramatically. Then it was the audience's turn to wait for something equally interesting to happen. Nothing did.

title: INSIDE
description: Pataki Faults Budget Deal

title: Market Place;A New Way to Measure an Exhausted Bull
description: Is the Q ratio signaling that the end is near for this great bull market?

title: Wage Study Was Based on Faulty Research
description: To the Editor:

title: Episcopal Bishop Hails Victory on Gay Priests
