description: At a time when public interest in issues of religion and sexuality runs high, the opinions of Bishop John S. Spong are heard far beyond the boundaries of his spiritual jurisdiction, the Episcopal Church's Diocese of Newark.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Bristol-Myers Unit Assigns Brands
description: Mead Johnson & Company in Evansville, Ind., a subsidiary of the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, has assigned brands to the two agencies that it selected in late March to handle its account, with billings estimated at $30 million.

title: Man Is Charged With Kidnapping 4 Boys
description: A Georgia man has been charged with kidnapping four boys and sexually assaulting three of them in a motel in Southington, Conn.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about a sweetened bid by Utilicorp United Inc. for the Kansas City Power and Light Company referred incorrectly to a requirement that two-thirds of Kansas City Power's shareholders approve any merger. It is imposed by Missouri law, not by the company's bylaws.

title: Hot Tub's Fatal Suction Claims a Teen-Ager Celebrating With FriendsAfter Her Prom
description: As a 16-year-old New Jersey girl sat with friends in a hot tub early Saturday, savoring memories of her prom night hours earlier, she dipped her head below water to wet her hair. Just then, someone threw the switch to bubble the water, and a moment later the girl was pinned on the suction grate at the bottom.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Canadian Press Empire to Face Scrutiny
description: Canadian regulatory officials said today that they would take a hard look at Conrad Black's aggressive moves to expand his newspaper empire in Canada.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Prosecutor's Trial Nears End
description: After three weeks of testimony, closing arguments were scheduled to begin today in the trial of the former Somerset County Prosecutor, Nicholas L. Bissell Jr., and his wife, Barbara, who are accused of defrauding their partner in a gasoline station in Bedminster by skimming off more than $140,000 in receipts. During the trial, an Amoco executive testified that Mr. Bissell threatened to plant cocaine in the fuel company president's car when it appeared as if the Prosecutor might lose his franchise, and Mr. Bissell's accountant testified that the couple asked him to file fraudulent tax returns. Mr. Bissell took the stand and denied all charges. Stuart Rabner, the assistant United States attorney who is prosecuting the case, said he expected the jury to get the case tomorrow.

title: Equity Offerings Scheduled for This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Chess
description: There are puritanical souls who take offense at versions of chess played at a rapid rate or without sight of the board or anything other than standard tournament regimen. For them, anything else is mere spectacle, a neglect of the profound possibilities of the game. Fortunately, there are others who don't take everything so seriously.

title: Observer;The Best of Times
description: One more sneer at the 1950's and I'm going to kick the TV set right in the kidneys. The 1950's was no worse than any other 20th-century decade and far better than most, and TV should abandon its smug assumption that because the cars looked silly and hair was worn short it was a contemptible time.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Big Japan Developer Seized For Blocking Land Auction
description: The police arrested a leading Japanese property developer today, once one of the world's richest men, in a growing investigation into the roots of Japan's debt crisis.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Easy Humor in a Massage With Tango
description: One might have expected the Joyce Theater to be less than packed over a holiday weekend. But the audience was large and vociferous at a performance by the Parsons Dance Company there on Sunday night, and the evening offered several clues to the enduring popularity of David Parsons's choreography and his company, which this former Paul Taylor dancer founded in 1987.

title: A Catholic Politician, and Northern Ireland, at a Crossroads
description: Twenty-four years ago, John Hume was a French teacher and fledgling politician leading a march to protest discrimination against this city's majority Catholics by the Protestants who still controlled local government. When he tried to negotiate a nonviolent standoff between angry demonstrators and British paratroopers, the soldiers hosed him down with purple dye and arrested him.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about a television debate in the Israeli election campaign referred incorrectly to the citizenship of Benjamin Netanyahu, the Likud candidate. He renounced his American citizenship in the early 1980's.

title: G.M. to Tap Asian Market, And 2 Nations Bid for Plant
description: In Thailand, where the country's bargaining position is strong, the official attitude is studied nonchalance. In the Philippines, where officials are desperate to get into the game, almost anything goes.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Pop CD's;The Black Influence In Drums
description: As many social observers have commented, American culture is profoundly influenced by its black citizens. An obvious example is the role of the drum in much of the popular music made in this country. Here are examples of both home-grown uses of the drum and of the traditions that make the collective American walk and talk what it is.

title: Ukraine's President Ousts Prime Minister
description: The President of Ukraine, Leonid Kuchma, unexpectedly announced the removal today of his Prime Minister, an influential former security chief.

title: Possible Drug for Crohn's
description: Doctors say they have induced remission of the severe chronic bowel inflammation called Crohn's disease with doses of part-mouse, part-human antibodies. In a study involving 108 patients, participants received single intravenous doses of a monoclonal antibody called cA2, which blocks tumor necrosis factor, a blood protein that plays a role in the inflammation.

title: Mutiny Ends in Central African Republic
description: French troops drove mutinous soldiers back to their barracks today in Bangui, the Central African Republic's capital.

title: Nintendo Capitalism: Zapping The Markets;Fast Electronic Trading Brings Increased Volatility
description: It's 7:29 A.M. high above South LaSalle Street and Patrick Beimford, the chief bond strategist of Zurich Kemper Investments, is poised like an orchestra conductor in front of three electronic screens. He and more than a dozen highly paid young traders and portfolio managers scan intently.

title: Deal Lets Infected Horses Enter Country for Olympics
description: Yielding to international pressure, Georgia and Federal agriculture officials have decided to permit some horses to compete in the Summer Olympics even though they carry a tick-borne disease and would ordinarily be barred from the United States. But other states' officials, horsemen and scientists are still debating the risks to the American horse population.

title: Making It in New York City
description: Few postwar trends have devastated New York City more than the collapse of manufacturing, which has hollowed out neighborhoods and eliminated at least 700,000 jobs. In recent years, however, a contrary trend has occurred. Smaller manufacturers, often operated by immigrants, are sprouting everywhere. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani is right to try to encourage the trend by promising to cut costs for these new businesses. At the same time, his administration calls for giving big "super stores" access to some areas now set aside exclusively for manufacturing. That approach could also stimulate the economy and widen the choices for consumers.

title: 2 Holiday Messages
description: On a Memorial Day trip to New Jersey, Senator Bob Dole attended a picnic and praised American veterans as "the best darn kids in the world." Mr. Dole's campaign hopes to make his war service a key theme against President Clinton, who yesterday laid a wreath in Arlington National Cemetery and asked Americans to set aside their differences.

title: Ride Is Open After Injury To 2 Riders
description: Less than 48 hours after two people were injured in an accident on Saturday night on the Jumbo Jet roller coaster, the Coney Island ride was open again for business yesterday, apparently without the permission of city officials, who immediately moved to shut it down again.

title: Patterns
description: Gala Date May Change

title: Gazans See Little Hope For Future In Israel Vote
description: Their future may depend on it, but Palestinians bottled up in this impoverished strip of sand and slums have only limited expectations from Israel's approaching election.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;An Officer's Funeral
description: Joined by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, thousands of state police and other officers from around the country filled St. Denis Roman Catholic Church yesterday and spilled out into the street for the funeral of Trooper Francis J. Belleran, 32. He died on Thursday, three days after he lost control of his cruiser while pursuing a motorcycle with stolen license plates on the Garden State Parkway. Louis D. Goodman, 19, of Asbury Park, has been charged with manslaughter in his death.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TELEVISION;New Station Chooses President
description: CAROLYN WALL has been named president of WBIS+, the business and sports channel owned by ITT, co-owner of Madison Square Garden, and Dow Jones & Company, that will be in operation by the end of the year. The station, formerly WNYC-TV/Channel 31, will carry financial programs, entertainment, plus some Knick and Ranger games that would be on the MSG Network, and some Yankee games that are now broadcast by WPIX-TV.

title: U.S. Warning 3 Foreign Companies Over Investments in Cuba
description: The Clinton Administration will send letters Wednesday advising private companies in Mexico, Canada and Italy that they may be subject to punitive action because of investments in Cuba, American officials said today.

title: PLAIN AND SIMPLE;Delicate Balance for Mouthwateringly Sweet Soft-Shell Crabs
description: This is the peak of the soft-shell crab season. They're mouthwateringly sweet, and prices have finally come down, at least a little.

title: La Pyramide's Founder
description: To The Living Section:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;What's After 'Born to Run'?
description: Since 1939, the Legislature has grappled periodically with the vexing problem of how to choose a state song. Finally, the State Council on the Arts will disclose three finalists -- culled from 240 entries -- today. It will then be up to the Legislature to choose a winner.

title: Real Estate;A developer has begun its first office building in the U.S. since the late 1980's, in Washington.
description: THE Hines Interests, an office developer based in Houston, has started excavations for an office building in the east end of Washington. Hines says it is the first office development it has begun in the United States since the office market collapsed in the late 1980's.

title: Gun-Running in the Balkans: C.I.A. and Diplomats Collide
description: Two summers ago, the C.I.A. station chief in Croatia thought he had uncovered a terrible secret: the United States Ambassador was involved in a rogue operation to smuggle Iranian weapons to Bosnia's Muslims, defying a worldwide arms embargo.

title: Personal Health
description: IT is almost as if many people cannot live without an in-your-face vice that flouts admonitions to lead a healthier life. The latest to achieve celebrity status is cigar smoking. In clubs and restaurants, at special parties and on city streets, the air is being filled with acrid cigar smoke by people with money to burn, from stars like Demi Moore, Whoopi Goldberg, Jack Nicholson and David Letterman to corporate high-achievers.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Cowens Is Fired Up to Coach
description: Enthusiasm and energy are what DAVE COWENS will be looking for when he takes over as the Charlotte Hornets' coach.

title: A Weed by Another Name: Salad
description: THERE'S an old saying that a weed is a green growing where you don't want it. Although this is a bit of an exaggeration, there is no doubt that one culture's tasty salad ingredient is another's noxious pest.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Television Notes column last Wednesday about a new weekend evening program, "About Books," misidentified the cable channel on which it appears from 9 P.M. to midnight on Saturdays and 9 P.M.to 11 on Sundays. The channel is C-Span 2, not C-Span.

title: Investors Look To Education As Possibility For High Flier
description: The 300 dark-suited investment industry executives sat crowded into heavily draped meeting rooms at the Plaza Hotel in New York, watching slide show after slide show about companies they had never heard of in an industry they know little about -- the business of educating children.

title: NEW JERSEY DEAL TO TIE BIG INSURER WITH BLUE CROSS
description: New Jersey Blue Cross and Blue Shield, the largest health insurer in New Jersey, with 1.9 million enrollees, has agreed to join forces with a big Midwestern company that is one of the nation's largest health insurers, people with knowledge of the deal said last night.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;An Interactive Unit Formed by Lowe
description: Lowe & Partners/SMS in New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, has formed an interactive unit, Lowe & Partners/SMS Interactive, which will work in media like CD-ROM's, interactive kiosks and the Internet for clients including the Mercedes-Benz of North America subsidiary of Daimler-Benz A.G. Shannon Mullen, 26, an associate strategic planner at Lowe, will head the interactive operation as vice president and unit director.

title: 21 U.S. Sailors Seized in Italy In Drug Inquiry
description: Navy investigators have arrested 21 American sailors based in Naples, Italy, on charges that they were involved in smuggling cocaine and heroin into Italy.

title: Shuttle Plans Return After Satellite Work
description: The Endeavour's six-man crew packed up today to return from 10 days of satellite work that required more precision flying than any other shuttle mission. The shuttle is scheduled to land at 7:09 A.M. Eastern time on Wednesday at Cape Canaveral, Fla., but rain could force a detour to Edwards Air Force Base, Calif.

title: No Headline
description: There's no danger. We hear the thunder from the volcano, but nothing else ever happens."

title: Bronx Man Indicted On a Lesser Charge In Officer's Death
description: A Bronx man implicated in the death of a police officer last week has been indicted on the lesser of two homicide charges filed against him, causing Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to complain, once again, that the Bronx District Attorney was not aggressively pressing the case.

title: A Boxing Tip
description: To The Living Section:

title: CLINTON PARTNERS IN ARKANSAS DEAL CONVICTED BY JURY
description: In the first trial of the Whitewater investigation, a jury today convicted President Clinton's former business partners of fraud and other crimes for a chain of bad loans issued by an Arkansas savings and loan association in the 1980's.

title: COMPANY NEWS;GENZYME TO BUY MAKER OF SURGICAL PRODUCTS
description: The Genzyme Corporation, a major biotechnology company, said yesterday that it had a definitive agreement to acquire Deknatel Snowden Pencer Inc., a surgical products company, for about $250 million in cash. The privately held Deknatel, which is based in Fall River, Mass., makes cardiovascular devices, surgical instruments and specialty surgical products. It had sales of $95.3 million in the year that ended on Sept. 30, 1995. Deknatel has 585 employees and manufacturing plants in Fall River; Tucker, Ga., and Coventry, Conn. Genzyme said it would retain Deknatel's plants and continue to pursue its growth strategy. Shares of Genzyme, based in Cambridge, Mass., fell $2.75, to $58.50.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY;Whalers Let Sator Go
description: The Hartford Whalers will not renew the contract of the assistant coach TED SATOR, the team announced yesterday. Sator, a former head coach of the Rangers and the Buffalo Sabres, signed a one-year contract last August after resigning as an assistant in St. Louis. Whalers General Manager JIM RUTHERFORD said the decision was mutual, allowing Sator to pursue other interests. Sator could not be reached for comment.

title: Florida A&M Official Is Named To Head York College in Queens
description: The City University's trustees yesterday named Charles C. Kidd Sr., an associate vice president of Florida A&M University, to the presidency of York College in Jamaica, Queens, effective Aug. 19.

title: Communists In Russia Unveil Plan For Economy
description: The Communist leader, Gennadi A. Zyuganov, released the outline of his economic program today, a plan to revive the economy by having Russia spend its way out of industrial and agricultural decline and seal itself off from foreign competition.

title: Agent Orange Payment
description: President Clinton expanded disability benefits to cover Vietnam veterans who suffer from prostate cancer or a nerve disease that may be associated with Agent Orange. He also said he would propose new benefits for children of Vietnam veterans who suffer from spina bifida.

title: In Quest of the Morel, A Very Special Fungus
description: Each year around this time, Bill Williams and his wife, Helen, become obsessed: They head north to a secret wooded enclave and sniff out an abandoned, overgrown apple orchard. Then, with eyes cast downward, they tramp through the decaying bramble, swiping at vines, bracing for ticks and steering clear of thorns and poison ivy, seeking the elusive morel.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Crime Report Shows Rise
description: After dropping in 1994, crime increased slightly in New Jersey during 1995, Governor Whitman said yesterday, citing preliminary figures from the state police's Uniform Crime Report. Juvenile crime is on the rise, the Governor said, but she would not elaborate. The crime report will be released late next month.

title: Ex-Prosecutor Is Portrayed in Federal Corruption Trial as Greedy
description: Final arguments started today in the month-old Federal corruption trial of Nicholas L. Bissell, a former Somerset County Prosecutor, with the Government portraying him as a thief who routinely stole from his partner in a gasoline station to maintain a grand life style with his wife, Barbara.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Rhone-Poulenc Weighs Drug Unit Spinoffs
description: Rhone-Poulenc S.A., France's biggest chemical company, is studying plans to spin off its drug units if efforts to improve shareholder value do not pay off soon, a company official said yesterday. The executive, Igor Landau, Rhone-Poulenc's managing director, also said $400 million to $500 million in asset sales would be announced.

title: A Nasty Surprise for Deutsche Bank
description: FRANKFURT  Deutsche Bank AG, Germany's largest bank, found itself at the center of yet another financial scandal on Tuesday when a subsidiary disclosed that it faced collapse after uncovering hundreds of millions of dollars' worth of losses hidden by managers over several years.

title: Beijing Vows To Punish Unauthorized Arms Exports
description: China said today that it would punish any company or individual who it finds has sold weapons or military equipment to the United States without Government review or approval.

title: Can Patients Survive H.M.O. Bureaucracy?
description: To the Editor:

title: Check Those Facts On Need for Abortion;A Case Study
description: To the Editor:

title: Tough Justice for Juveniles
description: Should we combat the problem of youth violence by sending more children to adult prison? The answer is simple: We're asking the wrong question.

title: Question Mark In Israel Ballot: 'The Russians'
description: The other day, Natan Sharansky, the former Soviet dissident, sat in a small classroom at Hebrew University in Jerusalem and listened to a dozen Russian physicists, chemists and engineers vent their dissatisfaction with their new lives as immigrants.

title: Paso de Cortes Journal;Life With a Fuming El Popo: Will It Blow Its Top?
description: The sky overhead was dimmed by a cloud of gray ash belched from the mouth of a mighty volcano. But the dark plume was of no concern to Teresa Rosas Hernandez. As she has most days for the last 15 years, she climbed the volcano's flank to a wooden lean-to about 15,000 feet up where she makes fresh cheese tacos for the tourists who come to the Popocatepetl volcano.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Ukraine Chief Picks His Fifth Prime Minister
description: President Leonid Kuchma of Ukraine selected a close political ally as Prime Minister today, while the man that Mr. Kuchma removed from the post protested his dismissal.

title: Teach the Schools the ABC's of Sharing
description: To the Editor:

title: Investors Shift To More Risky Mutual Funds
description: Cash continues to pour into mutual funds that invest in stocks. But American investors are steering growing amounts of that new money to the riskiest type of funds, the category known as aggressive growth, perhaps indicating that speculative fever among mutual fund investors is rising again.

title: Origin of Popular Lobster Fra Diavolo Bedevils the Experts
description: LOBSTER FRA DIAVOLO, lobster in a spicy tomato sauce with linguine, "brother devil" style, sounds Italian, tastes Italian and is a staple in Italian restaurants. But is it Italian?

title: Business Travel;More hotels are beginning to charge penalties for guests who check out earlier than planned.
description: PENALTIES charged to hotel guests who check out early continue to proliferate, with Hilton Hotels joining the ranks of Westin and Hyatt. The Inter-Continental, Loews and Renaissance chains are testing the concept.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Liberia Peacekeepers Fan Out in Capital
description: Fighters loyal to faction leaders have withdrawn from the center of Monrovia, the Liberian capital, and peacekeeping forces began fanning out today to more outlying districts.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;New Jersey Is for Fighters
description: Governor Whitman let it be known yesterday that she would not tolerate job-poaching governors. In February, Gov. George F. Allen of Virginia urged New Jersey companies to move to his state, saying they would be able to cut their corporate income taxes by one-third and their health care costs as much as 44 percent. New Jersey has been fighting back with advertisements urging Virginian companies to move to New Jersey for its tax breaks, skilled work force and "progressive environment."

title: An Abundance, Free for the Picking
description: IN the 1940's, when I was growing up, Glenn Miller's hit song "Moonlight Cocktail," a musical recipe that directed you to take a "coupl'a jiggers of moonlight and add a star," told me that life offered more enchanting food and drink than my daily lunchtime cheeseburger, fries and chocolate shake. Four decades later, at 50, when I began a solitary life on an island off the coast of Maine in a seaside cabin without electricity, plumbing, phone or road, I discovered a cuisine as enchanting, and delectable, as moonlight.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Britain to Privatize Nuclear Power Company
description: The British Government said yesterday that it planned to sell stock in the state-owned nuclear electricity generator, British Energy P.L.C. in July. Barclays de Zoete Wedd, the investment bank that is acting for the British Government, said details about the price of the offer, which is expected to raise L2.4 billion ($3.62 billion) to L2.8 billion ($4.23 billion), would be published at the end of June, with shares expected to start trading in mid-July. This is the last major British privatization.

title: Clinton Drops Military Issue In Request For Suit Delay
description: In the face of Republican attacks, lawyers for President Clinton filed new papers with the Supreme Court today saying his effort to delay trial of a sexual harassment suit against him until he leaves office did not rely on his status as Commander in Chief.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Charged as Terror Master, Surrounded by Mysteries
description: He has been portrayed as a spinner of deceits, a manipulator of childhood friendships and ideological hatreds, and a master terrorist who jetted about with a grab-bag of aliases, forged passports and demolitions manuals.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Ray Allen Erases All Doubts
description: RAY ALLEN has an agent, which means the all-American guard from Connecticut has officially ended his college career. Advantage International added Allen to a stable of basketball stars that includes DAVID ROBINSON, GRANT HILL and JERRY STACKHOUSE, among others. (AP)

title: Two Garden Spots for Elegant Dining
description: AUREOLE'S elegant little summer secret is its garden, newly redesigned with ivy and geraniums filling white planters and climbing the white trellis. Lunch and dinner are served in this romantic hideaway, at 34 East 61st Street. Another replanted garden spot is the lavish rooftop at Flowers, 21 West 17th Street, which now has its own separate kitchen. It is also open for lunch and dinner and is partly covered for shelter from rain.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Phone Rate Cuts Set For British Businesses
description: British Telecommunications P.L.C. said yesterday that it would cut the prices it charges business customers for domestic and international telephone calls by as much as 36 percent, exceeding by L100 million ($151 million) the cuts mandated by regulators. British Telecom estimated that businesses could save as much as L220 million ($332 million) each year from the move, which takes effect on July 1.

title: Theater in Review
description: Behind the Literary Masks, A Mama's Boy With Regrets 'The Wilde Spirit' Theater Off Park

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;A Big Partner for Blue Cross
description: New Jersey Blue Cross and Blue Shield, the state's largest health insurer, has agreed to join forces with a Midwestern company that is one of the nation's largest health insurers, people with knowledge of the deal said last night.

title: BASEBALL;Dream Game Becomes a Nightmare Loss for Rogers
description: Silent and stone-faced, Kenny Rogers sat beside Dwight Gooden between innings in the dugout. How appropriate. But Rogers did not need much advice from Gooden. He had been in this precarious situation before, as the zero beneath the hit column continued to shine brightly with every pitch.

title: AT WORK WITH: Andrew Selvaggio;Feeding Olympians And Other Fans Of the Big Mac
description: IF you were to guess that the man most responsible for the care and feeding -- O.K., feeding -- of the 15,000 athletes, coaches and officials at the centennial Olympic Games was the same pudgy kid dressed as a clown who would wave customers into Dorkie's Beef and Egger; if you were to guess that this man was now the executive chef of the McDonald's Corporation; even if you imagined McDonald's had such a thing as a chef, well, you'd probably deserve a break today.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: COMPANY NEWS;ALUMAX SELLS MEXICAN MINING STAKE TO PARTNER
description: Alumax Inc., based in Norcross, Ga., agreed yesterday to sell its Mexican mining interests to its partner, Industrias Penoles S.A., for $160 million. Alumax, the No. 3 United States aluminum producer, said the mines primarily produce silver, gold, lead and zinc. The stake in the Mexican mines was transferred to Alumax when the company was spun off from Amax Inc. in November 1993 at the same time Amax merged with the Cyprus Minerals Company. Industrias Penoles is Mexico's biggest silver-mining company.

title: Merrick Loses Suit Against Tony Panel
description: They had gone to Broadway in search of audiences and accolades. Now, in a downtown Manhattan courtroom, the producers of the musical "State Fair" were looking for something they felt they could no longer find in the theater district.

title: Pomp and Celebrity
description: To the Editor:

title: France to Replace Draft Next Year With a Week of Civic Lessons
description: President Jacques Chirac said tonight that French military conscription would end next January and be replaced with a week of civic education, mandatory for all young men turning 18 next year but also open to young women who volunteered.

title: Stylish New Cookbooks That Have Charitable Intentions
description: A GROWING number of cookbooks are being published to raise money for nonprofit organizations.

title: TV Notes;New Film From Dallas
description: Tonight, "CBS Evening News" will show segments of newly uncovered television film recorded on Nov. 22, 1963, the day of the assassination of President John F. Kennedy. The 16-millimeter film had been rescued from a trash can by a Dallas television station employee, who died last year; it then remained in the house of a friend whose family found it and last week gave it to the Assassination Records Review Board. The family also told Mary Mapes, a Dallas-based producer for "CBS Evening News," and her husband, Mark Wrolstad, a reporter for The Dallas Morning News. The newspaper reported the story yesterday; CBS scheduled its two-part report for last night and tonight.

title: Psychologist Admits Defrauding Insurers
description: A Bergen County psychologist faces up to six years in prison after pleading guilty today to defrauding state insurance carriers of more than $3.5 million in a kickback scheme involving 61 public school educators and nearly 150 other people.

title: Fraud Jeopardizes German Machinery Producer
description: Klockner-Humboldt-Deutz A.G., an ailing machinery maker, said today that its future was endangered because "several hundred million marks" of losses had been hidden by executives of a subsidiary company.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Wheat Prices Down Sharply As a Dry Spell Aids Planting
description: Wheat prices fell sharply yesterday after dry weather in the northern Plains allowed farmers to quicken the pace of planting, easing concerns over planting delays caused by heavy rain.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Barings Executive Penalized in Britain
description: Britain's main markets regulator said today that it had banned the former head of finance at the collapsed merchant bank Barings from working in the financial industry as a manager or director for at least three years and charged him L10,000 ($15,000) in costs.

title: Riot Police Beat and Arrest Albania Election Protesters
description: Stepping up the repressive tactics that marked parliamentary elections on Sunday, Government riot policemen beat and arrested opposition party supporters in the main square here today.

title: Broken Plastic Grate Cited In Death of Girl in Hot Tub
description: A health official said yesterday that a broken protective grating over a suction outlet caused a New Jersey girl to be pinned under 12 tons of pressure at the bottom of a hot tub, where she drowned.

title: COMPANY NEWS;C-CUBE MICROSYSTEMS TO BUY DIVICOM FOR $182 MILLION
description: C-Cube Microsystems Inc. agreed yesterday to buy closely held Divicom Inc. for about $182 million in cash and stock. C-Cube already owns 5.4 percent of Divicom's shares outstanding. It agreed to pay $70 million in cash and issue 2.4 million C-Cube shares for the remainder. Shares of C-Cube, based in Milpitas, Calif., fell $1.50, to $46.75, in Nasdaq trading before the deal was announced. C-Cube specializes in making chips for sending and receiving video on computers. Divicom makes digital video networking products, licensing the designs to third-party manufacturers. The company had sales of $34.1 million in 1995.

title: BASEBALL;Graduation Day for Wilson: Pomp and Studious Stance
description: One can still picture him in the on-deck circle at Shea Stadium, in a pinstriped Mets uniform, waiting his turn at bat. And when you checked the program, it read, "Mookie Wilson, outfielder."

title: City Awarded 4 Contracts To a Defunct Corporation
description: A construction company that failed to pay state taxes and was stripped of its corporate standing nearly two years ago has since won four contracts, worth more than $600,000, from the Fire Department and another New York City agency.

title: TV Notes;A Three-Hour Rule
description: The tug of war at the Federal Communications Commission over whether to require broadcast stations to carry at least three hours of children's educational programming each week to comply with the Children's Television Act took a lurch yesterday in the direction of the chairman, Reed E. Hundt.

title: BASEBALL;Gilkey Has Power; Mets Have Pitching
description: If only Bobby Jones and Mark Clark could pitch every other day, then maybe the Mets would be more than an afterthought in the National League East.

title: Don't Let Subpoenas Sink U.S. Foreign Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Find cyberspace too male-oriented? A cosmetics company hopes to draw its customers on line.
description: CLINIQUE, the No. 2 vendor of women's cosmetics in department stores, is going to cyberspace to jazz up its image.

title: BASEBALL;Ripken Is a Hit, at Short
description: Cal Ripken, assured he will not be forced to play third base, hit three homers in a game for the first time and drove in a career-high eight runs tonight, leading the Baltimore Orioles over the Seattle Mariners, 12-8.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MATRIX PHARMACEUTICAL DELAYS CANCER THERAPY TRIAL
description: Matrix Pharmaceutical Inc. said yesterday that its trial of Accusite Injectable Gel, a treatment for basal-cell cancer, had been delayed, leading to a sharp selloff of its stock. The stock fell $7.625, to $19.375, in Nasdaq trading of 3 million shares. Matrix, based in Menlo Park, Calif., which develops topical drugs to treat cancer and serious skin diseases, said Accusite failed in trials to meet Government standards as a treatment for basal-cell cancer.

title: TV Notes;Children's Winners
description: Sometimes it seems the only news from the daytime Emmy Awards is the annual futility report on Susan Lucci, the star of the ABC soap opera "All My Children," nominated for best actress in a daytime drama 16 times without winning. But daytime is children's time, too. And daytime Emmies for children's programming go out every year. Perhaps not surprisingly, most go to PBS shows.

title: TENNIS;Inconsistent Capriati Fizzles in First Round
description: Her game is fragile, and so is her psyche, bad ingredients in a sport with little patience for shortcomings, particularly those of a prodigy who spurned it.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Canada Says It Seized Two Russians as Spies
description: Canada said today that it had detained two suspected Russian spies and begun deportation proceedings.

title: Pacific Telesis Will Offer Internet Services
description: The Pacific Telesis Group became the first regional Bell company to offer Internet services to its telephone customers yesterday, aiming for the California market in which an estimated half of the nation's Internet users live.

title: Theater in Review
description: Words, Sentences, Paragraphs, All Inadequate to Reality 'Caught in the Act' Here

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: AUTO RACING;More Surgery for Driver
description: The driver ALESSANDRO ZAMPEDRI, injured in a crash on the last lap of the Indianapolis 500, had a second operation on both of his legs and feet yesterday. Zampedri, ROBERTO GUERRERO and ELISEO SALAZAR crashed in the fourth turn just as Sunday's race ended. Guerrero was not hurt and Salazar was treated for a bruised right knee and released from Methodist Hospital Sunday evening.

title: Milken Getting More Probation
description: A Federal judge has extended Michael Milken's probation for two months while regulators examine whether he violated terms of his forced exile from the securities industry.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Verdi and Janacek's Toppling Tipplers
description: In the half-hour before the curtain rose on a Spoleto Festival U.S.A. performance of "Falstaff" here on Monday evening, Anson Street -- a narrow road that leads from the palmetto-lined, cobblestone streets of the historic district to the blandly modern Gaillard Municipal Auditorium -- was full of operagoers making their way to the performance on foot. Others joined at every cross street, and an occasional bicycle-drawn rickshaw moved past the procession. The scene conveyed the sense of pilgrimage a visitor finds here during this multidisciplinary festival, now in its 20th season.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Disk War Figure To Lead Toshiba
description: An executive who played a central role in the Toshiba Corporation's victory last year in an industry-format battle over the new digital videodisk was named Toshiba's president today.

title: TRACK & FIELD;Sprinter Is Breaking More Than Just Paper
description: When he arrived at Jamaica High School in New York City from Trinidad, Ato Boldon had no desire to sprint, unless it was in pursuit of a soccer ball.

title: Co-op City Suffers While Its Board Bickers;An Election Focuses on a Battle for Control As the Complex's Management Is Investigated
description: Once upon a time, in an urban hamlet called Co-op City, the governing board members worked together in harmony, love and happiness, united in their zeal to improve the apartments, gardens and parking garages of the nation's largest cooperative housing development.

title: A Dominican Everyman As Unlikely Movie Hero
description: For almost a year, they've been lining up outside theaters, often ignoring tropical downpours, to see the film that has captivated this entire country. Residents of some isolated peasant villages have even strung up sheets in the town square and rented projectors so that they, too, can see "Nueba Yol."

title: Tribe Sends Early Christmas Gift to Hartford Ballet
description: Imagine Mark Twain wandering through the opening party in "The Nutcracker," a giant sequoia replacing the Christmas tree, and the ballet's Arabian divertissement changed to a pas de deux between an Indian warrior and an attractive eagle spirit.

title: Suit Says Racial Bias Led to Clustering of Solid-Waste Sites
description: In a rare test of Federal civil rights law, a group of residents in Chester, Pa., sued the State of Pennsylvania today, accusing its environmental agency of discrimination for concentrating the city's waste-processing sites in their black-majority neighborhood.

title: Weary Aide Is Buffeted In Gay-Marriage Storm
description: Living with AIDS and addicted to politics, Bob Hattoy, the Administration's unofficial envoy to the homosexual community, has been resorting to sardonic humor in facing friends concerned at the announcement that President Clinton would sign the Defense of Marriage bill, which would discourage same-sex unions.

title: Newborns Feel Pain
description: To the Editor:

title: Howard Chapnick, 74, Photo Agency Chief
description: Howard Chapnick, who headed Black Star, a leading worldwide picture agency based in Manhattan, from 1964 until his retirement six years ago, died on Monday at his home in Somers, N.Y. He was 74.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;One Bidder Drops Offer For Finnish Company
description: Svedala A.B., a Swedish maker of heavy machinery, withdrew its bid of 1.4 billion markka ($300 million) for Tampella Oy, a Finnish engineering company that specializes in drilling, mining and handling heavy goods. The announcement comes after Sandvik A.B., a Swedish maker of steel and industrial tools, said it had acquired 48.2 percent of Tampella.

title: A Partial Peace in Chechnya
description: Borrowing Senator George Aiken's 1966 exit strategy for Vietnam, Boris Yeltsin declared victory in Chechnya yesterday and said the war was over. Mr. Yeltsin's declaration to Russian troops during a lightning visit to Chechnya may prove as ephemeral as his earlier pronouncements about ending hostilities. But at least the Russian leader has a peace treaty of sorts in hand this time and he knows his re-election chances next month may hinge on whether the fighting stops.

title: Pataki Tries to Ease Strains With State Senate on the Budget
description: Trying to cool a rebellion among his fellow Republicans in the Legislature, Gov. George E. Pataki said today that he could reach a budget agreement with the Republican-controlled State Senate immediately and blamed the Democratic-led Assembly for the continuing stalemate, now two months old.

title: Tearing Out Vines to Plant Hops
description: The Benziger wine family is ripping out prime merlot grapevines in the heart of the wine country to plant hops, the prickly vine that produces the aromatic buds used in making beer.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page summary on Monday referring to an article about Stark County, Ohio, as a political bellwether where some voters who backed George Bush in 1992 are now turning to President Clinton misstated the duration of the current Republican control of Congress. It has been less than two years, not four.

title: Sports of The Times;Flopping Around Out West
description: THE Seattle SuperSonics kept saying the Utah Jazz knows all the tricks of flopping to draw personal fouls, but last night the Jazz also showed the heart of a veteran team.

title: Journal;Cradle and All
description: In "Of Thee I Sing," the Broadway musical satire that won a Pulitzer Prize during the Hoover-Roosevelt campaign year of 1932, the Presidential candidate John P. Wintergreen is so desperate for an issue that he runs on a platform of love. A Miss White House contest is held in Atlantic City to select the perfect First Lady -- there's a corn-muffin, if not a cookie, bake-off -- and the nation elects Wintergreen in a landslide.

title: For Lebanese Shiites, A Day to Recall Martyrs
description: There was human blood, and there were Katyusha rockets, both meant as gestures of devotion to a grandson of the Prophet Mohammed who was slain 14 centuries ago.

title: TV SPORTS;Hidden Cameras, Wired Bases
description: Imagine watching the Indianapolis 500 and U.S. 500 auto races without reports from the pits or shots from the minuscule in-car cameras. Without them, Sunday's competing races would be 450 laps of left turns at 230 miles an hour.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: CYCLING

title: COMPANY NEWS;APPLE COMPUTER ESTIMATES OPERATING LOSSES FOR YEAR
description: Apple Computer Inc. expects to post operating losses for the rest of the year, the company said in a recent filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Apple declined to elaborate on the size of the losses. The company's chairman, Gilbert F. Amelio, had previously said that Apple hoped to return to profitabilty within 12 months of its second quarter, which ended on March 29, 1996, for which it reported a $740 million loss. In the filing, dated May 13, the company also said it expected that sales would remain below levels of a year ago through the first quarter of 1997. Apple also warned that its board did not expect to resume dividend payments "for the foreseeable future."

title: Hindu Nationalist Cabinet Quits in India as Defeat Looms
description: Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee and his Government of Hindu nationalists resigned today ahead of certain defeat in India's new Parliament, making way for a new coalition of centrists, leftists and regional parties that will be India's third Government in a little more than two weeks.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: TV Notes;Who Drops, Who Buys
description: Perhaps because the cost of new entrees has never been higher, network leftovers seem to have become more appetizing than ever before.

title: A TREATY IN HAND, YELTSIN JOURNEYS TO CHECHEN CITY
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin embarked on his most audacious campaign trip today, traveling to the shattered capital of Chechnya only hours after concluding a peace treaty intended to stop the raging war in the secessionist southern region.

title: NYC;Public Cause Follows Private Tears
description: IT was last Wednesday when Linda Catalano realized that the woman who lived three doors down on Nancy Road was about to take a bold plunge and run for Congress. Carolyn McCarthy had come around to warn neighbors that after Memorial Day the police would close the street to traffic for a while because of all the reporters and cameras they expected.

title: Foreign Affairs;Bibi and Gennadi
description: They are worlds apart in so many ways: different countries, different parties, different histories. But Bibi Netanyahu, the head of Israel's right-wing Likud Party, and Gennadi Zyuganov, the head of Russia's left-wing Communist Party, actually have much in common, and you can learn a lot about the predicament of Russia and Israel by comparing the two.

title: Stocks Up in Tokyo
description: Stocks had small gains early today. At the midday break, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 78.08 points, at 22,022.61. On Tuesday, the Nikkei rose 244.77 points.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: New Jersey Blue Cross Said to Join Big Insurer New Jersey Blue Cross and Blue Shield has agreed to join forces with the Anthem Group, a big Midwestern company that owns Blue Cross plans in Indiana, Ohio and Kentucky, people with knowledge of the deal said.

title: Auction of Dahmer Items Is Apparently Off
description: The belongings of the serial killer Jeffrey L. Dahmer, which were once headed for the auction block in a controversial move to raise money for his victims' families, are now apparently headed for the incinerator instead.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Philandering Presidents: How Well They Work
description: Friends of talking heads will be drawn to "Character Above All" by the assemblage of historians (David McCullough), journalists (Ben Bradlee) and White House speech writers (Peggy Noonan) who know their Presidents. An hour with nine such close observers is bound to be illuminating, if not, as it turns out, blindingly so.

title: A U.S. Firm Is Said to Deal With a Serb Tied to Crimes
description: The Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, may not have many friends left in the outside world, but he apparently has a few in the American accounting firm of KPMG Peat Marwick.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SECURE COMPUTING TO BUY BORDER NETWORK TECHNOLOGIES
description: The Secure Computing Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the closely held Border Network Technologies in a stock transaction valued at about $190 million. The merger would create the second-largest computer-network security company. Under the agreement, a half share of Secure common stock would be exchanged for each of the roughly 13.1 million outstanding shares of Border. Secure Computing had total revenues of $20.7 million for the year that ended on Dec. 31, while Border's revenues were $3.3 million. Secure's stock rose $1.25 yesterday, to $30.25, before the deal was announced.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CADIZ LAND PLANS TO BUY SUN WORLD FOR $175 MILLION
description: The Cadiz Land Company said yesterday that it would buy Sun World International Inc., which has been in Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection since October 1994, for about $175 million. Most of the money would go to Sun World's creditors, Cadiz said; current stockholders of closely held Sun World would receive less than $10 million. The two companies grow fruit and vegetables in Southern California, where Cadiz owns 42,000 acres and Sun World more than 19,000. Cadiz's stock rose 56.3 cents, to $5.875, in Nasdaq trading. Cadiz, based in Rancho Cucamonga, Calif., said it would pay about $153 million to Sun World's secured lenders. Sun World's creditors and the United States Bankruptcy Court must approve the purchase.

title: Tattoos Are Rodman's Alone
description: For the time being, Dennis Rodman's tattoos will remain on his body, not on T-shirts. But he may have to bare his back in public to make that ruling stick.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Nissan Posts $814 Million Loss for Year
description: The Nissan Motor Company reported today that its group net loss narrowed in the latest fiscal year, and the company and analysts said they expected a return to profitability this year as conditions improved at troubled foreign operations.

title: Theater in Review
description: A Family That's of One Mind In Resisting Togetherness 'Wolf at the Door' One Dream Theater

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Burmese Rally Protests Opposition Group
description: The Burmese military Government organized a rally today to denounce the opposition National League for Democracy as the group issued a series of proposals for a more open society.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: Ciba-Geigy, Basel, Switzerland, to TBWA International, a unit of the Omnicom Group, and Grey Advertising, to handle the consolidated European account of its self-medication division, which had been handled by more than 20 agencies. Billings were estimated at $60 million.

title: A Fragmented War on Cancer
description: It has been 25 years since President Richard Nixon declared war on cancer. Having had two different cancers, I am a survivor of that war and a grateful beneficiary. My first, an aggressive lymphoma, was treated with an experimental therapy developed at the National Cancer Institute. Ten years later, my prostate cancer was detected early by the simple P.S.A. blood test, a diagnostic tool supported by Federal grants.

title: Newest Trial Therapy for Severe Head Injuries Shuns Complex Remediesfor Simple Ice Water
description: OF all traumas seen in the emergency room severe head injuries may be the most tragic. Most of the victims are young and most of them either die or remain profoundly disabled for the rest of their lives.

title: Obstacles Are Said to Block New Kinds of Contraceptives
description: In spite of a pressing need for new contraceptives, no new ones will reach the market without more research and better cooperation among government, industry and insurers, a panel of medical experts said today.

title: INSIDE
description: India Leader Bows Out

title: BALLET REVIEW;Partners in Classical Tchaikovskian Purity
description: American Ballet Theater brought back its all-Tchaikovsky program for another round on Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, this time with mostly new casting. Highlighting the program were role debuts by two of the company's most fascinating dancers, Vladimir Malakhov and Ashley Tuttle.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DEAN FOODS TO CUT 840 JOBS AND CLOSE 13 PLANTS
description: The Dean Foods Company said yesterday that it would close 13 plants and cut 840 jobs, or nearly 8 percent of its work force, to focus more on its core milk business and less on frozen vegetables. Dean said that it would take a $150 million charge before taxes in the fourth quarter for the reorganization, which it expects will cut costs by more than $20 million in fiscal 1997. The company said it would report a loss for the quarter and year, which ended on Sunday. Two months ago, the company reported a 61 percent decline in third-quarter earnings because of slack prices in its frozen vegetable products and increased costs in its pickle business. Dean, based in Franklin Park, Ill., is the nation's largest milk producer. Its shares fell 12.5 cents, to $24.50, before the announcement.

title: COMPANY NEWS;COCA-COLA ENTERPRISES TO BUY TWO BOTTLING COMPANIES
description: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., the world's largest bottler of Coca-Cola soft drinks, said yesterday that it would buy the Coca-Cola Bottling Company West and the Grand Forks Coca-Cola Bottling Company, as well as the convertible debt and warrants of Coke West held by the Coca-Cola Company, for about $158 million. Of the $158 million, $78 million is cash and the rest is debt. Coke West and Grand Forks, both closely held companies that are based in Billings, Mont., had pro forma 1995 net operating revenues of about $112 million and sold 23 million cases. Coca-Cola Enterprises distributes about 57 percent of Coca-Cola's domestic output.

title: Bishops Opposing Gay Clergy Members Will Try New Tactic
description: A group of 10 Episcopal Church bishops who had filed charges of heresy against a fellow bishop for ordaining a gay man as a deacon said yesterday that they rejected a church court's decision dismissing the charges.

title: Texas Instruments Creates New Chip Technology
description: Texas Instruments Inc. said today that it had developed new technology that would allow it to build computer chips with processing power 20 times greater than today's personal computers.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DATAPOINT CORP. San Antonio, will sell its European unit that creates computer software and hardware for car dealerships to Kalamazoo Computer Group P.L.C. for $33 million.

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;Pittsburgh Is Back In Control
description: The Panthers are trapped like rats. The Penguins are one victory from reaching the Stanley Cup finals.

title: In Their Own Words: Was It Murder or Manslaughter?
description: MAYOR RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI

title: Revisiting the Issue of Crime, Dole Offers List of Remedies
description: Labeling the current era "the age of violence" without guilt or remorse, Bob Dole returned today to the subject of crime, portraying himself as tougher than President Clinton and calling for a constitutional amendment to protect victims' rights.

title: City Hospital Subsidy Cuts Threaten Everyone
description: To the Editor:

title: A Secular India Must Have One Law for All
description: To the Editor:

title: Organ Improvisation as an Art Form
description: Jazz musicians learn to improvise. Classical musicians learn mostly to perform. But organists learn and study improvisation very seriously indeed in France, which is why five organ students at the National Conservatory climbed to the loft at the Church of St. Ferdinand des Ternes recently to learn at the hands and feet of a master improviser, Prof. Loic Mallie.

title: A Stacked Deck Against NEC
description: The National Science Foundation has startled American computer firms by planning the Federal Government's first purchase of a Japanese supercomputer. But the foundation has also said it would follow up on allegations that the Japanese maker, NEC, was offering its supercomputer below cost, a violation of trade rules known as dumping. That is the right message. NEC gets a fair shot at the contract, but only a fair shot. Unfortunately, another arm of Government, the Commerce Department -- which decides when dumping occurs -- may already have stacked the case against NEC.

title: Inmates Act To Deter Youngsters From Crime
description: Camillo Douglas, 15, still walked with a confident swagger, students and teachers at the Dunbar School say, when he returned after spending more than a month in a detention center for robbery, drug possession and driving without a license.

title: Check Those Facts On Need for Abortion
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place;A stock index of black-owned companies has been soaring.
description: IT certainly is not as well known as older, well- established cousins like the Standard & Poor's 500 index or the Dow Jones industrial average, but for the last 18 months a little-noticed market measure has outstripped the performance of both.

title: Theater in Review
description: Crosses, Double Crosses Even Triple Crosses. Whew! 'Three in the Back, Two in the Head' MCC Theater

title: COMPANY NEWS;MELVILLE SELLS WILSONS APPAREL DIVISION TO MANAGEMENT
description: The Melville Corporation said yesterday that it had sold its Wilsons leather apparel division to an investor group led by Wilsons management. Terms were not disclosed. The sale was part of Melville's reorganization under which it will split into two companies and sell other businesses to focus on its CVS drugstore chain. Wilsons chairman and chief executive, Joel N. Waller, and its president and chief operating officer, David L. Rogers led the management group that purchased Wilsons. The rest of the group, a Minnesota limited partnership, was led by Lyle Berman and Morris Goldfarb.

title: Guilty in Little Rock
description: A Federal jury in Little Rock, Ark., yesterday convicted President Clinton's former business partners on nearly every count in the fraud case Kenneth Starr, the independent prosecutor, brought against them. A third defendant, Arkansas's Governor, Jim Guy Tucker, stands convicted of two of seven counts against him. However analyzed, the verdict is strong vindication for the methodical work of the prosecution and politically troublesome for Bill Clinton, who was summoned as a witness for the defense.

title: Our Towns;Memorial Day Back Where It All Began
description: RIGHT around now, folks here come to realize how different Waterloo is from everywhere else in the country.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;BABY SUPERSTORE INC. (BSST,NNM)
description: Shares of Baby Superstore Inc. fell 30 percent yesterday after the retailer posted lower-than-expected earnings for the first quarter.

title: Moody's Combining 2 Units In First Big Shift in Years
description: Moody's Investors Service, one of the two major bond rating agencies in the nation, announced yesterday what it said was the first major revamping of its operations in more than a quarter-century.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Representative PATRICIA SCHROEDER, the Colorado Democrat who has spent 24 years in Congress, may be moving on to the halls of ivy when she leaves public office at the end of the year.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Car and Bus in Fatal Crash
description: A car veered out of control yesterday afternoon on Ridge Road near Route 23 and hit a New Jersey Transit bus head-on. Rene Simon, 14, of West Orange, a passenger in the car, was killed. Her brother Ronnie, 17, the driver, was listed in critical condition last night at University Hospital in Newark, and three other riders were also hurt, The Associated Press reported.

title: New Chief Named for School-Lease Program
description: A former Koch administration official was selected yesterday to take over the Board of Education's troubled school-leasing program.

title: Seeking New Answers In Trade Center Attack
description: The first trial of the slender young man whom prosecutors call Ramzi Ahmed Yousef, who is accused of being the mastermind of the World Trade Center bombing, could provide clues to what motivated one of the worst terrorist attacks on American soil, and who was behind the bombing. Opening statements are scheduled to start today in Mr. Yousef's trial in a related terror case, on charges that he and his accomplices plotted to blow up American jetliners in Asia.

title: TASTINGS
description: Bonnes-Mares 1993, Laboure-Roi (Burgundy). About $40.

title: Clinton Orders Expanded Agent Orange Benefits for Veterans
description: President Clinton ordered today that disability benefits be expanded to cover veterans who served in Vietnam and suffer from prostate cancer or a nerve disease that may be associated with the defoliant Agent Orange.

title: In His Own Words
description: BOB DOLE

title: Supreme Court Roundup;Justices to Review Law That Keeps More Than One Party From Nominating a Candidate
description: In a case raising an important issue of political free speech, the Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether parties have a constitutional right to choose candidates who have already been nominated by another party.

title: A Microbrew Gets a Macromug: A Homemade Beer Goes National
description: JIM SIMPSON is a plumber by trade, as his father was before him. Like any honest working man, Jim has never been averse to hoisting a few after a long day on the job.

title: China Rebuffs Taiwan Call
description: China has rebuffed an offer by President Lee Teng-hui of Taiwan to hold high-level talks.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;Bulls Must Wait As Jazz Survives
description: Just what Michael Jordan needed: more time off.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Tax Amnesty Exceeds a Goal
description: As State Treasurer Brian W. Clymer predicted last week, response to the heavily publicized New Jersey tax amnesty program has exceeded expectations, generating $90 million in revenue by last Friday, according to figures released yesterday. State tax officials had said earlier that the program would take in $80 million.

title: Eating Well;Food Heros or Zealots?
description: FOR the last few years, the Center for Science in the Public Interest has been examining the country's favorite foods and finding them lacking: movie popcorn contains almost three days' worth of "artery clogging fat"; fettuccine Alfredo is a "heart attack on a plate," and perhaps most frightening, that innocent-looking kung pao chicken is as bad as four Quarter Pounders.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Publisher of Ms. Will Sell Magazine Group to Investors
description: Ending months of uncertainty, Lang Communications, the ailing publisher of Working Woman, Working Mother and Ms., agreed yesterday to sell the magazines to a new company founded by Jay C. MacDonald, a longtime magazine publishing executive, and a group of investors.

title: G.E. Nuclear Plant Deal
description: The General Electric Company said today that its GE Nuclear Energy unit had received a $1.8 billion contract for a nuclear power plant from the Taiwan Power Company. GE Nuclear will supply the design, equipment and nuclear fuel for the project, at Yenliao, Taiwan, which is the fourth nuclear power plant in that country.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The black American soldiers of the 369th Infantry Regiment were heroes in France during World War I but were virtually unknown at the time at home. On Monday, one of the regiment's bravest members was honored in Albany, his hometown, with help from the entertainer GREGORY HINES, The Associated Press reported.

title: Los Angeles, Long Fragmented, Faces Threat of Secession by the SanFernando Valley
description: There has always been this nagging suspicion that Los Angeles is more a state of mind than proper city, a place too scattered, literally and figuratively, to hang together as a metropolitan whole.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;A Search for the Soul, if There Is One
description: OPEN HEART By A.B. Yehoshua Translated by Dalya Bilu. 498 pages. Doubleday. $24.95

title: Theater in Review
description: A Witty Domestic Facedown: He Deflates, She Frays Puerto Rican Traveling Theater 304 West 47th Street

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Hong Kong Group Buys Hilton Hotel in London
description: Ladbroke Group P.L.C. agreed yesterday to sell the Langham Hilton Hotel in London to a unit of Great Eagle Holdings Ltd. of Hong Kong for L100 million, or about $151 million. Ladbroke, a London-based hotel and leisure company, said the sale price was slightly below the book value of the hotel, which recorded an operating profit of L7.5 million ($11.3 million) last year. (Dow Jones)

title: Barney Wilen, 59, Saxophonist Known for His Jazz Soundtracks
description: Barney Wilen, a French saxophonist who performed regularly with American jazz musicians, died on Saturday. He was 59.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Rollerblade Narrows Its List
description: Rollerblade Inc., the marketer of in-line skates, said yesterday that it has narrowed its account review to 6 agencies, from 12. The account had been handled by Carmichael Lynch in Minneapolis for six years until that agency declined to participate in the review. Though the billings were not disclosed, Adweek estimated them at $10 million.

title: Did a Taiwan Ship Hurl Stowaways Overboard?
description: Canadian officials said today that they were holding a Taiwanese container ship in port and discussing with Romanian officials whether to investigate allegations that the ship's officers threw Romanian stowaways overboard while on the high seas.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TRACK AND FIELD;Holman Is Kicking Himself
description: STEVE HOLMAN is upset with himself because he ran what he called a slow and careless mile on Sunday. His time in the Prefontaine Classic in Eugene, Ore., was 3 minutes 52.86 seconds, not exactly pedestrian. But he did not see DAVID KIBET of Kenya slip by until it was too late, and Kibet won in 3:52.28.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The day before he was married in 1861 to the first of his two wives, William Steinway, a son of the founder of the piano manufacturing company who later became its president, began keeping a diary and stopped a few weeks before his death in 1896.

title: Police Propose Assault on 125th St. Crime
description: A top police official has proposed a plan to flood 125th Street with officers, both to clean up drug dealing, gambling and street crime in Harlem and to blunt criticism of the Giuliani administration by black politicians.

title: In Very Close Race, Israeli Candidates Make a Last Push
description: The forests and lampposts of Israel were draped with miles of blue-and-white banners, and the candidates made their final sallies to nail down wavering votes today as Israel braced for one of the most important elections in its history.

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;Fedorov Emerging as Wings' Point Man
description: It wasn't enough for Sergei Fedorov of the Red Wings to check Wayne Gretzky and stifle his offensive brilliance in the previous round against St. Louis. It still wasn't enough for Fedorov to set up a fistful of goals in the series against the Colorado Avalanche.

title: Corrections
description: A diagram in Science Times yesterday about fetal brain development misidentified a structure involved in guiding migrating neurons. It is the neural subplate, not the subneural plate.

title: Fox and TCI In Discussions About Offering News Channel
description: Fox Inc. and Tele-Communications Inc., the largest cable operator in the country, are discussing a partnership that would lead to distribution of Fox's new 24-hour news channel into as many as 10 million homes served by TCI.

title: Clinton Voices Sympathy For Whitewater Figures
description: President Clinton expressed personal sorrow this evening for his three Arkansas compatriots who were convicted today in the first trial of the Whitewater investigation, and he deflected questions about his own credibility to the jury and the political repercussions of the verdict.

title: Reasonable Immigration Reform
description: The House and Senate have come a long way in refining their immigration bills. But more work is needed. President Clinton rightly threatens to veto legislation unless it sticks to the worthy goal of barring illegal immigrants at borders, airports and workplaces and discouraging the abusive use of welfare programs by legal immigrants.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;A Consolidation By Domino's
description: Domino's Pizza Inc. said yesterday that it would consolidate its regional advertising and spot media-buying accounts at the Detroit office of the J. Walter Thompson Company, effective Aug. 1. The accounts, with billings estimated at $35 million, have been split among four agencies.

title: Theater in Review
description: Taking Miami Apart to See What Makes It Tick, Tick, Tick 'Radio Mambo: Culture Clash Invades Miami' Intar Theater

title: SOCCER;New Coach Has Worldly Flair
description: The soccer people in this country who lamented when Carlos Queiroz turned down the job as coach of the United States national team last summer were rejoicing this afternoon when the 43-year-old native of Portugal was introduced as coach of the MetroStars.

title: Defector Says North Korea Plans War, but Experts Express Doubts
description: A pilot who defected to South Korea said today that North Korea has drawn up a war plan to capture South Korea within a week and that pilots are training for a lightning strike.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Prices Decline For Treasuries In Quiet Day
description: Prices of Treasury securities drifted lower in lighter-than-average trading yesterday, as investors responded to housing data that was stronger than expected.

title: Food Notes
description: Correction Appended

title: As Budget Cuts Take Hold, the Growth of History at CUNY Is History
description: Baruch College's catalogue has a section that Myrna Chase, the chairwoman of the history department, calls the "dead letters" section -- courses that will not be offered for at least the next two years. Next year, the list will triple in size, with the loss of such popular subjects as "The Constitutional Era," "Civil War and Reconstruction" and "The Immigrant in American History."

title: Consumer Confidence Fades a Bit, but Home Resales Rise
description: Although consumer confidence waned a bit in May, many professional forecasters remain upbeat about the economy, seeing no recession at least through next year.

title: Governor's Resignation Will Give Arkansas G.O.P. a Stronger Hand
description: The resignation of Gov. Jim Guy Tucker has set off a game of political musical chairs that will immediately give Republicans a larger foothold in the government of Arkansas, the only Southern state that has been slow to move toward Republicanism.

title: Awaiting Execution, And Finding Buddha
description: William Frank Parker, a double murderer with a nasty habit of slugging corrections officers, was doing time in solitary confinement one day when he asked a prison guard, somewhat impolitely, for a Bible to read.

title: Surge Expected in Sales of Cable Modems
description: The consumer search for faster connections to the Internet will fuel an almost doubling in demand this year for cable modems in North America, the research firm Dataquest said today.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Chip Makers In Japan Post Strong Gains
description: Four of Japan's biggest electronics companies said today that group earnings rose in the double digits during the latest fiscal year, aided by strong sales of semiconductors. But with chip prices now falling, they said they expected profit growth to slow, and in one case decline, this year.

title: A Secular India Must Have One Law for All
description: To the Editor:

title: Spreading the Economic Word;Black Pulpits, a White Businessman and Buying Power
description: Strong in faith but weak in economic leverage, prominent black church leaders are joining hands with a little-known white conservative businessman in a secular alliance to cash in on black spending power.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Pitino's Answer May Be Coming Today
description: Trying to crawl inside of Rick Pitino's head is hard enough when he's within walking distance, but now he's an ocean away, playing the golf courses of Ireland, trying to make the best read on his next shot. Should he take the Nets' offer, or not? Though few have spoken to him directly since he left Sunday, the Nets, as well as some people close to Pitino, believe that his answer could come as early as today.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Southern Water of Britain Gets a $2.35 Billion Offer
description: Another company in Britain's rapidly consolidating utility industry is in play.

title: BASEBALL;Yankees Hotly Pursue A 16-Year-Old Phenom
description: Continuing to intensify their pursuit of international players, the Yankees appear to be the front-runners in negotiations to sign a power-hitting 16-year-old outfielder from Venezuela who is represented by one of baseball's premier agents, Scott Boras, and is expected to command a signing bonus of at least $1.5 million.

title: AT HOME WITH: Anne d'Harnoncourt;A Master of the Graceful Sidestep
description: ANNE D'HARNONCOURT was born and bred for the museum world.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Disney, Partner Study a Sea Park
description: The Walt Disney Company and the Oriental Land Company, its Japanese partner, have completed a preliminary study for an aquatic theme park next to Tokyo Disneyland.

title: Food Safety Data Need New Guardian
description: To the Editor:

title: Currents;Here's a Rainy Day Project (But Watch for Lightning)
description: WHEN Paco Rabanne introduced his first fashion collection in 1966, he called it, aptly, "12 Unwearable Dresses." One dress was made of plastic disks and metal links. It required a slender body, a blithe spirit, the desire not to sit and $1,000 in spare change.

title: A Trove of Singer Works Overlooked?
description: After combing more than 30 years of back issues of the daily and weekly Yiddish newspaper The Forward, a New York librarian says she has found 13 serialized and untranslated novels and more than 50 short stories of the Nobel laureate Isaac Bashevis Singer.

title: The Punitive Purpose
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Novell Loses $55.4 Million During Quarter
description: Novell Inc. said today that it lost $55.4 million in its fiscal second quarter primarily because of the sale of its former Word Perfect business.

title: Charges Dropped Against 2 Reporters
description: A judge yesterday dismissed misdemeanor trespassing charges against two reporters arrested last month at the Waldorf-Astoria while trying to determine the seating arrangements at a fund-raiser for Gov. George E. Pataki.

title: Burmese Dissident Presses Demands, Putting Junta on Defensive
description: In the last few days, the military Government of Myanmar has imprisoned hundreds of its opponents, filled the controlled press with threats against them, and gathered tens of thousands of people for pro-Government rallies. But it is on the defensive as it has not been for years.

title: New York Officer Held in Beating In Racial Incident at a Bar on L.I.
description: A New York City police officer has been charged in the beating of a 21-year-old man outside a Long Island bar where, the authorities said, a raucous Saturday night of drinking ended in racial epithets, drawn guns and blows from a tempered-steel club that left the victim near death.

title: COMPANY NEWS;KMART SECURES $3.7 BILLION CREDIT FACILITY
description: The Kmart Corporation said yesterday that the Chase Manhattan Corporation had completed the syndication of the retailer's new $3.7 billion credit facility, with the facility oversubscribed by about $1 billion. Kmart said the new facility was expected to become effective next month. Upon closing, the new $2.5 billion revolving credit facility and $1.2 billion term loan facility, each with a maturity of three years, will replace about $3 billion in existing credit facilities and other obligations and will provide Kmart with an additional $700 million in available liquidity.

title: Will Dole Really Contest California? The Signs Are Mixed
description: Bob Dole says he is determined to fight for California, but there are mixed signals here about how committed his campaign is to putting in the time and the money needed to give him a chance of winning this important state.

title: In Defense of the Defense of Marriage Act
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: U.S. Equestrian Team, Gladstone, N.J., to Burkhardt & Partners, New York, to handle its account, which had been handled by Classic Communication, Foxboro, Mass. Billings were estimated at $1 million.

title: Many Israelis Protested Attacks on Lebanon
description: To the Editor:

title: The Political Costs of Whitewater
description: The guilty verdicts returned on Tuesday in the Whitewater case in Arkansas hit political Washington like a bomb, surprising almost everyone. But after a night's reflection and a day's gossip, most of the political professionals concluded that it had been a small bomb.

title: Murder Charge Is Warranted in Officer's Death
description: To the Editor:

title: In Prime-Time Shuffle, Networks Try Change
description: Big stars will be back. Fewer friends will be sharing cafe lattes. Old shows will find new life on other networks. Homicidal maniacs will abound.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: COMPUTER SCIENCES CORP., El Segundo, Calif., which installs and manages computer systems, agreed to buy closely held American Practice Management, New York. Terms were not disclosed.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Mitsubishi's Yearly Profit Rises by 15%
description: The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation reported a 15.3 percent rise in pretax profit for the last fiscal year, as cost-cutting made up for a drop in export sales caused by a generally strong yen.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO BASKETBALL;Cowens Takes the Reins
description: The fiery stare DAVE COWENS got in his eyes during his playing days was back yesterday when he took over as coach of the Charlotte Hornets.

title: Starr Seeks Delay on Files
description: The Whitewater special prosecutor, Kenneth W. Starr, has asked Congressional Republicans not to seek White House documents related to his inquiry into dismissals at the White House travel office in 1993.

title: 8 Abused Women, Daring to Solo
description: THE rules were strict: Carmen Muniz was to sit on a rocky ledge overlooking a glistening lake for two hours, with only her journal as company.

title: Stocks Lower in Japan
description: Stocks traded lower here today. At the close, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 135.15 points, or more than six-tenths of 1 percent, at 21,886.35. On Wednesday, the Nikkei index closed up 76.97 points, or nearly four-tenths of 1 percent.

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;Panthers Don't Want It to End
description: Nobody here wants the fairy tale to end so soon. Certainly not Coach Doug MacLean, who got almost nostalgic today over what a warm and fuzzy story the Florida Panthers have been this season. "Can we just get a couple more chapters to the story?" MacLean asked with a smile after Florida's practice at Gold Coast Ice Arena today.

title: Market Place;An Internet link gives an old technology some new luster.
description: IN the newly deregulated world of telecommunications, it may not be enough any more to be just a telephone company, just a cable TV company, just a broadcaster or just an Internet company. Many of these companies want to provide customers with a broad array of digital services, but to do so they need to pump torrents of bits into homes at high speeds.

title: David B. Kriser, 90, Industrialist Who Aided Hospital and N.Y.U.
description: David B. Kriser, a major benefactor of Beth Israel Medical Center and New York University, where various medical services bear his name, died on Sunday at his home on the East Side of Manhattan. He was 90.

title: George Boolos, 55, Philosopher
description: George S. Boolos, a professor of linguistics and philosophy at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the president of the Association for Symbolic Knowledge, died on Monday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 55.

title: Peter F. Ostwald, 68, a Scholar Linking Music and Psychiatry
description: Dr. Peter F. Ostwald, an author, professor of psychiatry and the founding director of the Health Program for Performing Artists at the University of California at San Francisco, died on Saturday at his home. He was 68 and lived in San Francisco.

title: Terms Are Set For Sale Of Coliseum
