description: The Giuliani administration and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority reached an agreement yesterday to proceed with the sale of the Coliseum to a private developer, ending more than two years of squabbling between the two that had once again delayed long-stalled development of the site.

title: Essay;Partners in Crime?
description: The defense attorney could not have presented the choice to the jury more plainly: Are you to take the word of David Hale, an admitted crook, or will you believe the sworn testimony of the President of the United States?

title: COMPANY NEWS;DUN & BRADSTREET FINDS BUYER FOR CREDIT INSURANCE UNIT
description: The Dun & Bradstreet Corporation agreed yesterday to sell its American Credit Indemnity unit, a credit insurance company. Terms were not disclosed. Dun & Bradstreet, based in Wilton, Conn., said in January that it would sell the business as part of its plan to split into three separate companies. The unit is being sold to ACI Holding Inc., a Baltimore-based concern owned by Compagnie Financiere SFAC of France, a credit insurer, and the investment firm Securitas Capital L.L.C. SFAC acquired a 5 percent stake in American Credit Indemnity in 1992.

title: Church Leans Toward Yeltsin In Russian Vote
description: On a recent visit to Tbilisi, Georgia, Patriarch Aleksy II tipped his hand about the Russian presidential elections. "Today, in this fateful time for Russia, President Boris Yeltsin has played a great role in uniting the people," he said at a news conference. "If the old regime comes back to power, the country will suffer new tremors."

title: Farm Workers Sign Accord With Lettuce Growers, Ending a Long andBitter Conflict
description: After nearly 18 years of supermarket boycotts, legal clashes and bitter conflicts in the fields, the United Farm Workers of America and one of the nation's top lettuce growers signed a work contract today, laying to rest one of the oldest American farm labor disputes.

title: Jerry R. Junkins, 58, Dies; Headed Texas Instruments
description: Jerry R. Junkins, who rose from the factory floor to become chairman of Texas Instruments Inc., where he helped revive the American computer chip industry during the last decade, died yesterday. He was 58 and lived in Dallas.

title: Mostly Black School District Tells Justice Thomas to Stay Home
description: Bowing to protest, a predominantly black school district in suburban Washington has withdrawn a speaking invitation to Justice Clarence Thomas, the only black on the Supreme Court.

title: BASEBALL;Belle Swears at a Fan
description: The Cleveland Indians apologized today to a Texas Rangers fan for Albert Belle's profane response after the fan refused to give up a home run ball he had caught in the fourth inning.

title: Plot of Terror in the Skies Is Outlined by a Prosecutor
description: In a daring plot to wreak vengeance on the United States for its support of Israel, a small cell of terrorist bombers planned to kill several thousand air travelers last year by blasting a dozen American jumbo jetliners out of the skies over the Pacific Ocean and East Asia, a prosecutor said yesterday.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Hot Tub Safety Panel Named
description: A State Department of Health task force was named yesterday to examine whether changes should be made in hot tubs in order to prevent accidents like the one early Saturday that took the life of a Lakewood High School junior.

title: Feeling Devalued by Change, Doctors Seek Union Banner
description: With the spread of managed-care companies and their efforts to contain costs, many doctors say they are losing control over working conditions, treatments and incomes. In response, some are taking a most uncommon step to protect their interests. They are joining labor unions.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Ex-Official of Bankers Trust Charged With Securities Fraud
description: A compliance officer, whose job was to guard against insider trading by employees of the Bankers Trust Securities Company, illegally traded shares of at least nine companies in 1994, Federal prosecutors said yesterday, after charging him with securities fraud.

title: How to Honor a Fallen Hero
description: The death of Police Officer Vincent Guidice was a tragedy for New York City as well as for his family and friends. Officer Guidice died from an injury he received while responding to a report of a family dispute. Domestic violence is a dangerous and difficult area of police work. At the time he was wounded, Officer Guidice was visiting the same Bronx apartment for a second night running, even though the woman who lived there had declined to press charges the day before. His death will not make the fight against spousal abuse easier, but his fellow officers will honor his memory by emulating his brave persistence.

title: MERGING IDENTITY -- A special report.;New Sense of Race Arises Among Asian-Americans
description: It was on a late May afternoon in 1969, three months after he had left the Philippines for New York City, that Peter Bersamin says he began to realize he was Asian.

title: Currents;Lively Learning at the Renovated Brooklyn Children's Museum
description: IN the newly renovated Brooklyn Children's Museum, which reopened earlier this month, there are a new workshop, greenhouse, galleries, a computer-access system, gift shop and a rooftop performance and play area. There is even a precursor of the Swatch -- a sundial where a child's shadow falls on the correct time (above right). The total cost was $7 million.

title: BASEBALL;A Rookie Sensation Can't Win Them All
description: On paper, the pitching matchup looked like a major mismatch. On paper, Chuck Finley, one of the premier left-handers in the American League, is supposed to overshadow Ramiro Mendoza, a rookie making his second start. What seemed probable on paper was also true on the field tonight as Finley and the Angels silenced the Yankees, 4-0, at Anaheim Stadium.

title: BASEBALL;O'Neill Given A Little Rest
description: Paul O'Neill was 1 for his last 17 over all and 3 for 16 against Chuck Finley, the Angels' starter tonight, so he was not in the Yankees' lineup for the second time in 49 games. Ruben Rivera started in right field for O'Neill, who struck out as a pinch-hitter in the ninth inning of tonight's loss.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Almon Leaves Brown
description: BILLY ALMON, a former all-American at Brown who was the No. 1 pick in the 1974 major league draft and spent parts of 15 years with seven teams, resigned as coach of his alma mater yesterday to spend more time with his family. In four years, Almon's teams were 49-107, including 12-25 this year.

title: If Re-elected, Head of Board Faces a Fight
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew will use "every bit of legal authority available" to prevent Carmelo Saez Jr., the ousted president of Community School Board 9 in the Bronx, from reclaiming his seat should he win re-election to a new term, an aide to the Chancellor said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about wild-mushroom fanciers in the New York region referred incorrectly to the person shown hunting for morels. Morgan Gwenwald is a woman.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Good News for Butler: Lymph Nodes Benign
description: Los Angeles Dodgers outfielder BRETT BUTLER is looking forward to a complete recovery after learning that 49 of 50 lymph nodes removed from his neck are not cancerous, a close friend said yesterday.

title: Rockefeller Center Plan
description: A Federal Bankruptcy Court gave final approval yesterday to the Chapter 11 reorganization plan of the two partnerships that own the Rockefeller Center complex. The approval clears the way for the two partnerships, which are controlled by the Mitsubishi Estate Company, to transfer ownership to Rockefeller Center Properties Inc., which is its largest creditor. In turn, an investment group led by Goldman, Sachs & Company is set to acquire the complex by paying about $306 million, or $8 a share, to buy out shareholders of Rockefeller Center Properties, which holds a $1.3 billion mortgage.

title: Executive Changes
description: COLGATE-PALMOLIVE CO., New York, said its controller, Stephen C. Patrick, would become chief financial officer, succeeding Robert Agate, who will retire on July 1.

title: None-Too-Bright Criminals Spoiling Germans' Efficient Image
description: Pessimists in Germany, of whom there is no shortage, see evidence of their country's decline everywhere. The economy is at a virtual standstill, unemployment is worse than it has been in 30 years, public employees are threatening to call a national strike, and dynamic political leaders are nowhere to be found.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the conviction of President Clinton's former business partners, in the first trial of the Whitewater investigation into a failed savings and loan association, omitted a word in some editions and thus misstated the question to which the President was responding when he said: "You ought to ask them that. I doubt that. I doubt that that's what was going on." (A related article, about the White House's response to the verdict, also reflected the error.)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief report in Business Day yesterday about Michael Milken's probation referred incorrectly in some editions to the length of an extension he received. It was until the end of July, not July 1.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;France Dismisses Head Of Jet Engine Maker
description: The French Government has dismissed Bernard Dufour, the chairman of the jet engine maker that it owns, Snecma, after it grew increasingly irritated with his calls to recapitalize the company and the slow pace at which he was selling noncore assets. The surprise move yesterday, just a year and a half after Mr. Dufour was brought in to run Snecma, which makes civil and military engines, came as the chairman was helping prepare the company for sale to the public. Mr. Dufour had repeatedly called on the state to put 6 billion francs into the company, before selling it to the public. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: COMPANY NEWS;BORLAND INTERNATIONAL WARNS OF A PROBABLE LOSS
description: Borland International Inc. said yesterday that it would probably report a loss in the first quarter, as sales of its Delphi Desktop software fell below expectations. The company, which writes software that helps programmers write other software, said it would post a loss for the quarter, which ends on June 30, unless revenue picks up in the rest of the quarter. The company did not disclose the size of the expected loss. The software concern said the expected loss also stems from "distractions" associated with reorganization of its sales and marketing teams and its planned purchase of the Open Environment Corporation for $64 million. Borland, based in Scotts Valley, Calif., announced the possible loss after the stock market closed. Earlier, shares rose $1.25, to $17.125, in Nasdaq trading.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Eurotunnel Seeks to Lure Users by Cutting Prices
description: Eurotunnel, the British-French consortium that operates the tunnel under the English Channel, said yesterday that it was cutting prices by as much as half, beefing up services and introducing a loyalty program to try to lure more people to take their automobiles on its Le Shuttle service, which transports them through the tunnel on rail cars. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Upstairs Or Down, Now It's All in the Family
description: CONSIDER it a trendlet.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HORSE RACING;Heavy Load for Cigar
description: The weight is high and the odds are short for Cigar in the Massachusetts Handicap tomorrow. "I think it's a lot of weight," the trainer BILL MOTT said yesterday of the 130 pounds assigned to Cigar, the highest weight of his career, for the race at Suffolk Downs, which he won last year. "He'll be giving away 18, 19 or 20 pounds to some of his rivals."

title: No Headline
description: The marketplace has changed. For years physicians owned the store. Since the advent of managed care, we don't own the store any more."

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the sale of Working Mother, Working Woman and Ms. magazines by Lang Communications referred incorrectly in some editions to the copies of Working Mother that are distributed free. Some 215,000 copies, out of a circulation of 930,000, are paid subscriptions bought by child-care centers and sent free to the homes of women with children registered at the centers; they are not sent free to the centers. An additional 102,000 copies are distributed free to doctors' offices.

title: INSIDE
description: And Who's the Father?

title: Eugenia Price, 79, Romance Novelist, Dies
description: Eugenia Price, who turned a chance visit to coastal Georgia into a career as the South's most popular writer of antebellum romantic fiction, died on Tuesday at a hospital in Brunswick, Ga., not far from her home in St. Simons, the island she made famous through a series of novels. She was 79.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Industrial Production Bounces Back in Japan
description: Industrial output rebounded sharply last month in Japan, the Government said yesterday, reinforcing the view that a gradual economic recovery is continuing. The Trade Ministry announced that in April, Japanese companies increased production by 3.9 percent from the previous month, when production had declined 6 percent. Robust output of personal computers and cellular phones led the growth in April, but the ministry said the inventories of many companies remained too high. The data were largely in line with expectations. (Reuters)

title: Anthem's Strategy: Bigger the Better
description: L. Ben Lytle, whose Anthem Inc. is acquiring Blue Cross-Blue Shield of New Jersey, apparently figures there is one thing for certain in America's fast-changing health care system: you have to be big to be a player.

title: Captain Held On Suspicion Of Hurling 3 Men in Sea
description: Canadian policemen stormed a Taiwanese ship today and arrested the captain, who has been accused along with his officers of throwing three Romanian stowaways overboard on the high seas, Government officials said.

title: Health Plans In New Jersey Face Rivalries
description: New Jersey's fiercely competitive health insurance market will soon become even rougher. Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey yesterday agreed to merge with Anthem Inc., a big, diversified Midwestern insurer. The merger will create the nation's second-biggest holder of Blue Cross and Blue Shield franchises.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Priest Said to Leave France After Criticism
description: Abbe Pierre, an elderly priest regularly voted France's most popular man, has left the country after a dispute over his support for the author of a book which casts doubt on the Holocaust, a magazine reported today.

title: Study Finds Better Primary Care Leads to More Hospitalizations
description: Researchers set out to show that giving sick people better access to family doctors keeps them out of the hospital. But to the surprise of everyone involved, the study found just the opposite.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Abbey National Expects French to Demand Funds
description: Abbey National P.L.C., a British mortgage and personal finance bank, said yesterday that it might have to pay L140 million ($214 million) to the French Government because of a contested leasing transaction three years ago. Abbey National, Britain's second-largest mortgage lender, said it expected a demand for the funds from the French Government.

title: About New York;A Graduate Who Masters Perseverance
description: WHEN Ricardo Ramirez receives his electrical engineering degree from Brooklyn's Polytechnic University today, one slogan will mean more to him than any platitude uttered this season: Surrealism is myself.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Southern Water of Britain Accepts Offer From 2d Bidder
description: Southern Water P.L.C. today accepted a $2.42 billion acquisition offer from Southern Electric P.L.C. that exceeded a bid made on Tuesday by Scottish Power P.L.C.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;'Avs' Have The Stuff Of Cup Finalists
description: A little more than a year ago the underachieving Nordiques were upset in the first round of the Stanley Cup playoffs and closed up shop in Quebec.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Airport and Town in Accord
description: Princeton Airport and Montgomery Township have resolved a bitter seven-year dispute that began when officials tried to restrict the private airport's operations.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;German Company's Loss May Total $420 Million
description: Total losses at Klockner-Humboldt-Deutz A.G., the German engineering company, could be as high as 650 million marks ($420 million) from years of hidden losses at a subsidiary that were disclosed this week, prosecutors said yesterday. Regine Appenrodt, the public prosecutor in Cologne, Germany, said KHD, as the company is known, had cited this figure in a criminal complaint it filed late on Tuesday against 15 people. Prosecutors are investigating the possibility of embezzlement and fraud. (Reuters)

title: Intel Plans PC Video-Phone Technology
description: After years of false starts by AT&T and others, the Intel Corporation hopes to bring video-phone technology to the masses.

title: COMPANY NEWS;GENERAL NUTRITION ISSUES A WARNING AND ITS STOCK FALLS
description: The stock of the General Nutrition Companies dropped 24 percent yesterday after the company, the nation's largest vitamin and sports nutrition store chain, warned late on Tuesday of disappointing second-quarter earnings. The stock fell $4.50, to $14, on the Nasdaq market, where it was the most active issue with 36.6 million shares traded. General Nutrition said it expected per-share earnings of 19 cents, below the 21 cents forecast by Wall Street analysts. The Pittsburgh-based company said its third- and fourth-quarter earnings were expected to improve, but still fall short of analysts' estimates.

title: Study Finds Way to Produce an Animal's Sperm Cells in Another Species,Years Later
description: A discovery being announced today could make possible some strange new modes of reproduction. It allows the cells that make sperm to be put on ice and grown up in another species many years later.

title: Economic Scene;An economist sees a brief but fierce '97 slump. Others don't.
description: BORED with namby-pamby economic forecasts that all come out the same? Take a look at the prognostications of Richard F. Hokenson, chief economist of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities.

title: TENNIS;French Tests: Sampras Passes, Agassi Fails
description: Baked to a fare-thee-well by the same hot sun, and prodded by the same burning ambition, Pete Sampras and Andre Agassi took separate yet equally grueling forays into five-set territory today at Roland Garros.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Tarry Beach Balls Removed
description: About 70 workers yesterday resumed the tedious work of removing pea-sized tar balls from beaches in Brigantine, Atlantic City, Ocean City and Long Beach Island, officials said. Strong easterly winds were blamed for washing residue from a May 9 oil tanker spill in Delaware Bay back onto the beaches, said Leslie Sweet, a spokeswoman for France Ship Management, the tanker's owner.

title: COMPANY NEWS;STERLING VISION AGREES TO BUY VISION CENTERS CHAIN
description: Sterling Vision Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Vision Centers of America Ltd., a 90-store eyewear chain, from a unit of the Norwest Corporation. Terms were not disclosed. Norwest Investment Services Inc. acquired the chain, based in Louisville, Ky., after it performed a private foreclosure. Vision Centers has stores in 20 states, with most in Kentucky, Iowa, Minnesota and Michigan. The deal will increase Sterling Vision's chain by more than a third, to 330 sites. The purchase will make Sterling, based in Lynbrook, L.I., the fifth largest eyewear chain in the nation, up from the eighth largest.

title: GOLF;Lopez Finally Feels Fit For a U.S. Open Title
description: She has a Hall of Fame career with 47 victories, she has financial security and she has family bliss, with a husband that manages in baseball's major leagues and three healthy and intelligent children. But when she reached her 39th birthday, last Jan. 6, Nancy Lopez concluded that she wasn't quite satisfied with everything about herself.

title: Dow Chemical Wins a Dismissal Of Silicone Breast Implant Suits
description: The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday that the New York State Appellate Division had upheld a ruling that the company was not liable in 1,400 lawsuits over silicone breast implants made by its Dow Corning Corporation joint venture with Corning Inc.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;A Literary Friendship From The New Yorker
description: THE HAPPINESS OF GETTING IT DOWN RIGHT Letters of Frank O'Connor and William Maxwell, 1945-1966 Edited by Michael Steinman Illustrated. 282 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $26.

title: Sports of The Times;Pitino Hears The Call of The Suburbs
description: ON game day, midmorning, Rick Pitino would turn his luxury car off Route 3, into a giant parking lot that was nearly empty. He would glance up at the gray November sky and then at the lettering on the front of an uninspiring building known as Continental Arena. He would walk into the stillness of the lobby and ride the escalator down. Then across the corridor, onto the court to say hello to Yinka Dare.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption in The Living Section yesterday with an article about the Center for Science in the Public Interest identified staff members out of order in some editions. The members were, from the left, Stephen Schmidt, Jayne Hurley, Caroline Smith-DeWaal, Dr. Michael Jacobson, Bruce Silver glade and Bonnie Liebman.

title: Liberties;Hot Springs Eternal

title: COMPANY NEWS;PARK-OHIO IS SELLING ITS BENNETT INDUSTRIES UNIT
description: Park-Ohio Industries of Cleveland said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Bennett Industries unit to Nampac, an American division of Southcorp Holdings Ltd. of Australia, for about $50 million. Bennett makes plastic containers used by paint, chemical and food companies. The company had revenue of more than $80 million last year, while Park-Ohio, a diversified maker of industrial products, had 1995 revenue of $371 million.

title: Structure Set By Chief Lets A Chip Maker Bear His Loss
description: Jerry R. Junkins, the chairman, president and chief executive of Texas Instruments Inc., died unexpectedly of a heart attack while on a business trip in Germany yesterday. Despite the sadness and shock about Mr. Junkins's death, analysts said, his passing would have little impact on the company's future.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Psychologists Sue Care Plan
description: One of the country's largest providers of mental health care has been accused of dropping psychologists from its managed care plan if they recommended more treatment sessions than the company wanted to provide.

title: 1,000 Homes Are Damaged By a Tornado
description: More than 1,000 homes were damaged or destroyed by a tornado that struck this Louisville suburb on Tuesday, splintering homes as residents cowered in basements, the authorities said.

title: In Defense of the Defense of Marriage Act
description: To the Editor:

title: Calendar: Reading, Talks, Exhibition and Auction
description: A Neighborhood's History Hamilton Grange, Convent Avenue at 141st Street; (212) 281-4442.

title: Christian Coalition Pushes for Showdown on Same-Sex Marriage
description: Trying to keep the issue of same-sex marriage alive in the Presidential campaign, Ralph Reed said today that the Christian Coalition would push Congress to send President Clinton legislation by Labor Day to deny Federal recognition of such unions.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's;A Problem Of Image: Too Easy
description: It is always hard to make room for Mendelssohn. What is there to say, after all? He does nearly everything so unsensationally well. He doesn't inflict his problems and neuroses on the listener. Except in the E minor Violin Concerto and a few scherzos, he does not pose the sort of interpretive challenges or gratifications that might make performers swarm over his works. In short, he makes everything sound easy, as for him it may well have been.

title: Sired by Champion Out of Time? Unlikely
description: To all those who think the winner of the Kentucky Derby in 2096 might be sired by a currently prized stallion like Mr. Prospector or Seattle Slew, The Jockey Club offers one word: Whoa.

title: Woman Killed as Store Facade Collapses on a Yonkers Street
description: A section of a building facade broke loose in a busy retail section of Yonkers yesterday afternoon, dropping concrete and mortar onto the sidewalk and crushing a woman to death under tons of rubble.

title: An Embarrassment of Mandela Films (Too Many)
description: There isn't usually a graveyard behind the Hohenhort Country House Hotel here in this wealthy Cape Town suburb, but Oliver Tambo, a founder of the African National Congress, had to be buried somewhere. At least for the few seconds that Sidney Poitier will stand by the black plastic headstone to tell it the good news: that he has been elected President of South Africa.

title: New Details Intensify Dispute Over Officer's Fatal Struggle
description: Each seeking to bolster their positions in a bitter, nearly weeklong dispute, the Bronx District Attorney and the Giuliani administration offered starkly different versions yesterday of a crucial moment in a struggle that led to the death of a police officer last week.

title: The Pop Life
description: Pulp Facts

title: Asian Aliens Now Smuggled From Mexico
description: In a case that American officials said highlights a new trend in trafficking illegal immigrants through Mexico, authorities have broken up an organization that smuggled hundreds of undocumented Asians into the United States along a pipeline through Russia, Cuba and Central America.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;C.F.L. Team Eyes Peter
description: CHRISTIAN PETER, whose trouble with the police matched his exploits as a star defensive tackle at Nebraska, is being considered by the Montreal Alouettes of the Canadian Football League. Peter, a 6-foot-3-inch, 304-pound tackle, was selected by the New England Patriots in the fifth round of the National Football League draft, but was released three days later because of his history of incidents involving alcohol and assaults on women. (AP)

title: COMPANY NEWS;TOSCO SETS STOCK RATIO FOR ACQUISITION OF CIRCLE K
description: The Tosco Corporation said yesterday that it had set a stock-exchange ratio for its acquisition of the Circle K Corporation, which values the stock at $31.48 a share. Tosco, a refiner and marketer of petroleum products that is based in Stamford, Conn., agreed in February to buy Circle K, a Phoenix-based operator of gas stations and convenience stores, for about $900 million, including cash and assumption of debt. Circle K shareholders will receive 0.6162 share of Tosco common stock for each share of Circle K. Separately, Circle K said its chairman, president and chief executive, John Antioco, planned to resign after the merger. Robert Lavinia, Tosco's executive vice president, will then assume responsibility for Circle K.

title: Conviction Quashed In Heidi Fleiss Case
description: A state appeals court has overturned the pandering conviction of Heidi Fleiss, ruling that jurors engaged in vote-swapping misconduct to avoid a deadlock.

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;Lemieux's Latest Hit Enrages Wings
description: Last season, with the Stanley Cup champion Devils, Claude Lemieux won the Conn Smythe trophy as most valuable player in the playoffs. This season, as he heads into the finals with the Colorado Avalanche, Lemieux may force the National Hockey League to create a new award: most despised player.

title: BASEBALL;William Paterson Wins Title
description: William Paterson College played on a magnetic field, not a diamond, this season. Home plate was the center of its universe. The Pioneers averaged 11 runs a game while compiling a 38-5-1 record. Yesterday, in the Division III World Series championship game against California Lutheran in Salem, Va., the plate seemed a world away.

title: THE ISRAELI VOTE: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK;An Election-Day Hustle To Get Out All the Votes
description: Out of a shabby storefront in Jaffa, a district of Tel Aviv dominated by Israeli Arabs, Ibrahim Sakrafi, his face stubbled from a sleepless night, directed a fleet of 50 taxis and private cars to ferry sick, old or simply indifferent voters to the polls.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Pitino Is a Day Closer To Making a Decision
description: Hold on to your shamrocks. After playing golf on the mist-covered courses of Ireland, Rick Pitino's mind is almost clear on whether he will accept an offer to be the coach, general manager and part owner of the New Jersey Nets.

title: THE ISRAELI VOTE: ORTHODOX VOTERS;Religious Parties Seem To Be Biggest Winners
description: Israel's religious parties, who according to late returns will control more seats than they have ever had in Parliament, were perhaps the biggest winners in parliamentary elections on Wednesday.

title: THE ISRAELI VOTE: THE OVERVIEW;Election for Prime Minister of Israel Is a Dead Heat
description: Israeli voters confirmed their country's yawning divisions in elections on Wednesday by splitting their ballots almost evenly between the candidates for Prime Minister and, in the separate balloting for Parliament, abandoning the two major parties in droves for small religious, ethnic and other groupings.

title: Many Israelis Protested Attacks on Lebanon
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;New Houston Team?
description: Houston could get a National Football League team to replace the lame-duck Oilers, but the city first must decide whether to build a new stadium or renovate the Astrodome, Commissioner PAUL TAGLIABUE said yesterday.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;New Concerns About Rates Hit Treasuries
description: Bond prices dropped sharply yesterday as the market began to absorb this week's fresh supply of Treasury securities, which comes as investors are concerned that the economy is still expanding at a pace that may prompt the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates later this year.

title: Jimmy Rowles, 77, Lyrical Jazz Accompanist
description: The pianist and composer Jimmy Rowles, one of jazz's most gifted accompanists, died on Tuesday at Thompson Memorial Hospital in Burbank, Calif. He was 77.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SCB COMPUTER ACKNOWLEDGES AN INVESTIGATION
description: The shares of SCB Computer Technology Inc. dropped nearly 33 percent yesterday after the company said its billings for a consulting contract with the Tennessee Valley Authority were under Federal investigation. SCB shares fell $9.25, to $19, in Nasdaq trading. SCB, which provides consulting on computer systems, said the United States Attorney's office and a Federal grand jury in Memphis were investigating the billing practices. SCB, based in Memphis, said an internal review found questionable billings by T. Scott Cobb, SCB's chairman and president, and Steve N. White, the chief operating officer. SCB said it did not expect the investigation to have a material adverse impact on management or its financial condition.

title: BLOOD BANK POLITICS -- A special report.;Elizabeth Dole and Red Cross: 2 Powers at Work
description: Elizabeth Dole delivered the ultimatum with her usual charm and discretion. As president of the American Red Cross, she was sorry to report to the Defense Secretary that financial problems might force the organization to stop relaying news of births and deaths between American troops and their families back home.

title: Verdicts Buoy G.O.P. Prospects in Arkansas
description: With its guilty verdicts on Tuesday, the jury in the Whitewater trial turned Arkansas politics topsy-turvy and raised the prospects for significant Republican gains in a state that has long been dominated by Democrats, most notably Bill Clinton.

title: Nonvoters Are No More Alienated Than Voters, a Survey Shows
description: A new poll casts doubt on the conventional wisdom that people who do not vote are more alienated about the state of American politics than those who do.

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;They're 'Bad,' and They're Back
description: One of the extras in Michael Jordan's hoop extravaganza emerged from a modest celebration in the visitors' locker room at Orlando Arena over the weekend. "Make way for a man going to the finals," said John Salley, winking. "Make way."

title: ON BASEBALL;Ripken, Still at Short, Sounds Off at Bat
description: Ken Griffey Jr. stood behind the batting cage on Tuesday evening, chipper and content as he accepted congratulations for winning player- of-the-week honors and dealt with the line of inquisitive reporters that never seems to end in his presence.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Intuit Takes a One-Time Charge, Causing a Third-Quarter Loss
description: Intuit Inc. reported a slight loss for its fiscal third quarter today, mainly because of a one-time charge.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;2 Big Accounts Being Consolidated
description: A large retailer and a large telecommunications company have placed consolidated accounts in review.

title: Report Is Skeptical of U.S.-Backed Home Mortgages
description: A report to Congress raised questions today about whether the Government should continue to provide financial benefits to two private companies established by the Government to make mortgages more readily available to low- and middle-income home buyers.

title: U.S. to Reopen Trade Talks With China on Piracy Issue
description: The Clinton Administration said today that it would send trade negotiators to Beijing next week after the Chinese Government offered to reopen talks on Chinese piracy of American movies, music and software.

description: To the Editor:

title: Reporters Ordered to Leave Freemen Area
description: The F.B.I. ordered reporters and photographers to leave their hillside vantage point overlooking the Freeman compound near here today, but said the order was not a prelude to a move against the extremist group.

title: Currents;A New Web Site For Coping Parents
description: PARENTS of children with disabilities now have a central clearing house on the Internet. Last month, the Waisman Center, a research center for mental retardation at the University of Wisconsin at Madison, introduced its Family Village Web site. Designed to put parents in touch with one another, it has resources for 400 conditions, from autism to spina bifida.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Japan Airlines Returns to Profitability
description: The Japan Airlines Company, the biggest Japanese air carrier, reported yesterday that it recorded its first annual profit in five years in the year that ended on March 31, earning 492 million yen ($4.6 million) because of increased international travel. The return to profitability followed a loss of 1.2 billion yen in the previous year. Sales were 1.12 trillion yen, up from 1.04 trillion yen. Sales from international passengers rose 12 percent. (AP)

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Australia Investigates Diplomatic Sex Scandal
description: Australia launched an official inquiry today into allegations that its diplomats were involved in child-sex rings in Asia, but the opposition said the closed-door investigation needed to be made public.

title: Real Nice Kid' in Coma After Suffering Beating
description: From the street where he grew up to the high school where he graduated in 1993, Shane Daniels was described today as a skinny young man with a sense of purpose, lots of friends, a strong work ethic and a smiling, unassuming demeanor.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BRUCE RATNER, a New York real estate developer, is anything but blase about the encounter he is to have tomorrow with the his boyhood idol, LARRY DOBY, the Cleveland Indians' center fielder in the late 1940's and the 1950's.

title: Whitewater's Future
description: A day after the Arkansas verdicts, there was disagreement in Washington over whether the Presidential race would be affected. Bob Dole declined substantive comment on the verdict. But there was no shortage of predictions that the issue would receive more scrutiny before the election. News Analysis, page D21.

description: In percent

title: Horseshoe Crabs Dwindle, And Birds Are Endangered;Winged Migrants Need the Crab Eggs for Food
description: As the tide goes out, the beach disappears beneath a blanket of birds, screaming and near starvation after flying nonstop for 4,000 miles from South America.

title: Dollar Pulled Down by Surge In Pound Against the Mark
description: The British pound surged against the German mark yesterday, pulling down the dollar as currency traders sold dollars for pounds.

title: COMPANY NEWS;WEIRTON STEEL MOVES TO TRIM JOBS AND RETIRE DEBT
description: The Weirton Steel Corporation will cut 200 management and supervisory jobs and pay up to $100 million to retire long-term debt under a restructuring plan announced yesterday. Richard K. Riederer, the president and chief executive, said additional job cuts had not been ruled out. He said Weirton would lose money this year but would emerge stronger after the restructuring. The company expects to incur a cash cost of $17 million in the second quarter related to the job cuts, and will take a $6 million after-tax charge for retiring the long-term debt. The debt restructuring calls for issuing $125 million in new bonds to pay off up to $100 million in securities maturing in 1998 and 1999.

title: Arms Case Taints a Diplomat's Future
description: After 14 years as a senior staff member on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Peter Galbraith had made all the right connections, so when he was nominated to be Ambassador to Croatia in 1993, he sailed through his hearings and was confirmed with nary a dissent. Even Senator Jesse Helms, the conservative Republican, had nice things to said about Mr. Galbraith, a liberal Democratic activist.

title: POLITICAL BRIEFS;THE CAMPAIGNS FOR THE SENATE
description: Virginia Fraternal Fight Gets Tougher

title: Donna Karan to Offer 10.75 Million Shares
description: The New York fashion designer Donna Karan International Inc. plans to offer 10.75 million common shares in an initial public offering, selling more than half the company to new investors.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Sandvik Shifts Holding In Finnish Concern
description: Sandvik A.B., a Swedish maker of industrial tools, said yesterday that it had swapped its stake in a unit of the Finnish engineering company Tampella Oy for a convertible loan that can increase Sandvik's stake in Tampella to more than 50 percent. On Tuesday, another Swedish maker of machinery, Svedala A.B., withdrew its takeover bid for Tampella, which specializes in drilling, mining and the handling of heavy goods.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;U.S. Legislator Reports North Korea Food Crisis
description: A United States Congressman just back from North Korea said today that the country is too preoccupied with coping with a food crisis that has affected millions of people to focus on other issues.

title: BASEBALL;Mets Failing to Provide Support for Isringhausen
description: Jason Isringhausen thought wearing high stockings might change his luck after four consecutive losses had transformed him from a rising star to a frustrated youngster.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Food Notes column of The Living Section yesterday about the introduction of an American edition of La Cucina Italiana, a food magazine, misstated the toll-free telephone number for Mediterranean Gourmet and Travel, which is providing information about it. The number is (888) 742-2373.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;25 Future Auto Mechanics
description: In a city where decent jobs for young people are at a premium, a nonprofit group and an automotive powerhouse have a solution. Yesterday, New Community Corporation got a $200,000 grant from the Ford Motor Company and the president of the Hillside Ford dealership to train 25 teen-agers to be auto mechanics.

title: House Proud
description: IN every cowboy movie I ever saw, the weary horseman checks into a small-town hotel and takes a wash at a little table with a bowl and a pitcher of water. He's nearly dead -- exhaustion, Indians, whatever -- and this little wash puts him back in business.

title: 2 Monitoring Groups Call Albania Vote Marred
description: Two major electoral monitoring organizations said today that the parliamentary vote in Albania, a former Communist country struggling to transform itself into a democracy, was marred by serious irregularities.

title: OLYMPICS: 50 Days to Atlanta 1996;Gold Is the Aim, but Bubka Is the Biggest Hurdle
description: Even as he claimed the pole-vault title at the national collegiate championships here tonight with a jump of 19 feet 1 inch, Lawrence Johnson of Tennessee had his sights set on something higher. There would be more important heights to negotiate this summer, more urgent marks to attempt to break, like the world record and a long malaise among American jumpers.

title: Worse Than Communists
description: I'm often asked: "Why aren't you afraid of Gennadi Zyuganov? You suffered under the Communists yourself. Have you forgotten that you were sentenced to a labor camp for your literary work?"

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;2 Children Shot at Play
description: A 9-year-old boy and a 7-year-old girl playing video games in a restaurant were injured yesterday when they were struck by bullets that went through the restaurant's door, the police said.

title: Democracy Denied in Albania
description: Albania, Europe's poorest country, suffered for decades under a fanatical strain of Communism. Now it seems to have graduated to a harsh form of post-Communist governance.

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;Sampras and Agassi Will Serve in Atlanta
description: Pete Sampras and Andre Agassi, perhaps the world's best men's hardcourt players, were among eight men and women named yesterday to the United States tennis team for the Atlanta Olympics. The women include Monica Seles, representing the United States in the Olympics for the first time since becoming a citizen in 1994; Chanda Rubin and Lindsay Davenport, all of whom are suffering from or just overcoming injuries.

title: Drug Companies Take Step Toward Settling Hemophiliacs' AIDS Lawsuits
description: Four drug companies that sold hemophiliacs blood-clotting products tainted with the virus that causes AIDS have modified the terms of their $640 million offer to settle litigation with the estimated 6,000 people who were infected with the virus as a result.

title: Jurors Say Clinton Testimony Was Credible, but Incidental
description: When they finally began their deliberations on May 16, after absorbing three months of tortuous testimony and hundreds of documents about an interlocking chain of complicated financial deals, some of the jurors in the criminal trial of the Whitewater partners James B. and Susan McDougal discussed the testimony of President Clinton for a few brief moments.

title: Club Owner Freed on Bail
description: Peter Gatien, owner of three of Manhattan's largest nightclubs, accused of turning them into virtual drug bazaars, was released on $1 million bail yesterday.

title: China Is Learning From Its Market Mistakes
description: SHENZHEN  Inventing China's Capital Markets

description: To The Home Section:

title: A Jailed Police Detective Is Called Far From Flashy
description: Fellow officers yesterday described Detective Constantine Chronis, who has been charged in the beating that left a Long Island man critically injured over the weekend, as a quiet family man who did his job without flash or fuss.

title: Philadelphia Journal;A Leading Chef Reclaims His Kitchen
description: Here, take this. Break it. If you don't break it, I will."

title: Connecticut Scrounging for Electric Power After Closings of 3 Nuclear Power Plants
description: Reeling from the closing of three nuclear power plants in Connecticut earlier this year, utility officials today detailed a series of unusual steps to avoid a power shortage that could lead to brownouts and blackouts across the state in July and August, when electricity use is at its highest.

title: Long-Delayed Monorail to Open at Newark Airport
description: Bedeviled by engineering problems, a 1.9-mile monorail at Newark International Airport is finally scheduled to open on Friday, after more than a year of delays.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Prolific Paulownia

title: Oh, to Be Smart, Democratic and Elite
description: To the Editor:

title: GOLF;Norman Is Refreshed, And Ready to Swing
description: Greg Norman is in motion. This is his favorite mode. Like his namesake, the shark, he can't stay still. He must move, constantly, or he will sink to the bottom.

title: CITY BALLET REVIEW;A 'Coppelia' That Takes Classicism As Its Ideal
description: Nikolaj Hubbe was, as expected, very much at home in his debut as Frantz in the New York City Ballet's staging of "Coppelia" on Tuesday night. The Royal Danish Ballet, the company in which Mr. Hubbe was trained, has long had its own production of "Coppelia," albeit very different in emphasis from the version produced for the City Ballet in 1974.

title: New Drug Approved As Backup Therapy For Ovarian Cancer
description: The Food and Drug Administration approved a new drug today that may help ovarian cancer patients who have not been helped by other treatments.

title: NBC Names Anchor For Cable Newscast
description: NBC News announced yesterday that Brian Williams, the network's chief White House correspondent, would be the anchor and managing editor of its 9 P.M. hourlong newscast on MSNBC, the cable news network that NBC News and the Microsoft Corporation are starting on July 15.

title: In Search of Sleep With Baby Bop And Stuffed Toys That Eat in Bed
description: GETTING children to go to sleep can be so difficult that you almost wish you could sprinkle a little fairy dust on their heads and simply turn out the light. Instead, there are hundreds of bedtime books, filled with entire worlds of dozing humans and animals and even cars, all promising children that they will not be missing out on anything once they fall asleep -- and parents that "The End" will mean the end to their day, too.

title: Despite Years of Broken Promises, Accord Vows to Close S.I. Landfill
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki announced an agreement yesterday to close the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island by 2001, promising instead to find ways to export New York City's garbage and to increase recycling.

title: Blantyre Journal;Malawi Deprived? Well, TV's on Way
description: The road leading to Laston Chiseko's electronics repair shop in Lilongwe is more pothole than tar. In the ramshackle market across the street, poverty has forced savvy merchants to sell cups of cooking oil in Baggies. Most customers can't afford a whole bottle. Most don't have shoes, either.

title: Mr. Dole's Health-Care Task
description: Bob Dole says he wants to pass health-care reform before he steps down as majority leader and leaves the Senate next month. The task will not be easy. Bills passed by the House and Senate would perform a valuable service by requiring insurers to offer coverage to workers who lose or quit their jobs, a requirement known as portability, though nothing in these modest bills guarantees that coverage would be affordable for individual workers. But Congress is hung up over three ideology-laden provisions added to one bill or the other. Mr. Dole has yet to resolve the wrangling.

title: In Defense of the Defense of Marriage Act
description: To the Editor:

title: G.M. Expected to Put Plant in Thailand, Not Philippines
description: The General Motors Corporation will announce on Thursday that it has chosen Thailand over the Philippines as the site for a huge new assembly plant to supply cars for Southeast Asia, people close to the company said today.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Stock Plan Approved For France Telecom
description: The French Government approved a draft bill yesterday to turn France Telecom, the state-owned telecommunications provider, into a corporation, paving the way for the sale of up to 49 percent of its stock. The Telecommunications Minister, Francois Fillon, said the sale of shares in the company would probably take place in the first half of 1997, though the state would keep control of France Telecom, whose value is estimated at 200 billion francs ($38.5 billion), for a long time.

title: GOLF;Woods Trailing In N.C.A.A.
description: Arizona State's Pat Perez tied the course record with a 68 today to lead Tiger Woods by one shot, and the Sun Devils shot two-under to take the first-day team lead in the National Collegiate Athletic Association golf championships at the Honors Course.

title: Bridge
description: The oldest regional event in the game, the Goldman Pairs, was captured Sunday night by Rick Zucker of North Tarrytown, N.Y., and Rose Johnson of White Plains. Playing at the Sheraton New York Hotel, Seventh Avenue and 52d Street, they won by one of the smallest margins in the 68-year history of the event.

title: Gay Parents
description: To The Home Section:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Promotional sweepstakes are winning the day, and the payouts are now bigger and  bigger.
description: MAKE way, Publishers Clearing House. The Shell Oil Company is now running its biggest promotion ever, with a million-dollar grand prize. And last week the Coca-Cola Company began its Red Hot Olympic Summer promotion, which it called the largest in the company's history, offering $81 million worth of prizes.

title: Ups, Downs, and Now Hope at a Shirtmaker
description: It has been a tumultuous few weeks for the 515 workers of America's oldest shirtmaker, Hathaway, at its plant in Waterville, Me.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday about kindergartners who were getting warning posters about rabies misstated the locations of the scene and of the children's school. The site was Muscoot Farm in Somers, N.Y.; the children were from Meadow Pond Elementary School in South Salem, N.Y., not Connecticut.

title: Mirage Resorts Says It Plans Three More Casinos in Atlantic City
description: With gambling revenues in Atlantic City reaching a record high last year, an executive with Mirage Resorts said yesterday that the company was working on deals to add three new casino resorts to the city, in addition to the 2,000-room resort the Mirage company already has approval to build there.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Don't call the DUCHESS OF YORK "Her Royal Highness" anymore. Today, the Family Division of the High Court in London is to make final her divorce from PRINCE ANDREW, and when it does, she will no longer have any claim to that designation. But she will get to keep the title of Duchess of York.

title: Currents;Glasses That Work Out With You
description: LAST week, Philippe Starck, famed for his designer furniture, designer interiors, even designer toothbrushes and toilet brushes, introduced his first product for the designer body. Voila: eyeglasses so flexible they can bend to fit the wearer's face. The eyeglass temples, or sidebars, move up, down and sideways, attached by a ball and socket rather than the traditional screw and hinge.

title: Shuttle Lands in Florida After 10-Day Mission
description: The space shuttle Endeavour glided to a landing here today after a 10-day mission in which its crew of six astronauts tested an inflatable antenna and a self-stabilizing satellite.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Seagram Profits Drop on Lower Results at MCA and Liquor Unit
description: The Seagram Company said today that its earnings dropped to $23 million in the first quarter from a year earlier, when it recorded a huge gain from the sale of stock in E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: COLLEGE SPORTS;N.C.A.A. Censured
description: United States District Judge KATHRYN VRATIL censured the National Collegiate Athletic Association and four of its lawyers yesterday and set fines that could total thousands of dollars a day if information requested in an antitrust case is not delivered.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: G.M. Chooses Thailand As Site for Big Asian Plant General Motors plans to announce today that it has chosen Thailand over the Philippines as the site for a huge new Southeast Asian assembly plant.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HEALTHPLAN SERVICES IN DEAL FOR HARRINGTON SERVICES
description: The Healthplan Services Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the Harrington Services Corporation, a closely held health benefits administrator, for about $67 million in cash and stock. The acquisition of Harrington, based in Columbus, Ohio, will give Healthplan Services a presence in the administration of managed care plans for large corporations. Harrington had 1995 revenues of $72 million. Healthplan Services, based in Tampa, Fla., expects to complete the transaction with $32.5 million in cash and 1.347 million shares.

title: Food Safety Data Need New Guardian
description: To the Editor:

title: Warning on Condoms
description: People in New York and six other states should not use certain brands of condoms from Malaysia because they might not adequately protect against disease and pregnancy, the Federal Government said today.

title: Leading a Divided Israel
description: While the outcome of a breathtakingly close Israeli election awaits the count of absentee ballots, one result is already clear. Israel lacks a national consensus about its approach to peace and its place in the Middle East. Managing the divergent claims and expectations of a divided electorate will require sensitive and skillful leadership in the weeks ahead that seeks to bridge differences and emphasize common interests.

title: About Real Estate;5 Years Later, Sales Start At an East Side Condo
description: A sales campaign begun two weeks ago at the Mondrian, a 179-apartment luxury condominium on the East Side of Manhattan, signals the return of the five-year-old project to the market.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;French Tourist Unit Reviewing Account
description: The French Government Tourist Office has begun a review of its account, which has been handled by Jerry & Ketchum in New York since 1989. Billings were estimated at $600,000. George L. Hern Jr., a spokesman for the office in New York, said Jerry & Ketchum had been invited to participate along with David Sirieix Partners in New York and four other shops he declined to identify. A decision is expected at the end of June, Mr. Hern said. Jerry & Ketchum is a joint venture of Jerry Della Femina and Ketchum Communications.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;76ers Considering Calipari
description: The Philadelphia 76ers have spoken with an attorney for Massachusetts Coach JOHN CALIPARI about their head coaching vacancy, according to a university spokesman yesterday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Something for the Hamptons denizen who has everything: an album with songs about such Hamptons topics as "the A list," love on the 4:04 parlor car and walking on the beach at sunrise.

title: Pataki's Big Picture
description: To the Editor:

title: FILM REVIEW;Loud Fan Becomes Loud Coach
description: Whoopi Goldberg may not sound right for the role of an N.B.A. coach, but it turns out that "Eddie" suits her just fine. Ms. Goldberg has everything it takes -- terrific lungs, endless wisecracks, that ear-to-ear grin -- to play the New York Knicks fan who is the star of this Cinderella story. Plucked from obscurity, she's given a chance to help her heroes out of a losing streak. Does anyone seriously wonder if Ms. Goldberg and her can-do coaching can do the trick?

title: CURRENCY MARKETS;Late Surge Helps the Dollar To Recoup Most of Its Losses
description: The dollar ended slightly lower against most leading currencies yesterday, recovering from early sharp losses as United States stock and bond markets staged a late rally.

title: District Attorneys Unite to Attack Giuliani's Comments in Bronx Case
description: District attorneys from around the state condemned Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday for continuing to challenge the Bronx District Attorney over his prosecution of a man charged in the death of a police officer last week.

title: ART REVIEW;The Freshness That Dwelt in Genoa
description: On a damp May day in 1527, the army of Charles V of Spain broke through the defenses of Rome and entered the city, pillaging as it went. But an event that proved calamitous for the Eternal City had an upside for smaller towns and courts throughout Italy as terrified Roman artists fled to them for safety.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the New York City trial of three men accused of trying to bomb jetliners in Asia misattributed a quotation that was part of the opening statements by the defense. It was Clover M. Barrett, the defense lawyer for Abdul Hakim Murad, not David S. Greenfield, a fellow defense lawyer, who said: "You are here to judge my client in his own right. It's one thing to prove a conspiracy. It's another thing to prove that a particular person was part of it."

title: U.S. and Japan Fail In Insurance Talks
description: The United States and Japan have failed to agree on opening Japan's $470 billion insurance market to greater foreign competition and no further negotiations are planned, a United States trade official said today.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Addiction 1995. Polygram. $96.99. 82 minutes. Closed captioned. No rating. Release date: Tuesday.

title: Move the City's Campaign Finance Bill
description: Limping into the final weeks of the legislative session, the New York State Legislature remains too preoccupied with fund-raising from favor-seekers to give any real consideration to curbing the influence that big money exerts on state politics. Even a modest measure to make contribution data accessible by computer may not survive last-minute partisan machinations in the Republican-controlled State Senate. This is bad enough. But Senate Republicans also persist in blocking New York City from making needed improvements in its own decent program of public campaign financing.

title: Hashish Smuggling Ring Broken With Florida Arrests, U.S. Says
description: Two principal leaders of a multimillion-dollar international drug smuggling ring, with three of their workers, were arrested yesterday in Jacksonville, Fla., officials said, after undercover Federal agents seized nearly 34,000 pounds of hashish. It was one of largest seizures of the drug in the United States in about a decade, officials said.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Mavericks Hire Bulls' Cleamons
description: Chicago Bulls Assistant Coach JIM CLEAMONS will be hired today as coach of the Dallas Mavericks, the team said yesterday.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Moliere's Charlatan As a TV Evangelist
description: CERTAIN ideas are so obvious that they really should be shot down as soon as they come to mind. Directors with a penchant for French classics are unlikely to leave the Circle in the Square's clunky production of "Tartuffe: Born Again," which turns Moliere's religious mountebank into a televangelist, murmuring, "Now why didn't I think of that?" The odds are they already had, and wisely resisted the temptation.

title: The Spoken Word
description: E. L. DOCTOROW, Sarah Lawrence College, Reisinger Auditorium, Performing Arts Center, Kimball Avenue, Bronxville, N.Y. He will read from his novel "Ragtime." Tonight at 8:30. Free. Information: (914) 395-2411.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DANAHER RAISING ITS BID FOR ACME-CLEVELAND
description: The Danaher Corporation said yesterday that it had proposed raising its takeover bid for the Acme-Cleveland Corporation to $29 a share, a total of $186 million, and the two companies were discussing a bid of $30 a share. Danaher said it had sent a letter to Acme-Cleveland offering $29 a share and added, "Both parties are now discussing a transaction at $30 a share," or around $192 million. Danaher started a $27-a-share tender offer for Acme-Cleveland in March. The offer has been extended several times and is to expire on June 5. Acme-Cleveland has said $27 a share is inadequate. Shares of Acme-Cleveland fell 62.5 cents yesterday, to $29.50, and Danaher was up 37.5 cents, to $41.50, a 52-week high, on the New York Stock Exchange. (Reuters)

title: Art in Review
description: 'Baby Pictures' Bravin Post Lee Gallery 80 Mercer Street, near Broome Street SoHo Through June 29

title: COMPANY NEWS;BORLAND STOCK TUMBLES ON LOSS WARNING
description: The stock of Borland International Inc. tumbled yesterday in heavy trading after the computer software maker said late on Wednesday that its operations expect to lose money in the current quarter unless sales pick-up. The stock fell $3.75, to $13.375, in Nasdaq trading of almost 4.1 million shares. Borland, which is based in Scotts Valley, Calif., said sales of its desktop software had been surprisingly sluggish. To bolster sales, Borland plans to offer a $100 rebate on its Delphi Desktop software in the United States until Sept. 30. Sales of the software have been lower than expected, Borland said. (Reuters)

title: Critic's Choice/Film;Carte Blanche Years
description: When Hollywood opened its floodgates at the start of the 1970's, it unleashed an astonishing wave of creativity and experimentation. Whether the films of that era conveyed profound thoughtfulness or just suggested that the inmates were running the asylum (both were often true), they had a blazing, headstrong individuality that Hollywood's blockbuster mentality would all but destroy.

title: Inside Art
description: Works Stolen by the Nazis

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;The Answer Is Andorra
description: When he was 4 years old, Seyi Fayanju's family bought an atlas. From that moment on, his mother said yesterday, he was captivated by geography. Seyi, now 12, returned home to Verona yesterday after winning the National Geography Bee in Washington on Wednesday by correctly identifying Andorra, a tiny country between France and Spain.

title: THE ISRAELI VOTE: THE ORTHODOX;Orthodox Welcome New Powers, And See Big Effects on Daily Life
description: Although it was not a Jewish holiday, the streets of this ardently Orthodox suburb of Tel Aviv had an uncommonly festive air today, with the talk at the bustling shops and restaurants all about the new power the Orthodox have snatched in Israel.

title: For Albanians, in Carts and BMW's, a Hard Road
description: For Besa Mani, a 17-year-old high school student who watches American soaps, drinks Fanta soda and yearns to be a judge, her country is a confusing place.

title: New U.S. Data Show Economy Grows Stronger
description: Evidence of an increasingly strong economy mounted today as the Government reported that sales of new homes surged in April, especially in the Northeast.

title: S.E.C. Orders Broker to Execute Promptly
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has instructed A. R. Baron & Company to execute customer orders properly and to hire a compliance officer amid an investigation of the brokerage firm's trading practices. The move is the S.E.C.'s first use of an administrative proceeding that carries the weight of a court order.

title: TV WEEKEND;Modest Series on Modest Radio Show
description: American Movie Classics is a cable service best known for presenting Hollywood's golden oldies the way "they were meant to be seen," as the sales pitch goes, unsullied by commercial breaks or garish coloring. But as the commercial networks watch warily, AMC has been edging into other entertainment areas, most notably co-productions or acquisitions offering profiles on stars like Marlene Dietrich and Marlon Brando.

title: Arkansan Quits Senate Race to Lead State
description: Lieut. Gov. Mike Huckabee announced tonight that he would abandon his campaign for the United States Senate, choosing instead to fill the unexpired term of Gov. Jim Guy Tucker, who plans to step down.

title: World News Briefs;2 More Fled North Korea, Authorities in South Say
description: A scientist and a writer from North Korea have defected and are seeking political asylum in South Korea, South Korean authorities said today.

title: BASEBALL;Slam! Bang! Boom! O'Neill Fights Slump
description: Sometimes, Paul O'Neill talks to himself, criticizes himself in front of 50,000 disbelieving fans. Sometimes, he waves his arms in disgust or shrugs his shoulders in disdain at what he has done. Sometimes, he flings his bat, spikes his helmet like a football or torpedoes a water cooler. Most of the time, he wishes he could call time out and request a do-over.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Heavy Metal 1981. Columbia Tri-Star. $23.95. Laser disk, $39.95. 90 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Tuesday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the influence of immigrants from Russia on the elections in Israel referred incorrectly in some editions to the university affiliation of Sam Lehman-Wilzig. He is a professor at Bar-Ilan University, not Hebrew University.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DURACELL TO BUY A SOUTH KOREAN BATTERY BRAND
description: Duracell International Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the assets and operations of Sunpower, a South Korean alkaline battery brand, for $115 million. Duracell plans to buy Sunpower's brand-related trademarks and sales and distribution operations from the STC Corporation, a maker of batteries, tape and film products. STC would retain its manufacturing operations and continue to make the batteries, but the batteries would be marketed by Duracell under a multiyear supply agreement. Duracell, which is based in Bethel, Conn., would continue to sell Duracell-brand batteries in Korea. (Dow Jones)

title: TENNIS;Edberg Wins Match and Earns Ovation in Paris
description: Stefan Edberg, loath to retire without a French Open title to balance out his Grand Slam collection, still has Paris.

title: SOCCER;MetroStars Keep It Close but Miss Chances
description: New coach, same old results. But at least new optimism.

title: THE ISRALI VOTE: THE PRIME MINISTER;A Man of Promise Dogged by Failure
description: By rights, Shimon Peres should rank as one of the greatest figures in Israeli history. He was at David Ben-Gurion's right hand at the founding of the Jewish state, he built up its awesome defenses, he held every major government post, and he started the peace effort with the Palestinians.

title: Beating Was Racial Clash, Witnesses Tell Police
description: As investigators continued the hunt for more suspects, witnesses' accounts provided new details yesterday of a violent, racially charged confrontation outside a Westhampton Beach, L.I., club in which a white New York City police officer is accused of beating a young black man into a coma.

title: Live With Kathie Lee And Apparel Workers
description: In the latest episode of the Kathie Lee Gifford/sweatshop series, Mrs. Gifford moved to cast herself as a vigilant advocate for the rights of sweatshop workers, while she faced new criticism from workers who made her clothing line.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Thailand Adds G.M. to Its List of Auto Makers
description: The General Motors Corporation, establishing a base from which to tap the booming Asian auto market, formally announced yesterday that it would build a $750 million assembly plant in Thailand, choosing that country over the Philippines.

title: Ex-President of Venezuela Sentenced to 28 Months in Graft Case
description: Carlos Andres Perez, the former President of Venezuela who was impeached as a symbol of political corruption in 1993, was sentenced today to 28 months in prison for misusing a $17 million secret security fund soon after he took office in 1989.

title: Metro Matters;Disappearing In Legal Maze Of Jail System
description: IN the early morning hours of April 18, four members of Act Up, the AIDS protest group, knowingly broke the law. Furious that a pharmacy in Chelsea was making what they considered an unacceptably large profit for a new AIDS drug, they papered the store's windows with huge signs that read "Profiteers" and "Price Gougers."

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Cal's Abdur-Rahim Spurns N.B.A. Draft
description: The University of California freshman forward Shareef Abdur-Rahim, saying he wants "to stay a kid," announced today that he has withdrawn his name from next month's National Basketball Association draft and will return to school.

title: Home Video
description: Varied Pictures of Africa

title: World News Briefs;Bodies of 7 Slain Monks Are Found in Algeria
description: French and Algerian authorities said today that the bodies of seven French monks killed by the rebel Armed Islamic Group had been found near the monastery south of Algiers where they had been kidnapped two months ago.

title: POLITICS: THE AD;New G.O.P. Drive, New Finance Debate
description: The Republican National Committee is preparing to make its first major advertising push of the general election campaign, spending about $3 million in the next week to promote Senator Bob Dole and attack President Clinton, according to Republicans with knowledge of the party's plans.

title: COMPANY NEWS;A TOP EXECUTIVE AT APPLE COMPUTER RESIGNS
description: Apple Computer Inc. said late yesterday that James Buckley, senior vice president and president of the company's Americas division, would resign. Apple's chief executive, Gilbert F. Amelio, said in a statement that Mr. Buckley, who had been at the company 11 years, had chosen to pursue other interests. The company, which has been struggling to recover from falling revenues and huge losses, also announced a management reorganization intended to enhance accountability and improve customer focus. Under the new organization, six senior executives will report to Mr. Amelio. They are the chief operating officer, chief administrative officer, chief technical officer, chief financial officer, senior vice president for corporate marketing, and vice president for strategic planning. (Reuters)

title: GOLF;Williams, Beating Odds, Ties for U.S. Open Lead
description: Two years ago, a stray bullet struck Kim Williams in the neck as she walked into a drug store during an L.P.G.A. tournament in Ohio. Last fall, still in pain from the injury, she decided to have surgery to remove the bullet and her game has been improving ever since. It reached a higher level in today's opening round of the 51st Women's United States Open at the Pine Needles Lodge and Golf Club.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Grumpier Old Men 1995. Warner. $103.91. Laser disk, $34.98. 101 minutes. Closed captioned. PG-13. Release date: Tuesday.

title: Take the New Comedy. Please.
description: IN the big comedy boom of the 1980's, it was nearly impossible to channel surf without running into at least one average-looking man in an open-collar shirt talking about his mother-in-law, masturbation or Roman Catholicism. Stand-up comedy has had a bad reputation ever since.

title: In America;Brutal Cops -- a Long View
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, the press trailing behind him, was in Sardi's at the odd hour of 10 in the morning.

title: FILM REVIEW;A Couple of Buddies (One Breathes Fire)
description: Actors know the perils of appearing opposite scene-stealers like dogs and children; now dragons designed by Industrial Light and Magic can be added to that list. In "Dragonheart," the story's central fire-breathing creature is so well realized (and his dialogue is delivered so merrily by Sean Connery, whom the dragon has been made to resemble) that the human cast faces an uphill battle. In a film geared to extra-patient 8-year-old viewers, it's hard to compete with a giant flying toy.

title: BASEBALL;A Turn For Better For Wilson And Mets
description: Paul Wilson sat at a table in the middle of the Mets' clubhouse amid the notebooks and cameras. That's nothing new for the rookie right-hander.

title: Low-Rated School District's Chief Is Dismissed
description: The trustees appointed by Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew to oversee Community School District 9 in the Bronx, the worst-performing district in the city, have decided to terminate the contract of the district's superintendent this summer, one year early, officials said yesterday.

title: White House Challenged on Data Security
description: The United States Government should immediately relax export controls on electronic data coding products and allow the computer, software and telecommunications industries to set data security standards, a new report urged yesterday.

title: Excerpts From Defendant's Statement to Jurors
description: Following are excerpts from the opening statements by Ramzi Ahmed Yousef, the accused mastermind of the World Trade Center bombing, who is acting as his own lawyer in his current trial on charges that he plotted to blow up jetliners in Asia:

title: GOLF;Muirfield Rules Day, But Lowery Leads Field
description: For the first time in a long time, the big, brawling golf course designed by Jack Nicklaus has scored a first-round knockout. And the punch seemed to come out of nowhere. On a sparkling, cloudless and cool day -- the sort that would seem perfect for scoring -- Muirfield Village gave most of the 110 players in the Memorial Tournament a memorable cuffing.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Clemson Pitcher Named Player of the Year
description: KRIS BENSON, who was 14-0 with a 1.40 earned run average for Clemson this season, was named Baseball America's college player of the year yesterday. The announcement in Omaha came on the eve of the College World Series, which begins today. The right-hander, who also had 178 strikeouts in 142 innings, has a chance, with a good showing at the series, to become the first player in National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I to lead the nation in victories, earned run average and strikeouts. (AP)

title: Israel's Losingest Hero
description: Shimon Peres should rank as a great figure in Israeli history. But, if the current vote unwinds as many expect today, in his fourth defeat for Prime Minister, he may be remembered as the man who could not win.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Takeover Battle Looms For British Utility
description: A takeover battle for control of one of Britain's Big 10 water companies heated up yesterday as Scottish Power declared that it still wanted to buy Southern Water even though its first bid, worth L1.56 billion ($2.36 billion), had been overtaken.

title: Old Friends, New Foes: President and a Preacher;One 60's Activist Runs Columbia; One Fights It
description: Summer of 1963. Jersey City. George was a college student animated by social reform. Bobby, the man he quickly came to admire, was the nervy and alluring rector of a black church. Both were tethered to a program for impoverished black youths in that tormented city. And they were self-appointed gadflies of a crooked Jersey City administration.

title: Restaurants
description: Small, brown, casual and clubby, Butterfield 81 has lights so dim that everybody looks young and service so solicitous that everybody feels important. The banquettes are an embrace of soft leather and velvet. The lights are a romantic, golden flicker. People whose pictures you have seen in the papers pour through the door.

title: Art in Review
description: Squeak Carnwath David Beitzel Gallery 102 Prince Street SoHo Through June 15

title: Monitors, Citing $1 Billion Gap, Take Mayor to Task Over Budget
description: Despite the sharp spending cuts that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proposed in his $32.7 billion budget, two of the city's fiscal monitors issued reports yesterday that criticized the Mayor for not doing enough to balance future budgets. They concluded that the city still faces a gap of more than $1 billion in next year's budget.

title: POLITICS: JUVENILE CURFEWS;Clinton Backs Plan to Deter Youthful Violence
description: Keeping up his tough-love oratory on crime and values, President Clinton today urged more cities and towns to consider imposing nightly curfews on teen-agers to deter juvenile violence and promote family stability.

title: Long Service to the City
description: To the Editor:

title: A.A.R.P.'s Activism
description: To the Editor:

title: NBA PLAYOFFS;Jazz and Malone Turn Up the Heat
description: The rims shrunk again on the Seattle SuperSonics.

title: TV SPORTS;Olympic Guessing Game: Is It Live?
description: When is live TV live and when is it on tape? In Atlanta, for the Summer Olympics, NBC is unlikely to tell you when you're glued to its 171.5 hours of coverage. Maybe you don't want to know what's live and what's Memorex.

title: NHL PLAYOFFS;Avalanche's Lemieux Could Get a Fine or a Suspension
description: Claude Lemieux's check that damaged Kris Draper's face is under review, the National Hockey League announced today. A review doesn't necessarily mean a suspension or a fine, but both are possible.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Repealing Clean Air Law
description: The Federal Clean Air Act of 1990 required companies with more than 100 employees to develop a plan to encourage car-pooling and other means of reducing car traffic. After the state passed similar legislation, some companies developed plans and others did not, and enforcement was sporadic, said Assemblyman Guy R. Gregg, Republican of Flanders. Last year, the Federal law was changed to make the trip reduction plans voluntary, and yesterday, the Senate passed a bill that would repeal the New Jersey law. Instead, companies would be offered tax credits as incentives for implementing a reduction plan. The Assembly is scheduled to vote on the measure next month.

title: Tokyo Journal;Japan vs. Korea, Again, and Both Cry 'Foul!'
description: Ask Chie Suzuki what she thinks of soccer, and the one thing she doesn't say is, "It's just a game."

title: Sports of The Times;Do You Hear Another Bid For Pitino?
description: WHEN Rick Pitino decided in 1989 to abandon the Knicks for the blue of Kentucky's bluegrass, his wife, Joanne, didn't want to leave her New York roots.

title: FILM REVIEW;Is It Getting Hot in Here, Or Is It an Alien Invasion?
description: Strip away the jargon and fancy technology in David Twohy's science-fiction thriller "The Arrival" and you have a gosh-oh-golly-gee 1950's-style adventure film about an excitable boy and his magic telescope. You also have a movie that shoehorns a blunt warning into its silly but entertaining story of a young radio astronomer's one-man battle against sinister extraterrestrials.
