description: NEW YORK

title: Bitter Debate, Then a Vote for Rejecting Same-Sex Marriages
description: After intense debate about politics, morals, race and federalism, a House subcommittee voted today to authorize states to refuse to accept same-sex marriages from other states and to bar Federal recognition of such marriages regarding taxes, pensions and benefits.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Another Shadow Over the Tonys

title: Why Give Wife-Beaters Guns?
description: One of the most valuable provisions of the anti-crime bill passed by Congress two years ago prohibited individuals who are subject to a domestic-violence restraining order from purchasing or possessing a firearm. Now Senator Frank Lautenberg would extend the ban on gun purchases and ownership to people convicted of a domestic-violence offense. Even a Congress packed with friends of the National Rifle Association should find this measure worthwhile.

description: To the Editor:

title: Diner's Journal
description: I just passed by one day and the place looked so attractive that I couldn't help coming in," a woman at the espresso bar was saying to her companion. "Since then I've eaten here every day. I just love the food."

title: Abroad at Home;In a Divided State
description: Few elections have meant so much. Israel's voters have called into question the vision of general peace in the Middle East, until now a central policy aim of governments in Jerusalem and Washington.

title: 2 Lost at Zoo Found Hours Later on Subway
description: Two mentally handicapped teen-age girls who became lost yesterday afternoon during a school field trip to the Bronx Zoo were found unharmed by an off-duty police officer on a subway car in Greenwich Village late last night.

title: Ex-Im Bank Refuses Loan Backing for Big China Dam
description: Citing environmental concerns, the Export-Import Bank refused today to help finance a huge dam in China that is intended to be the largest hydroelectric project in history.

title: POLITICS: THE TRAVEL OFFICE;White House Gives Committee More Papers in Dismissal Case
description: Hours before a scheduled vote to hold the White House in contempt of Congress, President Clinton's top lawyer today turned over 1,000 additional pages of documents sought by lawmakers investigating the dismissals at the White House travel office.

description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Ainge to Be Suns' Coach-in-Waiting
description: DANNY AINGE, who left the Phoenix Suns a year ago because they would not let him continue his playing career, was introduced yesterday as the team's "future" coach.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;ISS A/S Stock Falls On Accounting Problems
description: The shares of the Danish cleaning company International Service System A/S fell sharply yesterday after it announced it had found irregularities in its United States unit's accounting. The company said that the New York-based unit's finance chief had left the company and that accounting irregularities might cost the company $100 million.

title: Rating the Positive in Children's TV
description: Saying he was concerned that the television rating system currently being designed would provide "signs of danger but no identifying marks of distinction," the president of the Public Broadcasting Service yesterday proposed adding a "positive" rating icon for shows with educational value for children.

title: A Plea of Not Guilty Is Entered for du Pont
description: A judge entered a plea of not guilty today on behalf of John E. du Pont, who is charged with murder, after Mr. du Pont indicated that he did not understand the case against him and identified himself as the Dalai Lama.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about crabbers gathering horseshoe crabs in New Jersey misstated one man's given name. He is Josh Wheatley, not John.

title: THE ISRAELI VOTE: THE OVERVIEW;NETANYAHU, SET TO LEAD ISRAEL, TO SEEK 'PEACE WITH SECURITY'
description: Benjamin Netanyahu, the conservative opposition leader who campaigned on charges that Israel's Labor Government neglected the country's security in its search for peace with the Palestinians, stood on the brink of victory today, waiting only for the military vote to be counted before he could formally lay claim to the Prime Minister's job, now held by Shimon Peres.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;ING Profits Up On Barings Income
description: The Dutch banking and insurance company ING N.V. said yesterday that its net income rose 41.5 percent in the first quarter, helped by new commissions from its purchase of Barings, the failed British merchant bank. But the company warned that the strong increase would probably hold up through the rest of the year.

title: Prosecutors v. Mayor
description: District attorneys from around the state condemned Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani for continuing to challenge the Bronx District Attorney over his handling of the prosecution of a man charged in the death of a police officer last week.

title: Switching Hospital Contractors Is Inefficient
description: To the Editor:

title: CREW;Favored Northeastern Eight Withdraws Over Eligibility
description: Northeastern, the favorite among the 20 men's varsity eights, withdrew its crew today from the Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta, the sport's equivalent of a national championship.

title: Lash LaRue, 79, Western Star With a Whip
description: Lash LaRue, who expertly cracked a bullwhip in nearly two dozen low-budget westerns of the 1940's, died on May 21 at the Providence St. Joseph Medical Center in Burbank, Calif. He was 79.

title: DANCE REVIEW;A Fairy Tale's Strong Acting
description: Most productions of "Cinderella" falter under the weight of exposition and the need to fill the music at times in Prokofiev's insistently narrative score. Ben Stevenson's "Cinderella," presented by American Ballet Theater on Tuesday night and Wednesday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House, is no exception. But the two performances suggested what an important variable good ballet acting can be.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MRS. BAIRD'S BAKERIES IS FINED $10 MILLION
description: Mrs. Baird's Bakeries Inc. was fined $10 million yesterday and placed on probation for five years, three months after it was found guilty of price fixing, the Justice Department said. Mrs. Baird's Bakeries said that it was disappointed with the decision by Judge Jerry Buchmeyer of the District Court in Dallas "to levy such a heavy fine," and that it was considering an appeal. In February, a Federal jury in Texas convicted Mrs. Baird's, the nation's largest privately held bakery, of conspiring for at least 15 years to raise prices for bread to customers in east Texas. In March, the company filed for bankruptcy protection, saying pending legal claims in connection with the price-fixing allegations threatened its financial health. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bundesbank Leaves Two Rates Unchanged
description: The Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, left the key discount and Lombard rates unchanged yesterday at its regular meeting.

title: Stocks Higher in Japan
description: Stocks were trading higher here today. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 75.37 points, or 0.34 percent, at 21,961.72. On Thursday, the Nikkei fell 135.15 points.

title: After a Furor, Justice Thomas Is Invited Anew
description: School officials in this Washington suburb reversed themselves today and extended a new invitation to Justice Clarence Thomas of the Supreme Court to speak at a school awards ceremony.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Bonds Slip on Housing Data, Then Recover
description: After faltering in the wake of a strong housing report yesterday, Treasury bonds rallied from session lows to end mixed. Contributing to the rebound was the Government's sale of five-year notes, which was surprisingly robust despite recent comments by Fed officials that have suggested an upsurge in inflation.

title: CHRONICLE
description: NAOMI NEVO, 72, who lives in Herzliya, near Tel Aviv, likes to point out that her last name comes from the name of the mountain on which Moses stood when he looked out on the Promised Land.

description: A 52-year-old guidance counselor at a lower Manhattan elementary school was arrested yesterday on charges that he tried to rape a 10-year-old student three years ago, the police said.

description: William J. Bennett, two Democratic Senators and the head of the National Political Congress of Black Women are renewing pressure on Time Warner and four other companies for selling rap and rock music with lyrics they termed "degrading and indefensible."

title: KPMG Plans to Acquire India's Largest Accountant
description: As part of an effort to expand its global reach, KPMG has signed a letter of intent to acquire the largest accounting and consulting firm in India. The terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: GIULIANI PLEDGES THOROUGH INQUIRY IN RACIAL BEATING
description: A day after saying the arrest of a New York City detective in a racially charged assault outside a Long Island bar did not reflect badly on the police force, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani pledged a thorough investigation yesterday and spoke strongly about officers' responsibility to behave properly, even when off duty.

description: In percent

title: New York City Files Suit Over Court Rules for Jails
description: Contending that the courts are micromanaging New York City's jails, the Giuliani administration is seeking to strike down a 1978 agreement that forced the city to improve living conditions for prisoners.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Black Poet's First Novel Aims the Jokes Both Ways
description: The White Boy Shuffle By Paul Beatty 226 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $19.95

title: Jennings Lang, 81, Executive On High-Gross Disaster Films
description: Jennings Lang, a former vice president of Universal Studios and a Hollywood producer known for "Airport" and other disaster films, died on Wednesday at a nursing home in Palm Desert, Calif., one day after his 81st birthday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ENRON TO FILE A BID FOR CAJUN ELECTRIC POWER
description: The Enron Corporation said yesterday that it planned to file a $1.04 billion bid for the Cajun Electric Power Cooperative, a Louisiana electric utility currently in bankruptcy. Enron, in a plan supported by Cajun's unsecured creditors, will offer $525 million in cash and $513 million in future payments for Cajun. But Enron may have trouble competing with a $1.11 billion bid filed by the Zeigler Coal Holding Company and the Northern States Power Company, and a $1.2 billion bid filed by the Entergy Corporation and the Central and South West Corporation. Enron said its bid was superior because it would offer an 18 percent discount on electricity rates to Cajun's member cooperatives. Clark Colvin, a senior vice president with Cajun, said Enron's offer "isn't even in the same ball park" with the Ziegler offer. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Man Describes Killing Wife
description: Sobbing, a jeweler told a jury yesterday how he accidentally killed his wife, Brenda, as robbers invaded their Franklin Township store. "I've run it through my head a million times over and over and over," The Associated Press quoted Jeffrey Wolf as saying. "I have no idea how this could have happened." Attorneys for Harry Insabella, a Franklin Park dentist who is on trial for robbery and murder, contend that Mr. Wolf intentionally killed his wife. The jeweler initially told police that the fatal bullet was fired by one of the assailants.

title: Sony to Reduce Mini Disk Prices
description: The Sony Corporation, whose four-year-old recordable digital mini disk format has found few buyers in the United States, said yesterday that it would try to revive the technology by test-marketing it at lower prices.

title: Air Force Ousts 3 From Duties In Brown Case
description: The Air Force announced today that a general and two other senior commanders had been relieved of their duties in Germany as a result of an investigation into last month's crash of a jetliner in Croatia that killed Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown and 34 others.

title: U.S. Urging New Treatment To Stem Newborn Infections
description: In a move affecting all pregnant women, Federal health officials yesterday recommended new strategies to reduce the incidence of a serious and often fatal bacterial infection in newborns.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Olympic Sponsors Battling to Defend Turf
description: Here are some of the weapons against "ambush marketers" that Darby Coker and the other Olympic advertising cops say they hope they never have to use: "Deceptive Advertising is Not an Olympic Event," says the headline on one of their attack ads, which would include a reproduction of the corporate enemy's pitch and the name, address and phone number of the disgraced chairman.

title: S.E.C. Eases Rules on Executive Stock Sales
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission adopted rules today that make it easier for companies to exempt their executives from having to surrender short-term profits made on stock trades involving routine compensation and benefit programs.

title: On Wall St., a Trade Dispute;New York and Cincinnati Battle Over Stock Prices
description: It may look as ludicrous as a battle between a rhino and a rabbit, but the fight raging on Wall Street is deadly serious both for the combatants and for American investors.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: * Monterey Pasta Co., San Francisco, to Ingalls Moranville Advertising, San Francisco, to handle its account, previously handled by Hyett, Broadbant & Heimbrodt, San Francisco. The billings were estimated at $3 million to $5 million. * Big Book Inc., San Francisco, to I-Traffic Inc., New York, as the first Internet media agency of record for the on-line Yellow Pages directory. Billings were estimated at $1 million to $3 million. * Amazon.com Inc., Seattle, to CKS Partners, Portland, Ore., a unit of the CKS Group Inc., as the marketing agency of record for Amazon.com Books, a bookstore on the Internet. Billings were estimated at more than $1 million. * Microsoft Corp., Redmond, Wash., to Spring, O'Brien & Co., New York, to develop an advertising and marketing program for Microsoft's financial services group. Billings have not been determined. * Black & Decker, Shelton, Conn., to Nick and Paul, New York, to handle a creative assignment for the household products group that includes advertising, direct mail and packaging for new products. Billings have not been determined. * Summit Bancorp, Chatham, N.J., a newly formed subsidiary of UJB Financial Corp., Princeton, N.J., and Summit Bancorporation, Chatham, to the Lunar Group, Whippany, N.J. Billings were not disclosed. * Consumer Health Services, Boulder, Colo., to Media Direct Partners, New York, to handle the media buying part of the account of 1-800-DOCTORS, a telephone medical service, with billings estimated at $4 million to $6 million. Those duties had been handled by Creative Media, New York, which is being acquired by the Omnicom Group. * Castrol North America Automotive, Wayne, N.J., a unit of Burmah Castrol P.L.C., to Castor Advertising Corp., New York, as the first agency to handle advertising and promotions aimed at Spanish-speaking consumers. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Exchange in House On Marriage Bill
description: Following are excerpts from an exchange about same-sex marriage today between Representatives Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts, and Henry J. Hyde, Republican of Illinois, as transcribed by The New York Times.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;First Profit in 5 Years For Minolta Company
description: The Minolta Camera Company Ltd. said yesterday that cost-cutting and a rise in sales helped it earn an operating profit in the year that ended on March 31, its first such profit in five years. Minolta's operating profit of 3.96 billion yen ($36.75 million) compared with a loss of 736 million yen a year ago. Sales in the information-equipment division, which includes copiers, rose 2.9 percent on the year, to 126.27 billion yen. Sales of optical equipment, which includes cameras, rose 10.8 percent, to 67.49 billion yen.

title: Pataki Asks for Approval Of School Aid Till March
description: In the clearest sign yet that the fight over the state budget is far from over, Gov. George E. Pataki said today that he would ask the Legislature to provide aid to public schools through March 1997 -- a move that would relieve the single greatest pressure on him and the Legislature to reach a budget agreement soon.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Higher Consent Age Sought
description: A 21-year-old who has sexual intercourse with a 17-year-old could be charged with statutory rape under a bill introduced yesterday in both houses of the Legislature. The measure would raise the age of consent -- the age at which a person is deemed capable of consenting to have sex with someone at least four years older -- from 16 to 18. A study last year by the Alan Guttmacher Institute showed that half of babies born to mothers under 18 are fathered by men 20 and older.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: AUTO RACING;Lazier Doing the Rounds, but Carefully
description: Knowing when to slow down comes in handy for a racing driver, especially one recovering from a broken back. But when you are BUDDY LAZIER, the winner of last Sunday's Indianapolis 500, there is promotional hay to be made. So Lazier strapped on his back brace, picked up his high-tech walking stick and headed for New York for the usual post-race television appearances.

title: EUROPEAN TOPICS : Strasbourg Mayor Courts Muslims With a Mosque
description: In an oddity of history, the 2,000 priests, pastors and rabbis of Alsace, unlike their counterparts in the rest of France, are appointed and paid by the state. And Strasbourg, the region's largest city, has France's only two state-run theology schools.

title: On My Mind;Israelis Vote for Peace
description: On Election Day, Benjamin Netanyahu had the support of a substantial majority of Israeli Jews. They included some leftists, plus moderate conservatives, centrists and much of the Orthodox right. This majority voted for peace, not war, with the Palestinians and other Arab peoples. They thought Mr. Netanyahu would be more likely to give them the reality of peace, not a charade of peace, than Shimon Peres.

title: Regulators and Stratton Oakmont Near Deal
description: Regulators in as many as 20 states are close to reaching settlements with the embattled brokerage firm Stratton Oakmont Inc. that will put the firm on "conditional registration" for five years.

title: COMPANY NEWS;NINE WEST TO PAY $42.5 MILLION TO U.S. SHOE
description: Nine West Group Inc. plans to pay $42.5 million to the U.S. Shoe Corporation to resolve a dispute about Nine West's purchase of one of the shoe company's divisions. The dispute started in July, shortly after Luxottica Group of Italy bought U.S. Shoe for $1.3 billion, largely for its Lenscrafters eyeglasses chain. Nine West, which is based in Stamford, Conn., already had an agreement with U.S. Shoe to buy its footwear group for $600 million. After the purchase closed, Nine West said it was owed $105 million because of a balance sheet discrepancy. Luxottica, meanwhile, contended that Nine West owed it $10 million. Under the settlement, U.S. Shoe plans to pay $25 million to Nine West, while Nine West plans to buy back $67.5 million worth of the 3.7 million common stock warrants it had issued to U.S. Shoe. (Bloomberg Business News)

description: TRACK AND FIELD

title: Permitting Iran to Arm Bosnia Was Vital, U.S. Envoys Testify
description: Two United States Ambassadors testified today that the survival of Bosnia's Muslims depended on the Clinton Administration's decision to do nothing to discourage Iranian arms shipments to them in 1994.

title: Art in Review
description: Jose Bedia George Adams Gallery 50 West 57th Street Manhattan Through June 14

title: ART REVIEW;Old Chinese Rocks: Rorschach Blots In 3 Dimensions
description: With luck, every semester of the art season has a sleeper, some quietly excellent show just off the beaten path. This spring's contender is the wonderful, eccentric "Worlds Within Worlds: The Richard Rosenblum Collection of Chinese Scholars' Rocks." It features 80 examples of the beautifully textured, unusually shaped rocks collected as art by Chinese scholars as early as the Sung Dynasty (960-1279). Prized for their intimations of mountain landscapes, tigers or withered trees, such rocks were often distinguished by dramatic outcroppings and overhangs or deep furrows and were displayed on carved wood bases that were themselves minor works of art.

title: Roof Leaks and Winter Tied to Facade's Fall
description: A leaky roof and the brutal winter may have contributed to the collapse of a building facade that crushed an elderly woman to death on Wednesday, investigators said today.

title: Valujet Cockpit Tape Includes Noise Supporting Blast Theory
description: The cockpit voice recorder of the Valujet Airlines DC-9 that crashed in the Everglades on May 11 recorded "a brief unidentified sound" less than six minutes after takeoff, and almost immediately, the captain "stated the need to go back to Miami," National Transportation Safety Board investigators said this evening.

title: F.C.C. to Reauction Two Wireless Licenses
description: More than $800 million in next generation wireless phone licenses in 18 markets, including Denver and Seattle, will be reauctioned after two small companies that won them at a Federal auction failed to make required down payments. BDPCS Inc., a Questcom Inc. subsidiary, failed to make a required $37 million payment to the Federal Communications Commission last week to cover the 17 licenses it bid $873.8 million to win at the agency's auction that closed earlier this month.

title: ART REVIEW;Shapes That Just Happen to Be Objects
description: Like many realists, Avigdor Arikha likes to say that his works are really abstract (many abstract artists, naturally, claim the reverse). In Mr. Arikha's case, he has a point to the extent that his paintings depict shapes arranged often asymmetrically on a rectangular field, meaning the canvas or paper, and the shapes can seem only incidentally, secondarily, to be tomatoes, eggs, jugs or windows. Even when they do register first as those things, the effect is still a certain abstractness: a flat upward-tilting of the image so that its geometry is always paramount.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AHOLD N.V., Zaandam, the Netherlands, a supermarket company, announced that it has extended its $2.9 billion tender offer for the Stop & Shop Companies, which is based in Boston, for a third time, until June 14.

title: The Fortress Within
description: We Israelis woke up yesterday morning and saw the stuff of which our dreams are made -- for better and for worse. At the time of this writing, I still do not know the final election results, but I do know one thing: After three years in which Yitzhak Rabin and Shimon Peres tried to lead Israel into a different future, into an era of peace, it is clear that while our heads may have surged forward, our heels are still dug deep into the ground.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Food Notes column of The Living Section on Wednesday about the 1996 National Organic Directory, which lists farmers, wholesalers and related businesses, misstated the toll-free telephone number for its publisher, the Community Alliance of Family Farmers. The number is (800) 852-3832.

title: No Headline
description: You're not supposed to cover up history. The only way you're going to know history is to talk about it."

title: BACKSTAGE WITH: Julie Andrews;Life's Medicine Without the Sugar
description: JULIE ANDREWS says that giving up the Tony nomination for her performance in "Victor/Victoria" was easy. It's doing "Victor/Victoria" that's hard.

description: Sales of New Homes Surge

title: Assembly Votes to Force S.I. Dump to Close
description: The Assembly gave final legislative passage today to a bill that would require the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island to close by the end of 2001.

description: Two weeks after Jimmy Key's stiff left shoulder forced the Yankees to put him on the disabled list and stirred concern about his future, the pitcher and his manager, as expected, expressed optimism on the eve of his return.

description: Elective politics in Northern Ireland has always been strictly a man's game. But now an energetic new women's movement is running in an election here, saying it would bring nonpartisan, nonsectarian voices to the negotiating table.

title: THEATER REVIEW;From 3 Playwrights, 9 Characters in Search Of Fun in the Hamptons
description: If you can't get to the Hamptons this weekend, or if you wonder what their attraction is, you might want to stop by the Manhattan Theater Club where "By the Sea, by the Sea, by the Beautiful Sea," the collective title for a program of three one-act plays, opened last night at Stage 2.

title: The Verdict on Whitewater: It's in the Eye of the Beholder
description: Jason Burnette, 25, a local television producer who votes Republican, was at home channel surfing the other day when he hit a CNN news bulletin on the Whitewater verdict.

description: A Brooklyn man has been arrested on charges that he worked as a gynecologist in Washington Heights even though he did not have a medical license, the State Attorney General's office said yesterday.

title: Cardinal Duval, 92, Critic of French Army
description: Leon-Etienne Cardinal Duval, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Algiers who denounced the torture of Arab nationalists by the French Army in the 1954-1962 war of independence, died today in Algiers. He was 92 and had been retired since 1988.

description: Jerry Kearns Alternative Museum 594 Broadway, near Houston Street SoHo Through June 8

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Thieves Pose as Workers
description: The man posed as a United Water Company employee checking to see if the drinking water was safe. He distracted the elderly homeowner long enough for an accomplice to take $6,000 in cash from a tin box she kept in her bedroom.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: * Michael Breda, senior vice president and account services director at Ingalls Moranville Advertising, San Francisco, was promoted to the new position of president. * Linda Srere, executive vice president and new-business director of the New York office of Young & Rubicam Inc., was promoted to an added new post, group managing director. She will oversee new business worldwide; Waring & LaRosa, which Y.& R. recently acquired, and the Madison Group, the Y.& R. in-house design unit. * Larry Aarons was named to the new post of executive vice president and executive creative director of the Mingo Group, New York. He had been a partner and creative director at Taylor-Gordon, Aarons & Co., New York, now known as Taylor-Gordon & Co. * Rich Gagnon, senior vice president and media director at FCB/Leber Katz Partners, New York, a unit of True North Communications, was named the media director at its sibling agency FCB Direct, New York.

title: Terror Defendant Presents His Case
description: Ignoring a judge's advice that he not act as his own lawyer, the man accused of mounting an international campaign of terror that included the World Trade Center bombing began personally presenting his defense against charges that he plotted to blow up a dozen American jetliners.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Samsung Is Cutting Back Output of Computer Chips
description: The Samsung Electronics Company, the world's largest producer of computer memory chips, said today that it would shut its factories for two days a month for the rest of the year to cut production in the face of a sharp oversupply that has sent prices plunging.

title: Filing Sets Wired's Worth at $450 Million
description: The publisher of Wired magazine has filed for an initial stock sale that values the company at up to $450 million, a price more in line with the Internet companies it follows than with those in its own industry.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Building Blocks From Sludge
description: A House Appropriations subcommittee voted yesterday to approve $2 million in start-up funds for a project to test the feasibility of decontaminating materials dredged from Newark Bay. Under the project, to be managed by Brookhaven National Laboratory, toxic materials would be converted into concrete-like blocks that could be disposed of safely or used in construction work.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FLEETWOOD ENTERPRISES BEGINS DUTCH AUCTION
description: Fleetwood Enterprises Inc. said yesterday that it would begin a Dutch auction tender offer to buy up to 11.4 million of its 45.6 million outstanding shares, or about 25 percent of its common stock. The offer begins today and expires on June 27. Under the tender offer, Fleetwood plans to buy the shares for no less than $27 and no more than $31 each. In a Dutch auction, the company sets a price range and each shareholder specifies the minimum price within that range at which he is willing to sell the shares. After the offer expires, the company will determine a single price to be paid for each share bought. Fleetwood reserves the right to buy more than 11.4 million shares. Shares of Fleetwood gained $2.375 yesterday, to $30, on the New York Stock Exchange. (Reuters)

title: Market Place;The bets are on Yeltsin, but in any case, a Russian stock rally.
description: TWO weeks before Russia's second presidential election, market analysts are betting that the incumbent, Boris N. Yeltsin, will emerge as the winner and complete the nation's transition to market capitalism, sending stock values soaring.

title: 75 Years Later, Tulsa Confronts Its Race Riot
description: The Tulsa of 1921 was awash in oil money, so much so that even the poorer, predominantly black Greenwood section enjoyed a measure of prosperity that earned it a reputation as "the Negro Wall Street of America."

title: World News Briefs;Anti-India Protests Erupt During Kashmir Balloting
description: Anti-India protests erupted outside polling stations across Kashmir today as Indian troops clashed with demonstrators during the second part of balloting in the first election here in seven years.

title: HORSE RACING;Rested Cigar Out to Prove He Can Carry His Weight
description: He will be met by a state police escort when his van reaches the Massachusetts Turnpike this afternoon. He will be piped to an executive stall at Suffolk Downs, where he will wait in royal splendor until the race tomorrow. He will be asked to outrun five ordinary horses to win a purse of $150,000 plus a bonus of $250,000, which none of his rivals qualifies to win under the rules.

title: Anti-Abortion Governor Seeks Softer Plank
description: Wisconsin's Governor, Tommy G. Thompson, a Republican opposed to abortion, said today that his party ought to modify its stance on the issue to accommodate abortion rights supporters and head off a split at the national convention in August.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: AWARDS;Rizzotti Earns Scholar-Athlete Award
description: JENNIFER RIZZOTTI, the Connecticut basketball star, and center AARON GRAHAM of Nebraska's national champion football team were among 10 winners selected yesterday for the scholar-athlete award by the National Association of Collegiate Directors of Athletics. The winners will each receive a $5,000 grant to be used toward postgraduate studies. (AP)

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;2 Convicted in Bribery Case
description: Two former officials charged in a continuing Federal investigation into corruption in Newark were convicted yesterday of conspiring to award a $50,000 towing contract with the city of East Orange in exchange for a $10,700 campaign contribution. Ralph Harris, a former East Orange Councilman, sought the contribution for his 1993 mayoral campaign, prosecutors said. Ralph T. Grant Jr., a former Newark City Council president, was accused of conspiring with him to solicit the bribe. The towing company turned out to be headed by an undercover F.B.I. agent.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Marbury Signs Endorsement Deal
description: STEPHON MARBURY is already reaping the benefits of giving up three years of college eligibility, and the N.B.A. draft is still more than three weeks away. The former Brooklyn high school player left Georgia Tech after his freshman season to make himself available for the June 26 draft. Yesterday, at a news conference in Manhattan, he announced his first endorsement deal, to promote First Down jackets. (AP)

title: For Children
description: 'Summer Salute to Danny Kaye' Walter Reade Theater 165 West 65th Street Manhattan (212) 875-5600 Recommended ages: 6 and up Weekends through Aug. 18

title: THE ISRAELI VOTE: THE ARABS;Arabs Assess Peace: 'It's Not Impossible'
description: He wasn't their preferred choice to win the Israeli election, but now that Benjamin Netanyahu is likely to become Israel's next Prime Minister, Palestinians seemed resigned today to life with a tougher negotiating partner.

title: Mr. Silver's Clever Health Reform
description: Assembly Democrats in New York's State Legislature have outlined an inventive way for the state to deregulate hospital rates without harming hospitals that treat the poor and train medical residents. Speaker Sheldon Silver's proposal may not be the last word on state health reform -- it lacks details, omits some attractive features found in Gov. George Pataki's health-care reform and could be challenged in court. Yet the crux of his plan finds a way around a Federal law that has stymied previous deregulatory efforts.

title: POLITICS: DOMESTIC VIOLENCE;Dole Is Confronted on His View of Welfare
description: Bob Dole ventured into a black, drug-infested neighborhood here today and suggested that domestic violence had been produced by the welfare system, a notion that a local social worker immediately upbraided him for.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ST. JOE PAPER SELLS ITS PULP AND PAPER MILL
description: The St. Joe Paper Company said yesterday that it had closed the sale of its pulp and paper mill and container plants for $360 million -- $30 million less than the price that was originally agreed on. The Florida Coast Paper Company L.L.C., a venture between the Stone Container Corporation and the Four M Corporation, bought the assets of St. Joe Forest Products, which consist of a pulp and paper mill in Port St. Joe, Fla. St. Joe Paper, which is based in Jacksonville, Fla., also said it changed its name to the St. Joe Corporation. (Reuters)

title: THE ISRAELI VOTE: THE POLICY;CLINTON IS SHAKEN, BUT REAFFIRMS TIE
description: Shaken by what might well be the defeat of one of its closest allies, the Clinton Administration struggled today to put the best face on Israel's election results and to reach out to Benjamin Netanyahu, the challenger whom President Clinton had all but campaigned against.

title: Tamara Toumanova, 77, Ballerina, Dies
description: Tamara Toumanova, a child-prodigy ballerina of the 1930's who became familiar to American audiences as one of the most glamorous stars of 20th-century dance, died on Wednesday at the Santa Monica Hospital in Santa Monica, Calif. She was 77 and lived in Beverly Hills.

title: Terror Suspect Defends Himself and Offers Jury an Alibi
description: Spurning a judge's entreaties, the young man accused of mounting an international campaign of terror stood up yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan and began personally presenting his defense against charges that he plotted to blow up a dozen American jetliners early last year.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Leaving Las Vegas 1995. MGM/UA. $100.71. Laser disk, $34.98. 111 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Tuesday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Urged to Relax Curbs On Data-Coding Products The United States Government should immediately relax export controls on products for electronic data coding and allow the computer, software and telecommunications industries to set data-security standards, a report urged.

title: Comptroller Challenges No-Bid Deals With Agency
description: The New York City agency that broke city bidding rules to grant $43 million in welfare contracts to a nonprofit organization also violated a number of rules in preparing to award a $3.4 million contract to the United Way without competitive bidding, according to City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi.

title: COMPANY NEWS;THAILAND TO BUY MCDONNELL DOUGLAS PRODUCTS
description: Thailand plans to buy FA-18 Hornet fighter jets and Harpoon missiles valued at more than $390 million, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation said yesterday. As part of an agreement with the United States Navy, Thailand is buying four single-seat models and four two-seat models of the FA-18, which is manufactured by McDonnell Douglas, based in St. Louis. The aircraft are expected to be delivered to Thailand in 1999. (Dow Jones)

title: THE ISRAELI VOTE: THE REGION;Israeli Election's Apparent Outcome Leaves Arab Neighbors Bitter and Apprehensive
description: As the prospect grew that Benjamin Netanyahu would become Israel's next Prime Minister, the country that has become Israel's most ardent peace partner seethed with a sense of betrayal.

title: Basque Woman Held By the French Police In Attacks in Spain
description: The French police have arrested one of Spain's most wanted Basque separatist guerrilla suspects, French and Spanish Interior Ministry officials said today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Doner Spins Off Marketing Unit
description: W. B. Doner & Company in Baltimore and Southfield, Mich., said yesterday that it had spun off its direct marketing division into an independent operating unit called Doner Direct. The new unit, with 30 employees, has billings estimated at $48 million from clients like the American Association of Retired Persons and the Independent Insurance Agents of America. Tony Everett, 50, an executive vice president at Doner, was named to head Doner Direct as president. Kathy Schofield, 47, senior vice president and account direct at Doner, was named executive vice president and account services director, and Scott Rasmussen, 38, senior vice president and creative director at Doner, was named executive vice president and creative director.

title: New Data Point to the Ultimate Recovery of the Ozone Layer
description: The quantity of ozone-destroying chemicals in the atmosphere is declining for the first time, according to researchers, who say this means that ozone destruction should peak by the end of the decade, as scientists previously forecast.

title: Rwanda Genocide Trial Hears First 2 Suspects
description: The first two suspects to appear before a United Nations tribunal for the genocide in Rwanda pleaded not guilty today to charges that they organized Hutu extremists in massacres of some 500,000 people in 1994.

description: International A3-11
